name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council (17-18 March 2016) and on the outcome of the EU-Turkey Summit (2016/2502(RSP)). First of all, I would like to give the floor to the representative of the Presidency of the Council, the dear Minister and long-time colleague, Mrs Jeanine Hennis-Plasschaert. Welcome, Minister!

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I am pleased to address Parliament today on the next European Council meeting on 17 and 18 March. It will be dedicated to migration and economic issues and yes, of course, I will also refer to the outcome of Monday’s meeting of EU Heads of State or Government with Turkey. First, on migration: in our relentless efforts to stem the flows, Monday’s meeting was an important one. Progress has been made. We will continue to further a European solution to the crisis and this is – and will continue to be – crucial, as underlined by President Tusk in his latest address in this Chamber, since the only way forward is a comprehensive European plan.  First of all let me outline the outcome of discussions with the Turkish Prime Minister. Monday’s meeting was a timely opportunity to look at where we stand on the EU—Turkey agenda and assess the progress made so far. Our view was clear. Progress is being made in the implementation of the joint action plan but, if we are to put an end to the flow of migrants, both moves are needed: to close down people smuggling routes and to break the business model of the smugglers. In that context, the additional proposals put forward by Turkey are a welcome move.  We agreed to work on the basis of a number of principles: first, the return of all new irregular migrants crossing from Turkey into the Greek islands; second, the acceleration of the implementation of the visa liberalisation roadmap; third, the speeding up of the disbursement of the EUR 3 billion and additional funding for the refugee facility for Syrians; fourth, the preparation for the opening of new chapters in the accession negotiations; five, the possibility of establishing in Syria areas which will be safer; and finally, sixth, to resettle Syrian refugees on a one-for-one basis.  Clearly more work is needed with Turkey on the details of their proposals and President Tusk will ensure that this work is taken forward before the European Council meeting on 17 and 18 March. If Turkey delivers on a commitment to take back 100% of the migrants arriving on Greek shores we really have a chance to break the business model of the smugglers and to end the human tragedy that is taking place in the Aegean Sea. We would be able to replace the current pattern of uncontrolled irregular migration with a controlled mechanism of humanitarian resettlement.  I have to stress that it is still way too early to declare success. As always in these issues, everything will be depend on implementation, but if at the next European Council we can conclude the agreement with Turkey along these lines, it would signify a possible breakthrough.  Clearly this is just one element of our common strategy. Beyond plans with Turkey, our cooperation with third countries is key – and will continue to be key – to stem the flow of migrants attempting the perilous journey to Europe.  Obviously, strengthening the protection of our external borders remains a priority as well and work in the Council on the proposal for a European border and coastguard is progressing fast. I know that in this House you have started discussing the proposal in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) and we look forward to a fruitful cooperation with you to make sure that the new system is operational as soon as possible. As you are aware, the European Council has called for a political agreement between our two institutions by the end of June. Yesterday I had the opportunity to speak with your rapporteur, Mr Pabriks, and I sense a true willingness on both sides to reach this objective.  Let me now turn to the situation along the Western Balkan route. In February the European Council agreed to gradually get back to a situation where all members of the Schengen Area apply fully the Schengen border code. The flows along the Western Balkans route have now come to an end. The practice of wave-through is no longer applied. Yes, restoring Schengen is essential but it will be difficult. It has consequences on the ground which require rapid action.  First, if we are to avoid a humanitarian crisis, we need to make sure we rapidly provide assistance to those affected, especially in Greece. Following the call of the February European Council, last week the Commission put forward a proposal on emergency support within the EU and we welcome this initiative. Work on the proposal has already started and we are doing all we can to ensure its adoption before the March European Council.  As you know, this will also require Parliament and the Council to adopt an amending budget for 2016 in order to create the budget line needed and yes, we stand ready to work with you to ensure that Greece gets the financial support it deserves in a spirit of true European solidarity.  Secondly, we need to act in a coordinated way to restore the proper functioning of the Schengen Area. The Commission Communication ‘Back to Schengen’ that you discussed yesterday identifies the steps that need to be taken to achieve this objective. It is an important contribution to guide our actions in the months ahead.  Things are moving fast. I think it is clear to all of us that the situation requires us to act rapidly and to act jointly. The March European Council will have a comprehensive debate on all these aspects in order to set orientations for the months to come. In other words, all these developments are getting our full attention.  At the same time we cannot lose sight of other challenges the European Union is currently facing. The March European Council will therefore also address jobs, growth and competitiveness. As usual in spring, the European Council will discuss the economic situation and there are positive signals. Europe is experiencing a recovery. Unemployment, although still at a historically high level, has been falling. We are slowly emerging from the crisis but nothing can be taken for granted. In many ways the recovery is still fragile and we must not ease up but strengthen our efforts.  The Annual Growth Survey launched the 2016 European Semester and the implementation of the country—specific recommendations is at the heart of the European Semester. Therefore the Presidency has put particular emphasis on their implementation in several Council conclusions. The joint debate that we had at the mini-plenary in Brussels two weeks ago was a useful contribution.  The European Council will provide guidance on the economic and social priorities which should guide our efforts this year. When we talk about growth, jobs and innovation clearly the internal market is our most important asset to deliver lasting economic benefit. We are happy that currently much work is being done with regard to the single market strategy and that concrete proposals under the digital single market strategy are now being discussed. Clearly at this very moment a large part of its potential remains untapped.  In this light our Presidency is pleased that the European Council will mark the importance of the internal market with a view to further boosting delivery of its agenda and full implementation and enforcement of the existing acquis. We hope that the June European Council will provide an opportunity to discuss this issue.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, today I am speaking on behalf of President Juncker, so allow me to underline a message that he has conveyed many times to this House: ours is a political Commission that delivers a political response to the major challenges of our time. Nowhere is this more true than in our vision for the European economy. Just as the euro represents a political project that requires political governance and democratic accountability, so our economic strategy demands a political debate at all levels, European and national. In the end, we will be measured by our ability to improve the prospects of our people, today and tomorrow. This is why the European Semester is not a technocratic exercise but a political process, shaped by dialogue and debate. This is why this Parliament and our national parliaments play a central role. Not only do you strengthen our legitimacy; you also hold the policymakers to account. This year’s European Semester takes place in a complex global environment. As our Winter Economic Forecast observes: ‘While growth is continuing at a moderate rate in Europe, significant parts of the world economy are grappling with major challenges.’ These challenges include a slowing down of the emerging economies, including China, geopolitical tensions in our neighbourhood and volatility in global markets. 2016 will be the fourth year of recovery for the European Union as a whole, and we expect a growth of 1.9%. Confidence is returning, and the euro area is no longer a bad pupil in the class. Employment has risen to its highest level since 2008. Yet these signs of progress are not enough. Twenty-two million Europeans are still without work, and 4.5 million of these are below the age of 25. When this Commission took office, we put in place a clear strategy to deliver growth and jobs – a virtuous triangle of investment, structural reforms and responsible fiscal policy. This strategy drives everything we do, and it has social fairness at its core. When it comes to responsible public finances, average budget deficits in both the euro area and the EU as a whole are clearly going down. In the euro area we expect a budget deficit going down from an average 2.2% of GDP last year to 1.9% this year.  Cleaning up our public finances and reducing national debt are essential. Not only for ourselves – as the markets remind us – but also for future generations. Today, for the first time in years, our levels of debt have begun to fall. Let us continue the good work. Structural reforms are in the hands of our Member States. Our latest country reports send a clear message: those with the courage to reform make progress. They show that we now have a window of opportunity to modernise our economies. When this Commission took office, our first major initiative was to respond urgently to one of the greatest weaknesses of the European economy: a lack of investment. With the help of this Parliament we launched a major offensive to boost investment across the European Union. Today we see the first results and they speak for themselves. In its first six months, the European Fund for Strategic Investment has already mobilised more than EUR 60 billion of investment in 22 of our Member States. Around 80% of this new finance takes the form of new private capital – exactly what we wanted to achieve. In short, we are making progress, but this is precisely the moment to redouble our efforts and continue what we have started. Now is the time, as the recovery takes hold, for Member States to act. This brings me to the European Semester – and a political process that this Parliament is shaping. The Semester helps us to identify new risks, increase stability and encourage the reforms that deliver growth. By focusing on its most urgent priorities, each Member State strengthens the European Union as a whole.  Last month we published our latest country reports. These reports are vital to the quality of our policymaking. Each one analyses the economic and social developments in our Member States. Each one ensures that the national programmes are properly debated and prepared. This year’s reports paint a varied picture. Overall, our Member States are tackling their imbalances. They are making progress with the country-specific recommendations we issued last year, although that progress varies from country to country. As a whole, these efforts will strengthen the European recovery and help our economies to converge. Yesterday, we discussed the winter package of the European Semester and we finalised the decisions under the Macroeconomic Imbalances Procedure. The main conclusion is that there are now fewer Member States with macroeconomic imbalances than last year. This is encouraging, because it means that we are making progress in reforming our economies, and that the conditions for renewed convergence are gradually being restored. Of the 18 countries examined in depth, six were found to have no imbalances, seven show signs of imbalances, and five are experiencing excessive imbalances. The situation differs across countries but, in general, the main reasons for concern are the persistence of very high levels of indebtedness – be it public, private or external – vulnerabilities in the financial sector or deteriorating competitiveness. A clear reversal of these trends requires a decisive policy response.  High debt levels are a drag on growth and make the economies vulnerable to shocks. They need to be brought down. This is also crucial to keep up structural reform efforts to address long-standing weaknesses. It is not always easy, as reforms have political costs. But this is the only way to unlock the growth potential of our economies, make them more competitive, create more jobs and reverse the deterioration in social conditions. But overall, the system of closer monitoring and stronger coordination is bearing fruit, which should convince us to go further in our efforts. We will now take this assessment into discussions with Member States this month and next.  The Semester is still in its early years, but we have already made changes that make it more effective, more transparent and more accountable. There are changes big and small that will make a difference, from a new focus on employment and social performance to a streamlining of the process as a whole. But more than anything we have created time and space for dialogue, and focused on the urgent priorities that will deliver growth. By publishing our country reports earlier, we now have a more open and substantial discussion. Our country-specific recommendations are more targeted. We focus on a limited number of priorities that require the government’s attention in the coming 12 to 18 months. And we published the recommendation for the euro area at the start of the Semester. This keeps our eye on the bigger picture, and helps us to develop a common understanding of the challenges we face together and the policies that will serve us all.  The European Semester is the lifeblood of our economic governance. Its credibility depends not only on the quality of our analysis and judgment, but also on the transparency and accountability of the process. That is why we improve the Semester at every opportunity. We have made changes that ensure a truly political debate at all levels. We have built bridges between all the actors, starting with this Parliament. This is how we build ownership and partnership. This is how we strengthen the legitimacy of economic governance. But above all, this is how we ensure that our economic strategy delivers the growth and jobs that our people want. Let me conclude with a few words about the meeting of EU Heads of State and Government with Turkey, which took place on Monday this week. As you have seen, both sides agreed a number of steps that will significantly limit the flow of irregular migrants to the EU. An agreement in principle was found with Prime Minister Davutoğlu that Turkey will readmit quickly all irregular migrants who do not qualify for international protection, and who arrive in Greece. Turkey will thus anticipate the entry into force of the EU-Turkey readmission agreement. It was also agreed that Turkey will readmit Syrian nationals returned from the Greek islands under the logic that they can apply for asylum in Turkey and on the understanding that for every Syrian readmitted, one will be resettled to the EU directly from Turkey. As President Juncker has said, this is a ‘game-changer’. The new plan will help us to break the business model of smugglers who exploit human misery. There will no longer be an incentive for Syrians to pay criminals to smuggle them across the Aegean. It will make clear that the only viable way to come to Europe is through legal channels. Meanwhile, to ensure that Syrian refugees can benefit from decent conditions in Turkey, the newly created Facility for Refugees in Turkey is already starting to finance the first projects. The initial EUR 3 billion put into the Fund could also need to be supplemented after 2018. Regarding the proposal to liberalise the EU’s visa regime with Turkey, let me underline what President Juncker has said. The Commission will ensure that Turkey fully respects its commitments and upholds the standards we have agreed. The same principle applies to the opening of new chapters in Turkey’s accession negotiations. Details of Monday’s deal will need to be worked out in time for the next European Council on 17-18 March. European Union leaders also welcomed the Commission’s new roadmap which will restore Schengen to its proper functioning by the end of this year. This means strengthening our external borders, putting an end to the so-called ‘wave-through’ approach, and coordinating all temporary border controls at European level. As EU leaders recognised on Monday, this roadmap requires more support for our frontline Member States, starting with Greece. Last week, the Commission adopted proposals for a new Emergency Assistance instrument, whose first priority will be to relieve the situation in Greece. EU leaders called on the Council to adopt the new scheme before next week’s March European Council. Parliament, as an arm of the budgetary authority, will play a central role in filling this proposal with life. That is why the Commission will urgently propose an amending budget for 2016 to create the budget line for the instrument. The estimated needs for 2016 are EUR 300 million with a further EUR 200 million each year for use in 2017 and 2018, respectively. Funding would therefore not be diverted from existing external humanitarian aid programmes outside the EU. The Commission is working in order to ensure a strong and coordinated European response and we count on this Parliament to help us in making it so.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work and for the work she has It is good that we have a minister here with us. I would be interested to know what it is like when you sit in front – you get coffee served, and you can talk as long as you want. I think that's a good place up there that you have. But we can talk about this afterwards and compare our places. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, which First of all, on the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to say that it is good that we had the summit last Monday and that, for the first time, a concrete and comprehensive solution is in sight, that we are talking to each other, that Europe, together with Turkey, is on the way to finding a common solution, because only that is a sustainable solution. Putting the smugglers through, stopping the wave- and stopping illegal migration from Turkey to Greece – all these are the right answers. I would also like to make it very clear that it is important that we now support Greece. We cannot accept the pictures that have come from Idomeni in the last few days. We must try to help the people on the ground. That is the first point: positive that we had the summit, and positive that a result has been come out. I would like to make it clear that when we talk about Turkey, we want to express respect first. Turkey has taken in 2.5 million people in recent years, providing nine billion of its own money to help Syrian refugees on its own territory. And we Europeans must admit that we have looked away for too long, that we have not been too busy with this development and that we must now become all the more active. These are the two points to be addressed. Nevertheless, we must make one thing clear: the partnership with Turkey is about partnership; it is not a question of dependence on Turkey. When we talk about Turkey, it is not acceptable that in future Turkey should continue to put pressure on Europe on the question of how many refugees it is letting into Europe or not letting them in. It is not acceptable for Morocco to say in the future: well, if we open our borders to Spain in the future, then perhaps we can negotiate the same conditions as Turkey for us. It is about partnership, not dependency. That is why it must be clear to us that Europe must first of all be able to secure its own borders, and that also means applying technical measures, including building border fences when it is necessary to secure Europe's borders accordingly. The second thing that is clear is that when we talk about Europe's self-confidence, we then look very critically at it when it comes to visa exemption. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats is ready to talk constructively about the visa issues. But I do not want to hide the fact that there are many concerns about this visa liberalisation. Turkey must first comply with all standards. In particular, when I imagine that a data protection law has only recently been agreed in Turkey, which in turn has not made it possible to have an independent data protection authority, it shows that the ball is not with us, but the ball is mainly in Ankara if we want to meet the deadlines. I would like to make it clear that, from our point of view, there is no blank cheque, and I would like to make it clear that the European Council should also be somewhat reluctant to legislate for detail. The question of how we are doing visa liberalisation is the responsibility of the interior ministers and the European Parliament, not the European Council. Fourthly, when we talk about partnership and not about dependency, it must also be clear that the financial resources we are now providing are actually where we want it to be. I strongly support Johannes Hahn in considering that we are really investing the money on the ground in the camps on a project-by-project basis and not transferring it directly to the Turkish Government. Partnership, but not dependence on Turkey – that is the message that is important to us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. I would like to say one final thought: we must separate matters. The migration issue is a common task that we want to solve. But the enlargement of the European Union, Turkey's full membership, is a completely different issue. These are two separate issues. My group is very sceptical about membership, so there is no doubt about it. We believe that Turkey's full membership is not positive for both sides. Nevertheless, we must make it clear to Turkey that if it wants a partnership with us, it must not move further away from Europe. The Attacks on the media in recent days are unacceptable! Zaman, the newspaper under surveillance and supervision by the Turkish authorities, belonged to the opposition and, on the first day after being placed under state supervision by the state, published a front page with a large photo of Erdogan on it. In other words, the turnaround in putting these media under government supervision is obvious. And that is why you are appealing and asking the President of Turkey to show the partnership with Europe. Therefore, please stop attacking the media, stop building an autocratic state in Turkey! Please do not lead Turkey further away from Europe! Finally, a brief reference to the actual subject to be discussed next week, namely the question of semesters and the euro, which Valdis Dombrovskis raised. This should actually be the focus of the European Council's planning. We believe that Europe is on the right track because we have pushed through reforms. In the EPP-governed countries in particular, we are doing well, with falling unemployment rates, less new debt and growth. We ask the European Council not to leave this course during the discussions. In all the countries where we are on the right track, this course has been taken. Let us continue along this common path: self-confidence and not dependence!

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome Mr Jeanine. I would have liked to comment on the agreement, but the agreement is not yet there. And this is the sign, let me tell you, of a Europe of governments that can no longer decide. In order to save Europe and, above all, the thousands of Syrians fleeing war, the agreement with Turkey is a necessary step, provided that all ambiguity is avoided.  Those people – I am thinking in particular of girls and boys – are men and women, not numbers, not commodities. I say this clearly: this agreement cannot be bartering or haggling on the skin of refugees, on human rights, on freedom of the press and freedom of expression; we are not negotiating and the closure of the Zaman newspaper, the treatment of the European Parliament's rapporteur, Kati Piri, are all facts that President Schulz was right to condemn at the summit. The attitude towards the Kurdish minority is a negative sign of the negotiations.  We must also keep the plans separate and not confuse the dialogue on the refugee crisis and Turkey's accession negotiations, as well as visa liberalisation, and turkey must first do the things it needs to do in order to allow the European Commission to make a proposal that Parliament will examine and then decide on. It is right that the Eu ropean Union should make financial efforts to support Syrian refugees by funding NGOs for project management and not the Syrian authorities. But this is not a blank cheque: we need sincere cooperation which, with full respect for human rights and international law, in particular the Geneva Convention, will allow a dignified solution for migrants and refugees.  And I cannot forget Greece, which is in danger of becoming a cage for refugees, a gateway with no exit doors. The Greek people and authorities must be supported by concrete actions, by humanitarian aid, as the European Commission is doing, and by the relocation of tens of thousands of refugees to the other Member States, as has already been decided. When the first relocation of refugees from Greece begins, all clandestine routes, not only those in Macedonia but also those passing through Albania and Bulgaria, will have to be closed.  And then there is the root of the problem: Syria, which is now europe's periphery. What is happening there has a huge impact in our countries. It is therefore good to cease fire in Syria. Work is now being done on a political agreement with a leading Europe with Federica Mogherini.  The refugee challenge is first and foremost a European challenge. However, we must look to the Mediterranean and Africa if we are not to live in an eternal and painful emergency. Whether it is Turkey, Russia or any other country, we are against the relocation of European problems to other countries. It is not the others who have to solve our problems. It is time for the Member States to assume their responsibilities through binding decisions.  We do not expect others to do what we have to do. The decline of European civilisation will only be halted by regaining our moral strength, the dignity that has made us appreciate and esteem throughout the world.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, last week Donald Tusk gave a very clear message to potential irregular migrants when he said: ‘do not come to Europe, do not believe smugglers’. Finally, a European leader was trying to break the link between getting on a boat and bypassing legal migration channels, because stemming the flow of irregular migrants will allow our countries to focus on helping the refugees who need and deserve our help directly from the conflict zones. But let us be clear: our enemies are not the refugees who are fleeing from war, conflict and persecution. Our enemies are not the irregular migrants who come from safer countries and who may use the conflict to understandably seek a better life in our countries. Our enemies are the people traffickers who prey on innocent and desperate people, who care little for the lives of their human cargo and who deserve to be taken out of action. So, on Monday, EU leaders agreed the outline of an agreement with the Turkish Government and I hoped, like Gianni, to be standing here today welcoming a deal, but instead I have to admit I have a number of reservations and questions. Firstly the process: yet again we see one or two leaders going off to negotiate with Turkey on behalf of the EU without really consulting the other countries. Secondly, I struggle to see how much of this is either legal or practical. Even in desperate times, should we just tear up our own rules and international conventions? Thirdly, I am very concerned that we are replacing one series of pressures from economic migration with another by granting Turkey visa liberalisation in a matter of weeks, without thinking through the implications. Fourthly, how will the EUR 6 billion be delivered? Will it be tied to clear targets that must be met? Or otherwise would we not be better off and safer spending that vast sum of money here on reception, processing and returns? Turkey itself is testing the EU. Those of us who believe in freedom of the press should be concerned about the actions of the Turkish government against the Zaman newspaper. But if we are to work with Turkey on migration as friends then, as friends, we should also be honest with them about whether EU membership is realistic, and with our concerns over freedoms in their country. Whatever our views, we must all realise that we will not begin to control this crisis until we all realise there is no one silver bullet to solve this crisis. We made that mistake last year with the relocation scheme. Let us not make that same mistake again. While we may not be able to stop the flows altogether, we can show that our borders are not a free-for-all. In the short term, we can work on finalising readmission agreements and speeding up returns; we can fingerprint upon arrival and find resources to speed up the processing of applications; we can put NATO ships in the Aegean to target the traffickers. In the long run, we can talk about reform of Dublin, but should we really be reinventing Dublin in the midst of a crisis? Or should we find a way of making a system we have work effectively and helping those facing the greatest pressures? Dublin has failed because countries stopped implementing it. Yes, Greece does have a significant humanitarian crisis, but EU politicians would be making a huge mistake to try to launch a hostile takeover of Greece under Article 78 of the Treaty, as I see some politicians are proposing. Guy, I see you looking at me. I imagine you are going to attack me again this week. The number of times you mention Mr Kamall in your speeches really is flattering. I just hope for your partner’s sake you do not mention my name in your sleep. But on an issue as important as this, I ask you and others here today not to seek to score cheap political points but to agree how all of us can work together to find effective answers – not undeliverable silver bullets, not initiatives designed purely to grab the headlines, but practical solutions to save lives and help refugees. Because we owe it to our citizens and the refugees that desperately need our help, to stem the flow of those who are not refugees, to help frontline states take responsibility and to provide a refuge for those genuinely fleeing for their lives. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for choosing me, as I appreciate that everyone is keen to talk to Mr Kamall. The last time we spoke, Mr Kamall, I had the honour of asking you a question about Turkey and you contradicted the position that your leader, the Prime Minister, has held for many years about Turkish membership of the EU. I wonder if now you would like to join with me in condemning your leader’s, the Prime Minister’s, part in a very shoddy deal that is being done with Turkey, the payment of protection money – basically on his knees with the rest of the EU begging Turkey to solve the problems we have got. And, while we are at it, give us a critique of his other failed re-negotiations – any that might come to mind?

name: Syed KAMALL
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Etheridge, you are either naive or a real optimist if you expect me to stand here and criticise the leader of my party – the Prime Minister of my country. I would say wake up or get some coffee before you come into the Chamber.  What I would say to you is that you also criticised him over the negotiation. No prime minister has done more to negotiate a different relationship with the EU than this current prime minister, and for that you should give him credit.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I understand that it is forbidden to look at Mr Kamall, but anyway I am going to surprise Mr Kamall, because essentially I am in agreement with him on the critical points he has made on the proposal that is on the table.  I do not deny that we need practical and technical arrangements with Turkey as part of a global approach, but this is not a practical or technical arrangement. It is a deal with Turkey in which we outsource our problems. It is a deal in which we are, in fact, giving the entrance keys to the gates of Europe into the hands of Turkey, to the successors of the Ottoman Empire, to Erdoğan – should even say maybe to Sultan Erdoğan. He shall now decide on the entrance into the European Union.  Because what is the deal in fact? The deal is that we are blocking, collectively, entrance to the European Union for Syrians and for other people, and it is Turkey which shall decide, on an individual basis, who is a refugee who can enter, in a trade-off, one to one. Some Syrians will maybe enter but, for example, Afghanis who are fleeing from IS in Afghanistan, may not. A Kurd who wants to leave Iraq or maybe another country shall certainly not be allowed to enter under that scheme. I have to tell you I am on the same side as Mr Kamall for once. I find this deal hugely problematic because it is a type of collective refoulement and, in my eyes, this is forbidden by the Geneva Convention.  Moreover, you have to know, dear colleagues, that Turkey is a very poor member of the Geneva Convention. It has ratified a number of protocols. One example is that Turkey does not give political asylum to Syrians; it only gives political asylum to refugees from countries belonging to the Council of Europe. Secondly, it does not give asylum, for example, to victims of internal civil conflicts, such as the conflict raging for the moment in the south—east of Turkey. So I think it is hugely problematic to ask a country which has not fully accepted all the protocols of the Geneva Convention to do the business. It is like the Americans saying to the Mexicans, you manage the borders in the future. That is what we are doing. I think it is hugely problematic.  Secondly, while I understand the reasoning – which Mr Dombrovskis and Mrs Plasschaert  repeated this morning – that this is the way to stop the smugglers and the only way to stop human trafficking, I am absolutely not of that opinion. I think the opposite will happen. By reducing the entrance points to the European Union in such a narrow way as we are doing now, by giving only Turkey the possibility on an individual basis to grant entry to the European Union, desperate refugees are going to look to alternative routes and in a few weeks we will have again a debate in this Parliament about the revival of the Lampedusa route. We are going to have a debate about a new route in Albania, a new route via Malta, a new route in Bulgaria and it will not solve the problem because the problem cannot be solved by others, by third countries, but it has to be solved by us, the European Union. That is what we lack at the moment.  My plea to you, Mr Dombrovskis and Mrs Plasschaert, is to now do what is necessary on the next count. First, take a decision on the European border and coast guard. It is fantastic that you tell us we are making progress, but we have been making progress for months. Why not use Article 78, paragraph 3 of the Treaty? Article 78 gives you the possibility to take emergency measures in case of an influx into the European Union of refugees and of migrants, but you are not doing it. You do not need legislation from this Parliament and the Council. You can do it based on the actual Treaty. Do it. Start with this border guards on the border with Greece and Turkey. Secondly, as for the EUR 3 billion, how many times are we going to decide on the EUR 3 billion? Can the Member States perhaps pay the EUR 3 billion for once and pay it not through the Turkish authorities, not through Turkey’s NGOs, but directly in the camps to the refugees so that they no longer have to live with USD 7 per month. That is the reason they come to us, because they have to survive with USD 7 a month. We have to put this EUR 3 billion into direct financial aid to the refugees.  Finally, what we also need to do is to strengthen our asylum system, and change the Dublin system. You know what we are doing, in fact? We are not changing the Dublin system now. No. We have put Turkey inside the Dublin system. That is what we have decided, instead of changing the Dublin system definitely and making a fair share between the Member States of the European Union.  So, in the beginning I was of the opinion that maybe this deal could help, but the more I look at it, the more I am critical of it, and the more sceptical I am. I have one plea to Mrs Plasschaert: ask Mr Tusk to redo and remake his copy and to go for real European action. (The speaker agreed to take a blue- card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – It is clear that your dissatisfaction has resulted from the speech, and I totally agree, but I want to ask you bluntly: you, after the Speech of the Vice-President, leave here with the perception that we have a coherent and clear programme. The Vice-President was telling us that the Schengen area had resolved it this way by the end of the year. Does it seem normal to you that the Commission has done a project for such a serious problem for three months, for six months, or do we need a coherent project for citizens to have a correct perception? And what do you think of dividing Europe into two areas, Schengen and excluded countries, even though they have signed the Treaty and are members of the European Union?

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Moment, Mr Verhofstadt, before you reply.  Ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Grapini, if you speak faster than our interpreters can hear, then the interpreters have trouble translating. I would ask you all, ladies and gentlemen, to speak at a rhythm that our interpreters can cope with.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: blue-card answer. – I did not understand the question very well, as this was ‘lost in translation’ perhaps – something about Schengen and non—Schengen. But I think that it is clear that there is a common solution; it is not a question of Schengen alone.  The problem, however, is the following. It is like with the euro: we started with the euro and we made the mistake of not having a government of the euro treasury. In Schengen we made the same mistake: we started with Schengen and then afterwards we said ‘Oh, we do not have a European border and coastguard to protect Schengen. Oh, we do not have a common asylum system’. So we have to learn the lessons now and not start to say ‘okay, here come the Turks who are going to solve our problem’. No, it is we who have to take our responsibility, inside and outside Schengen.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Verhofstadt, however, you have given a broad answer to a question that you did not understand, I must tell you now.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which What a shabby picture we, as the EU, are giving at the moment! On Monday, the representatives, the heads of the governments of the 28 member states, sit in a round and look at what the Turkish prime minister is offering. They are prepared to accept a poisoned offer, because they have agreed in principle and only want to negotiate further. However, it must be made clear that we are not acting with people and with fundamental rights. No one should act on it, not even the EU! What has now been proposed, however, is very reminiscent of a trade in indulgences: those who define and exchange refugees, asylum seekers and protection seekers according to national, regional origin are in breach of international agreements, international agreements and international law. I am thinking only of the images of the people in Idomeni waiting for them to have access to the European Union, for them to be able to move on, and to whom this right is being denied. Never – and I say this very clearly to all those who want to tell us here that we have a European solution on the table – have we never been as far removed from a European solution as we are now. Nothing you found on Monday is intended to be a European solution. The questions, the doubts raised by individual Heads of State, were only to questions that affected their own interests as a state. It wasn't anything else. The penultimate summit included an agreement not to close the borders. The day after, the borders were closed. On Monday evening, at night, in the early morning, the heads of state left, and the first thing that was was the announcement was that the next state would close its borders. Then I look to Greece: it is nice that the Commission has put forward a proposal to create a new instrument and to provide humanitarian aid, in particular to support the activities of organisations. But that does not change the problems. Nothing changes in the real burden on Greece and on the unsolidarity of the other Member States. In my biography, I know exactly what it means to build walls and close borders. I can only tell you that if the phrase suddenly applies: 'Nobody has any intention of making Greece ungovernable', that sounds ridiculous to me. If, for example, Mr de Maiziére says on Monday that Greece should not be like this, they must endure it, they must be able to do so, then I can only say that this is pure cynicism! That is the rejection of the common ground of the European Union. On Turkey, anyone who goes into Turkey's hands is giving up on himself – at least with this Turkey, with this government. We have always been in favour of negotiating membership with Turkey. However, we are strongly opposed to all the criteria, all the requirements, all agreements, everything that applies to accession being simply set aside.   We are making a deal with a country that is prepared to kill people at home, which is prepared to throw bombs at Kurds in Syria, which has contributed to the Syrian war, to the refugee crisis, by supporting Islamist fighters. We're looking away - we're ready to do a deal with them. I believe that we cannot and cannot accept that. I call for this together!

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, moral bankruptcy, these are the words that come to mind following Monday's European Council. Moral bankruptcy, when instead of sanctioning it, the red carpet is rolled out to a regime that subjects justice and the police to the will of a single man, who muzzles and imprisons all free press, who disqualifies all democratic opposition and who, in order to win an election, revives the civil war and bombards its own populations. Moral bankruptcy, when we want to measure the reception reserved for Syrian war refugees in terms of the number of those who will try to enter the European Union by less legal paths, net, of course, of those who will have died along the way. Money, visa, relaunch of the accession process, nothing is too much to seduce the Putin of the Sublime Gate, all because a majority of The Member States of the Union, unlike Germany, took the side of "not this, not these barbarians in our country", some in the name of a thunderous defense of the myth of a white and Christian Europe, others, more prosaically, to defend the tourist season at the Vlaamse Kust, not to mention all those who hide cynically and cowardly behind it. There is still time, ladies and gentlemen, heads of state or government, to pull yourself together and adopt next week measures that bring the European Union up to its responsibilities, both moral and legal. You are right, we must create a safe and legal path to the European Union. But this path cannot be reserved only for Syrians - as far as I know, Iraq, Afghanistan and Yemen are just as many war zones. It cannot be dependent on the number of failed asylum seekers returned to Turkey. I would like to remind you that under the Geneva Convention, every refugee or asylum seeker is entitled to an individual review of their claim. If you are able to find billions - three, six or more, whatever - to encourage reception in Turkey, I think we, the rich Europe, should be able to do at least the same for the reception here. I would remind you that the European Union last year took in refugees to the tune of 0.25% of its population. That's 100 times less - 100 times less! - that the number of refugees taken in by a fragile country like Lebanon, a country that, like Jordan and much more than Turkey, needs our help. So yes, to put this policy in place, we will have to talk with Turkey. But the stronger our common determination to face our responsibilities, the stronger we will be facing Erdogan, because, you face, Turkey is geopolitically and economically weakened. It needs at least as much of the European Union as Turkey's Europe. The primary condition for the success of such a policy assumes that we Europeans act together. "Zusammen schaffen wir das." I would like to address two countries in particular. Mrs Hennis-Plasschaert, you are from the Netherlands and you are currently the President of the Council of the Union. I would like to remind you that your country is the home of political liberalism. When Europe was confronted with absolutism and religious wars, the Netherlands was able to transform itself into a land of welcome for all European refugees. As for France, rather than displaying a façade solidarity while letting its Prime Minister teach the Chancellor a childish lesson, rather than lose her honour by handing over the legion of the same name to the crown prince of the Islamic State — I mean, Saudi Arabia - I would like her to assume her responsibilities to deserve the title of "homeland of human rights", which she drapes herself a little more often than in her turn, that she takes her fair part in welcoming refugees and that she assumes her share of leadership that is so lacking. Finally, and I will end with this, Mr President, in the face of the Kaczynskis, Orbon, Fico, Morano, Pegida and Le Pen who are constantly invoking a Christian Europe to build our continent into a fortress, I want to recall the words spoken here, eighteen months ago, by Pope Francis. He told us that it is necessary to tackle the migration issue together. The Mediterranean Sea cannot be tolerated as a great cemetery. He told us that Europe will be able to deal with immigration-related issues: first, if it can clearly define its own cultural identity and implement adequate legislation capable, at the same time, of protecting the rights of European citizens and guaranteeing the reception of migrants; second, if it adopts fair, courageous and concrete policies that help countries of origin resolve their internal conflicts, cause of the phenomenon, instead of the self-serving policies that fuel these conflicts. According to Pope Francis, it is necessary to act on both the causes and the effects. More recently, he reminded us that a person who wants to build walls, not bridges, is not Christian. I would remind you that what we put on our banknotes, ladies and gentlemen, are bridges and not walls. You know what you have to do.

name: David BORRELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again we are faced with situations that are now becoming constant in our debates: the migration crisis and the economic crisis. These two issues are very different in nature and dynamics, but they are necessary to our attention at the same time for their urgency and importance. We must now recognize that they are also necessary because of the ineffectiveness of the solutions adopted so far.  Despite all the efforts to combat the economic crisis, we have not succeeded in substance in ferrying the majority of our fellow citizens to waters that are neither safer nor calmer; On the contrary, the example of insufficient solidarity, which is insufficient, especially in the method, which has been given to the Greek people, cannot reassure those of our fellow citizens who are in a particularly weak situation.  The migration crisis, then, even finds us uncovered by those instruments and mechanisms on which the response to the financial crisis has been able to count. In fact, we have seen governments which, in view of the not-so-huge numbers of migrants, have called for the removal, or even abolition, of rules given by all to be acquired and presented to the world as irrevocable achievements of the process of European unification. The results of the last Council still confirm a situation of substantial paralysis: without prejudice to the usual statements of principle and the slightest progress, everything is postponed to the next meeting.  This inability to design in the face of known problems has even put the European Union in the position of having improper conditions put in place by a government, the Turkish government, which, just a few days after egregious actions contrary to the values that the Union claims, such as freedom of the press, is demanding the acceleration of accession negotiations.  It is now clear to anyone who wants to see that the governments of the European Union are at a standstill in the face of the current challenges. It is up to us, who have direct representation of our fellow citizens, for issues that affect the whole continent, to show that it is possible to think, plan and want a different and even more effective approach to crises that pose challenges to us. So what to do?  First of all, call back the values. The European Union has told the world that it wants to offer an area of freedom, justice and security. Let's start from here. Freedom: we are aware of the effort turkey is making to take in Syrian refugees and we have already allocated considerable resources; But we cannot agree to exchange this welcome, which is also a duty for the Turkish Government, with the continued denial of freedom of expression and the press. This is improper negotiation and those who apply to join the European Union must be clear about this distinction, in principle and in actions.  Justice: we have more than 500 million inhabitants in the European Union. In 2015, we took in 1 200 000 asylum seekers and it is not acceptable for our governments to go into crisis for such numbers. We have other capabilities and it is not right to accept humanitarian situations, such as those we are seeing these days, on the Greek-Macedonian border.  Security: acting with justice also means knowing how to distinguish and give one's name to things. It is necessary to tell our fellow citizens clearly, in words and deeds, who will be welcomed and why, how it will be managed and integrated, who cannot be accepted forever and how this decision will be enforced. And we need clear, enforceable and certain rules for the whole of the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: "blue card" question. I have a question about the clarity of the debate. I've listened to you carefully. I too am very familiar with UKIP's position on immigration and illegal migration, a position which I, very often by the way, wholeheartedly agree with. Have you spoken here today on behalf of the entire EFDD Group or only on behalf of your own party?

name: David BORRELLI
text: Answer to a blue card question. This curiosity was resolved, I believe, a few months ago, when I stood up in this House and said that the EFDD, on the issue of migration, is divided because, as Italians, we have another vision. Maybe she was absent.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the truth is cruel! In the last negotiations between Turkey and Europe, President Erdogan launched a diktat to this european Union, which is inherently weak, it must be said, and failing. I had called it once the big soft jellyfish, and I think I had just typed it. After having obtained, last November, three billion euros to dry up the flow of migrants, a promise obviously unfulfilled, he is now demanding six billion to do so. The evidence of broken promises can be seen in the figures: in January 2016, twelve times as many migrants from Turkey landed in Greece, compared to January 2015. Erdogan rolls you in the flour, Erdogan makes you sing. It even goes so far as to demand today the abolition of visas to allow its nationals to join the European Union and, finally, the acceleration of Turkey's accession process to the European Union, as a reward for its non-cooperation. The proof is that the European Union does not make any stronger. On the contrary, it generates a permanent blur and a mortal weakness, which Mr. Erdogan benefits greatly from. He shows you every day how little he does with your moral lessons, because because of your irresponsible choices, you have made him super-powerful. For example, a major Turkish opposition newspaper was invaded last week by police, who drove out journalists with water cannons and tear gas, the Turkish army is bombing the Kurds in Syria - I remind you that the Kurds are the fiercest opponents of Daesh and Al-Qaeda - Turkey has fired on a Russian plane, it is involved in smuggling oil from Daesh - which you refuse to watch; and, finally, it is destabilized by multiple attacks on its soil, caused by mr Erdogan's major domestic and foreign policy errors. Is this the country you want to integrate into Europe? Finally, a country has found an effective solution to stop migration crises. This is, of course, Australia. A wide-art advertising campaign was carried out in all emigration countries to prevent illegal immigrants and boats from being systematically returned to their countries of origin, and this is the case. This clear and firm policy has produced indisputable results. So let's be pragmatic, responsible, let's adopt it. Let's create as many filters as we can by putting in place strong national boundaries! Let us create, under the aegis of the United Nations, protected refugee camps in Syria or in countries close to Syria, to secure war refugees in decent conditions. Everyone will win: Europeans, who can no longer afford it, will no longer be overwhelmed by unmanageable migration phenomena, migrants who will no longer be attracted by false promises, with the risk of death and the stalemate at the end of the journey.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask the Minister, on behalf of the Council, and the Commissioner, on behalf of Mr Juncker, to be so kind as to clarify in a straightforward way for the citizens of Europe what exactly the big change is we are talking about. Did we, as optimists, understand correctly that the big change is that, from now on, the European Union will not allow anybody from any unfortunate country to come and settle in the European Union, but only refugees from countries at war? Could you please answer yes or no, very briefly, as to what is the status. My second question – and European citizens are also extremely interested in this – refers to the fact that sometimes you talk about migration or migration policies, on behalf of the EU, and sometimes asylum or refugee policies. This is a factual question, not a matter of opinion, but nevertheless, for the sake of European citizens, let us clarify that the European Union has nothing to do with the migration policy of individual Member States. Migration in general is the competence of Member States. Is that clear? Is this a fact? Do you agree that this is a fact?

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. The details matter: according to the key points negotiated on Monday, the fight against smugglers and traffickers is to be targeted. I would like to remind you that yesterday, on International Women's Day, we spoke for a long time about the situation of migrant women and highlighted the dangers and risks that women and children in particular are exposed to if traffickers and smugglers are not put to work here. An agreement with Turkey is now being considered, in which this very problem is also being addressed. I can only tell you that I welcome these negotiations, I welcome the progress that was made on Monday. It is not yet a breakthrough, but we must face up to the facts, and we will only get a solution if we involve Turkey. We must, of course, support Greece, but that is not enough. People are coming across the sea, so we do not need to lie in our pockets. Without an agreement with Turkey, we will not be able to deal with smuggling. For me, what is crucial is the price we, as Europeans, have to pay for this. I would like to make it clear that there must be no accession rebate. For us in the European Union, there are clear rules for membership, clear conditions, which also apply to Turkey. Many Members have already discussed this: the accession negotiations are one thing, and the question of how we solve the problems in the refugee and migration crisis is another matter. The other point I would like to raise is the issue of visa facilitation. I am very, very critical of that. I think that we in Parliament will deal with this issue in the most intensive way. With regard to the Presidency of the Council, I would also like to say once again that there will be no visa facilitation without Parliament. So please take up the critical voices that are being brought to you from this House with a view to these facilitations.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, two months ago Mr Rutte and Mr Tusk said that we had two months to deal with the solution of the migration problem. The two months are in the next week. Looking ahead to next week's Council, I think we need to raise our voices in this Parliament to say a few clear things to the heads of state and government. The first is that we're worried about what they agree with others, but we're ashamed of what we do in here. Let us ask the heads of state and government to know clearly that the men, women and children who roam, who are lost in the European winter are of the same condition, have the same dignity as the men, women and children who escaped the Spanish civil war, the Second World War in their various scenarios, the fascist and communist dictatorships , of the wars in the Balkans. Let us tell the heads of state and government not to fall into the temptation of populism, not to give themselves to fear, to defend before their public opinion the fundamental values and laws of the European Union; and, above all, let us also ask them to respect the principles of humanitarian action and international humanitarian law in everything they agree with third countries. But above all, let us not be silent in the face of this epidemic of inhumanity which we are witnessing in so many countries of the Union. Parliament has a large majority which cannot accept this inhumanity being exercised on its behalf. Not on behalf of Parliament. Not on behalf of our House. No, of course, in my name.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Let me start with the March European Council. For all of us, increasing the competitiveness of the European Union is an extremely important issue, but I believe that, in the light of the forthcoming referendum in the United Kingdom, this agenda is particularly important and I appreciate the Commission's work in preparing this Council.  As regards the EU-Turkey Summit: I am pleased that, after many months of not saying after many years, the European Union appreciates the geostrategic importance of Turkey as a partner. Naturally, this is happening in a situation of severe migration crisis, and therefore Turkey's negotiating position and capabilities are also slightly different than they may have been a few years ago. I don't think we should be afraid at the moment of what colleagues call outsourcing or fear of addiction. I think we should beware of this, but the issue of readmission in such serious crises is usually dealt with in partner countries. That's what's happening this time. There are various dangers associated with this agreement, but they should... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: Madam Minister, it is a great pleasure to see you here again. I would like to start with a few quotes in English: "What a Europe without internal borders is crying out for is a common approach in this field. The problem is that every time the Council has to take a concrete decision, the highest common denominator suddenly seems to become the lowest one. To be quite frank, I am fed up with merely hearing fine words on this matter". Do you recognize the words? Yes, these are the words of MEP Hennis-Plasschaert, then rapporteur for asylum policy, expressed on 6 May 2009. And you even argued passionately for a mandatory European defence mechanism. Madam Minister, this deal between the EU and Turkey is not a show of strength, but of weakness of the European Union. It is a deal that is legally dubious and morally totally unworthy. We are talking about plans for economic growth, but Mr Dombrovskis, who wants to invest in this European Union that is falling apart? Madam Minister, I urge you and the Dutch Presidency to fight for the full and sustainable asylum policy that you so passionately advocated in 2009.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Mr President, I have just returned from Turkey and the results of the summit are reaching me. What I heard there is beyond comprehension: journalists and magistrates muzzled, academics resigned, accused of terrorism, activists coldly murdered. Of course, there is also the South East and the cities under curfew: more than 760 civilians murdered since July, including a hundred children including young people - terrorists of course! Cizre is a symbol of these abuses. The images I have seen are more like the war in Syria than a so-called democratic country: the city completely destroyed, the law of war not even respected, the evidence of massacres destroyed, and we try to make the corpses disappear. And that's where we want to outsource migration policy. This is the country we want to make a safe country. The Turkish authorities themselves created the refugee crisis in Europe. They are now blackmailing the European Union, and it works! We need to avoid a new Cizre in Sour. I'm ashamed! The European Union is losing its soul. Finally, we must open our eyes, we must have an official mission of the European Parliament, Mr President, to go there quickly. There are many groups asking for it.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: – Mr President, many arguments have been put forward. I just want to underline two things. First, that the Member States of the Union are responsible for helping refugees. This means that even if Turkey is commissioned, we remain obliged to monitor, control and give it guarantees. And we have an obligation to find other solutions for the thousands of Afghans, Iraqis, Libyans, etc. who are not covered by the Syrian agreement with Turkey. Second, we must not be wrong now too. Turkey's assistance is humanitarian and expediency. We cannot afford it with political facilities for Turkey's entry into the European Union, which is an entry with one's own and demanding mechanisms and standards of respect for human rights. In short, we must continue to assume our political and moral obligations. To help refugees should not mean kneeling before an authoritarian state that does not respect basic human rights.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: – Mr President, we are embarked upon a course of almost unbelievable stupidity. The historic error made by Chancellor Merkel last year by saying all can come has led directly to this mess and now we are being blackmailed by Turkey.  First they came for EUR 3 billion in a promise to reduce the numbers coming into Greece and the rest of Europe and, of course, when the numbers increased many-fold they came back for another EUR 3 billion. And they will keep on coming back for more and more and more, as the British poet Rudyard Kipling observed of the Danish incursions into England. That was called paying the Danegeld, but we proved again and again that if once you have paid him the Danegeld you will never get rid of a Dane.  And now they have got us over a barrel, this new deal where for every one illegal migrant we send back, if our human rights laws allow it, they will send us another one from Syria. So the argument is that we paid them a fortune not to reduce numbers, and yet we have given in. And we have said yes to visa-free access for 75 million Turks from June of this year. In theory, they can stay for 90 days. In practice, many will disappear or, of course, claim family reunion. The numbers will go sharply up. And in return for all of this, we are now going to fast-track Turkey as a full member of the European Union. My goodness me, I wish that David Cameron was as good at negotiations as the Turks are! So we are going to go into political union with a country that has got borders with Iraq, Iran and Syria. We are going to go into political union with a country that is poorer than anybody else in the European Union and give free movement to 75 million people and join up with a government that is increasingly Islamist and authoritarian.  The Turkish Prime Minister said this week that Turkish membership will be a turning point. Too right! The British Prime Minister has long supported Turkey being a member of this Union. In fact he has fought hard over 10 years for them to join. He does not bat an eyelid at the extra GBP 500 million we will stump up to help fund this crisis.  Well this referendum in Britain is all about what is the safest option, and given that the boss of Europol says there are already 3 000 to 5 000 Islamist terrorists that have come into Europe using the migrant routes, it is pretty clear to me that a vote to remain is a vote for Turkey. A vote to remain is a vote for massively increased immigration into Britain and a vote to remain is a vote that makes Britain more vulnerable to terrorism. Safer to vote to leave and take back control of our borders.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: – To the cowardly European leaders I say: "Shame on you!" You capitulated fully to the dodgy Turkish dictator Erdogan on Monday. You are betraying our European values, you are squandering the interests of our sovereign states and you are jething our freedom.  Your acceptance of all Turkish demands clearly demonstrates the impotence of your collapsing EUSSR. The Europhile elite is in total panic. In a panic, you let the Turks march visa-free into the EU, in a panic you pay the Sultan of Ankara EUR 6 billion and in a panic Turkey is allowed to join the European Union at an accelerated time. In total panic, you submit to Islam and you are pushing for an Islamic Europe, a historical mistake. And you call that "peace in our time." Nonsense! This ill-food plan must now be off the table, now! Stop the billions heading for Turkey. Stop the Islamic invasion, stop betraying the People of Europe. Enough is enough. There is only one solution, there is only one way out of this crisis. There is one powerful and effective response to this rampant influx of fortune seekers. Close the internal and external borders and guard them. Right away!

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, later this month, the Council of Ministers will reconvene and return to the nitty-gritty of tackling the mess created by the EU project’s failed approach to migration and competitiveness. Despite Mr Weber’s valiant attempts to present this week’s deal in our relationship with Turkey as one of partnership and not dependency, the reality is that migration policy is chaotic, expensive and giving into the bullying of Turkey in terms of visa liberalisation and accession. Meanwhile, in the United Kingdom, the Prime Minister continues to tour the country to sell that other failed deal. Thankfully, for millions of people across the United Kingdom, there is hope. We believe that the extent of our ambitions must be about more than making the best of a bad deal. There is another way. To paraphrase the now-former Director of the British Chamber of Commerce: ‘there can be a brighter future, one outside the European Union’.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have heard very different assessments of the agreement with Turkey, from satisfaction to great criticism that this is a dictatorship. But at the same time, can we deal with this crisis without Turkey's participation and without cooperation with it? I have long said that it is necessary to establish cooperation with regional partners such as Turkey, but also with north African countries. At the same time, however, it is necessary to internationalised this process, including the inclusion of the UN. This is not only a regional problem, but also a global problem, both in terms of the consequences and the possibility of tackling the sources of migration.  We agreed in September 2015 that we must help those countries under migratory pressure in solidarity. They, in turn, have committed to carrying out the procedure for applying for refugee status. We, on the other hand, also wanted them to restore the protection of the external borders at the same time. Unfortunately, it does not work, it does not work. Not all countries are also complying with their commitments in this regard, although my government confirms these commitments.  Turkey can do a lot by fighting smuggling networks, which, after all, make their fortunes by preying on migrants who are transported illegally to Europe, while at the same time lying about the opportunities these migrants will face here. But by protecting Europe's borders, we cannot rely solely on external partners. It is also our part to restore control, to bring about theciliation of the migratory stream. Nor can we stop working to eliminate the sources of migration: above all, war, attacks on civilians, war crimes and genocide. Turkey is a big neighbour with great opportunities, but at the same time we must talk about the challenges of human rights, freedom of the media, which must be respected there. Whatever the importance of the solutions we adopt, we must say that the Union is a value in itself and that Schengen and the Union must be protected.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – I was in the south-east of Turkey last month. One thing is crystal clear. It is not the European Union, and turkey, that can solve the refugee crisis on their own. And they both have a problem, that's the failure to handle the situation. Now is not the time to blackmail, to gain the benefits of one side or the other. The key now is that cooperation is sincere. Financial assistance to Turkey must get where it is most needed – for food, for education, for work. Turkey must step up the fight against human trafficking. The exchange of refugees must take place in accordance with international principles on the protection of human rights and not a la carte. What is happening in Greece is a tragedy. It is the result of an incompetence of a common Union response and a disgrace to Europe. You said that the currents on the Balkan route have stopped, I wish that was the case. Slovenia is once again implementing Schengen at the border with Croatia as of today. But Greece needs to be helped, otherwise people smugglers will expand the business. It is high time that all countries – including the Višegrad Quartet – took responsibility for the existence of the Schengen area. Turkey is a strategic partner for the Union, but its future in connection will depend on its progress. What is happening to the media is intolerable, as is violence against the Kurds. Otherwise, the guarantee of a moderation of the refugee situation will only be a permanent ceasefire in Syria, for which not only the Union and Turkey must strive, but the entire international community.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, the european Union-Turkey refugee summit the day before yesterday is a monument to failure and cynicism. Postponing refugee measures and referring it to the European Union Summit on 17 and 18 March means that refugee flows will continue unabaised in Greece, bringing the number of stranded refugees to 150,000 by the end of March. The European Union must put its hand in its pocket and grant Greece funds for refugees here and now.  Mr Dombrovskis, Greece will not tolerate turning into a vast refugee Dachau. He will not tolerate Turkey's oriental bazaars aimed at increasing the dowry he is asking for in order to stop the slave trade that fills the Aegean islands with refugees and illegal immigrants. Greece will not tolerate the illegalities of the Macedonians and Albanians, who have closed the borders. It is time for Greece to withdraw from Schengen, suspend Dublin III and impose an economic embargo on Skopje and Albania in retaliation for closed borders. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Congressman, I'm sorry. I would like to ask you a question, linked to your remarks, in which you mainly mentioned cynicism and the emergence of various blackmail techniques in European politics. It is true, Greece does not use this tool, Turkey all the more so. But there's blackmail inside, too, for example. Prime Minister Cameron, who, you know, blackmailed the European Union with his Labour questions. And what do you think of the creation of this culture?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), answer a question with a blue card. – For Mr. Cameron went into detail yesterday and explained that the decision on Britain, voted for by all leaders, actually creates a situation where decisions are now imposed against all workers on the basis of their nationality. Thus, Europeans working in Britain will have no rights, but British working in Germany will have limited rights.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, please do not get me wrong, I do see progress at the summit with Turkey and I know that we are in partnership with Turkey. Sometimes we cannot choose our partners even if they confiscate media or crackdown on human rights organisations or whatever else. But what we can do is influence the content of the agreement and I am not really sure that the deal that has been struck with Turkey will lead us in the right direction.  Firstly, I can understand that we are legalising, maybe, migration – but not necessarily under our norms. However, I do not see us limiting migration in this respect. Exchanging for visa liberalisation? How on earth is it connected? Even more – I negotiated the Czech accession to the EU – we will be opening chapters with Turkey at the same time as Erdoğan does what he does. So for me it is a question of a comprehensive agreement that we expect from the summit, with concrete deadlines, concrete measures and concrete issues in place.  One final remark on the internal market: I am very much in agreement with the Minister but I would like to see also progress, in practice. The Fourth Railway Package trilogue, Madam Minister: move the Council please.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I would sign this agreement if it referred to goods, if it referred to crates or coffins. I'm really ashamed because human beings decided on human beings in this way. Even the United Nations issued a statement saying it was violating human rights. Why don't we give these three, six, nine billion dollars? – and I do not know how much will be done – to proclaim two cities within Syria as safe cities under the protection of the United Nations, America and Russia and to rebuild two cities for them, to return to their homes? It's a russet deal for Turkey.  I came back the other day from Diyarbakir. We saw the closure of the Zaman newspaper, the persecution of a thousand academics and two hundred people trapped inside The Sor. We demand that there be a safe way and a way out of these people.  And in all this, the following picture yesterday: Mr Davutoğlu giving roses for Women's Day to women journalists, while in his country he is closing ...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Mr President, I would say to the President of the Council that Monday’s Council was a Council of shame. What you – by which I mean the 28 heads of state and government – have been deciding is to break international law, European law, and, what is even worse, the basic principles of humanity. You are planning to do push-backs against refugees, back to Turkey, from where Turkey might very well expulse them back to Syria or Iraq. You are closing the border to people in need of international protection. You are putting an end to the right to claim and seek asylum. I wonder – and this goes for all heads of state and government – how you can sleep at night?

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr We are opposed to Turkish membership of the EU for a number of reasons.  The first and most important is that the country is not in Europe. Only 3% of Turkey is entering Europe, and that the EU would have a border with Syria, Iraq and Iran, I hope you will understand for yourselves what this might lead to.  Secondly, it is now engaged in blackmail against the EU, which is demanding more money and visa facilitation for Turkish citizens and a quick file into membership in order to help at all.
