Repression against minorities is common in Turkey, for example against the Kurds. Human rights do not respect. The view of freedom of the press is, to say the least, worrying when it comes to the media and freedom of expression, and one can with great concern observe an Islamist development in the country in recent years with the ruling Party akp.  Turkey's GDP is a fraction of my own country's GDP, and we have enough expenditure for europe as it is now. I do not want to put any further stone on the burden on Swedish taxpayers, because that is where it ends up in the end.  The fact that the EU, in its state of panic over not being able to deal with the migration crisis, would succumb to blackmail is totally the wrong way to tackle this problem. We are opening the way for dialogue and cooperation with Turkey to resolve the problems, but let me be clear when I say that it ends there too.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by expressing my anger. It is annoying because a phalanx of Austrian MEPs, consisting of the two government groups – Social Democrats and Christian Democrats, SPÖ and ÖVP – together with the participation of the two left-wing parties, has jointly drafted a declaration in which the results of this recent EU summit were expressly welcomed. This means that the door is to be kept open in Europe. This means that billions of European taxpayers' money will continue to be moved to Turkey. This means that, from June, visa-free travel for Turks in the EU will be made possible here. And that means that Turkey should continue to be led towards EU membership. This behaviour of the SPÖ and ÖVP will be discussed in Austria and is an internal Austrian problem. However, it is not only a problem of domestic politics that is what is happening in Germany. For the behaviour of German Chancellor Merkel, which threatens to drag an entire continent into the abyss, is something that affects Europe as a whole. If The German Chancellor Merkel wants to show more heart for people in Arabia and North Africa than for her own compatriots, then it is okay, then perhaps she should go to Arabia or North Africa as a refugee worker. As Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, she is no longer sustainable because her decisions affect the entire continent. This summit must be rejected. We want to regain control of our borders in Austria. And if the situation of Turkey becoming a member of the European Union continues, I want to have a referendum in Austria as well.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Mr President, the day before yesterday the summit between the European Union and Turkey took place. The results of this were not only disappointing but a diplomatic Waterloo for union leaders. Twenty-eight Turkish leaders of dwarf stature sat and listened to a brutal blackmailer, a common con man, Davutoğlu, set conditions for surrender and subjugation. I will mention four of the unacceptable conditions he has set out, among other things: additional funding of three billion euros, a more favourable visa regime, first the evacuation of the Greek islands by refugees and then the start of the refoulement of illegal immigrants, an immediate restart of five chapters of the accession route.  Gentlemen, as Ottoman scholars have written: The Turk is spiritually barbaric, god-fearing, savage and filthy. The Turk is like a dog; he does the savage, but when he has to face the opponent he run away. The only meaningful way to deal with the Turk is with strength and determination. But such gifts are lacking in Europe's elected and non-political masters. You've sold out to Ottoman Erdogan.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, when someone in this House calls a people or a nation barbaric it is not just inacceptable, he should be expelled from this House. It is a shame on the European Parliament.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We shall examine this, Mr Bostinaru.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear Colleague, do you not consider that the negotiations with the Islamist and dictator Erdogan, agreeing to his blackmail, are a shame and a disgrace to the European Commission? Don't you think this agreement is an unacceptable collaboration in turkey's favour, yet another grave political mistake of the incapable bureaucrats in Brussels who invited millions of illegal migrants into our homes, then completely failed with the quota distribution and now agree to pay a racketeering, one ransom to dictator Erdogan? Indeed, with this agreement, the European Union recognises that it cannot protect its borders. The ideas of visa liberalisation and new negotiating chapters, payment of billions of "ransom" in my opinion are purely political suicide for the European ... (the speaker is interrupted by the President)

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), answer to a blue card question to Angel Dzhambazki. – I agree with what you said, Mr President, and I think That Europe may well protect its borders vis-à-vis Turkey. Simply, these are games and bazaars that are played between Turkey and the European Union.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I wanted to point out that the speaker, who has already been reprimanded by my colleague, referred to the Turks as dogs. We must not let this racism go through. I would ask you to examine the Minutes and draw the appropriate conclusions.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Bütikofer, I would like to thank Mr Bütikofer for his excellent work I have promised that we will look into this. At that very moment, I was busy recording Mr Dzhambazki's interim question. That is why I did not follow German interpretation for a moment.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Mr President, last Monday in Brussels was another last-chance summit. One more! The outcome of this summit, like the previous eight, is not only disappointing, but very worrying. This must be of concern to us because the European Council on 18 and 19 March will be crucial, because we will have to choose between, on the one hand, a Europe of union such as the one that was conceived 60 years ago and, on the other, a Europe of one's own own. At a time when Schengen is under threat, this Europe of selfishness is not the solution to the migration crisis. As always, our position with regard to Turkey is totally ambiguous. The negotiations with Turkey last Monday are probably the worst we have seen in a long time. Europe negotiates with Turkey by being divided as never before and without an elaborate strategy, without consultation among all. Europe, distraught, surrenders itself to the hands of the Turks, it throws itself into the mouth of the wolf. Madam Minister, what you are proposing is irresponsible. Every week Turkey comes up with a new list of claims. It's climbing. With regard to visas, 72 criteria must be met before Turkish citizens benefit from them. However, the European Council has committed to authorising these visas by 1 June. Madam Minister, you forget that this is a competence of the European Parliament, which intends to fully exercise its power of co-decision in this matter. The Council is committed to paying an additional $3 billion, but it is a market of dupes, since you were not able to pay the $3 billion promised last October. How much control will you have over the use of that six billion? The hypocrisy is total, finally, with this sea snake represented by Turkey's accession to the European Union. We know that such a prospect is unrealistic and will not come true. What we want are actions, because Europe cannot constantly discard its responsibilities over others. Let us cease this disgraceful blackmail for the European Union! (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, Mrs Grossetête, I fully agree with what you have just said. You denounce this European Union agreement with Turkey, which you quite rightly described as a market of dupes. You reiterated that visas will be liberalized far too easily and without, for that matter, complying with rules that should be. You reminded us that we are going to pay six billion euros, and all this in return for what? In return for promises made by a government that, it is clear, does not respect any of the freedoms in its country. I therefore ask you this question: how can you continue to support the European Union under such conditions?

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I simply believe that Europe has been built on crises. She is experiencing unprecedented crises today. I still have confidence in the European Union's ability to respond. However, it must fully exercise its responsibilities!

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, I strongly believe there is no solution to the current migration challenges without close cooperation with Turkey, but I am not sure that the terms of the discussion on Monday are the right ones. It seems to me that reducing the flow of people entering Europe has overridden the concerns about human rights and international law. The deal with Turkey could be a breakthrough as much as a failed opportunity for our Member States to face, united, their common responsibility in the face of a very difficult crisis. That being said, Turkey needs to be praised for its efforts in dealing with a very large number of Syrian and Iraqi refugees, and for its willingness to welcome an even larger number. I also welcome the agreement on taking all necessary measures to close down people-smuggling routes and equally to break the business model of the smugglers. Turkey is a candidate country, but the refugee crisis and the accession path have to be dealt with separately and criticisms have to be part of the enlargement process. Here the Commission is completely shy. Therefore I condemn the seizing of the Zaman newspaper by the Turkish police this weekend. Finally, I would like to ask Turkey to refrain from any actions that could undermine the Syrian ceasefire and the international peace talks on Syria. While deploring the recent attacks against Turkish citizens, I call on Turkey to restart the peace process with the Kurds.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Would you not agree with me that Europe’s borders are obviously completely porous? Chancellor Merkel invites numerous people from all over the world to come to Europe and then offloads the problem onto the rest of us. The agreement with Turkey on migration is ludicrous and a joke. It is like bailing out a boat with a sieve. All we are doing is swapping one set of immigrants for another, would you not agree?

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: blue-card answer. – Dear colleague, beside the populist speech and talk which is so common on your side of the House, I want to tell you that pragmatically, we desperately need a system to protect our EU external border – not just the Schengen border but the EU external border – for all, and secondly, to deal pragmatically with our neighbours to confront the problem of refugees. Simple populist solutions will never fly.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: – Mr President, we really must be honest with each other. This is a crisis and we cannot afford to create yet another failure. It was relocation last year and a misjudged Turkey agreement this year. As Mr Kamall has said, friends need to be honest with each other. They do not just tell you what you want to hear. My fear is another miracle solution which fails will overshadow all the other important and sensible actions which are being taken. But a EUR 6 billion mistake is a big mistake. Stop looking for silver bullets because some time you might end up with a nuclear bomb. Direct resettlement, sticking to the rules, border controls and faster processing are what we need. It is not headline-making but it is necessary in the present crisis. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question. – I think you were right to say that there are no simple solutions and that external borders must be protected. But is this not the idea of an agreement between Turkey and the EU? Let us try to prevent the worst of what is happening, the smuggling business, then to bring some coherence to the external borders of the European Union. Here's the point.

name: Timothy KIRKHOPE
text: blue-card answer. – I am not sure whether that is the point. I think that this whole project is one which is being approached with great haste and not with enough thought. I think we need to be very calm and collected, despite the crisis, and we need to concentrate on the proposals that the Commission and, indeed, national governments have already made to try and alleviate the situation in other ways.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Mr President, it is normal to talk with Turkey, but it is indecent to delegate to it the management of our borders and our right of asylum by promising, moreover, an accession that would run counter to the integrated Europe we want. If Europe wants to exist, it must assume its own responsibilities: to play its part in welcoming refugees, of course; not leave Greece alone on the front line; processing asylum claims from those in its territory; to operate, as needed, the regular readmission mechanisms; setting up EU-run offices in the host countries to register, process and accept asylum applications there; link its financial assistance to Turkey to the dismemberment of criminal smuggling networks and, finally, monitor and manage its own borders by setting up a coastguard and border guard corps. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), blue card question. Mrs de Sarnez, I would like to ask you a question. Greece has no land border with Schengen countries. Do you agree with the idea that Greece should leave Schengen so that these people are not motivated to come to Greece to get papers and travel to Europe?

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my vision is diametrically opposed to yours. Greece is part of Schengen. We must show him solidarity every minute and every moment, which we have not done enough in the last months and years. The external border of the European Union is the Greek border, but it is the external border of our European Union, and we must stand with the Greeks more than ever.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the proposal for an agreement proposes to return people who are entitled to asylum without even allowing them to apply, by canonizing hot returns, which is not only unfair and immoral, but violates international and European law, as the United Nations High Commissioner in this House reported yesterday. With this agreement Europe denies itself, outsourcing the management of our borders and our reception duties, hiring the Turkish gendarmerie to do so. No person can be returned to a country where their human rights may be infringed. Turkey is not a safe country. With this agreement, the European Union legitimizes and becomes complicit in the Turkish Government's attacks on press freedom, demonstration, systematic violation of human rights and repression of minorities and bombings in Kurdistan. With this agreement they are complicit.  If you want to take down the mafias, open safe passages to reach Europe. If you don't, your hands will be stained with blood.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which This summit showed that it is the lack of solidarity and shared responsibility for the women, men and children who are fleeing bombs, murder and manslaughter and seeking refuge with us, which the EU is delivering to an increasingly authoritarian Turkish regime. It is the governments of the Member States that are moving further and further away from European values and from values of humanity, which should in fact be the basis of the actions of governments on this continent. Unfortunately, the government of my own country, Austria, is the trailblazer for this shame for this Europe.  I am very pleased – and rightly so – that the heads of delegations of the four pro-European Austrian delegations made a joint statement here in the EP yesterday and said that going it alone is wrong and that we must act together.  As the UN High Commissioner for Refugees, Mr Grandi, said yesterday, fences and walls are not the solution, they only increase suffering. That must not be allowed to happen, and I am also directing this to the Austrian Federal Government, because it is not only the images in Idomeni that are disturbing, as the Austrian Foreign Minister has said. It is the suffering of the people that disturbs. Only joint solutions can help us and actually help the refugees.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: " Many are pleased with Monday's agreement with Turkey. I find that joy pretty weird. I keep trying to understand whether Turkey bought a six billion euro visa-free visa with the countries of the European Union here, or whether it has already been a membership? Does this mean that Turkey will become a member of the European Union, along with its problems and with the returned migrants? Or does that mean that a significant proportion of the seventy-five million Turks will move to the European Union and stay here? Or do we succumb to such blackmail, and do we hope that Turkey will solve the problems that we must solve ourselves? Ladies and gentlemen, democracy has nothing to do with kneeling and hitting. Respect for human rights is primarily respect for the rights and freedoms of citizens of their countries, for centuries-old values and traditions. Bans on decorating a Christmas tree or eating pork sausages, hiding information about immigrant crime and media silences about their actions – what are these things meant? Is this european democracy, if it can still be called? Or is it only forced to put mats under the feet of the world's powers to establish agreements that no one respects?  (The speaker agrees to answer the blue card question of the person who raised the Blue Card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Turkish game is clear: to raise the stakes, to get EUR 3 billion, to obtain visas, to obtain a blank-seing for Turkish domestic policy. Do you not think, ladies and gentlemen, that Europe is weak today, that the European Union is very weak in this negotiation with Turkey?

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: answer to the blue card question. – I believe that the European Union should move from languages to work, and I would mention only two points – that is, the protection of the external borders – and make every effort to bring the heart of the conflict, the wars about the European Union to a weakened or no longer exist. The world has good examples of australia's example of how Australia has coped with the flow of migrants. Let's go down those roads, let's not reinvent the bike again.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Minister, in order to save yourself from the consequences of your serious mistakes with regard to the great openings of this German-powered Europe, the solution found is simply indecent: to open the doors and rely on Erdogan and a totally unreliable regime, as a good blackmailer.  I would not like the politically correct to entrust me to censorship too, as you want to do with my Greek colleague, who used somewhat incisive terms to indicate not the Turkish people – I am convinced of this – but this aggressive and arrogant policy of a Turkey that blackmails Europe. And so, certain terms may be not fair or comprehensible but understandable.  I repeat: a blackmail that originally – the newspapers do not write it – was 20 billion, a sum that then the ability of those who have to defend us reduced to 6 billion, which will then become perhaps 10 or 12 billion. But what did they do? We have to go and check it out. They didn't help. The landings continued. And how does the Turkish regime use the money that the European taxpayer gives it? It uses them to keep poor refugees in subhuman conditions, as amnesty international has denounced, in conditions not of poverty but of poor sanitary conditions, etc. A disgrace to Europe! This is what someone who has always spoken out against immigration says: but faced with such a solution, even those who are opposed to immigration on principle – because they see it as a challenge to our identity – must agree that there is only to be ashamed! Surely the founding fathers of Europe would be ashamed to see such a commodity. It's a disgrace!

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). Mr President, the conclusions of the summit as a whole are a challenge for the people, welcoming the barbarity of thousands trapped in Greece, rewarding border sealing and deportations. White make it black. The refugees hunted by the fire of the imperialist war that you, the European Union, NATO and your competitors have turned on are considered irregular immigrants. Who is a refugee is arbitrarily judged in the cynical Alisverisi European Union - Turkey with the fervent support of the Greek government. NATO, which does not recognise borders in the Aegean, is becoming a gendarme. Turkey's bourgeoisie, which systematically contests borders and sovereign rights, which exacerbates its aggression in Syria, enjoys Euro-Nato backs, trade, subsidies and trade agreements.  The conclusion is effortless: Schengen, Dublin and all the mechanisms of repression are strengthened and the European Union and NATO are fully revealed as opponents of the peoples and associations of interests of monopolies. That's why popular struggle must put them and their exploitative system in the crosshairs.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems to me that there are four essential points in the treatment of this matter, in addition to the many things which have been said to be very interesting.  Firstly, there is one principle that we must not forget: this situation can only be tackled from a common action, and that puts the European Union in value more than ever.  Secondly, regional partnerships, such as Turkey or the Countries of North Africa, are essential in situations like these, as much as we have big differences. Good agreements have to be made, but the principle is that these regional alliances are essential – in this case, of course, with Turkey.  Thirdly, I think it is important to ensure mechanisms for aid for refugees to actually reach refugees and not to risk being part of them along the way.  Fourthly, an issue which I believe is linked to this further: more than ever, the strengthening of the European economy is essential because it is a factor in dealing with the situation of uncertainty, the crossroads and the challenges we face and which will help a great deal to make this possible.  In this context, strengthening the internal market is essential, but also the free movement of people, because it is not only the free movement of goods and services. Without the free movement of people, the single market will be 'lame', it will have a significant shortcoming. The Commission's roadmap must therefore be supported so that the Schengen area is fully operational by the end of 2016.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, this time we really need to think big if we want to avert the risk of a political, geostrategic and moral failure of the European Union. We need to organise safe corridors from the origin and transit countries for refugees. This is for sure, but most of all we need to build up the means to regain control of the situation with our own response. I believe this implies the building of a real European border to protect Schengen. I am not speaking about a wire wall. I am speaking about advanced infrastructure providing useful services of border control, making sure that refugees are received with decent standards and organising relocation across Europe, and then integration. This is the priority for us if we want to regain control of the situation. This should be organised as a big strategic investment for the sake of Europe. We are dealing with the vital interests of Europe, and these investments can create many new jobs for Europeans. That is why I see a connection between dealing with this refugee crisis and addressing solutions for a stronger recovery in Europe. I count on the Dutch presidency and the Commission to come up with more ambitious solutions for the next European Council.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: – Just as Doctor Faustus once sold his soul, so Europe is now giving itself away to Turkey!  With a lot of aggression and violence, the Turkish government took over the zaman newspaper last week. And that wasn't surprising, because Erdogan's regime has been at the top of the world for years when it comes to: where are most journalists imprisoned?  What was surprising was that two days later, our heads of government surrendered themselves to Turkey. What was not successful at the siege of Vienna in 1683, the Turks were now off the hook! Erdogan packed Europe and got more money and visa-free travel. Accession to the EU seems imminent. Freedom of the press, minority rights, religious freedom, all of this is at stake in Turkey. Europe should not give itself away as Dr Faustus. Stop the deal with the Sultan of Turkey and stop Turkish accession!  (The speaker shall respond to a "blue card" question in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Blue card question. I would like to know from my colleague what he would do if he had the opportunity to decide at the next meeting at European level, what main action would he take to counter what he said just now?

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" answer. – At least three things must be done.  1. There should be no link between this package and Turkish accession. Both cases are completely unrelated.  2. We are now going to give away a huge amount of money to Turkey, but where is that money going? How is it checked that it is well spent? I would much prefer that we, as Europe in Turkey, build these reception locations ourselves and arrange everything there to prevent the money from disappearing into the pockets of some Turkish government official. 3. We must show solidarity with Greece, ensure that Greece is now helped to make these hotspots operational and to ensure proper reception and registration of refugees there.  Those are the three points.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Mr President, a Member said a few minutes ago that she wants to feel confident and that Europe has been building from one crisis to another. I can't feel any confidence right now.  The anticipation of the massive and immediate deportation of all new Syrian refugees to Turkey seems to me to be a historic mistake which we are watching in this Parliament impotently. Governments have de facto destroyed respect for the value of solidarity that unersies us to Europeans; they believe to protect our states, but they do not: their panic and neglect in this globalized world certifies poverty for a more insecure future for us too, because we cannot be left out of the great problems of our planet.  We are told that this agreement will eliminate incentives to cross the sea irregularly, but we will return people who have the right to exercise a request for asylum without allowing them to apply, after months of promises and false words.  It is that, in this dark time, our countries have not fulfilled the previous commitments of relocation, financing and that is that, when it comes to even making the commitment to Turkey – indecent commitment – they will surely not provide the funds either.  We cannot continue to trust you or the Council, or almost, or less, the Commission. Please react!

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, gentlemen of the Council, you are investing excessive expectations in the oriental bargain with the anti-democratic Erdogan regime, because you, the twenty-eight governments, are proving incapable of implementing your own decisions, the decisions you took in September on a European solution to the refugee crisis, in line with what the Commission has proposed and agreed and pushed for the European Parliament to implement. So my country, Greece, is in danger of becoming a huge refugee camp with its northern borders closed and with the drama of Idomeni, which is a disgrace to Europe.  We must all realise that there is no European solution to the refugee crisis without Greece and much more against Greece. The European Balkan corridor must now be opened up to refugees and not in time, as you told us. The Visegrad countries, which violate the common European decisions, must be penalised in accordance with Article 7 of the European Treaty. Greece is an integral member of the Schengen Treaty and guards European borders, so more European solidarity is needed, not punishment. We Greeks are tired of hearing words and friendly blows to the back. We finally want practical solidarity and action, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Most of it has already been said, and I can see that there is considerable criticism in this House, both from my Green colleagues and from the vast majority of others. I hope that the Commission and the Council will take this criticism on board.  I wonder how you really think. You are selling out our European core values and you are proposing that we violate the Geneva Convention in exchange for a trade in refugees. We're swapping Syrians for Syrians. It's absurd.  I want to know which Syrians are to be sent back, and why, and who should be brought here. I want to know how to examine asylum cases, without violating the right of asylum, and who decides a case. I want to know how to uphold the right of asylum for all other nationalities, and I have many questions that I think you do not have answers to.  This is a bad proposal, which I hope falls on its own absurdity. We must take joint responsibility in Europe. We should not barter with neighbouring countries. Turkey is also not a safe country to send refugees back to.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: – In your European Union ideology, the ideology of the majority here in the European Parliament, the ideology of the humanitarian problem, the mere refugee problem - which has nothing to do with material matters, nothing to do with legal immigration, nothing to do with the rush for our prosperity - in that ideological scheme you have now started and concluded negotiations with the Turks and you have established a link between that value pattern by , first, to immediately issue issues such as two time-honoured political demands of the Turks, the visas for 80 million Turks, and to usher in a new chapter for the accession negotiations. You have also established a link of that value pattern with follow the money, money! Three billion, then six billion! Even the leader of the Liberal Group here used the term outsourcing, a term from the business world. So you have mutilated your values and dragged them into the dark caves of the blackmail of political politicis, brutal power and dirty business. Your open borders policy is becoming a nightmare for the People of Europe who are left with nothing but deep anger and great fear, a great fear that we represent here. This is not a European Union, this is a European non-Union. We are here to give that anger and fear a voice. We are the new European patriots after the word of Martin Luther. Here we are, we have no choice.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in 2015 more than a million people arrived in Europe and more than 3 700 people died in Mediterranean waters, from the Straits of Gibraltar to the Aegean Sea. Unfortunately, in the face of this phenomenon, politics always appears to be a step backwards in terms of the rapid evolution of migratory flows and the events that have caused them and which unfortunately continue to provoke them.  We are talking here today about an agreement which, let us face it, we do not like. We do not yet know it in detail, we will know it after the Council of 17-18 March, but we do not like it. It is also clear from what has been said today: there are many different doubts among the 28 States. The sad feeling is that we are now faced with an obligatory step given the emergency and we have to admit that someone or something has made a mistake. Because we have known a different Turkey. There was a Turkey that was truly a country committed to modernisation. Today we are at the negotiating table in a different country, and I believe that we have also made some mistakes. But let me say something that I am really sorry about, even as an Italian. Because, for some time now, we have been talking exclusively about the Aegean Sea. The agreement between Frontex and NATO to patrol the Aegean Sea is a good one; well ships coming from Britain. But why is there no more talk of the central Mediterranean and the routes from Tunisia and Libya? In Libya we know that ISIS is there and we know that the revenue of traffickers is one of the greatest income of these terrorists.  Well, I believe that we really must get away from the logic of emergency response and the logic of a short-term policy. We need to recover the capacity for a common long-term vision. Only in this way, I am convinced, will we be able to close an agreement that does not look like a surrender.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), blue card question. Thank you, Mrs Gardini, for accepting my question. I wanted to ask you: If the Greeks, who are affected by these unacceptable concessions made yesterday by the European Union, react forcefully, what do you think the attitude of the European Union will be? Perhaps you will tell me that this is a naïve question, because the answer is that it will do nothing. Do you think something can be done about this?

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Answer to a blue card question. Look, maybe I didn't quite understand your question. But I repeat what I said, which I think is the heart of the answer. We must find a capacity to be Europe. The Member States must get out of nationalistic logic, because we cannot have an answer that has effective results, in the face of a phenomenon and the many phenomena that we are facing.  I don't know if I answered her! In any case, we can continue privately.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the We are talking about very complex contexts, and they do not allow for simple answers or definitive answers. Yes, it is necessary for us to talk to Turkey. She is our neighbour - a very important neighbour. Neighbours cannot be chosen, but it is wise to have a good relationship with neighbours: respect, honesty and reliability are required.  But many questions remain unanswered: what about the rule of law in Turkey? How serious is their fight against organised crime and corruption? What about respect for human rights, freedom of the press, freedom of expression, and is our neighbour prepared to end the war in our own country and resolve the Kurdish question peacefully? We will not only get satisfactory answers. Yes, we must cooperate with our neighbours, including in the interests of Greece, which is otherwise facing a humanitarian catastrophe. But this must be in line with international law, and that must certainly not be naive.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: – The deal with Turkey is a suicidal bad deal. We lie to them that we will accept them into the European Union, they lie to us about stopping immigrants. There is no chance that Erdogan's totalitarian regime will become part of Europe. Turkey is in Asia, not Europe. Islam is not part of European culture, from the European continent. As a journalist, I ask: why did none of the European leaders say in Davutoglu's eyes that the brutal attack on the Seman newspaper was a crime against humanity?  Sultan Erdogan's ghost roams Europe and other semi-tholitalitarian European countries such as Bulgaria and Hungary. The weak and helpless European Union has turned Erdogan from the creator of the problem Islamic State into our savior. Mrs Merkel's mistake will be costly, not just as money. Instead of protecting our external borders, we pay the robbers to protect us and encourage them to gass democracy.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: Mr President, like a majority of European citizens, I have never been in favour of Turkey's accession to the European Union. I also have a very bad view of the reckless rush with which the Union will allow all Turkish citizens who wish to return to its territory without a visa at the end of June without a visa. Moreover, I have no confidence in Mr Erdogan, whose megalomania, bad faith and brutality are unbearable. As you will understand, I do not like the draft agreement with Turkey, which is on the table and which I believe will face considerable legal difficulties. But in the current circumstances and for want of better in the immediate future, I resolve to do so, even if the price to pay seems excessive and that Turkey has behaved more as a blackmailer than as a loyal partner. I do it because I am convinced of two things. Firstly, the European Union is already shaken, it risks sinking if, this year and next, one or two million more refugee applicants land, in the greatest disorder, on the shores of the Greek islands and seek to make their way through barbed-wire borders. Secondly, we have no right to turn Greece into a gigantic Calais jungle, where tens if not hundreds of thousands of migrants will vegetate for years in the worst of conditions.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to recall a few words that President Tusk recently said to the fugitives. He said it on 3 March "don't come Europe" It's all for nothing"!, as if they had a choice when they run away. Yesterday he said: 'The days of irregular migration to Europe are over'. It's false, and Tusk knows it. 91% of arrivals in Greece flee wars and you reject them all in Turkey, calling them irregular migrants.  You are accused of illegality, refoulement by the UN High Commissioner, the Council of Europe, Amnesty International... Give Erdogan everything, twice as much as promised: silence on the massacres in Kurdistan and the attack on the media, as well as a protected area in Syria that Erdogan will use to strike the Kurds, saving Al-Nusra.  And what are you going to get? The fugitives will take more lethal routes and you will be dishonored. I call this appeasement.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Madam Minister, it must be a strange sensation for you. You're sitting there now, in the past you've been here. And I think that if you had been sitting here, you would have clapped hard for the speech of Guy Verhofstadt, who expressed shame at the European Council's plan and predicted that we would see other smuggling routes where refugees would be at great risk.  That was your political leader. Now you have a new political leader, Mark Rutte, the Dutch Prime Minister. And Mark Rutte is tame all over the place that the influx of refugees has to go to zero, to zero!  Now I want to ask you, Madam Minister. Do you want to organise security for refugees or stop them?  And then another question: Turkey can get a trade for Syrians: we send one back, they can put one on a flight. Doesn't this actually lead to extra people on boats to get extra people on planes?

name: Herbert REUL
text: - Herbert Reul (PPE). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very high-key one. A preliminary remark: I have no catching up to do with criticism of violations of the rule of law or human rights violations in Turkey, and I have been and remain opposed to Turkey's accession to the European Union. Nevertheless, I find this debate today appalling, and I say that. Because since we have been discussing the refugee issue, I have heard a wide variety of complaints here, but only complaints about what is going wrong. We were right to discuss Hungary and the fences, and I think we were right to criticise when we waved through or blocked in Austria. Some criticize Merkel's overly humane policies. In any case, there is always a rumbling, and today the vast majority of speakers have even criticised it, although I believe that this model, which is now before us, could, for the first time, be a solution that goes a little further, ensures that refugees have secure access, that we have a limit in Europe to those who are really persecuted. That is what we always wanted, and we have always said that. We may also be well on the way to finally getting the smugglers, the smugglers, under control, at least from them a bit of demand. It won't be perfect, there's no hundred percent solution. But if this works as it is now prepared, then there can be a real breakthrough, a step forward, on the refugee issue. This is a great opportunity; I would like to use them. And I would like to thank those in the Council and the Commission who have worked on it. Rumbling, which is not possible, is relatively easy, but let's finally take a step forward! This Council, too, has finally brought common ground. We have criticised the fact that there are only egotists sitting around who cannot agree. And now they have come to an agreement. The number isn't perfect, it's not even finished yet! With regard to visa freedoms, I also have a few questions. But for me, this is more hope, more opportunity, and I would like to say to the Council and the Commission and to those who work there: please, please, continue to work properly! Incidentally, not only to the Council and the representative of the Presidency, but also to Mr Hahn personally: what has the man invested in time to make a little further progress with Turkey? We could also say: keep going! We are taking another good step – finally another good step. That is why I am an optimist, despite all the problems I see with Turkey, and that remains the case! But you can do one thing and you don't have to leave the other. (The speaker agreed to answer two questions under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – This agreement with Turkey has, in my opinion, good parts and some parts that are not very good. We are going to pay EUR 6 billion in EU taxpayers’ money, and probably the smugglers and all the others are going to find other ways and means to bring migrants into Europe. Do you not think that in the end, at the twelfth hour, the European Union might need a special European court to defend, guard and monitor EU external borders?

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you have indicated that you are satisfied with what the Commission is doing. I bring before you a recent survey in which 52% of Europeans do not understand the policy of the European institutions. What do you think the road is and what is the understanding you have been talking about here?

name: Herbert REUL
text: Answer to two questions about the "blue card" procedure. Firstly, I think that is progress. I didn't say it was perfect. Secondly, progress lies in the fact, firstly, that it is limited, secondly, for refugees who want to have access, that it is also organised, and thirdly, that the people smugglers are deprived of demand and that more people do not have to get on board and risk their lives – that is progress! This is not perfect, but it is progress. We do not need special dishes, I do not think of them at all. The paths that have been tried so far in Europe – closing borders, pulling up fences – have definitely been a huge nonsense, and this is better. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Reul says that it is not perfect. Nothing is perfect, but suggesting that we do business with a leader of a country who talks favourably about Adolf Hitler’s form of government and the structure of it? We do not have perfection, but surely you should have higher standards than dealing with – I reluctantly say – a man like that?

name: Herbert REUL
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Believe me that this also bothers me. But sometimes you have to find ways. Should we carry on as before: let refugees be resusated, put on boats and have no solution just so that we are morally right?  No, our job is to help concretely, and sometimes you have to make your fist in your pocket.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Mr Reul, I agree with you on what you have just said. For the first time, Too, I hope that when the conductor Tusk raises the baton, 28 musicians will not start playing their favourite piece. But now it's about what kind of play they should play – because something is not enough for us. I say to you: Mr Verhofstadt and others are, of course, right in their criticism, but we must also show a little pragmatism. I see common approaches with Turkey. But I also hope that the outstanding issues will be resolved soon and that we will get better information. This includes: what is the actual content of this action plan? Who actually gets money for what? How do we ensure that the individual examination is not undermined in the asylum procedure? It is necessary that, in the context of the Turkey report, we make a clear statement on the critical media and that we state clearly that we expect the government to return the confiscated facilities to its owners without delay. We must not abandon those people in Turkey who are hoping for us and who are counting on further development towards greater freedom.  That is why I agree with the opening of further chapters. But if Chapter 23, 24 is not included, you will not get my support for your work.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the When I think back to this Turkey summit, I think of the following quote: 'If someone agrees to a matter in principle, he has no intention of making any concrete changes'. And I think that's exactly how we have to see it. It is to be feared that this alleged agreement contains no details at all precisely for this reason. In other words, we do not know what exactly is to come. However, this great crisis finally requires that we become concrete. We do not just need individual mosaic blocks, but we need an overall concept. An overall approach must include, in particular, how many refugees the EU states are prepared to take in. That is the key issue. Anyone who mudds around will never come to a sensible solution. And I think help is voluntary. That is why we must ask the EU states how much aid they want and can provide. Everything else is a sham world. I believe that the poor people fleeing their homeland deserve more than building a sham world. EU citizens are also entitled to clarity here. I sincerely ask you to do so: let us fight together for an overall package!

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Mr President, regarding the overall development of relations between the EU and Turkey, we should take Turkey not as a temporary, but rather as a strategic, reliable and long-term partner. In the process of cooperation our goal should be to convince our Turkish counterparts of our sincerity and unreserved support for the development of mutually beneficial cooperation. In our interconnected world, constantly threatened by multiple crises, the only way to survive is to maintain very close friendly relations and work together to counter the challenges.  The role of Turkey in resolving the refugee crisis is indispensable. To assure security in the region adjacent to the EU, strengthening cooperation with Turkey is of particular interest to us. From that point of view, it is not productive to concentrate our attention just on the promise, for now, of handing out money. We need to start implementing the EU-Turkey Joint Action Plan as soon as possible in order to decrease the pressure on European borders.  Finally, it is extremely important for us as Europeans to talk less and work out a unified position with Turkey as to how we respond to the challenges. Europe has to export security, otherwise we are in no time going to import insecurity.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, what happened at the Summit with Turkey and what will happen at the next European Council brings us to some of the darkest pages in European history. Faced with a humanitarian drama affecting millions of human beings, a drama in which the European Union has direct and indirect responsibilities in the face of millions of human beings fleeing war, hunger and extreme poverty, the European Union, supported by nato's war machine, responds with intimidation, humiliation, criminalisation and expulsion of immigrant refugees. Demonstrating a sleathing ethical and moral dimension, the European Union thus highlights the decrepit state in which it finds itself, fuelling a xenophobic, racist, intolerant, authoritarian and undemocratic agenda. If you look at history, you realize that there's a great risk of all this blowing up in your face one of these days, but maybe that's what some are thinking. These decisions will push hundreds of thousands of people to other, perhaps more dangerous crossing routes, foreseeing further tragedies in the Mediterranean. I don't know if they'll sleep peacefully at night or not. One thing is certain, these tragedies will have political leaders.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The so-called refugee crisis is indeed a crisis of European cohesion, European self-confidence and European humanity. The EU-Turkey Summit on 7 March did not bring about a change for the better in this crisis – it continues. This was demonstrated to us in this debate, for example, by Vice-President Dombrovskis, who had difficulty getting the issue to take up in the first place, and also by the representative of the Dutch Presidency, who refused to use the words 'refugee' and 'asylum' in the first place. She knows only irregular migrants. Language can be liberating, and it can do violence. Anyone who sees only the irregular migrants in the refugee will opt for the second option.  Everyone is saying 'common European solution' at the moment. After all, Mrs Merkel has achieved this. But it is a Europe that refuses to face its challenges, to bear its responsibilities, to lose its global power, and a Europe that loses its moral dignity as a result.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. As Vice-President Dombrovskis said, we make political decisions and the consequences of our political decisions are appreciated by our voters. That's all right. It is important to know what our constituents think about the issues. We are living in an age of successe crises: economic crisis, demographic crisis, 4.5 million unemployed under the age of 25 in the European Union, and the migrant crisis. I think that there are good examples, things that have been solved, managed well – such as the economic crisis. When I think of the next subject of the Council, the European Semester, I think that this is a good tool for getting a look at the state of the countries. And I am proud that Hungary from the extremely difficult, near-bankruptcy situation of 2010 to the fact that it is performing well economically, that our macroeconomic indicators are sustainable, that we can show growth. Moreover, in connection with Women's Day, I can say that the pay gap between men and women has decreased the most in Hungary. Then we get to the migration issue, the migrant crisis. I think that the agreement that was reached on Monday is not a perfect agreement. But I agree with Congressman Reul, we do not have to complain, we have to find a solution. Steps must be taken towards a solution. These are strengthening border protection, such as closing borders, as Leader Weber said, with fences if necessary. But there are still open questions. Such an open question is what we need to talk about, how we think about visa liberalisation for Turkey. Why aren't we talking about Ukraine? How do we think of a one-on-one exchange? What do we think of the three billion with which we value Turkey's efforts? And that's going to be six billion, then ten billion. Where is the guarantee, Commissioner Hahn, that we will use this resource well, that this resource will be targeted? It is not a short-sighted solution, but a common solution. In order to achieve this common solution, I think we have taken a good step forward. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I want to underline that the blue card is only for a question, because many Members utilise the blue card for a speech. The blue card comes after the speech and not before.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Blue card question. – (The first part of the opposition was not recorded due to a technical problem.) ... Mr President, the preliminary warning, while I suppose you did not know exactly what question I wanted to ask. But I am obliged to ask the Vice-President of the European Parliament, who is also vice-president of Prime Minister Orban's party. Prime Minister Orban went to the European Council with the exclamation that we should not make Europe out of Hungary! What does this sentence mean in the light of Monday's agreement, which you have now welcomed here? How can we not make Europe out of Hungary? Should we follow Erdoğan or Putin's system?

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Blue card answer. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Mr President, he warned you because you had no idea what I was going to talk about, and you had already raised your blue card. It's only right that you know what I'm talking about and then put up the blue card. He asked me a question he would like to ask the Prime Minister - but he clearly cannot do it. I think Monday's summit is finally a good step in a common direction. I think the detention, closure, protection of borders, the protection of Europe is a good step in the right direction. I think that instead of irresponsible statements, the common path is the way forward. Hungary the hungarian government and you have an interest in protecting the hungarian government. And what I was talking about, Congressman, is before 2010. That's how we got here. I would never want to see you again in Hungary, the time that you did before 2010.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Mr President first, to state the obvious, the EU and Turkey need each other in order to find a joint solution for the refugee crisis. This does not mean stopping the flow, but managing it in such a way that people in need of protection can get it, economic migrants are returned and the burden is shared fairly. The recent agreement does not provide an adequate answer to the humanitarian crisis we are facing. How can the leaders of 28 European countries come up with a plan whereby legal routes for refugees are provided only if other refugees continue to risk their lives via human smugglers? Not only does this go against international law, it is also morally very wrong.  The EU has put itself in a very weak position by maintaining a one-dimensional dialogue with Ankara only based on the number of people arriving on a daily basis on the Greek islands. Migration first; human rights will come later. This is a very dangerous strategy at a moment of a major crackdown on press freedom and rule of law in Turkey and at a time the 355 000 Kurdish citizens of Turkey had to flee their houses because of the violence that re-erupted in the south-east of the country. The EU cannot continue to look the other way.  My plea to the Council is to start with large-scale resettlement for the most vulnerable refugees. This will also be a genuine burden sharing with the Turkish people, who have showed great hospitality during the past five years.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Contrary to diplomatic enunciations, the last European Union-Turkey summit in Brussels ended in a spectacular defeat for the European Union, which gives Turkey a nose-to-nose. While European Council President Donald Tusk is trying to swear by reality with the words: "The days of illegal emigration to Europe are over", and The Head of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker says that the summit was a success, saying: "This is a real revolution!", the European Union has died. The Union is not sure of anything: it is asking Turkey, and this one, with eu leaders, is raising the stakes. The last summit thus turned out to be an ordinary Turkish bazaar, where billions of euros were traded, migration policy, visa policy and membership of the Union. Finally, Turkey gets what it wants, and the Union, backed by a wall, must agree. Today, the Dutch Minister, speaking on behalf of the Presidency, is talking about speeding up the one-for-one exchange. That is why I have a question: Minister, please tell me how many more migrants will enter the European Union as a result of this exchange?

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: – We are in a situation where the issue of refugees, asylum seekers or migrants and their pain and suffering is no longer just a question of our moral commitment to the values of compassion or mercy – I believe that we all feel it here – but a test of our ability and the political responsibility of a united Europe to be fully in solidarity and effective in its rule. If we ignore our blame for the tragedy of the Middle East at this time, it must be seen that turkey has the keys to resolving the acute crisis. We cannot, of course, come to terms with the growing authoritarianism of the Erdogan regime, the imprisonment of journalists and the media, the violation of human rights. Nevertheless, we must – perhaps with our teeth pressed – recognise that we need Turkey as a partner today and in the future. It is not a cow deal, as some colleagues say, but about the real interests of Europe and an important country that is primarily asserting its own interests at the moment. Perhaps it would have been easier if the European Union had already really cleared its relationship with Turkey and its European future. The refugee crisis is not the best reason for this.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Mr President, the European Union-Turkey agreement, for Turkey to act as Europe's wall, is to put human rights up for sale. For 6 billion euros we sell to people. How much is each worth? Thousand? Two thousand? Three thousand euros? What's the price? This agreement condemns refugees and migrants to survive in a black hole. Nobody knows what's going to happen to these people. We pay and forget. They can have them in camps in inhumane conditions, return them to war, or hunger, or do as they see fit. We pay the bill and Turkey takes care of the dirty work. However, Turkey will border in exchange for the European Union looking the other way when the Kurdish people are massacred or in the face of a lack of freedom and repression in Turkey. This agreement forever burys the Geneva Convention. You cannot catch people from Syria, Afghanistan or Sudan and return them to Turkey. That's illegal. This agreement is contrary to international human rights standards, and I hope that those who sign it will one day be judged.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, let me start with migration and Turkey. I believe and I agree with the Presidency that only a European plan that will be realised by all participants will bring us closer to a solution. I agree also that negotiations with Turkey are a very important part of the plan. This has many limitations, for example as mentioned by our Chair, Mr Weber, but it is very important. We must be very sensitive to our values. I am surprised at the discussion about money. The money that we should give to the refugees in Turkey is important and is justified if it is distributed properly. We should not forget that our agreement with Turkey is only part of the plan as, most likely, with the closing of the Balkan route, the other routes will be used more frequently and we must be ready for that. Secondly, let me talk a little bit about the economy as was mentioned by Commission Vice-President Dombrovskis. I guess that the situation in the global economy is very important, and obviously we must be concerned at what is going on, concerned at the situation in China, but what is the most important for the huge and the rich economy of the European Union – the economy of the part of the world that is close by – is the domestic situation , the stability of domestic demand and investment. This is the only way of assuring our main priority, and growth and jobs. That means providing that the economy will be competitive. That is why respecting the rules, those included in the European Semester too, is a key priority, and the Commission has my full support in implementing them. Last but not least, let me mention one issue that is not on the agenda. This is the situation in eastern Ukraine, where the situation is getting more dangerous. Fighting is going on, people’s lives are under threat and this is a zone of instability just close to the European Union. We should be reflecting that more in our policy and not expect that we can normalise the situation with Russia, because Russia is a very important part of this problem.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr President, there is no shortage of qualifiers for commenting on this EU-Turkey summit. For the more moderate, he gave birth to a mouse. For many others, it is, on the contrary, the height of shame. I'm one of the runners-up. Since the next European Council on 17 and 18 March will decide, we must face the impact of the guidelines resulting from Monday's discussions. I can only talk about a few of them. The effects of the closure of the Balkan route, first of all: the Member States are miscalcating here, because, in one movement, Greece is being put on an infusion, but at the same time it is asphyxiated. Explain to me how we can proclaim the Schengen bailout, while endorsing unilateral decisions to close borders in and around the Union. Cooperation with Turkey, then: it is certainly an essential partner in the region, and cooperation between the EU and that country is necessary, but if solutions are to be sought elsewhere, they should also and above all be found within the Union. In this case, we are not only complying with the requirements of this partner, but we are outsourcing the management of the crisis, with an increase in auctions. Member States are clearing themselves of their responsibilities, the principle of solidarity and, ultimately, their principles. This is evidenced by the principle modestly entitled 'resettlement of Syrians in the EU, on a one-for-one basis'. This undignified barter in fact that a Syrian must risk drowning in order for another Syrian to enter the Union. I never imagined that the demand for legal avenues would take this sordid form. The legality of such a scheme and its applicability also remain to be demonstrated. In the quest for an agreement at all costs, the EU is losing itself in the name of realpolitik, Member States seem ready to sit on a number of principles and turn a blind eye to the power in place in Turkey, its control over the media, the imprisonment of academics and threats to the judicial system. In the end, the results of this summit show that, under the guise of joint decisions, the very idea of a united and responsible Europe is likely to be defeated.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mrs Merkel was indeed right: there is a european solution in sight. But not the one that the German Chancellor had in mind. The EU has ended the policy of wavering. Many countries have simply created facts, thereby making it clear that Germany is isolated with its attitude.  For example, Angela Merkel, who single-handedly opened the borders in September last year, says that she disapproves of Austria's single-handedness. Austria, however, has at least agreed with the countries in the region that are also affected. Now Turkey is to take on the task that Angela Merkel is afraid of: to protect the borders. It is astonishing that we are making ourselves dependent and extortionate on a country that is not so precise with democracy or women's rights, which sets new standards in freedom of the press, and that accession negotiations are even being resumed with that country. Germany, which is so fond of patronising the other countries, now seems to want to ignore Turkey's internal problems.  The question then arises: are it only German or European values that are sacrificed here in order to encourage others to take actions that one shies away from? In any case, the EU has no future.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: Mr President, when he arrived at the European Council, the Turkish Prime Minister might have expected to meet the Government of Europe. It is in fact in the middle of a big bazaar that it landed. Our heads of state or government, unable to decide, have mastered the art of haggling. After the blackmail of David Cameron, who asks that his country set foot outside the Union, here we are facing the blackmail of the Turks, who intend to put a foot in it. Our leaders spend a lot of energy tinkering with occasional answers. But for what result? The European Coast Guard and Border Guard Corps and the centralisation of asylum processing have yet to be established. There is no real development policy that conditions readmission to third countries. The Europeans do not have the beginning of a credible foreign policy to end the conflict in Syria. Three billion for Turkey. How much for Lebanon and Jordan, and tomorrow for the reconstruction of Syria? I'm ashamed of this Europe. I am ashamed of the show of helplessness we give to our fellow citizens. I still want to believe in the start for Europe to regain its place in history. Yes, the next Council is a historic meeting.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that today, at this very moment when we are talking here, the new President of the Portuguese Republic has just taken office and that he has made a clear intervention in the sense of protecting the values which I think we must protect here on this issue of refugees, which are the humanitarian values and identity values of Europe.  This means, first of all, that we have to make a huge humanitarian welcome, we have to give great support to Greece. I am very pleased to see that in this Council, finally, funds have been set aside so that Greece can deal with the situation in which it is and I also think it is very important, on the one hand, the NATO response, which is a response, say, of emergency to ensure border control, but it is even more important that in the Council of 17 and 18 March we can , finally, start with a European police force for control of the coast and borders.  This is the first step towards European security and European defence. I would like to remind you that in the last survey of the Bertelsmann Foundation, it is said that 79 % of Europeans are in favour of setting up a European border and coast police force and advocating a common policy on immigration and asylum, not a national policy and not a shared policy, a common policy in Europe, and that they advocate the redistribution of refugees across the 28 countries and not just for a , by two or three. There are majorities of 70 and 80 % across Europe and, even in those countries that are more reticent, such as the Visegrad countries, this survey says that the majority is around 55 %, 60 %. So with this support from european public opinion, I think that the next European Council has no reason not to take a big step forward in defence of our values, more security and more humanity.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this divided and therefore weak Europe is negotiating with Turkey under too subordinate conditions. We need an agreement to stem the flood of refugees, but the problems in our house remain. Let us not delude ourselves that an external solution frees us from our responsibilities of reception and relocation.  The pre-agreement seems to us to be very, very critical and with too many ambiguities. Firstly, the idea of restarting asylum applications from Turkey's camps – and I say this to the Commission and the Council, from which I would like to pay a little attention – is acceptable only by ensuring that the procedure and choice are a matter for the European Union and with a role for international organisations.  Secondly, it must be very clear, dear representative of the Netherlands and the Presidency of the Council, that the agreement must not cover refugees who have already arrived in Europe. We will never be able to agree to return to Turkey the refugees who are already in Greece, after a hellish journey. It would be cruel and contrary to every human principle, as well as to all international conventions.  It would be like playing the children's goose: you go back to the starting box. We will not accept that.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Mr President, two comments on the summit. First, one positive. It is good that there is finally an effort to separate refugees from Syria from refugees from else, and that there is an effort to separate war refugees from purely economic ones, and that there is also an effort to finally do something to ensure that the millions of people who are already in Turkey, and three million people, do not go on their way to Europe. Having access to the labour market in Turkey is good news. It is quite clear that it will cost Europe something, but I think we need to do everything we can to ensure that these people stay where they are and that they do not go to Europe on a massive scale.  What is bad news is the effort to exchange here in some way one for one those refugees who are being relocated in Turkey for those who are already somewhere else. This is a return to a system of dysfunctional quotas, it is once again an attempt to violate the sovereignty of states, it is even a violation of the existing relocation agreements, which the European Union agreed on last September, and it is essentially just social engineering, hiding behind flashy words about solidarity and common solutions, and this is unacceptable.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We have a common European asylum and immigration policy and the relevant laws on it. The problem is that our Member States – many of the Member States – are unwilling to abide by the existing European law that they themselves have co-decided. They refuse to comply with international law, they simply ignore it. That is why we are in the situation with the refugees we are in now. In this situation, we are dependent on Turkey's offer to withhold, withdraw and exchange refugees. Is this a diabolical plan? Is this in line with international law? And what image will the European Union itself give, should this deal come about? A pathetic picture, definitely. But this pitiful picture has to be attributed to the Member States, which refuse to share a common policy of solidarity with refugees: first of all, to mention Austria today, which has triggered a whole cascade with its refusal to take in the vulnerable. This is a denial of international law. Of course, Turkey is asking for compensation, and that is quite clear. That is what we would do in such a situation. But what is another EUR 3 billion? That sounds a lot. But when you think about how much money has already gone to Greece, six billion euros are not against it. Six billion euros is nothing at all if we oppose the fact that we may also be able to bring all these refugees to us. Yes, it is not a nice solution to pay for keeping the refugees out of Europe. But obviously it is no different. The right-wing populists, who are also speaking the big word here in this House, have pushed many governments in the European Union so far. And the horrible thing is that they are already putting the government somewhere. It is the right, it is the extremes that are partly responsible for our Europe being in such a crisis that I am ashamed of it. It is the task of this Parliament to ensure that the deal that is being concluded with Turkey, which is obviously the only way out and which we need, is that it is in line with our values. We are responsible in the European Parliament. Without us no visa liberalisation, without us no accession of Turkey! Do not forget this: we too are responsible.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the How do we deal with refugees? Yes, there can also be safe places for refugees outside Europe. But Monday's result and the latest news reinforce the impression that Europe is closing in. The Balkan route will be closed, refugees will be sent back to Turkey in the Aegean Sea and, conversely, the resettlement of refugees from Turkey to Europe is completely open. European states make us blackmailable, and Turkey uses that. Why? Because national politicians are staring at right-wing parties, or even moving to the right, instead of showing a clear edge for democracy, for human rights, notwithstanding the large number of citizens who volunteer for refugees. The next summit must bring results for a humane refugee policy and for a European Union of freedom, democracy and respect for human rights!

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Mr. President, I can say that these days the news rang out positively in the media when we heard that the Balkan route was slowly closing because my country Croatia is also on that route. However, we must be aware that this is a major humanitarian catastrophe and that there is nothing to look forward to at this time. Also welcomed was the appeal of Donald Tusk, who told refugees or those who are about to become one: "Don't come to the European Union, don't trust criminals, don't trust smugglers." However, dear colleagues, dear colleagues, this is about men, women, children, this is not about numbers. So it is time to welcome this agreement, which I would not call trade, but this agreement has yet to be concreted at the next summit and at the next summits, and I hope that we will finally succeed in doing so.  However, we should not consider this agreement a bianco check because it is not a bianco check, since we know what is happening in Turkey. So negotiations should be separated for Turkey and entry into the European Union from this refugee crisis because if we don't separate that then we will accept all the bad that is happening in Turkey, and we are talking about jeopardizing freedoms, especially media freedoms. This is something we have to appeal to here today and I believe that will be our condition for Turkey.  I agree to legalise migration in such a way that an additional 3 billion, so now we are talking about 6 billion funds of all European countries, give to help Turkey, to help all refugees or those who intend to become one. I think if it was just regular and legal, everything else would be bad. So we have to go back to the external borders of the Union, we have to strengthen control, and in that I fully support what the heads of state have done and I hope that we are going in that direction, that we finally have a concrete solution. Anything else would be bad. Likewise, when it comes to Greece, I think we need to help Greece because Greece cannot become a cage. We need to help her get rid of the problems that have happened to her because of her geopolitical or geographical location.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D). Mr President, Europe's inability to deal effectively with the refugee crisis, for which European countries and Turkey also have a responsibility, is evident. It is obvious and devastating that Europe is being blackmailed by Mr Erdogan's policies. This is where a cheap oriental bazaar of the worst form develops, where everything is sacrificed on the altar of purpose, and all this arises, because Europe unfortunately does not operate on the basis of the principles and values on which it was built, but on the basis of interests. Community solidarity has long gone for a long time and only the national interest works. Fences are standing and hundreds of innocent souls are still lost at sea, instead of working together to tackle the problem as in a family. To do this, political unification must go ahead. The Union is in danger of disintegration and this has allowed eurosceptics within the walls to feel vindicated. We must decide immediately that any refugees who cross land legal routes will be admitted in order to deal with the inhumane phenomenon of trafficking by sea with the sad results.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE). Mr President, the refugee issue is not only a European problem, it is also an international problem and it certainly needs a European solution but also an international solution based on the decisions of the United Nations. We understood the crisis with time deprivation. He found us unprepared. That is why we need more Europe, a better Europe, a deepening of our democratic institutions, political and economic integration.  The agreement with Turkey is important. But we don't give a blank cheque. The agreement with Turkey cannot be the subject of an oriental bazaar. Turkey needs a partnership in all areas and not a relationship of dependence on Turkey. The solution must be given by us. Many colleagues have referred to European borders. However, the Law of the Sea does not refer to the conclusions and the Law of the Sea is what all the countries of the European Union have ratified and, since 1982, since the decisions of the United Nations only Turkey has not ratified the Law of the Sea.  We also need to return to the Schengen rules. What about the Visegrad countries? They do not follow the European acquis. They refuse to apply international law. There needs to be aid and an emergency within the European Union, a very positive decision of political solidarity in the countries of the European Union and especially in the South and Greece.  But in the Western Balkans, the situation in Idomeni does not honour the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, we await the decisions of the European Council on 17 and 18 March. The devil is hiding in the details, as Mrs. Merkel and Mr Juncker.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: – Mr President, a week ago we were listening to the President of the Council, Mr Tusk, to warn migrants not to come to Europe. Our guts were stirring and today we understand the content of these threats.
