The inability, for months, to manage the refugee crisis culminates in a principle of agreement that violates human rights, treats people as goods and uses Turkey as a great wall of contention; we wash our consciences with billions of euros. We have seen cruel images: children dying on our beaches, women attacked by tear gas, parents who lose their children on the journey; a real human drama. And what is the solution of the heads of state? Return them to Turkey. What a pity and shame! We're on time. This Parliament today has shown with many voices that it is possible to change this decision. Please think of people and think about giving Europe back the little dignity you have left today.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, listening to the debate, I am somewhat bemused because I am thinking that if the European Union did not exist, what would be happening regarding the migrants? Would individual countries be trying to do a deal with Turkey? Would the United Nations, for all its talk, be offering EUR 6 billion to Turkey? Would the situation be better or worse? I think the answer is worse. So at least the European Union deserves credit for trying to solve a problem that is not of its making. We have our sense of values. We want to offer support and succour to those from other areas who are worse off than ourselves.  People have spoken about the one for one and criticised it, but at least it is an effort to try and solve the situation. One for one is not like for like. It is legal rather than illegal. It is regular rather than irregular. It is safe rather than dangerous, and I think that must be taken into consideration. 17 March, incidentally, is the Irish national holiday, St Patrick’s Day. He himself was a migrant or a slave coming from Wales to Ireland. He might inspire the leaders on that day to come up with a good solution.  That brings me to the necessity of our borders being rendered safe and controlled, because we cannot have free movement within the European Union unless our borders, in wartime or peace time, are fully controlled and I welcome this move. We also have to look at the question of quotas. If Member States say that there is a maximum number they can or will take in, then that is going to dictate what we can actually do. We have to be practical, we want to help but I think at least we are moving in the right direction and, without the European Union, where would this crisis be? That is a question we have to ask ourselves.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Mr President, the answer we expect from the Heads of State or Government on 17 and 18 March is not to tell us that the future of the European Union depends on Turkey. They have to take responsibility, and they're screaming. No one can think that the influx of refugees will be solved solely by their return to Turkey. If the proof had not been made so far, I believe that the European Council, which took place on this subject, demonstrates this. The Spring European Council is the meeting, as Mr Dombrovskis has indicated, to check the state of the European economy. There is a bridge to be organised in order to loosen the stranglehold of austerity policies and to allow the European Union to borrow where it is necessary to both welcome refugees with dignity and give the means to the States, which need to support their people after years of austerity, to do so under the correct conditions. This European Council must solve an economic equation, but it must also be an opportunity for a call for solidarity, which implies a capacity to borrow to finance this solidarity.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). Mr President, I believe that this European Parliament, which represents the peoples, must speak clearly, without twists and turns and without incomprehensible theories and without ambiguities, both on the refugee issue and on Turkey. We must all admit that the refugee issue is not only a predominantly European issue, it is not only a matter for the Member States of the European Union, but it is an international issue, so the other countries, internationally, must also support and support the European Union in this effort to resolve it. As for the contractors of destruction and Euroscepticism who want and believe that the European Union can be enthused with the refugee crisis, I am convinced that Europe can also find solutions to this issue. For Turkey. What has Turkey done all the way to the refugee camp? Let me remind you that Turkey was part of the problem, because with its attitude and behaviour and policy in the region it created the refugee crisis. Let me remind you that the previous agreement to limit flows to Greece not only did not respect it, but also increased flows, and I would remind you now that a country that is acceding and even wants to speed up accession processes is behaving towards the European Union as a brute cynical blackmailer, putting the humanitarian issue forward and using it as a spear. , so that it can serve its own interests and get rewards.  I must remind you once again that there are rules in this European Union. Turkey cannot today call for the opening of funds in order to move forward with its accession process, when all countries know the principles, values and process that exists for accession to the European Union. The Council must not again agree to the opening of Turkey's capital if Turkey does not implement the agreements with the European Union, the Ankara Protocol and if it does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus. That must be the message to Turkey and it must respect it to the end.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Monday's EU-Turkey summit appears to provide a good basis for resolving the refugee crisis. However, the relevant decisions remained at the council meeting on 17-18 March and these will be difficult decisions. Greece must be helped, but the agreement with Turkey demands unacceptable compromises. Primarily because of a lack of political courage. Confront extremist, populist politicians and selfish Member States, which are constantly, knowingly and systematically blocking a common European asylum policy. They say the European Union is powerless when it is themselves. Who, for reasons of low political interest, do not accept any common solution. Yet there is no other way but to receive, to distribute asylum seekers in solidarity between Member States and to social inclusion. A common European system must be operated. The fate of the European Union cannot be a prisoner of xenophobic politics that promotes closure, builds fences.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, Monday’s summit was the best solution among poor options. The first thing is to get smuggler-controlled flows of migrants under control and to make sure who is who and also to neutralise the inhuman business of smugglers, who often cooperate with terrorists. But that is not enough. I encourage the Council to also concentrate on the establishment of safe areas in Syria. This was a welcome message presented by the Minister today – or, a hint, I would say. Secondly, the efficient protection of the EU’s external borders should not only remain a priority, but should be achieved in real terms. This is about money and cooperation. In the same way, I think we should prepare for the joint protection of the EU’s north-eastern borders. In fact there are millions of illegal residents in Russia, as the Finnish example has warned us. Russia could make an attempt to destabilise the EU from an unexpected direction. Thirdly, regarding the data protection package, the Minister’s predecessor promised it by December and fulfilled that promise. We expect no dragging of feet under the Dutch Presidency to formally finalise it. All practical implementation measures related to the implementation of the single digital market will be delayed over the summer if the Council will not take a decision. Even worse, this House – as we saw on Monday – is blocked in adopting the urgently needed PNR decision, because some Groups link it with finalising the data protection package. Please, Council, hurry up.

name: Iliana IOTOVA
text: S&D). – Council President Tusk announced on Monday an end to illegal immigration – more to reassure European citizens than to tell the truth. The agreement with Turkey will not stop people fleeing war and misery or restrict their entry into Europe. I don't know what you're going to decide at the next Council, but as we have these discussions, thousands of people have been holed up in the mud of Idomeni, and the countries of the so-called Islamic State have been killed. "Balkan Road" knocked on the doors in front of them. And is the Council not aware that the policy of extinguishing fires does not solve anything, because after Greece and the "Balkan Road" there will be other routes – Bulgaria, Albania.  How do you imagine this exchange as one for a Syrian, with what human factor, with what financial and administrative? What are the guarantees on the Turkish side to cross human trafficking to all European borders, once a parallel lucrative economy is developing in the country, in the eyes of the authorities, which does not restrict but stimulate sanitation. These are just some of the issues that are on the agenda for both the Commission and the Council, and we have been waiting for their answers for a long time.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: – This week we finally have better news from the migration front, as well as from the economic front, after many months of bad news, which aroused a sense of helplessness of the European institutions, weighed on their credibility, gave rise to populist movements. Indeed, the European Union's immigration policy has been the victim of ill-identified threats. Initially, they were located primarily on the eastern border, later the signals from the Mediterranean were ignored, when Malta and Lampedusa were alone, and a major industry of the 21st century was born and finally born. Finally, dormant vigilance as people from Syria gathered in camps in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan. So it is good that a common European response to the migration problem is finally born. This is a prerequisite for saving the Schengen area. It is good that difficult cooperation with Turkey is concrete (difficult – it has been said – but nevertheless necessary) and the rules on aid to Greece. And we have some chance of a political solution to the problems of Syria, where the source of the threats lies. Indeed, Tusk, as head of the European Council, said that the days of illegal emigration to Europe had come to an end. May he be right, because it was too expensive for all of us.

name: István UJHELYI
text: – The European structure, the institutional system of the European Union, is in crisis. And we've been arguing about a Monday summit for 3.5 hours, and I don't think any of us were there. It is possible that even the honourable Minister was not there and the Vice-President of the Commission was not there. Or, if they were there, they gave us information at the beginning that would not give us a judgement of what really happened at the EU summit. A lot of times you feel that it is better to read Politico, because you get more information from it than you get here in this Chamber. I demand that, President Tusk, that one of the Members of the Commission who took part in the debate be the next President of the Commission, like Mr Juncker himself, and that they report to us so that we can have a substantive debate. Because it is indeed true that every ominous remark about the Union now looking for a way out, its own future, is now in europe's greatest crisis since world war. That's why we should take each other seriously.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: – Mr President, I would like to say that I consider the absence of President Tusk and President Juncker to be truly regrettable in this debate. Unfortunately, just as many of us here think that Europe is abdicating its principles and responsibilities. The pre-agreement we have known in a bad way, certainly not because of the information that the Council has given to offer us, is of dubious legality, of dubious effectiveness and of dubious morality. Tell President Tusk that it is incredible that the mention of respect for people and human rights does not appear in this text once. How could they have forgotten that little detail? And my only interest in this House today is for the Council and the Commission and the Member States to hear that there are people here who do think of others and that we do tell European citizens that there is a different Europe than you are drawing in these European Councils.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Mr President, at a European Council with migration and priorities in terms of growth, employment and competitiveness as its central themes, it is essential not to miss the diagnosis and the diagnosis is very clear. It was not migration that triggered the European crisis, it was the political, economic and social anaemia of the European Union that transformed a problem that could be managed in solidarity into a serious identity crisis of the European project.  In the European Semester, the Commission sends recommendations to the Member States. These recommendations, especially for the countries that are most difficult, are paradoxical exercises and without internal coherence. On the one hand, it is well recommended to focus on education, vocational training, research, the rise of the value chain, the fight against macroeconomic imbalances, but on the other hand it requires blind cuts in the central functions of the State which are the necessary pillars for such reforms to be possible.  We need, Mr President, a new impetus of the European project, vision and leadership, of European leaders who, for once, are up to the challenge.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, my hope and wish is that the heads of an agreement reached by the European Council in Turkey will develop into a fully-operative agreement because I have not seen any better deal yet. However, beyond wishes one must also acknowledge realities. Turkey and the EU have different, asymmetric, and sometimes mutually—exclusive interests regarding the relationship between them over the refugee crisis and regarding the civil war in Syria.  This reality is being fudged through ambiguities, which is dangerous. Ambiguities become acute at the wrong moment in time and lead to collapse. The EU wants to control the flow of refugees to Europe and is prepared to provide funds for this to happen. It is in Turkey’s interest for refugees to leave. Turkey wants to see serious progress with its membership application to join the EU, yet a majority in the EU is against Turkish membership. I find myself in the minority on this one. Meanwhile, the EU has been critical of Turkey’s efforts to contain Kurdish separatism and of the growing authoritarianism of its government. The EU is divided; Turkey presents a united front. Tough as it is, perhaps eventually the best approach would be to call a spade a spade and to define a way forward that recognises the differences between the two sides.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, after six years of war in Syria, it has turned into the biggest humanitarian crisis since World War II. Likewise, the drama in the Middle East has caused very serious blockages in the functioning of the EU.  It is good that the talks between all involved have finally become very concrete, as they contain the most ambitious plan to date to deal with the migration crisis. I welcome some of its parts, in particular the prevention of abuse of human suffering and human smuggling. However, member states and those wishing to become members should not manipulate a humanitarian catastrophe due to particular interests. In this context, turkey's demands should be seen, where the human rights situation deteriorates on a daily basis and dramatically.  Regardless of the wording in the Council's conclusions, as of today, the so-called Balkan route has been officially closed, but people continue to arrive and remain blocked at the Macedonian-Greek border. States at the external borders remain under a lot of pressure. Plans to save Schengen must not be ignored by members who are not part of Schengen, but are already literally wired by razor blades from the rest of the EU.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, I would say to the Minister: another week, another summit, and yet we are no closer to solving the refugee crisis. A long-term strategy is way overdue. Instead of addressing the problems that Greece and other frontline States are facing with the inflows, we have outsourced the problem to Turkey. My real concern is the price we are paying not in euros, but in compromising our values for the sake of political expediency. What is worse is that we are turning a blind eye to the near-total crackdown on freedom of expression and the media by the Turkish authorities; and we cannot ignore the fact that the Turkish army is engaging in collective punishment of the local population in south-east Turkey.  A ceasefire between the PKK and the army needs to be put in place immediately. Offering visa-free travel and speeding up accession negotiations as bargaining chips will do irreparable damage to our credibility and clout on the world stage – the credibility that has allowed the EU to make huge strides in spreading stability and rule of law in our neighbourhood.

name: Giorgos GRAMMATIKAKIS
text: S&D). Mr President, the fine words that are contradicted by the actions have so far been displayed in the face of the refugee tragedy. It is clear that a satisfactory solution must also include a cooperative Turkey. But unlike Greece, which is honouring its commitments, Turkey has not implemented the existing agreement and is constantly making new demands in an oriental bargaining chip, except that this bazaar concerns souls and human rights. So how should Europe respond if it wants to remain united and in line with its fundamental values? It must first of all assume its own responsibilities towards refugees and disproportionately tested areas such as the Greek islands. Finally, it must insist that Turkey's cooperation on refugees is a prerequisite for accession and not, for God's sake, the key to opening the door to it. I want today to remember Jean-Paul Sartre's phrase: "If we cannot use our eyes to see, then we will need them to cry."

name: Soraya POST
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr "Today was a good day," Angela Merkel said yesterday about the negotiations with Erdoğan's regime. That is true in a European laughter mirror chamber. Yesterday was a good day for creamers at the Turkish bazaar. Yesterday was a good day for traffickers. One by one, it's called. If ten Syrian boat refugees are stopped in the Mediterranean and sent back to Turkey, ten Syrians will be sent from Turkey to Europe. But not the same people. It is a haggling and checkerof a slave market. It's dealing with people. It is to bargain with human rights.  It does not appear that Merkel's and Rutte's colleagues in the Council are buying their proposals. Orbán has already threatened a veto. The problem is that Merkel's opponents have even worse solutions. Or none at all.  No, yesterday wasn't a good day. It's been a long time since human rights had a good day. In my Europe, people act with wisdom and responsibility and not as Erdoğan's hostages.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D). Mr President, in the Chamber of Parliament as well as in the Council there are representatives of peoples who seem to have forgotten their history and the fact that they have been protagonists of huge refugee flows for decades. If they also do not remember how the common European vision was created and all they care about is the Structural Funds, they should also forget them, as long as they do not implement the common decisions on relocation.  Others also do not see the agreement with Turkey as unworkable. It violates international law and provokes, when it conceals Mr Erdogan's true role both in the instability of Syria and the violation of the rule of law and human rights in Turkey itself. As long as this tragic work continues, the first victim will be refugees and the second will be Europe's moral, legal and political culture. As a Greek, the only comforting thing I can note is that a people living in a difficult economic situation, with very high unemployment rates, proves overwhelmingly that solidarity is not only a kart and is not only useful when you accept it, but above all it is redeeming when you offer it.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Commissioner, Madam Secretary, it is good to hear that this year the European Union expects at least modest growth, although some states still have to fulfil their tasks. It is necessary to see how European Union policy contributes to this growth. This year, however, we must also take measures of legislative and financial instruments that will promote jobs and growth. On the agreement on Turkey, I would like to say that I consider it necessary, but it must not be seen as a single solution that is self-sparable. We must, of course, continue to strive for peace in the Middle East, for border guards for the external border of the European Union. I would like the European Commission, as well as the Member States, to know how these funds will be used when deciding on the allocation of three billion to Turkey. They should be in control. I personally consider the principle of one-for-one exchange to be an effort to prevent and support irregular migration.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, Turkey should be part of the solution for this crisis, but it is very much part of the problem, not just by manipulating the people-smuggling tap but in fuelling violent conflict in its southern region and in neighbouring Syria and Iraq.  The Council neglected all that and succumbed to unashamed blackmail by President Erdoğan under the foolhardy idea that it is possible to outsource European legal and moral obligation towards refugees to Turkey in exchange for facilitating accession and of visas and turning a blind eye to the violations of the Copenhagen criteria and to the brutal repression that President Erdoğan  is directing against Turkish citizens and media , against Turkish Kurds in particular, and against Kurds in Syria who have been brave fighters against Daesh and other terrorist groups.  What the Council contemplates in the return and readmission policies in the ‘one per one Syrian’ bazaar is, ominously, violation of the non-refoulement principle. How can the Council and the Commission keep a straight face when speaking of the rule of law and human rights if they do not act to discipline those Member States who ganged up to asphyxiate Greece and to submit refugee women and children to animal treatment at the Greek FYROM border.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Mr. President, from the first day of this migrant crisis, I have been saying that the problem must be solved at its source – in Syria and Iraq, and refugees should be cared for in consultation with the international partners in the environment. This current agreement with Turkey would be a step in the right direction if it were a partner who can be trusted at the moment. Turkey cannot be blamed for taking care of the huge number of Syrian refugees, but it is quite clear that Ankara has been using this crisis for political extortion and pursuing its geopolitical interests for some time. The problems Europe is experiencing as a result of the migrant crisis are not negligible and will become more acute. We cannot therefore expect the Americans and Russians to be as motivated to solve this problem as we are.  I think the time has come for European countries to show that in coordination they can solve this problem and take a leadership role in solving the crisis in the Middle East.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, (the beginning of the speech is not heard)... agreement as a start for solving the global problem. Better a half-way deal than the anarchy we've witnessed over the last months and years. We know what was happening on the Balkan route, we saw how anyone behaved on that Balkan route. We have seen that even some non-EU countries, namely Macedonia and Serbia, have done more than members of the European Union.  We saw some countries put up wire fences. I invite you to influence the wire fences to finally be removed if the Balkan route is now under control, because this is a shame for what we have experienced these past months, especially the border line between the Republic of Croatia and the Republic of Slovenia. That wire needs to be removed now.  Here I would like to stress in particular the dramatic situation on the Greek-Macedonian border. Greece needs help, macedonia needs help.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Mr President, Madam Minister, next week, in the Agriculture Council, when you talk about employment, remember the crisis in the European agricultural sector, a crisis which, at the moment, has sectors such as fruit and vegetables, pork or dairy in the pillage.  Commissioner Hogan's inability to put solutions to the European dairy crisis highlights the failure of his policies.  Please, in the next Council, go back to real life and open the door to the regulation of production in the dairy sector. That will mean s stop the destruction of employment. It not only counts the job that is built, but also the one that is destroyed. Therefore, take into account the situation in the agricultural sector, stop this bleeding, to contribute to job creation and a living rural environment in Europe.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: – Mr President, Mrs Hennis-Plasschaert, Commissioner, Turkey is certainly a problem. But Turkey is not the problem that calls us today, the problem is Europe. Europe cannot be the sum-subtraction of national interests. Who represents Europe in this debate? The Council certainly does not. The Council acts with intergovernmental logic, abandoning the Community principle. We pay a police state, Turkey, not to take responsibility, and we do so in open contradiction with international law. We punish a member country, Greece, and make it a prison state, so that the Balkan walls we have already erected cannot be skipped. It is the hope for Europe that this Parliament represents. Member State Number 29, a Member State called Europe, is headquartered here. We're going to exercise our right of veto. We're going to stop Europe's suicide. We're going to keep you from taking Europe back to the 1930s. You can remain impassive and indifferent to this debate. You know that decisions are made elsewhere, but we are going to recover, hand in hand with the citizens, the strong, united, generous and welcoming Europe that you are liquidating. Don't forget when you meet next week.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Thank you for the dedicated debate, especially to those ladies and gentlemen who have taken part in this debate all the time. I would also like to join the ranks of those who say that we need something. Yes, we need a political solution in Syria, we need a global solution to migration flow, we also need sustainable and functioning protection of our external borders. But I believe that 'face reality' is also important, and that means that we need a short-term solution. And for a short-term solution, it is necessary to conclude a working agreement with Turkey as well. That is what we need to work on. Monday was a very important step towards moving closer to this agreement in a sustainable and effective manner. But it was also a day that showed that only a European solution is possible, including all those involved. This solution must be developed by everyone, decided by everyone and, finally, implemented by everyone. This is the only way it works. Going it alone will not get us to our destination. We must be clear about this; Monday showed that. I would like to comment very briefly on a number of key points that have been raised time and again, both in terms of possible visa liberalisation and the accelerated opening of accession negotiations. I can assure you – at least on the part of the Commission – that this is not at the expense of standards, principles, respect for human rights, the independence of the judiciary and cetera. That will be the subject of the assessments. Anyone who wants to follow the European Union must accept our rules of the game. It's not like we're shopping around here and saying, "Become a member, there's a special tariff here." No! Anyone who wants to do so must have serious and proper negotiations with us. Incidentally, in the case of visa liberalisation, which is not so much in focus, part of such an agreement is also a readmission agreement, which includes turkey having to take back migrants from all the Member States of the European Union if no asylum can be granted. This, too, is a step forward in Europe's interest. Now to the eur 3 or six billion. Honestly, I can no longer hear Turkish representatives in particular saying that they have not yet seen a penny. You won't see a penny either, because the money is managed directly by us. However, we have not only already provided funds, but have already paid for it. I was myself in Eastern Anatolia, Gaziantep and another city on Friday, and I looked at a refugee camp there myself. I must pay respect here to the Turkish Government, but also to the international organisations, for the way in which the refugees are housed: in a human environment, in a refugee camp where everything is available – supermarkets, schools, even high schools, where there are 3 800 tents for 18 000 inhabitants, but which are properly accompanied. I can tell you that, for example, by providing 'only' EUR 40 million, we have ensured that 300 000 refugees in Turkish camps are cared for for six months. We have made sure, with EUR 55 million, that 200 000 children and young people will be able to attend school for a whole year. So, you see, with comparatively little spending, we can make sure that the people in the region have a safe home. And I can also tell you, by the way, that I have spoken to many Syrian refugees in eastern Anatolia. They all want to return to Syria as soon as possible, they don't want to go to Europe. Therefore, we must a) work on a political solution, but b) also ensure that they can live on decent conditions where they are at present and, above all, that children and young people, in particular, have a perspective by having a proper education. I took something from this visit with me: that we also need to do more to promote economic activities so that jobs are created there and the refugees also have an opportunity to take action. Monday was an important step. But it is clear that President Tusk has the task of finalising the negotiations here. I hope that this will succeed in a European spirit of solidarity, cooperation and, ultimately, unanimous implementation afterwards.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, as I said earlier this morning, more work is needed with Turkey and that is why leaders have tasked President Tusk to take forward the proposals and work out the details with Turkey by the March European Council. Details count so not all questions can be answered in detail at this stage. Let there be no mistake, European Heads of State and Government insisted – and have said explicitly in their statement – that work on the proposals will respect European and international law. I fully agree with Mr Weber that all this should be taking place in partnership with Turkey, so no dependency.  Let me be clear that the aim is not simply to stop refugees from coming. The aim is to move from irregular to legal controlled migration. The aim is to put an end to people dying at sea. And to be clear once more, we are not selling out on our values. We are speeding up, but not compromising, on the roadmap for visa liberalisation. The conditionality remains in place and the same goes for the accession negotiation chapters. So let me stress once again that accession and visa liberalisation are both condition—based processes, based on well-known conditions. So whatever arrangements we agree with Turkey, it will have to respect EU and international law. The statement of the European Council of 7 March states this clearly. We cannot – and will not – cut corners when it comes to our legal obligations.  At the same time, I would like to underline that the moral high ground is a luxury we cannot afford. As Mr Reul said, there is no such thing at this very moment as perfection. Already, under the existing Greece—Turkey readmission agreement, as well as under the EU—Turkey readmission agreements, Turkey is expected to readmit all irregular migrants not in need of international protection that have transited through Turkish territory. The EU and Turkey have to agree to skill up and accelerate the implementation of these commitments, which have started already with the transfer from Greece to Turkey of over 300 irregular migrants. We will expect Turkey to live up to international obligations, such as the principle of non-refoulement, and let us not forget that currently over 2.5 million refugees already enjoy protection in Turkey.  Finally, to those who invoked the Geneva Convention, I understand your concerns but, as I said, we will not cut corners when it comes to our legal obligation. There is no such thing as a trade—off. I would ask at the same time whether you truly think that the current situation, in which people are forced to make a dangerous journey in a little boat, is in line with international law? Are the dead bodies washing up on Turkish and Greek shores in line with national law? I do not think so. We need to do everything in our power to break this preferred model of the people smugglers. That is our moral obligation and Mr Kamal is right that the real enemies are not the refugees. The smugglers are our enemies.  To conclude – because it is a bit crowded in the Chamber right now – I would like to end with some words on the takeover of Zaman by the Turkish authorities. Our concerns were clearly raised in the meeting with the Turkish Prime Minister which my Prime Minister and Chancellor Merkel had on Sunday, as well as the meeting of the 28 on Monday. Media freedom, the freedom of speech, is not negotiable and clearly Turkey will need to improve its track record in this field. There is no such thing as turning a blind eye. To conclude, and in reply to Mrs in 't Veld, I would thank you so much for reminding me of my own statements years ago. I continue to stand by them. I would say, with the benefit of hindsight, that it was quite visionary. I asked for European solutions back then and I will continue to ask for European solutions.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. Before the vote, President Schulz will make a statement. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – In the next Council, we have to raise our voices ALL to tell Heads of State and Government that the men, women and children who roam in the European winter have the same status of dignity as those who escaped the Spanish civil war, world war II, etc. Let us also tell them not to fall into populism, to remember the fundamental values and laws of the EU; and let us ask that everything agreed with third countries respect the principles of humanitarian action and international law. Let us not stand before the inhumanity of which we are witnessing. This principle of agreement with Turkey violates human rights, treats people as goods and sheds a smokescreen over the real problem of the refugee crisis. Fundamental rights (freedom of the press, religious pluralism...) are not negotiable in the EU-Turkey relationship. Any solution must be based on respect for human rights and the Geneva Convention. Visa membership and facilitation should be related to solutions to the migration problem. Parliament has a large majority which cannot accept this inhumanity being exercised on its behalf. No, of course, in my name.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. – Because of its geostrategic position and the historical relations with the EU, Turkey is a truly indispensable piece in responding to the refugee crisis. In this context, increased cooperation with Turkey is not only desirable but imperative. The Turkish-European agenda adopted in November was going in the right direction, providing for significant financial aid to Turkey to improve the humanitarian conditions of the 3 million refugees there. The outcome of the summit on 8 March, however, can only be repudiated. Instead of promoting the sharing of responsibilities, it promotes the unaccountability of the EU through subcontracting the right of asylum. The proposals that follow it constitute a means to national selfishness and a victory of the model of "fortress Europe" to the detriment of a europe of solidarity and humanist. Furthermore, compliance with international "one out, one in" measure law applied to Syrians is highly doubtful. Unable to solve the refugee crisis, the EU has decided to find someone to solve it, buying Turkey's agreement with the reopening of accession negotiations and closing its eyes to the recent authoritarian drift.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. – In the face of the next Council, we must raise our voices in this Parliament to tell the heads of state and government that the people who roam in the European winter have the same dignity as those who escaped the conflicts of the twentieth century. Let us tell them not to fall into the temptation of populism, to defend the fundamental values and laws of the EU to their public opinions, and to respect the principles of humanitarian action and international law in any agreement with third countries. Let us not be silent in the face of this epidemic of inhumanity that we are seeing in so many countries of the Union. This principle of agreement with Turkey violates human rights. This agreement cannot become a smokescreen on the real problem of the refugee crisis. The issues of fundamental rights in the EU-Turkey relationship are non-negotiable. Any solution must be based on respect for human rights, international law and the Geneva Convention, and visa accession or facilitation should not be mixed with the search for solutions to the migration problem. Parliament cannot accept the exercise of this inhumanity. Not in my name.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – The most important outcome of this summit is that we can finally put an end to the chaos and this humanitarian catastrophe, with refugees still being killed every week in European waters. There are no simple solutions to the tragedy that is unfolding at our borders. It is clear to everyone that we need a stronger Europe, that we need to focus on the European border and coastguard and more solidarity. But we must also work towards better reception in the refugee camps and to drain the business model of smugglers.  The draft agreement with Turkey is far from ideal, but it is at least an important step forward for Turkey to accelerate the recovery of economic refugees and to be involved in the Union's distribution plan. That does not mean that we are closing our eyes to the problems in Turkey or turkey becoming a member of the EU tomorrow. Turkey cannot join the EU today, and not tomorrow, because it is going in the wrong direction with freedom of the press. A new summit is due next week. Our priority remains to ensure that people do not drown at sea and that the most vulnerable, the people who need protection, receive that protection.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. After Turkey secured 3 billion euros last November to stem the flow of migrants into the EU, it is now demanding 6 billion euros. And all without a single effect since, between January 2015 and January 2016, twelve times as many migrants arrived in Greece from Turkey. President Erdogan is blackmailing the EU and even calling for his country's accession to the EU to be accelerated. Turkey simply has no place in the EU because of its geography, but even less because of its values. Freedom of the press is being violated. Turkey is a transit hub for oil harvested by the Islamic State group and one wonders even if it does not encourage its expansion. The only viable solution to end this massive immigration is to restore strong national borders, stop the aspiring immigration pumps and ask the Middle Eastern states to take in Daesh refugees at home to avoid the human tragedies of boat crossings or across Europe.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – In the face of the next Council, we must raise our voices in this Parliament to tell the heads of state and government that the people who roam in the European winter have the same dignity as those who escaped the conflicts of the twentieth century. Let us tell them not to fall into the temptation of populism, to defend the fundamental values and laws of the EU to their public opinions, and to respect the principles of humanitarian action and international law in any agreement with third countries. Let us not be silent in the face of this epidemic of inhumanity that we are seeing in so many countries of the Union. This principle of agreement with Turkey violates human rights. This agreement cannot become a smokescreen on the real problem of the refugee crisis. The issues of fundamental rights in the EU-Turkey relationship are non-negotiable. Any solution must be based on respect for human rights, international law and the Geneva Convention, and visa accession or facilitation should not be mixed with the search for solutions to the migration problem. Parliament cannot accept the exercise of this inhumanity. Not in my name.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The agreement negotiated between the European Union and Turkish President Erdogan is, in my view, unbalanced: in exchange for the return to Turkey of Syrian refugees, the country has asked the European Union for an additional EUR 3 billion, visa liberalisation for Turkish citizens and the opening of five chapters of EU accession negotiations. This summit demonstrates that the Turkish President does not hesitate to take advantage of the humanitarian crisis and to take refugee men and women hostage to achieve his goals. This is unacceptable blackmail and I call on the heads of state of the European Union not to give in.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – I would like to take this opportunity to express my absolute disgust for the proposals that have been put forward by EU leaders as a ‘solution’ for one of the biggest humanitarian crises in recent years. Humanitarian crises should be met with humanitarian responses, however, this bartering system for refugees poses only further danger and dehumanisation. By trading away the rights and dignities of some of the world’s most vulnerable people, the EU has sunk to a new low. Our obligation to provide access to asylum has been effectively discarded with this deal and, with it, all of our commitments to international human rights law.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The position of Vice-President Dombrovskis on behalf of the European Commission in the debate on the European Semester, i.e. essentially on the Commission's supervision of budgetary developments in the Member States, is marked by glaring contradictions. The Commission assures that the euro is a political project that requires political governance and democratic responsibility and notes that we will all be judged by our ability to improve the prospects of our peoples.  In reality, however, the Commission itself is a mixed body, political and technocratic at the same time, and the European Parliament's control over it is stiflingly limited under the current rules. Similarly limited is the democratic legitimacy of economic and fiscal policy, all the more so when non-European organisations are involved in its planning, completely devoid of such legitimacy and inaccessible to the attribution of responsibility, such as the International Monetary Fund. In addition, the Commission acknowledges that high public debts hinder growth and expose Member States' economies to the risk of crises, but does not present any plans to drastically reduce debt levels.  Europe needs new, unconventional mechanisms for restructuring public debt in order to achieve a substantial reduction and less involvement of non-democratic and non-European mechanisms in its own homes.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. – Last Monday the heads of state agreed that next week they will decide something concrete and that they will speed up the implementation of the agreement signed with Turkey in November. Looking at the general lines announced, more is promised, in exchange for more, without the Member States having complied with the least.  The substance of the agreement will be based essentially on two pillars: more money and so-called resettlement (something similar to the relocation mechanism, but with Turkey). Once again, the Heads of State have promised a Third State what they cannot fulfil. It grows the feeling that it is even easy to opt for outsourcing. It seems easier to promise money to those who claim to be able to accomplish what we are not able to do. More serious, however, according to Eurojust, the European Commission, and several NGOs, are the many doubts that fall on Turkey in respect for the rule of law, fundamental rights and even asylum rules. Reality advocates concrete solutions, not inconsequential ideals. But we must be concerned that, in the face of an existential crisis, Europe decides to ignore precisely what gave rise to it: values.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. – It seems to me that the deal discussed during the EU-Turkey summit results from a sudden change of heart by Germany. Though Germany is not openly mentioning any limits to the number of refugees it wants to host, reality is showing that some form of limit does exist. This change of heart is translating into a pushback of migrants to the EU’s external borders and shifting the burden back to border Member States. The flow of migrants passing from Turkey to Greece shows no sign of abating and if the numbers remain unmanageable there is little hope that the EU would be able to deal with the situation in a pragmatic manner. In my opinion, the EU-Turkey deal should not take the form of a trade-off. However, as things stand today, the agreement seems to be exactly that. The EU must be vigilant for any human rights violations and not turn a blind eye to what happens. Human rights safeguards should be ensured when Turkey deals with migrants. The EU-Turkey deal must not be considered an end in itself, and the EU needs to continue expanding its efforts in the field of migration and asylum.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. – Turkey does not meet any accession criteria and cannot and must not open any negotiating chapters because it crushes freedom of speech, beats and kills journalists, commits genocide against its own people and ethnic cleansing in Syria and Iraq. In addition, Turkey finances, organizes, trains, supplies weapons, treats and trades with probably the most degenerate and human-like terrorist organization of our time – Islamic State. In addition, Turkey illegally conducts combat operations, invades and violates the territorial borders and national sovereignty of two neighbouring states – the Syrian Arab Republic and the Republic of Iraq.  More importantly, Turkey is preparing to illegally annex and occupy territory of a neighboring sovereign state. Remind you of Crimea? Let's not forget that Turkey has occupied a completely illegal part of the territory of an EU Member State for decades, namely Cyprus, has not suffered any responsibility for the ethnic cleansing of the Greek Cypriots, still holds at least 30,000 occupying corps there and does not give Access to Cyprus' seagoing vessels and aircraft to the water, airspace, ports and airports of the so-called " Northern Cyprus.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. Europe's inability to approach and manage migration forces it to be blackmailed by the Turkish Government. A further three billion and demands to facilitate the negotiations for accession to the European Union represent Turkey's counter-offer to stem the flow of refugees who, through its territory, reach Greece and the countries of Northern Europe. There is little guarantee that funding for cooperation with Turkey will strengthen, not undermine, the rights of migrants and refugees.  The EU is not only under the illusion that Turkey can stop those fleeing war and persecution to save their lives, but persists in dealing with a country that has entered a spiral of authoritarianism and repression that undermines the fundamental rights of its citizens and migrants and gags the freedom of the press. The European Union, not least because of the predominancing of the national self-interest of the Member States, continues to have little international impact on the real causes of the migration problem, but risks reneging on the principles on which it is based and showing itself to be an accomplice of a state accused of serious human rights violations.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – In the face of the next Council, we need to raise our voices in this Parliament to tell the heads of state and government that the men, women and children who roam in the European winter have the same status as the men, women and children who escaped the Spanish civil war, the Second World War in their various scenarios , fascist and communist dictatorships, wars in the Balkans. Let us also tell them not to fall into the temptation of populism, to defend the fundamental values and laws of the EU to their public opinions; and, above all, let us ask them, in everything they agree with third countries, to respect the principles of humanitarian action and international humanitarian law. But above all, let us not be silent in the face of this epidemic of inhumanity which we are witnessing in so many countries of the Union. This principle of agreement with Turkey violates human rights and treats people as goods. Parliament has a large majority which cannot accept this inhumanity being exercised on its behalf. Not on behalf of Parliament. No, of course, in my name

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – In previous meetings, the European Council has repeatedly debated the protection of the EU's external borders, the reduction of irregular migration and the guarantee of the integrity of the Schengen area. Now concrete decisions have finally begun to be taken on this issue. Nato's declaration to assist in reconnaissance, monitoring and control of illegal border crossings in the Aegean Sea was also welcomed. In this respect, we are still waiting for a concrete action plan from NATO.  The full and rapid implementation of the EU-Turkey Action Plan is a priority for halting migration flows and combating networks of traffickers and smugglers. While there is already concrete progress in some areas of action, the number of people crossing the border between Turkey and Greece remains worrying. EU leaders agreed with Turkish Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoğlu to step up cooperation to achieve concrete results. Turkey has pledged to accept all migrants entering Greece and then turn back those who do not need international protection. The migration crisis has not yet been resolved. We are now m.in to speed up the implementation of the Action Plan on Visa Liberalisation and other proposals that need to be clarified before the next European Council.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. – In the face of the next Council, we must raise our voices in this Parliament to tell the heads of state and government that the people who roam in the European winter have the same dignity as those who escaped the conflicts of the twentieth century. Let us tell them not to fall into the temptation of populism, to defend the fundamental values and laws of the EU to their public opinions, and to respect the principles of humanitarian action and international law in any agreement with third countries. Let us not be silent in the face of this epidemic of inhumanity that we are seeing in so many countries of the Union. This principle of agreement with Turkey violates human rights. This agreement cannot become a smokescreen on the real problem of the refugee crisis. The issues of fundamental rights in the EU-Turkey relationship are non-negotiable. Any solution must be based on respect for human rights, international law and the Geneva Convention, and visa accession or facilitation should not be mixed with the search for solutions to the migration problem. Parliament cannot accept the exercise of this inhumanity. Not in my name.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: in writing. – In the face of the next Council, we must raise our voices in this Parliament to tell the heads of state and government that the men, women and children who roam in the European winter have the same status and dignity as the men, women and children who escaped the Spanish civil war, of World War II in their various scenarios , fascist and communist dictatorships, wars in the Balkans. Let us also tell them not to fall into the temptation of populism, to defend the fundamental values and laws of the EU to their public opinions; and, above all, let us ask them, in everything they agree with third countries, to respect the principles of humanitarian action and international humanitarian law. But above all, let us not be silent in the face of this epidemic of inhumanity which we are witnessing in so many countries of the Union. This agreement cannot become a smokescreen on the real problem of the refugee crisis.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Writing. – Today we are witnessing a protracted refugee crisis in Europe, which will be with us for some time to come. In war-torn areas, the conflict does not appear to be resolved and persistent crises have developed. The number of refugees will not decrease. We can only respond to this at a common European level. Our strength also depends on joint action, one of the basic conditions of which is cooperation. Any partisanship that undermines joint action undermines the power of successful joint action and causes lasting damage to the entire European community, including those on special missions. The problem is that on Monday evening Hungary not only kicked up European solidarity, but also caused very serious damage to the entire Union, significantly weakening its external negotiating position. So the situation is worse now in the Member States, including Hungary. Member States cannot deal with the crisis alone. If we do not help, we can create new crisis threts close to our borders, pulling the problem even closer to ourselves, rather than trying to remedy it at its roots. Today, Greece, before italy, has faced a flood of refugees. Now we leave them alone, next time another Member State in trouble, whose problems we should solve together? What if it's my country? Who's going to help me? This Hungarian action has seriously harmed Both Europeans and Hungarians. If we keep this up, we'll be alone in the world when we get in trouble.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The agreement with Turkey on migrants is a landmark step in EU policy in the face of the escalating migration crisis, as was Donald Tusk's call to economic migrants: 'Do not come to Europe'. The agreement foresees that the EU will provide Turkey with an additional EUR 3 billion (eur 2x3 billion in total) for the maintenance of refugee camps in Turkey, but also for their introduction into the Turkish labour market. In addition – and I consider these arrangements crucial – the EU will open channels for legal migration for asylum seekers in exchange for an end to irregular migration.  This kind of exchange is aimed at regaining control of the crisis and stopping the criminal activities of human traffickers, smugglers and document forgers who have created a profitable and inhumane empire of pathological business more profitable than the arms or drug trade. Thus, the EU hopes to stop the illegal influx of migrants; in return, it will legally and controlledly accept war refugees and introduce visa-free travel at the EU-Turkey border for EU and Turkish citizens.  Of course, halting irregular migration is only part of the solution, which must also include controls at the EU's external borders, biometric passports, effective exchange of information within the EU and other elements of controls, complemented by active efforts to integrate migrants and respect the European value system for all EU citizens and residents.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. – In the face of the next Council, we must raise our voices in this Parliament to tell the heads of state and government that the people who roam in the European winter have the same dignity as those who escaped the conflicts of the twentieth century. Let us tell them not to fall into the temptation of populism, to defend the fundamental values and laws of the EU to their public opinions, and to respect the principles of humanitarian action and international law in any agreement with third countries. Let us not be silent in the face of this epidemic of inhumanity that we are seeing in so many countries of the Union. This principle of agreement with Turkey violates human rights. This agreement cannot become a smokescreen on the real problem of the refugee crisis. The issues of fundamental rights in the EU-Turkey relationship are non-negotiable. Any solution must be based on respect for human rights, international law and the Geneva Convention, and visa accession or facilitation should not be mixed with the search for solutions to the migration problem. Parliament cannot accept the exercise of this inhumanity. Not in my name.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. – The EU-Turkey relationship goes back years, when in 2005 Cyprus, with one third of it under illegal Turkish occupation, granted Turkey a date to open accession negotiations with the expectation that it would converge with European values and rules of law, with the aim of a European solution in Cyprus. Since then, we have invested as an EU politically and in money in this expectation. Today Turkey is violating basic principles to a greater extent than when its accession process began. My disappointment is not that only turkey still maintains its troops in Cyprus. It is not just because a despotic Islamist regime prevails in Turkey, nor because Turkey's Europeanisation has failed, to the point where democracy is in the plaster. My biggest disappointment concerns the eu-Turkey haggling over refugees.  Turkey has tabled a blackmail proposal with the desperate refugees hostage, which would not even be done for animals. My great disappointment is that instead of european-wide Turkey, ultimately with the tolerance of the EU leadership we are altering the core of our principles and rules of law. If the EU proceeds with this transaction, I do not want to be a part of this crime.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. It would be important for member states that use both the euro and the non-euro to join the European Banking Union. This is a prerequisite for protection such as that of euro area depositors, for example, for hungarian bank depositors, regardless of the basis of the bank's customers. If a Member State is not covered by a common European deposit guarantee, customers will be able to migrate to euro area-based banks, which are backed by greater protection. Depositors in the Member State joining the Banking Union are backed by European protection. Thanks to the Single European Bank Resolution Fund, where a bank is in difficulty, its costs are borne not by taxpayers but by creditors, shareholders and investors. Thanks to the European Deposit Insurance Funds, full protection of small deposits below EUR 100 000 is ensured even in the event of bank failures. Thanks to the Bank Resolution and Deposit Guarantee Fund, which is the cornerstone of the Banking Union, we can prevent crises and make the European financial system more stable and predictable. This is not a question of sovereignty, but an existential issue for Hungarian bank depositors.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. - Meetings and consultations between Turkey and the EU are important, especially in view of the current migration crisis. At the same time, it is clear that the EU must also take responsibility for what is happening at its borders. The most important thing is to create an effective, well-equipped and well-manned EU border guard. The EU must be able to accept asylum applications and process them quickly and securely. Sufficient resources must also be ensured to improve the living conditions of refugees, both in refugee camps and at borders. Of course, the EU must take a more active stance on Russia's actions in Syria and also find a way to contribute to the end of the conflict in Syria as soon as possible and for people to return to their homeland in order to rebuild a bombed-out life.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. - Syria has been at war for five years now. For two years now, those living in a conflict situation have had a "roadmap" aimed at Europe. But it has only been a few months since Europe had a "roadmap" to protect the security of its borders.  The European Union was not set up to function as a crisis instrument. It is for this reason that we must anticipate the emerging crises and not allow them to become uncontrollable forces. In April last year, we started taking "urgent" measures to deal with the refugee flow. But the threat to free movement within our continent was also clear a long time ago. The Commission's roadmap for a return to a strong Schengen system is necessary but extremely late. Pan-European border police for external border guards will start work by August 2016, and internal borders are not scheduled to be open until the end of the year. This time we must act quickly and decisively, ahead of deadlines, not overdue them.  Another key measure that does not receive sufficient attention is the fight against traffickers. Closing our borders is not in itself a solution, as human trafficking channels are rapidly reoriented. After the closure of the Western Balkan route, Bulgaria and Hungary become potential destinations for these channels, which we have to stop at all costs.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – In the face of the next Council, we must raise our voices in this Parliament to tell the heads of state and government that the people who roam in the European winter have the same dignity as those who escaped the conflicts of the twentieth century. Let us tell them not to fall into the temptation of populism, to defend the fundamental values and laws of the EU to their public opinions, and to respect the principles of humanitarian action and international law in any agreement with third countries. Let us not be silent in the face of this epidemic of inhumanity that we are seeing in so many countries of the Union. This principle of agreement with Turkey violates human rights. This agreement cannot become a smokescreen on the real problem of the refugee crisis. The issues of fundamental rights in the EU-Turkey relationship are non-negotiable. Any solution must be based on respect for human rights, international law and the Geneva Convention, and visa accession or facilitation should not be mixed with the search for solutions to the migration problem. Parliament cannot accept the exercise of this inhumanity. Not in my name.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: Writing. – When considering whether the EU-Turkey agreement will really help to make unmanaged migration manageable, I see too many challenges for this. Since the start of intensive negotiations between the EU and Turkey, one of the main demands for Turkey has been to suspend the illegal migrant smuggling network. So far, however, we have seen no more serious action by Ankara in this direction: although at the beginning of the year the migration through the Aegean Sea was lower than in the same period in 2015, a new wave of migrants and up to 100,000 migrants are predicted to be affected by the weather. new arrivals by the end of March. The scale of the war in Syria is not diminishing, and russia's dictation of conditions and the in principle inciting conflict do not reduce the flow of refugees to Turkey, with around 2.7 million people already in Turkey. refugees and migrants. Perhaps that is what Ankara is not taking to shut down the road to Europe? There is no recipe for a recipe for the arrivals already in Europe today, and there is doubt about the commitment to accept every illegal migrant returned to Turkey as a refugee. These are new hundreds of thousands of asylum seekers. Europe promises Turkey a great deal: visa-free travel, a huge financial injection, the opening of new chapters on EU membership, although the situation of civil rights and freedoms in Turkey is deteriorating. Today, however, I doubt that Ankara will pay the appropriate tribute, as this, so far, is more reminiscent of the clever move to make the migration crisis a shake-up of Turkey's frozen integration with the EU.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Writing. – With regard to the draft agreement tabled at the EU-Turkey Summit, which ended yesterday, it is not entirely clear what the negotiators mean by accelerating accession negotiations. If it is indeed accelerating, then I appreciate this positively, because it means that Turkey is accelerating the adaptation of its legal system to EU law and reaffirming its willingness to respect freedom of expression and expression and the rights of minorities, including the Kurdish population of millions.  However, if this speeding up in any way means that EU Member States turn a blind eye to the facts or apply specific rules to Turkey in the accession negotiations, then I can only express my strong opposition. The negotiations are indeed complicated, but they are precisely designed to prepare candidates for EU membership thoroughly. The worst message that exists would be the coherence of the enlargement process if a country were treated differently by the EU for political reasons than other candidates.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing – The dialogue between the European Union and Turkey on coping with the migration crisis will continue. The main theme will be the visa regime in particular. However, both sides – both the Union and Turkey – have expressed the same view on stopping the influx of illegal migrants.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. Will the EU-Turkey summit held on 7 March be the one that announces the end of the European project? The decisions that are looming at the end of this summit are an unacceptable shift, which we may not recover from. The Council would decide to replace repression with solidarity. Unable to implement a fair and inclusive distribution of refugees, Member States seem ready to do anything to reach an agreement with Turkey to stop the migrants. After closing their borders one by one by isolating Greece, they are determined to send refugees back to Turkey, violating the principle of non-refoulement and the obligation to protect the right of asylum of the Geneva Convention. Turning a blind eye to the authoritarian excesses of the Turkish regime, the heads of state promise to speed up the accession process of this country, while promising billions of euros, which we doubt will one day be financed. This repressive orientation is not mine. The Council has until 17 March to regain its spirits and renew solidarity!

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), in writing. – At the recent EU-Turkey Summit, an agreement with Turkey was sought again with no real results in order to minimise refugee flows to the EU. However, Turkey is constantly making heterogeneous and absurd demands, such as doubling financial aid, lifting visas for Turkish citizens travelling to the EU and continuing accession negotiations by opening more funds, "threatening" Europe with uncontrolled waves of migrants and refugees. Any new agreement with Turkey should be subject to clear rules and timetables as well as strict monitoring of the implementation of the agreements. It is not acceptable to involve issues, such as the continuation of accession negotiations, that are not related to the management of the refugee problem. In particular, with regard to any additional funding for Turkey, the EU must exercise strict control over how European aid to Turkey is spent so far. , acting undisturbed on the Turkish coast.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen! I would ask you to listen to me for a moment. I now, admittedly, am taking an unusual measure, which I consider inevitable for the dignity of this House. There has been an incident in this House this morning which I believe the European Parliament cannot react, but must respond. I am now giving you the sentence which, firstly, I consider unacceptable and, secondly, absolutely penalisable. It is the phrase of Mr Synadinos who, in the debate on the EU-Turkey Summit this morning, said the following. I quote: "As Ottoman scientists have written: the Turks are spiritual barbarians, despised by God, swindlers and dirty. The Turk is like the dog playing the savage, but when he has to fight the enemy, runs away. The only effective way to deal with the Turks is the fist and determination." This, ladies and gentlemen, is a sentence which, within the meaning of Rule 165 of the Rules of Procedure, constitutes a serious violation of the values and principles of the Union. (Strong applause) As an immediate measure, I have therefore ordered – and I would add, ladies and gentlemen – also as a decision of principle, because I believe that there is a systematic attempt here to cross red lines in order to make racism acceptable here. I told you yesterday: not with me! Therefore, in accordance with Rule 165 of the Rules of Procedure in conjunction with Rule 11, I am withinmodeof Mr Synadinos from the sitting with immediate effect. (Strong applause) Mr Synadinos, I call on you to leave the Chamber. They will be heard in accordance with the usual procedures. Nor is there any debate on my immediate action. I would now ask you to leave the Chamber. Please, Mr Synadinos, leave the Chamber.  (Interjections) No, there is no point of order. Mr Synadinos, please leave the Chamber, please very much. Ok. I now call on you once again to leave the Chamber. (Interjections) I would ask the ushers to lead Mr Synadinos out of the Chamber. You're welcome! (Applause) Please leave this Chamber. If you want to accompany Mr Synadinos, I cannot prevent you from saying goodbye. (Interjections) There is no debate on the Rules of Procedure on this order, you do not need to try anything. Mr Synadinos will be heard. There is no debate on the Rules of Procedure, and if you do not calm down, Mr Gollnisch, you will get a sedative. (Interjections) We are acting in accordance with the Rules of Procedure. I will keep you informed of the progress of the procedures. (Applause)

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: The next item is voting time. (Vote results and other details about them: see Minutes)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Sulphur is naturally present in small quantities in oil and coal. With Directive 93\12\EEC, the EU has tried to combat sulphur dioxide emissions, which are considered to be one of the main causes of acidification and the formation of particles harmful to human health. The procedure for codifying European law, provided for in Article 103 of the Regulation, makes it possible to proceed with the mere codification of the law, thus avoiding any essential changes to the text or content of the law. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the codification proposal, considering it essential to encourage collective action by all Member States to protect the ecosystem, biodiversity and the health of citizens.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it represents a technical improvement in legislation in the field of emissions of certain liquid fuels. Specifically, this act compilations amendments to the regulation affecting fuels mainly used in shipbuilding and groups all Member States' obligations in the control and supervision of these emissions within their waters. An improvement in the legislative framework in the field of transport emissions is necessary to ensure that there are no scandals such as those related to the automotive sector. Since it is a technical codification which integrates into a single legislative act the basic act and its subsequent amendments which, in this case, does not imply any substantial change in its content, I have given a vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report, which is a codification dossier. Simply put, codification means that they unify fragmented and updated modifications into one instrument, enhancing legal clarity. No substantial changes were made to the codified text. Therefore, and specifically because it enhances legal clarity, we voted in favour of this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This proposal is a simple codification of existing texts without amendment to the substance and I am voting in favour of its adoption

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The pollution of the air by the sulphur is very harmful to human health. The directive sets the maximum rate of sulphur that boats can reject. I voted for this text, which is limited but positive in scope.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This was an attempt to rehash existing laws. I voted against this measure because it was a proposal for further legislation. I do not believe that the European Parliament should be making any law that would be applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels, which is intended solely to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The directive in question sets out the maximum permitted sulphur content of heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the EU. Emissions from marine fuel vessels are high in sulphur, contributing to air pollution and harming human health. In addition, acidification and release of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere damage fragile ecosystems, reduce biodiversity, and harm agriculture and forests. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which proposes above all to clarify the law in this area.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In the interests of clarity and transparency, the purpose of this proposal, which I have approved, is to codify the Council's 26 April 1999 Directive 1999/EC on a reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. The proposed new directive would replace the various acts incorporated into it. It fully preserves its substance and merely groups it together by making the only formal modifications required by the coding operation.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Ferrara report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. This is a technical measure which is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without making any substantial changes. The text presented has been adapted in particular to the recommendations of the Advisory Group of Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. Considering the process of simplifying legislation in this area to be useful, I have decided to support the proposal.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, concerning a proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council, on the reduction of sulphur in the content of some liquid fuels. The new Directive will replace the various acts incorporated into it; the proposal fully respects the content of the codified texts and, therefore, only compiles those formal modifications required by the encoding operation itself. According to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a direct codification of the existing texts without any substantial amendment thereof. The proposed Directive aims to reduce the emission of sulphur dioxide resulting from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels and thus reduce the harmful effects of such emissions on humans and the environment.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This directive regulates the maximum permitted sulphur content of heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the EU. Marine fuel boats have a high sulphur content, which is air pollution and harms health. Naturally, acidification and release of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere damage fragile ecosystems, reduce biodiversity and harm agriculture and forests. This is only a codification and this text encourages the fight against pollution and acidification, which damage the environment. I vote for this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ferrara report that provides for the reduction of the presence of sulphur in some liquid fuels is acceptable and without critical issues, which is why I supported it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution, which is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to adopt a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of sulphur content in certain liquid fuels. Having regard to the Council decision of 20 December 1994 on the The Interinstitutional Agreement on an accelerated working method for official codification of legislative texts, the Consultative Working Party, composed of representatives of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, considered the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council.
