This proposal codifies the proposal of 26 April 1999. Council Directive 1999/32/EC on the reduction of sulphur content of certain liquid fuels and amending Directive 93/12/EEC. After considering this proposal, the Consultative Working Party of the EU institutions decided by consensus that the proposal is intended only to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposed resolution on the proposal for a directive on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain types of liquid fuel, as this case is only a codification of existing texts which do not have any substantive changes.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. In the fact that, on the one hand, it is merely a codification and, on the other hand, the codified text participates in the fight against pollution and acidification, which damage our environment, I have no reason to oppose it. I voted for it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the codification of the rules on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels makes it possible to eliminate duplication and contributes to the simplification of the legal system.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. Having regard to the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method for the official codification of legislative texts, in addition to the outcome of the meetings of 25 September and 14 October 2014 of the Council and the Commission, it is considered that the proposal in question should have been approved, which does not provide for any substantial amendments but which constitutes an act codifying the existing texts.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The purpose of this proposal for a directive is to codify a text aimed at setting the maximum sulphur content of heavy fuel oil, diesel and marine diesel used in the European Union. Emissions from fuel-fuel boats are high in sulphur, which is dangerous to marine ecosystems and biodiversity. This codification contributes to the fight against pollution and acidification; that damage our environment. That is why I voted for this proposal for a directive.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Pollution is one of the most pressing problems of this century, so the measures required to reduce the amount of substances contributing to the amplification of pollution are of immediate importance. Moreover, the prospects for European legislation must be set towards finding new ways to prevent pollution. A major branch of fuel production, in particular the oil industry. Of course, in order to be able to solve the substantive problems that arise in this area, we must first of all have coherent and compact legislation that can provide affordable solutions. This proposal by the European Parliament and of the Council is precisely what this sets out to be: to amend Directive 1999/32/EC so that the text has more clarity. I voted to support the advisory working group composed of representatives of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, supporting the proposal in question which is limited to a simple codification of the existing texts, without any substantive changes thereto.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 A purely codification measure on Community legislation to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions. Vote

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is a codification dossier. Simply put, codification means that they unify fragmented and updated modifications into one instrument, enhancing legal clarity. No substantial changes were made to the codified text. Therefore, and specifically because it enhances legal clarity, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because all the amendments to the Council Directive 1999/32/EC should be brought together into one single act which will make the legislation more orderly. There is no change in substance and the aim still remains to reduce the emissions of sulphur dioxide and their damaging impact on human health and the environment.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is concerned with the proposal to codify the many substantial amendments made to Directive 1999/32/EC on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. This codification is essential for the clarity and rationalisation of the regulated material, namely the maximum sulphur content allowed for heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel oil used by the Union.  I voted in favour of the codification proposal because, as confirmed by the Legal Service of the European Parliament, the text is limited to a mere rationalisation of the legislative changes that have followed one's time without introducing some arbitrary substantive changes.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote in favour of the report and note that the reduction in sulphur dioxide emissions resulting from the combustion of certain petroleum-derived liquid fuels is achieved by imposing limits on the sulphur content of these fuels, as a condition for their use within the territory, territorial waters and exclusive economic zones or pollution control zones of the Member States.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels concerns the process of codifying an existing text, without modifying its content. As part of a wider effort to speed up procedures, I think it should have received a positive response from all Members and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 It was easy to vote in favour of this proposal as it represents a mere codification of existing texts without any substantial modification. This is a proposal which, in my opinion, represents an improvement in the quality of legislation.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Sulphur is naturally present in small quantities in petroleum and coal. Sulphur dioxide (SO2) has been recognised for decades as a major cause of the ‘acid rain’ and air pollution which affect urban and industrial areas. More recently, it has been recognised that SO2 emissions contribute to the formation of secondary inorganic aerosol gases, fine particles which are harmful to human health. Directive 93/12/EEC, as subsequently amended, is intended to combat emissions of sulphur dioxide, which are one of the causes of acidification and particle formation in the European Union (EU), and are one of the factors causing damage to ecosystems, biodiversity and human health. On 12 March 1997 the Commission adopted a communication on a Community strategy to combat acidification [COM(97) 88 final - not published in the Official Journal]. Limiting sulphur emissions from the combustion of certain liquid fuels was recognised as an important element in the strategy. The reduction in sulphur dioxide emissions applies to heavy fuel oils and gas oil (liquid fuels derived from petroleum, including, since Directives 1999/32/EC and 2005/33/EC, those used by seagoing ships).

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report for the simple reason that the proposal in question is limited to the codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes being made to it.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It is our responsibility to regulate against emissions due to the combustion of marine fuels with a high sulphur content. This is realised in air and contributes to air pollution in the form of sulphur dioxide and particulate matter, which harms our health and the environment, and contributes to acid deposition. Air pollution caused by ships at berth is a major concern for many harbour cities when it comes to their efforts to meet the Union’s air quality limit values. Passenger ships operate mostly in ports or close to coastal areas and their impacts on human health and the environment are significant. It is worth noting that in accordance with existing guidelines on state aid for environmental protection, and without prejudice to future changes thereto, Member States may provide state aid in favour of operators affected by this directive, including aid for retrofitting operations of existing vessels, if such aid measures are deemed to be compatible with the internal market obligations.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns proposals for the codification of EU law. The technical procedure provided for in Article 103 of the Regulation is intended to verify that the codification proposal is in fact limited to mere codification, without any substantial changes. Each codification proposal is examined in advance by the legal services of the Commission, the Council and Parliament. I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. •u2012 Reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it represents a technical improvement of legislation in the field of emissions of certain liquid fuels. Specifically, this act compilations amendments to the regulation affecting fuels mainly used in shipbuilding and groups all Member States' obligations in the control and supervision of these emissions within their waters. An improvement in the legislative framework in the field of transport emissions is necessary to ensure that there are no scandals such as those related to the automotive sector. Since it is a technical codification which integrates into a single legislative act the basic act and its subsequent amendments which, in this case, does not imply any substantial change in its content, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 European Security Strategy – A safe Europe in a better world identifies environmental degradation as a risk factor for contemporary society. Since the quality of the environment has strong effects on human activity and health, and natural disasters can cause humanitarian crises and major migratory flows, it is necessary to comply with the rules governing the use of various pollutant factors, such as sulphur dioxide resulting from the burning of various liquid fuels.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Due to the ordinal nature of the document, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text as it is a straightforward codification of the existing texts on codifying Council Directive 1999/32/EC of 26 April 1999 relating to a reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels and amending Directive 93/12/EEC without any change in their substance. Changes include a change in the numbering of recitals and articles, and slight wording changes to Article 2(g) and Article 20 of the text.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. On the one hand, it is merely a codification, i.e. a formalization of the law which aims at better legibility and thus a simplification of it. On the other hand, the text aims to strengthen the fight against pollution and acidification, which harm our environment. For these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I supported this codification because it does not contain problematic or controversial text. In the present case, it is a merger of existing texts, without altering the substance of the legal acts.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Positive, because these are purely safety issues but above all a matter of health and protection of the already polluted environment.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. In the field of EU law, there are still a large number of provisions which have undergone various, often essential, changes and which are dispersed between the original act and subsequent acts of amendment, making it difficult for them to accessibility and understanding by the citizen. In this regard, the purpose of this proposal is the codification of Council Directive 1999/32/EC of 26 April 1999 on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels and amending Directive 93/12/EEC in order to provide greater clarity and accessibility to EU law. This codification provides legal certainty with regard to the law applicable in this area and will help to determine the provisions in force.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method with a view to the official codification of legislative texts, the Advisory Group held meetings to examine the above proposal presented by the Commission. The analysis thus made it possible to conclude, by common agreement, that the proposal under consideration is effectively based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive changes.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour, because the codified text contributes to the fight against pollution and acidification, which damage our environment.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report endorses the Commission's codification on Directive 1999/32/EC on the subject. Some amendments are making progress which little alter the Commission's proposal, which in turn merely has formal amendments to nomenclature and articulation with other documents.  In essence, the Directive aims to control the amount of sulphur that ships use in their fuels, taking into account the damage they inflict on the environment, by means of a check done during navigation but also when they are moored.  It proposes fuel alternatives, establishes the percentages of sulphur in fuels, proposes deterrent, proportionate and effective sanctions for vessels using this compound in their fuels. It also defines the maximum level of these fuels that can be used in the Exclusive Economic Zones of the Member States.  In the case of this report, we are only dealing with codification, that is, it is an eminently technical issue that does not meet the fundamental matters associated with legislative acts. In any case, we voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it is positive for the environment.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels, because it is purely a safety issue but above all a matter of health and protection of the already polluted environment.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal, as it contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Limiting the sulphur content emitted into the atmosphere by acidifying pollutants through certain liquid fuels, such as the maximum sulphur content in fuels for maritime vessels in Europe and focusing on alternative fuels with a low sulphur content, are actions aimed at a single result: the protection of the environment and the health of citizens in the EU. That is why I am voting in favour of the report.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels because I am in favour of codification of existing texts that guarantees legal certainty and ease of understanding of it. I believe that the Commission's decision to request the codification of those legislative texts that have undergone numerous major changes over the years since their first adoption goes in the right direction with regard to the clarity and transparency of EU law. Directive 1999/32/EC laying down the maximum permitted sulphur content for heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel oil used in the Eu ropean Union is an important part of EU environmental legislation.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. As a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs, I am in favour of setting limit values for sulphur content in maritime transport in view of the high level of air pollution. Emissions from shipping will soon be higher than those of all other onshore sources. Measures, on the other hand, were also urgently needed with regard to compliance with the climate protection targets.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, concerning a proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council, on the reduction of sulphur in the content of some liquid fuels. The new Directive will replace the various acts incorporated into it; the proposal fully respects the content of the codified texts and, therefore, only compiles those formal modifications required by the encoding operation itself. According to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a direct codification of the existing texts without any substantial amendment thereof. The proposed Directive aims to reduce the emission of sulphur dioxide resulting from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels and thus reduce the harmful effects of such emissions on humans and the environment.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support this revision because it is simply a codification of the text of the original proposal, meaning it does not have any effect on the substance of the law (which I support) itself.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report concerns only the codification of existing texts, without modifying their substance. That is why we voted in favour of the report, adopting the position as adapted on the basis of the recommendations of the Legal Services Advisory Group.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as this directive will be important to reduce the emissions of sulphur dioxide resulting from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels, thereby reducing the harmful effects of such emissions to our environment and to the global population.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The report refers to reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. The proposal is basically a simple codification of existing texts, with no substantial changes to their substance.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive by Parliament and the Council to reduce the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels, as I consider it an obligation of the European Union to provide its citizens with easy access to legal order acts. Codification is therefore directed towards simplification that does not change the essential content of acts. In this context, I support an interinstitutional agreement allowing for an accelerated procedure for the swift adoption of codified acts and for Commission staff to codify acts after a maximum of ten amendments.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This directive sets out the maximum permitted sulphur content of heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the EU. Emissions from marine fuel vessels are high in sulphur, which contributes to air pollution and harms human health. In addition, acidification and release of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere damage fragile ecosystems, reduce biodiversity, and harm agriculture and forests. In the fact that, on the one hand, it is merely codification and, on the other hand, the codified text participates in the fight against pollution and acidification, which damage our environment, we have no reason to oppose it. So I voted for this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Laura Ferrara's report on the European Parliament and Council's proposal for a directive on reducing the sulphur content of certain fuels. It is an overhaul of the existing texts for the sake of clarity without changing the substance of them. The aim of this text is to reduce toxic amounts in the air and thus improve its quality. I support this regulation because poor air quality in the Union is responsible for many deaths and respiratory diseases. There is therefore an urgent need to achieve the levels of quality that the Union has set itself in order to address the negative consequences on health and the environment.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on a directive to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels. This will reduce the effects of these hazardous emissions on humans and the environment.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This is a codification of the existing legal situation, which there are no objections. I therefore agree with this proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as the proposal contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns a proposal to reduce the emissions of sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. We have to reduce the harmful effects of such emissions on man and on the environment through the reduction of sulphur. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Sulphur dioxide emissions contribute to the problem of acidification of the waste, with direct effects on human health and the environment. Sulphur, which is present in small quantities in oil and coal, has been recognized as the main source of sulphur dioxide emissions. The latter is one of the major causes of "acid rain" which, in addition to having an impact on human health, can cause significant damage to buildings and the architectural heritage, as well as to agriculture, precisely as a result of acidification of the land.  I have chosen to vote in favour of this report because I agree with the objective of gradually reducing sulphur dioxide emissions from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels, in order to reduce the harmful effects on public health and the environment.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. This is a codification that intervenes in a process of simplification and clarification. The directive sets out the maximum permitted sulphur content for heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the European Union. Emissions from marine fuel vessels are high in sulphur, which contributes to air pollution and harms human health. In addition, acidification and release of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere damage fragile ecosystems, reduce biodiversity and harm agriculture and forests.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it is in favour of codifying a text that fights against a form of pollution.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted for this text. It is part of the fight against pollution and acidification by setting the maximum permitted content of heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the Union. I agree with the directive's desire to protect fragile ecosystems, biodiversity, agriculture and forests. The approach of simplifying and clarifying EU law on this subject, undertaken by the directive, and, although formal and not substantial, is desirable.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it represents a technical improvement in legislation in the field of emissions of certain liquid fuels. Specifically, this act compilations amendments to the regulation affecting fuels mainly used in shipbuilding and groups all Member States' obligations in the control and supervision of these emissions within their waters. An improvement in the legislative framework in the field of transport emissions is necessary to ensure that there are no scandals such as those related to the automotive sector. Since it is a technical codification which integrates into a single legislative act the basic act and its subsequent amendments which, in this case, does not imply any substantial change in its content, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agree that the proposal in question is limited to codification. In the same regard, the Committee of the Regions ruled. In these terms, I welcome the draft Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels in which pure and simple codification of existing texts is made, without any substantial amendment there matter.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. This is a proposal concerning directives calling for a reduction in the content of hydrogen seed in fuels. While I do not agree with the very principle of these directives that the EU determines fuel parameters for member states, I abstained because this vote was merely a codification that does not alter the factual content of the directives, only simplifies them.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. The Council and the Commission met on 25 September and 14 October 2014 when they discussed a proposal to reduce the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. It was agreed to establish an Advisory Working Group to investigate and give its opinion on the proposal. After consideration, the Advisory Working Group unanimously concluded that the proposal only codifies the existing text, without changing its basis, so I supported this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a directive is not a new legislation. It constitutes a unification of legislation in the field of sulphur reduction in certain liquid fuels - Council Directive 1999/32/EC of 26 April 1999 amending Directive 93/12/EEC. The substance of the current rules remains.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstain from voting on the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels (coded text) because it is not complete.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for it. This report comes as part of an effort to simplify and clarify EU law, in order to make it more readable and accessible.  This directive is responsible for setting the maximum permitted sulphur content for heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the EU. These fuels contain high sulphur levels that cause pollution and health problems in humans, which reduce biodiversity and harm agriculture and forests. This text will contribute to the fight against pollution and acidification, which damage our environment.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that the Consultative Working Party was able to conclude, without dissent, that this proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to reduce the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. This report, which aims to reduce emissions of sulphur dioxide by setting maximum sulphur levels for heavy fuel oil and gas oils, such as heating oil and light gas oils used by ships, is limited to a mere codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of a directive of the EP and the Council on the reduction of sulphur content in certain liquid fuels. The aim of this proposal is only to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report to reduce the amount of sulphur in some liquids.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The pollution of the atmosphere suffers from it is very harmful to human health. The directive in question sets the maximum rate of sulphur that marine fuel boats reject. As this text is not harmful, I found it appropriate. As a result, I voted for it.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the proposal for a Directive by the European Parliament and of the Council on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. The EU's air quality targets remain unmet. Air pollution is one of the main environmental concerns facing citizens. The EU should be aware of the significant negative public health effects caused by the high sulphur content of certain liquid fuels.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it concerns the codification texts regarding pollution and emissions from shipping-related activities in the form of sulphur dioxide, which harms health and the environment.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I have spoken in favour of the outright codification of the european Parliament and Council's proposal for a directive on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. There have been no substantive changes to this proposal for a directive. Codification has the dual merit of clarity and brevity. It allows users to consult only one authentic text and reduces the volume of the "Community acquis" which brings together all the binding legal acts adopted by the European institutions.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the codification of the report on the reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels because I am in agreement with the codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of the sulpin content of certain liquid fuels. In the opinion of the Advisory Working Party composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal contains a simple consolidated text without any substantive amendment. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that Parliament agree with the proposal amended in accordance with the recommendations of that advisory working group. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This directive sets out the maximum permitted sulphur content for heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the EU. Emissions from marine fuel vessels are high in sulphur, contributing to air pollution and harming human health. In addition, acidification and release of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere damage fragile ecosystems, reduce biodiversity and harm agriculture and forests.  This text is a codification with a constant right. It participates in a necessary fight against pollution and acidification, which damage our environment. It must therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report on the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels which serves to codify existing texts without substantive amendments.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Ferrara report is part of a process of simplifying and clarifying EU law in order to make it more readable and accessible to the public as well as to lawyers. It stems from a welcome desire for transparency. This proposal specifically focuses on changing trade rules to help developing countries in their fight against the following pandemics: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. In that it only changes at the margins and for clarity a beneficial mechanism in the development of third countries, as well as in the fight against deadly diseases, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report in that it is only intended to codify a proposal for a directive by the European Parliament and the Council, concerning a reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels, without changing the content of the text.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for the directive on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The Legal System of the European Union directly affects European citizens, which is why it is essential that it is comprehensible and transparent to all. Particular attention should also be paid to the three legislative institutions, the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council. As a Member of the European Parliament, I feel obliged to adopt proposals that serve this purpose. For example, the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the reduction of the sulpin content of certain liquid fuels.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that aims to reduce the emissions of sulphur dioxide as a result of combustion of certain types of liquid fuels and thereby to reduce the negative effects of such emissions on man and the environment. These reductions in emissions will be achieved by imposing limits on the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels as a condition for their use within the territory of the Member States.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 This Directive lays down the maximum permitted sulphur content of heavy fuel oil, diesel fuel, naval engine fuel and naval diesel fuel used in the Union. Emissions from maritime transport through the combustion of high sulphur marine fuels contribute to air pollution by sulphur dioxide and particulate matter, which harms human health and the environment and contributes to acid deposition. In the absence of the measures laid down in this Directive, emissions from maritime transport would have been shortly higher than emissions from all terrestrial sources. In order to facilitate the transition to new engine technologies with the potential to ensure further significant emission reductions in the maritime sector, the Commission should also explore other possibilities to enable and encourage the use of gas-powered engines on ships. In accordance with existing guidelines on State aid for the protection of the environment, Member States may grant State aid to operators affected by this Directive, including aid for operations to modernise existing vessels, provided that such aid is considered compatible with the internal market.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I do not think there are any objections to the present codification of the existing legal situation. I therefore agree with this proposal.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The report regulates the sulphur content of the combustion of certain liquid fuels in order to reduce harmful air pollution. It is a codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the codification of existing texts on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels is useful, I am voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a directive on reducing the sulphur content of certain types of liquid fuel, as it is necessary to limit environmental pollution. By strengthening commitments to environmental protection and related standards, the report represents an important step in the right direction.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒Council Directive 1999/32/EC has been substantially amended several times, and according to the agreement between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the codification process had to be carried out. The basic version of the Directive itself seeks to reduce the emission of sulphur dioxide generated by the combustion of a certain type of liquid fuels, thereby reducing the harmful effects of such emissions on man and the environment. The Directive lays down the maximum permissible sulphur content of heavy fuel oil, gas oil, marine gas oil and marine diesel oil used in the Union.  Given the limitation of sulphur content in heavy fuel oil, codification shall be carried out with a view to ensuring the compatibility of a Union act with international law, as well as ensuring the proper implementation of new globally established standards for sulphur within the Territory of the Union. The codified directive should, following the implementation of codification, comply with the revised Appendix VI of the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships as amended by the 1978 Protocol and containing regulations to prevent air pollution from ships. The amended Annex VI protocol entered into force on 1 July 2010 so that due to the need for greater legal certainty for obliged entities in implementing the obligations of the convention on the territory of the Union, I support this codification.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This directive sets out the maximum permitted sulphur content for heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the EU. Emissions from marine fuel vessels are high in sulphur, contributing to air pollution and harming human health. In addition, acidification and release of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere damage fragile ecosystems, reduce biodiversity and harm agriculture and forests. To the extent that this is merely codification and the codified text contributes to the fight against pollution and acidification, which damage our environment, I have no reason to oppose it and I therefore vote for this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. \u2012 The European Commission's Directive 1999/32 aim to reduce sulphur content in certain liquid fuels is to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions generated by the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels, thereby reducing the harmful impact of such emissions on man and the environment. These reductions in sulphur dioxide emissions will be achieved by imposing restrictions on sulphur content due to the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels, which creates a condition for their use on the territory of the Member States. Sulphur dioxide emissions are one of the causes of acidification and particle formation in the European Union, cause acid rains that pollute forests, rivers, lakes and other natural resources, and are one of the factors that cause damage to ecosystems, biodiversity and human health. For this reason, I support the codification text of the European Parliament and the Council on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The report endorses the Commission's codification on Directive 1999/32/EC on the subject. It is a number of amendments which have little amendment to the Commission's proposal, which in turn is limited to formal amendments to the text: nomenclature amendments and articulation with other documents.  In essence, the Directive aims to control the amount of sulphur that ships use in their fuels for the damage they inflict on the environment, by means of a check done during navigation but also when they are moored.  It proposes fuel alternatives, sets the percentages of sulphur in fuels, proposes dissuasive, proportionate and effective penalties for vessels using this compound in their fuels. It also defines the maximum level of these fuels that can be used in the EECs of the Member States.  We voted in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I support my colleague Ferrara's report. With its environmental policy, the European Union is tasked with achieving a satisfactory level of air quality, primarily to preserve the health of its inhabitants. Sulphur is an element of very widespread use in industry, as certain shares are found in certain liquid fuels used in shipping on EU territory. Delaying the reduction in the percentage of sulphur in fuel will result in ships becoming more air pollutants than all land sources combined. The proposal for a directive encourages environmental awareness and I consider it necessary to reduce the percentage of sulphur content in liquid fuels and to encourage the use of other renewable energy sources, such as electricity. Despite all efforts to change the situation, a significant proportion of EU residents live in areas where air quality standards are still exceeded and pollution is at a high level, which is particularly harmful to residents with respiratory problems. While methods of reducing sulphur emissions will require large financial expenditures, it will also have a major impact on the environment and human health.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to codify the text on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. Codification is a continental legal tradition, which consists of bringing together into a single new text a piece of legislation and all its amendments.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. The purpose of this Directive is to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels and thereby mitigate the harmful effects of these emissions on man and the environment. To this do so, the report lays down, for example, the maximum sulphur content allowed for heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel oil used in the Union.  The report also states that the reduction of sulphur dioxide emissions from the combustion of certain liquid fuels derived from oil should be achieved by imposing limits on the sulphur content of those fuels as a condition for being used in the territory, territorial seas, exclusive economic zones and pollution control areas of the Member States. I welcome the presentation of this report and i would like to vote in favour of it because, without the measures introduced therein, emissions from maritime transport could soon exceed emissions from all land sources.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 It is only the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive changes.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution which is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The purpose of this directive is to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels and thereby reduce the harmful effects of these emissions on humans and the environment. Acidification and release of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere damage fragile ecosystems, reduce biodiversity, reduce the value of amenity, and harm crops and forest growth. Sulphur dioxide pollution can also have important effects on human health, especially among the population suffering from respiratory conditions. The adopted text, which I supported, therefore sets out the maximum permitted sulphur content of heavy fuel oils, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the Union.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this document. Increasing fuel quality, at least until we have implemented or developed sufficiently powerful fuel-free alternatives, for example, until we have implemented or developed sufficiently powerful fuel-free alternatives, for example. solar energy is an important means of cleanlinessing the environment. At the same time, I call on the Commission to bear in mind that nature does not recognise borders, and environmental quality must therefore be achieved not only in the EU, but also in the rest of the planet. I therefore call for these fuel quality issues to be included and on the EU's agenda for relations with the rest of the world.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this report codifying a directive on reducing the sulphur content of certain fuels.  The proposed codified directive aims to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels and thereby reduce the harmful effects of these emissions on humans and the environment. In particular, it sets the maximum permitted sulphur content for heavy fuel oils, diesel oil, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the EU. The EU and the various Member States are part of the EEC-UN Convention of 13 November 1979 on long-range cross-border air pollution. This Convention, and in particular its protocols, has undergone changes in recent years to which the Union must adapt, in line with its international commitments, but also to pursue its objectives of environmental protection and public health.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, concerning a proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council, on the reduction of sulphur in the content of some liquid fuels. The new Directive will replace the various acts incorporated into it; the proposal fully respects the content of the codified texts and, therefore, only compiles those formal modifications required by the encoding operation itself. According to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a direct codification of the existing texts without any substantial amendment thereof. The proposed Directive aims to reduce the emission of sulphur dioxide resulting from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels and thus reduce the harmful effects of such emissions on humans and the environment.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. We have to look after the environment. That is why we must limit the sulphur content of fuel. Only in this way can we reduce the harmful effects of such emissions. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I have decided to vote in favour of this report because it represents a technical improvement in legislation in the field of emissions of certain liquid fuels. Specifically, this act compilations amendments to the regulation affecting fuels mainly used in shipbuilding and groups all Member States' obligations in the control and supervision of these emissions within their waters. An improvement in the legislative framework in the field of transport emissions is necessary to ensure that there are no scandals such as those related to the automotive sector. Since it is a technical codification which integrates into a single legislative act the basic act and its subsequent amendments which, in this case, does not imply any substantial change in its content, I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report codifies existing Directive 1999/32/EC on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels, without making any substantial changes. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this codification of the directive relating to a reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels, as it contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any changes in their substance, and the subject of the directive contributes to our need to have better air quality and reduce pollution.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: In writing \ u2012 The objective of this Directive is to reduce emissions of sulphur dioxide resulting from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels, thereby limiting the harmful effects of these emissions on humans and the environment. This vote was a proposal where the subject matter is only a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without changing their substance. I therefore agreed with this proposal.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. I supported this regulation as it represents a step forward in reducing the harmful environmental impacts of sulphur dioxide. Any decrease in sulphur in the atmosphere also reduces its harmful effects on eco-systems, crop production and forest growth, as well as reducing the occurrence of acid rains. Today, there is technology to enable this innovation, and studies have shown that the benefits of reducing sulphur dioxide in certain liquid fuels, primarily used by ships, will be greater than the projected costs of industry. The success of this initiative also requires the engagement of the Member States of the Union, in order to ensure frequent and accurate sampling of marine fuels on the market and control on the ships itself, from the control of logs to the delivery points of certain fuels. In addition to controls, analyses of the cost-effectiveness of maritime transport should be made and the development of this transport should be promoted against land transport, as land transport in any case creates more traffic congestion and is the opposite of the Union's climate change objectives.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I agreed with the Commission's proposal adjusting the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels, as this is mainly a codification of earlier legislative texts. This proposal for a directive can be supported because, according to the EP Legal Services Consultative Working Group, the subject of that proposal is only a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without changing their substance. This Directive aims to reduce emissions of sulphur dioxide generated by the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels. This is also expected to reduce the adverse effects that emissions have on human health and the quality of the environment. The modification of the Directive is also intended to bring the Union's legal texts into line with international law concerning new global standards on the amount of sulphur in the environment. In addition, the Directive is to set maximum levels of permitted sulphur content in heavy fuels, natural gas or marine fuels. For these reasons, I hope that the proposed directive will contribute to reducing discharges of harmful substances into the environment.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The purpose of the proposed directive is to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions from the incineration of certain types of liquid fuel and thus to reduce the harmful effects of these emissions on man and the environment. This Directive establishes a maximum sulphur content of heavy fuel oil, gas oil, gas oil for vessels and diesel oil for vessels used in the European Union. It is important to reduce the sulphur content at EU level overall, as environmental acidification is a cross-border phenomenon. Codifying regulations aims to simplify and clarify EU law. In this case, the codification of Council Directive 1999/32/EC of 26 April 1999 on the reduction of the sulphur content of certain types of liquid fuel amending Directive 93/12/EEC may be considered. According to the Consultative Group of Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal is a codification of existing texts without any significant changes in their content. For this purpose, I voted in plenary to support the report and therefore supported the proposal for a directive.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. 2012 Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on the accelerated method of work for the formal codification of legislative texts, the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs and since, according to the Advisory Group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes, I supported the report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ This report deals with the codification of the rules in the already existing Commission Regulation 1999/32/EC of 26 April 1999 concerning the reduction of sulphur in certain liquid fuels, as well as the supplementation of Regulation 93/12/EEC. In the preamble to the codified version of the Regulation, the point specified under number 30 should be inserted between point 39 and 40. As a result, points numbered between 31 and 39 should be renumbered from 30 to 38 and the previous point 30 should be renumbered to point 39. The text in Article 20 should be replaced by the following text: 'The Regulation will enter into force on the twentieth day following its publication in the official journal of the European Union'. This proposal is a simple codification of a Regulation in which its substance does not change. I support this proposal because I think it will make the content of the Regulation clearer, allowing for a better and more concrete application of the Regulation.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ It has been concluded that this is a straightforward codification of existing text, without any change to the substance, and therefore I voted in favour.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This proposal is limited simply to codifying existing texts, without modifying their substance. That is why we voted in favour of the report, adopting the position as adapted on the basis of the recommendations of the Legal Services Advisory Group.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the reduction of the sulpin content of liquid fuels, which supports the related Commission codification process. The Commission's proposal takes account of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated method of working for the formal ffrafting of legislative texts. The Directive merges a number of acts and seeks to reduce sulphur dioxide emissions for certain liquid fuels. I believe that every step we take in this direction can reduce the amount of harmful substances that are harmful to people and the environment. For example, the Directive sets the maximum sulphur content in the European Union for heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel. It defines this by allowing member states and regional derogations where environmental conditions permit, or by making concessions for combustion plants which comply with emission limits of Directives 2001/80/EC and 2010/75/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council. With all this, I believe that we can ensure the principle of gradation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ferrara's text, in line with the opinion of the experts in our political group.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Sulphur, which is naturally present in small quantities in petroleum and coal, is harmful to man and to the environment when combusted. In fact, it has been recognised that emissions of sulphur dioxide are one of the causes of acidification and particle formation in the EU, and are one of the factors causing damage to ecosystems, biodiversity and human health. This is why I voted for this proposed directive, which suggests reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. I hope this will be a step forward in protecting our health, our ecosystems and biodiversity.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I supported this report because I think this proposal will contribute to the protection of the environment and people. Sulphur has been shown to be present in small quantities in oil and is the main source of sulphur dioxide emissions, which is one of the main causes of acid rain and air pollution. In addition to directly affecting the air quality that surrounds us, reducing the sulphur content is perhaps even more important because with the application of motor fuels with very little or practically no sulfur, highly developed and sophisticated engine exhaust after-treatment systems can be successfully applied.  I come from a country that is extremely rich in flora and fauna and for which it is important that such proposals are adopted. This will ensure better living conditions for our descendants and preserve the diversity of biological life, as well as the beauty of the environment.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on reducing the sulphur content of certain types of liquid fuel, as it is an important directive that interferes with the area of regulating air pollution, which is one of the main concerns relating to the environment facing European citizens. Unfortunately, a large proportion of the European population lives in areas where the EU's air quality objectives are still not fully achieved. I believe that the proposed directive represents an even greater effort to ensure higher air quality and natural living conditions throughout the Union. The latter directive will also take us one step closer to innovative and efficient use of resources.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, concerning a proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council, on the reduction of sulphur in the content of some liquid fuels. The new Directive will replace the various acts incorporated into it; the proposal fully respects the content of the codified texts and, therefore, only compiles those formal modifications required by the encoding operation itself. According to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a direct codification of the existing texts without any substantial amendment thereof. The proposed Directive aims to reduce the emission of sulphur dioxide resulting from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels and thus reduce the harmful effects of such emissions on humans and the environment.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This directive sets the maximum permitted sulphur content for heavy fuel oil, diesel, marine diesel and marine diesel used in the EU. Emissions from marine fuel vessels are high in sulphur, contributing to air pollution and harming human health. In addition, acidification and release of sulphur dioxide into the atmosphere damage fragile ecosystems, reduce biodiversity and harm agriculture and forests. I therefore vote for this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Legislative texts should be formal consolidated, as in this case the Advisory Working Group composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission examined the proposal submitted by the Commission. As a result of the examination of the proposal, the Advisory Working Party unanimously concluded that the proposal included a simple consolidated text without any substantive amendment. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, concerning a proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council, on the reduction of sulphur in the content of some liquid fuels. The new Directive will replace the various acts incorporated into it; the proposal fully respects the content of the codified texts and, therefore, only compiles those formal modifications required by the encoding operation itself. According to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a direct codification of the existing texts without any substantial amendment thereof. The proposed Directive aims to reduce the emission of sulphur dioxide resulting from the combustion of certain types of liquid fuels and thus reduce the harmful effects of such emissions on humans and the environment.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical report as this is official codification of legislative texts; the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive concerning the reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. The report demands for the reduction of emissions of sulphur dioxide resulting from the use of certain types of liquid fuels. The final aim is to reduce the harmful effects of these emissions on the population and the environment. The suggested method to achieve such a goal is to impose limits on the sulphur content of such fuels as a condition for their use within Member States’ land and sea territory. The report strives towards a healthier and more ecological environment.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. By this decision, the European Parliament, considering that according to the Advisory Group on legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes, proceeds to approve at first reading the Commission's proposal as adapted to the recommendations of the European Parliament's Legal Services advisory group Council and the Commission. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that decision.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'This report regulates the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels in order to reduce harmful air pollution. This is a simple codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded in its opinion that this proposal is based on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments, and therefore approval is justified.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. There are no objections to codification. There will be no changes in content. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. The text merely involves a recoding of the existing regulations without going beyond the previous regulatory content.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Laura Ferrara's report on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs. The draft submitted shall take account of the relevant opinion of the competent legal services of Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. Emissions from the combustion of fuels for high sulphur craft pollute air with sulphur dioxide and particulate matter, which harm human health and the environment and contribute to the formation of acidic sediments.  The existing Council Directive 1999/32/EC, which sets a maximum sulphur content for marine fuels, has been substantially amended several times and is therefore opaque.  As I believe that it is necessary to maintain air quality, which will not have major negative effects on human health and the environment and will not endanger them, I supported the proposal for a new Directive, which brings a transparent and clear regulatory framework.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has always played a key role in simplifying access for developing countries to essential medicines through innovative trade policies. Providing medicines for countries that are already in serious economic condition is undoubtedly a fundamental objective. The proposal to codify the existing legislation in this field, in accordance with Article 103 of the Regulation, categorically prohibits substantial changes to the rules, i.e. they may affect their meaning or scope. I therefore voted in favour of codification, because making the framework clear and uniform will undoubtedly make it possible to achieve the proposed objectives more effectively.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. Despite being a mere codification, I have opposed this report in order to make clear my opposition to the base regulation, which has failed to ensure access to medicines in developing countries. We cannot make progress merely with voluntary commitments from multinationals and a framework that privileges the protection of pharmaceutical patents over access to generics.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report which is a codification dossier. Simply put, codification means that they unify fragmented and updated modifications into one instrument, enhancing legal clarity. No substantial changes were made to the codified text. Therefore, and specifically because it enhances legal clarity, we voted in favour of this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This proposal is a simple codification of existing texts, without amendment to the substance, and I am voting in favour of its adoption

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The proposal codifies trade rules to help poor countries fight AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis. The regulation prohibits the re-export to Europe of medicines sold at low prices in these countries. So I voted for this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This is a consolidation of regulations into a proposed codified regulation that claims to serve the purpose of preventing tiered priced medical products from being import to the EU. I voted against this measure because it was more legislation that the UK would have to adapt. I believe that the UK should be making its own rules on the tiered pricing of medical products.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted for this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the diversion of trade in certain basic medicinal products to the European Union, which is intended solely to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 953/2003 of the Council of 26 May 2003, which provides for trade rules to help poor countries in their fight against one of three pandemics: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, which kill millions of people every year. Indeed, the regulation establishes a mechanism to prevent low-priced medicines from being re-exported to the European Union. The regulation prohibits the entry into EU customs territory of products approved as products that are priced at different prices and have therefore been exported as such to a poor country. That is why I voted in favour of this report, which proposes above all to clarify the law in this area.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In the interests of clarity and transparency, the purpose of this proposal, which I have approved, is to codify the Council's Regulation (EC) 953/2003 to prevent the diversion of certain essential medicines to EU countries. The proposed new regulation would replace the various acts incorporated into it. It fully preserves its substance and merely groups it together by making the only formal modifications required by the coding operation.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the Ferrara report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at avoiding the diversion to the European Union of certain essential medicinal products.  The aim of the measure, which is of a technical nature, is to codify the existing legislation without making any substantial changes. Here too, considering it essential to facilitate the simplification processes, I have decided to vote in favour of the report, which also follows the recommendations of the Advisory Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at preventing the commercial diversion of some key medicines. The new Regulation will replace the various acts incorporated into it; according to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a direct codification of the existing texts without any substantial amendment thereof. The proposed Regulation, codified by Regulation (EC) No 953/2003, is linked to the Millennium objective of combating pandemics such as HIV, as parallel trade in low-priced prevention medicines for less developed countries is prevented.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 953/2003 of the Council of 26 May 2003, which provides for trade rules to help poor countries in their fight against one of three pandemics: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, of which the deaths number in the millions each year. This regulation sets up a programme to prevent cheap medicines from being re-exported to the European Union. The regulation prohibits the entry into customs territory of the European Union of medicines approved as products subject to different prices that have been exported as such to a poor country. This is only a codification and it encourages the fight against epidemics that are spreading in developing countries. Which leads me to vote for this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Ferrara's report on the diversion of certain essential medicines to the European Union is balanced and I can therefore support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. For the sake of simplification and clarity of EU law to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of this Regulation codating Council Regulation (EC) No 953/2003 of 26 May 2003 to prevent the commercial diversion into the European Union of certain essential medicines. The proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial modification thereof.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to adopt a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at avoiding the diversion of trade in certain basic medicinal products to the European Union. Having regard to the Council decision of 20 December 1994 on the The Interinstitutional Agreement on an accelerated working method for official codification of legislative texts, a consultative working group composed of representatives of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, met on 10 July 2014 to discuss, among others, the above-mentioned proposal submitted by the Commission. Having considered the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council codifying the Council Regulation (EC) No 953/2003 laying down the objective of avoiding the diversion of trade in certain basic medicinal products to the European Union, the Consultative Working Party decided by consensus that the proposal merely aims to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. As with the previous item on the agenda, I have no comment on this. I voted in favour of the proposed resolution on the proposal for a regulation to prevent the diversion of trade in certain key medicines to the European Union. It is only a codification of existing texts which have no substantive changes.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. In the fact that, on the one hand, it is merely codification and, on the other hand, the codified text participates in the fight against epidemics in developing countries, I have no reason to oppose it. I therefore voted for it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the codification of the rules on the diversion of certain essential medicinal products to the European Union makes it possible to eliminate duplication and contributes to the simplification of the legal system.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. Having regard to the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method for the official codification of legislative texts, and having regard in particular to point 4 of that Agreement, , among other things, the proposal in question presented by the Commission, is considered to be due to the approval of this proposal as it does not contain substantial amendments to the Regulation but only codification adjustments.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. The purpose of this motion for a resolution is to codify Council Regulation 653/2003 of 26 May 2003, which provides for favourable trade rules to help least developed countries combat the following three pandemics: AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis. In practical terms, this regulation establishes a mechanism to prevent cheap medicines from being re-exported back to the European Union. The regulation prohibits the entry of products subject to differentiated prices into the CUSTOMS territory of the Union. This codification contributes to the fight against these epidemics, which are responsible for the deaths of millions of people every year. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Protecting the health of its citizens and ensuring a superior quality of medicines were important objectives for the Union. To guarantee them, more attention is needed to the substances that end up being produced, marketed and consumed within its borders. At the marketing stage, the risks to be monitored are related to obtaining the necessary authorisations and establishing the selling markets. Of course, in order to comply with the regulation of these problems, we need to create coherent legislative measures, knowing that the implementation of the legislation can create more problems than issuing them.  That is why this proposal is aimed at improving the legislative act, which I support and voted in favour.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 A purely codification measure on EU legislation separating trade in certain essential medicines in the EU and developing countries. I am voting in favour.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is a codification dossier. Simply put, codification means that they unify fragmented and updated modifications into one instrument, enhancing legal clarity. No substantial changes were made to the codified text. Therefore, and specifically because it enhances legal clarity, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the proposal to codify Council Regulation (EC) No 953/2003, that is, bring together all the amendments that have been made to it over the years in order to make it clearer and more transparent. No change should be made to the substance of the directive.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report expressing the European Parliament's agreement to the codification proposed by the Commission on the diversion of certain essential medicinal products to the European Union. The Community framework in this area has been subject to numerous changes since 2003. Codification in a single text is therefore essential for the rationalisation and clarity of the provisions.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, which aims to avoid the diversion of trade in certain basic medicinal products to the European Union

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for the reconditioning of existing texts on essential medicinal products allows for a greater order of codification and therefore an improvement in regulatory consultation without, on the other hand, any substantial changes. That is why it was easy to vote in favour of this proposal.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Many factors may influence to what extent medicines are available and accessible to the populations of developing countries. Numerous important factors come to play to determine price of medicines: taxes and import tariffs, distribution mark—ups, lack of an efficient procurement system, etc. Scientific and technological innovation has significantly improved the treatment of human diseases.
