Intellectual property stimulates pharmaceutical companies to invest money to develop and produce new and better medicines. Bringing a medicine to market is a long and complex process that is very costly and takes many years to complete. Without the prospect of return on their investments, pharmaceutical companies will not allocate large budgets to more research and development. Patent protection can lead to higher prices by delaying the supply of cheaper generic alternatives. Hence, the argument is often made that patents on medicines restrict access to treatment for citizens in low—income developing countries. However, developing countries are increasingly using patents to protect their innovative companies’ efforts and help them compete more effectively on global markets.  The EU seeks to strike the right balance between the need to promote and finance the research of new and better medicines and to ensure that medicines are accessible to those in need.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Simplification and clarification of EU law is a central objective of the EU. Making it more accessible and easier for ordinary citizens to understand will allow these new opportunities and the possibility to benefit from the specific rights assigned to them. The dispersion of numerous provisions, amended on several occasions, often substantially (a fact which requires a reading of both the original act and the acts amending it), means that, for the sake of legal clarity and transparency, the rules must be codified. I support the Ferrara Report which codifies Council Regulation 953/2003 to prevent the diversion of certain essential medicines into the EU and which does not make substantive changes to existing texts, and the new Regulation replaces the various acts integrated into it.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report for the simple reason that the proposal in question is limited to the codification of existing texts, without any substantial changes being made to it.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a technical procedure provided for in Article 103 of the Regulation to verify that the codification proposal is in fact limited to mere codification, without any substantial changes. Each codification proposal is examined in advance by the legal services of the Commission, the Council and Parliament. Vote.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. Despite being a mere codification, I have opposed this report in order to make clear my opposition to the base regulation, which has failed to ensure access to medicines in developing countries. We cannot make progress merely with voluntary commitments from multinationals and a framework that privileges the protection of pharmaceutical patents over access to generics.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Developing countries have a high number of people suffering from communicable diseases. Since certain medicines necessary to treat these diseases are not produced in the territory of developing countries and in order to ensure the right of individuals to quality healthcare, the European Union provides that the prices of essential pharmaceutical products exported to those Countries are adapted to the purchasing possibilities.  I hope that by codifying the texts governing these European decisions in a single regulation and without any substantive changes to these European decisions, support for people for access to adapted pharmaceutical products will be maintained.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 In view of the nature of the document, which is limited to simply harmonising existing legal texts, without changing them in substance, I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it contains a straightforward codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 953/2003 of 26 May 2003 to avoid trade diversion into the European Union of certain key medicines without any change in the substance.  As this is an already—existing text, and has already been approved by the respective legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission as stipulated in the interinstitutional agreement of 20 December 1994, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This codification is part of a process of simplifying and clarifying EU law in order to make it more readable and accessible. In addition, the text contributes to the fight against epidemics in developing countries. For these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I supported this codification because it does not contain problematic or controversial text. In the present case, it is a merger of existing texts, without altering the substance of the legal acts.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Positive because it concerns imperative. Proper drug pricing also helps lower strata of the population to access them. It has been known for many years that pharmaceutical multinationals have been playing with the sale of medicines at low prices and their introduction through third routes in Europe at high prices.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: in writing. This proposal is codified by Regulation (EC) No 953/2003, which is intended to prevent the commercial diversion into the European Union of certain essential medicines. The codification provides legal certainty with respect to the applicable law in a given area and time. Such codification must be carried out in full compliance with the procedure for the adoption of Union acts and to that effect the advisory group established, by common agreement, that the proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantial amendments thereof.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 on an accelerated working method for the official codification of legislative texts, the Advisory Group held meetings to examine the above-mentioned proposal presented by the Commission. The analysis thus made it possible to conclude, by common agreement, that the proposal under consideration is effectively based on a pure and simple codification of the existing texts, without substantive changes.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour because the codified text is part of the fight against epidemics in developing countries.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The report supports a codification of Regulation 953/2003/EEC of 26 May 2003. The Commission merely codifies the texts that exist without substantive changes in the general text: essentially, nomenclature changes and articulation with other documents. This is an eminently technical report. As far as the facts are concerned, the Regulation addresses the diversion of essential medicinal products to the European Union and the implementation of the necessary control. Essential medicines are those that are necessary for certain serious diseases, such as ISIS and tuberculosis, and which the countries with the most economic difficulties are not able to acquire. For this reason, different prices are set for those medicines for the least developed countries. The Regulation aims at the implementation of control mechanisms, fines and sanctions to prevent countries or the pharmaceutical industry from taking advantage of this price differentiation, reselling them and generating profit in this exchange.  Among other measures, it enables seized medicines to be used for countries that need them as humanitarian aid. It also provides for penalties imposed on the importer or any other person responsible for the attempted illicit importation. We voted in favour.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report aimed at avoiding the diversion to the EU of certain essential medicines.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council to avoid diverting trade in certain basic medicinal products to the European Union, because there is an urgent need for proper pricing of medicines, while also helping the lower strata of the population to have access to them.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal, as it contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at avoiding the diversion to the European Union of certain essential medicinal products because I am in favour of codification of existing texts that guarantees legal certainty and ease of understanding of the same. I believe that the Commission's decision to request the codification of those legislative texts that have undergone numerous major changes over the years since their first adoption goes in the right direction with regard to the clarity and transparency of EU law. Council Regulation (EC) No 953/2003 of 26 May 2003, which aims to ensure that developing countries supply medicines against communicable diseases at graduated prices and to prevent these low-cost medicines from ending up on the European market, is an important part of EU legislation on medicines.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The regulation ensures that even the poorest countries have access to basic medicines by allowing for sharply reduced prices.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable in Wales and the rest of the United Kingdom

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at preventing the commercial diversion of some key medicines. The new Regulation will replace the various acts incorporated into it; according to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a direct codification of the existing texts without any substantial amendment thereof. The proposed Regulation, codified by Regulation (EC) No 953/2003, is linked to the Millennium objective of combating pandemics such as HIV, as parallel trade in low-priced prevention medicines for less developed countries is prevented.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I support this proposal because putting these key medicines in the hands of Europe’s most efficient exporters will be of great help to European citizens who are experiencing health problems and need these medicines to improve. Because of this, trade diversion should absolutely be avoided in this case.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a proposal for a European Council regulation on the avoidance of trade diversion of certain basic medicinal products. It fully respects the substance of the acts to be codified and therefore does nothing more than bring them into contact with only the formal amendments required by the codification process itself (some codifications are linked to the Millennium Goals to combat the AIDS pandemic). Due to the procedural/updated nature of the report we voted in favour.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, as did the majority of my colleagues. The Consultative Working Party of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed the proposal in question contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance. I firmly believe that there is a need to encourage pharmaceutical manufacturers to make pharmaceutical products available at heavily reduced prices in significantly increased volumes by ensuring through this regulation that such products remain on the poorest developing country markets. It is inappropriate for people or companies to redistribute lower priced pharmaceuticals/tiered-priced products into the Union. Thankfully, this report will provide such security.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe this regulation is necessary to condense the other previous pieces of legislation into one regulation. I also believe this regulation is important as it ensures that the poorest developing countries have access to and are supplied with essential pharmaceutical products at highly reduced rates, and therefore price segmentation is necessary.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The report refers to the avoidance of trade diversion into the European Union of certain key medicines. The proposal is basically a simple codification of existing texts, with no substantial changes to their substance.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council on avoiding the dictation of trade in certain essential medicines into the European Union, as this adopts a position at first reading, and the proposal is only related to codification which does not imply substantive changes.  Codified acts do not change in content, but they are simplified and become clearer and more accessible to citizens. This reduces the need for research work to find the rules in place, and in this context I also support the recommendations of advisory groups of parliament's legal services, the Council and the Commission that have contributed to make EU law more certain and transparent.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Council Regulation (EC) 953/2003 of 26 May 2003, which provides trade rules to help poor countries in their fight against one of three pandemics: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, which kill millions of people every year. Indeed, the regulation establishes a mechanism to prevent low-priced medicines from being re-exported to the European Union. The regulation prohibits the entry into EU customs territory of products approved as products that are priced at different prices and have therefore been exported as such to a poor country. In the sense that, on the one hand, it is merely codification and, on the other hand, the codified text participates in the fight against epidemics in developing countries, we have no reason to oppose it. I then voted in favour of this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Laura Ferrara's report on the European Parliament and Council's proposal for a regulation to prevent the diversion of certain essential medicines to Eu Countries. It is an overhaul of the existing texts for the sake of clarity without changing the substance of them. The purpose of this text concerns the establishment of reduced prices for medicines in developing countries that often do not have the capacity to manufacture medicines. But these are sometimes illegally returned to the original market at the same price. I therefore agree with this text, which wants to prevent these medicinal products from being imported into the Union.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. Mrs Ferrara's report deals with a proposal for a Commission regulation on the diversion of certain essential medicines to EU countries.  There is indeed a difference in the price-fixing of essential medicines in the markets of developed countries and those of the poorest developing countries. In order to ensure that they were provided with essential pharmaceuticals at sharply reduced prices, it was necessary to codify rules to prevent essential medicines subject to differentiated prices from being imported into the EU. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. This is a codification of the existing legal situation, which there are no objections. I am therefore voting in favour of the proposal.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as the proposal contains a straightforward codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 This report concerns a proposal for a Council Regulation to prevent the diversion of trade in certain key medicines to the European Union. A large number of poor developing countries face difficulties in providing access to basic medicines to treat edible diseases. These countries are heavily dependent on drug imports because local production is not sufficient to meet the requirements. Price differences in developed and developing countries' markets are evident, so there is a need to ensure access for developing countries to basic medicines for the treatment of communicable diseases at an affordable price. It is necessary to avoid redirecting products sold at reduced prices to developing markets to developed markets where products are sold at higher prices. The aim of this Regulation is to avoid such a procedure and to prevent the import of tiered priced products into the EU so that they remain on the markets of the poorest developing countries. It is therefore appropriate to support the proposal for a regulation as it is important to establish procedures to identify products, countries and diseases falling within the scope of this Regulation.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it deals with the procedural aspects of the codification of the regulation 953/2003 of the 26 May 2003 to avoid trade diversion into the European Union of certain key medicines. The proposal contains straightforward codification without any change in the substance of the existing regulation.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the diversion of certain essential medicines to European Union countries. This is a codification that intervenes in an effort to simplify and clarify the regulation of the European Union in order to make it more readable and accessible. The purpose of this proposal is to codify a regulation that includes trade rules to help poor countries in their fight against AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, which kill millions each year. Indeed, the regulation establishes a mechanism to prevent low-priced medicines from being re-exported to the European Union. The regulation prohibits the entry into EU customs territory of products approved as products that are priced at different prices and have therefore been exported as such to a poor country.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it favours the codification of a text that fights against certain epidemics.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. This proposal aims to codify Regulation (EC) 953/2003, which addresses trade rules governing the fight against AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria in poor countries, three major pandemics that kill millions of people each year. This regulation is intended to regulate the sale of low-priced medicines and to prevent diversion of these products away from poor countries. As a result, I voted for this text.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. Despite being a mere codification, I have opposed this report in order to make clear my opposition to the base regulation, which has failed to ensure access to medicines in developing countries. We cannot make progress merely with voluntary commitments from multinationals and a framework that privileges the protection of pharmaceutical patents over access to generics.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, after examining the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at preventing the commercial diversion into the European Union of certain essential medicines, decided, by common agreement, that the proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts , without substantial modifications thereof. All the entities consulted agree that the proposal in question is limited to one encoding. In the same regard, the Committee of the Regions and the Committee on Legal Affairs spoke. In these terms, I welcome the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at preventing the commercial diversion into the European Union of certain essential medicines in which certain essential medicines are made to a pure codification of existing texts.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. Regardless of the substance of the 2003 regulation on preventing imports of certain medicines into the EU, this is only a codification, that is, a simplification of the text, which does not alter the substance of the regulation in force.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The proposal for a resolution by the European Parliament and the Council concerns price differences in certain key medicines between developed and poorest countries. The poorest countries need to be provided with access to primary pharmaceutical products at reduced prices, but abuse of this system should be prevented. I supported the proposal for a resolution by clearly defining the instruments and methods of controlling the trade in medicines in order to help the poorest, but also to prevent fraud on the EU market.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council to avoid diverting trade in certain basic medicinal products to the European Union (coded text) because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for it. As with the previous report, this text is part of an effort to simplify and clarify EU law, in order to make it more readable and accessible. The relevant regulation provides for trade rules to help poor countries in their fight against one of three pandemics: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, which kill millions of people every year. This text will contribute to the fight against epidemics in developing countries.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a reduction in the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels, which is intended solely to codify existing texts without changing their substance.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that avoids diverting the trade of certain key medicines.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The proposal codifies trade rules aimed at helping poor countries fight three major diseases: AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis. In short, the regulation prohibits the re-export to Europe of specially sold medicines at differentiated prices in those countries, the codified text to be used to combat these diseases which prevail in many developing states, as a result, I voted in favour.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council to prevent the diversion of certain essential medicinal products into the European Union. It is necessary to codify the rules which have been frequently changed, and it is therefore essential to simplify and clarify EU law for reasons of legal certainty.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution as it concerns the codification texts regarding blocking the importing of tiered-price medicine into the Union, as well as encouraging pharmaceutical companies to make drugs available at heavily reduced prices to the poorest developing countries.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that an examination of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 953/2003 of 26 May 2003 to avoid trade diversion into the European Union of certain key medicines resulted in the Consultative Working Party’s concluding, without dissent, that the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I supported the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council codifying the Council Regulation (EC) 953/2003 of 26 May 2003 to prevent the diversion of certain essential medicines to european Union countries, as this proposal does not in any way alter the substance. The codification of the "community acquis" improves the accessibility of EU legislation. It has the merit of clarity, efficiency and brevity. It provides better legal certainty and improves the quality of texts.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the codification of the report on the trade diversion into the European Union of certain key medicines because I am in agreement with the codification of the existing texts without any change in their substance

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the avoidance of diversion of trade in certain essential medicinal products to the European Union. In the opinion of the Advisory Working Party composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal contains a simple consolidated text without any substantive amendment. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs recommends that Parliament agree with the proposal amended in accordance with the recommendations of that advisory working group. I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The purpose of the text is to codify Regulation (EC) 953/2003 of the Council of 26 May 2003, which sets up trade rules to help poor countries in their fight against one of three pandemics: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. Indeed, the regulation establishes a mechanism to prevent low-priced medicines from being re-exported to the European Union. It prohibits the entry into EU customs territory of products approved as products that are priced at different prices and have therefore been exported as such to a poor country.  This text can therefore be supported.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. In view of the urgent need of many of the poorest developing countries to have access to essential medicines for the treatment of communicable diseases at affordable prices, these countries are overly dependent on drug imports. It is crucial to introduce price differentiation between the markets of developed countries and the markets of the poorest developing countries in order to ensure that they have access to essential drugs at very low prices. There are currently legislative and regulatory instruments in most developed countries to prevent the import of pharmaceutical products in certain circumstances. However, there is a risk that these mechanisms will be insufficient in view of the possible economic interest of diverting these products to higher-priced markets. It is essential to establish a mechanism for identifying the products, countries and diseases covered by this Regulation, which aims to prevent imports into the Union of products with differentiated prices. I support the rapporteur's position on the adoption by manufacturers of a different presentation of the products so that they are easily identifiable, and I consider it essential to review the lists of diseases and countries of destination covered by the Regulation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The Ferrara report is part of a process of simplifying and clarifying EU law, in order to make it more readable and accessible to the public as well as to lawyers. It stems from a welcome desire for transparency. This proposal specifically focuses on changing trade rules to help developing countries in their fight against the following pandemics: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. In that it only changes at the margins and for clarity a beneficial mechanism in the development of third countries as well as in the fight against deadly diseases, I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report in that it is only intended to codify a proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council, with the aim of preventing the diversion of certain essential medicines to the countries of the European Union, without altering the content of the text.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for the regulation to prevent the diversion of certain essential medicines to EU countries.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the avoidance of the diversion of trade in certain essential medicines to the European Union proposes to implement small changes which have no impact on the content of the existing legislation, but which, by their application, will give us a simpler and clearer text. The European Parliament's priority is to increase the clarity of legislation, which is why I have decided to cast my vote in favour of this report.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Council Regulation (EC) 953/2003 adopted in May 2003 was intended to increase the availability of pharmaceuticals covering treatments for HIV/AIDs, tuberculosis and malaria in the poorest developing countries. More than 10 years after the regulation’s adoption, the mechanism created has been used only to a limited extent by one company only. I have voted for this report that should supply medicines at sustainable low prices to poor and developing countries in the fight against major diseases.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation aims to prevent products with differentiated prices from being imported into the Union. Derogations are provided for certain situations, provided that the final destination of the products concerned is one of the countries listed in Annex II to this Regulation. Many of the poorest developing countries urgently need access, at affordable prices, to medicines essential for the treatment of communicable diseases. Those countries are heavily dependent on imports of medicinal products, as their local production is reduced.  It is therefore necessary to set different prices on the markets of developed countries and on the markets of the poorest developing countries in order to ensure that the latter are supplied with essential pharmaceutical products at greatly reduced prices. Consequently, these much reduced prices cannot be considered as a reference for the price to be paid for the same products on the markets of developed countries.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. This is also a codification of the existing legal situation, and I do not think there are any objections to it. I am therefore voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is a codification of existing legislation without any substantive changes.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the existing texts on the diversion of certain essential medicinal products to the European Union are adequate, I am voting in favour of this proposal.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I supported the report because it is important that the world's poorest countries, which are suffering from some of the most serious diseases, have the potential to be supplied with the necessary medicines at the lowest possible price. Unfair commercial practices in the procurement and distribution of medicinal products must be prevented while ensuring a sufficient quantity of medicines for poorer countries.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒The proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council to avoid the dictation of trade in certain essential medicines into the European Union consists only in codifying existing texts without substantive changes.  Adjusting the prices of certain key medicines in the markets of developed countries and the poorest developing countries is necessary to ensure that the poorest countries are supplied with basic pharmaceutical products at cheaper reduced prices. On this basis, enormously low prices cannot be taken as a sample reference for paying for the same products at the same prices in developed countries. The proposed codified Regulation aims to prevent imports of products at a market-lower, harmonised price into the European Union. Exceptions are possible only in emergency situations.  I welcome the Regulation taking into account the socio-economic situation of the poorest developing countries and prioritising the availability of medical medicines to the most vulnerable groups of society.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 953/2003 of the Council of 26 May 2003, which provides for trade rules to help poor countries in their fight against one of three pandemics: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, which kill millions of people every year. Indeed, the regulation establishes a mechanism to prevent low-priced medicines from being re-exported to the European Union. The regulation prohibits the entry into EU customs territory of products approved as products that are priced at different prices and have therefore been exported as such to a poor country. To the extent that this is merely codification and the codified text is involved in the fight against epidemics in developing countries, I agree with this text and vote in favour of it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒Supplying medicines to the poor and developing countries is one of the key objectives in the fight against diseases that are at risk of these countries. To achieve this, the European Commission has consistently advocated a policy of sustainable and low prices for medicines, combined with market segmentation between rich and poor countries. The advantage of such a policy is that it encourages manufacturers to distribute certain key medicines to targeted countries at the lowest possible price, while offsetting R&D expenditure with higher prices charged in developed countries (OECD). This approach promotes the sustainability of stocks and the continuous distribution of medicines to help eliminate those diseases that rule these areas: HIV/AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria. For this reason, I support the codification of the Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council on codifying Council Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013. 953/2003 since 26 May 2003 on avoiding the dictation of trade in certain essential medicines into the European Union, as these diseases pose the greatest challenge to public health and the main obstacle to the development of those countries.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The report supports the codification of Regulation 953/2003/EEC of 26 May 2003. The Commission merely codifies the texts that exist without substantive changes in the text: essentially amendments to the nomenclature and articulation with other documents. The Regulation addresses the diversion of essential medicines to the European Union and the implementation of the necessary control. Essential medicines are those that are necessary for certain serious diseases, such as ISD and tuberculosis, and which the countries with the most economic difficulties cannot acquire. For this reason, different prices are set for those medicines for the least developed countries. The Regulation aims at implementing control mechanisms, fines and sanctions to prevent countries or the pharmaceutical industry from taking advantage of this price differentiation, reselling them and generating profit in this exchange. Among other measures, it enables seized medicines to be used for countries that need them as humanitarian aid. It also provides for penalties imposed on the importer or any other person responsible for the attempted illicit importation. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I fully support my colleague Ferrara's report. In addition to Africa being a symbol of extreme poverty, it is also a symbol of the high level of mortality from transmitted diseases such as AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis. Stopping the spread of infectious diseases is one of the United Nations' millennium goals, and the European Union will contribute to this goal with this Regulation. Mortality caused by AIDS could be reduced by practicing antiretroviral treatment, but the necessary medications are either unavailable or too expensive. Price segmentation is the only fair solution that provides assistance to the inhabitants of the African continent. I support the proposal for a regulation as it introduces a differentiated pricing obligation which means that the price would be set according to the wealth of the country to which the medicine is distributed. No one is at a loss because residents are given medicines that keep them alive, medicines must be constantly produced, and a shortage of money is offset by a higher price of the same drugs in richer countries. But on the other hand, there is a risk of abuse and running a parallel market where medicines destined for underdeveloped countries in the developed would be sold at a higher price. This regulation prevents imports of products with differentiated prices by keeping a list of medicines, countries and formulas for product identification.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to codify the text on the diversion of certain medicines to European Union countries. Codification is a continental legal tradition, which consists of bringing together into a single new text a piece of legislation and all its amendments.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded that this proposal is to be combed to the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments. That is why this report, in which I voted in favour, approves its position at first reading, making its own the Commission's proposal, in the wording resulting from the adaptation to the recommendations of the Advisory Group on legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 It is only the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive changes.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. For the sake of simplification and clarity of EU law to make it more accessible and understandable to the citizen, I voted in favour of this Regulation codating Council Regulation (EC) No 953/2003 of 26 May 2003 to prevent the commercial diversion into the European Union of certain essential medicines. The proposal is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing texts, without any substantial modification thereof.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which, in view of the report of the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, considers that the proposal in question is limited to an outright codification of the existing texts, without altering their substance. Parliament therefore endorsed the Commission's proposal as adapted to the recommendations of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group, the Council and the Commission and instructed its President to convey Parliament's position to the Council and the Commission as well as to the national parliaments.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council setting out the objective of avoiding the diversion of trade in certain basic medicinal products to the European Union. It is extremely non-controversial, but it codifies the list of medicines that are restricted to the EU. I am sure that it will contribute to a more transparent EU market for medicines.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at preventing the commercial diversion of some key medicines. The new Regulation will replace the various acts incorporated into it; according to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a direct codification of the existing texts without any substantial amendment thereof. The proposed Regulation, codified by Regulation (EC) No 953/2003, is linked to the Millennium objective of combating pandemics such as HIV, as parallel trade in low-priced prevention medicines for less developed countries is prevented.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. The poorest developing countries do not have the same amount of resources as developed countries. That is why we must ensure price segmentation when it comes to medicines. It is important that the poorest countries can buy essential medicines at heavily reduced prices. The markets for medicines are very different in the country and in the country. This agreement is trying to take that into account. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. Despite being a mere codification, I have opposed this report in order to make clear my opposition to the base regulation, which has failed to ensure access to medicines in developing countries. We cannot make progress merely with voluntary commitments from multinationals and a framework that privileges the protection of pharmaceutical patents over access to generics.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report codifies existing Regulation (EC) No 953/2003, which aims to avoid diversion to the European Union of certain essential medicinal products, without making any substantial changes. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this measure because this was a proposal for legislation. UKIP is opposed in principle to the European Parliament making any law which is applicable to the United Kingdom.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This text is a straightforward codification and I see no reason to not vote in favour of it.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution. Many of the poorest developing countries urgently need access to affordable essential medicines to treat contagious diseases. It is necessary to introduce price segmentation between the markets of developed countries and those of the poorest developing countries in order to ensure that the poorest developing countries supply basic pharmaceutical products at substantially reduced prices.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the proposal for a regulation on preventing the commercial diversity of essential medicines in the EU, as this is mainly a codification of earlier legislative texts. I agreed with this proposal for a regulation because, according to the EP Legal Services Consultative Working Group, the subject of this proposal is only a clear and simple codification of the existing texts without changing their substance. The new regulation seeks to prevent imports of certain medicines into the EU at prices at which they are traded on markets in developing countries. The price segmentation of certain basic medicines is necessary in order to provide pharmaceutical products for poor developing countries at significantly reduced prices. On the other hand, the price difference between products sold on developing country markets and the rich markets of developed countries should be maintained. The prices at which these particular medicines are sold in poor countries cannot serve as a reference for prices in the EU. To that end, the Regulation lays down criteria for the labelling of products exposed to commercial diversity, the conditions which the customs authorities should fulfil in order to act on the matter and the measures which should be taken by the various authorities of the Member States.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. For the treatment of infectious diseases, poor developing countries have a high need for basic medicines that are affordable. Often, these countries are almost entirely dependent on imported medicines because their local production is not sufficient. Prices need to be distinguished between the markets of developed countries and those of the poorest developing countries. The latter should be provided with basic pharmaceutical products at very reduced prices. However, these prices should not become a reference to the price paid for the same products on the markets of developed countries. The proposed codified regulation aims to prevent products with parallel pricing being imported into the European Union; exceptions are provided for certain circumstances. Codifying regulations aims to simplify and clarify EU law. In this case, the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 953/2003 of 26 May 2003 to prevent the diversion of trade in certain key medicinal products into the European Union may be considered. According to the Consultative Group of Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal is a codification of existing texts without any significant changes in their content. For this very part, I voted in plenary to support the report and therefore supported the proposal for a regulation.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 A different level of drug prices on the market of developed and developing countries is essential. The poorest countries thus have the opportunity to access basic medicines at reduced prices. However, such reduced prices cannot reflect the price of the same medicine in developed countries.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 – Accelerated method of work for formal codification of legislative texts, report of the Committee on Legal Affairs (A8-0038/2016), and since, according to the advisory group of legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited only to codifying existing texts without substantive changes, I supported the report.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ This report deals with the codification of Commission Regulation No 953/2003 of 26 May 2003 concerning the prevention of trade in certain key stocks from being redirected to the European Union. This proposal is a simple codification of a Regulation in which its substance does not change. I support this proposal because I think it will make the content of the Regulation clearer, allowing for a better and more concrete application of the Regulation.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ It has been concluded that this is a straightforward codification of existing text, without any change to the substance, and therefore I voted in favour.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report because of its nature. We do not oppose a common wording of the labelling of essential medicines in the Union, particularly medicines that combat diseases or the AIDS virus.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because, in the opinion of the Advisory Working Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a simple consolidated text without any substantive amendment. The codified text states that price segmentation is needed between the markets of developed countries and the poorest developing countries in order to provide the poorest developing countries with highly reduced-priced basic pharmaceutical products. These prices cannot, of course, be considered as reference prices on the markets of developed countries for the same products. The proposed codified legislation is intended to prevent the import into the Union of tiered priced products, with appropriate exceptions. I consider it an important element that common principles are set out in the legislation, where concrete action can be taken by the customs authorities of the Member States and by the other competent authorities.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament and the Council's proposal for a regulation to prevent the diversion of certain essential medicines to the countries of the European Union.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Suffering from scarce local manufacturing, many of the poorest developing countries are in urgent need of access to affordable essential medicines, which is why pharmaceutical manufacturers have been encouraged to make imported medicine available at heavily discounted prices. While most developed countries have put in place rules to prevent importation of these discounted medicines into their markets, these rules are becoming insufficient when large amounts of discounted medicines are sold. This is discouraging pharmaceutical manufacturers from making this essential price effort. I voted in favour of this proposal to remedy this situation. The regulation will put in place stricter rules to make sure that such medicines remain on the poorest developing country markets and to further encourage pharmaceutical manufacturers to make medicines available at accessible prices.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. I supported this report because I believe it contributes to the protection of the right to the health of every man. I believe that economic differences between different countries must not be an obstacle to the availability of quality and affordable medicines and that citizens of countries of lower economic standards, i.e. lower levels of development, are harmed in terms of their availability.  I am of the opinion that every man has the right to access basic medicines, but it is often the case that countries of lower level of development do not have local production and are extremely dependent on imports.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council to prevent the diversion of certain key medicines to the European Union, as the proposal constitutes a meaningful codification of the texts existing so far, without any substantive changes added, namely the codification of Council Regulation (EC) No 953/2003 of 26 May 2003 to prevent the diversion of trade in certain key medicines to the European Union.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at preventing the commercial diversion of some key medicines. The new Regulation will replace the various acts incorporated into it; according to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a direct codification of the existing texts without any substantial amendment thereof. The proposed Regulation, codified by Regulation (EC) No 953/2003, is linked to the Millennium objective of combating pandemics such as HIV, as parallel trade in low-priced prevention medicines for less developed countries is prevented.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The purpose of this proposal is to codify Regulation (EC) 953/2003 of the Council of 26 May 2003 which provides trade rules to help poor countries in their fight against one of three pandemics: AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria, which kill millions of people every year. Indeed, the regulation establishes a mechanism to prevent low-priced medicines from being re-exported to the European Union. The regulation prohibits the entry into EU customs territory of products approved as products that are subject to differentiated prices and have therefore been exported as such to a poor country. I voted for this proposal.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Legislative texts should be formal consolidated, as in this case the Advisory Working Group composed of the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission examined the proposal submitted by the Commission. As a result of the examination of the proposal, the Advisory Working Party unanimously concluded that the proposal included a simple consolidated text without any substantive amendment. I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at preventing the commercial diversion of some key medicines. The new Regulation will replace the various acts incorporated into it; according to the legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question contains a direct codification of the existing texts without any substantial amendment thereof. The proposed Regulation, codified by Regulation (EC) No 953/2003, is linked to the Millennium objective of combating pandemics such as HIV, as parallel trade in low-priced prevention medicines for less developed countries is prevented.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this technical report as this is official codification of legislative texts; the proposal is a straightforward codification of existing texts, without any change in their substance.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation concerning the diversion into the European Union of certain key medicines. Many of the poorest developing countries are dependent on imports of affordable essential medicines for the treatment of transmissible diseases. Price segmentation between developed country markets and these country markets is necessary to ensure that the poorest countries are supplied with essential pharmaceutical products at significantly reduced prices. The report underlines the need to encourage pharmaceutical companies to make medicines directed to the poorest countries available at greatly reduced prices in significantly increased volumes, in line with the regulation.  It equally states the need for a procedure which identifies the products, countries and diseases covered by this regulation, as well as the need to differentiate the appearance of reduced-priced medicines in order to prevent their import into the EU. The overall aim of this report is to call for greater help to be provided to those in need of essential medication as well as for preventing the abuse of such help.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. By this decision, the European Parliament, considering that according to the Advisory Group on legal services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the proposal in question is limited to a pure and simple codification of existing acts, without substantial changes, proceeds to approve at first reading the Commission's proposal in its version adapted to the recommendations of the European Parliament's Legal Services Advisory Group Council and the Commission. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of that decision.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report, given that it is simply a codification of existing legislation, without any substantive changes.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The Advisory Group on the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission concluded in its opinion that this proposal is based on the pure and simple codification of existing texts, without substantive amendments, and therefore approval is justified.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. There are no objections to codification. There will be no changes in content. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as Parliament's position at first reading, as tabled for the vote by the rapporteur.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported both mrs Ferrara's reports on preventing the commercial diversion of essential medicines into the EU, as well as the report on reducing the sulphur content of certain liquid fuels. Both reports were codifications of existing legislation without any change in substance, and thus both reports aimed to re-codify legislation that was no longer clear after numerous changes. I support this principle. I believe that, in order to better understand European Union legislation, it is essential that it is comprehensible and, at the same time, that we do not overeit the large number of newly created rules.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported a legislative proposal preventing parallel-priced pharmaceutical products from being imported into the European Union.  It is necessary to ensure that these products remain on the market of the poorest developing countries and to prevent an increase in economic interest in redirecting trade to high-priced markets. Indeed, many of the poorest developing countries urgently need access to affordable basic medicines for the treatment of infectious diseases.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of fiscal and financial cooperation is relevant from the point of view of compliance with tax obligations at international level. The European Union and the Principality of Andorra have signed an agreement for the automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of their residents, which should lead to an improvement in the current situation. Nevertheless, the agreement still contains regulatory gaps that can be easily circumvented. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – Treaties and agreements entered into by the EU could just as easily be entered into by Member States directly, UKIP opposes the authority of the EU to act in its own legal capacity in this fashion, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with Andorra on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States by natural or legal persons who are nationals of a Member State of the Union.  The European and Spanish Socialists are firmly committed to the definitive abolition of tax havens in the world, and particularly within or on the margins of the European Union, as they erode the financing of the welfare state and, ultimately, social justice.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – Treaties and agreements entered into by the EU could just as easily be entered into by Member States directly, UKIP opposes the authority of the EU to act in its own legal capacity in this fashion, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it presents a tax cooperation agreement between Andorra and the EU which improves this legislative framework and extends the exchange of tax information. While the exchange of information cannot be the only axis of action in tax matters at EU level and we consider the full abolition of such tax havens necessary, the agreement voted here unquestionably improves the current functioning of the exchange of information with Andorra, clarifying responsibilities in the sheer tax evasion that takes place through this tax haven. Despite its manifest inadequacy, the formalisation of such agreements is necessary to know the real dimension of fraud and tax evasion of European taxpayers in such jurisdictions. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – This file concerns an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, whereby it seeks to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion. The automatic exchange of financial information is crucial to combating tax evasion and exposing any illicit financing. Therefore, we voted in favour of this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 With this report, the European Union is signing an agreement with the Principality of Andorra on the automatic exchange of financial account information, starting in 2017, with a view to improving international cooperation and compliance in the field of taxation and avoiding cases of tax fraud and tax evasion. In particular, I voted in favour of this report, as it is an agreement which emphasises the need for transparency in the Union's taxation issues and in its relations with third countries.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The vote was to validate an exchange of financial information from EU residents in order to combat the concealment of income or assets. This report is in line with our positions on previous votes for the end of banking secrecy in Europe. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This is an agreement between Andorra and the European Union. I oppose closer economic, political and monetary unions between the EU and Member States. I believe that such agreements would be better made with Member States directly. I voted against this agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement because it will contribute to efforts to combat tax evasion by increasing tax cooperation and automatically exchanging information between the Eu and Andorra.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with Andorra on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States by natural or legal persons who are nationals of a Member State of the Union.  The European and Spanish Socialists are firmly committed to the definitive abolition of tax havens in the world, and particularly within or on the margins of the European Union, as they erode the financing of the welfare state and, ultimately, social justice.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for an Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Andorra on the automatic exchange of financial account information. On 12 February 2016, the EU and Andorra signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information in order to improve international cooperation and compliance with tax. This agreement is an important step in the ongoing fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. Under the new agreement, from 2018, the EU and Andorra will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts held by eu and Andorra residents in their territories from 1 January 2017. The aim is to respond to cases where a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets for which no taxes have been paid.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is on the proposal for a Council Decision on the conclusion on behalf of the European Union of the amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Andorra on the taxation of savings income. On 12 February 2016, the European Union and Andorra signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement represents an important step in the fight against tax fraud and evasion. It updates the 2004 Agreement, which ensures that Andorra applies measures equivalent to the EU Directive on the taxation of savings interest income.  Under the new agreement, an automatic exchange of information between EU Member States and Andorra on data collected from 1 January 2017 will be established for the financial accounts of citizens of another country in the territory of one country from 2018 onwards. The aim is to address situations where taxable persons seek to conceal capital conbodied in the sense of income or property for which the tax has not yet been paid. The aim of the agreement is to ensure automatic exchange of information enabling full tax transparency and cooperation between tax authorities, and I supported its adoption accordingly.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This vote was to validate the agreement signed on 12 February 2016 between the EU and Andorra on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. The text provides that the European Union and Andorra will automatically exchange information on the accounts of their respective residents from 1 January 2017.   The aim is always to deal with so-called "ordinary" tax evasion, i.e. the concealment of income or assets in order to avoid their taxation. In accordance with OECD standards, the agreement provides that the information exchanged relates not only to savings income (interest and dividends), but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.  I logically voted for this text, in line with my previous votes on similar agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein and San Marino.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this agreement, which is in line with the need for more transparency on tax issues in the European Union and in its relations with third countries. This amendment protocol implements the OECD global standard between EU Member States and Andorra.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Principality of Andorra and the European Union signed, on 12 February 2016, an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes to bring their relations into line with the new EU legal framework and standards set by the OECD in 2014. As long back as 2004, the two companies had concluded an agreement providing for the application by the Principality of measures equivalent to those contained in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income.  The Viegas report, which I supported with my vote, effectively underlines the main objective of the agreement: to improve cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. Through it, it will be possible to guarantee an automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts held by their residents, in the face of attempts to conceal capital resulting from tax evasion. The agreement is undoubtedly a positive element of the Eu ropean Union's strategy to combat fraud and tax evasion, and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, which establishes an agreement between the Union and Andorra establishing a cooperation framework for the exchange of convergent tax information with which it already operates between Member States. This agreement relates only to interest taxes received by savers as creditors. The agreement moves forward to combat tax avoidance and tax evasion and facilitate transparency.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This agreement signed on 12 February 2016 between the EU and Andorra on the automatic exchange of financial account information will be effective on 1 January 2017. The aim of this agreement is to avoid ordinary tax evasion aimed at not paying taxes on certain assets, in a logic of combating tax evasion, I vote for this agreement.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement between Andorra and the European Community on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes is an improvement in international cooperation in the fight against tax evasion, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution by which Parliament approves the conclusion of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Andorra on the establishment of measures equivalent to those provided for in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. This Automatic Financial Account Information Exchange Agreement improves tax cooperation and compliance with tax obligations, while a major step is being made in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion. Under the new Agreement, the Member States of the Union and Andorra will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their respective residents from 2018 for information collected from 1 January 2017. The purpose of the Agreement is to resolve situations in which a taxpayer attempts to conceal an estate representing income or assets over which no taxes have been paid.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Andorra. On 12 February 2016, the European Union and Andorra signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information with a view to improving international cooperation and tax compliance. This agreement is an important step in the ongoing fight against tax fraud and tax evasion; it adjusts the 2004 agreement to ensure that Andorra applies measures equivalent to those of the EU Savings Tax Directive. Under the new agreement, from 2018, the EU and Andorra will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts held by eu and Andorra residents in their territories from 1 January 2017. The aim is to respond to cases where a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets for which no taxes have been paid.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the proposed decision to conclude an agreement between the EU and Andorra on the exchange of financial account information, as it is an important step in the context of efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. The agreement builds on the one of 2004, which made it possible for Andorra to implement measures equivalent to those laid down in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. According to some estimates, the grey economy in the EU Member States represents a staggering EUR 1000 billion per year in un collected taxes and contributions. There is undoubtedly, therefore, a major anomaly which constitutes damage both in the area of free competition and in the provision of access to public services financed by tax. The fight against tax fraud is one of the priorities of the whole EU, which is already showing results. Examples of revelations about the tax malversions of multinationals we have witnessed following the disclosure of the Lux Leaks affair are steps in the right direction. In order to achieve the objectives, that is to say, to reduce the number of tax irregularities, we need an enhanced exchange of information on financial accounts and all other relevant information concerning the cross-border business of companies. That agreement will make this one possible.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the fight against tax evasion is a priority for the European Union and I believe that the EU-Andorra agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes is an important step in the right direction by making the work of the authorities easier.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 On 12 February 2016, the European Union and Andorra signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. The agreement represents an important step forward in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and improves the 2004 agreement that ensured that Andorra implemented measures equivalent to those contained in the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. The European Parliament must support the agreement, which aims to ensure that Andorra applies enhanced measures equivalent to those provided for in the EU legal framework, as updated in December 2014, and complies with the procedures for the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standard. The agreement will also benefit Andorra, which has recently reformed its national tax system with the introduction of a personal income tax.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to validate the agreement signed on 12 February 2006 between the European Union and Andorra on the automatic exchange of financial account information as part of better tax cooperation. The aim of this agreement is to combat tax evasion, i.e. the concealment of income or assets in order to avoid their taxation. These fraudulent practices result in a significant shortfall for the Member States of the Union in which austerity measures are being put in place to meet the budgetary requirements of the European Commission. In accordance with OECD standards, the text provides that the information exchanged relates to savings income, account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. We are in favour of better tax cooperation between EU Member States and third countries in order to curb tax evasion, in particular by ending bank secrecy in Europe. So I voted for this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The automatic exchange of information between the Member States of the Union, but also between those states and other third countries, is an essential element in ensuring fairness for European citizens in the case of tax and financial measures. EU Member States and Andorra will automatically exchange information on financial accounts held in their territory by their respective residents, starting in 2018 for information collected from 1 January 2017, in order to deal with situations where the taxpayer is trying to hide capital representing income or assets for which no taxes have been paid. I appreciate that this proposal will also benefit Andorra, which has recently reformed its national tax system by introducing personal income taxation for its residents. I therefore voted in favour of the measures provided for by this legislation which comply with the OECD's 2014 global standard for the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 On 12 February 2016, the European Union and Andorra signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. Same as at the last session for San Marino. Vote.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The geographical location of the Principality of Andorra, located on the Franco-Spanish border, requires special tax measures. The 2004 agreement between the European Union and Andorra guarantees the application by the Latter of measures equivalent to those provided in the Directive on the Taxation of Savings Income. This new agreement will allow for increased exchange of information on the financial accounts of their respective residents, which will increase tax cooperation between the two entities. I voted in favour of this report, which is another step in strengthening tax transparency.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Principality of Andorra, as I believe that the agreement signed on 12 February 2016 on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion.  I have spoken on this subject on several occasions and I believe that it is of prime importance for the development of a healthy European economy, and in particular for union banking, cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. The automatic exchange of information, which will be carried out by the EU Member States and Andorra, on the financial accounts held on their territories by their residents is an effective means of combating the taxpayer seeking to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This file concerns an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, whereby it seeks to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion.  The automatic exchange of financial information is crucial to combating tax evasion and exposing any illicit financing. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Treaties and agreements entered into by the EU could just as easily be entered into by Member States directly, UKIP opposes the authority of the EU to act in its own legal capacity in this fashion, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I approve the conclusion of the Amending Protocol to the EU agreement with the Principality of Andorra on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The measures outlined are equivalent to those in the already-existing Council Directive (2003/48/EC) and will improve international tax cooperation and compliance. Most of all, the agreement aims to eliminate tax avoidance.
