That is very good, it is to be welcomed, and it must be said that it is important to note that the directive will also apply to those who have reached the age of 18 but who have not reached the age of 21. However, it would be logical to extend this directive or to develop a new one that would directly apply to children under the age of 14.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, more than one million children are subject to criminal proceedings each year, the Commission estimates. This equates to 12% of all persons involved in criminal proceedings. That's a huge number! Children's rights are not sufficiently guaranteed in reality, in practice, in the various criminal proceedings in many Member States. The ECHR already has numerous convictions against specific situations in which children's rights have not been respected during criminal proceedings by various authorities in the Member States. It is therefore very important to have some minimum standards for respecting the procedural rights of children, so that they enjoy a fair trial: for example, legal aid, the right to a lawyer, the right to an interpreter if necessary and so on.  I voted for this report precisely because we must guarantee a fair trial and common minimum standards for people under the age of eighteen who are, for various reasons, accused or victims and are therefore involved in criminal trials.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, this report bases its legal status on the EU’s Charter of Fundamental Rights and Freedoms – a document that, when it was negotiated, we were assured by the then Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, Tony Blair, would not apply to the UK. Then his Europe Minister said: well, okay it is there but it does not really mean anything. He said it had all the legal force of a copy of The Beano. We were then told again by the current Prime Minister that opting out of the Charter of Fundamental Rights was a critical part of the recent negotiations. Nothing has changed. Again we see the way in which there is a one-way agglomeration of powers by the institutions of the European Union. Britain had thought that the European Union was an intergovernmental organisation about trade and commerce and that the Council of Europe was the human rights organisation, but we now see that the EU has to acquire jurisdiction in every field of policy. That is the bus which we are going on. If we want to stay put, we do not literally remain motionless on that bus – we have to step off it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I will admit that this vote has not been very easy for me, as well as many of my colleagues. I am not very much in favour of the European Union speaking into criminal law policy. On the other hand, the positives that I saw in the proposal put forward outweighed certain reservations that I, too, have about the circle of, for example, those guaranteed rights. For me, it is essential that this ensures basic equality of arms for children, which is currently being balanced by their young age. That the guarantees that are being given are precisely to balance how they can or cannot proceed with criminal proceedings. And it is a fact that the extension to twenty-one years is not the happiest, on the other hand, Czech criminal law knows precisely the concept of the age of close age of adolescents, so even in this sense I finally decided to support this report.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I support this proposal for a directive protecting the rights of children in criminal proceedings. I recognise that this agreement came after nine  trilogues and I commend the committee and those involved in the work. Given that there are an estimated 1 086 000 children in the EU who have faced criminal justice proceedings, there is clearly a need for a harmonious safeguards to be put in place. It is essential to protect a child throughout the process, ensure a fair trial, and also – and perhaps more importantly – prevent children from reoffending and to foster their social integration in order to avoid further problems down the line. This is of paramount importance and very challenging. Finally, I just want to say that I condemn again the Egyptian authorities for postponing the trial of Ibrahim Halawa; we passed a resolution here on this a few weeks ago asking the Egyptian authorities to release him. He was arrested over three years ago now, when he was still a minor.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, every now and again a sentence, a procedure, a directive comes out in language that most of us would see as reasonable, or indeed would think is acceptable. In these circumstances, today, these procedures about protecting children in criminal proceedings appear reasonable.  The United Kingdom has opted out of the directive related to this because our procedures in relation to children have a higher standard than those being proposed by the EU. But that is not necessarily the point. The point here for people in the United Kingdom, who have to vote in the referendum on June 23, is that they must realise that the EU is introducing procedures on children which differ from ours. Tomorrow they will be introducing legislation that is different to ours and, if we vote to remain, we will always be subject to these rules at some stage. This is not about the status quo. This is about the future, and the UK will remain in something that is dark and desperate.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 In the area of freedom, security and justice, the Stockholm Programme had already highlighted the need to proceed with the development of common rules ensuring compliance with procedural guarantees for children under investigation or accused. According to the latest research, more than 1 million children are involved in criminal proceedings. Despite the high percentage, Member States continue to provide for different systems and treatments, often incurring convictions by the European Court of Human Rights. The Directive establishes a fairly organic catalogue of rights with provision for minimum standards, respecting the specific needs of minors, at all stages of the procedure. I have chosen to vote in favour of the proposal for a directive, because ensuring respect for procedural rights and guarantees for children involved in criminal proceedings must be not only a commitment for Europe, but a responsibility.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. The UK has had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. The UK has had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive on the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, since I understand that it is a step forward in establishing procedural safeguards aimed at protecting the right of minors to have a fair trial and to avoid their recidivism by promoting their social integration. In the process of negotiating with the Council, Parliament has succeeded in including in the Directive its main claims, such as the strengthening of the right to information by the child, as well as the obligation for the child to be assisted by a lawyer, to have the right to appear at trial and medical follow-up, and for deprivation of liberty to be considered the last resort. Therefore, considering that this directive is a positive step towards the protection of the procedural safeguards of minors in criminal proceedings, I voted in favour.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this report which was concerned with safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. Children require special measures of protection to take account of their particular vulnerability and needs (UN CRC Committee, General Comment 10, para 10). This report moved to enhance the rights and protections of children involved in criminal proceedings. Approximately 1.09 million children pass through the criminal justice system in Europe each year and the procedural safeguards which are afforded to them are often woefully lacking. This report is to be commended for significantly strengthening these legal protections. However, it must be noted that whereas the directive on the right to a lawyer permits suspects or accused persons to waive this right, the original Commission proposal prohibited waiver in the case of children. It is disappointing this has been dropped. Ensuring that every child gets legal representation would have been an important step forward in ensuring rights are protected.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This legislative report is a proposed agreement at first reading on the Directive on procedural guarantees for children suspected or accused of criminal offences, on the basis of a Commission proposal from November 2013. The directive is part of a legislative package on the procedural rights of suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings. It was intended to treat children as a special category of vulnerable people. I voted in favour of the report because it contains strong minimum standards at EU level and will contribute to the protection of children in criminal proceedings across the Union.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This directive clearly interferes with the competence of the Member States. Every step is being done to complicate the procedures for minors. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as the UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. In the European Union, an estimated one million children are subject to criminal proceedings. However, there are considerable and worrying differences between Member States in the treatment of children involved in these procedures. The rights of the child are not sufficiently guaranteed within the Union and give rise to numerous condemnations on the part of the European Court of Human Rights For all these reasons, and in order to improve the treatment of children prosecuted by the courts, I voted in favour of this legislative resolution.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to establish a catalogue of the rights of children suspected or accused in criminal matters, providing for a structured set of minimum and interrelated norms adapted to the specific needs of children at all stages of the process. This proposal for a directive aims to protect the rights of the child. According to the European Commission, more than one million children are involved in criminal proceedings in the EU each year, representing 12% of all persons involved in criminal proceedings in the same territory. There are also serious differences in the treatment of children in the Member States in criminal proceedings, which currently do not sufficiently guarantee children's rights at all stages of criminal proceedings within the Union. To date, there is no definition of what is the right trial for the child, so the courts must act on the basis of a partial and fragmented legal action. Currently, only six Member States have public prosecutor's offices with specialisation – children's cases, and in nine Member States there are no special courts for children's cases. I agree with the proposals that it is necessary to ensure the mandatory right to consult a lawyer who is closely linked to the right to free legal aid, the right to individual assessment. Mandatory specific training must also be provided for judges, law enforcement agencies and prison staff who work with children.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The European Commission estimates that one million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the European Union, or 12% of those subject to criminal proceedings. The report does not mention that much of youth crime is related to immigration. This directive will make procedures more cumbersome and complicated, and procedural errors more likely. The European Union, moreover, is in the process of developing a common criminal law, even though it is the competence of the Member States. I therefore logically opposed this new attack on the sovereignty of France... and other Member States.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. This proposed directive is part of the package to strengthen the rights of individuals in criminal proceedings. In addition to this proposal, the package includes a directive on strengthening certain aspects of the presumption of innocence and a directive on legal aid for persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings. The report, which I approved, is important because, for example, today only six Member States have public prosecutors for children and nine countries do not even have specialised courts. The draft directive and the amendments to this report will therefore provide a significant addition in some Member States to the procedural guarantees offered to children. Examples include: children's right to complete and understandable information at the beginning of the proceedings, the right to counsel at every stage of the proceedings, the right to see parental authority before any interrogation, the right to be assessed at the beginning of the proceedings, the right to separation between adults and children in case of pre-trial detention , a doctor's examination at the beginning of the procedure to improve the child's health or well-being,...

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. This Directive is part of the EU Agenda for the Rights of the Child and the Stockholm Programme. Its main purpose is to establish common minimum standards and to ensure procedural safeguards throughout the European Union with regard to the rights of suspected or accused minors in criminal proceedings. I consider it essential to guarantee the same rights for minors throughout the Union. The rapporteur shares the general lines of the text and introduces some amendments to strengthen and extend the procedural rights and guarantees contained in the proposal. That is why I voted in favour of it.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a directive on procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings is part of the path for strengthening the rights of suspects and defendants promoted by the Council since 2009.  The data confirm that every year in Europe, more than 1 million children are subjected to criminal proceedings with treatments that vary widely from country to country. I felt it was necessary to support the Chinnici report because I believe it is essential to tackle effectively the issue of guarantees in legal proceedings, providing a common European model of due process for minors.  The directive adopted requires Member States to guarantee the essential right to be assisted by a defence lawyer by identifying deprivation of liberty as an extreme measure, to be imposed only for a short period of time. The text reiterates the need to guarantee children separate detention from adults, while strengthening the right to be accompanied, at hearings and at different stages of the process, by eligible parents or other adults.  In general terms, this is a good proposal which takes up the positive Italian experience in this field in a significant way.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Chinnici report. The rapporteur proposes some amendments aimed at improving, extending, strengthening or clarifying the rules on the various rights affected by a Commission Directive which aims to define a reduced but organic catalogue of the rights of minors suspected or charged in criminal proceedings (or the subject of proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant) , through a structured body of 'minimum' standards, linked to each other and adapted to the specific needs of minors throughout the process. Its approval implies a significant development of the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: In writing. This text offers us an opportunity to welcome Europe's intervention. This proposal for a directive is in many ways very positive. Indeed, the desire to ensure, through common minimum standards, effective and sufficiently uniform access for minors to the right to a fair trial at all stages of the proceedings must be a fundamental right that is beyond doubt.  Unfortunately, it is currently clear that children's rights in the various phases of criminal proceedings are not sufficiently guaranteed within the Union. They even give rise to numerous condemnations from Member States by the European Court of Human Rights. For example, there are countries where children do not have the fundamental right to counsel. However, it should be an inalienable right of the child.  I therefore agree with the general approach of this report and many of its proposals and I voted in favour of it.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I objected to this report, which merely attempts the creation of a European criminal law by proposing the establishment of procedural safeguards for children, which already exist in any respectable rule of law. While of course everyone can understand the need for a right to information or compulsory legal assistance for juveniles prosecuted, this directive will only make the procedures more cumbersome and complicated, even though such rights are already applied in France. Moreover, while the European Commission estimates that one million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU - or 12% of those subject to such procedures - it fails to see the statistical links between juvenile delinquency and immigration. In view of the Commission's attempt to violate one of the three fundamental pillars of our political system, and the naivety chosen by the drafters of this text, I could only vote against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the arguments set out in her report on procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings. It is important to guarantee, through basic common legislation, the right to a fair trial for children under eighteen years of age. I therefore supported the text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. The proposal reflects the agreement reached with the Council after lengthy negotiations in the tripartite dialogue and strengthening the Commission's proposal by extending its material scope and strengthening legal assistance – the child will receive such assistance ex officio, without requesting it – the individual evaluation of the processing and medical examination of the processing.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to adopt a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. The Stockholm Programme emphasised the importance of individuals' rights in criminal proceedings. The need to ensure, through common minimum standards, that persons under the age of 18 can actually exercise a sufficiently uniform right to a fair trial at all stages of criminal proceedings, is linked to the objective of facilitating mutual recognition of judgments and judgments in criminal matters and to ensuring the smooth functioning of the European area of justice. The European Commission estimates that more than one million children are involved in criminal proceedings in the EU each year, representing 12% of all persons involved in criminal proceedings in the same territory. In addition to the large number of concerns, there are significant differences in the treatment of children in the Member States when faced with criminal proceedings. This proposal for a directive is part of the EU Agenda on the Rights of the Child and aims to promote the rights of the child in the light of other measures, in particular the guidelines of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe on child-friendly justice, bearing in mind that such measures do not have binding force on Union legislation and therefore the guarantees provided for therein are not fully and uniformly applied in the Member States.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this directive is to provide policy assurances to children who are suspected or accused of committing a crime. The text voted on today guarantees that the most important interests of minors will be protected throughout the procedure. The most important clauses of the directive for me are: the right to information, the right to assistance from a lawyer, the right to individual treatment, the right to a medical examination, the right to audiovisual recording of interviews and special safeguards in the detention of children. It is equally important for me to be clear in the wording, i.e. for example, the concept of 'child' clearly applies to all persons under the age of 18. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I also supported my colleague Chinnici's proposed report on the proposal for a directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. The main purpose of the proposal is to create uniform standards across the EU in the exercise of procedural rights in criminal proceedings for persons under the age of 18. In addition, the Directive also focuses on promoting mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions in the field of criminal law.  More than one million children are involved in criminal proceedings in the EU annually, which receive very different treatment across Member States, mainly from the point of view of guaranteeing rights. It is therefore necessary to unify standards at EU level.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 The text voted on today is an important milestone for the final adoption of a directive that is a founding part of the European package on procedural guarantees in the judicial field. The report, in particular, highlights the importance of harmonising the existing rules and setting common minimum standards for safeguards for a category with special specificities, namely children involved in criminal proceedings.  Given the profound heterogeneity that currently exists in this area between The Member States, I welcome a text that aims to lead to greater harmonisation within the Union on such a sensitive issue, acting primarily in the interests of the child, as required by Article 24 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union.  The minimum rules and standards identified in the report aim to standardise and extend the level of protection of children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings within the EU, for example by providing for the right of the child to have a lawyer, to enjoy an individual assessment in the commissioning of measures and sanctions related to the proceedings, greater protection of privacy during the trial and a separate detention regime from that of adults , aimed at promoting their reintegration into society.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I support this report, which aims to strengthen the safety of child suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings, as particularly vulnerable groups. This report ensures, inter alia, that the suspected child always has a lawyer present without having to request it or apply for legal aid. Strong minimum standards at EU level will help properly protect the child suspected in european union-wide criminal proceedings.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. With this directive, the European Union is in the process of developing a criminal law, an area that falls solely within the competence of the Member States. In addition, this text will have the effect of making procedures more cumbersome and complicated, and procedural errors more likely. So I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that the situation of procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings on European territory needs to be substantially improved. The enormous heterogeneity of the relevant provisions in the various national legal systems and the lack of the most basic procedural guarantees in some of them make it necessary to create a system of minimum guarantees which will allow, on the one hand, greater homogeneity and, on the other, greater protection for the accused minors.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission estimates that more than 1 million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU each year, or 12% of those involved in criminal proceedings in the same territory. Research carried out at European level shows that, at present, children's rights at the various stages of the procedure are not sufficiently guaranteed within the Union, and there are numerous cases of condemnation of states by the European Court of Human Rights. The European Parliament must help to ensure that a lawyer's right to compulsory care in the event of minor offences is automatically guaranteed. There are no offences which do not have consequences for the child which justify not respecting his or her rights of defence. It is therefore parliament's task to approve the proposal for a directive on 'procedural guarantees for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings' which, together with some measures already adopted and others currently under discussion, forms part of the roadmap for strengthening the procedural rights of suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings adopted by the Council on 20 November 2009.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This proposed directive aims to put in place safeguards for individuals between the ages of 18 and 21 who are prosecuted in criminal proceedings when the alleged offence was committed before the age of 18.  It provides for the granting of a number of rights to the suspect, such as the right to information, the right to mandatory counsel at every stage of the proceedings and the right to be assessed in a personalised manner in order to better take into account the social environment in which he has evolved.  Through this directive, the European Union is beginning to develop a common criminal law, thus violating the principle of subsidiarity as it is a competence of the Member States. That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to a fair trial can only be ensured by establishing common minimum standards and exercising it effectively and sufficiently homogeneously at all stages of the procedure. Moreover, in the case of persons under the age of eighteen, this right is linked to the objective of facilitating the mutual recognition of judgments and decisions in criminal matters and of ensuring a fair functioning of the European area of justice. I appreciate that the proposal seeks to define a limited but properly structured set of rights of children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings (or who are the subject of a European arrest warrant procedure) by means of a set of minimum standards, interconnected and calibrated for the specific needs of children throughout the proceedings. In conclusion, I support the EU Agenda for the Rights of the Child and the effective implementation of justice in the interests of the child by voting in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently only in 6 Member States there are specialised public prosecutors' bodies for minors (Belgium, Czech Republic, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg and Slovak Republic) and in 9 countries there are also no specialized courts. In some countries, the assistance of the lawyer is not guaranteed; in others it is only possible in court and not in police stations; in others, the decision is referred to the competent court.  There is therefore no attempt to harm the sovereignty of our Member State. The report needs to ensure, by means of common minimum standards, the effective and sufficiently uniform enjoyment of the right to a fair trial at all stages of the procedure by persons under the age of eighteen. The report reflects the inspiration and general approach of the proposal, among which we mention cases of particular importance such as: the indispensable right to be assisted by a lawyer, in close connection with the right to legal aid and the right to an individual assessment. The report has received our support and the vote in favour of Mr De Clercq. Fontana in the LIBE Committee, where it was approved by a single vote against. Vote.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings because the child is in a particularly vulnerable situation when detained. Special efforts are needed to prevent it from being deprived of its freedom, given the risks to its physical, mental and social development and to its reintegration into society. Deprivation of liberty must be a solution of last resort and last as little time as possible. With this measure, we are introducing an obligation for all European countries to grant legal assistance to the child at all stages of the procedure, an individual assessment of the child's experience and personality, separate detention between minors and adults, medical assistance and specialist training of magistrates working in the field of juvenile justice.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. Children require special measures of protection to take account of their particular vulnerability and needs (UN CRC Committee, General Comment 10, para 10). This report moved to enhance the rights and protections of children involved in criminal proceedings. Approximately 1.09 million children pass through the criminal justice system in Europe each year and the procedural safeguards which are afforded to them are often woefully lacking. This report is to be commended for significantly strengthening these legal protections. However, it must be noted that whereas the directive on the right to a lawyer permits suspects or accused persons to waive this right, the original Commission proposal prohibited waiver in the case of children. It is disappointing this has been dropped. Ensuring that every child gets legal representation would have been an important step forward in ensuring rights are protected.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. The UK has had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we should give special attention to children who are involved in criminal proceedings and the proposal outlines such safeguards. The situation in the EU is still unsatisfactory. For example, nine Member States still do not have juvenile courts. Common minimum standards and the right to a fair trial need to be ensured. We must remember that minors need to be treated fairly and in a manner appropriate to their age and that all kinds of discrimination and mistreatment must be avoided.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a directive on procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings is part of the roadmap on European procedural rights. The need to guarantee common minimum rights is added to the need to promote the mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions in criminal matters; both contribute to the absolutely primary objective of safeguarding children. The proposed text is positive and identifies a structured body of minimum standards tailored to the specific needs of children; My vote was wholely positive.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the proposal and consider the following to be particularly important: the inalienable right to legal aid, which is inextricably linked to the right to legal aid; the right to an individual assessment; the arrangements relating to the interrogation; providing for the participation of the minor in the proceedings; the provision of compulsory special training for judges, law enforcement authorities, prison authorities, lawyers and other persons in contact with minors in the course of their work; provisions relating to deprivation of liberty, which dictate the application of pre-trial detention in prisons only as a last resort, where alternative measures cannot be taken, and in any case where it is ensured that minors are kept separately from adults, unless otherwise appropriate, for their own benefit.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider this an important vote in favour because this proposal for a directive on "procedural guarantees for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings" introduces first of all certain rights that I consider fundamental, such as the inescapable right to be assisted by a lawyer, the right to an individual assessment or even the provision of the child's participation in the proceedings and the provision of a specific training obligation for subjects as magistrates , lawyers and prison authorities working in contact with minors. All these elements are necessary, in my opinion, to ensure that minors have the effective enjoyment of the right to a fair trial and to guarantee them the proper functioning of the European area of justice. For these reasons, I could only vote in favour of it: the protection of children's rights is a sensitive issue and, in my opinion, this report deals with it in a concrete way.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ On 16 December 2015, the Permanent Representatives Committee (Coreper) approved a compromise text agreed with Parliament on a directive on procedural safeguards for children in criminal proceedings.  The purpose of the directive is to provide procedural safeguards for children who are suspected or accused of having committed a criminal offence. The directive will be applied to children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings until the conclusion of the proceeding which means the final determination of question.  The text agreed with the Council is very clear on the definitions, as they have been considered an important element clarifying the scope and the application of this directive, in particular: the definitions of ‘child’, which means a person below the age of 18 years, and that of ‘the holder of parental responsibility’ which means any person having parental responsibility.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. The UK has had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. The free movement of European citizens, which has its first pillar in Schengen, also translates into an area of Freedom, Security and Justice. Among these three dimensions, the case of justice means judicial cooperation and, what is in this report, ensuring a common denominator of guarantees and rights for all European citizens. That is why the procedural rights roadmap has been developed, but also why this Directive has now been adopted for the procedural safeguards of minors - normally subject to a special regime in criminal proceedings.  The Directive applies to all criminal proceedings and ensures the harmonisation of numerous concepts and guarantees, which were not consensual in the traditions of the various Member States. Notethe definition of child as all under the age of 18, access to a lawyer and legal aid, as well as special safeguards in medical examinations and interrogations.  I cannot therefore fail to congratulate myself and see that, in certain areas, it is still quite clear that there can be no security without justice.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. The UK has had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission estimates that more than one million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU each year, i.e. 12% of those involved in criminal proceedings in the same territory. In addition to the figures, it is the large differences between Member States in the treatment of children subject to this procedure that are of concern. Research carried out at European level shows that, at present, children's rights at the various stages of the procedure are not sufficiently guaranteed within the Union, and there are many cases of condemnation of states by the European Court of Human Rights.  In this proposal for a directive, attention has been paid to the need for the recognition of special guarantees on account of the child's age and the vulnerable status of the suspect or accused person not to distort what is and must remain the function and structuring proper to criminal proceedings, linked to the objective and impartial assessment by the judicial authority of a person's criminal liability for a given crime. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in the hope that Member States are encouraged to bring about awareness on the matter and provide children involved in criminal proceedings with appropriate support.  Children are persons with their own rights; rights that are equal to those of adults. It is imperative that children who are involved in criminal proceedings are treated in a manner and pass through a process that is adequate and proper to their age and their vulnerability.  Furthermore, children also need to have procedures leading to their being charged or accused that also fully respect their vulnerability and their age maturity. Procedural safeguards for children should therefore not be restricted to court procedures but should exist in all the different stages of the criminal justice system.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings because 1 million children are involved in criminal justice every year in Europe and they are particularly vulnerable. They need special protection and assistance to understand what is at stake, the law and their rights.  While criminal law is a national competence, the minimum standards laid out in this directive will improve legal certainty.  I believe that mandatory assistance by a lawyer, children’s right to an individual assessment of their familiar and social situation, specialised training for justices, prosecutors, and other professionals involved in criminal justice are crucial safeguards and represent a step forward in the direction of guaranteeing a fair trial for children in the EU.  Indeed, as co-Chair of the Intergroup on Children’s Rights in the European Parliament, I am happy that the best interests of the child is at the core of the directive, which provides a comprehensive protection system at all stages for children involved in criminal proceedings, putting children’s rights at the top of the EU political agenda.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution deals with the importance of protecting children's rights in criminal proceedings, which applies to persons under the age of 18. The protection of children's rights must be a key objective of the European Union, which is why children's rights are also enshrined in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. The rules and principles contained in international instruments for the protection of the child, as in the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, must continue to guide the Union's policies and actions.  The resolution is included in the 'roadmap for strengthening the procedural rights of suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings' adopted by the Council on 30 November 2009, defining a catalogue of the rights of children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings. Since I believe that the commitment to children's rights must be translated into concrete political actions, I am voting in favour of the resolution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive on the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, since I understand that it is a step forward in establishing procedural safeguards aimed at protecting the right of minors to have a fair trial and to avoid their recidivism by promoting their social integration. In the process of negotiating with the Council, Parliament has succeeded in including in the Directive its main claims, such as the strengthening of the right to information by the child, as well as the obligation for the child to be assisted by a lawyer, to have the right to appear at trial and medical follow-up, and for deprivation of liberty to be considered the last resort. Therefore, considering that this directive is a positive step towards the protection of the procedural safeguards of minors in criminal proceedings, I voted in favour.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report because I believe that uniform procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings are essential. In fact, the European Union has successfully defined an area of free movement and residence from which citizens who increasingly travel, study and work in countries other than their country of residence benefit, with the consequent elimination of internal borders. This situation has inevitably led to an increasing number of people being involved in criminal proceedings in a Member State other than their country of residence.  All the more so, it is important that, even in the case of underage defendants, the rights of defence should be guaranteed equally in all Member States. At present, only six Member States have specialised public prosecutors' bodies for children, nine do not even have specialised courts and only twelve provide compulsory specific training for practitioners of justice in contact with children. In this extremely uneven context, Parliament's efforts to introduce common minimum standards of particular importance, which are adopted by all Member States, are to be welcomed.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Every year, more than one million minors from the Member States of the European Union find themselves in situations of illegality. The lack of education and the ease with which minors may be influenced in carrying out wrongdoing are only two of the reasons why it is necessary to adapt legal systems to their particularities. Regardless of the act produced or what the minor is suspected of, he must be treated according to his intellectual and understanding capacities. It is also important from the early stages of the procedure to carry out an assessment that takes into account the degree of maturity, the family, social and economic environment in which the minor developed. Particular attention should be paid to minors from vulnerable groups, such as street children, minorities, immigrants or persons with disabilities.  I believe that the European Union and the Member States must provide procedural guarantees for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, respecting both their particularities and dignified and non-discriminatory treatment.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 As the People's Party Responsible for the Directive, I was pleased to vote in favour of the text, which was co-ordinated with the Council. As a result of the many months of interinstitutional consultation, a common text was drafted, to which Parliament has now formally approved it. The European Commission estimates that more than 1 million children are prosecuted in the EU each year, while the treatment of children prosecuted varies considerably between Member States. The directive aims to eliminate these differences and to establish uniform European minimum standards. Suspected or accused children are much more vulnerable than suspected or accused adults and therefore have special safeguards. I am convinced that this directive ensures adequate, child-friendly conditions for prosecution and is in the best interests of children.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The aim of the Directive is to provide procedural guarantees for children (i.e. persons under the age of 18) who are suspected or accused of committing a criminal offence in an EU Member State. Children's rights vary very differently in the EU, as persons under the age of 18 are often suspected or accused of committing a crime in a country other than their country of origin or are being questioned in such a country. The directive aims to introduce basic rules in this area and establish fundamental rights across the EU, as well as to improve cross-border cooperation in criminal investigations.  This Directive will provide additional safeguards for those already applicable to suspects and accused persons in criminal matters. The main provision of that directive refers to the assistance of a lawyer. Member States should ensure that the child receives the assistance of a lawyer, if necessary by providing legal assistance for this purpose. In view of the seriousness of the issue raised, I voted in favour of this document.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as because it amends slightly the Commission’s most recent proposal on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings as part of its November 2013 package of proposals to further strengthen procedural safeguards for citizens in criminal proceedings. The modifications to the Commission’s legislative proposal in the first reading of the agreement for a directive strengthen the proposal and broaden the scope of the directive, including key aspects which will ensure that rights of children and the best interest of the child. One such key aspect is the proposal to ensure that children suspected of criminal acts always have a lawyer present to assist them and thus this will be an automatic right granted to children without any request for legal aid.  Another such safeguard introduced by Parliament’s rapporteur is the proposal that Member States ensure that children are informed promptly both in writing and orally about the charges against them, the conduct of the proceedings and their rights in a way which is understandable and appropriate to their age, language capabilities and intellectual ability.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to ensure a fair trial for children under the age of 18 suspected of crime, with minimum procedural safeguards in all Member States. First of all, it stresses the need to take into account the best interests of the child. They will now have the right to be accompanied by a lawyer and the holder of parental responsibility (or another appropriate adult) during the proceedings and may resort to a careful medical examination. Considering that children, because of their age and their vulnerability to reoffending, constitute a public requiring special attention, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I am pleased that this report for which I was referring to the French delegation has been adopted. With this vote, we have signed our agreement with the Council of the EU in the European Parliament to ensure the rights of children and minors suspected of crimes in legal proceedings. Among the rights highlighted are the assistance of a lawyer, their parents, and the need for them to be held separately from adults.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this draft directive which will ensure that children suspected or accused of a crime receive a fair trial in whatever EU state they are in. The text presents a list of rights and guarantees for a common European model of due process for children, in which a balance can be struck between the need to establish responsibility for the crime and the need to take due account of the vulnerability of defendants. Particularly important is the provision to ensure that minors always have the inescapable right to be assisted by a defence lawyer.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this directive is to provide policy assurances to children who are suspected or accused of committing a crime. The text voted on today guarantees that the most important interests of minors will be protected throughout the procedure. The most important clauses of the Directive for us are: the right to information, the right to assistance from a lawyer, the right to individual treatment, the right to a medical examination, the right to audiovisual recording of interviews and special safeguards in the detention of children. It was equally important for us to be clear when drafting, so, for example, the term 'child' as a concept clearly applies to all persons under the age of 18. On the Fidesz side, we all support the text, in agreement with the Council and the Commission, and this also fully respects the EPP's position.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported the adoption of provisions to ensure that children prosecuted for a crime could receive a fair trial. It is a complex subject that requires balancing the need to establish responsibility for the crime with the need to take into account the vulnerability and specific needs of minors.  I am satisfied with the safeguards, starting with the right to be assisted by a lawyer and to be accompanied by the parenting holder for most of the proceedings; the right to an individual assessment by qualified staff and a medical examination if the minor is deprived of his liberty; guarantee that deprivation of liberty will be imposed on children only as a last resort and for the shortest possible appropriate period; the right of the minor to be informed promptly of his rights and the proceedings; the right to privacy during the criminal proceedings or the specific training for judges, prosecutors and other professionals in charge of criminal proceedings involving children.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This directive tends to complicate procedures and thus increases the risk of errors. I voted against this text because it is part of the development of a common criminal law, which goes against the regal powers of states. Finally, the report does not mention that much of youth crime is related to immigration. Once again, the causes should be dealt with before the consequences.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I supported this report, as the topic of procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings is extremely important.  Around 1 086 000 children a year face criminal proceedings, representing 12% of all Europeans facing criminal justice, and legislation in different EU Member States varies. Common implementing standards are needed. Protecting children must be a priority for our society. They are his most vulnerable representatives and need special protection. We must be able to address legal gaps in our systems, taking into account member states' legislative systems, while creating European standards to ensure the protection of children's rights within the Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a requirement to ensure full respect for the fundamental rights and procedural rights of suspects and accused persons, especially on the basis of the presumption of innocence, with particular care for children, in order to be treated in all proceedings with care, sensitivity and respect for their age, special needs, level of maturity and capacity to understand them, and to take into account any communication difficulties they may have. Finally, children involved in criminal proceedings should be given appropriate support and assistance in their efforts to reintegrate into society, in particular by taking measures to prevent discrimination against them in terms of access to education and the labour market, and to protect them from marginalisation. The only asterisk concerns the recognition of the limits of adulthood, which in any case must be the 18th year. The reference to the 21-year limit, due to the lengthening of the period of transition to adulthood, should be examined at national level with reference to encouraging the application of the guarantees herein (see Roman case).

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this directive is to provide policy assurances to children who are suspected or accused of committing a crime. The text voted on today guarantees that the most important interests of minors will be protected throughout the procedure. The most important clauses of the Directive for us are: the right to information, the right to assistance from a lawyer, the right to individual treatment, the right to a medical examination, the right to audiovisual recording of interviews and special safeguards in the detention of children. It was equally important for us to be clear when drafting, so, for example, the term 'child' as a concept clearly applies to all persons under the age of 18. On the Fidesz side, we all support the text, in agreement with the Council and the Commission, and this also fully respects the EPP's position.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission estimates that every year more than one million minors will be subject to criminal proceedings in the EU, accounting for 12 % of those involved in criminal proceedings in that territory. Research at European level shows that the rights of minors at present at various stages of the proceedings are not adequately guaranteed within the Union and that there are many cases of conviction by the European Court of Human Rights. Currently there are specialised prosecution bodies for minors in only six Member States and in nine countries there are not even specialised courts. In some countries, the assistance of a lawyer is not guaranteed; in others, it is possible only in court and not in police stations; in others, the decision rests with the competent judge. It is in this context that the proposal for a directive is included which seeks to define a narrow but organic range of rights of minors who are suspects or accused in criminal proceedings, reputing a structured body of 'minimum' standards, reciprocally linked to each other and appropriate to the specific needs of minors throughout the process.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: this directive will make procedures more cumbersome and complicated, and procedural errors more likely. With these acts the European Union is in the process of developing a common criminal law, even though it is a competence of the Member States.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a directive on 'procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings' is an important step forward in the implementation of the EU Programme for the Rights of the Child. It is essential, in fact, to introduce appropriate legislation aimed at ensuring justice on a child-friendly basis, the guarantees of which are applied in a full and uniform manner in the Member States. The outcome of the negotiations with the other institutions involved in the legislative process is, after all, satisfactory: the directive defines a small but organic catalogue of the rights of children investigated or charged in criminal proceedings (or the subject of a procedure for executing the European arrest warrant), through a structured body of 'minimum' standards, mutually linked and tailored to the specific needs of minors throughout the procedure. I therefore declare my vote in favour of this legislative resolution.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Directive on procedural safeguards for suspected or accused minors in criminal proceedings is part of the "Roadmap for strengthening the procedural rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings", adopted by the Council on 30 November 2009. It comes in line with other initiatives, including the Guidelines of the Council of Europe Committee of Ministers on child-adapted justice. It is estimated that every year more than one million minors are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU, accounting for 12% of those involved in criminal proceedings. It is in this context that the proposal for a Directive is included, which aims to define a set of rights of minors who are suspects or accused in criminal proceedings, reputing a structured body of "minimum" nomas, reciprocally linked to each other and appropriate to the specific needs of minors throughout the process. The following stand out: the inalienable right to be assisted by a defender; the right to an individual assessment; the possibility of the minor's participation in the process; the inclusion of mandatory specific training for judges, police and prison authorities, lawyers and other individuals working with minors; provisions on deprivation of liberty. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The main purpose of the proposal for a directive is to strengthen the procedural rights of children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings within a Member State of the European Union. I voted in favour of the directive. Indeed, the need to ensure, through common minimum standards, the effective and uniform enjoyment of the right to a fair trial during all stages of the proceedings by minors is closely linked to the objective of promoting the mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions in criminal matters, ensuring the proper functioning of the European area of justice. Furthermore, the directive places the protection and safety of the child at the centre of the issue, providing for special guarantees during the dramatic period of detention.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ Provisions advance the protection of children so I voted in favour

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 There is a tradition of strong protection of the rights of the child in the European Union. However, it is necessary and necessary that we work constantly to strengthen juvenile guarantees. Such measures include a proposal for a directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. Unfortunately, there are still major differences in the treatment of children involved in criminal proceedings across the Member States of the European Union in the Member States. We must work together to improve the protection of children and adolescents facing criminal proceedings in the future.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report because I am in favour of ensuring common minimum standards of guarantee for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is a requirement to ensure full respect for the fundamental rights and procedural rights of suspects and accused persons, especially on the basis of the presumption of innocence, with particular care for children, in order to be treated in all proceedings with care, sensitivity and respect for their age, special needs, level of maturity and capacity to understand them and to take into account any communication difficulties they may have. Finally, children involved in criminal proceedings should be given appropriate support and assistance in their efforts to reintegrate into society, in particular by taking measures to prevent discrimination against them in terms of access to education and the labour market, and to protect them from marginalisation. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support this report, which strengthens the initial Commission proposal, as children are a specific category of vulnerable persons and strong minimum standards at EU level will help to properly protect child suspects safe in criminal proceedings across the Union. I welcome the important gains obtained by my colleagues during the negotiations with the Council, such as the provisions on assistance by a lawyer, the individual assessment and the medical examination. Moreover, I welcome the fact that the text counteracts negative provisions introduced by the Council in relation to audio-visual recording of interviews, the use of detention as a measure of last resort, the right to privacy, and possible costs implications. Consistency with the previous adopted measures of the roadmap should be maintained; Member States must fully respect fundamental rights and prevent violations giving rise to European court rulings.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it establishes common minimum standards throughout the European Union on the rights of children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings and those subject to european arrest warrant execution proceedings.  Strengthening the rights of individuals in criminal proceedings is a priority under the Stockholm Programme. I believe that, given the vulnerability of persons under the age of 18 drawn to criminal proceedings, their rights should be fully protected at the various stages of criminal proceedings within the European Union. In this regard, it is important that the adoption of this legislative proposal ensures mandatory access to a lawyer for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. Another key element of this is the provision of an obligation to specialise in the training of magistrates, law enforcement authorities and prison officers, lawyers and other persons in contact with children. The establishment of minimum standards is therefore necessary to establish an effective standard for the protection of children and to enhance mutual trust and judicial cooperation.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this directive is to provide policy assurances to children who are suspected or accused of committing a crime. The text voted on today guarantees that the most important interests of minors will be protected throughout the procedure. The most important clauses of the Directive for us are: the right to information, the right to assistance from a lawyer, the right to individual treatment, the right to a medical examination, the right to audiovisual recording of interviews and special safeguards in the detention of children. It was equally important for us to be clear when drafting, so, for example, the term 'child' as a concept clearly applies to all persons under the age of 18. On the Fidesz side, we all support the text, in agreement with the Council and the Commission, and this also fully respects the EPP's position.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this directive is to provide policy assurances to children who are suspected or accused of committing a crime. The text voted on today guarantees that the most important interests of minors will be protected throughout the procedure. The most important clauses of the Directive for us are: the right to information, the right to assistance from a lawyer, the right to individual treatment, the right to a medical examination, the right to audiovisual recording of interviews and special safeguards in the detention of children. It was equally important for us to be clear when drafting, so, for example, the term 'child' as a concept clearly applies to all persons under the age of 18. On the fidesz side, we all support the text in agreement with the Council and the Commission, and this also fully respects the EPP's position.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted positively on this report with the conviction that the child's figure must be endowed with a special category in all judicial proceedings in the EU. Due to the different laws of the different countries of the Union, in many cases minimum assistance is not guaranteed in accordance with the status of minor. That is why, with my vote, I intend to establish minimum requirements in all Member States for the prosecution of minors, thereby guaranteeing their fundamental rights.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. – Every year, more than 1 million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU and, unfortunately, too many children are still denied the basic right to legal aid: in 6 Member States alone (Belgium, the Czech Republic, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg and the Slovak Republic) there are, in fact, specialised public prosecutors' bodies. This is unacceptable for the Europe of rights, for the Union which supports the protection of human dignity and which promotes the rights of the child. I very much welcome the complex work carried out by Mrs Chinnici in this legislative report, which promotes minimum measures to guarantee assistance to minors in cases of criminal proceedings against them and which commits itself to reconfirming Europe as attentive to the protection of the rights, especially those of the most vulnerable citizens.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted with conviction in favour of Mrs Chinnici's report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings because I believe it is important to have a core of common rules on the protection of children guilty or suspected of crimes as vulnerable. Indeed, I believe it is essential to take action to resolve the major differences in the laws of the Member States, which currently see some States offering courts and magistrates specialising in juvenile crimes and others that do not even provide for the basic right to legal assistance without the authorisation of the judicial authority. I believe that the report makes considerable progress in strengthening guarantees and rights in relation to the Commission's initial proposal and the Council's negotiating position, with important results with regard to the right to comprehensible and clear information on procedure, individual evaluation and medical examinations, extension of the scope to offences committed by persons over the age of 18 and a reference to the best interests of the child. Finally, I fully agree with the obligation for the child to be assisted by a lawyer at all stages of the procedure and the definition of that right as indispensable: these are principles of civilisation, which must play a fundamental role in EU law.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. With today's vote on common European minimum standards for suspects or accused children, we have taken a significant step towards fair procedural guarantees. In particular, a uniform legal framework must be available in this area for minors who are worthy of protection.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. Wales and the UK have had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this package of proposals by the Commission because I believe it is key that we adopt minimum standards throughout the EU to better protect the rights of suspects or those accused in criminal proceedings who are children. Ensuring that these children are treated with respect, dignity and professionalism is not only a moral duty, it is also vital to facilitating reintegration of these minors in society and giving them a fair shot at a second chance. Given the UK will not opt in to this directive, there is no conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Chinnici report. The rapporteur proposes some amendments aimed at improving, extending, strengthening or clarifying the rules on the various rights affected by a Commission Directive which aims to define a reduced but organic catalogue of the rights of minors suspected or charged in criminal proceedings (or the subject of proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant) , through a structured body of 'minimum' standards, linked to each other and adapted to the specific needs of minors throughout the process. Its approval implies a significant development of the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. I voted for my colleague Caterina Chinnici's report containing procedural safeguards for minors suspected or charged in criminal proceedings because it is the first European text to force a catalogue of rights, based on minimum standards, to meet the specific needs of these children.  The new rules are expected to affect one million children; this is the estimated number of children coming into formal contact with the police and justice in the EU each year, and so far their protection has varied from one Member State to another. This text thus allows it to be harmonized and to move forward in the construction of an area of freedom and common justice.  It aims to enable children to understand and follow the legal process, to exercise their rights and to prevent re-offending; including ensuring the presence of a lawyer during the proceedings, the right of minors not to be heard at public hearings, and the detention of minors as a last resort - states having to find alternative solutions.  I welcome the adoption of this text, which is not sufficiently publicized, while it establishes a more just model of juvenile justice.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. There must be set minimum legal procedures on this matter. According to the Commission’s estimates, more than 1 million children are involved in criminal proceedings in the EU each year. EU research shows that, at present, children’s rights are not being sufficiently protected at the various stages in criminal proceedings in the EU.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this Directive is to provide policy assurances to children suspected or accused of committing a criminal offence. The text voted on today guarantees that the most important interests of minors are protected throughout the procedure. The essential clauses of the directive for us are: the right to information, the right to assistance from a lawyer, the right to individual treatment, the right to a medical examination, the right to audiovisual recording of interviews and special safeguards in the detention of children. It was equally important for us to be clear when drafting, so, for example, the term 'child' as a concept clearly applies to all persons under the age of 18. On the Fidesz side, we all support the text, in agreement with the Council and the Commission, and this also reflects the EPP's position.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report greatly strengthens the process of protecting children accused of criminal acts. In particular, they guarantee: (1) the right to information that children should be informed in a timely manner – in writing and orally, and in a simple language which they understand – about the charges against them, the conduct of the trial and their rights (2) the right to compulsory assistance by a lawyer (3) the right to medical examination (4) the right to freedom (children may be deprived of their liberty only as a last measure, while respect for human dignity and the rights of the child in detention is ensured in any case) (5) the right of children to attend and participate in their proceedings and to take all necessary measures to enable them to participate fully, including the opportunity to be heard and express their views.  That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. Given that children face 12% of criminal proceedings within the EU every year and that only six Member states have specialised units dealing with children in prosecution, I believe it is imperative that there are common minimum standards throughout the EU which protect the rights of children who have been accused in criminal proceedings, specifically the right to a lawyer and that any questioning of a child be audio-visually recorded. I agree that all officials dealing with children in criminal procedures should be given appropriate training, and for these reasons I have voted in favour on the motion.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as this directive asserts that Member States need to provide adequate safeguards to children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, such as the right to information, the right to privacy and the right to a lawyer. This directive is important to ensure that all Member States’ criminal justice systems uphold a minimum standard.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. The UK has had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I salute the proposal for a legislative report regarding a Directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. This report strengthens the initial proposal – in particular with regard to provisions on assistance by a lawyer, individual assessment mechanisms and the medical examination.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings, as I am deeply convinced that a problem with particular caution for children needs to be addressed. I fully support the intention to set minimum standards to guarantee children's rights during the procedures. First of all, it is necessary to provide them with a lawyer, as well as free legal assistance, to allow them to attend proceedings and others.  There are major differences in the treatment of children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings across the Union.
