Often their rights have not been sufficiently respected and I therefore consider that further efforts and urgent measures are needed in this regard.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The directive should apply to persons suspected or prosecuted subject to criminal proceedings who have reached the age of 18, but not yet 21 years, when the offence is presumed to have been committed before the age of 18. A range of rights are named, including the right to information of children, the right to counsel, the right to be the subject of a personalized study, the right to be examined by a doctor, among others. This directive will make procedures more cumbersome and complicated, and procedural errors more likely. The European Union, moreover, is in the process of developing a common criminal law, even though it is the competence of the Member States. The European Commission estimates that one million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the European Union, or 12% of those subject to criminal proceedings. The report does not mention that much of youth crime is related to immigration. However, many of the rights mentioned in the directive are fundamental rights in a rule of law, and they are minors. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. The UK has had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 This regulation is particularly important precisely because it is intended for the most vulnerable in our society – children. I agree that children being investigated for committing a crime (or suspected of the same) need to be given a fair trial. Due to their young age and immaturity, they are more vulnerable during criminal proceedings, so I support the idea of unifying procedural rights on this issue and overarching standards of child protection. Children must be treated with dignity and fairness. I consider the right to information to be absolutely essential, I also welcome the right to legal aid, the presence of a legal representative during proceedings or the protection of privacy.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Caterina Chinnici's report on procedural safeguards for children suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings. This text grants guarantees for the specific needs of minors at all stages of the procedure. The directive allows any minor to be assisted by a lawyer and wants the deprivation of liberty to be a conviction as a last resort and to be carried out separately from adults. These bases can be a European model. I support these new balanced provisions that give special status to children even if they have broken the law. It is also a question of preventing recidivism which proves the failure of the only strategies of confinement. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. Ms Chinnici's report deals with a directive to set common minimum standards in Europe for procedural safeguards for children suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings. More than one million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU and only six Member States have public bodies specifically dedicated to them. It was therefore necessary to adopt a body of minimum standards adapted to the specific requirements of the child in the context of criminal proceedings. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. Although stronger directives on the protection of children in criminal proceedings are necessary in many cases, in most countries they are already well implemented and do not require any special consideration from the Union. I am therefore abstaining from this vote.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, which includes one on safeguards for children and another on legal aid. Labour MEPs support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as procedural safeguards for children.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. EU citizens enjoy legal certainty across the EU. This should also apply, and above all, to minors. For it is particularly important to preserve the welfare of children here, and all measures must be based on prevention rather than punishment. That is why I voted in favour of the Chinnici report with the ECR Group.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Children who are suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings are at a very vulnerable age when they can easily turn the wrong way. They must therefore be given particular attention in order to preserve their internal development potential and consequently promote their reintegration into society. The directive aims to introduce procedural safeguards to ensure that children, i.e. persons under the age of 18 who are suspected or accused persons in criminal proceedings, are able to understand and monitor these proceedings and exercise their right to a fair trial, and to prevent children from repeating the crime and to promote their social integration. This objective is sufficiently evidenced that the establishment of common minimum rules for the protection of the procedural rights of suspected or accused children should strengthen Member States' confidence in the criminal justice systems of other Member States, thus improving mutual recognition of decisions in criminal matters. Any child who is a suspected or accused person in criminal proceedings should have the right to an individual assessment aimed at identifying their specific needs as provided for in Article 7 of this Directive. It is also essential that Member States ensure that children are adequately informed of the rights referred to in this Directive.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this directive is to provide policy assurances to children who are suspected or accused of committing a crime. The text voted on today guarantees that the most important interests of minors will be protected throughout the procedure. The most important clauses of the Directive for us are: the right to information, the right to assistance from a lawyer, the right to individual treatment, the right to a medical examination, the right to audiovisual recording of interviews and special safeguards in the detention of children. It was equally important for us to be clear when drafting, so, for example, the term 'child' as a concept clearly applies to all persons under the age of 18. On the Fidesz side, we all support the text, in agreement with the Council and the Commission, and this also fully respects the EPP's position.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The directive aims to establish procedural safeguards to ensure that children who are accused in criminal proceedings are able to follow the proceedings. It is essential to enable the children to exercise their right to a fair trial and also foster their social integration. I voted in favour of this directive to ensure the establishment of special safeguards for children.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ In reality, a proposal for a directive on procedural safeguards for children who are suspected or accused in criminal proceedings is more than needed. Children’s mentality is weak and can be easily upset, therefore we should protect them. In order for this to happen, Member States should implement the directive that states that suspects and accused children are presumed innocent until proven guilty under the law. Furthermore, the directive on procedural safeguards for children who are suspected or accused will enhance the right to a fair trial in criminal proceedings by laying down minimum rules and presumption of innocence and the right to be present at the trial.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I would like to begin by congratulating Mrs Chinnici on her excellent work and on the agreement by a large majority reached on an important directive. It aims to ensure, through common minimum standards, the right to a fair trial for persons under the age of eighteen, during all stages of criminal proceedings. At present, there is no common regulatory definition of the fundamental elements of the fair juvenile process at European level.  I would like to highlight some important priorities, which are part of the final package, such as guaranteeing assistance for the child of a lawyer from an early stage, a right not recognised today in some Member States, and measures aimed at achieving rapid social reintegration of the child and discouraging the phenomenon of reoffending. In general, it is a balanced text, which lays the minimum foundations for a fair trial for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. Children are a particularly vulnerable part of society. Children who are suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings should be able to avoid repeating the crime and the possibility of reintegration into society. This Decision lays down minimum procedural rights and protection for such children. The aim is to set minimum standards to strengthen mutual trust and cooperation in criminal matters between EU Member States.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on procedural safeguards for children suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings. To be quite precise, these are persons suspected or prosecuted who are the subject of criminal proceedings who have reached the age of 18, but not yet the age of 21, when the offence is presumed to have been committed before the age of 18.  Of course, their fundamental rights must be guaranteed, as is already the case in all Member States. I am citing, among other things, access to a lawyer. However, this Commission directive will make procedures more cumbersome and complicated, and procedural errors more likely. The European Union, moreover, is in the process of developing a common criminal law, even though it is the competence of the Member States.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it tries to draw up the basics of a European children's criminal law. Criminal justice, in my view, must be a matter of state sovereignty.  The text is also worrying, because each guarantee it enshrines comes with vague and overly general exceptions. The protection of children does not come out of it.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted AGAINST this proposal. It applies to persons who are the subject of criminal proceedings for an offence committed before the age of 18 and who are between the ages of 18 and 21 at the time of the proceedings. With good intentions, it advocates the adoption of a panel of rights for these children such as the right to information, the right to be assessed in a personalised manner or the right to be examined by a doctor. Nevertheless, this directive would add to and complicate criminal proceedings. Moreover, the majority of the rights mentioned in the text are fundamental rights in a rule of law and do not require regulation. The European Union is therefore grossly interfering, once again, in the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive on the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, since I understand that it is a step forward in establishing procedural safeguards aimed at protecting the right of minors to have a fair trial and to avoid their recidivism by promoting their social integration. In the process of negotiating with the Council, Parliament has succeeded in including in the Directive its main claims, such as the strengthening of the right to information by the child, as well as the obligation for the child to be assisted by a lawyer, to have the right to appear at trial and medical follow-up, and for deprivation of liberty to be considered the last resort. Therefore, considering that this directive is a positive step towards the protection of the procedural safeguards of minors in criminal proceedings, I voted in favour. .

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. A study carried out at European level shows that the rights of minors subject to criminal proceedings in the European Union are currently not sufficiently guaranteed. In fact, there is no legal definition of the fundamental elements of a 'fair process for minors'. This is not isolated, as the Commission estimates that more than one million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU each year. The main purpose of this report is to establish a number of rights of suspected or accused minors in criminal proceedings through a structured body of minimum standards tailored to the specific needs of minors facing prosecution. Within this body of minimum standards we would find the right to be assisted by a lawyer (right to legal aid), right to an individual evaluation and right to participation of the child in the process, among others. I vote in favour of this report on the belief that it is necessary to establish a framework to ensure the necessary legal certainty for minors facing criminal proceedings and not to leave these cases to fragmented case-law.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I understand the requirement that persons under the age of 18 accused of crimes be treated "with care, sensitivity and their age, maturity and intellectual abilities, and should also take into account communication problems on the part of children." I also agree that 'criminal proceedings involving children should take place in such a way that children are not intimidated and treated sensitively'. On the other hand, I do not want the EU to impose on the Member States how strangely they should treat juvenile defendants.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. According to the latest Commission figures, over 1 million children in the EU are currently suspected or charged with criminal offences. The treatment of children who are suspected or charged in criminal proceedings varies greatly between Member States. Currently, only 6 Member States have criminal proceedings specialising in minors and only 12 Member States are specifically educated by judicial staff for dealing with children in criminal proceedings. It is important to establish a single system of rules for all Member States that ensures compliance with the rights of children and minors suspected or charged in criminal proceedings, so I supported this report.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ at present, the laws of the Member States regulate the status and treatment of children subject to criminal proceedings in different ways. Children have different, often insufficient, levels of protection in this proceeding from country to country. In this respect, the European Court of Human Rights has also handed down a number of judgments against the Member States. I support the adoption of the proposal for a directive that takes into account the special status of children and ensures uniform minimum requirements for the protection of children's rights in criminal proceedings (inseparable right to assistance of a lawyer, right to free legal aid, right to individual assessment, rules on the conduct of hearings, etc.). The directive will also apply to young people aged between 18 and 21 if they have committed the offence before the age of 18.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on procedural guarantees for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/3/2016, and because this report is not complete.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this directive. It should apply to persons who have reached the age of 18, but not yet the age of 21, suspected or prosecuted, subject to criminal proceedings, where the offence is presumed to have been committed before the age of 18: any child deprived of liberty would have the right to challenge the legality of that deprivation of liberty before a court or competent authority. , independent and impartial. This text will make the procedures even more cumbersome and complicated and will encourage procedural errors. It is also an attempt by the Union to establish a common criminal law, when it is normally a competence of the Member States. According to the European Commission, around 1 million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU, or 12% of the total number of people subject to criminal proceedings. Moreover, this report does not mention that a large part of youth crime is related to immigration!

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings.  At present, there are still too many differences in the treatment of children in criminal proceedings in the various Member States and, all too often, the rights of children in proceedings are not sufficiently guaranteed in the European Union.  This proposal aims to ensure that European citizens have the right to a fair trial throughout the Union and to increase mutual trust in the justice systems of other Member States, in order to facilitate the mutual recognition of their judicial decisions. It is of great importance to ensure that children are guaranteed the right to a fair trial throughout the criminal proceedings and thus to ensure the proper functioning of European justice.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal. Currently, only six Member States (Belgium, Czech Republic, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg and Slovakia) have dedicated juvenile prosecution services, and nine Member States do not even have juvenile courts. Special training for judges and lawyers who come into contact with children in their work is compulsory in only 12 Member States. In some Member States, there is no legal obligation for children to be assisted by a lawyer; in others, it is available only in the courts, but not in police stations; in others still, the decision is up to the relevant court. As a result, a substantial number of children in the EU do not enjoy the basic right to be assisted by a lawyer.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this directive because it strengthens the guarantees for minors investigated or charged in criminal proceedings, establishing the new principles for juvenile due process. Minors are not and cannot be prosecuted like adults. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. U2012 We must ensure that minors who are suspected or charged with a crime have a fair trial. For that reason, my support for the Directive recognising the right of any person under the age of 18 to be assisted by a lawyer and accompanied by the holder of parental responsibility (or other appropriate adult) during most proceedings. We establish a catalogue of rights and guarantees as a common European model of fair trials for minors, which will ensure that in all procedures there are guarantees for minors, ensuring that the child's interest is always the primary consideration.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The right to a fair trial is a fundamental right of every citizen, constitutionally enshrined in almost all EU Member States and protected by the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the European Convention on Human Rights.  The need to preserve it appears even more imperative in criminal cases involving the possibility of deprivation of liberty of a person, let alone when that person is a minor. Procedural guarantees or procedural rules regulating judicial proceedings form an integral part of that right. National justice systems must therefore ensure all guarantees of a fair and impartial trial, taking into account the particular needs of those minors. The resolution rightly points out that there should be special courts for minors, staffed with specially trained judges, with direct provision of free legal assistance by the State to the arrested minor. Special reference should be made to interrogation methods, which may not be the same as those used for adult suspects. Finally, the prison measures imposed on minors should be reformative and not punitive in nature, taking into account the psychosynthesis of young people. This requires the imposition of a prison sentence as a last-term means and detention in special juvenile prisons.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. More than one million children are involved in criminal proceedings in the EU every year, according to the European Commission. There are significant differences in the treatment of children in the Member States when faced with criminal proceedings. According to various sources, it is clear that children's rights are currently not sufficiently guaranteed, and I therefore support the proposals set out. I also believe that Member States should provide specific training to judges, law enforcement agencies and prison staff who work with children.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to provide children with procedural safeguards when suspected of committing a crime and to provide them with the right to legal aid.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I reject this directive, which aims to establish a common law, which is so far the competence of States. It's like we want to burden and complicate the procedures to make them fairer. As a result, I have spoken out against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive on procedural safeguards for suspected or accused minors in criminal proceedings. Considering Article 82(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, it is the establishment of specific minimum standards with regard to the procedural safeguards of suspected or accused minors in criminal proceedings, with a view to the specific needs of minors throughout the proceedings, promoting the application of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The aim of the Directive is to ensure that minors are able to understand and monitor the proceedings by exercising their right to a fair trial, preventing recidivism.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it is important to protect minors and with this resolution, the interest of minors accused will be ensured and protected at every stage of criminal proceedings.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome Parliament's adoption of its position on the draft directive on procedural safeguards for children who are suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings. An essential tool for the right to a fair trial, this new legislation represents a significant step forward in the protection of persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings. Given the vulnerability of children and the need to put the best interests of the child first, the establishment of common European minimum standards was a necessity to strengthen the protection of minors involved in legal proceedings. These children must be able to enjoy the same level of protection and rights throughout the Union. The provisions concerning the deprivation of liberty of minors are particularly important: detention should only be used as a last resort and, if necessary, the child should be detained separately from adults. In general, it is important that all decisions made against minors in criminal proceedings take due account of the best interests of the child. I am also pleased that, with this legislation, a further step has been taken in the establishment of a European area of justice.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – According to current estimates, around one million children in the EU are subject to criminal proceedings annually. In order to protect the rights of juveniles, law enforcement authorities and courts should take into account the specific needs of juvenile suspects/accused of a crime by providing minimum procedural guarantees. Investigating crimes committed by juveniles is difficult and requires a specific approach compared to investigating adult offenders. The legislation on criminal proceedings with minor suspects/accused in the Member States remains incoherent and contains shortcomings which are reflected in the lack of regard for the specific nature of trials against juvenile offenders (e.g. the absence of specialised courts and the juvenile prosecutor's office in some Member States). I believe that this directive, which includes procedural guarantees such as the right to a lawyer and free legal aid, the right to individual case-law assessment, rules on the conduct of hearings (including the right to audiovisual recording), ensuring the participation of a child in legal proceedings, the right to medical assessment, the right to special treatment in the event of deprivation of liberty, the establishment of mandatory special training for judges or the clarification of key definitions such as 'child' or 'holder of parental responsibility' will also contribute to overcoming certain shortcomings. The proposal as presented will ensure that juvenile rights are protected at all stages of criminal proceedings, so I support it.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings because it will help to properly protect child suspects’ safety in criminal proceedings across the European Union.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission estimates that more than 1 million children are prosecuted in the EU each year. Research shows that children's rights are currently not sufficiently secured at different stages of proceedings within the European Union. In view of this, the Commission has submitted a proposal for the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council aimed at defining a limited but integral list of the rights of children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings (or children subject to European arrest warrant procedures).  In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament adopt the Commission's proposal at first reading with almost 80 amendments. The vast majority of amendments are aimed at refining, expanding, strengthening or clarifying the rules on the various rights referred to in the Commission proposal. In addition, it is proposed to introduce a new article providing redress in the event of a breach of rights under this Directive and to include a new paragraph at the beginning of Article 12 in order to provide for certain minimum guarantees applicable in the event of the child's possible arrest and not covered by the Commission's text, including access by the holder of parental responsibility or other appropriate adult persons. I supported the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This directive sets out the rights of persons under the age of 21 who are the subject of criminal proceedings, where the offence is alleged to have been committed before the age of 18, including questioning, the assistance of a lawyer or a doctor. It will make procedures more cumbersome and complicated, and procedural errors more likely, often resulting in undue nullities. The European Union, moreover, is in the process of developing a common criminal law, even though it is the competence of the Member States. For these reasons it is not desirable to support this text.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 It is estimated that more than one million minors are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU each year, representing 12 % of those involved in criminal proceedings. In addition to these data, there are other alarm factors, such as the discrepancy between Member States in the treatment of minors subject to criminal proceedings. Currently, according to studies carried out at European level, the rights of minors at various stages of criminal proceedings are not adequately guaranteed within the Union and there are many cases of conviction by member states by the European Court of Human Rights. I support, like the conclusions of the Stockholm Programme, the need to ensure, by means of common minimum rules, the effective and sufficiently uniform benefit of the right to a fair trial during all stages of the proceedings by persons under the age of 18. I would like to point out as essential, and safeguarded in the proposal, the right to be assisted by a defender, the right to an individual assessment, the participation of the minor in the proceedings, the inclusion of compulsory specific training for those who work with minors and the provisions on deprivation of liberty, on the basis of which the application of pre-trial detention should be established only as a last resort.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This report focuses on the establishment of procedural safeguards for minors suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings. It aims to grant special rights before or during interrogation to minors and adults prosecuted for acts committed during their minority.  This directive will make criminal procedures more cumbersome, tedious and complicated, and procedural errors more likely. I see it as an attempt to develop a common criminal law across the EU, when it is an exclusive competence of the Member States. So I chose to vote against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, which includes one on safeguards for children, and another on legal aid. Labour MEPs support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as procedural safeguards for children. Along with Ireland and Denmark, the UK will not opt into this directive so there is no conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of a report that is part of the "procedural rights package". It aims to define common minimum standards for procedural safeguards for children suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings.  In a European Union where legal and judicial cooperation is strengthened, it is essential to adopt a common basis to guarantee each individual equal rights in each Member State. Such provisions will also, in the case of a conflict of law, ensure that children have less different rights regardless of the judge's choice.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for the agreement reached by Parliament setting common minimum standards for procedural safeguards for children suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 The protection of children's rights is of particular importance and requires special care. That is why I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings.  Some Member States of the European Union treat child prosecutions differently. While in some countries, as in my own country, Slovakia, minors are dealt with by special prosecutors, there are Member States where even the assistance of lawyers is not guaranteed in such cases. As the report confirms, the introduction of minimum standards for child prosecutions is very important in many respects. On the one hand, it would ensure that all minors receive adequate legal protection and, on the other hand, it would motivate Member States to trust each other's criminal justice systems, which would have a good chance of increasing the number of mutually recognised judicial decisions and decisions.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal for a directive is established in order to strengthen procedural rights of suspected or accused persons in criminal proceedings. I have voted for this report that has as its main provisions: the rules on questioning; the right to an individual assessment; the mandatory right to be assisted by a lawyer, in close connection with the right to free legal aid; the provision for the child to take part in the proceedings; compulsory special training for judges, law enforcement authorities and prison staff, lawyers and others who come into contact with children in their work; the provisions on detention, under which children should be held on remand only where there is no alternative, and in such cases, it must be ensured that the children are held separately from adults, except where it is in their best interests not to do so.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported the proposal for a directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. I believe that as part of the EU agenda on the rights of the child, it will also promote children's rights within other legal instruments. According to current data, the number of children brought to court in the EU exceeds one million each year. At the same time, there are large differences in their treatment between Member States. Not all countries have specialised juvenile courts and only a small proportion of them have prosecution services.  I voted for the directive because I believe that it will be able to impose a set of rules that balance the differences in the different legal systems of the Member States.  I believe it is our moral duty to ensure maximum protection for children at the various stages of criminal proceedings. We need to remind ourselves more often that it is they who are our future.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ As there is at present no definition in the EU of what constitutes a ‘fair trial’ for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, this proposal is very timely. The continuous involvement of the European Court of Human Rights in challenging Member State court rulings against children, as well as the fact that only in some Member States do children have the right to be assisted by a lawyer, testifies to the need for a more coherent and streamlined catalogue of rights to protect children throughout the EU. It is with this in mind that I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that, in line with European tradition, children and adolescents should have greater legal protection in criminal proceedings, taking into account their vulnerability and lower degree of maturity. In particular, I welcome the amendment to the right to privacy under which Member States are to ensure that court hearings involving children are normally held with the exclusion of the public, or to allow courts or judges to decide to hold such acts with the exclusion of the public. I have a reservation about the provision adopted under which The Member States, with full regard to freedom of expression and information and media freedom and pluralism, call on the media to take self-regulatory measures in order to achieve the objectives of protecting children's privacy. First of all, it is a provision that is legally un enforceable. In addition, the call for self-regulatory measures lags behind the level of legal protection, for example in the Czech Republic, where the publication of the first and last names of minors in criminal proceedings and information leading to the identification of minors applies directly.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. In most countries, the Directives on the protection of children have already been well implemented and do not require any additional consideration by the EU. I abstained from voting.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim of the report is to strengthen the procedural rights of children suspected and accused in criminal proceedings and to ensure uniform minimum standards that take account of the specific needs of children. The European Commission estimates that more than one million children take part in criminal proceedings each year, i.e. 12 % of all criminal cases are children. In addition to the figures, there are also major differences in the treatment of children involved in criminal proceedings among Member States. Studies carried out at European level show that at present children's rights are not sufficiently protected in the Union at different stages of the procedure.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the report submitted.  All Member States must respect human rights and ensure their proper implementation. The EU should have a common catalogue of the rights of children suspected or accused in criminal matters, adapted to the specific needs of children at all stages of the proceedings, and ensure a fair trial for the child. In particular, children suspected or accused should exercise their right to understand and follow the proceedings and their right to a fair trial.  I believe that it is appropriate to extend the scope of the directive to young people under the age of 18 but not yet 21 years old, when a certain offence was committed before the age of 18. In addition, it is essential to ensure that the restriction of liberty to the child is limited to the last resort. The courts should make every effort to impose this sentence only where this cannot be avoided and to provide specific and detailed reasons for that decision. In each case, respect for human dignity and the rights of the child in custody must be respected, taking due account of the child's personality and the particular circumstances in which he or she committed the offence. Particular attention must be paid to the prevention of child crime and the promotion of social inclusion.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I can only be positive and vote in favour of the proposed legislation which ensures the correctness of the judicial process for children who are suspected or accused of a crime. This legislative framework is an important guarantee of safeguarding children's rights in the judicial process.  These arrangements fill a gap that is observed in many Member States, including my own, where there does not seem to be an adequate written legislative framework for the care and safeguarding of the rights of minors.  This directive, in short, guarantees a common European standard for the provision of fair judicial proceedings to minors and its content can only be accepted.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. The UK has had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that it is estimated that 12% of criminal proceedings in the EU concern children and that only 6 states have specialised public prosecutors' bodies, I believe that the proposal for a directive creating a structured body of 'minimum' standards is necessary in order to ensure a fair trial of the child. In the same way, I welcome the amendments which lead to a strengthening of discipline, and i must therefore vote in favour of them.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Effective human rights protection is fundamental to any concept of fairness in the criminal justice system. Fairness, however, is relative: it may require different levels of protection in different circumstances. Children require special measures of protection to take account of their particular vulnerability and needs. According to the Commission, approximately 1 million children face criminal justice proceedings in the EU each year. I welcome the clear standards protecting children’s rights and hence I voted in favour of the report.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I support the proposal because, through minimum common rules, it is necessary to ensure the effective and more uniform exercise of the right to a fair trial for all persons under the age of 18. This is linked to the objective of promoting mutual recognition of judgments and judgments in the field of criminal law and to ensuring the necessary legal protection for children.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I express my concern at the Commission's estimates that say that more than 1 million children in Europe are involved in criminal proceedings each year, i.e. 12% of the total. As a person who advocates the protection of human rights, I would like to point out the lack of protection of the rights of minors, as confirmed by eu research.  In order to reduce these disastrous figures, I want to highlight the important role of families in the upbringing and formation of children, as the Convention on the Rights of the Child explicitly states. We should first of all be based on solving causes, not consequences. The report introduces improvements in terms of better protection of minors in terms of the right to free legal aid, as well as the right to assistance of lawyers. Furthermore, training for judges and lawyers and law enforcement and prison staff shall also be cited in particular. On the basis of all this, I welcome the Report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The criminal status of minors is not part of the competence of the European Union. It is up to the Member States to decide what measures they want to put in place for children suspected or prosecuted.  Moreover, the text introduces cumbersome procedures which are sure to lead to an increase in procedural errors. Finally, many of the rights mentioned in the text are fundamental rights already recognised by all Member States. For all these reasons, I am voting against this report.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report improves on the Commission's already positive proposal for a directive on procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings, part of the 'Stockholm Programme' aimed at ensuring the effective exercise of the right to a fair trial.  The Commission estimates that more than one million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the Union every year. There are major differences between Member States in their treatment and, in many cases, children are not sufficiently guaranteed, as demonstrated by the numerous condemnations of states by the European Court of Human Rights. In this situation, it was essential to intervene in order to establish a minimum but essential catalogue of rights. I agree with the main measures proposed by the Commission, including the essential right to the assistance of a lawyer and free legal aid, the obligation to train all those in contact with children, measures concerning the deprivation of personal freedom, etc. Equally important are improvements, such as the extension of legal aid at every stage of the procedure, which is the subject of strong conflict with the Council, but on which Parliament has finally managed to extend its scope.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. More than 1 million children in the EU are involved in the case each year, accounting for 12% of total criminal proceedings. There are large differences between Member States in the ways in which children in criminal proceedings are treated. Worryingly, children's rights are not sufficiently protected at different stages of criminal proceedings in the EU and that the European Court of Justice has had to intervene countless times with a judgment against Member States. Currently, only six Member States (Belgium, the Czech Republic, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg and Slovakia) have a special prosecutor's office for minors, while nine Member States do not have youth courts. Special training for judges and lawyers who come into contact with children in their work is mandatory in only 12 Member States. In some Member States, there is no legal obligation for lawyers to support children, while in other countries this right is only achievable in court, but not in police stations, or the decision is within the discretion of the court. As a result, a significant number of children in the EU do not enjoy a fundamental right to assistance from lawyers. For this reason, I strongly support this directive, which creates minimum standards at EU level in order to properly protect suspected children in criminal proceedings across the Union.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The Stockholm Programme stressed the importance and need to ensure, through minimum rules, the effective benefit of the right to a fair trial during all stages of criminal proceedings.  This Directive is part of a set of measures already adopted to promote the rights of minors. It is estimated that every year more than one million minors are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU, accounting for 12% of those involved in criminal proceedings. It is in this context that the Commission's proposal for a directive is part of the Commission's proposal for a directive, which seeks to define a set of rights of minors who are suspects or accused in criminal proceedings in a structured body of "minimum" standards. Among others, the: the inalienable right to free legal aid and to be assisted by a defender; the right to an individual assessment; the interrogation procedure; the possibility of the minor's participation in the process; the inclusion of compulsory specific training for all those working with minors; provisions on deprivation of liberty and ensuring that minors are detained separately from adults.  We voted in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I welcome this report and fully support it. I am convinced that children and young people need better regulated protection and guarantees in criminal proceedings. All Member States of the European Union are signatories to a number of international documents on the rights of the child, including the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, and as such should guarantee all rights of children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. However, practice often shows that many of them do not offer sufficient guarantees when it comes to protecting the rights of suspects or accused minors. Of utmost concern is the fact that as many as nine Member States of the Union do not have special youth courts, and only twelve members by law oblige judges and lawyers to dress specifically for working with minors. I therefore hope that this report will also contribute to improving legislation in the field of protection of minors in criminal proceedings across the Union.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 More than one million children in the European Union face criminal charges every year. That's 12% of the total number of criminal judicial procedures. It should be noted that every individual under the age of 18 is considered to be a child in this context. The proposed directive wants to set minimum common standards for the rights and treatment of children prosecuted or accused. The common rules should include the right to the presence of a lawyer during all hearings, which should also be recorded audio-visually in such cases. Priority should always be given to a solution other than remand, if detention is necessary for any reason, due care and consideration must be guaranteed. I do not want to stand up for criminals regardless of age, but there are many, many cases where a crime is committed by a child abused, abused or self-defence. This must be borne in mind and guaranteed by law with dignified and fair treatment. I think that the directive is of good quality as a result and will lead to the regulation of the disproportionate psychological burden on these children.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission estimates that more than 1 million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU each year. In addition to the figures, the strong differences between Member States in the treatment of children subject to criminal proceedings are of concern. To date, only six Member States have specialised public prosecutors' bodies for children, in 9 Member States there are not even specialised courts, while only in 12 Member States is there compulsory specific training for judges and lawyers working in contact with children.  The result is that a substantial number of children in the EU do not have the basic right to be assisted by a lawyer. I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal for a directive because I believe that establishing a catalogue of the rights of children being investigated or charged in criminal proceedings through a structured body of 'minimum' standards is necessary to ensure the right to a fair trial during all stages of judicial proceedings.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. This text, which is part of the "procedural rights package", aims to define common minimum standards for procedural safeguards for children suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings. I'm in favour of it.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. The UK has had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 Specialised prosecution bodies currently exist for minors in only six Member States (Belgium, Czech Republic, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg and the Republic of Slovakia) and in nine countries there are not even specialised courts. Only 12 Member States provide for mandatory specific training for judges and lawyers working with minors and, in some countries, the assistance of a lawyer is not guaranteed; in others, it is possible only in court and not in police stations; in others, the decision rests with the competent judge. That is why a significant number of minors in the EU are not recognised today with the basic right to be assisted by a lawyer. It is in this context that the Commission's proposal for a directive is included, which seeks to define a narrow but organic range of rights of minors who are suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings (or the subject of a European arrest warrant execution procedure), with a structured body of "minimum" standards, reciprocally linked to each other and appropriate to the specific needs of minors throughout the proceedings. In view of the foregoing, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. I voted with my entire political group on this text, which harmonizes the legal protection of children suspected or accused of a crime, promising them a fair trial wherever they are in Europe.  It is now impossible to obtain European statistics on the number of children facing justice each year. In Belgium, in 2010, 2,062 minors were convicted of criminal activity and they represented 0.8% of the prison population. Perhaps more worryingly, 96 children were tried in adult courts in criminal cases in 2011, a 72% increase over the previous year. In such circumstances, it is important for the child to understand the legal process he or she is facing, to be accompanied by a lawyer and a parent, and to have the right to individual assessment in order to give priority to the prevention of recidivism.  In this afternoon's vote, MEPs called for juvenile justice in Europe to meet their specific needs and for the best interests of the child to prevail - a right guaranteed by the Declaration of the Rights of the Child.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission estimates that every year more than one million minors will be subject to criminal proceedings in the European Union, accounting for 12 % of those involved in criminal proceedings in that territory. There are many discrepancies between Member States in the treatment of minors subject to criminal proceedings. Specialised prosecution bodies for minors exist in only six Member States (Belgium, Czech Republic, Greece, Italy, Luxembourg and the Republic of Slovakia) and in nine countries there are not even specialised courts. Only in 12 Member States is mandatory specific training is provided for judges and lawyers working with minors. A significant number of minors in the EU have not recognised the basic right to be assisted by a lawyer. This proposal aims to define a narrow but organic range of rights of minors who are suspects or accused in criminal proceedings, with a structured body of 'minimum' nomas, reciprocally linked to each other and appropriate to the specific needs of minors throughout the process.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing.  I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. The proposal reflects the agreement reached with the Council after lengthy negotiations in the tripartite dialogue and strengthening the Commission's proposal by extending its material scope and strengthening legal assistance – the child will receive such assistance ex officio, without requesting it – the individual evaluation of the processing and medical examination of the processing.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament in Strasbourg on Wednesday afternoon backed new provisions to ensure that children suspected or prosecuted for a crime receive a fair trial. This directive, informally concluded with the Council last December, recognises the right of any minor to be assisted by a lawyer and to be accompanied by the holder of parental responsibility (or another appropriate adult) for most of the proceedings.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I see this document as very important and very well prepared. The provisions on children's rights, the assistance of a lawyer, the maintenance of family relations and the like can only be accepted. The only thing that could be added is that the prosecution of children must have the aim not only of punishing them, but also of re-educating, socialising and returning to society full citizens. I missed this statement in this document.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is part of the "procedural rights" package and aims to define common minimum standards for procedural safeguards for children suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings. The agreement reached as a result of negotiations with the Council establishes clear definitions of the child and parental responsibility. It also establishes the right to information for children with specific rules. The final text also enshrines the right of minors to have access to a lawyer in order to provide them with legal aid. Other rights are also present in the directive, such as the audiovisual recording of the interrogation or the right to a medical examination. In the end, this text is balanced; it aims to ensure that children can understand and follow the legal process and to prevent reoffending.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote in favour of this report stems from the need to provide greater procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings. Despite these very sensitive situations, I believe that as minors we have a duty to protect them adequately in order to teach these young people lessons of justice who could return to crime tomorrow. For this reason, guarantee them the essential right to be assisted by a lawyer; the right to be assessed individually; provision for specific training for magistrates, are some of the elements that will help these children.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Chinnici report. The rapporteur proposes some amendments aimed at improving, extending, strengthening or clarifying the rules on the various rights affected by a Commission Directive which aims to define a reduced but organic catalogue of the rights of minors suspected or charged in criminal proceedings (or the subject of proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant) , through a structured body of 'minimum' standards, linked to each other and adapted to the specific needs of minors throughout the process. Its approval implies a significant development of the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive on the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, since I understand that it is a step forward in establishing procedural safeguards aimed at protecting the right of minors to have a fair trial and to avoid their recidivism by promoting their social integration. In the process of negotiating with the Council, Parliament has succeeded in including in the Directive its main claims, such as the strengthening of the right to information by the child, as well as the obligation for the child to be assisted by a lawyer, to have the right to appear at trial and medical follow-up, and for deprivation of liberty to be considered the last resort. Therefore, considering that this directive is a positive step towards the protection of the procedural safeguards of minors in criminal proceedings, I voted in favour.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 According to statistics, more than one million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU every year, most often in a country other than their own. The problem lies in the fact that the treatment of children in criminal proceedings differs considerably between Member States. The proposed directive aims to establish common minimum standards for the rights of minors who are investigated or charged in criminal proceedings and in proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant, in order to facilitate mutual recognition of judgments and judicial decisions and cross-border cooperation. The provisions relate in particular to the right of the child to be assisted by a lawyer, the right to an individual assessment, the right to a medical examination and the right to request the audiovisual recording of the interrogation. I hope that this strengthening and extension of rights will provide a further guarantee that the child will be treated in the same way in all the countries of the European Union with the care and sensitivity appropriate to his or her age and particular needs. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ This is a legislative report that seeks to create common minimum standards for children in criminal proceedings. The UK has had, for many years, high standards of safeguards in place for children in criminal proceedings. The UK Government has chosen not to opt into this directive as the current text would cause operational difficulties for the UK. In light of this, UKIP MEPs have voted to abstain on this vote for two reasons. Firstly, whilst we are of course not against high standards of safeguards for children involved in criminal proceedings, we are principally against the EU interfering in Member States’ judicial systems. Secondly, as the UK has chosen not to opt into this directive, it should not be the business of British MEPs to vote on laws that will not affect us.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. – I supported this directive to ensure that children accused of crimes in any Member State are treated with dignity, and are made aware of their legal rights, while also ensuring that young criminals cannot escape justice across the whole EU.  Children are a crucial and scarce resource for our continent, and we must create a legal justice system that both respects and disciplines them.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported this proposal for a directive that will provide guarantees for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings across The Member States of the Union for fair judicial proceedings. The proposal emerges from the Commission's long-standing plan to empower suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings, as well as the 2011 Children's Rights Plan. It is necessary to set common minimum standards at Union level for children's rights in these proceedings, as currently only 6 Member States have specific departments dealing with children in criminal proceedings, while in other countries children are tried in ordinary court. Also, only 12 Member States have specially trained judges for the purpose of trialing children. The proposed directive considers every person under 18 to be a child and ensures that every child in these procedures must be informed of their rights, as must the parents/guardians of the child. It also sets criteria for the protection of personal data as well as the right to a lawyer, individual assessment, medical examination.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing \ u2012 The proposal for a directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings forms part of the EU agenda on the rights of the child and aims to promote children's rights with regard to other instruments, including guidance from the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe on child justice. More than one million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU each year, representing 12% of the total number of persons involved in criminal proceedings, according to Commission estimates. In addition, significant differences between Member States in the treatment of children subject to criminal proceedings are also worrying. EU research shows that children's rights are currently not sufficiently protected in the EU at different stages of criminal proceedings and that there are a number of judgments of the European Court of Human Rights against Member States. Particular attention must be paid to the fact that specific safeguards, taking into account the age and vulnerability of children of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings, do not cause distortions which would prevent criminal proceedings from fulfilling a proper purpose, which is to establish objectively and impartially whether the person concerned can be held criminally responsible for the offence in question.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a directive at first reading, which aims to set a minimum standard of rights for children accused or suspected in criminal proceedings. The legislation on this issue varies from one Member State to another, a specialised court is set up in some Member States, others do not, the training requirements for persons involved in child proceedings vary, and I could go on. Harmonisation of rules is important to strengthen trust between states in cross-border judicial cooperation. In particular, the Directive provides children with the right to information – important for the exercise of other rights – to a compulsory defence, to the protection of privacy, to the protection of personal freedom, to a timely and proper hearing of the case and others. I consider the emphasis on the protection of children's privacy or the minimum use of the detention institute to be key, as this reduces the risks of children being ousted from society by the procedure itself. The proposed regulation also develops cross-border procedural rules in the context of the European Arrest Warrant. We already have a number of procedural safeguards in Czech law for children in criminal proceedings, but the directive nevertheless develops, for example, the rights of the holder of parental responsibility or gives greater emphasis to the individual assessment of the case. I believe that the benefit for Czech law will be specifically mandatory professional training of lawyers who will defend children, in communication with children and in the psychology of children.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The Commission estimates that more than one million children in the EU are involved in criminal proceedings every year. That's 12% of all cases. However, the treatment of children in criminal proceedings differs significantly between Member States. For example, in some Member States, children are not granted a fundamental right to the assistance of a lawyer. For this reason, in 2013, the Commission proposed a directive protecting the rights of children in criminal proceedings as part of a broader legislative package of procedural rights. It is important that persons under the age of 18 are guaranteed the effective and uniform exercise of the right to a fair trial at all stages of the proceedings. The right to the assistance of a lawyer is inalienable and relates to the right to legal aid. The directive puts the child's benefit at the forefront, as it contains important elements such as the right to an individual assessment and the way in which the hearing is to be carried out. Judges, lawyers and others dealing with children must be trained specifically to do so. If other safe measures are disabled, children may be detained only on condition that the children are detained separately from adult children. I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive because it will establish good minimum rights for children who are suspected or accused in criminal proceedings and will generally improve children's rights throughout the EU.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the proposal for a directive establishing procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings, offering this particularly vulnerable group adequate conditions to understand and follow the procedure involving them, exercise their right to a fair trial and facilitate their social reintegration. The Directive introduces a number of safeguards to address the particular situation of the child involved in criminal proceedings: for example, to strengthen the provisions on the indispensable right to legal aid, to ensure a thorough individual assessment aimed at identifying the specific needs of the child in terms of protection, education and training with a view to social reintegration and to ensure full respect for human integrity and dignity at all stages of the procedure. I believe that these measures are necessary to preserve the potential for growth and reintegration into society of children involved in criminal proceedings, while at the same time allowing the normal conduct of judicial activity.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. EU citizens enjoy legal certainty across the EU. This should also apply, and above all, to minors. For here, the best interests of the child must be preserved in particular, and all measures must be based on prevention rather than punishment. That is why I voted in favour of the Chinnici report with my ECR Group.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. The European Commission estimates that more than one million children are exposed to criminal proceedings in the EU every year. They are significantly disadvantaged by their young age and therefore need to be guaranteed procedural rights reflecting their specific needs in criminal proceedings. To date, there is special legislation governing the criminal proceedings of children in only a few Member States and, moreover, it is often fragmented. A set of minimum standards that would be linked and adapted to the specific requirements of children throughout the procedure appears to be an appropriate solution. I welcome the introduction of a single list of procedural rights across the EU and have therefore voted in favour of this proposal, which contains it. In particular, for example, the right to compulsory assistance of a lawyer, the right to information to parents or other designated person, the right to escort during criminal proceedings or the possibility for a court to decide on a non-public hearing.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Although Member States are party to the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, the International Agreement on Civil and Political Rights and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, experience has shown that this in itself does not always ensure a sufficient degree of trust in the criminal justice systems of other Member States. Member States should therefore ensure that judicial and law enforcement authorities and prison staff, dealing with cases involving children, are experts specialised in the field of criminal proceedings involving children. They should receive appropriate training on children's legal rights, appropriate interview techniques, child psychology, child-friendly language communication and pedagogical skills. Therefore, I supported the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ This directive is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, which includes one on safeguards for children, and another on legal aid. Labour MEPs support the idea of establishing minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as procedural safeguards for children. Along with Ireland and Denmark, the UK will not opt into this Directive so there is no conflict between national constitutional rules and secondary EU law.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ In December 2015 COREPER (Committee of Permanent Representatives) approved a compromise text agreed with the European Parliament on the Directive on the Procedure for the Protection of Rights for Children in Criminal Proceedings. The purpose of the directive is to provide protection to children under the age of eighteen who are suspected or charged in criminal proceedings, and will apply to suspected or accused children until the proceedings are closed. According to Commission estimates, more than 1 million children are involved in criminal proceedings annually in the European Union, and there are too many differences between the way children are treated in criminal proceedings in the Member States, which means that in some Member States the rights of suspected or accused children are not guaranteed at every stage of criminal proceedings. I support my colleague Chinnica's report on the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on procedural guarantees for children suspected or charged in criminal proceedings. It is important that Member States ensure that a lawyer is available to children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, that they have the right to an individual assessment in order to determine whether there are specific needs or conditions of the child, the right to a medical examination, the right to audio-visual recording of interrogations, and to provide them with specific safeguards during deprivation of liberty, especially when it comes to placing them in custody.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately today the rights of minors at the various stages of the procedure are not adequately guaranteed, hence the cases of conviction of states by the European Court of Human Rights. The proposal for a directive on procedural guarantees for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings contributes to strengthening the procedural rights of children. The aim of the report is to promote the rights of minors on the basis of a justice that takes into account the specificities of children. What is being sought is to draw up a limited but comprehensive list of the rights of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings (or subject to a European arrest warrant procedure) on the basis of a structured set of 'minimum' standards, interlinked and adapted to the specific needs of minors throughout the procedure. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal, which aims to regulate in the European Union directive that children who come before the justice system of the Member States should be provided with information, legal and parental protection appropriate to their age. In my work as a Member, it has already played an important role in promoting the special protection of the most vulnerable groups in society, especially children. I also wished to underline, by my vote, that this privileged protection is also applicable to the child as a defendant or suspect. I find the catalogue contained in the draft directive, which summarises the rights and guarantees of a fair trial, useful, and in the case of children in particular, I agree with the principle of regulation that the main purpose of the procedure or punishment should be to prevent a repeat of the crime.  The proposed legislation, in my view, contains reassuring guarantees for the separation of the child from adult criminals and for the proper child-specific preparation of prosecutors and judges acting. I hope that, following our decision, this directive will prove to be yet another European law that makes a meaningful contribution to the practicality of legal certainty, equality of rights and social solidarity in all Member States.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Every year, more than one million children are criminally examined in the EU, representing 12% of those facing criminal proceedings within the UNION. In addition to the figures themselves, there are also large differences in the treatment of children subject to criminal proceedings in different Member States.  The possibility of using a fair trial at all stages of the proceedings is a fundamental right that should be enjoyed by all persons, regardless of age. Unfortunately, this right is treated differently in many EU countries. Currently, only 6 Member States have prosecutorial bodies specialised in proceedings against children, while in 9 Member States there are not even specialised courts. The Commission's proposal for a directive, aimed at defining a limited but essential set of rights for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, is definitely a step in the right direction.  Parliament's report rightly points out the need to include in the Directive the right to compulsory assistance of a lawyer, closely linked to the right to free legal aid, the right to an individual assessment, the organisation of a hearing, the admission of a child's participation in proceedings, special training of judges, etc. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the EP report and I believe that a directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings will be adopted as soon as possible.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The administration of justice within the EU Member States remained, for the most part, a strictly national task. However, at general level, the European institutions can issue recommendations and even directives on the procedures applied by the Member States. One such area, quite sensitive, is that of procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings.  Children are, by their very position in society, the most vulnerable to criminal offences, and they generally do not have the necessary discernment to avoid certain criminal behaviour. In those circumstances, cases of juvenile delinquency should be provided with special legal assistance of their own motion, together with the necessary medical and individual assistance. The use of audio-video recordings of hearings should also be limited as far as possible, along with the right to privacy.  Another, very important element is the use of measures with deprivation of liberty in the case of juvenile offenders, which should constitute the last instance and only in extremely serious cases, involving especially adolescents. This document is a first step towards regulating this rather complex area, but it is a necessary measure. That is why I consider its adoption to be auspicious.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the proposed directive on the establishment of "procedural safeguards for children suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings", which is part of, along with several other measures adopted previously, as well as measures currently under discussion, the "roadmap to strengthen the procedural rights of suspects or persons prosecuted in criminal proceedings" adopted by the Council on 30 November 2009.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ 1 million children undergo criminal proceedings every year, which is 12% of all offenders. This is why I believe it to be fundamental that we agree on minimum and equal standards to guarantee that every child receives a fair trial, as standards currently vary enormously. This will also prevent children from reoffending and enable them to reintegrate into society more easily.
