Although Member States have already signed the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and other international conventions protecting children’s rights, experience has shown that, at present, children’s rights are not being sufficiently protected at the various stages in criminal proceedings. The Czech Republic is one of only 6 Member States to have a dedicated juvenile prosecution service.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 This directive is aimed at the creation of an ad hoc measure, which for the first time considers the specificity of the juvenile process at supranational level, providing clear guarantees for the children involved. This directive aims to define rights for children suspected or accused through a body of minimum standards that put the best interests of the child at the centre. It is extremely important, as this report rightly points out, that the directive establishes, again in view of the specific needs of the child and his social reintegration at the end of criminal experience, that detention must always be considered as an extreme rationale, to be available when alternative measures are not effectively viable. And, where it is inevitable to deprive the child of personal freedom, he must do everything possible to safeguard his psychophysical development and his needs for re-education.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Although Member States are signatories to the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms, the International Agreement on Civil and Political Rights and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, experience has shown that these facts alone do not always ensure a sufficient degree of trust in the criminal justice systems of other Member States. I therefore supported the proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on procedural guarantees for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, since the purpose of the Directive is to ensure a procedure for the protection of the rights of children, i.e. persons under the age of 18 who are suspected or accused of having committed crimes in a Member State of the European Union.  In my view, this Directive will provide specific measures to protect children during deprivation of liberty, in particular during detention, to ensure their right to a medical examination and to provide them with the assistance of a lawyer at each stage of the procedure.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings, as there is a very worrying high number of children involved in criminal proceedings and a large difference between Member States in relation to the treatment of children involved in criminal proceedings. There is also an alarmingly small number of special prosecutors for children. The latter directive brings many important rights and opportunities for special treatment of children, the availability of lawyers, legal aid, special provisions on deprivation of liberty and ensuring that children are detained separately from adults. The proposal for a directive also provides that judges, law enforcement and enforcement of criminal penalties, lawyers and others dealing with children are to be trained in this purpose. I consider this proposal to be a good one, as it concerns one of the most vulnerable groups, for which, despite many international acts, there is no legal definition of the basic components for a fair trial. It is also part of a plan that strengthens the procedural rights of suspects and accused persons in criminal proceedings.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Chinnici report. The rapporteur proposes some amendments aimed at improving, extending, strengthening or clarifying the rules on the various rights affected by a Commission Directive which aims to define a reduced but organic catalogue of the rights of minors suspected or charged in criminal proceedings (or the subject of proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant) , through a structured body of 'minimum' standards, linked to each other and adapted to the specific needs of minors throughout the process. Its approval implies a significant development of the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with this proposal, firstly because all citizens have the right to be presumed innocent until proven otherwise. Therefore I support the judicial process being transparent and fair, especially in the case of minors.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The European Commission estimates that one million children are subject to criminal proceedings in the European Union, or 12% of those subject to criminal proceedings. The report does not mention that much of youth crime is related to immigration. This directive will also make procedures more cumbersome and complicated, and procedural errors more likely. The European Union, moreover, is in the process of developing a common criminal law, even though it is the competence of the Member States. So I voted AGAINST this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission estimates that more than 1 million children are prosecuted in the EU each year, which is 12% of the persons involved in criminal proceedings in the same area. In addition to the figures, it is also worrying that the treatment of children prosecuted varies considerably between Member States. Research carried out at EU level shows that children's rights are currently under-secured at different stages of proceedings within the European Union, and the European Court of Human Rights often condemns Member States. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Chinnici report. The rapporteur proposes some amendments aimed at improving, extending, strengthening or clarifying the rules on the various rights affected by a Commission Directive which aims to define a reduced but organic catalogue of the rights of minors suspected or charged in criminal proceedings (or the subject of proceedings for the execution of the European arrest warrant) , through a structured body of 'minimum' standards, linked to each other and adapted to the specific needs of minors throughout the process. Its approval implies a significant development of the procedural safeguards of minors suspected or accused in criminal proceedings.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive as it will establish good minimum rights for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – The European Commission estimates that more than one million children are involved in criminal proceedings in the EU each year, representing 12% of all persons involved in criminal proceedings in the same territory. In addition to the large number, there are significant differences in the treatment of children in the Member States when faced with criminal proceedings. European studies show that children's rights are currently not sufficiently guaranteed within the Union at all stages of criminal proceedings and that the European Court of Human Rights has made decisions that are unfavourable to Member States on numerous occasions.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. The report seeks to formulate a properly structured catalogue of rights for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings with the aim of uniform protection of children’s rights across the EU. The main aim of the report is to promote children’s rights, as the legal mechanisms for children protection are not fully and uniformly applied in the Member States. According to EU researchers there are major discrepancies in the way in which children involved in criminal proceedings are treated in the various Member States, leading to insufficient children’s rights protection at the various stages in criminal proceedings in the EU.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a Directive promoting the application of rights contained in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, in particular Articles 4, 6, 7, 24, 47 and 48 there, on the basis of Articles 3, 5, 6 and 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights. Its purpose is to lay down the minimum standards which are considered indispensable in order to achieve the objective of achieving an effective level of protection for minors throughout the territory of the Union and strengthening mutual trust and judicial cooperation between its Member States. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'I support this text which better guarantees procedural safeguards for minors who are suspects or defendants in criminal proceedings. In such a situation, it is important that the minor understands how the legal proceedings work and that he is accompanied by a lawyer and a family member. Only in this way will the right to a fair trial be sufficiently guaranteed.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This report focuses on the European Parliament and Council's proposal for a directive on the establishment of procedural safeguards for children suspected or prosecuted in criminal proceedings.  Within the EU, one million children are subject to different criminal proceedings from one country to another. Nine Member States do not have jurisdiction in this area and in other states there is not even specific training for judges and lawyers.  The directive aims to establish common standards to improve access to a fair trial and child-friendly conditions across the EU. Children must be particularly protected in criminal proceedings, they must be able to be informed of the charges against them and their rights, be able to use a lawyer, etc.  Deprivation of liberty should only be used as a last resort and under certain conditions in accordance with the Convention on the Rights of the Child.  Ensuring the protection of children in criminal proceedings is important.  So I voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Directive on procedural safeguards for suspected or accused minors in criminal proceedings is part of the 'Roadmap for strengthening the procedural rights of suspects or accused persons in criminal proceedings', and falls within the EU programme for the rights of minors which seeks to promote the rights of minors in the light of other instruments, including in particular, in particular, , the guidelines of the Committee of Ministers of the Council of Europe on justice adapted to children, taking into account the fact that such instruments do not have the binding force of Union law and, therefore, the guarantees provided for therein are not fully and uniformly implemented in the Member States. It is estimated that every year more than one million minors are subject to criminal proceedings in the EU, accounting for 12% of those involved in criminal proceedings. It is in this context that the Commission's proposal for a directive is included, which seeks to define a set of rights of minors who are suspects or accused in criminal proceedings (or the subject of a European arrest warrant procedure), with a structured body of 'minimum' standards, reciprocally linked to each other and appropriate to the specific needs of minors throughout the proceedings.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The guidelines for the protection of children in criminal proceedings are to be supported in principle. However, EU interference in national criminal/procedural laws must be rejected. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament resolution on procedural guarantees in criminal proceedings for suspects or accused children. The EU should not have competences over the rules of criminal procedural law. The report clearly exceeds the COMPETENCEs of the EU and regulates an area where there should be no role for the EU.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I am delighted this important report has been adopted with such an overwhelming majority.  This directive is part of a package of proposals to further strengthen procedural rights for citizens in criminal proceedings, which includes one on safeguards for children, and another on legal aid. It is important to establish minimum standards across the EU in areas as fundamental as procedural safeguards for children. I am happy that this report reaffirms that the child’s best interests must always be a primary consideration. The field of juvenile justice must be integrated into the broader framework of children’s rights seen as human rights, also encompassing issues related to children’s poverty, their access to care and services, parenting and family, formal, non-formal and informal education, education to citizenship and their participation in societies.  That is precisely the kind of approach advocated in the Written Declaration on ‘investing in children’ that this House adopted last year, which, I would like to remind my colleagues, is the declaration signed by the highest number of MEPs since 2011.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 This report was adopted by a large majority by the relevant Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs.  Of course, I approved it by giving my vote in favour.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the report on the proposal for a directive on procedural safeguards for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. I believe that it is in the interests of children, that is, persons under 18, that minimum standards be introduced throughout the European Union in criminal proceedings, and of course the new regulation does not preclude the introduction of greater national protection. It is these uniform standards that will ensure, in addition to a minimum level of protection, easier mutual recognition of judicial decisions. Most importantly, persons under the age of 18 will always have the right to defend, to be treated in accordance with the interests of the child, to assess individually whether detention only in cases of genuine need. However, we should also not forget the protection of children who, for example, are not yet criminally responsible under Slovak law, which are children who are not yet under the age of 14 (or in some cases 15). Where these children commit a criminal offence, they are not dealt with under the criminal law system and are therefore not covered by the minimum protection provided for in this Directive. Member States with similar legislation should therefore also think about the rights of these children and ensure that they are treated in a way that always protects their interests so that these children have a chance of being properly included in life without unnecessary stigmatisation.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I supported a legislative proposal providing procedural guarantees for children suspected or accused in criminal proceedings. I believe that these special safeguards are necessary in order to establish a uniform regime within the Union, since it has been found that in some Member States procedural safeguards for children are lackly regulated. Children in criminal proceedings will be guaranteed, inter alia, the right to a counsel, the right to a medical examination, the right to an audio-visual recording during a hearing and special guarantees during deprivation of liberty.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: – Mr President, we voted today on the first lines for the 2017 budget. There is still a long process of concretion of funds and, therefore, we have abstained, to keep the dialogue open before finally closing the budget.  However, it seems that this budget for 2017 has not learned much from the experience. We must work for a larger European budget and a budget with better distributed incomes based, above all, on the per capita income of the Member States.  In the coming days an agreement will be closed for the return of refugees and to store them literally in third countries. It's not something you can sweep out, we understand. The representative of UNHCR told us yesterday that these agreements are illegal.  We are ashamed of the increase in budget to militarise the Aegean Sea and not for rescue and humanitarian reception. I believe that we still lack flexibility to adapt to humanitarian emergencies and firmness to be supportive and supportive. Let us not reject the values of the European Union, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, I voted against this report because it confirms the neoliberal orientation of European budgets, starting with their increasingly regressive funding and lack of democratic control over them.  I think it is serious that the European budget should be aimed at strengthening economic governance structures, supporting with public budgets measures to liberalise and individualise industrial relations which result in the loss of social rights for most Europeans.  Just as dramatic is that the same funds are increasingly aimed at strengthening market mechanisms, rather than being an autonomous hub for public investment, so the State ends up subsidizing private investment, rather than helping to generate a different productive model.  We need Europe to strengthen its funds in support of the democratic and sovereign decisions of its states, rather than blackmailing them, and we need agricultural and industrial development investment items to go to social and regional cohesion rather than being a crutch for the market.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, 800 years ago on a reedy stretch of riverbank in my constituency on the Thames, a bargain was struck between a recalcitrant king and some barons that led to the foundation of what was within 50 years to become a parliament meeting at Westminster. The primary function of that parliament, right from the beginning, was not representation, but holding the government to account, especially on financial questions. Everything else was a side-line – the debates, the constituency representation. The core role of a parliamentarian was to keep the executive in check. Now look at the difference between all our national parliaments when it comes to these budgetary questions and the attitude of this Parliament in this report. We as MEPs in the majority are constantly asking for more money, for more European resources, for increases in budgets. It is precisely the opposite of what national assemblies were set up to do. We keep hearing about all the uncertainties that will follow the British vote on whether to leave the EU. Well here is one absolute certainty: the budget is never going to get any smaller.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur It is clear that the main line of the guidelines was to obtain additional funds outside the limits of the multiannual financial framework. Maximise rationalisation and, above all, align with the major Member States from which these funds could also come. But of course, one can also only be congratulated for the repeated link with horizon 2020, support for the digital market, the Erasmus+ programme, and the budgetary allocations for small and medium-sized enterprises. By the way, entrepreneurship, especially among young people, education, well-being and the parallel provision of their systems, must be a priority for the European Union budget.  Clearly, I would like to conclude by noting that the additional aid resources for Greece, which will also be able to give this Member State the much needed momentum and combat existing internal economic instability more effectively. I voted in favour.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, yesterday in the United Kingdom Parliament, Mark Carney, the Governor of the Bank of England, said that there are risks to the United Kingdom leaving the EU. He ignored two other factors. One, the risk of staying in the EU, and two, the risks also of having no change within the EU.  Within this budget report today which sets out the guidelines for the 2017 budget was a statement that talked of duplicitous states trying to prevent the EU from getting more money. People in the United Kingdom must understand that if they vote to remain they are going to vote for an organisation run by civil servants whose key principle is to increase the budget of the EU without their own representation. There was a state that moved away from the United Kingdom because it said very clearly there should be representation for any taxation. Well here we are going to have increases of budgets without parliamentarians being able to do anything about it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I supported these guidelines, which are important for budgeting. For the general reason, first of all, I think that the European Union does not need to falt in another important area, and that is therefore in the budgetary area. I believe that, for example, in last year's Presidency, Luxembourg showed us how it is possible to budget effectively and approve the budget. This was one of the very successful steps taken by the Luxembourg Presidency, and I am convinced that the current Presidency of the Netherlands, as well as perhaps the Slovak Presidency, will also follow through on next year's budgeting as the last one.  I would very much like the budget to also be compiled with some variability, with some flexibility, because there are important tests before Europe, whether it be the migration crisis, whether it be strategic investments, global tensions in the European neighbourhood. These are all issues to which the European budget must respond.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on its first bid to the Council for the EU budget for 2017. Europe faces many challenges and the EU budget is crucial to meeting them. Unfortunately, the Committee on Budgets, which produced the report, wants to increase expenditure in virtually all areas instead of reprioritising the budget and focusing on core issues. The report also proposes to relax the budgetary rules. In addition, the report reappears, which the Christian Democrats clearly rejected in the election campaign. The Christian Democrats are clear that the long-term ambition is to gradually reduce EU spending on agricultural, labour market, regional and industrial policies. I therefore voted against the report. However, in separate polls, I marked support for more money to deal with migration challenges.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The positive note of the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget is economic support for large flows of people and the migration emergency. For the rest, the report talks about the need to continue coordination between the European budget and economic governance policies, and there are also weak responses to EU support for the fight against unemployment. In my opinion, this report represents another missed opportunity on the part of the EU to play an important role in European recovery. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for the 2017 Union budget because we need a strong budget for 2017 to give us the tools to respond to the many challenges we face. First, this means that we need to provide ourselves with the resources to effectively deal with the migrant and refugee crisis.  We need to make sure that we have sufficient resources and flexibility to react to a situation that, like today's, changes rapidly, while ensuring that the budget allows us to show solidarity with countries facing the brunt of the crisis. Moreover, the solution of the refugee crisis must go hand in hand with boosting European growth and competitiveness. The EU needs greater investment in areas such as education or infrastructure in order to compete in the 21st century. Too many young Europeans are still struggling to get a job and we need more action at EU level to meet this challenge. That is why we are asking for more funding for the Youth Employment Initiative to ensure that no young people in the EU are left behind.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This 2017 budget guidelines consolidate, on the income side, an uns ambitious resource policy that limits the ability to develop ambitious policies at the core levels of the European budget, such as agriculture and cohesion. On the contrary, the neoliberal management of expenditure is deepened, with its linkage to the European Semester and its market orientation being particularly serious. In addition, they support an aggressive and anti-human rights foreign policy, as is the case with funds provided to Turkey to make it a prison for refugees wishing to seek asylum from Europe. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – While there were some positive aspects to the report, there were a number of provisions which we had particular concerns with, notably own resources. Whilst it is recognised that Ireland does contribute to the EU Budget through the Traditional Own Resources (customs duties) and there is an obligation to do so, this nonetheless does not negate our concerns with how the EU budget expenditure is financed by Member States and moreover how the EU budget is allocated each year. Whilst our party considers it necessary to reform the system of financing the MFF, it considers it imperative that the revision of the forecast of Traditional Own Resources and the budgetary [revenue] of GNI balances and VAT remains free from political interference and based solely on the latest economic data, thereby providing a greater degree of certainty for both Member States and the Commission alike in forward planning. In addition, we have a number of concerns with the proposed Financial Transaction Tax, environmental tax, etc. which we believe is intended to strip a Member State of their financial competencies, whilst also being mindful of their positive intentions and of how, if used constructively, they could be very progressive.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The report on the guidelines that set out the European Parliament's key political priorities for the EU budget in 201, and provides a comprehensive overview of the current budgetary situation. Key points include: refugees and the migration crisis, the European Fund, Strategic Investments -EFSI, economic development, the initiative for the employment of new child guarantees (poverty), climate change, the payment crisis, EU relief funds and the Refugee Facility for Turkey. I voted in favour of the report, in which the European Parliament is ready to mobilise all available instruments to tackle the crisis (refugees and migration, the economic crisis, poverty, etc.).

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. By a large majority, the EU Parliament adopted a resolution setting out the Commission's general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget. With this resolution, Parliament had set what it saw as the strongest priorities for the next budget, which also correspond to my personal views. In the course of this, I have also advocated thinking about ways in which the EU budget can be used to make the Member States more balanced in terms of solidarity with each other, and supported an amendment to that effect.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The list of expenses has been lengthened by current events: that of "migrants", all considered political refugees.  In short, the EU's logic is always to increase spending in order to promote immigration. I have therefore spoken out against this text

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, I would vote against the report on principle anyway. However the report is also highly critical stating that “the Union Budget has been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour”. We do not believe that the European Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted for the 2017 budget, but the budget as it exists is not up to the challenges facing Europe. Locked in a 7-year multi-year financial framework, our annual fiscal year is excessively constrained. There is an urgent need to provide the Union with a more political and democratic budget.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for the 2017 Union budget because we need a strong budget for 2017 to give us the tools to respond to the many challenges we face. First, this means that we need to provide ourselves with the resources to effectively deal with the migrant and refugee crisis.  We need to make sure that we have sufficient resources and flexibility to react to a situation that, like today's, changes rapidly, while ensuring that the budget allows us to show solidarity with countries facing the brunt of the crisis. Moreover, the solution of the refugee crisis must go hand in hand with boosting European growth and competitiveness. The EU needs greater investment in areas such as education or infrastructure in order to compete in the 21st century. Too many young Europeans are still struggling to get a job and we need more action at EU level to meet this challenge. That is why we are asking for more funding for the Youth Employment Initiative to ensure that no young people in the EU are left behind.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the priorities of the 2017 budget, which remain growth and job creation. The recovery must be strengthened by developing key growth factors in order to stimulate job creation and restore full employment. The level of long-term unemployment, in particular unemployment in the Union's poorest regions and youth unemployment, is still a cause for concern and the EU is facing difficulties in restructuring industry. In addition, there are still differences in the economic development of European regions and Member States. The European Fund for Strategic Investments will be one of the main tools for increasing investment at EU level and will help to promote job creation. I support the calls on the Commission to actively promote synergies between the various EU funds and to set up a monitoring system to identify cases of harmonisation of EU funding. Horizon 2020, COSME, SME funding programmes, Erasmus+ are important, as well as programmes and policy instruments supporting the creation of an innovation-friendly environment and contributing to the successful implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy. The Youth Employment Initiative is an essential contribution to the Union's priority target for jobs and growth.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report covers the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget and covers the Commission section. This is the stage that formulate the general economic policy of the Union, since most of the expenditure is assigned to the individual Directorates-General, i.e. the Commission budget essentially represents the economic policy of the EU as a whole. The report underlines that the EU budget has limited capacity to deal with these crises through the use of the flexibility instrument agreed in the MTM Negotiations. In the event of further escalation of crises, the full use of existing flexibility provisions will not be sufficient to solve the problems that arise, and therefore urges the Council to loosen the constraints on the EU budget.  In fact, one can agree with this, but ultimately the report is an endorsement of the neoliberal economic policy that has been applied and failed so far. In this spirit, austerity measures are being forced on the Member States, which have pushed down real wages and contributed to the drag on the economic and social crisis. The EU budget should be used in such a way as to give priority to integration and cohesion policies for genuine convergence, based on social progress and solidarity, the creation and protection of decent, high-quality and secure jobs and the sustainable use of natural resources. On this basis, I voted against the report.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. More injunctions to member states to reduce the size of their own budget in favour of increasing their contributions to the EU... Worse, the aim is to help ever more the sacrosanct "migrants" at the expense of the citizens of our respective nations. Unacceptable!

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out Parliament's top priorities for the 2017 budget. These include financing the migration crisis and related European measures, reviving public and private investment, the youth employment initiative and supporting SMEs. It should also be noted that the report calls for more flexibility in Member States' spending in areas such as the fight against unemployment, poverty and inequality, security threats or the migrant and refugee crisis. Similarly, the report regrets that corporate tax evasion has caused huge losses in tax revenue for Member States and, consequently, a reduction in their contribution to the EU budget!

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. This report is the first step in the European Parliament's annual budgetary procedure. It aims to give the Commission a political message on the budgetary priorities of the 2017 European Parliament, before the Commission submits its draft budget for the European Union at the end of May. I voted in favour of the report as the budget has proven to be a key resource in the fight against recent crises and to respond to needs that had not been foreseen during the negotiation of the Multiannual Financial Framework for the period 2014-2020. However, I would like to clarify the meaning of my vote in Amendment No 26. While I have already spoken out in favour of increasing real wages in the most punished countries, such as Spain, by the EU's austerity policy, this amendment is formulated in a simplistic way and away from reality. Budgets cannot and should not be used for this purpose alone. That is why I abstained in that amendment

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of Mr Geier's report on the guidelines for the 2017 budget. The difficult economic, social and international context requires careful consideration of the prospects for the European budget for next year; this reflection must take account of the constraints imposed by The Council's policy and the tight-sighted agreements concluded between the Member States. The main objective of the budget must be to ensure a resumption of economic growth, a definitive overcoming of the crisis, while at the same time addressing the challenges posed by security problems and the consequences of a likely continuation of the refugee crisis. These are ambitious objectives, which require additional resources and increased investment. Coordination between public and private resources must be improved and, at the same time, the Commission must be clearly defined as to how the planned expenditure can be covered by the ceilings provided for in the 2016 and 2017 budgets. Today's vote is an important first step in defining the bottom lines of the next budget and in calling for a careful assessment of the choices.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I strongly opposed this report, which is a new representation of 'do what I say, not what I do', on the part of the European Union. The failure of the Juncker plan, subtly accepted but not admitted, gives the Social Democrat rapporteur Jens Geier a pretext to lecture the Member States called for a reduction in their national budgets and an increase in their contribution to that of the EU; all this to finance the migrant crisis and put a bandage on the wounds opened by the EU itself! For example, the report calls for an increase in the ceilings on the appropriations of special instruments, mainly to finance the EUR 3 billion in aid to Turkey. Worse, the Member States, which, suffocated by the budgetary austerity imposed on them by the Commission, had asked for a reduction in the contribution to the EU budget, are being singled out, asked to give ever more to the Guru of Brussels, with the results that we know. Bad faith which has no other purpose than to assassinate European nations by squandering their budgets in catastrophic policies.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 As every year, the Commission is trying to make what is negative pass as positive: it is not possible to demand austerity from the Member States and not to cut the unnecessary expenditure of the European institutions. I also believe that the issue of work should find much more place in the Union's programmes, given the serious inconvenience of the citizens, who do not see the supposed recovery announced by Brussels.  The EU's failed policies are clear to us all. For these reasons, I did not support the report with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against the guidelines.  I believe that the EU budget is too large and should be cut back. The report supports the agreement with Turkey on the issue of the expulsion of refugees coming to the EU. An agreement which, inter alia, contravenates the binding Geneva Convention on the Status of Refugees. Support is also being given for the payment of at least EUR 3 billion to Turkey, a country that violates human rights and the principles of democracy on a daily basis.  The report supports the extremely costly ITER fusion energy project, when the EU should instead invest heavily in renewable energy and energy efficiency and saving. The report continues to strongly support the regional and structural funds, which have long been also exposed to widespread fraud. These are some of the reasons why I choose to vote 'no'.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Geier report lays the foundations for the EP's position on the 2017 EU budget, while providing an overview of the current budgetary situation. Tackling the economic and refugee crisis are the main priorities, which will require a real revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework. A billion contribution is expected to be made to the Refugee Fund for Turkey, along with the remaining two billion that Member States have committed to contribute.   In addition, the report addresses, inter alia, the Youth Employment Initiative, the Children's Poverty Guarantee initiative or the European Strategic Investment Fund, beyond the global perspective on economic growth or climate change. Since the S&D Group, we have advocated flexibility in contributions to the budget of Member States under the Stability and Growth Pact. We also believe that solidarity, as a fundamental principle of the EU budget, must also be respected in the treatment of the refugee crisis.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament stresses that the Youth Employment Initiative is an essential contribution and priority in order to achieve the European Union's economic growth and jobs. It is therefore necessary to continue funding this programme in order to expand it, thereby providing a greater proportion of young people with effective access to the labour market through a proposal for good quality work, continuing education or apprenticeship. Parliament regrets that the negotiations on the EU budget for 2016 did not include new commitment appropriations for further funding of the Youth Employment Initiative, although youth unemployment in the EU remains particularly high. The objective of further funding must be achieved while meeting the need to promote youth mobility, supported by erasmus+. Parliament notes that, despite the initial delays in the implementation of this initiative and the constant delays in the allocation of the bodies responsible for the ACTION programmes of the YEI in many Member States, current implementation data show the capacity to fully use the funds. Parliament therefore calls on the Commission to present an evaluation of its YOUTH EMPLOYMENT Initiative by April 2016. and in any case in time to take into account the continuation of the programme in the 2017 EU budget.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Most of the Amendments tabled by the Hungarian People's Party to this report have been included in the report adopted by the European Parliament. As a result, Parliament calls on the European Commission to take account of the accelerated payment needs for cohesion investments at the planning stage and to raise funds to the necessary level. It is important that the Commission already anticipates in its draft budget the accelerated implementation of regional development programmes in the Member States and, in proportion, to increase cohesion resources. In 2017, our aim is for the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated by the projects already carried out in the Member States. The European Parliament takes the view that the 2017 budget should also ensure that funds mobilised to deal with the migration crisis are not taken at the expense of other EU programmes already in place. This proposal protects cohesion and agricultural funds when determining resources to deal with the migration crisis. The European Parliament's resolution underlines the importance of school milk and fruit schemes. On our proposal, the European Commission should examine how EU funds to finance these programmes can be raised in the 2017 budget. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 With the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget and their support, meps, including myself, have expressed our expectations for the preparation of the European Commission's budget for the following year. In this way, we pointed to the need to take economic forecasts into account in the planning itself and to maintain adequate flexibility in financial planning while overcoming crises. At the same time, payments that must be regular and foreseeable in advance are particularly exposed, in particular for the purpose of implementing the absorption of the European Structural and Investment Funds. We have also expressed the expectation that all Member States will also fulfil their commitments in the area of budgeting, because only in this way will we be able to maintain the EU's equality and unity at a satisfactory level and respond appropriately to internal and external crises.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. This report makes recommendations that have already been proposed many times, such as increasing payment credits, injunctions for Member States to reduce the size of their budgets in favour of increasing their contributions to that of the EU, an expansionist concept in the EU budget, and the novelty of further increasing funding for migrants. Therefore, I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that, for a variety of reasons, the 2017 budget will be a turning point for the European Union. The worsening of the various crises (migration, economic, etc.) and the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) will require a major effort on the part of the Union budget and, I believe, effective and permanent solutions must be found to enable the EU to cope adequately with them.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa said "to the States rigour, to the Union development". The Union must become the institution that promotes growth and development in Europe, both by acting as a catalyst for the positive realities already operating in the Union and as the architect of macroeconomic initiatives aimed at giving Europe the steering it needs.  For us progressives, the Junker Commission's investment plan is not the end point but the starting point of the shift towards growth and development that we want to give to the Union. achieving its strategic objectives on competitiveness, growth and employment, on the one hand, and in managing the current migration and refugee crisis, on the other; the persistence of socio-economic inequalities and the difficulties in terms of socio-economic convergence are worrying.  I hope that the Eu ropean budget will promote policies of convergence, integration and cohesion by pursuing the objectives within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable, supportive and inclusive growth.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This report sets out the main guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget. The rapporteur deplores the lack of resources to respond to the current migration crisis and therefore recommends raising the ceilings on the multi-year financial framework. As the peoples of Europe tighten their belts to meet the budgetary requirements of the European Commission, it proposes to increase the contributions of the Member States of the Union. We strongly oppose the 2017 budget guidelines set out in this report. It is essential, in times of economic downturn, to block the increase in the EU budget and to devote all funds to Europeans. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the refugee crisis, member Member States' solidarity is a highly debated topic at European Union level. I believe that, with regard to the aid granted by each State, account should be taken of the possibilities of each State in being able to help unblock this crisis. One of the amendments to this report, namely Amendment 22, speaks precisely about this solidarity, manifested by the Member States. It stipulates that it is uneven in the Member States and calls on the Commission to present a proposal on how the EU budget can lead Member States to take a more balanced approach to this. In other words, the European Commission should sanction states which, in the opinion of some people, would not have shown solidarity in the refugee crisis. In view of the fact that this amendment was voted on and was therefore adopted, I cannot express myself in favour of the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget, Section III because, by complying with Amendment 22, the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union would clearly be violated.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The resolution for the 2017 draft budget does not offer any interesting ideas. On the contrary, it is emphasised that many, too many statements are favourable to the work of the European institutions. Furthermore, given the serious situation of mass illegal immigration to the EU, there are several references to the (in our opinion) failed policies proposed by the Commission.  In short, one more fly, as every year, we are faced with a text that is not courageous and that does not highlight the real needs with regard to the EU budget: a net cut in expenditure, also in order to meet the needs of increasingly harassed Member States. There are too many positive references to the Union's so-called 'own resources' (including the high-level group chaired by Mario Monti), the Junker Plan and EU monetary policy.  Net of some particularly fanciful demands, a number of amendments are acceptable, but very few will gain the support of the two main political groups.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for the 2017 Union budget because we need a strong budget for 2017 to give us the tools to respond to the many challenges we face. First, this means that we need to provide ourselves with the resources to effectively deal with the migrant and refugee crisis.  We need to make sure that we have sufficient resources and flexibility to react to a situation that, like today's, changes rapidly, while ensuring that the budget allows us to show solidarity with countries facing the brunt of the crisis. Moreover, the solution of the refugee crisis must go hand in hand with boosting European growth and competitiveness. The EU needs greater investment in areas such as education or infrastructure in order to compete in the 21st century. Too many young Europeans are still struggling to get a job and we need more action at EU level to meet this challenge. That is why we are asking for more funding for the Youth Employment Initiative to ensure that no young people in the EU are left behind.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Parliament's report on the general budget guidelines marks the beginning of the annual budget procedure for Parliament. The text outlines the various elements that the 2017 budget must address: improving investment, competitiveness and job creation, as well as resolving migration and agricultural crises.  It is an ambitious budget that the European Union needs to meet the various major challenges that lie ahead. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today to enable the EU to overcome the crisis and accelerate economic recovery. Next year's Eu ropean budget must focus on the refugee crisis and economic recovery, with a quantitative and qualitative increase in investment. In particular, it must tackle the problems of long-term and youth unemployment and close the disparities in economic development in Europe. On the migrant emergency, it must be said that the European budget has already provided an immediate response to the ongoing refugee crisis. However, the crisis is still a long way from being resolved and, therefore, additional financial resources are needed to deal with it. I am deeply concerned about the low level of member states' contributions to the Regional Trust Fund for Syria and the Emergency Trust Fund for Africa and the lack of uniformity in the solidarity shown by Member States in the face of the refugee crisis. It seems clear that once again there will not be enough resources to enable the EU to tackle all the tasks assigned to it by the Member States. I therefore appeal to the Council: just deny the reality, let us ensure that the EU budget can deal with crises in a concrete way!

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ While there were some positive aspects to the report, there were a number of provisions which I had particular concerns with, notably own resources. Whilst it is recognised that Ireland does contribute to the EU Budget through the Traditional Own Resources (customs duties) and there is an obligation to do so, this nonetheless does not negate our concerns with how the EU budget expenditure is financed by Member States and moreover how the EU budget is allocated each year. Whilst my party considers it necessary to reform the system of financing the MFF, it considers it imperative that the revision of the forecast of Traditional Own Resources and the budgetary [revenue] of GNI balances and VAT remains free from political interference and based solely on the latest economic data, thereby providing a greater degree of certainty for both Member States and the Commission alike in forward planning. In addition, we have a number of concerns with the proposed Financial Transaction Tax, environmental tax, etc. which we believe is intended to strip a Member State of their financial competencies, whilst also being mindful of their positive intentions and of how, if used constructively, they could be very progressive.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as the report is a good basis for the 2017 budget. Boosting investment which will result in job creation, growth and greater competitiveness should continue to be our priority, but we also need to focus on how best we can use our budget to address the challenges related to migration and the refugee crisis. I agree that a compulsory review of the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020 is greatly needed and needs to be followed by a legislative proposal. Lastly, I deeply regret that corporate tax avoidance has caused such enormous losses in income for the Member States and their subsequent contributions to the EU budget.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the European Parliament's annual report setting out the guidelines for the 2017 budget approach. Although it is certainly to be welcomed that for the first time the issue of immigration is placed at the heart of the European budget (as requested loudly by the delegation of the 5-Star Movement during the two previous budget years), the report contains many critical and unacceptable aspects. These include the many considerations on the need to continue coordination between the European budget and the failed policies of economic governance, the absence of references to the fight against unemployment and concrete solutions to the problem of backpaying, as well as over-praise for the EFSI.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ The report addresses very well priorities for the EU budget in 2017, including reflections of the migratory flows, security issues and economic targets. The EU should be able to balance requests to mobilise quick funds in order to help to solve critical situations on one side, and needs to finance sectors which help to boost growth and create new jobs. We should not get caught by what is considered to be an acute problem and have to keep in mind our long-term visions and priorities as they will shape the EU’s future. For that reason, I did not support the amendment calling for the Commission’s proposal ‘as to how the EU budget can prompt Member States towards a more balanced approach to solidarity.’ We’ve heard several times that lack of solidarity with refugees can lead to cut in the ESIF funds to particular Member States. I do not want to see the EU budget going down this road as it represents a dangerous precedent.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and point out that the Union budget has proved to be a key instrument in dealing with recent crises and responding to needs that were not necessarily predicted when the MFF 2014-2020 was negotiated, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the migration and refugee crisis or geopolitical tensions in the European neighbourhood, which cause serious challenges and emergencies , at a time when in the EU the pace of economic recovery and investment levels are falling short of capacity, while maintaining the investment gap.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget comes at a particularly turbulent time, due to the intense social and political fermentations that make it difficult to anticipate the needs for the coming period. However, it is an important process that directly affects the course of the Union. As I believe that there are areas where this proposal does not protect the interests of the citizens of the Union and the Member States, I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I share the European Commission's political priorities for next year's budget by calling for a greater boost to investment in growth, competitiveness and employment. It was an important vote because the Eu ropean Union budget in this document proves to be an essential resource for dealing with the recent crisis. On the other hand, I could only vote against the call for greater flexibility with regard to Member States' expenditure on, for example, investment in the fight against unemployment, poverty and inequality, or even investment to deal with emerging security threats and the migration and refugee crisis, as current issues that are too important to be dealt with freely by individual Member States.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Parliament’s resolution on general guidelines for the budget is the starting point of the annual budgetary procedure for Parliament. Parliament presents its budgetary priorities for 2017 ahead of the Spring Budgetary Trilogue and the adoption of the Draft Budget by the Commission. The report highlights Parliament’s political priorities for next year’s budget. It emphasis the following most important elements for the 2017 budget: boosting investments for growth, competitiveness and job creation as well as addressing the challenges of the ongoing migration and refugee crisis. The report stresses that the European Union budget has proven to be an essential resource in tackling recent crises and responding to needs that had not been anticipated during negotiations on the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2014-2020, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the migration and refugee crisis or geopolitical tensions in countries in Europe’s neighbourhood.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The general budget of the European Union is a key instrument for addressing recent crises and addressing the needs that had not been foreseen during the multiannual financial framework negotiations. I share the view that the EU budget, as an investment budget, brings added value by stimulating growth, competitiveness and job creation and should not be taken as a burden by Member States which regard their contribution as an adjustment variable subject to macroeconomic conditions. As in the past, I reiterate the need to reform the EU's own resources system, as it is impossible to demand more Europe and Union intervention when the budget cake accounts for less than 1 % of European GDP. The 2017 budget will be affected by migration and internal and external security challenges, and particular attention should be paid to these emerging phenomena, but should not neglect concerns about unemployment, socio-economic disparities, support for SMEs and the revitalisation of the internal market.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's political priorities for next year's budget have been highlighted in this report. The most important elements that led to my vote in favour are: the need to boost investment in growth, competitiveness, employment and, of course, the ongoing migrant and refugee crisis. The Eu ropean Union budget has proved to be an essential resource in addressing recent crises through, for example, the use of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI).

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Geier's 2017 BUDGET guidelines should be able to respond to the most urgent needs of Member States, while continuing to play a key role in the development and achievement of EU objectives. In Genier's proposal, however, there is no mention of the support that the EU budget and guidelines could bring to the crisis in the world of work, to immigration, to the issue of backpay. Although EU policies should provide the necessary resources to address the major problems facing the current European situation, no concrete solution is proposed in the 2017 budget guidelines. I believe that more attention should be paid to the sectors that create EU added value and to the terrible conditions in which small and medium-sized enterprises, workers, the unemployed and young people find themselves, through concrete commitments and actions that will effectively and efficiently change the current state of crisis. I believe that the guidelines presented by the rapporteur are neither sufficient nor adequate, and I certainly welcome the fact that immigration has been included as a subject at the heart of the European budget, but otherwise I do not see any concreteness in the report. That is why I am voting against.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This 2017 budget guidelines consolidate, on the income side, an uns ambitious resource policy that limits the ability to develop ambitious policies at the core levels of the European budget, such as agriculture and cohesion. On the contrary, the neoliberal management of expenditure is deepened, with its linkage to the European Semester and its market orientation being particularly serious. In addition, they support an aggressive and anti-human rights foreign policy, as is the case with funds provided to Turkey to make it a prison for refugees wishing to seek asylum from Europe. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and the Member States face various internal and external crises, which can have an impact at budgetary level. Firstly, externally, the EU faces emerging security threats (terrorism, extremism), as well as a migrant and refugee crisis. These external crises have a strong impact on internal crises. But the EU must remain an area of freedom, security and justice and strengthen cross-border operational cooperation in order to ensure conditions that are committed to human rights. At the internal level, the European Union and the Member States must continue to promote the social values underlying the Union through proximity to the population. To this end, the general guidelines of the budget must take into account: reducing unemployment – especially among young people, combating poverty, socio-economic inequality, exploitation and social exclusion. They can be improved by promoting the convergence, integration and cohesion policies presented under the Europe 2020 strategy.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget makes it clear that the budget is an important tool for keeping the EU together. It is essential that each member receives the common hat at his or her own abilities, in accordance with a fair distribution.  The report states that the EU budget has proved to be a key resource for dealing with recent crises. The report addresses the issues that take into account economic forecasts, it addresses the importance of budgeting in line with the European Semester of economic policy coordination and details the challenges of overcoming the crisis, including the need to eliminate social inequalities, improve youth employment, the refugee situation, the loss of GDP from tax avoidance, the role of EU programmes to promote innovation, but also mentions the importance of school milk programmes and school fruit schemes and recommends examining the increase in their funding.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Section 3 of the EU budget consists of the Commission's administrative activities and expenditure, which account for around 95% of the budget. The report sets Parliament's political priorities for 2017, in the form of guidelines, before the Commission publishes its working budget in May. The report focuses on the capacity of the EU budget to deal with the crises facing the EU. As the emphasis has been placed on supporting jobs, growth and competitiveness and on using the budget in areas where real added value is for the EU, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ With the European Union facing an economic crisis, the budget for 2017 needs to speed up the slow economic recovery through increased investment. Further investment needs to be allocated for long-term problems such as youth unemployment and moreover we need to continue investing in order to induce economic development. The migration and refugee crisis in the European Union needs further attention. We need to ensure solidarity among Member States in order to ensure further investment to complement the collective efforts being implemented in this regard. I voted in favour of these guidelines, as we need to prepare and organise all the means available in addressing the above-mentioned issues.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. In this report, the European Parliament outlines its political priorities for the allocation of the 2017 budget. Accelerating investment to stimulate growth and jobs and resolving the migration crisis are the key objectives we have championed. It should be noted that the 2014-2020 multi-year fiscal framework, i.e. the budget for the specified period, provides resources to address this type of crisis and unanticipated needs. We therefore call for the mobilization of these financial instruments to guide the European Union's action on the resolution of these unprecedented crises.  Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour of it.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I supported this report because it is important, at a time when we are in the midst of a security and migration crisis, to re-examine the multi-year financial framework and to clearly identify the budgetary priorities for 2017 in order to better manage the internal and external crises facing the European Union.  The EU budget is an essential resource for managing recent crises and helps to meet the needs that were not foreseen during the negotiations on the multi-year financial framework.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text is a summary of proposals from the Europeanist ideology: increased payment appropriations, injunctions for Member States to reduce the size of their budgets in favour of increasing their contributions to that of the EU, an expansionary concept of the EU budget.  More recently, there is a clear desire to increase funding for migrants. In other words, the report proposes more and more spending and tax revenue, including a European tax, to finance ever more immigration. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget because I believe it does not reflect the requirements of the European taxpayer. I believe that the guidelines for the preparation of the budget should be related to the reduction of unnecessary costs and tightening of financial controls. The report focuses more on the capacity of the European budget to deal with the crises overhanging the Union, including the migrant and refugee wave, high unemployment and sluggish economic growth. I do not believe that the report pays sufficient attention to areas of true EU added value. I do not believe that it is necessary to increase the overall budget, its use should be better focused and oriented towards achieving the right objectives.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against, because in the midst of the worst economic crisis in recent decades the Union insists on providing funds for the economic and social support of illegal immigrants, rather than supporting European citizens.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Most of the Amendments tabled by the Hungarian People's Party to this report have been included in the report adopted by the European Parliament. As a result, Parliament calls on the European Commission to take account of the accelerated payment needs for cohesion investments at the planning stage and to raise funds to the necessary level. It is important that the Commission already anticipates in its draft budget the accelerated implementation of regional development programmes in the Member States and, in proportion, to increase cohesion resources. In 2017, our aim is for the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated by the projects already carried out in the Member States. The European Parliament takes the view that the 2017 budget should also ensure that funds mobilised to deal with the migration crisis are not taken at the expense of other EU programmes already in place. This proposal protects cohesion and agricultural funds when determining resources to deal with the migration crisis. The European Parliament's resolution underlines the importance of school milk and fruit schemes. On our proposal, the European Commission should examine how EU funds to finance these programmes can be raised in the 2017 budget. We have flatly rejected the socialist initiative, which hypocritically, on the grounds of 'solidarity', wants to penalise Member States that reject plans for compulsory resettlement of migrants by means of EU budgetary instruments. We know that the Socialists aim to deprive these Member States of cohesion funds!

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 The report sets out general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget. Overall, I agree with the guidelines in the report. There are a number of problematic wordings in the report; I think, for example, that school milk and school fruit should be handled at national level; I believe that globalisation funds should be abolished; some wordings on the EU's own resources were too far-reaching. In future votes on specific budget lines, I will vote against these points. Since this report did not have the opportunity to vote on the individual wordings and because the report contains important political signals, for example that the budget must take into account the global climate agreement concluded in Paris last year and the importance of full funding for eu research programmes, I nevertheless chose to vote in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Vote against: an injunction for Member States to reduce the size of their budget in favour of increasing their contributions to that of the EU.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report contains the European Parliament's position on the guidelines to chair the preparation of the EU budget for 2017. Unsurprisingly, it is a report that does not advocate profound differences in relation to what have been the budgetary priorities of previous years. By imposing these profound changes, we can only vote against them. As usual, we have actively intervened in the debate on budgetary priorities, proposing several amendments to the report. Examples include: the defence of substantial budget reinforcement, in particular the components dedicated to economic and social cohesion, by creating an investment plan mobilising at least 2% of EU GDP annually over the next ten years; the defence of cuts in military spending and associated with EU external interventionism; the defence of measures to combat poverty, inequalities and social exclusion, as well as unemployment; the creation of specific support programmes for countries such as Portugal, which are intervened by the troika and facing greater difficulties; the establishment of support programmes for countries opting for a negotiated exit from the Euro which, among other things, provides for adequate compensation for the damage caused by entry and stay in the single currency. These are changes that point an alternative path to the current course of disaster. Unfortunately they were rejected.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: Written. \u2012 We cannot support the European Parliament's call for higher spending for 2017. Instead, we want to prioritise EU spending to focus on things that strengthen Europe's competitiveness and create the conditions for growth and jobs. The EU should give priority to the infrastructure, research and long-term capacity of the internal market to develop an effective foreign policy and jointly strengthen control over our borders. We therefore welcome priorities in the field of migration and research and development. However, we want to reduce agricultural subsidies, industrial subsidies and those parts of regional policy that make well-functioning economies dependent on subsidies. We cannot support the demands to loosen the EU's budgetary rules, to increase the flexibility of the Stability Pact, to the requirements for a larger long-term budget or to give the EU the right to tax. It is not a larger EU budget that strengthens Europe's competitiveness and the conditions for growth and jobs. It requires structural reforms, balanced public finances, deregulation and cutting red tape.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ It is an unquestionable fact that the European Union budget will have to respond more flexibly in future years to the challenges of a huge and sudden increase in the number of refugees and migrants arriving in Europe over time. In the area of youth employment, we must continue to finance the Youth Employment Programme and gradually place these people on the labour market, because the European Union has to cope with socio-economic disparate people and thus gradually achieve the objectives of socio-economic convergence. The European Union budget should therefore support convergence, integration and cohesion policies based on the protection and promotion of entrepreneurship, the creation of decent, quality and stable jobs, the sustainable use of natural resources and the protection of the environment through the achievement of the Europe 2020 targets for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. Last but not least, it is very important that the European Commission does not forget gender equality when drawing up its budget and implements the principle of gender mainstreaming.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because, once again, the real needs of the EU budget are not highlighted.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017-Section III budget, because in the midst of the worst economic crisis in recent decades the Union insists on providing funds for the economic and social support of illegal immigrants instead of supporting European citizens.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against these guidelines as they demand an increase in the size of the EU budget. I believe that the funds already allocated in the 2014-2020 period are sufficient.  Should additional financial support for new priorities be needed, then the EU should reallocate funds from existing programmes.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which sets the guidelines and the main political priorities for the European Parliament for the 2017 EU budget, and provides a comprehensive overview of the current budgetary situation. I welcome the fact that flexibility regarding contributions to the EU budget from the Member States under the Stability and Growth Pact (SGP) has been included. However, I regret the fact that the idea of solidarity as an underlying principle of the EU budget, an idea that should also be respected in dealing with the refugee crisis, has not been included. Finally, I believe we must be ready to mobilise all means available to address the current social and economic crises.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Most of the Amendments tabled by the Hungarian People's Party to this report have been included in the report adopted by the European Parliament. As a result, Parliament calls on the European Commission to take account of the accelerated payment needs for cohesion investments at the planning stage and to raise funds to the necessary level. It is important that the Commission already anticipates in its draft budget the accelerated implementation of regional development programmes in the Member States and, in proportion, to increase cohesion resources. In 2017, our aim is for the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated by the projects already carried out in the Member States. The European Parliament takes the view that the 2017 budget should also ensure that funds mobilised to deal with the migration crisis are not taken at the expense of other EU programmes already in place. This proposal protects cohesion and agricultural funds when determining resources to deal with the migration crisis. The European Parliament's resolution underlines the importance of school milk and fruit schemes. On our proposal, the European Commission should examine how EU funds to finance these programmes can be raised in the 2017 budget. We have flatly rejected the socialist initiative, which hypocritically, on the grounds of 'solidarity', wants to penalise Member States that reject plans for compulsory resettlement of migrants by means of EU budgetary instruments.
