We know that the Socialists aim to deprive these Member States of cohesion funds!

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Most of the Amendments tabled by the Hungarian People's Party to this report have been included in the report adopted by the European Parliament. As a result, Parliament calls on the European Commission to take account of the accelerated payment needs for cohesion investments at the planning stage and to raise funds to the necessary level. It is important that the Commission already anticipates in its draft budget the accelerated implementation of regional development programmes in the Member States and, in proportion, to increase cohesion resources. In 2017, our aim is for the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated by the projects already carried out in the Member States. The European Parliament takes the view that the 2017 budget should also ensure that funds mobilised to deal with the migration crisis are not taken at the expense of other EU programmes already in place. This proposal protects cohesion and agricultural funds when determining resources to deal with the migration crisis. The European Parliament's resolution underlines the importance of school milk and fruit schemes. On our proposal, the European Commission should examine how EU funds to finance these programmes can be raised in the 2017 budget. We have flatly rejected the socialist initiative, which hypocritically, on the grounds of 'solidarity', wants to penalise Member States that reject plans for compulsory resettlement of migrants by means of EU budgetary instruments. We know that the Socialists aim to deprive these Member States of cohesion funds!

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted positively on the report on the guidelines for the 2017 EU budget. The EU needs to be equipped with the necessary budgetary mechanisms to open the way for economic growth and job creation. We must use EU resources as effectively and efficiently as possible, bearing in mind that they are limited. Similarly, we must stress to the Member States that the EU budget can never be considered a burden, as it contributes decisively to the economic and social progress of all Europeans.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for the 2017 Union budget because we need a strong budget for 2017 to give us the tools to respond to the many challenges we face. First, this means that we need to provide ourselves with the resources to effectively deal with the migrant and refugee crisis.  We need to make sure that we have sufficient resources and flexibility to react to a situation that, like today's, changes rapidly, while ensuring that the budget allows us to show solidarity with countries facing the brunt of the crisis. Moreover, the solution of the refugee crisis must go hand in hand with boosting European growth and competitiveness. The EU needs greater investment in areas such as education or infrastructure in order to compete in the 21st century. Too many young Europeans are still struggling to get a job and we need more action at EU level to meet this challenge. That is why we are asking for more funding for the Youth Employment Initiative to ensure that no young people in the EU are left behind.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for the 2017 Union budget because we need a strong budget for 2017 to give us the tools to respond to the many challenges we face. First, this means that we need to provide ourselves with the resources to effectively deal with the migrant and refugee crisis.  We need to make sure that we have sufficient resources and flexibility to react to a situation that, like today's, changes rapidly, while ensuring that the budget allows us to show solidarity with countries facing the brunt of the crisis. Moreover, the solution of the refugee crisis must go hand in hand with boosting European growth and competitiveness. The EU needs greater investment in areas such as education or infrastructure in order to compete in the 21st century. Too many young Europeans are still struggling to get a job and we need more action at EU level to meet this challenge. That is why we are asking for more funding for the Youth Employment Initiative to ensure that no young people in the EU are left behind.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the general guidelines for the 2017 EU budget because, without prejudice to the appropriations in terms of payment and commitments, already set out in the multiannual financial framework, they clarify the EP's objectives for 2017. With this important parliamentary passage, the budgetary procedure for 2017 has come to life. However, there is an urgent need to reconsider the multiannual financial framework as part of a broader reform of financial resources. Indeed, it is clear that in order to tackle the migration emergency and the need to accelerate the slow recovery and finally emerge from the long crisis, through strategic actions in favour of long-term unemployment and to address growing social inequalities and disparities in economic and therefore territorial development within the EU and between regions, more financial resources are needed. The Union budget cannot be regarded as an adjustment variable subject to macroeconomic constraints but rather as a means of promoting a faster recovery, stimulating investment in strategic sectors capable of creating quality development and employment and ensuring better coordination between public and private investment. The EP strongly supports greater coordination of economic policies within the European Semester, taking account of economic forecasts.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. The budget is an important part of the EU's policy on determining and monitoring the use of financial resources. I support this decision in order to provide funds for dealing with the refugee crisis and strategic economic policy investments for 2017.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted against calls to increase the EU budget. The multiannual financial framework (MFF) for the EU budget is adequate, if properly directed, to deal with the main challenges Europe is facing. When looking at reform of the MFF, the priority should be looking at redistribution of the available budget between different areas. More needs to be done within current budget ceilings, and spending must be prioritised and redirected towards boosting sustainable growth and employment, and dealing with the refugee crisis. There are many examples of money well spent in the EU budget – the European Research Council, for example, helps us to maintain our position as a world leader in science in research. The European Fund for Strategic Investments also holds great promise and is being used in the UK to boost investment in key energy infrastructure.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We refrain from supporting Jens Geier's report, because we want to give dialogue a chance, inviting us to look into the eyes of the stark reality. We welcome the recommendations it makes in the broad terms of the 2017 budgets, as regards the inclusion of a gender perspective, or greater flexibility of these budgets in the face of economic or refugee crises, and their recommendations on the environment. But we must make a criticism of the budget as a whole; its cut remains neoliberal, the current model is a failure and a thorough review of the EU scheme and budget model is urgently needed. The budget is insufficient, with a poorly distributed income system, which should be based on Member States' Per Capita Income. Investment spending is clearly insufficient, and Geier's guidance, while calling for more flexibility, delves into the insolidary tonic of budgets. We don't think it's enough to overcome the stringing to which the MFF forces. A comprehensive, more social and fairer review of these budgets is therefore needed to be able to meet the challenges that are to come.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The 2017 budget will face many challenges: the persistence of the economic and social crisis is compounded by the outbreak of new needs (refugee crisis, the fight against terrorism) which are further weakening the European Union today. However, its budgetary capacity remains limited and is under increasing pressure. In voting for this report, I wanted above all to stress that the EU budget cannot be considered an 'adjustment variable': its consolidation is essential to stimulate investment and enable a faster economic recovery within the European Union. In addition, the EU budget must be able to overcome crises: while it has provided immediate responses to the current crises (refugee reception, agricultural crisis), the EU budget in its current format and proportions does not have the financial means to address it in a sustainable way. Finally, with the S and D, I have defended solidarity in Europe applied in all its dimensions, which seems to be forgotten by the countries of the Viegrad Group, the main beneficiaries of the Structural Funds but which are the most quick to close their borders and refuse to implement Community decisions to help refugees.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The Union budget has proven to be a crucial resource in tackling recent crises and responding to needs that had not been anticipated during the negotiation of the multiannual financial framework for 2014-2020, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the migration and refugee crisis or geopolitical tensions in Europe’s neighbourhood.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for the 2017 Union budget because we need a strong budget for 2017 to give us the tools to respond to the many challenges we face. First, this means that we need to provide ourselves with the resources to effectively deal with the migrant and refugee crisis.  We need to make sure that we have sufficient resources and flexibility to react to a situation that, like today's, changes rapidly, while ensuring that the budget allows us to show solidarity with countries facing the brunt of the crisis. Moreover, the solution of the refugee crisis must go hand in hand with boosting European growth and competitiveness. The EU needs greater investment in areas such as education or infrastructure in order to compete in the 21st century. Too many young Europeans are still struggling to get a job and we need more action at EU level to meet this challenge. That is why we are asking for more funding for the Youth Employment Initiative to ensure that no young people in the EU are left behind.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Most of the Amendments tabled by the Hungarian People's Party to this report have been included in the report adopted by the European Parliament. As a result, Parliament calls on the European Commission to take account of the accelerated payment needs for cohesion investments at the planning stage and to raise funds to the necessary level. It is important that the Commission already anticipates in its draft budget the accelerated implementation of regional development programmes in the Member States and, in proportion, to increase cohesion resources. In 2017, our aim is for the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated by the projects already carried out in the Member States. The European Parliament takes the view that the 2017 budget should also ensure that funds mobilised to deal with the migration crisis are not taken at the expense of other EU programmes already in place. This proposal protects cohesion and agricultural funds when determining resources to deal with the migration crisis. The European Parliament's resolution underlines the importance of school milk and fruit schemes. On our proposal, the European Commission should examine how EU funds to finance these programmes can be raised in the 2017 budget. We have flatly rejected the socialist initiative, which hypocritically, on the grounds of 'solidarity', wants to penalise Member States that reject plans for compulsory resettlement of migrants by means of EU budgetary instruments.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Our position on the budget is stable, as long as it remains in the same philosophy. We are voting against him because he expresses the Union's neoliberal economic policies of harsh austerity. His political orientations are again this year within the framework of the austerity policies of the MFF 2014-2020 and are determined by the neoliberal and conservative dominant circles of the Union.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget. This report is the first step of the annual budgetary procedure in the European Parliament. We are sending a political message to the Commission. One of the things we ask for is a medium- and long-term political and financial plan to deal with the migration crisis. Also we believe that the response to the migrant crisis should not come at the expense of the EU programmes. Such EU programmes strengthen the EU economy, enable growth and create jobs. In this context boosting investment is a key priority. I voted against Amendment 24 as it called for an increase in the payments made by Member States with the highest per capita income. Ireland would be one of those countries so I voted against the amendment. We are simply not in a position to pay. I also voted against Amendment 32 which calls for ‘a more harmonised and progressive tax regime’ at EU level.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe this report provides a good basis for the priorities for the 2017 budget, which should focus on economic growth, job creation and solidarity. The 2017 budget should take into account both the fact that many Member States are still recovering from the financial crisis, while at the same time recognising that global threats still present a significant danger to the EU economy.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. The 2017 budget preparation report argues that the existing budget is insufficient to deal with existing crises. The solution to the problem is to increase the ceilings of the multiannual financial framework. It also criticises Member States' efforts to consolidate their budgets and the prospect of a new 'EU tax' rather than a thorough reform of the EU budget. An increase in the EU's overall budget is completely unnecessary from an ALFA point of view, and additional financial support should be found through a review of long-held priorities and a reallocation of existing funds. ALFA is committed to concentrating spending on future challenges rather than an annual update of the status quo. We stand for identifying savings and for the general aim of encouraging the start of a project. This prevents permanent financing and take-away effects. This is the only way to create an efficient and sustainable budget. That is why I voted against the above-mentioned report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report is about the main priorities for the European Parliament for the EU budget 2017, and gives an overview of the current budgetary situation. This includes among others: refugee and migration crisis, EFSI, economic growth, Youth Employment Initiative, child guarantee (poverty), climate change, payment crisis, Refugee Facility for Turkey. The European Parliament is ready to mobilise all means available to address the existing crisis in Europe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget, Part III - The Commission, because I believe that the budget for the coming year should be flexible, and in line with Union policies in order to overcome the financial and migrant crisis, i.e. reduce their negative consequences. Geopolitical tension at the EU's external borders, but also internal ones, is certainly a major challenge for which the Union and its Member States must be prepared. However, it is also necessary that the 2017 budget enables investment, both public and private, to strengthen the economy, and to be clearly geared towards young people in the form of job creation and improving the competitiveness of European SMEs.  Moreover, I believe that the budgetary plan should take into account economic forecasts and be in line with the European Semester for economic policy coordination in order to create a strong and efficient budget, and therefore I support this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report repeats the refrain of all Europeanists for years: increased payment appropriations, injunctions for Member States to reduce the size of their budget in favour of increasing their contributions to that of the EU, expansionary notion of the EU budget, etc. However, the novelty lies in the desire to increase funding for migrants. In other words, more and more spending and tax revenue (European taxes, etc.) to finance more and more immigration. I voted against it.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the overall direction of Parliament’s guidelines for preparation of the 2017 budget. However, I do have concerns with the call to the Commission to use the budget to encourage more solidarity between Member States in relation to the refugee crisis. I believe that no link should be drawn between unrelated policy areas in an effort to ‘blackmail’ Member states into agreeing to something against their will. Nevertheless, I support the calls for boosting investment in Europe and for the budget to take into account economic forecasts. If used in the correct way, the European Union budget can stimulate growth and investment in Europe while helping Member States develop their infrastructure and transport connections.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Jens Geier's report on the guidelines for the 2017 budget - Section III, in which Parliament affirms its political priorities for the 2017 budget. These include the priority areas that I am advocating with my political group, the EPP, namely stimulating investment for growth, focusing on competitiveness and job creation. Particular attention is being paid this year to the management of the refugee crisis. Parliament therefore calls for adequate resources and more flexibility in the multi-year financial framework. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. This resolution sets out Parliament's political priorities for the coming budget year. I voted in favour of this text because it provides a good basis for the priorities of 2017, namely to stimulate investment for growth, to focus on competitiveness and job creation and, finally, to meet the challenge posed by the refugee crisis. This will require adequate means and more flexibility in the multi-year financial framework.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report clearly seeks to reduce the constraints on the Union's budget. He sees the EU budget as a major factor in overcoming the current crises. From this point of view, the multiannual financial framework should be watered down and payment ceilings as set per year should be abolished in order to increase budgetary flexibility. Although there is a flexibility instrument, the appropriations for payments for the special instruments are to be calculated beyond the ceilings of the MFF. The primary objective must be to close the gap between poor and rich EU countries, which in turn could incentivise structural reforms and be urgently needed. In my view, this has been missed in this report, which is why I am voting against the report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against calls by many other MEPs to increase the EU budget. Labour MEPs have argued and continue to argue that more needs to be done within current budget ceilings, and that spending must be prioritised and redirected towards boosting sustainable growth and employment, and dealing with the refugee crisis.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Writing. The 2017 budget preparation report argues that the existing budget is insufficient to deal with existing crises. The solution to the problem is to increase the ceilings of the multiannual financial framework. It also criticises Member States' efforts to consolidate their budgets and the prospect of a new 'EU tax' rather than a thorough reform of the EU budget. An increase in the EU's overall budget is completely unnecessary from an ALFA point of view, and additional financial support should be found through a review of long-held priorities and a reallocation of existing funds. ALFA is committed to concentrating spending on future challenges rather than an annual update of the status quo. We stand for identifying savings and for the general aim of encouraging the start of a project. This prevents permanent financing and take-away effects. This is the only way to create an efficient and sustainable budget. That is why I voted against the above-mentioned report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 European Parliament resolution of 9 March 2016 on guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget, Section III – Unfortunately, I could not in good conscience support the Commission and I decided to abstain. The text of the resolution did not contain much downright evil truth, but I find the part of the text 'The European Parliament welcomes the principle and objectives of the refugee instrument for Turkey, in which EUR 3 billion is to be invested, and urges each Member State to keep its political promises and provide adequate financial support as part of the aid package for the Refugee Facility for Turkey'. I believe that the European Parliament, as the only directly elected EU institution, should not have to be limited to parroting the German Chancellor. I find it absolutely absurd to have a debate about sending EUR 3 billion to Turkey and not discussing how it will be used in real life. I have long warned against overly accommodating policy towards Ankara. It is clear that Turkey must be part of the migration issue. But it is impossible for a NATO state to let Islamic State fighters cross its borders, buy extra oil from it, and shoot down the plane of a country fighting ISIS at a spare moment's time. Moreover, it is not possible for us to send them billions of euros, introduce visa-free travel, etc. without taking advantage of them.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Most of the Amendments tabled by the Hungarian People's Party to this report have been included in the report adopted by the European Parliament. As a result, Parliament calls on the European Commission to take account of the accelerated payment needs for cohesion investments at the planning stage and to raise funds to the necessary level. It is important that the Commission already anticipates in its draft budget the accelerated implementation of regional development programmes in the Member States and, in proportion, to increase cohesion resources. In 2017, our aim is for the European Commission to fully pay the bills generated by the projects already carried out in the Member States. The European Parliament takes the view that the 2017 budget should also ensure that funds mobilised to deal with the migration crisis are not taken at the expense of other EU programmes already in place. This proposal protects cohesion and agricultural funds when determining resources to deal with the migration crisis. The European Parliament's resolution underlines the importance of school milk and fruit schemes. On our proposal, the European Commission should examine how EU funds to finance these programmes can be raised in the 2017 budget. We have flatly rejected the socialist initiative, which hypocritically, on the grounds of 'solidarity', wants to penalise Member States that reject plans for compulsory resettlement of migrants by means of EU budgetary instruments. We know that the Socialists aim to deprive these Member States of cohesion funds!

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This is the annual report of the European Parliament, concerning the budget of the year to come. The budget of 2017 reflects some objectives to attend to. It is still a preliminary stage of the budget procedure. I voted abstention to this report, since I think we need more progressive and solidarity instruments in the EU budget, more transparency and shared decision-making on the EU budget.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. The Union's budget is of fundamental importance because, to a very large part, an investment budget. As we all know, economic recovery is slow and we absolutely must strengthen the instruments that can promote growth and encourage the creation of new jobs. Agriculture, structural funds, growth and management of migration flows are among the main priorities for 2017. With the report adopted today, we have highlighted Parliament's wishes for the procedure that is about to begin and we call on the Commission to take due account of this in the drafting of the draft budget, by ensuring the necessary appropriations for important programmes such as Horizon 2020, Cosme, Life, the programmes for the financing of SMEs and Erasmus+, as well as for policies related to migration.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the 2017 budget guidance report. This report makes some rather original recommendations. According to the rapporteur, national budgets must reduce their size in favour of an increasingly expansionary European Union budget which should finance investment. In short: the wrong role for the states, the good role for the EU.  In passing, there is a thinly veiled admission of failure of the Juncker plan, unable to fill the investment gap in the EU. To deal with this, the report requires more own resources for the EU and therefore the introduction of a European tax...  This report repeats the refrain that all Europeanists have been saying for years: an increase in payment credits, an injunction for Member States to reduce the size of their budget in favour of increasing their contributions to that of the EU, an expansionary concept of the EU budget. However, the novelty lies in the desire to increase funding for migrants. In other words, more and more spending and tax revenue to finance more and more immigration.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it calls on Member States to reduce their budgets, in the name of a policy of austerity which we see as a failure. It also asks them to increase their contribution to the EU budget to finance ever more immigration!

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to determine the general guidelines for the 2017 EU budget. Four main lines stand out from the text.  First, the demand to increase the ceilings of the multi-year financial framework (MFF 2014-2020), which does not withstand the surplus of funding caused by migratory pressure, and the granting, in this context, of 6 billion euros to Turkey.  The second request is to increase Member States' contributions to the EU budget, which forces them to reduce the size of their national budgets. The third injunction again joins the migrant crisis and proposes an increase in European aid in this area, which will create a huge call for air and densify the influx of refugees. Finally, the suggestions are to increase the pressure on arrears of payments and the remnants to be liquidated, which encourages the European Union to want its own resources, including the possibility of creating a European tax. This text therefore does nothing to solve Europe's catastrophic economic situation and even aggravates it by advocating the support of mass immigration, so I voted AGAINST IT.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Written. 'This report calls for a number of measures that the N-VA does not support. That is why the N-VA delegation has decided to vote against this dossier. In 2016, the funds for asylum and migration (under the chapter 'Security and citizenship') almost doubled compared to 2015. The N-VA supports the increase in the budget for this chapter, because two EU agencies, Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office, suddenly received a lot of extra powers last year.  It is important that the Commission first looks for resources in the EU portfolio for 2017, which are not or not used efficiently. These resources must then be used to deal with the refugee crisis. One area where EU funds need to be better used, including to improve local reception of refugees, is development aid. These issues are not sufficiently addressed in the report.  Moreover, in his report, the rapporteur also calls for a thorough reform of the own resources system, something which the N-VA does not agree with.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for the 2017 Union budget because we need a strong budget for 2017 to give us the tools to respond to the many challenges we face. First, this means that we need to provide ourselves with the resources to effectively deal with the migrant and refugee crisis.  We need to make sure that we have sufficient resources and flexibility to react to a situation that, like today's, changes rapidly, while ensuring that the budget allows us to show solidarity with countries facing the brunt of the crisis. Moreover, the solution of the refugee crisis must go hand in hand with boosting European growth and competitiveness. The EU needs greater investment in areas such as education or infrastructure in order to compete in the 21st century. Too many young Europeans are still struggling to get a job and we need more action at EU level to meet this challenge. That is why we are asking for more funding for the Youth Employment Initiative to ensure that no young people in the EU are left behind.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the criticism of tax competition between Member States. On the contrary, I believe that Member States should have the right to apply different rates of company income tax. I do not agree with the increase in the EU budget in order to better deal with crises. On the contrary, money should remain as much as possible in the hands of citizens and Member States that are able to face crises like the refugee one more effectively.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament's resolution on the general budgetary guidelines is the starting point of the annual budgetary procedure for Parliament. The report highlights Parliament's political and economic priorities for next year, which are to stimulate investment to achieve growth, competitiveness, job creation, but also address current challenges such as the refugee crisis. The report highlights how the budget has proven to be an essential element in addressing the economic crisis and has been able to address needs that were not outlined during the negotiations on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2014-2020. I supported the 2017 budget guidance report - Part III, as I consider it essential that the guidelines cover Parliament's priorities.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 More and more companies are tax avoiding. This has caused huge losses in member states' tax revenues and thus a reduction in their contributions to the EU budget. The European Union must therefore urgently address the problems associated with unfair tax competition, which in some cases means transferring GDP from one Member State to another and transferring GNI to tax havens outside the EU. It is therefore necessary for the President of the Commission to fulfil what he has committed to under pressure from the Socialists and Democrats: that profits will be taxed in the country where they arise. The system solution for the revenue part of the budget is the reform of own resources. The aim is to achieve a more autonomous, stable, simpler, fairer, more sustainable and predictable side of eu budget revenue, while alleviating the burden of excessive expenditure from national budgets and improving transparency and visibility for citizens, without increasing the overall tax burden on citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget, Section III – Commission, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/3/2016 and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this text. Without much originality, this socialist report calls for an increase in the ceilings of special instruments, it increases Member States' contributions to the EU budget, it increases aid to migrants and it increases the pressure on arrears of payments and the leftovers to be liquidated. In short, we have here a summary of the European ideas of recent years, which increasingly pressurizes the Member States for the benefit of the EU. And there is, clearly expressed, the will to finance the reception of ever more immigration, even though Europe can no longer cope.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal as my national delegation does not believe an increase in the EU budget can be justified in the present circumstances.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The document voted on today contains useful guidelines for the drafting of the 2017 budget. The inclusion of funds to improve the problem of youth unemployment is particularly crucial at the moment. I am pleased that the mention of size has been included. Gender equality can be a huge advantage for the economy. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. The priorities of the EU budget for next year must remain the fight against the migration and refugee crisis, while we invest more and better to accelerate economic recovery. My support for this Parliament's report on budgetary priorities for 2017, which makes it clear that we must continue to make a clear commitment to strengthening the fight against youth unemployment, one of the great problems that Europe still has.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the general guidelines for the establishment of the 2017 budget. This resolution draws attention to the key factors, economic and geopolitical trends that may have a decisive impact on revenue and dissusement of the EU budget.  I support the provisions contained in the resolution aimed at ensuring that the revenues of the Union budget are more independent, stable, simpler, fairer, more sustainable and predictable, as well as reducing the burden of excessive expenditure on national budgets and increasing transparency for citizens without increasing their overall tax burden.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which is the first step in outlining Parliaments priorities to the Commission, such as tackling the migration and refugee crisis, Direct Provision centres and also long-term and youth unemployment for the 2017 EU budget.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. I can only look tenderly at the melodging that has been the face of the entire European caste for years. I note the famous verse of the injunction made to the Member States to strengthen the EU budget by reducing theirs. The list has been lengthened by the news, the flow of "migrants" implied as all political refugees by a tearful advertisement that is no longer to be done to the European institutions.  In the end, I see that the EU's logic is to increase spending in order to promote immigration. As a result, I have spoken out against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget. The Union budget is a key instrument for responding to recent crises and needs that have not been foreseen in previous instruments. With timid growth, the EU is growing below its growth potential. Better fundamentals and more options that invest and promote employment growth in a sustained and responsible way.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution.  Some of the most important elements of the 2017 budget include: increasing investments for growth, creating jobs and increasing competitiveness, as well as addressing the on-going challenges of the migration and refugee crisis.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. The 2017 budget will face a multitude of challenges as part of its internal and external policies. The aim is to help economic recovery and job creation in a particularly weak economic recovery, to assume the migrant and refugee crisis that will continue beyond 2016, to contain any terrorist threat and extremist acts, etc.  In the face of these problems, the multi-year framework must be flexible. We have entered a new era in terms of budget that requires more responsiveness. The EU has responded to the majority of crises by creating funds (managed by Member States). It is clear that if our States are increasingly called upon under these funds over which the institutions have less control, they will no longer be able to meet their commitments made under cohesion policies. Therefore, rather than having a multitude of instruments, can we not imagine that in the event of a crisis situation, the Union's budget can be increased. The aim is to safeguard the principle of the uniqueness of the budget and its legibility.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The EU budget has emerged as an effective tool in implementing European policies and overcoming both internal and external crises not included in the development of the Multiannual Financial Framework 20014-2020 (e.g. the establishment of a European Fund for Strategic Investments, the Migration Crisis or geopolitical security challenges in our neighbourhood). The guidelines play a key role in budgetary planning and represent a first step towards launching the whole process. 2017 will not be an easy year for Europe because of the expected continuation of crises, and it is therefore essential that the budget considers and effectively addresses the most pressing challenges. Promoting employment (especially young people and citizens living in the poorest parts of Europe), growth and competitiveness are among the most important priorities for the coming period. This is inevitably linked to the promotion of investment and innovation (through Horizon 2020, Erasmus+, etc.). Due attention should also be paid to the fight against tax evasion, which is being used annually by the EU for a large amount of money. Within the framework of economic and social cohesion policy, the Union should direct support primarily to the least developed regions in order to close disparities between Member States and achieve their convergence. Last but not least, sufficient resources must be allocated to the health care and education of children living in poverty , which are reliant on assistance for inclusion in society. I am voting in favour of the proposal tabled.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the Guidelines for the 2017 Budget – Section III because it is important to mobilise all means available in order to address crises, such as refugees and migration, the economic crisis, poverty, etc.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Budgets has tabled a motion for a parliamentary resolution on the preparation of the 2017 budget. The motion emphasises that the budget should lay the foundations for a trajectory towards economic growth and job creation, while economic recovery and investment levels in the EU remain below potential and the investment gap persists. It points out that the EU budget is currently able to deal with these crises primarily through the use of all instruments agreed in the TPM negotiations, and in particular through the use of specific instruments such as the Flexibility Instrument.  At the same time, it underlines that, in the event of further exacerbation of crises, the full use of the existing flexibility provisions will not be sufficient to solve the problem. Reiterates, in this context, the need to go beyond the ceilings set out in the TPK when calculating payment appropriations for specific instruments (flexibility instrument, European Union Solidarity Fund, European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and Emergency Aid Reserve), and recommends that Parliament express its expectation that this issue will be resolved in the context of the TPK's mid-term review. I supported the motion.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to make recommendations and general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget. The recommendations are: to increase the ceilings of special instruments to deal with unforeseen and unanticipated expenses, particularly those related to the migration crisis and Turkey; Increase Member States' contributions to EU budgets; Increase aid to migrants for their safety and integration; increase the EU's own resources and thus introduce a European tax. It goes without saying that we oppose this report.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The purpose of this text is to formulate recommendations and general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 EU budget. In particular, it envisages: increasing Member States' contributions to the EU budget; increase the possibilities for budgetary flexibility to finance aid to migrants pouring into Europe and the agreement with Turkey in exchange for its aid on the migration field; to create nothing more or less than a European tax to finance the EU's lifestyle and ambitions. Opposing the growing demands for an increase in the EU budget at the expense of The Member States and their citizens, as well as the injunction to help migrants even more, I voted against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted today against calls by many other MEPs to increase the EU budget. Labour MEPs believe the multi-annual financial framework (MFF) for the EU budget is adequate, if properly directed, to deal with the main challenges Europe is facing. Labour MEPs believe that when looking at reform of the MFF, the priority should be looking at redistribution of the available budget between different areas. Labour MEPs have argued and continue to argue that more needs to be done within current budget ceilings, and that spending must be prioritised and redirected towards boosting sustainable growth and employment, and dealing with the refugee crisis. There are many examples of money well spent in the EU budget – the European Research Council, for example, helps us to maintain our position as a world leader in science in research. The European Fund for Strategic Investments also holds great promise and is being used in the UK to boost investment in key energy infrastructure.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I abstained on the occasion of the vote on this report, which is the first step in the budgetary procedure during which the European Parliament informs the Commission of the guidelines it wants. I have objected to all the provisions in this report which will result in an increase in the reception budget for migrants or which call for an increase in funding for the resettlement of migrants within the European Union. For greater efficiency, EU appropriations must be directed more towards aid to countries such as Jordan or Lebanon, which allow migrants to stay close to their country, rather than towards budget increases to accommodate them in conditions that remain unworthy in the European Union.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for Parliament's direction for the 2017 budget year. Parliament makes investment in growth, competitiveness and job creation, as well as the refugee crisis, its three priorities for the coming year. The adoption of the report will allow Parliament to discuss its objectives with the other European institutions.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the 2017 budget will be impressed by the internal and external security challenges of the European Union. In particular, I would like to highlight the key role of the Internal Security Fund. I consider it a priority to address the challenges that continuous migration and the refugee crisis bring, as this is the source of a high percentage of crimes today. Furthermore, it is essential to increase investment, as this is the only way to achieve economic growth and development, the competitiveness of individual Member States and the reduction of unemployment!

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The current geopolitical situation that Europe faces will affect the 2017 budget through the evolving migration and refugee crisis and by the economical dependency on global developments of the EU. I have voted for this report that should lay down the road towards economic growth and job creation, in the current context of a fragile economic recovery that is jeopardised by the situation in emerging global markets and ongoing geopolitical tensions.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because setting the 2017 budget is a very important issue and must take into account the continued economic growth of the EU and the creation of jobs, in the context of a fragile economic recovery, jeopardised by the current geopolitical situation and tensions.  In this respect, as the report also proposes, I believe that budget preparation must take into account the incentive for public and private investment, but also the increase in the use of the Structural Funds in order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. These policies must be the main instruments for ensuring stable economic growth and strengthening cohesion within the EU, which is why I am pleased that the European Parliament has expressed its consensus on this issue.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of this report, I would like to point out that in the 2015 and 2016 budgets, the Commission has in many cases not requested additional payment appropriations for a number of its responses to the crisis (forwarding EUR 2 billion to Greece, the first migration initiative) and has instead resorted to reallocating existing resources. This has increased the pressure on payment appropriations in 2016 and in subsequent years, when there may potentially be a situation where the funds may not be sufficient to meet the real needs of financial programmes across headings, which will have a direct impact on projects and citizens. It is thus of concern that, in addition to the delayed start of the implementation of the 2014-2020 programmes, there is a risk of a repeat of the situation at the end of the last MFF in the form of unprecedented levels of outstanding commitments and an unsustainable backlog of payment claims. Consideration should therefore be given to whether unforeseen payment needs should be covered by new appropriations.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report as a whole as it underlines the importance of the Youth Employment Initiative and identifies it as the Union's priority objective for jobs and growth, as well as the commitment to further finance this programme in order to expand it.  The report found that, despite initial delays in the implementation of this initiative and the continued postponement of the designation of bodies of youth employment operational programmes in many Member States, the current implementation figures show full absorption capacity. The report also stresses the need for an in-depth reform of the Union's own resources system.  However, I believe that eu budget funds for the refugee crisis should not come at the expense of investment, nor should the budget be used to force Member States to respond to the refugee crisis. It would be a mistake to set up a mechanism in the EU budget to similarly influence countries.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The EU budget for 2017 sets the economic situation of the Member States as key priorities and the refugee crisis, and highlights the importance of revising the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020 in the context of unforeseen crises.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The 2017 budget comes at a crucial moment in the evolution of the migration crisis and refugees. We must therefore have the necessary budgetary means to be able to meet this challenge and seek the best solutions.  A review of the reflective and consequential Annual Financial Framework can help us with this. Through these guidelines we also request a thorough investigation into the case of the 10,000 missing children according to information from Europol.  Supporting these guidelines is not only an exercise of responsibility but an obligation; that is why I have supported this text.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 The situation of the European economy remains very difficult. It is therefore essential to continue to promote growth and decent employment, poverty eradication and investment. Next year's budget must be aligned with the coordination of European policies and based on economic forecasts. It is essential to ensure an adequate level of resources. In addition, access to markets and funding for SMEs needs to be improved through existing programmes. Further steps and the development of new financial instruments should be taken to increase investment. I do not support the envisaged facility for refugees in Turkey. It is not clear how it will be used by the Turkish authorities. The question is whether this is just the price of a bizarre exchange agreement with Turkey, after all, Turkey will not solve the problems that we must solve ourselves.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the budgetary targets set for 2017, it must first be borne in mind that the desired recovery is difficult to achieve. I believe that the revival of growth and employment through the possibility for Member States to use a more flexible policy and the use of part of the quotas as a response to the refugee crises and geopolitical tensions in the Near East are a priority for Parliament's political activity. I therefore say that I am voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The report highlights Parliament’s political priorities for next year’s budget that emphasises an important element, which I am fully supporting in my mandate as MEP – boosting investments for growth, competitiveness and job creation. I believe that strategic investment is crucial for maintaining the European economy as a key player in the world market. Investment and support, in particular to SMEs and individual entrepreneurs, is vital for the future of European market competitiveness and growth, and that is why I support the guidelines for the 2017 Budget.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ Agriculture represents a significant and strategically important branch of activity for every country in the world. If food production is compromised, especially in times of pronounced effects of climate changes that we witness almost daily, there is a great danger to the nutritional safety of citizens of the European Union. Russia's food embargo has deepened a crisis in the agriculture sector that has been ongoing for the past few years. Since the budget should be set up to stimulate the growth of the economy and jobs, I believe that investing in agriculture is precisely investing in our own future and preserving every job of a small local producer is a priority. In particular, I support the fact that the Union recognises the importance of milk and fruit schemes in schools, as this is an exceptional way to promote healthier eating habits, but also to connect consumers with local food producers. While the Russian embargo is driving down fruit and vegetable prices, this program is a major incentive for agricultural producers as well as consumers to adopt healthy habits. By bringing agricultural production around to school-age children, they connect with local producers and gain knowledge of the values of work and are encouraged to engage in local activities.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report repeats the refrain that all Europeanists have been saying for years: an increase in payment credits, injunctions for Member States to reduce the size of their budgets in favour of increasing their contributions to that of the EU, an expansionary notion of the EU budget, etc. However, the novelty lies in the desire to increase funding for migrants. In other words, more and more spending and tax revenue (European taxes, etc.) to finance more and more immigration. It is of course out of the question for me to support such a project and I am voting against this report.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 A very difficult debate on the Eu ropean Union budget is also expected this year, especially with very small figures in relation to the challenges facing the Union. While the Commission undoubtedly needs to work more effectively with a lighter administration, we must never forget that 94% of the Union's budget is devoted to investment in employment, the environment, migratory flows, businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and research. Our budget is the only real element of support for the real economy and, in particular, thanks in particular to EFSI in 2017, we will try to relaunch those strategic investments that have been missing from the European agenda for too long. Migration crises and neighbouring countries on both the Mediterranean shore and the eastern border will also have to be addressed. The challenges continue to be global and common, and I hope that with these first guidelines of what the 2017 budget will be, we will be able to give a clear and strong response to these challenges.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The 2017 budget lays the foundations for economic growth and job creation in the context of a fragile economic recovery that threatens the situation in emerging world markets and current geopolitical tensions. I welcome the guidance report and the European Parliament's set priorities with the EU budget for 2017: the stressed need to address the crisis, in particular migration and refugee; the importance and role of the European Fund for Strategic Investments; measures for economic growth; allocations under the YEI; guarantees for children; climate change and the implementation of the Facility for Refugees in Turkey. The guidelines make it clear that the European Parliament is ready to mobilise all resources at its disposal to properly address crises, both refugee and economic.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 The report advances the European Parliament's position on the guidelines to guide the preparation of the EU budget for 2017. Predictably, it does not advocate greater differences in relation to what have been the budgetary priorities of previous years. We believe that profound changes in the priorities set are necessary. Accordingly, we have actively intervened in the debate on budgetary priorities, making several amendments to the report of which are examples: the defence of substantial budget reinforcement, in particular the components dedicated to economic and social cohesion, with the creation of an investment plan mobilising at least 2 % of EU GDP annually over the next ten years; the defence of cuts in military spending and associated with EU external interventionism; the defence of measures to combat poverty, inequalities and social exclusion, as well as unemployment; the creation of specific support programmes for countries, such as Portugal, which are intervened by the Troika and facing greater difficulties; the establishment of support programmes for countries opting for a negotiated exit from the euro which, among other things, provides for appropriate compensation for the damage caused by entry and stay in the single currency. Regrettably rejected amendments, which frame the necessary break with current policies. We voted against it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I welcome this report and fully support it. Among the guidelines for next year's EU budget, I would particularly like to stress the need for the Union to provide more assertive support to the Eastern Partnership countries with which the Association Agreement was signed, which is primarily conditional on the sensitive geopolitical situation in this part of Europe. Such an approach is needed in order to successfully implement the reforms initiated in the Eastern Partnership countries and to deepen their relations with the Union. In addition, I particularly welcome the guidelines in the report, which pay attention to the external and internal challenges for European security that will affect the Union budget for 2017. These security challenges relate largely to the terrorist threats facing the Union. Past practice has shown that funding from the European budget to tackle the migrant crisis has not proved sufficient and I therefore support the call on the Commission to put forward a long-term policy and financial plan to tackle the migrant crisis.

name: Pavel POC
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to abstain on the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget - Section III. I did so because an amendment against the democratic principles on which the European Union itself is founded was agreed in the report. Although I deeply respect the principle of solidarity, I do not want to support any efforts to encourage the European Commission to start penalising or otherwise in motivating Member States to change their position on tackling the migration crisis to date. Moreover, this amendment does not comply with the regulation in force on the common provisions on the European Structural and Investment Funds No 1303/2013, as well as with the regulations relating directly to specific funds. Furthermore, I do not understand why my colleagues supported the proposal, which is incompatible with the wording of the report itself. This rightly points to the risk of undermining or undermining the implementation of other important European policies in the context of the migration crisis. Europe is currently marked by economic divergening. How, therefore, do my colleagues want to justify any cuts to resources for the poorest regions and the most vulnerable people? Do they really want to be responsible for deepening existing disparities, including the uneven distribution of both the population and non-European migrants? So far, European integration has been a positive project, bringing positives at all levels in the long term. I will therefore fight to ensure that this is not undermined by the efforts of populist politicians selling cheap slogans to their electorate.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to abstain on this report, although I agree with the bulk of the text and, in particular, the need to express solidarity and help the states most affected by the migration crisis. However, I cannot agree with the approved amendment to make the common budget a coercive instrument turning voluntary expression of solidarity into a compulsory contribution. It is not only a political question, but also a matter of fact and procedural. What should be the criteria for assessing how solidarity each Member State was. In this respect, I already raised a question about the European Commission four months ago (see questions to be answered), and the Commission's response confirmed that there are no instruments that could support such a move. Furthermore, I completely disagree that the appropriations from the common budget for financial programmes across the different headings should be arbitrarily drained by the Commission without Parliament's knowledge. Once again, I consider this to be completely unjustified pressure from the Commission on the Member States. It is completely unacceptable for a financial deficit to be created at European level due to the Commission's actions, threatening the absorption of funds from the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The priorities for the 2017 budget are the problems related to long-term youth unemployment, the disparities that characterise economic development in Europe and the refugee crisis. This report shows that the funds to meet all the commitments will not be sufficient. For example, the level of member states' contributions to the two trust funds dedicated to some of the existing crises (the Regional Trust Fund for Syria and the Emergency Trust Fund for Africa) is too low. Furthermore, as far as Turkey is concerned, it is not clear how the Eu ropean contribution will be made available within the ceilings of the Union budget for 2016 and 2017. Over and above the obvious difficulties, the EU budget remains a very important instrument and must be used to the full, especially in order to respond to the needs of security and economic growth. That is also why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the 2017 perspective, commitment expenditure was set at €137.1 billion and payments at €126.8 billion. The budgetary resources in place in the 2014-2020 MFF are insufficient for the Union to cope with the escalating immigration crisis, low economic growth and high levels of unemployment, especially among young people.  THE EU's commitments to Turkey (after the last EU-Turkey summit amounting to as much as €6 billion), the creation of trust funds for Syria, and Africa, which are partly to be funded by the EU budget, additional resources for Greece facing successive waves of migrants, a commitment to rebuild resources in Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe in view of their previous cuts to the European Fund for Strategic Investments , all of which require a revision of the 2014-2020 MFF spending upper spending thresholds.  On the other hand, I am opposed to the rapporteur's position in favour of introducing an EU tax, which would be the main revenue of the EU budget, instead of the existing contributions, which depend mainly on the GNI (gross national income) of individual Member States.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 While I agree with a number of proposals on the budget, I cannot support the proposal as a whole. The draft contains provisions calling for countries that, according to the petitioners, are not sufficiently in solidarity with refugees to be budgetaryly punished. This is a procedure that is completely unacceptable. Some countries have different views on how to deal with the refugee crisis, and the rest of the EU cannot punish them for doing so. Such proposals only break down the unity of the EU. That's why I reject them.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I am in favour of this report on the guidelines for the 2017 budget - Section III, because it sets out Parliament's political priorities for the coming budget year that I fully share: boosting investment through growth, focusing on competitiveness, promoting job creation and addressing the challenges posed by the refugee crisis. However, the EU budget should not be seen by the Member States as a mere adjustment variable. On the contrary, I argue that this budget can be an investment tool, especially in response to the current crises. Finally, this issue is also linked to the principle of subsidiarity and I call on European states to take responsibility.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the 2017 budget guidelines, which should have as its main objective economic growth and job creation in the context of a fragile economic recovery threatened by the situation of emerging world markets and current geopolitical tensions. I welcome this report as it states that the budget should be drawn up on the basis of economic forecasts and in line with the European Semester for economic policy coordination. Furthermore, I believe that the revision of the budget is necessary to effectively finance the implementation of EU policies to tackle the refugee crisis in order to create a European solution to overcome a situation considered to be emerging, but also the serious crisis affecting European agriculture, especially in the milk sector. To this end, I stress the importance of fully implementing the joint declarations on payments agreed between Parliament, the Council and the Commission in 2015 and 2016. Finally, I voted in favour of this report because I consider it necessary to reform the EU's own resources system, established under the Agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2014-2020, the mid-term review of which will coincide with the 2017 budget.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. Halfway through the current programme (2014-2020), this report is an important political message to the Commission before Parliament presents its draft EU budget in the spring. It takes stock of the past period and Parliament's recommendations on the Future Priorities of the Union.  From the balance sheet, the report highlights the role played by the EU budget as a central resource in responding to the various crises facing the EU. In addition, it introduces flexibility in the budget in the face of un anticipated situations initially during the negotiations of the 2014-2020 Multi-Year Financial Framework (MFF). With regard to the recommendations, the report identifies two key priorities for Parliament for 2017: overcoming the economic crisis by reviving public and private investment and supporting SMEs; response to the refugee crisis that will grow.  I agreed with these political lines, so I voted in favour of this text.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. We need a budget for 2017 that is sufficiently strong and progressive and provides us with the tools to respond adequately to the multiple challenges facing the Union. We need to ensure that we have the resources and the flexibility to react to complex situations that change constantly, while ensuring that the budget allows us to show solidarity with countries facing the burden of the crisis. The European Parliament will need to be prepared for the mobilisation of funds to deal with the various crises it faces and which had not necessarily been foreseen during the negotiations on the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the serious challenges and emergencies resulting from the migration and refugee crisis, geopolitical tensions in europe's neighbourhood and the slow pace of economic recovery and EU investment.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The Geier report lays the foundations for the EP's position on the 2017 EU budget, while providing an overview of the current budgetary situation. Tackling the economic and refugee crisis are the main priorities, which will require a real revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework. A billion contribution is expected to be made to the Refugee Fund for Turkey, along with the remaining two billion that Member States have committed to contribute.   In addition, the report addresses, inter alia, the Youth Employment Initiative, the Children's Poverty Guarantee initiative or the European Strategic Investment Fund, beyond the global perspective on economic growth or climate change. Since the S&D Group, we have advocated flexibility in contributions to the budget of Member States under the Stability and Growth Pact. We also believe that solidarity, as a fundamental principle of the EU budget, must also be respected in the treatment of the refugee crisis.   For all these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Tackling the dramatic migration and refugee crises and, at the same time, more and better investment to accelerate today's slow economic recovery should continue to be the EU's budget priorities for next year! That is what we voted for this afternoon in a plenary session in a resolution on the guidelines of the European budget for 2017. The adopted text thus focuses on the problems of long-term unemployment and youth, as well as disparities in economic development in the Union, and indicates that the refugee crisis will not be temporary.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document, although unfortunately I have many comments for it. The document rightly points out that the EU is currently facing a number of crises. It is both economic and migration, and much more. Unfortunately, I have missed another crisis in this document. The crisis, which is currently plaguing a large number of Europeans, is threatening the whole survival of the countryside in the long term. This is a crisis in the agricultural sector. We are all well aware that in many Member States farmers can no longer survive from their work. Unfortunately, as a mockery of their difficult situation, the 2017 budget guidelines only refer to agriculture, trade with Russia, the problems of falling prices and climate change, leading to a single insignificant sentence. I very much want to believe that the draft 2017 draft budget will take a more responsible view of agricultural and rural issues. In next year's budget, we must provide for measures to address the agricultural crisis and hope that there will be something else to save.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out Parliament's political priorities for the 2017 budget year. Above all, it is about paving the way for economic recovery and job creation. This requires stimulating investment for growth and focusing on competitiveness. Programmes such as Erasmus, Horizon 2020 and COSME, which are essential for developing social, educational and economic conditions conducive to European growth, must also be strengthened. It is also necessary to confirm our commitment to continue funding the Youth Employment Initiative in order to strengthen it and thus offer more young people the prospect of actually entering the labour market. Finally, it is a question of establishing a budget that will really meet the challenge posed by the refugee crisis. The mobilization of significant European budgetary resources has not enabled the refugee crisis to be dealt with effectively and sustainably in 2015 and 2016. This is why significant additional financial resources are needed. Long-term solutions, based on the principle of solidarity, must be found in order to address the root causes of the migration phenomenon.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Every year in this month, as per procedure, the European Parliament prepares a report in which it highlights what for all of us are the guidelines that we are asking for to be taken into account when organising the next year's budget by the other co-legislators. We have, of course, called for greater impetus for economic growth, which means a reduction in unemployment and greater stability in the economy of the entire European Union, despite the fact that we know that the biggest and greatest problem at the moment is the migration crisis. In order to put an end to this unstoppable flow, we need to guarantee a slice of the budget for the various instruments that we have put into practice and the future ones that we are going to adopt, also in the light of the conclusions of the European Council in mid-March.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We refrain from supporting Jens Geier's report because we want to give dialogue a chance, inviting us to look into the eyes of the stark reality. We welcome the recommendations it makes in the broad terms of the 2017 budgets, as regards the inclusion of a gender perspective, or greater flexibility of these budgets in the face of economic or refugee crises, and their recommendations on the environment. But we must make a criticism of the budget as a whole; its cut remains neoliberal, the current model is a failure and a thorough review of the EU scheme and budget model is urgently needed. The budget is insufficient, with a poorly distributed income system, which should be based on Member States' Per Capita Income. Investment spending is clearly insufficient, and Geier's guidance, while calling for more flexibility, delves into the insolidary tonic of budgets. We don't think it's enough to overcome the stringing to which the MFF forces. A comprehensive, more social and fairer review of these budgets is therefore needed to be able to meet the challenges that are to come.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ My vote in favour of this report was conditioned by its acceptance that the regional socioeconomic cleavage in the EU continues to increase especially vis-à-vis the European Union’s southern periphery. The report also acknowledges that the economic crisis of past years has dramatically reduced the manoeuvring ability of the different national and regional budgets of poorer Member States. As a result an ever increasing deficit has emerged in the EU’s goal of socioeconomic convergence. This can only be overcome by financial measures specifically targeted at countering the particular problems that characterise peripheral and/or isolated conditions. I welcome the emphasis placed on the point that one-size-fits-all calculations based on GDP are not always necessarily the best indicators when it comes to calculating European Union budget commitments through its funding tools. This is especially the case when dedicating funding for isolated and/or peripheral regions as well as islands.  Because of transport difficulties and costs, plus diseconomies of scale when holding stocks of consumer goods or components of production systems, higher transactional costs and longer delays are incurred when funding or managing projects. For this, no compensation is possible under current rules, except on an ad hoc basis.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This 2017 budget guidelines consolidate, on the income side, an uns ambitious resource policy that limits the ability to develop ambitious policies at the core levels of the European budget, such as agriculture and cohesion. On the contrary, the neoliberal management of expenditure is deepened, with its linkage to the European Semester and its market orientation being particularly serious. In addition, they support an aggressive and anti-human rights foreign policy, as is the case with funds provided to Turkey to make it a prison for refugees wishing to seek asylum from Europe. For all this, I voted against it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ This report is all about the preparations for the 2017 EU Budget. Since there is no fundamental prospect of cutting the huge amounts of taxpayers’ money sent to Brussels, we would vote against it on principle anyway. But the report is also highly critical, stating that ‘the Union budget has in recent years been a collateral victim of Member States’ duplicitous behaviour’. We do not believe that the Union should lecture Member States when the Member States are already providing too much finance to the European Union.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted against calls of other MEPs to increase the EU budget; I believe, like my Labour colleagues, that the MFF – the Multi-Annual Financial Framework – for the EU is sufficient and adequate and that if it is properly managed then it has the capability to deal with the main challenges Europe faces. I believe that, when looking at the reform of the MFF, the main thing that we should be looking at is the redistributive nature of the available budget between different areas. We – Labour MEPs – have continually argued that more needs to be done and can be done within the current budget ceilings and that spending must be prioritised and redirected towards boosting sustainable growth and employment and dealing with the refugee crisis.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
