text: Written. ‒ I have decided to abstain from this report, and this reasoning for voting comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the 2017 budget will be affected by internal and external security challenges, which may also take the form of threats of terrorism or extremism. The Union has faced several crises in recent years, such as war conflicts and the refugee crisis, and it is here that the Union budget has proved to be an important resource in resolving them.  In recent years, the Union budget has been the victim of dual behaviour by the Member States, which has led them to regard their contributions to the Union budget as a burden. In this context, more flexibility is needed with regard to expenditure incurred by Member States in specific areas, such as investments under the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the fight against unemployment, poverty and inequality, including in relation to the need to address emerging security threats and the migration and refugee crisis. As an investment budget, the EU budget can bring extremely high EU added value by boosting growth, competitiveness and job creation in the Member States.  Therefore, Member States' contributions to the Union budget must not be treated as a variable depending on macroeconomic conditions. In the final vote, I did not support the resolution because it passed an amendment to take account of the aspect of the redistribution of migrants when drawing on Euro funds.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The budget for the year ahead needs to further boost growth and job creation, while successfully addressing the problems associated with the growing migration and refugee crisis. At this stage of the (pre)preparations for next year's budget, I would like to point out, above all, that we must continue to work to reduce youth unemployment. Let me recall the joint declaration by the three institutions under the 2016 budget that reducing youth unemployment is an important common priority. I certainly welcome this binding statement, but I wonder why, therefore, no new commitments have been made for additional funding for the YEI for 2016. According to a recent Eurostat survey, youth unemployment is expected to fall in many Member States - especially those with the highest rates. At EU level, it was 1.5% lower at the end of last year. This is a sign that our past efforts have been successful. I believe that the Yem Employment Initiative is one of the main factors for this success. However, I note that the Multiannual Financial Framework is too rigid and flawed in tackling European challenges. In addition, support for the very expensive ITER project on the exploitation of nuclear fusion continues. As a result of that report, I did not support the report in plenary, but I abstained from the vote.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the document defining the European Parliament's main political priorities for the 2017 budget and providing an assessment of the current financial situation in relation to the challenges we face today as the European Union. In Parliament's view, the 2017 budget should focus on increased investment in economic growth and job creation, which are still struggling to recover, ensuring a balance between the limited financial resources and the new emergencies that the EU is experiencing. That is why the text calls for the Council's full support for the use of flexibility instruments, which involve a reform of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). I personally believe that this step is crucial if the EU budget is really to be an instrument for managing current crises, including in particular the migrant and refugee crisis, but also support for economic growth (for example through the EFSI) and climate policy. I therefore strongly support the need to insist that the review of the 2014-2020 MFF be carried out in a legislative proposal by the end of 2016, so that the review can be carried out in good time.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: Writing. The 2017 budget preparation report argues that the existing budget is insufficient to deal with existing crises. The solution to the problem is to increase the ceilings of the multiannual financial framework. It also criticises Member States' efforts to consolidate their budgets and the prospect of a new 'EU tax', rather than a thorough reform of the EU budget. An increase in the EU's overall budget is completely unnecessary from an ALFA point of view, and additional financial support should be found through a review of long-held priorities and a reallocation of existing funds. ALFA is committed to concentrating spending on future challenges rather than an annual update of the status quo. We stand for identifying savings and for the general aim of encouraging the start of a project. This prevents permanent financing and take-away effects. This is the only way to create an efficient and sustainable budget. That is why I voted against the above-mentioned report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing \ u2012 The 2017 budget will be mainly affected by internal and external challenges. The Union budget thus constitutes an important source of finance in resolution, which is not necessarily planned. However, the issue of several programmes of major programmes, such as Erasmus+, as well as the issue of tackling youth employment promotion or many others, remains a focus.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Writing. \u2012 As one of the two components of the EU budgetary authority, the European Parliament has been involved in the budgetary procedure every year since the preparatory phase. Through the budget preparation guidelines approved today, Parliament sets out its priorities for drawing up the budget before the European Commission itself presents the proposal. I am glad that the text also addresses the issue of the migration and refugee crisis, in addition to supporting the EU's main priorities, such as competitiveness, investment for growth and job support. It does so by highlighting the need for a more flexible solution to existing and future migration challenges. The European Union budget is still a key tool for dealing with the current crisis. It should therefore include the support of European agencies, the strengthening of humanitarian aid and other necessary measures to manage and address the current situation and future challenges. In view of the current very fragile geopolitical situation, I also very much welcome the call for support for the Eastern Partnership countries. EU assistance to these countries should contribute to progress in their reform efforts and also deepen their relations with the EU in the future. I therefore voted in favour of the report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The 2017 budget should lay the foundations for economic growth and job creation in the context of a fragile economic recovery that threatens the emerging markets and current geopolitical tensions, and will be affected by the development of the migration and refugee crisis in the 2017 budget. The Union budget has already proven to be a key tool for addressing the ongoing crisis and responding to challenges that were not necessarily foreseen during the 2014-2020 MFF negotiations. - 2020, such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the migration and refugee crisis, and geopolitical tensions in the European neighbourhood, which are the cause of many serious challenges and emergencies, while in the EU the pace of economic recovery and the pace of investment are lower than potential and the investment gap remains. Taking into account the Commission's annual growth survey for 2016, I believe that boosting investment, including by better coordinating the increase in public and private investment with a focus on the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, is the right political solution to achieve a more balanced economic policy. I call for a stronger synergy effect between the Eu-related aspect of the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination and the Union budget, which is also the cornerstone of the stability of the euro area.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The 2017 budget should lay a stable foundation for job creation as well as economic growth in the context of a fragile economic recovery that threatens the situation in emerging world markets and current geopolitical tensions. The 2017 budget will also be affected by the development of the migration and refugee crisis, and it should be taken into account that the balance between internal demand and foreign trade makes the European Union somewhat economically dependent on global developments. The budget will be affected by internal and external security challenges, which can also arise in the form of terrorist threats or extremism. The Union budget is already a proven means of addressing the current crisis. Parliament also recognises the importance of certain programmes such as the school milk and fruit programme and proposes to analyse the extent to which funding for these and similar programmes can be increased.  I support this report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget, as I believe that the guidelines in it are well developed and will have a positive result that will contribute to economic growth as well as to the resolution of current crises.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Our position on the budget is stable. We always vote against him because he expresses the Union's neoliberal economic policies of harsh austerity. His political orientations are again this year within the framework of the austerity policies of the MFF 2014-2020 and are determined by the neoliberal and conservative dominant circles of the Union with the tolerance of the Group of socialists and democrats.  For the above reasons we voted against the report.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 With regard to this report, I voted against the eur 3 billion in direct aid to Turkey for the asylum crisis. This is such a large amount of European taxpayers' money that it must be possible to take a closer look at the money going to the destination for them. Since I remained in the minority in the vote, I hope that the European Commission will follow closely to ensure that this money is spent carefully and that any part that may be saved from it will be returned to the problems within the European Union.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The European Union budget is the main instrument by which European structures can ensure the smooth functioning of the European project in practice. The general guidelines for the 2017 budget indicate the Union's main priorities in the period ahead. These include the refugee and migration crisis, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, economic growth, the Youth Employment Initiative, the Child Guarantee (against poverty), climate change, late payments, the Facility for Refugees in Turkey, etc.  There are still a number of problems with the flexibility of Member States' contributions to the EU budget and respect for the principle of solidarity. Unfortunately, solidarity between Member States is being put to the test by the problems of the moment, so it has not been possible to include it in the current document. Overall, however, the document reflects the main areas of union interest where consistent action is needed. The adoption of this document will allow for a better response to the crises facing the EU today, although there is also a need for greater member member commitment to overcome existing problems.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I believe that the EU's own resources system needs to be reformed in depth and gives a high-level political importance to the work of the High Level Group on Own Resources set up under the 2014-2020 MFF Agreement. I expect the Commission and the Council to take into account the conclusions of this work, which should be formulated by the end of 2016 at the latest, as well as any potential new own resources. The primary objective of the reform of own resources is to make the revenue component of the EU budget more autonomous, more stable, simpler, fairer, more sustainable and more predictable, as well as to reduce the burden it places on national budgets in terms of excessive spending and to improve transparency and visibility towards citizens, without increasing the overall tax burden borne by citizens.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report laying out guidelines for the 2017 Budget, which is an important first step for drafting the 2017 budget. I certainly agree that the EU’s budget should both support the economic recovery by supporting investment and job creation and be flexible to be able to respond effectively to unforeseeable crisis situations, such as the refugee and migration crisis, terrorism or the instability of the global market we saw in 2015.  I hope that the 2017 budget will further facilitate SMEs’ access to markets and funding, such as through Europe’s programme for small and medium-sized enterprises (COSME). I am in fact convinced that the EU’s future, credibility and competitiveness lie in its capacity to innovate in key strategic sectors.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the general guidelines for preparing the 2017 budget. While this report focuses on the European Union budget to address the migrant and refugee crisis, high youth unemployment and sluggish economic growth, I do not think a significant increase in the Union budget is needed to effectively implement European Union policy to tackle this crisis.  I believe that the 2017 budget should lay the foundations for economic growth and job creation in the context of a fragile economic recovery that threatens the situation on world markets and the current geopolitical situation. Once again, I would like to point out that increasing the Budget of the European Union is unnecessary and that the situation can be

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the general guidelines for the preparation of the 2017 budget, Section III – Commission, as I believe that, in addition to the estimated resources spent responding to the envisaged needs for the financial period 2014-2020, I believe that the Union budget has proved to be a key resource for resolving the recent crisis situations that have hit us and caused many serious challenges and emergencies. I also think that the budget is prepared in line with the European Semester and taking into account economic forecasts.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We refrain from supporting Jens Geier's report, because we want to give dialogue a chance, inviting us to look into the eyes of the stark reality. We welcome the recommendations it makes in the broad terms of the 2017 budgets, as regards the inclusion of a gender perspective, or greater flexibility of these budgets in the face of economic or refugee crises, and their recommendations on the environment. But we must make a criticism of the budget as a whole; its cut remains neoliberal, the current model is a failure and a thorough review of the EU scheme and budget model is urgently needed. The budget is insufficient, with a poorly distributed income system, which should be based on Member States' Per Capita Income. Investment spending is clearly insufficient, and Geier's guidance, while calling for more flexibility, delves into the insolidary tonic of budgets. We don't think it's enough to overcome the stringing to which the MFF forces. A comprehensive, more social and fairer review of these budgets is therefore needed to be able to meet the challenges that are to come.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Writing. The 2017 budget preparation report argues that the existing budget is insufficient to deal with existing crises. The solution to the problem is to increase the ceilings of the multiannual financial framework. It also criticises Member States' efforts to consolidate their budgets and the prospect of a new 'EU tax' rather than a thorough reform of the EU budget. An increase in the EU's overall budget is completely unnecessary from an ALFA point of view, and additional financial support should be found through a review of long-held priorities and a reallocation of existing funds. ALFA is committed to concentrating spending on future challenges rather than an annual update of the status quo. We stand for identifying savings and for the general aim of encouraging the start of a project. This prevents permanent financing and take-away effects. This is the only way to create an efficient and sustainable budget. That is why I voted against the above-mentioned report.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The report calls for an increase in payment appropriations, urging Member States to reduce the size of their budgets in favour of increasing their contributions to that of the EU, a well-known European refrain. However, the novelty lies in the desire to increase funding for migrants. In other words, more and more spending and tax revenue (European taxes, etc.) to finance more and more immigration. So I voted AGAINST this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU budget has proved to be a key resource for dealing with recent crises and meeting unforeseen needs when negotiating the TPK for the period 2014-2020. The Commission's Annual Growth Survey for 2016 strongly believes that boosting investment, including a more coordinated increase in public and private investment, with a focus on europe 2020 objectives, is an appropriate policy response to a more balanced economic policy. With my vote, I followed the position of the S&D group.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We refrain from supporting Jens Geier's report because we want to give dialogue a chance, inviting us to look into the eyes of the stark reality. We welcome the recommendations it makes in the broad terms of the 2017 budgets, as regards the inclusion of a gender perspective, or greater flexibility of these budgets in the face of economic or refugee crises, and their recommendations on the environment. But we must make a criticism of the budget as a whole; its cut remains neoliberal, the current model is a failure and a thorough review of the EU scheme and budget model is urgently needed. The budget is insufficient, with a poorly distributed income system, which should be based on Member States' Per Capita Income. Investment spending is clearly insufficient, and Geier's guidance, while calling for more flexibility, delves into the insolidary tonic of budgets. We don't think it's enough to overcome the stringing to which the MFF forces. A comprehensive, more social and fairer review of these budgets is therefore needed to be able to meet the challenges that are to come.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because it confirms its support for international ITER research.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on guidelines for the 2017 Budget – Section III. The report objectively states future priorities and concerns related to the EU budget. It states that the EU budget priorities for 2017 will be related to the migration and refugee crisis, but also related to greater investing and the acceleration of the slow post-crisis recovery. Concerns are expressed regarding problems of long-term and youth unemployment and disparities in economic development across the EU. In addition, the refugee crisis is a long-term challenge and additional financial resources will be needed to deal with it.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. The report highlights the European Parliament's political priorities for next year, emphasizing the most important elements for 2017: boosting investment for growth, competitiveness and job creation, as well as responding to the challenges of the current migrant and refugee crisis. In this regard, the report underlines the importance that the medium-term budgetary review will have in order to be able to respond more appropriately to the Union's current challenges. We are talking about a report which is coming to collect the most important elements for 2017, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for the 2017 Union budget because we need a strong budget for 2017 to give us the tools to respond to the many challenges we face. First, this means that we need to provide ourselves with the resources to effectively deal with the migrant and refugee crisis.  We need to make sure that we have sufficient resources and flexibility to react to a situation that, like today's, changes rapidly, while ensuring that the budget allows us to show solidarity with countries facing the brunt of the crisis. Moreover, the solution of the refugee crisis must go hand in hand with boosting European growth and competitiveness. The EU needs greater investment in areas such as education or infrastructure in order to compete in the 21st century. Too many young Europeans are still struggling to get a job and we need more action at EU level to meet this challenge. That is why we are asking for more funding for the Youth Employment Initiative to ensure that no young people in the EU are left behind.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. This report too, which outlines the guidelines for the 2017 budget, is in staggering continuity with the previous ones, confirming the inability of the establishment to question what has not worked and thus identifying concrete and effective measures to raise the economic situation, especially in the most vulnerable sectors and regions. At the heart of the report, as in previous years, remains a distorted reading of the current economic situation and the causes of the crisis, as well as the conviction that the technocratic and neoliberal coordination mechanisms of the European Semester, in which absurd economic recipes have been prescribed, must be taken into account and integrated into the preparation of the next budget. I also believe that this report fails to express adequate and concrete solutions, or at least to envisage alternatives to an approach that has not produced any tangible benefit, while appreciating the fact that there are dutiful references in the text to the fight against unemployment, the migration crisis and also the problem of late payments. Finally, our highly critical amendments on current economic governance policies and instruments, the controversial Juncker Fund and the misuse of the Youth Guarantee Fund, as well as our demands for a reduction in administrative expenditure, were rejected. For these reasons, I voted against this report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against an increase in the European budget. I feel that it is important that we ensure that the budget is good value for money across the board. However, it is important to acknowledge the importance of investment from the EU into my constituency of Wales. Wales receives a net gain of GBP 838 million directly from the EU. Investment from the EU has seen university campuses either built from scratch or expanded at Swansea, Cardiff, Aberystwyth and Bangor. It also been used to improve lives across Wales, through programmes like Project Y that is focused on helping young people at risk of falling out of education, and Bridges to Work, designed to help people into employment. Therefore the budget as a whole represents a vital resource for Wales and other regions like it, across the European Union; however it needs to be managed carefully and spent on priorities like the projects mentioned.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of these guidelines. After all, the European Union's budget has shown that it had a crucial role to play in addressing the recent crises and responding to needs that could not be expected during the multiannual financial negotiations, such as the refugee crisis or geopolitical tensions in Europe's neighbouring countries.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This annual report of the European Parliament sets out the guidelines for the 2017 budget and aims to establish a preliminary position to influence the Commission, which is drawing up the draft budget for the coming year. In the report's positive points, there is a reminder of the growing gap between the poorest and richest regions and between EU countries, in order to foster greater cohesion within the European Union.  The report also stresses the European Parliament's role as a co-decision and believes that Member States' contributions to the EU budget should not be taken into account when calculating the structural deficit. My group has tabled several amendments, calling for more investment in particular in social areas and to encourage the reception of refugees, especially children, as well as an in-depth investigation into the "disappearance" of 10,000 migrant children, and to analyse all the measures and projects deployed and financed in the areas of migration and their compliance with European and international law.  Unfortunately, our amendments were largely rejected. So I chose to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This is a report that does not advocate profound differences from what have been the budgetary priorities of previous years. With these profound changes we can only vote against. As usual, we have actively intervened in the debate on budgetary priorities, proposing various amendments to the report. Examples include: the defence of substantial budget reinforcement, in particular the components dedicated to economic and social cohesion, by creating an investment plan mobilising at least 2 % of EU GDP annually over the next ten years; the defence of cuts in military spending and associated with EU external interventionism; the defence of measures to combat poverty, inequalities and social exclusion, as well as unemployment; the creation of specific support programmes for countries, such as Portugal, which are intervened by the Troika and facing greater difficulties; the establishment of support programmes for countries opting for a negotiated exit from the euro which, among other things, provides for appropriate compensation for the damage caused by entry and stay in the single currency. These are amendments that point an alternative path to the current course of disaster. Unfortunately they were rejected.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report considers the EU budget to be one of the main factors in overcoming the multi-crisis (euro, finance, growth, refugees). On the same line as this logic, the multiannual financial framework should be watered down and payment ceilings, as they are now set per year, abolished in order to increase budgetary flexibility. Although there is a flexibility instrument, the appropriations for payments for the special instruments (the Flexibility Instrument, the European Union Solidarity Fund, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the Emergency Reserve) are to be calculated beyond the ceilings of the MFF. The report calls for structural and investment funds to be tapped to implement the country-specific recommendations, introducing more flexibility in Member States' deficit calculation for certain expenditures and abolishing the ceiling on payments from the annual EU budget, which is not the purpose of the recommendations and which never really creates stability. The final demand is: "underlines that the Union's budget has enabled an immediate response to the crisis and should be substantially revised upwards so that the implementation of EU policies to deal with this crisis can be effectively financed, and stresses that it should serve as part of a European solution to overcome this emergency in the future;" I therefore reject this report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on the guidelines for the 2017 budget. The report argues that the budgetary resources now available are insufficient to deal with today's crises. It calls for an increase in the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). I am opposed to an increase in the EU's overall budget. The MFF should in principle be scrapped and additional funds can be made available at any time by reviewing the current allocation of funds.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the multi-annual financial framework for the EU budget is adequate, if properly directed, to face the main challenges Europe is facing. I believe that when looking at reform of the MFF the priority should be redistribution between headings. More needs to be done within current ceilings and spending needs to be clearly prioritised towards boosting sustainable growth and employment, as well as dealing with the refugee crisis.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report tabled in the Committee on Budgets on the preparation of next year's draft. The resolution shall take into account both the economic forecasts and the European Semester for the coordination of economic policy.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 As every year, the General Rapporteur for the EU budget presents guidelines for setting what the 2017 budget will be. The approach of this text changes very little compared to previous years, following a well-established pattern. We start from some economic considerations, which I strongly criticize, on the need to continue the coordination between the European budget and the failed policies of economic governance, and then enter into the merits of some priorities and issues to be addressed, with a particular focus on the issue of immigration. There is no shortage of references to the support that the EU budget could give to businesses and in the fight against unemployment, as well as a dutiful reference to the problem of backpaying, without, however, proposing any concrete solution. While we can be satisfied that immigration is at last also at the heart of the European budget, otherwise there is little new, if not fine but useless words and intentions that are then difficult to translate into concrete action.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Geier report, because I believe that Parliament's proposal mobilises the means available to deal with the crises that europe is experiencing today. Not only the humanitarian crisis in refugees and migration, but also the economic crisis, with proposals such as the Youth Employment Initiative, which is a key contribution to the Union's priority objective of growth and jobs, including young migrants arriving in the EU. The European Union budget, although admittedly insufficient, is one of the key resources to deal with recent crises, while addressing needs that had not necessarily been foreseen during the negotiations on the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the guidelines for the 2017 budget, which places emphasis on increasing investment for growth, competitiveness and job creation, and addresses the current challenges of the refugee crisis.  I am pleased that the Union's priority objective in the field of jobs and growth also remains the financing of the Youth Employment Programme. This will allow more young people to enter the labour market effectively through quality job offers, continuing education or traineeships.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Although I abstained, I did not vote 'yes', I really liked some parts of this report. In particular, those which have reinforced the importance of subsidiarity and proportionality and the role of national parliaments in the relationship between the European Union and the Member States. Why did you like this so much, and why do I suggest to my fellow Members of Parliament and fellow politicians at home that you read this report as carefully as possible? Because we must also recall time and time again to our citizens what subsidiarity means. It means that nation states, Member States, retain their sovereignty. We are not giving up our right to decide for ourselves in the case of our own country, but only in an area that is very limited by law. And migration, for example, is not like that, it is up to us to decide, in our own state, e.g. as Hungarians.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I supported this report because I am aware that the quality of our legislative acts is sometimes debatable. And at the time when I was responsible in the Czech Republic for legislation and for the transformation of European law into the Czech legal order, we often encountered possible interpretations of certain directives and wondered how best to transpose a directive into national law.  I am therefore very glad that there is such an agreement on the table, which focuses explicitly on the quality of the law, because, in my opinion, this is not only a technical matter, but also has a major political impact. In short, when poor legislative acts come from our Parliament and the Institutions of the European Union in general, this also has an impact on how our citizens perceive the idea of European integration and the idea of the European Union as such.  I consider it very important that the role of national parliaments under the Treaty of Lisbon is strengthened and needs to be used more in practice.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I, too, voted in favour, but I have to say something about it, with some stomach pains. I believe that this is all going in the right direction. However, I would have liked to see a little more clarity and a little more concrete facts at one point or another. From the point of view of small and medium-sized enterprises, for example, I would like to see a binding SME test. What has also bothered me a little is that, in my view, the negotiations between the Council, the Commission and Parliament could perhaps have been a little more transparent. I also believe that, if you are honest, the Commission proposal as we originally had was a good one. But in the negotiations it was then somewhat watered down. So, as I said, I agreed, but with some abdominal pain.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Clearly, the legislative process in the European Union must be of such high quality, because otherwise it affects more than one in half a billion people. In all areas, from culture to education. And it is clear that, when it comes to this document, the idea of taking small and medium-sized enterprises into account is welcome. Because it is small and medium-sized enterprises that make up an absolute majority of our Community businesses and the economic backbone of the Union. Also, the idea of maximum simplification of the legislative process is good, I think. It is no secret that the majority of the citizens of the European Union have no idea what is happening in the European institutions and that is why we need to bring these institutions closer to the people of our electorate. Finally, it is clear that there is an important exchange of views between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, we have in the European Union a rich, perhaps too rich, sometimes unclear legislation, because each or many of our colleagues come up with a personal agenda and, then, our legislation is full of 'but', 'and', 'or', 'in addition', 'in particular', 'in particular', and that makes it like a Christmas tree. That is why, for many European citizens, it is not clear what we mean: everything; and sometimes we get to lack of content. That is why I very much agree with this report. Laws must be simple, clear, precise, short. Short, I insist! We are here to legislate for European citizens and not to promote on the agenda a subject that we want to find in every law we adopt. The Commission, Parliament and the Council must consult each other and also consult the citizens we work for. Transparency and public consultation!

name: Markus PIEPER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I voted in favour of the Hübner report, because the positive thing is that small companies are the focus of cutting red tape, and there is also a little more independence in the Commission's assessment of the quality of impact assessments. However, I would like to remind you of the Commission's draft. The Commission wanted a stronger reporting obligation for gold-plating. The Commission wanted to make the Council and Parliament more responsible for its own impact assessments. The Commission wanted to make a commitment to an annual list of acts to be taken back. I wonder why the Council and Parliament, especially Parliament, prevented or massively weakened all this? In the nirvana of a trialogue negotiation without a parliamentary vote, important progress towards greater transparency has simply disappeared, and our negotiator has not given a good light on this either. The Commission is now keeping the buck of European bureaucracy. It is a pity, because we are squandering the opportunity for European citizens to know who is really responsible for what at what stage of European legislation. This agreement deserved more.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, the three elected PS members of this Parliament voted against this agreement, because it is unbalanced and in fact provides that Parliament is only consulted by the European Commission and the Council. The mere consultation of a co-legislator is obviously insufficient in these fundamental matters.  Furthermore, the PS considers that REFIT, which is included in this agreement, represents a danger and a tool of destruction and threat against rules of social protection, environmental protection and public health.  That is why, for us, there could be no question of accepting this institutional agreement. Today, Europe is sick. It is in great need of social integration, of laws that go towards more tax and social harmonisation. This text does not meet these fundamental expectations.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, we are talking about better laws and better regulation, and who would discount the idea that we need better laws? The EU certainly does need better laws because, after all, 40 years of EU regulation is leading GDP levels to the lowest they have ever been. EU laws have led to lower productivity, unemployment across the continent at an average of 13% and youth unemployment at an average of over 30%. This is a continent that is dying because of EU laws.  But when you look at EU laws, you also have to look at how those EU laws are created. In the United States, you have senators and congressmen who make the laws because the people want them to. In the nation states it is the parliamentarians who make the laws, because the people do. But here in the EU it is civil servants. In reality, the EU stating it wants better regulation is like the captain of a sinking ship shouting out loudly he wants more holes.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The main objective of the Interinstitutional Agreement is to 'produce better rules', which are more effective, but also to debureaucratise the European Union: objectives that we fully support. In fact, although the agreement has improved, it is weak on issues that are fundamental to us: transparency on so-called trialogues, control of lobbyist contacts and direct involvement of citizens in the Union's political decisions. I have chosen to abstain because deepening these three issues is fundamental for us to the development of a healthy and participatory democracy.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – UKIP today voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. UKIP is opposed in principle to the EU having any power of any kind to make and pass legislation, whether by way of Directive, Regulation or any other means which will have primacy over UK law and thus over-ride the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. Secondly, we do not believe that this interinstitutional agreement will alter in any way the profoundly undemocratic nature of the European Union in general or the European Parliament in particular. Thirdly we note that this document is, in terms, a singular and ringing indictment of the nature of the last 59 years of legislation by the EU and its predecessor organisations. The new agreement identifies with clarity the very real deficiencies in EU law-making which has placed so damaging a burden on the competitiveness and profitability of UK businesses, the vast majority of whom do not even do business outside the UK. For those reasons, we have voted against this agreement.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Interinstitutional Agreement on the Improvement of Legislation which seeks to ensure that EU legislation best serves the interests of citizens and businesses. The European and Spanish Socialists are defending reducing the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, and strengthening close cooperation between institutions, in particular in the area of legislative programming. It is also essential that the new Agreement strengthens impact assessments of new initiatives and the cost of non-action at EU level is valued. Finally, I welcome the establishment for the first time of a procedure to ensure that the Commission has to respond to proposals for acts coming from this Parliament.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP today voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. UKIP is opposed in principle to the EU having any power of any kind to make and pass legislation, whether by way of Directive, Regulation or any other means which will have primacy over UK law and thus over-ride the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. Secondly, we do not believe that this interinstitutional agreement will alter in any way the profoundly undemocratic nature of the European Union in general or the European Parliament in particular. Thirdly we note that this document is, in terms, a singular and ringing indictment of the nature of the last 59 years of legislation by the EU and its predecessor organisations. The new agreement identifies with clarity the very real deficiencies in EU law-making which has placed so damaging a burden on the competitiveness and profitability of UK businesses, the vast majority of whom do not even do business outside the UK. For those reasons, we have voted against this agreement.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against this agreement, negotiated behind Parliament's back through the irregular appointment of the liberal group's head of row as its representative, because it is a tremendous democratic involution. Parliament has reduced its powers over the Commission, which will strengthen technocratic and neoliberal control over the legislative process. Moreover, the setting of quantitative targets for the reduction of legislation and the fight against 'overregulation' in the text are tools to reduce the harmonised protection enjoyed by European workers and citizens (as has already been demonstrated by REFIT), which is a disturbing development to which we must oppose it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against the interinstitutional agreement on Better Regulation as it was a missed opportunity to open up the legislative process to scrutiny. After all, consultation, evaluation and transparency are what better regulation should be about, not deregulation which suits only corporate interests. It must be remembered that Brussels is second only to Washington DC in terms of paid professionals attempting to either influence public policy or political decisions. The EU capital has an estimated 30 000 lobbyists. This is not accidental; it is a concerted effort to retain power and to remove political and economic decisions from democratic debate and influence and thus from the hands of citizens. In a modern democracy, there is no reason why the decision-making process cannot be both efficient and transparent. That is the crux of the issue: the EU is fundamentally undemocratic and it is not concerned with efficiency, it is deregulation that they are concerned with, and efficiency is used to conceal the agenda of financial deregulation.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report allows for better implementation of European Union legislation, respecting agreements with the social partners and at the same time ensuring greater transparency. In particular, Parliament has a greater say in annual and multiannual programming, there is a commitment to greater transparency in the Council's legislative procedures, agreements between the social partners are protected and will not be subject to impact assessments. For these reasons I voted in favour of this report.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. In May 2015, the Commission published a new Interinstitutional Agreement aimed at making the work of the EU's main institutions – Parliament, council and Commission – more efficient. Given that the agreement entails increased transparency of the legislative process, this decision is expressly to be welcomed.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Report to better legislate: extensive programme... But to do that, lobby groups would have to be put on the map, because they are too often the source of legislative initiatives. This report is therefore once again a uselessness draped in beautiful feelings: I have spoken out against this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on better law making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. I am opposed in principle to the EU having any power to make and pass legislation, whether by directive, regulation or any other means that would have primacy over UK law and override the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. Secondly I do not believe that this agreement will alter in any way the profoundly undemocratic nature of the EU in general or the European Parliament in particular. The document is a singular and ringing indictment of the nature of the past 59 years of legislation by the EU and its predecessor organisations. The new agreement identifies with clarity the very real deficiencies in EU law making which has placed such a damaging burden on the competitiveness of profitability of UK businesses.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which strengthens cooperation between the European institutions so that the drafting of legislation is more transparent. This agreement between Parliament, the Council and the Commission should improve regulation on our continent and reduce bureaucracy for our companies, which will simplify their work and give them greater flexibility.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Interinstitutional Agreement on the Improvement of Legislation which seeks to ensure that EU legislation best serves the interests of citizens and businesses. The European and Spanish Socialists are defending reducing the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, and strengthening close cooperation between institutions, in particular in the area of legislative programming. It is also essential that the new Agreement strengthens impact assessments of new initiatives and the cost of non-action at EU level is valued. Finally, I welcome the establishment for the first time of a procedure to ensure that the Commission has to respond to proposals for acts coming from this Parliament.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for better law-making. This proposal aims to improve the quality, annual and multiannual programming of draft legislative acts drafted by the Commission and to strengthen its impact assessment of its draft legislation.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is based on the fact that the European Parliament has repeatedly requested the modernisation of the 2003 Interinstitutional Agreement (between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on improving regulation). However, the proposal does not contain any breakthrough elements, subsidiarity is not given sufficient emphasis, the democratic deficit continues to prevail: only the Commission can put forward a legislative proposal. It is objectionable that the proposal to improve the quality of legislation does not comply with the principle of norm-lightness, the points are high, the sprained, the lack of professional legal assistance. There is no guarantee that the quality of legislation will increase and, in particular, there is no guarantee that central regulation will gradually be reduced, and instead, the stealth deprivation of powers, supported by the European Court of Justice and the Commission, is increasing.  The reason why I did not reject the report, but abstained from voting, is point 12. This means: "better use should be made of the rules for political dialogue with national parliaments; underlines, in this context, the important role that the Treaty of Lisbon has given national parliaments, and stresses that, in addition to monitoring respect for the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, they have the opportunity to make a meaningful contribution to and make use of political dialogue; encourages the better application of the existing subsidiarity and proportionality mechanisms laid down in the Treaties'.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This report aligns the need for ongoing dialogue among stakeholders, wishful thinking about the role and effectiveness of impact assessments, and unfulfilled promises about transparency. No concrete measures are envisaged only to combat lobbying - the Brussels student has overtaken his master in Washington - or to take into account the interest and will of the peoples. It is an internal kitchen, completely self-centered, without consistency. When you see how the TTIP negotiations are going (formerly TAFTA), the promises of transparency make you want to laugh yellow. When we know the weight of lobbies with the Commission, the commitments to assess the impact of legislation through impact studies sound wrong. When we see the devastation of the directives already in place every day, we have little confidence for the future.  It is high time that the Eurocrats questioned themselves... before peoples free themselves from their mortal tutelage.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The three members of the Belgian PS elected in this Parliament voted against this agreement because they believe that, under the guise of simplifying European legislation, the REFIT programme poses a serious threat to many provisions relating to social protection, environmental protection and public health. However, even more than before this long period of austerity, Europe must protect its citizens and its workers. We voted against this point because, in addition to this deep concern, the inter-institutional approach is unbalanced as it only provides for consultation with the European Parliament by the European Commission and the Council in the implementation of REFIT. This is clearly insufficient in view of the threats to the safety and health of workers or, more generally, European citizens.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Hübner report on the conclusion of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. This is an important text which aims to improve the planning, transparency and quality of the legislative production process. This updated the previous agreement of 2003, which did not provide for the institutional framework established by the Treaty of Lisbon. Fundamental, in the new agreement, is the provision for an assessment of the impact of legislation. This will not only cover the economic, social and environmental aspects, but will also assess the consequences of laws passed in terms of competitiveness, particularly with regard to regional realities and SMEs. From the point of view of programming, coordination of the three institutions will be envisaged at the beginning of each parliamentary term in order to define the multiannual priorities, which will be accompanied by a similar process on an annual basis.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We voted against it, since although there are improvements in terms of transparency and procedures, they are not sufficient. Moreover, behind certain sections which are committed to 'better regulation' there is actually a path to deregulation, which in the context of the macro trade agreement negotiations is a very high risk. This report also gives the European Commission more legislative powers to the detriment of the European Parliament. Parliament is the only body directly and democratically elected by European citizenship, so giving the Commission more powers only deepens the current model of European institutional architecture, with a Parliament with hardly any legislative capacity, which is a democratic anomaly.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is merely a product of bad faith and/or blindness of the Brussels institutions to the lack of democratic legitimacy of the European Union. It is all very well to follow up the great declarations of intent on the dialogue between the Council, the Commission and Parliament, which are easy to profess incantations in favour of greater transparency and a re-enactment of impact studies! The reality is quite different: total opacity regarding the most serious negotiations for European peoples such as TTIP; a European Union governed by lobbies, real lawyers for multinationals and defenders of foreign interests at the expense of the interests of European nations. Finally, when we see the scandalous inefficiency of the directives already in place, we think that in Brussels, "better regulation" apparently means a negotiation between notorious criminals to determine which will have the largest share of the loot.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I can largely support them, there are passages in this text that I consider controversial and that could cause future critical issues, which is why I abstained.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I have voted against the report. There have been improvements compared to the original text, but the basic tone of the report is still mainly about the interests of businesses in simplification and reducing the administrative burden. I am in favour of implementing reforms that reduce the administrative burden on businesses, but not if simplification of legislation has negative consequences in terms of, for example, health and safety at work, or limit the legislator's ability to regulate. I also believe that the European Commission is given too much power and control during the proposed decision-making process. Furthermore, I believe that the legislative process would be much more transparent. Transparency is important for the functioning of democracy. For these reasons, I choose to vote 'no'.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Interinstitutional Agreement on the Improvement of Legislation which seeks to ensure that EU legislation best serves the interests of citizens and businesses. The European and Spanish Socialists are defending reducing the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, and strengthening close cooperation between institutions, in particular in the area of legislative programming. It is also essential that the new Agreement strengthens impact assessments of new initiatives and the cost of non-action at EU level is valued. Finally, I welcome the establishment for the first time of a procedure to ensure that the Commission has to respond to proposals for acts coming from this Parliament.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which agrees between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on better law-making. The purpose of this interinstitutional agreement is to facilitate negotiations under the ordinary legislative procedure. The three institutions agree that the results of the evaluation of the possible 'European added value' of any proposed Action of the European Union, as well as the results of the evaluation of the 'absence of expenditure on european action' should be fully taken into account when drawing up the legislative agenda. They also consider that public consultation and stakeholder consultation, ex-post evaluation of existing legislation and impact assessments of new initiatives will contribute to the objective of better law-making. The three institutions agree that European Union legislation should be comprehensible and clear, enable citizens, administrations and businesses to easily understand their rights and obligations, establish appropriate reporting, monitoring and evaluation requirements, avoid excessive regulatory and administrative burdens and be put into practice.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The current interinstitutional agreement is the first review of the legal rules of the game between EU institutions since 2003. At the same time, this legal language and form must effectively convey the political will that created it, and Parliament reinforces this with this report.  Better and more effective legislation should aim to avoid extreme over-regulation and under-regulation. It is therefore important that all parties involved can participate and be heard in the legislative process; not only the largest, but also the smallest, small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens.  The report provides an interpretation of the Interinstitutional Agreement in which the advocacy of SMEs is guaranteed; the provision of a legal form of political will follows from the binding nature of pre-decision impact assessments, and it is important for institutional actors to achieve a balance between delegated and implementing acts. However, the success of the interinstitutional agreement lies in its implementation. I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ by supporting the Interinstitutional Agreement on better law-making, the European Parliament continues its fight for more efficient drafting and adoption of legislation on the union, Parliament, the European Commission and the European Council. Above all, it is important that we include SMEs as transparently and actively as possible in measuring impacts. It is also necessary to speed up the exchange of best practices and methodologies and to take into account any burden that is further prescribed to companies under the new rules. The Regulatory Scrutiny Committee, which oversees the effects of better law-making measures and must maintain its independence from political decision-making as much as possible, will play a key role in this.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒I support this report on the interinstitutional agreement on better law-making, which will allow for better application of EU law, while respecting agreements with social partners, and more transparency.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. While it is clear that there is much to complain about the democratic level of functioning of these entities, this report only raises the issue of impact assessments and the necessary transparency. These last points are a smile when we know the weight of lobbying with the Commission and the level of opacity of the TAFTA treaty negotiations. This report does not call into question the system that led to the current economic disaster of the European Union. I am in favour of returning legislative power to the peoples of the Member States, and therefore I voted against this report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that this new interinstitutional agreement finally takes due account of the social dimension of the Union's policies. The role given to social dialogue and social and environmental impact assessment will, in future, make it possible to increase the quality of European legislation.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European institutions have a number of tools at their disposal to improve and simplify European legislation. With the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking, these institutions are committed to working together to better legislate and to ensure that EU policies and rules achieve their objectives at a minimum cost and administrative burden. The European Parliament must support and implement the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking and thus strengthen cooperation with the European Council and the European Commission in order to improve the way in which the European Union legislates and to ensure that EU legislation provides a better service to European citizens and businesses. This agreement should make the EU legislative process more transparent, open to contributions from stakeholders and easier to follow. It will also contribute to the assessment of the impact of EU law on small and medium-sized enterprises, local industry and citizens. The new agreement between the EU institutions will also aim to make cooperation between them easier and clearer.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to ensure a decision-making process based on good information, inclusive and transparent and for the correct application of legislation, with provisions protecting the prerogatives of legislators, interinstitutional negotiations were formally opened between the three main institutions of the Union on 25 June 2015. A number of priorities have been set in their course, in particular as regards the quality of the drafting of the Commission's legislative texts, the multiannual and annual programming, the strengthening of the impact assessment of draft laws, the equal treatment of the two components of the legislative authority throughout the legislative process on access to information, appropriate interinstitutional consultations, the course given by the Commission to Parliament's proposals and recommendations and the provision of detailed justifications for each withdrawal envisaged. The three institutions believe that public and stakeholder consultation, ex-post evaluations of existing legislation and impact assessments of the new initiatives will contribute to achieving the better regulation objective. Given that this Agreement reflects the powers of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, as well as the balance between these institutions, as set out in the Treaties, I voted in favour of this draft.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. The new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking and the annexed "Convention of Understanding on Delegated Acts" contain practical rules, agreed between Parliament, the Council and the Commission, for the conduct of the ordinary legislative procedure and the consequent delegated and implementing acts. The important innovation compared to the previous IAI is the introduction of a prior impact assessment of each legislative proposal and more in-depth and detailed ex-post evaluations of existing legislation, with the ultimate aim of avoiding over-regulation and unnecessary burdens, with particular reference to SMEs. Another objective is a more uniform and transparent application of delegated acts. Among the measures taken, a common functional register of delegated acts containing well-structured and user-friendly information will be established by the end of 2017. The content and objectives of the IIA are acceptable, net of the well-known considerations on the congenital democratic deficit in the EU. It should be noted, however, that, in the AFCO report, "the need for greater flexibility in the application of the eight-week deadline available to national parliaments to deliver a reasoned opinion on non-compliance with the principle of subsidiarity", underlined in § 12, is in direct contrast to the support expressed for the 'one fits all' approach, because '1 costs less than 28' (§ 7) – in other words, , the malevolent idea of the 'cost of non-Europe'.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Interinstitutional Agreement on the Improvement of Legislation which seeks to ensure that EU legislation best serves the interests of citizens and businesses. The European and Spanish Socialists are defending reducing the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, and strengthening close cooperation between institutions, in particular in the area of legislative programming. It is also essential that the new Agreement strengthens impact assessments of new initiatives and the cost of non-action at EU level is valued. Finally, I welcome the establishment for the first time of a procedure to ensure that the Commission has to respond to proposals for acts coming from this Parliament.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. This report contains the IIA Inter-Institutional Agreement on "Better Legislation". As Chairman of the Committee on Fisheries, I particularly welcome the creation of the group that will negotiate the terms of cooperation on international agreements, including fisheries agreements. It is essential for the inter-institutional balance that each institution be able to exercise its rights in the negotiation and conclusion of international agreements. The now obligatory inter-institutional exchange of views in the event of a change in the legal basis is a very good initiative. This report rightly recalls the Commission's role as a facilitator in inter-institutional negotiations. It treats both branches of legislative authority in the same way. In adopting this report, MEPs oppose any attempt to undermine the legislative powers of Parliament.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of this agreement which aims to improve the way the EU legislates and to ensure that EU legislation provides better services for citizens and businesses. With this agreement, small and medium-sized enterprises, local industry and citizens will be more involved in the decision-making process, in particular through the creation of a web portal that will allow initiatives and new public consultations to be followed during the evaluation of existing policies or possible new proposals. A permanent platform for dialogue with stakeholders is also established, to involve businesses, civil society and the social partners in the effort to reduce regulatory and administrative burdens. This agreement makes cooperation between the EU institutions easier and clearer. Measures are finally agreed to improve the exchange of views and information between Parliament and the Council as legislators. However, I believe that we need to deepen, in particular, with regard to mutual access to information and meetings, so that we can ensure real balance and equal treatment between legislators throughout the legislative process by ensuring that the principle of loyal cooperation between the institutions is up to the rules.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the interinstitutional agreement on Better Regulation as it was a missed opportunity to open up the legislative process to scrutiny. After all, consultation, evaluation and transparency are what better regulation should be about, not deregulation which suits only corporate interests. It must be remembered that Brussels is second only to Washington DC in terms of paid professionals attempting to either influence public policy or political decisions. The EU capital has an estimated 30 000 lobbyists. This is not accidental; it is a concerted effort to retain power and to remove political and economic decisions from democratic debate and influence and thus from the hands of citizens. In a modern democracy, there is no reason why the decision-making process cannot be both efficient and transparent. That is the crux of the issue: the EU is fundamentally undemocratic and it is not concerned with efficiency, it is deregulation that they are concerned with, and efficiency is used to conceal the agenda of financial deregulation.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP today voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. UKIP is opposed in principle to the EU having any power of any kind to make and pass legislation, whether by way of Directive, Regulation or any other means which will have primacy over UK law and thus over-ride the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. .

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ In general, I welcome the interinstitutional agreement on Better Regulation which should provide foundations for better cooperation between the institutions, especially in that it covers some very important areas, namely better regulation, interinstitutional relations, and the legislative process.  The draft is rather satisfactory but I would like to see greater importance being attached to the impact assessments for small and medium enterprises. The needs of SMEs need to be taken into account at all stages of policy making as they are a crucial part of our economy.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking introduces elements of improvement compared to the 2003 agreement which replaces it, but has two important critical elements, one of method and one of substance. Parliament's representative conducted the negotiations without any discussion in the committee responsible of the guidelines on individual chapters and questions of substance. This has therefore in fact been removed from its powers. Furthermore, the text of the agreement often contains vague and non-specific commitments, in particular on the introduction of greater transparency and on the issue of monitoring contacts between lobbyists and institutions. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking is yet another confirmation of the commitment of Parliament, the Council and the Commission to a clearer and more transparent legislative process. Better lawmaking will mean greater cooperation between the three institutions and will make it possible to simplify existing legislation by avoiding over-regulation and the resulting administrative burdens for citizens, administrations and businesses, including SMEs, by ensuring that the objectives of the legislation are achieved. Legislative proposals will be accompanied by impact assessments that will support the legislative process with the aim of improving and rationalising existing and future legislation. I welcome the text voted on in plenary because it is aimed not only at speeding up the decision-making process but also at drawing up more comprehensible and clear legislation for European citizens.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We vote in favour of the report and welcome the agreement reached between the institutions. It is a good basis for developing a new, more honest and transparent relationship between them with a view to improving legislation for the benefit of the citizens of the Union.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted on the conclusion of an interinstitutional agreement on better regulation between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. This process is, in theory, about trying to improve, rationalise and speed up the Union's legislative procedures, which has been an objective for several years. In reality, however, I fear that under the cover of "better regulation" the neoliberal deregulation may in some cases be hidden. That is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it represents a renewal, in my opinion effective, compared to the previous Interinstitutional Agreement of 2003. It has been a long process of important negotiations between the Council, the Commission and the European Parliament, which, in my opinion, has achieved important objectives such as avoiding over-regulation and up-to-date and simplified legislation which in turn has led to better interinstitutional relations. I also voted in favour because this agreement is a clear commitment by the institutions to observe the general principles of Union law, to promote simplicity, clarity and coherence in the drafting of Union legislation and, above all, to promote maximum transparency in the legislative process, all of which I believe are fundamental to simplifying the whole of legislation by making it more comprehensible and clear. , thus enabling citizens, businesses and administrations to understand their rights more easily and avoid excessive administrative burdens.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission published on 19 May 2015 its Better Regulation package, including the draft proposal for an interinstitutional agreement (IIA) on better regulation (also referred to as the IIA on better lawmaking). This IIA will replace the existing 2003 interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking and the 2005 interinstitutional common approach to impact assessment, and will oversee working practices between the Council, the European Parliament and the Commission. Mr Verhofstadt was mandated to conduct the negotiations, working in close cooperation with JURI and AFCO. Negotiations between the Council, Commission and EP on the IIA were completed in December 2015, and endorsed politically by the Conference of Presidents on 16 December. The agreement covers three main areas: better regulation; interinstitutional relations; and legislative processes, including programming and delegated and implementing acts. In the draft report, the EPP rapporteur, Danuta Hübner, recommends the approval of the draft interinstitutional agreement and of the related joint declaration. The draft report also contains an appreciation of some of the main provisions of the new IIA, calls for an examination of the extent to which amendments or interpretations of the Rules of Procedure are necessary for the implementation of the agreement and points to a number of issues where further follow-up is needed.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP today voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. UKIP is opposed in principle to the EU having any power of any kind to make and pass legislation, whether by way of Directive, Regulation or any other means which will have primacy over UK law and thus over-ride the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. Secondly, we do not believe that this interinstitutional agreement will alter in any way the profoundly undemocratic nature of the European Union in general or the European Parliament in particular. Thirdly we note that this document is, in terms, a singular and ringing indictment of the nature of the last 59 years of legislation by the EU and its predecessor organisations. The new agreement identifies with clarity the very real deficiencies in EU law-making which has placed so damaging a burden on the competitiveness and profitability of UK businesses, the vast majority of whom do not even do business outside the UK. For those reasons, we have voted against this agreement.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 The institutional architecture of the European Union is complex, largely reflecting the sui generis nature of this entity. This condition is reflected in the relationship between the three institutions of the legislative triangle: The Commission, Parliament and the Council. This interinstitutional agreement is part of the package of measures launched by the Commission in 2015 on Better Regulation, and focuses precisely in particular on the legislative procedure, the relationship between the institutions and legislation.  At the legislative level, this agreement aims to give greater transparency and flexibility to the whole process, to ensure fair cooperation between the institutions, in particular by ensuring parliament's role as co-legislator. It also wishes to comply with an idea advocated by the EPP and, in particular, by the candidate - now President - Juncker: that the Union be big on the big and small things in the small things. In other words, that it is always the level of power as close as possible to the voters to make the decision and, on the other hand, that the regulatory momentum does not translate into an unnecessary burden for citizens and businesses. I therefore support this agreement.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report, even if the result falls short of expectations. The Commission's ambitious proposal, according to which we would no longer only have talked about better regulation in Europe, but actually enforced it, was watered down in the triliog procedure. The opportunity for the signal to e citizens that the European Parliament is fighting against unnecessary regulations remains untapped. On the positive side, however, particular attention should be paid to the impact of legislative proposals on small and medium-sized enterprises. The rapporteur has taken up this important point, which is important for me, so that we will really be able to talk about cutting red tape here.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP today voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. UKIP is opposed in principle to the EU having any power of any kind to make and pass legislation, whether by way of Directive, Regulation or any other means which will have primacy over UK law and thus over-ride the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. Secondly, we do not believe that this interinstitutional agreement will alter in any way the profoundly undemocratic nature of the European Union in general or the European Parliament in particular.
