Thirdly we note that this document is, in terms, a singular and ringing indictment of the nature of the last 59 years of legislation by the EU and its predecessor organisations. The new agreement identifies with clarity the very real deficiencies in EU law-making which has placed so damaging a burden on the competitiveness and profitability of UK businesses, the vast majority of whom do not even do business outside the UK. For those reasons, we have voted against this agreement.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The last agreement in force on 'better lawmaking' was in 2003, when the European Union comprised only 15 Member States. The 'better lawmaking' package published by the Commission in 2015 and adopted politically at the end of last year allows the existing rules to be updated to the regulatory framework created by the Treaty of Lisbon. The agreement covers three areas: better regulation, the interinstitutional report and the legislative process, which includes programming, delegated acts and implementing acts. I voted in favour of Parliament's proposal for a decision because it will help to consolidate best practices and bring them into line with modern concepts of 'better lawmaking'.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Laws should address actual realities without making regulation burdensome on stakeholders. Overregulation, and laws that increase administrative burdens, greatly affect citizens and businesses, especially SMEs. Tools such as impact assessment, consultation processes and respect for principles of subsidiarity and proportionality are important for better law-making.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against this agreement, negotiated behind Parliament's back through the irregular appointment of the liberal group's head of row as its representative, because it is a tremendous democratic involution. Parliament has reduced its powers over the Commission, which will strengthen technocratic and neoliberal control over the legislative process. Moreover, the setting of quantitative targets for the reduction of legislation and the fight against 'overregulation' in the text are tools to reduce the harmonised protection enjoyed by European workers and citizens (as has already been demonstrated by REFIT), which is a disturbing development to which we must oppose it.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the complexity of the European Union's legislative process and the crisis of confidence we are currently facing, it is necessary to promote simplicity, clarity, coherence and transparency in drafting legislation, while preserving the importance of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. It is also appropriate for the three institutions to take into account the impact of its legislative and non-legislative initiatives, public consultation and stakeholders through feedback tools, and ex-post evaluation of the legislation in force.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission needed to be better. The Parliamentary report considers that the interinstitutional agreement contributes to re-establishing the relationship between the institutions and to establishing a more open and transparent relationship in order to better legislate in the interests of the citizens of the Union. An important element for the EP is that appropriate EU legislation also reduces the administrative burden on SMEs. Annex I to the report on the Interinstitutional Agreement contains the text of the Agreement. In its introduction, the three institutions recognise their joint responsibility to create high-quality EU legislation that can provide the greatest added value, be as effective as possible in achieving the common objectives of EU policies, be as simple as possible and avoid over-regulation. The agreement mentions the role and responsibilities of national parliaments in the Treaties. In the commitments and objectives section of the Agreement, it stated that the institutions respect the principles of Union law, such as democratic legitimacy, subsidiarity and proportionality, and legal certainty, in the exercise of their powers and in accordance with the procedures laid down in the Treaties.  The EU's annual and multiannual programme is central to cooperation. The three institutions agree that they need to cooperate more structuredly in order to assess the application and effectiveness of EU law.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Giving between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission is a decisive step forward in the area of relations between the European institutions constituting European law. Thanks to this agreement, these relations will further foster both faster legislative work and cooperation between the institutions in the law-making process itself. I voted in favour.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The new interinstitutional agreement recognises the need for a renewed commitment on the part of all three institutions involved in the legislative process (Parliament, Council and Commission) in order for better lawmaking efforts to be successful. This agreement outlines the phases of the policy cycle, including provisions such as better lawmaking tools, transparency, and implementation and simplification. I positively believe that the common commitment to promote simplicity, clarity and consistency outlined in this agreement is a positive step forward in ensuring better law-making. I voted in favour of this agreement as it will facilitate and allow a better and simplified application of EU law, including more transparency.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This report proposes to support the new inter-institutional agreement to improve working methods between the European Commission, Parliament and the Council. The aim of this agreement is to clarify and increase the transparency of the legislative process in order to make it more democratic. In Parliament, we call for more information for citizens to be made available in the negotiations between the European institutions. The agreement also plans to strengthen evaluations to better take into account the impacts, particularly in terms of financial cost, of the proposed legislation.  Supporting these objectives, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. This report aims to promote a policy of "better legislation" between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. In order to stop the bureaucratic machine that the European institutions can quickly become, it is indeed crucial not to have "more Europe", with ever more restrictive legislation, but a 'better Europe', which is pronounced only when necessary, and which does not burden existing national laws. Satisfied with the text's proposals, I voted in favour of it.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The current interinstitutional agreement is the first review of the legal rules of the game between EU institutions since 2003. At the same time, this legal language and form must effectively convey the political will that created it, and Parliament reinforces this with this report.  Better and more effective legislation should aim to avoid extreme over-regulation and under-regulation. It is therefore important that all parties involved can participate and be heard in the legislative process; not only the largest, but also the smallest, small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens.  The Hübner report provides an interpretation of the interinstitutional agreement in which the advocacy of SMEs is guaranteed; the provision of a legal form of political will follows from the binding nature of pre-decision impact assessments, and it is important for institutional actors to achieve a balance between delegated and implementing acts. However, the success of the interinstitutional agreement lies in its implementation.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. This proposal is a step in the right direction in that it improves Parliament's visibility and place in the European legislative process. The rules are simplified and Parliament has its rights to access documents and meetings, a prelude to the Commission's decision-making, put forward. As everyone knows, the nerve of war with finance is information: that of Members of Parliament for better legislative work, of course, but above all that of the citizens whose relays we are relaying. This is a real democratic issue.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I supported this agreement. I encourage any initiative to improve the planning, quality and transparency of the European legislative process. It is essential to strengthen public understanding of how the EU prepares its legislation, to develop a more open relationship between the institutions in order to achieve a better legislative process in the interests of all EU citizens. I am particularly sensitive to the impact assessments which are an indispensable step in the European legislative process and which should include not only the economic, environmental and social consequences of the planned legislation, but also, where possible, the competitiveness implications and red tape, taking into account in particular small businesses, digital aspects and territorial impact.  I am in favour of greater involvement by MEPs in the development of the EU's long-term priorities and for Parliament to consult on proposals that remove or simplify legislative projects.  Finally, I am also calling for greater transparency in informal tripartite negotiations, a register for "delegated acts" and a database on the state of the legislative projects.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This report multiplies good intentions for stakeholder dialogue, effectiveness of impact assessments and transparency. It is regrettable that no concrete measures are proposed to combat lobbying or to take into account the will of the people. For all these reasons, and being committed to the sovereignty of states, I voted against this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I supported Mrs. Hübner's report on the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making. I don't think it's exhaustive, and there's a lot more to achieve, but it's a good step in the right direction and needs to be supported. The bureaucracy is large, laws are still being worked on that create more problems and do not solve the problems of the average citizen and create difficulties for small and medium-sized enterprises, instead of revising existing legislation, the modernisation of which would be the best solution. One of my main tasks here in the European Parliament during this mandate is and will continue to be to monitor all proposals for legislation affecting SMEs, their functioning and successful existence, because they are the basis of the economy and the state of us depends on them.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote against, because during the negotiations the established practice in relation to the procedure in a committee of the European Parliament was not followed. It also grants super powers to the Commission.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The current interinstitutional agreement is the first review of the legal rules of the game between EU institutions since 2003. At the same time, this legal language and form must effectively convey the political will that created it, and Parliament reinforces this with this report.  Better and more effective legislation should aim to avoid extreme over-regulation and under-regulation. It is therefore important that all parties involved can participate and be heard in the legislative process; not only the largest, but also the smallest, small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens.  The Hübner report provides an interpretation of the interinstitutional agreement in which the advocacy of SMEs is guaranteed; the provision of a legal form of political will follows from the binding nature of pre-decision impact assessments. However, the success of the interinstitutional agreement lies in its implementation.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Parliament has repeatedly called for the 2003 interinstitutional agreement to be renegotiated in order to take account of the new legislative framework created by the Treaty of Lisbon, to consolidate current best practices and to update that agreement in line with the better regulation agenda. The Conference of Presidents adopted by a majority the interim agreement that had been reached between negotiators on the text of a new interinstitutional agreement on better regulation ('new IIA'). I therefore congratulate the agreement reached between the institutions, which is a good basis for establishing and developing a new, more open and transparent relationship between the institutions, with the aim of better legislating in the interests of the citizens of the Union.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. Voted against: no concrete measures envisaged to combat lobbying or take into account the interest and will of the peoples.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the idea behind the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking, between the Council, Parliament and the European Commission, is certainly to be welcomed, we unfortunately cannot be entirely satisfied with the way in which the agreement has been reached. The negotiator appointed by Parliament received a general mandate from the AFCO Committee without, however, having defined guidelines on individual chapters and on matters of substance. This has in fact left the negotiator a very wide margin of discretion, reducing the committee's prerogatives. On the substance, although the agreement reached has some appreciable aspects, it remains lacking in some respects: firstly, there is no guarantee of greater transparency in the trialogues, nor in delegated acts and in implementation. It is also regrettable that the question of the control of lobbyists and contacts between lobbyists and the institutions has not been addressed in practice. Finally, the opportunity to introduce a reference to the need for greater direct involvement of citizens in the decision-making process has been lost. For these reasons, since I am not fully satisfied with the agreement reached, I will refrain from approving this proposal for a decision of the European Parliament.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 The report approves the Interinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Council on better regulation. It's a negative deal for several orders of reason. We highlight three. First, the stated objective hides the interests that one intends to serve. The so-called "competitiveness" of enterprises becomes the first and absolute criterion in determining the opportunity and content of EU legislation. It is not the interests of SMEs that are intended to be defended. But those of the great capital, the great economic groups, the great powers. Even harder than so far. Social and environmental criteria, if any (little) thing could still contribute to improving the living conditions of workers and peoples, are now relegated to an even more secondary plan. Secondly, this agreement represents new and more serious limitations to the democraticity of the legislative and decision-making process. The door is open to a greater concentration of power in the European Commission and to limit the capacity of co-legislators to intervene, especially members. Thirdly, declarations of good intentions about "transparency" result in a handful of nothing. In the shadow they send the fatic powers. They're the ones who want to legislate better.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking, despite doubts as to how the negotiations were conducted. The agreement addresses key points of the issue, including references to PMI and competitiveness tests, impact assessments on substantive changes, maximum duration and review clauses, and a commitment to burden reduction. This agenda is a step in the right direction for informed, inclusive and transparent decision-making and the correct application of legislation.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ I welcome the cooperation agreement reached by the institutions to update and simplify legislation and exchange views in this regard, before finalising the European Commission's work programme. Significant progress has been made in the area of measures to improve the mutual exchange of views and information between the European Parliament and the Council. The measures in question should be further developed, in particular as regards mutual access to information and meetings, in order to ensure a genuine balance and equal treatment between legislators throughout the legislative procedure and to ensure that the principle of mutual sincere cooperation between the institutions is respected. We must also strive to improve political dialogue between the European Parliament and national parliaments in the future and to try to involve national parliaments more in political dialogue.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because the report contains conflicting and unclear elements.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the conclusion of an interinstitutional agreement on improving legislative work between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission, because during the negotiations the established practice in relation to the procedure was not followed in a committee of the European Parliament. It also grants super powers to the Commission.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe the interinstitutional agreement is balanced but we must continue to push for the cost of non-Europe (social, environment etc.) to be included in impact assessments. Moreover, we must continue to fight to protect the right of the legislator to decide, and for any regulatory targets to be assessed case by case in the legislation. I welcome the fact that social partner agreements are protected and will not be subject to impact assessments. Impact assessments are a tool to help not a substitute for political decisions within the democratic process, and must include social and environmental impacts as well as economic ones. I support the call for a commitment to more transparency in the legislative process by the Council. Finally, I would like to express my support for the agreement which will allow for better application of EU law, respecting agreements with social partners and more transparency.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. – I voted for the adoption of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making because it constitutes a good basis for building and developing a more open and transparent relationship between the EU institutions in the interests of Union citizens. I believe that the renegotiation and updating, in line with the 'better law-making' programme of the 2003 Interinstitutional Agreement, is necessary to take account of the new legislative environment created by the Lisbon Treaty to consolidate current best practices. The new interinstitutional agreement ensures that EU legislation focuses on areas where it has the highest added value for European citizens, that it is as effective as possible in achieving the general policy objectives of the Union, that over-regulation and administrative burdens for citizens, administration and businesses, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), are avoided. In this regard, it is important that the EP's call for the wording on impact assessments to fully engage the three institutions with the inclusion of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and competitiveness tests in their impact assessments.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. – The current interinstitutional agreement is the first review of the legal rules of the game between EU institutions since 2003. At the same time, this legal language and form must effectively convey the political will that created it, and Parliament reinforces this with this report. Better and more effective legislation should aim to avoid extreme over-regulation and under-regulation. It is therefore important that all parties involved can participate and be heard in the legislative process; not only the largest, but also the smallest, small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens.  The Hübner report provides an interpretation of the interinstitutional agreement in which the advocacy of SMEs is guaranteed; the provision of a legal form of political will follows from the binding nature of pre-decision impact assessments, and it is important for institutional actors to achieve a balance between delegated and implementing acts. However, the success of the interinstitutional agreement lies in its implementation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 The current interinstitutional agreement is the first review of the legal rules of the game between EU institutions since 2003. At the same time, this legal language and form must effectively convey the political will that created it, and Parliament reinforces this with this report. Better and more effective legislation should aim to avoid extreme over-regulation and under-regulation. It is therefore important that all parties involved can participate and be heard in the legislative process; not only the largest, but also the smallest, small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens.  The Hübner report provides an interpretation of the interinstitutional agreement in which the advocacy of SMEs is guaranteed; the provision of a legal form of political will follows from the binding nature of pre-decision impact assessments, and it is important for institutional actors to achieve a balance between delegated and implementing acts. However, the success of the interinstitutional agreement lies in its implementation.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report with the firm will to help the three actors responsible for European legislation – Parliament, the Commission and the Council – work more closely for more efficient legislation for European citizens. That is why I endorse the three main points of the agreement: promoting the improvement of legislation, respecting the general principles of EU law, such as the principles of democratic legitimacy, subsidiarity and proportionality and legal certainty, and the need for EU legislation to be understandable and clear.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Interinstitutional Agreement on the Improvement of Legislation which seeks to ensure that EU legislation best serves the interests of citizens and businesses. The European and Spanish Socialists are defending reducing the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, and strengthening close cooperation between institutions, in particular in the area of legislative programming. It is also essential that the new Agreement strengthens impact assessments of new initiatives and the cost of non-action at EU level is valued. Finally, this is the first time that a procedure has been established for the Commission to respond to proposals for acts coming from this Parliament.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I support the inter-institutional agreement on improving the quality of legislation that was concluded a few weeks ago, it is a text that improves the transparency and functioning of the EU and better involvement of the social partners. Among the points of particular importance of the agreement, I would like to highlight the guarantee that the impact assessments carried out by the Commission before a legislative proposal also include the consideration of social and environmental standards and also take into account the so-called 'costs of non-Europe', that is, the cost to citizens resulting from the delay in implementing common measures at EU level.  Indeed, I think it is important to include various measures of greater transparency in the Council's work, as well as greater control in the effective correct transposition of Community directives in the Member States.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the conclusion of an interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission, because I believe that the issue of the effectiveness of the European regulatory process and 'better lawmaking' is a key issue for regaining confidence in the EU on the part of our citizens and businesses. I share the position of the S&D Group, which supported the agreement negotiated by Parliament with the other institutions, an agreement necessary to adapt the EU legislative procedure to the Treaty of Lisbon and to guarantee the quality and programming of EU law while ensuring an equal role between the different institutions and therefore greater involvement of Parliament. I welcome the reference to the cost of non-Europe in the Commission's impact assessments as well as the need to take into account the social, environmental and labour effects of EU rules before they are adopted, because this is an important step in protecting the rights and interests of our citizens. Finally, I agree with the reference to the dimension of SMEs in the decision-making process and the link with the national parliaments, which are also called upon to play an important role in a Europe that legislates less but with higher quality.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The 'Better Regulation' instrument is an important tool for improving the EU legislative process, transposing legislation in the Member States and ensuring respect for the law under Article 258-260 TFEU. More transparency and openness to the needs of Union citizens is needed in order for it to work. To this end, a new interinstitutional agreement will be created, including a new better regulation agreement to ensure that EU rules are respected with the least administrative burden. It assumes that policy decisions will be developed and taken in an open and transparent manner, based on accurate information with the relevant participation of stakeholders.  The programme covers all legislative stages: planning, adoption, implementation, application and assessment of the impact of a given law. At each of these stages, specific rules and procedures would apply to ensure that the regulation in question is appropriate. It should be borne in mind that delays and irregularities in transposition and the incorrect application of EU law lead to inconsistencies between Member States and consequently have a negative impact on citizens. I therefore welcome the outcome of the vote, which underlines the need to continuously improve the EU legislative process.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. For citizens, businesses and administrations in the Member States, the bureaucracy is significantly reduced by selective, efficient and simple rules. In practice, this increases the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union's economy.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP today voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. UKIP is opposed in principle to the EU having any power of any kind to make and pass legislation, whether by way of Directive, Regulation or any other means which will have primacy over UK law and thus over-ride the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. Secondly, we do not believe that this interinstitutional agreement will alter in any way the profoundly undemocratic nature of the European Union in general or the European Parliament in particular. Thirdly we note that this document is, in terms, a singular and ringing indictment of the nature of the last 59 years of legislation by the EU and its predecessor organisations. The new agreement identifies with clarity the very real deficiencies in EU law-making which has placed so damaging a burden on the competitiveness and profitability of UK businesses, the vast majority of whom do not even do business outside the UK. For those reasons, we have voted against this agreement.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The current provisions date back to 2003 and were in need of revision. I welcome the fact that impact assessments will take social and environmental – as well as economic – factors into account. Other good aspects include the commitment to enhanced transparency in the law-making process.  The institutions calling on Member States to ‘clearly communicate’ to their public when implementing EU measures is valuable. In light of the UK referendum the benefits of EU membership do need to be articulated. People need to see us in this Parliament acting in their interest.  The onus is on national capitals to keep people abreast of developments at European level. There are, of course, other factors – such as how much of what we discuss in this place will get reported and in what way. This we cannot control.  Nonetheless, this agreement goes some way to allaying concerns about bureaucracy. It represents a step in the right direction if people can be better aware that this Parliament is on the side of citizens from Birmingham to Bucharest.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. It has been more than ten years since the Relevant European Institutions, the Commission, the Council and of course the European Parliament, have claimed to act to "better legislate": clear, simple, coherent legislation with real European added value, respecting the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality, based on serious and in-depth impact analyses, and regularly assessed on the achievement of its objectives. Very nice speech in truth, to which we can only subscribe, but which will remain a dead letter. The new agreement almost ignores the intervention of the lobbies, renamed in a less anxious way "stakeholders" and whose considerable, and not always benevolent, role they play in the drafting of European laws. He talks about transparency, but everyone here knows the difficulty of having access to important documents concerning the ongoing trade negotiations, access reserved for a few happy few and totally denied to non-registered Members. The practice of trilogue negotiations from the first reading, which aims at soft consensus at the expense of true democratic debate, is not in question. However, it often transforms the plenary into a simple recording chamber. I fear that European legislation will remain what it is: complex, bushy, prolific, often useless and too often harmful, alas.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted against it, since although there are improvements in terms of transparency and procedures, they are not sufficient. Moreover, behind certain sections which are committed to 'better regulation' there is actually a path to deregulation, which in the context of the macro trade agreement negotiations is a very high risk.  This report also gives the European Commission more legislative powers to the detriment of the European Parliament. Parliament is the only body directly and democratically elected by European citizenship, so giving the Commission more powers only deepens the current model of European institutional architecture, with a Parliament with hardly any legislative capacity, which is a democratic anomaly.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. Better to legislate, certainly, but while respecting a number of democratic principles. This is the meaning I wanted to give to my vote in favour of the resolution on the inter-institutional agreement "better legislate". Indeed, this agreement provides a good basis for the development of a new, more open and transparent relationship between the European institutions, in the interests of European citizens, in accordance with agreements with social partners.  In this debate, the Socialists and Democrats fought to demand that the cost of non-Europe - from a social, environmental, etc. - be systematically included in the impact assessments. These same impact assessments should be seen as a tool to assist in the decision, but under no circumstances will they be a substitute for political decisions taken in the democratic process.  We also call for more transparency on the part of the Council, whose meetings remain organised, for the vast majority, behind closed doors, in contrast to those of the European Parliament which are very largely public.  Finally, we call on the Commission to provide a more regular state of the implementation of legislation within the EU.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Part of its better regulation agenda, the aim is to design EU policies and laws so that they achieve their objectives in the most efficient and effective way possible.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Interinstitutional Agreement on the Improvement of Legislation which seeks to ensure that EU legislation best serves the interests of citizens and businesses. The European and Spanish Socialists are defending reducing the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, and strengthening close cooperation between institutions, in particular in the area of legislative programming. It is also essential that the new Agreement strengthens impact assessments of new initiatives and the cost of non-action at EU level is valued. Finally, I welcome the establishment for the first time of a procedure to ensure that the Commission has to respond to proposals for acts coming from this Parliament.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 The current interinstitutional agreement is the first review of cooperation between EU institutions since 2003 in order to consolidate and modernise current best practices. An agreement between the institutions must effectively convey the common political will that Parliament provides to the institutions through this report.  Better and more effective legislation should aim to avoid extreme over-regulation and under-regulation. It is therefore important that all parties involved can participate and be heard in the legislative process; small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens. The Hübner report provides an interpretation of the interinstitutional agreement in which the advocacy of SMEs is guaranteed; ensuring the legal form of political will is due to the binding nature of pre-decision impact assessments, and it is important for institutional actors to achieve a balance between delegated and implementing acts. However, the success of the interinstitutional agreement lies in its implementation.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Despite renaming and recasting, the agreement is still an extension of the program that is already in effect. Therefore, there is an excessive emphasis on 'excessive regulation and administrative burdens' throughout the text and not on 'quality in regulation'. We believe that the democratic process is not adequately safeguarded in the Report, that the impact assessments proposed must be broad and balanced and that there is a need for quality regulation and not deregulation. We have therefore abstained.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making. The IIA will improve the quality of European law-making. It calls for increased negotiations between the institutions and for the Commission to explain and justify its choice of legal basis and compliance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality when proposing legislative instruments. It also promotes transparency between Parliament, the Council and the Commission in proposing legislation by contributing better law-making tools such as impact assessments and appropriate handling of trilogues. Increased transparency amongst the institutions will lead to a more coordinated legal system within the Union and also makes the implementation of European law easier for the governments and judicial systems of the Member States. The IIA calls upon Member States to communicate clearly to their citizens when transposing Union legislation and distinguish additions that are in no way related to Union legislation as to avoid ‘gold-plating’, leading to greater harmonisation between the institutions and the citizens of the EU.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I believe this provides a good basis for developing a more open and transparent relationship between the institutions. This report also promotes the better lawmaking agenda which should be a vital part of the EU institutions’ approach to legislation in the coming years.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP today voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. UKIP is opposed in principle to the EU having any power of any kind to make and pass legislation, whether by way of Directive, Regulation or any other means which will have primacy over UK law and thus over-ride the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. Secondly, we do not believe that this interinstitutional agreement will alter in any way the profoundly undemocratic nature of the European Union in general or the European Parliament in particular. Thirdly we note that this document is, in terms, a singular and ringing indictment of the nature of the last 59 years of legislation by the EU and its predecessor organisations. The new agreement identifies with clarity the very real deficiencies in EU law-making which has placed so damaging a burden on the competitiveness and profitability of UK businesses, the vast majority of whom do not even do business outside the UK. For those reasons, we have voted against this agreement.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I believe that we need this agreement which will allow for better application of EU law, respecting agreements with social partners and more transparency.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament on the conclusion of an Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission, as I believe it is necessary to improve the legislation in order to make it effective and effective in achieving the political objectives of the Union.  It is also necessary to avoid administrative overload for citizens and businesses, and to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the European economy. In this context, transparency of the process is very important in order to increase citizens' trust in the European institutions, involve the European Parliament in negotiations on the conclusion of new international agreements, improve coordination between the Council and Parliament, and encourage regular comprehensive impact assessments to determine what the real situation is.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report aligns the need for ongoing dialogue among stakeholders, wishful thinking on the role and effectiveness of impact assessments, and unfulfilled promises about transparency. No concrete measures are envisaged only to combat lobbying or to take into account the interest and will of the peoples. It is an internal kitchen, completely self-centered, without consistency.  When we see how the TAFTA negotiations are going, the promises of transparency make you want to laugh yellow. When we know the weight of lobbies with the Commission, the commitments to assess the impact of legislation through impact studies sound wrong. When we see the devastation of the directives already in place every day, we have little confidence for the future.  The report does not question anything, does not reveal the shadow of the slightest criticism of the system. Nothing positive comes out of it. Its reading therefore leads to only one conclusion: the legislative power must be restored to the peoples of the Member States and we must stop blowing wind at great expense to their detriment. I logically voted against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP today voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. UKIP is opposed in principle to the EU having any power of any kind to make and pass legislation, whether by way of Directive, Regulation or any other means which will have primacy over UK law and thus over-ride the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. Secondly, we do not believe that this interinstitutional agreement will alter in any way the profoundly undemocratic nature of the European Union in general or the European Parliament in particular. Thirdly we note that this document is, in terms, a singular and ringing indictment of the nature of the last 59 years of legislation by the EU and its predecessor organisations. The new agreement identifies with clarity the very real deficiencies in EU law-making which has placed so damaging a burden on the competitiveness and profitability of UK businesses, the vast majority of whom do not even do business outside the UK. For those reasons, we have voted against this agreement.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: Writing. \u2012 The Interinstitutional Agreement wants to ensure more transparent and functioning legislation, in particular by increasing the emphasis on the results of impact assessments in the legislative process. Parliament will also have an enhanced role in comitology consultation procedures. The new agreement will strengthen cooperation between the European institutions, improve regulation in the EU, allow for greater flexibility and reduce the administrative burden on our companies. I think this is the Right Union's response to citizens' declining confidence in the European institutions, and I believe that greater LEGISLATIVE TRANSPARENCY for the EU can only have a positive effect for all concerned.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Danuta Maria Hunner's report on the conclusion of the inter-institutional agreement 'Better Regulation' between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission.  This agreement between the main EU institutions aims to improve the planning, quality and transparency of the European legislative process. I support this agreement which aims to improve the quality of European legislation and to strengthen citizens' understanding of this legislative process. For example, impact assessments will be widespread and will now take into account red tape. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of the Inter-Institutional Better Legislation Agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. The agreement focuses on three different areas of better regulation, inter-institutional relations and legislative procedure. This agreement is a good basis for the development of a more open and transparent relationship between the European institutions. It also promotes a better legislative agenda. I believe that it is necessary to make the European Union clearer, more transparent and coherent for our citizens and this report contributes to this.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report. Although it contains very fundamental proposals for improvements to the legislative process, interinstitutional cooperation, transparency, the review of the need for new laws and regulation, more far-reaching measures should have been proposed.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it will allow for better application of EU law, respecting agreements with social partners, and for more transparency.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 The current interinstitutional agreement is the first review of the legal rules of the game between EU institutions since 2003. At the same time, this legal language and form must effectively convey the political will that created it, and Parliament reinforces this with this report.  Better and more effective legislation should aim to avoid extreme over-regulation and under-regulation. It is therefore important that all parties involved can participate and be heard in the legislative process; not only the largest, but also the smallest, small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens.  The Hübner report provides an interpretation of the interinstitutional agreement in which the advocacy of SMEs is guaranteed; the provision of a legal form of political will follows from the binding nature of pre-decision impact assessments, and it is important for institutional actors to achieve a balance between delegated and implementing acts. However, the success of the interinstitutional agreement lies in its implementation.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The effort to cope with ‘burdensome’ regulation is accentuated within the context of the Juncker Commission Agenda. It is well known that administrative burdens have a negative effect on citizens and businesses, in particular on small and medium-sized enterprises.  Under this scope, the present report deals with the proposed interinstitutionnal agreement between the Commission, Parliament and the Council, in which they recognise their joint responsibility in providing high-quality Union legislation and present their commitment in order to pursue mutual consultations and exchanges of views.  However, my major concern is related to the overemphasis of the agreement on tackling the ‘overregulation’. The risk is to disorientate the notion of quality regulation towards complete deregulation. In order to express this concern, I decided to abstain.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. – The Better Regulation Agreement aims to improve the way the EU legislates and to ensure that EU legislation provides a better service to citizens and businesses. Another important objective, with which I fully agree, is to make the EU legislative process even more transparent, open to contributions from stakeholders and easier for non-experts to follow. The provisions of the new Interinstitutional Agreement are intended to continue to promote informed, inclusive and transparent decision-making. I would also like to stress that measures to improve the mutual exchange of views and information between Parliament and the Council represent a great step forward. I have chosen to vote in favour because the framework outlined shows that the three European institutions are fully aware of the importance of more open dialogue, fair and transparent cooperation, in order to legislate better in the interests of the citizens of the Union.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I approved the report by my EPP colleague Danuta Hunner on the conclusion of the inter-institutional agreement 'Better Regulation' between the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, drawn up in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, of which I am a member. This report aims to reinforce the idea that the action of the European institutions must focus on what is useful to citizens. In keeping with our campaign commitments, we support the action plan launched by Jean-Claude Juncker and Frans Timmermans, whose idea is to "less regulation to better regulate". We also call for a better upstream account of SMEs in impact assessments or greater transparency in national transposition mechanisms to avoid 'overtransposition', a practice too often implemented by many Member States at the expense of the image of the EU, which is responsible for normative inflation in the eyes of citizens.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The inter-institutional agreement must facilitate work between the three institutions that make European law (the Council asks for a text, the Commission drafts it, proposes it, and then Parliament and the Council vote on it). Without asking the question of the very content of texts that increasingly promote competition and call for more austerity, an agreement facilitating cooperation between institutions may seem logical. However, the "better legislation" in the Commission's language is all too often summed up not to legislate when it comes to social progress or the defence of workers, and above all to leave an ever greater place to interest groups and ever more upstream. The consequence is a Commission that is increasingly attentive to the lobby, especially on the very opportunity to legislate, which kills any social initiative, and which relies on them to co-write certain texts. Suffice to say that the rules already define the meaning of laws before they are even considered by citizens' representatives. This inter-institutional agreement may contain some positive elements, notably on transparency, but I have refused to support a text that aligns itself with managerial procedures for law and the interests of the largest Brussels lobby.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted against the report on the inter-institutional agreement "Better Legislation". This report aligns the need for ongoing dialogue among stakeholders, wishful thinking on the role and effectiveness of impact assessments, and unfulfilled promises about transparency. No concrete measures are envisaged only to combat lobbying or to take into account the interest and will of the peoples. It is an internal kitchen, completely self-centered, without consistency.  When we see how the TAFTA negotiations are going, the promises of transparency make you want to laugh yellow. When we know the weight of lobbies with the Commission, the commitments to assess the impact of legislation through impact studies sound wrong. When we see the devastation of the directives already in place every day, we have little confidence for the future.  The report does not question anything, does not reveal the shadow of the slightest criticism of the system. Nothing positive comes out of it. Its reading therefore leads to only one conclusion: the legislative power must be restored to the peoples of the Member States and we must stop blowing wind, at great expense, to their detriment.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it advocates "better lawmaking", dialogue and transparency in an incantatory way, without daring to solve the real problems.  Thus, it does not provide for anything concrete to combat lobbying, nor to improve the transparency of the TAFTA negotiations, nor to take into account the will of the European peoples.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted AGAINST this report. Indeed, far from questioning the weight of lobbies on the European Commission, the covert negotiations of the TAFTA (transatlantic free trade agreement) or the disastrous consequences of the directives in place, he proposes the creation of studies of the impact of legislation, the dialogue between the European institutions. It therefore does not call into question the problems associated with this excessive standardization policy.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Interinstitutional Agreement on the Improvement of Legislation which seeks to ensure that EU legislation best serves the interests of citizens and businesses. The European and Spanish Socialists are defending reducing the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, and strengthening close cooperation between institutions, in particular in the area of legislative programming. It is also essential that the new Agreement strengthens impact assessments of new initiatives and the cost of non-action at EU level is valued. Finally, I welcome the establishment for the first time of a procedure to ensure that the Commission has to respond to proposals for acts coming from this Parliament.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted against this agreement, negotiated behind Parliament's back through the irregular appointment of the liberal group's head of row as its representative, because it represents a tremendous democratic involution. Parliament has reduced its powers over the Commission, which will strengthen technocratic and neoliberal control over the legislative process. Moreover, the setting of quantitative targets for the reduction of legislation and the fight against 'overregulation' in the text are tools to reduce the harmonised protection enjoyed by European workers and citizens (as has already been demonstrated by REFIT), which is a disturbing development to which we must oppose it.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The ordinary legislative procedure is not characterized by a rapid process. That is why the European Union is making efforts to coordinate its institutions and achieve more synchronized and less bureaucratic legislation. The parties to this interinstitutional agreement are the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Council of the European Union. These three institutions will exchange views on their priorities and objectives for the coming legislatures. Similarly, they should be agreed to draw up an indicative timetable. One of the measures taken in that report would be for the European Parliament and the Council, as co-legislators, to maintain close contacts at a pre-interinstitutional phase. Thus, a greater understanding of their respective positions would be generated. On the basis of the above, I support this report as it will contribute to the synchronization of legislative proposals and the implementation of a fully harmonised legal framework.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. There are only empty words in the proposal about the need for greater transparency, prudity, democratic legitimacy, etc. when drafting legislation. It is false to claim that 'the Treaty of Lisbon entrusts an important role to national parliaments'. Better legislation will not be brought about by the new method, which would only bring restraint in legisating and respect for democratic will in individual Member States, so that eu proposals are not completely disconnected from the reality and common sense of ordinary people.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ On 19 May 2015, the European Commission published a package for better regulation of legislation, including a draft proposal for an Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making (IIA). This proposal will replace the existing 2003 Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Legislation and the 2005 Interinstitutional Common Impact Assessment Approach, which will oversee working practices between the Council, the Commission and Parliament. The agreement covers three main areas: better regulation, interinstitutional relations and the legislative process, including the programming and implementation of acts. The agreement calls on the Commission to produce a detailed report on the demands of Parliament and the Council within three months, and to explain if it does not, so I supported this report.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 On 9 March, my Colleagues in the European Parliament approved by 516 votes in return 92 votes against and 95 abstention votes in the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making. The agreement between Parliament, the Council and the Commission aims to improve the way the European Union creates legislation. The tools for improving legislative activity at European level are clearly listed: (1) systematic impact assessments and public consultation, experts and all stakeholders; (2) reducing the administrative burden and the so-called over-regulation for citizens and businesses (especially for small and medium-sized businesses); and (3) more transparency and coordination in interinstitutional negotiations. I welcome the commitment made by the three institutions to cooperate in order to modernise, simplify and ensure more transparency in the trilogue negotiation process.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing \ u2012 I support the conclusion of a new Better LawMaking Agreement, which replaces the original 2003 Agreement. Lawmaking is a continuous and, above all, complex process that has to respond flexibly to objective social conditions and needs. In addition to the important principles of consensuality and consistency of procedures, I consider it necessary to simplify the whole process and make it more efficient and understandable to the public. The lawmaking process must always take into account the reduction of administrative burdens and the non-increase of costs for legal entities. Such improvement, streamlining and transparency of the law-making process can lead to better acceptance of the applicable law and thus reduce its violations.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the report on the conclusion of an interinstitutional agreement on better regulation between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 8/3/2016 and because this report is not complete.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this agreement. This incondictable and contemptuous report is more a matter of the internal kitchen of the European institutions than of a negotiation. Parliament, the Commission and the Council decide among themselves to set up more dialogue, without a concrete or even realistic proposal. It advocates more transparency, while denying Members access to certain TTIP documents, more objectivity, without fighting lobbying, and better representation, regardless of the interests and will of the peoples. Nothing positive emerges from this report.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of concluding an interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. This Agreement lays down the general principles and arrangements for cooperation between those institutions, in particular during the legislative process, with the aim of improving the drafting and application of Union law. Through this agreement, the institutions will be able to better coordinate the legislative process, improve transparency and accessibility of information for citizens and produce clear, simple and effective legislation.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Transparency in our role is crucial. As the only EU institution directly elected by the citizens, we have a clear responsibility to our constituents. Improving legislative procedures is now more important than ever in affirming European values. I therefore voted in favour of this agreement.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: in writing. U2012 I welcome the agreement between the Community institutions to improve the planning, quality and transparency of the legislative process. We will improve public understanding of how the EU makes its laws and also the quality of new and updated EU legislation.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: In writing. The functioning of the European institutions is very complex, which is why greater transparency is needed. Naturally, the original flaw in this operation is the lack of legislative initiative of the European Parliament. But the introduction of this missing piece to the institutional puzzle calls for a revision of the treaties that member states are blocking in the immediate future.  The inter-institutional agreement (Commission, Council, Parliament) concluded on 8 December is a small step towards greater transparency in the decision-making process and greater participation by the European Parliament, but which should be supported. Parliament and the Council will be consulted on the development of the Commission's annual work programme, Parliament will be consulted as soon as the Commission wishes to withdraw a legislative proposal, and as soon as the Council wishes to change a legal basis, which is currently in the legislative process. Parliament has also been granted systematic access to meetings of experts, Commission and national experts.  The report approves this agreement as a good basis, adds requests for evaluation, and above all reminds us that the Council must be subject to the same transparency requirements as the other two institutions. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 We have made many efforts in the past to adapt and revise the 2003 Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Regulation between the Commission, the Council and Parliament with a view to its harmonization with new practices. Issues that need to be addressed include the quality of the bills by the Commission, the planning, the carrying out of more detailed assessments of the impact of the proposals for laws, the achievement of a better balance between the two legislative bodies of the Union, better access to information and a more extensive examination of Parliament's proposals in conjunction with the full justification of any rejection or withdrawal. I therefore believe that the conclusion of an interinstitutional agreement will lay the foundations for better and more effective cooperation between the institutions and will have the ultimate beneficial effect of upgrading the legislative process in the interests of European citizens. At the same time, however, Parliament's legislative powers must be ensured and any possibility of its side-by-side should be ruled out. Finally, the main objective of the new interinstitutional agreement will be to improve the legislative process through the proper application of the rules of law, more complete information and information for stakeholders and more efficient and transparent cooperation between the three institutions.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the conclusion of the Interinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the Commission on better law-making. The main objective of this Interinstitutional Agreement is to make the legislation developed by the EU institutions comprehensible and clear, to enable citizens, administrations and businesses to easily understand their rights and obligations, to establish appropriate requirements and to avoid excessive regulatory and administrative burdens, to be put into practice.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report for better regulation and inter-institutional dialogue between the European institutions in the decision and law-making process.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It is not even tempting to be lulled by the singing tomorrows of this report. We would like to legislate better, but it seems to involve at least two things in terms of the current situation. First, put the lobby groups in step, because they are, at least, at the starting point of legislative initiatives. I believe above all in a second time that the bias they instill obstructs reality. For it is not a question of remaining the prostrate gaze on studies presented by courtiers. It is the responsibility of politicians to take into account the reality of the world. What about the disastrous consequences of most population directives, other than that they denote a pedagogy and ultraliberalism on a forced march.  As a result, I have spoken out against this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Better regulation means legislative simplification, with the aim of promoting certainty and legal certainty. I have voted in favour of the conclusion of the interinstitutional agreement, which is fundamental to the functioning of a legislative machine which is sometimes too complex.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I support this agreement because, since the Treaty of Lisbon has created a new legislative environment, there is a need to consolidate current best practices between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union, and the Commission, and bring this agreement up to date.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. It was time to renegotiate the 2003 inter-institutional agreement to take account of the new legislative environment created by the Lisbon Treaty, to consolidate existing good practices and to update the agreement in accordance with the Better Legislation programme. On the one hand, we have focused on strengthening democracy by improving transparency and, on the other hand, reducing bureaucracy. This quality agreement is a strong signal to work better together, respecting our skills. As such, impact assessments will allow us to assess the quality of EU legislation on a regular basis. Finally, I would like to reaffirm the importance I attach to political dialogue with national parliaments.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: writing – Open and transparent relations between the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council of the EU and their effective cooperation is an essential prerequisite for the proper institutional functioning of the Union and for the development of quality legislation that responds sufficiently to the needs of European citizens. I welcome the new agreement on better law-making reached by the three institutions at the end of last year, because I believe that it will contribute to the overall streamlining of the legislative process, better governance and more interactive interinstitutional relations. These are crucial for the management of a meaningful trilogue, for further consultation and for reaching agreements, in particular in the multiannual interinstitutional planning and adoption of related measures. I also see the importance of these elements in the practical application of better law-making tools such as public and stakeholder consultation, impact assessment of European legislation, cost assessment in its implementation for producers, workers, final consumers or the environment, etc.). Solid relations between the institutions are an important aspect in communicating with member states' authorities, national parliaments, mutual exchange of information and good practices between them. From the point of view of EU citizens, it is desirable that the lawmaking process be of good quality, sufficiently coordinated and, above all, does not present an increase in administrative burdens in key sectors.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report for the interinstitutional agreement on Better law-making because it will allow for better application of EU law, respecting agreements with social partners and more transparency, which is essential.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament has repeatedly requested the renegotiation of the 2003 Interinstitutional Agreement in order to take account of the new regulatory environment created by the Treaty of Lisbon. The negotiations on a new interinstitutional agreement on improving regulation, formally opened on 25 June 2015, were successful on 8 December 2015: negotiators from the three institutions reached a conditional agreement on the text of the new Interinstitutional Agreement on Improving Regulation, which was approved by the Conference of Presidents on 16 December 2015. In its report, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the draft agreement. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. This report aligns the need for ongoing dialogue between the parties between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. This report does not present any concrete measures to combat lobbying and to take into account the interests of the people. It is without any consistency. When we see the negotiation procedures within the framework of the TAFTA and the lack of democratic respect for them, we can only worry that no criticism will come out of this report. We are voting against this report which opposes the only real solution against the technocratic tyranny of Brussels: to return legislative power to the people.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. Parliament welcomed the opening of negotiations for a new interinstitutional agreement on better legislation and set out a number of priorities, notably as regards the quality of the Commission's legislative drafting, multiannual and annual programming and to strengthen the impact assessment of draft legislation. I voted in favour of this report mainly because I believe it is essential that the three institutions recognise their joint responsibility to provide the Union with high-quality legislation and to ensure that this legislation focuses on the areas where it can bring greater added value to European citizens. I also believe it is important that more efficient legislation be adopted to address citizens' daily problems, and the EU should focus on concrete areas that improve the quality of life of its citizens and businesses.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text deals with the conclusion of the inter-institutional agreement "Better Legislation" between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission.  The report does not call into question the undemocratic functioning of the current European legislative process: no tool for direct citizen participation, no brakes or control over-regulation of our SMEs and citizens, no increased control over lobbying activities with the Commission and the various EU bodies, no demand for transparency in the negotiations of international agreements - notably absent , the scandal of the concealment of TAFTA working papers - no reassurance of the crucial role of national parliaments. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the conclusion of an agreement that will replace the 2003 inter-institutional agreement. In particular, I support the provisions to put in place more transparency in national transposition mechanisms in order to avoid as much as possible the over-transposition of European directives, which harms economic sectors in certain states such as, for example, French agriculture.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for the institutional better-legislate agreement reached with the Council and the European Commission. The agreement must improve regulation, institutional relations, and legislative procedures. In addition, I find the responses provided by the Commission and the Council to the concerns we have raised satisfactory.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Close cooperation between the three leading institutions, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, is essential for the effective functioning of the European Union. Their number one joint responsibility is to ensure high-quality EU legislation, all in such a way that the legislation is simple and clear, respecting the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. I consider it essential to ensure full transparency of the legislative procedure, as well as the development of an effective dialogue between the three institutions.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement accompanies several past agreements and declarations on better law-making. I have voted for this report on better law-making that will take into consideration the general principles of EU law, such as democratic legitimacy, subsidiarity, proportionality, legal certainty and transparency throughout the legislative process.

name: Dan NICA
text: in writing. \u2012 I stress the importance of the provisions of the new Interinstitutional Agreement on Instruments for Better Regulation (Impact Assessments, Public Opinion and Stakeholder Consultation, Assessments, etc.) for a decision-making process based on good information, inclusive and transparent and for the correct application of legislation. I believe that impact assessments should be comprehensive and balanced and should assess, inter alia, the costs incurred by producers, consumers, workers and managers and the environmental costs that are generated by the failure to adopt the necessary legislation. The SME impact assessment should be included in the impact assessment reports and we ask the Commission to provide further information on this practice. The three EU institutions agreed to cooperate in updating and simplifying legislation and to exchange views on this before the Commission's work programme is completed. Task reduction targets in specific sectors should be carefully assessed on a case-by-case basis, in close cooperation between institutions, focusing on the quality of legislation and without undermining relevant Union standards. This agreement will allow for better application of EU law, respecting agreements with the social partners and ensuring greater transparency.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report because I believe that the good relationship and collaboration between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission underpins this Union, and improving them in the sense of openness and transparency will provide the means for better regulation, in the interests of all European citizens. In this respect, as the report proposes, the three institutions must continue to promote the most effective regulatory instruments, such as harmonisation and mutual recognition of decisions taken. This is indispensable for reducing excessive regulation and administrative burdens.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking, the benefits of which I consider to be, inter alia, the setting of common priorities for the Commission, the Council or the commitment of the institutions to open negotiations within 6 months on the form of practical measures to inform the EP of the negotiation of international treaties. I also consider it beneficial to make a new obligation for the EP and the Council to carry out an impact assessment of the changes adopted in the legislative process, although it will still need to be clarified what range of changes this obligation will ensue. Considerable efforts will still need to be made to put the agreement into practice, but it is important that the basic framework is already in place.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Although the report contains, in principle, commendable proposals for improvements to the legislative process and interinstitutional cooperation, it does not go far enough with its proposals on many points. I abstained from voting on this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim of the agreement is to enhance the interinstitutional legislative process in order to ensure the EU's policy objectives and to avoid excessive regulation and administrative obligations for citizens and businesses alike.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. Legislating is not an easy job, but legislating for all 500 million Europeans in twenty-eight countries is certainly very difficult. This agreement has to do in particular with the understanding of the rules, with better collaboration between co-legislators, with the applicability of the legislation that we are going to pass, with the anticipation of the impact, on the one hand, and the cost of non-Europe on legislation, and with the account of SMEs, which are indeed eternal forgotten in many european regulations and policies. Institutions have technically very sophisticated gears, and the truth is that many European citizens sometimes see us as if we are installed in a distant galaxy. With this agreement, Parliament has lowered some of the barriers we have identified and successfully negotiated a broader and balanced approach to better regulation. And, with this aim of giveing the European Union the strongest possible legal framework, we will work.  That's why I supported the report.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that this interinstitutional agreement on better law-making will introduce more effective measures that will allow the achievement of ambitious polar objectives to be properly achieved and improve the quality of EU legislation. In particular, excessive regulation and administrative burdens for citizens and companies need to be reduced. In addition, it is essential that SMEs pay particular attention to the impact assessment. I believe that further efforts should be made to establish an appropriate mechanism to ensure greater direct participation of Union citizens. In order to increase transparency, a common binding and legally binding transparency register for lobbyists should be established.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP today voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. UKIP is opposed in principle to the EU having any power of any kind to make and pass legislation, whether by way of Directive, Regulation or any other means which will have primacy over UK law and thus over-ride the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. Secondly, we do not believe that this interinstitutional agreement will alter in any way the profoundly undemocratic nature of the European Union in general or the European Parliament in particular. Thirdly we note that this document is, in terms, a singular and ringing indictment of the nature of the last 59 years of legislation by the EU and its predecessor organisations. The new agreement identifies with clarity the very real deficiencies in EU law-making which has placed so damaging a burden on the competitiveness and profitability of UK businesses, the vast majority of whom do not even do business outside the UK. For those reasons, we have voted against this agreement.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the Better Regulation Agreement signed on 19 May 2015, which aims to replace the current Interinstitutional Agreement of 2003, will lighten the interinstitutional legislative process and make it even more able to respond to the needs facing the EU on a daily basis. I therefore welcome the understanding between the institutions and the simplification of legislation and say that I am voting in favour.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Planning, quality and transparency are essential elements of law-making process. I fully support the agreement between the EU institutions to clarify and communicate better to the public and the media how decisions are made at European level.
