A large part of my work and commitment as an MEP is to facilitate the information flow between EU level and my Member State, so that both citizens and businesses are aware of the benefits of the EU.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I support the proposal as this agreement will replace the agreements already in force in 2003 and 2005. The agreement will increase cooperation between the Council, Parliament and the Commission, leading to better legislative initiative and, therefore, to improve the quality of the legislation that we will adopt in the future. The negotiations between these three institutions have led to an agreement which, in my opinion, covers three of the most important areas: better regulation, interinstitutional relations and the implementation of legislation. Progress must be made in each of these areas, to what extent we want the European Union to function better. The report also covers some new procedural rules between these institutions that will facilitate cooperation, which I particularly welcome. In our group of deputies, we are particularly committed to the so-called SME test and transparency at national level, which goes beyond the requirements of European legislation. After compromises with other political groups and a satisfactory result, I also accepted the proposal.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the agreement reached and the need to repeatedly consider improving the transparency of the conduct in the legislative process. The services available in monitoring the creation of European legislation through online services when it comes to directives and regulations are clear and transparent with a view of the status of the legislative proposal, as well as the necessary information on deadlines and available substrates.  Delegated acts contribute to the functionality, efficiency, flexibility of Union legislation, which enables swift action in case of need, which was both very positive and applied at the very beginning of the Russian embargo on EU fruit and vegetables. Unfortunately, today the process of drafting legislation in the part of creating delegated acts is not yet at the level of transparency and simple accessibility that me Members of the European Parliament, as well as the citizens to which these acts relate, would like. That is why I support this agreement that a common functional register of delegated acts will be established by the end of 2017 at the latest, through which the information will be accessible in a user-accessible manner, with the aim of improving transparency, facilitating planning and monitoring all stages in the adoption of a specific delegated act.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report aligns the need for ongoing dialogue among stakeholders, wishful thinking about the role and effectiveness of impact assessments, and unfulfilled promises about transparency. No concrete measures are envisaged only to combat lobbying or to take into account the interest and will of the peoples. It is an internal kitchen, completely self-centered, without consistency.  When we see how the TAFTA negotiations are going, the promises of transparency make you want to laugh yellow. When we know the weight of lobbies with the Commission, the commitments to assess the impact of legislation through impact studies sound wrong. When we see the devastation of the directives already in place every day, we have little confidence for the future.  The report does not question anything, does not reveal the shadow of the slightest criticism of the system. Nothing positive comes out of it. Its reading therefore leads to only one conclusion: the legislative power must be restored to the peoples of the Member States and we must stop blowing wind at great expense to their detriment. I am, of course, voting against this indigent text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this decision in support of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking because I believe that a qualitative leap is needed during this period and that Europe needs to improve in many respects, one of which is certainly transparency in its legislative procedures. The Union is a machine that all too often does not tell the citizens what it is doing for them or that is all too often ineffective because of the cumbersome nature of its procedures. This agreement finally calls for greater transparency and a more important role for Parliament, the only institution that directly expresses the voice of the citizens. I also think it is important to include the cost of 'non-Europe' in the impact assessments, because it is worth remembering how much in many areas the European Union's action has saved citizens and businesses and that the lack of a common policy will lead us all to lose out, not only politically, but also, and above all, economically. I therefore support this agreement in the hope that Europe will once again become the dream of civilisation and solidarity that the founding fathers had in mind 60 years ago.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the new Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making, which foresees further interinstitutional negotiations and considers it a good basis for establishing and developing a new, more open and transparent relationship between institutions with a view to better law-making, better application of EU law and more transparency for the benefit of all Union citizens. Transparency and parity between legislation are key to achieving agreements and quality legislation more quickly in the areas that carry the greatest value for European citizens, and quality legislation reduces excessive regulation and administrative burdens for citizens, administrations and businesses, in particular SMEs, which contributes to strengthening the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union economy.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. The report approves the Interinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Council on better regulation — a negative agreement which we highlight three reasons for. The first, the stated objective hides the interests it intends to serve. The so-called "competitiveness" of companies becomes the first and absolute criterion in determining the opportunity and content of EU legislation. It is the interests of the large capital, the large economic groups and the major powers, not the interests of The SMEs, which are intended to be defended. Any social and environmental criteria that could, even if little, contribute to the improvement of the living conditions of workers and peoples are now seconded. The second reason concerns the new and more serious limitations on the democraticity of the legislative and decision-making process that the agreement promotes. The concentration of power in the European Commission is envisaged, restricting the capacity of co-legislators, including Members, to intervene. The third reason, the declarations of good intentions about "transparency" result in a handful of nothing.  We voted against it.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. - I welcome this report and fully support it. I am convinced that the agreement reached between the European Parliament, the Council and the European Commission on better law-making will contribute to a more open relationship between these institutions, with a view to the interests of union citizens. I welcome this step by Parliament, the Council and the Commission towards better law-making, but I would also like to recall that the European institutions still have a lot of work to do in this regard, as the law-making processes should be more transparent and simpler. Success in this process, as stated in the report, is hardly conceivable without close cooperation not only between the European institutions and without cooperation with the parliaments of the Member States, bearing in mind the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The Better Lawmaking Agreement aims to improve the way the EU legislates and to ensure that EU legislation provides a better service to citizens and businesses, seeking to make the EU legislative process more transparent, open to contributions from stakeholders and easier to follow. The 'Better Lawmaking' agenda covers the entire policy cycle: policy design and preparation, adoption, implementation, implementation, evaluation and review. Specific principles, objectives, tools and procedures will be defined for each stage of the cycle to ensure that the EU has the best possible regulation. I voted wholely in favour of approving this inter-institutional agreement.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that there is general agreement on the functioning within the European Union of a single interinstitutional agreement that would improve the drafting of legislation between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. I consider it necessary to provide for measures to improve the quality of legislative proposals put forward in particular by the European Commission. Similarly, the quality of the impact assessments of draft legislation and the equality of the two legislators throughout the legislative procedure should not be neglected. It is not acceptable to me that there should be any informal exchanges of positions within the legislative process of the European Union, which would create scope for non-transparent interinstitutional negotiations. I therefore unequivocally welcome the agreement, which will contribute to the development of more open and transparent relations between the Institutions of the Union, which will ultimately allow for better regulation, especially in the interests of the citizens of the European Union.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this institutional agreement, which will replace the 2003 agreement and provides for more democratic planning in the long term, a new database of planned EU legislation and more information for the press and the public on the negotiations between the various EU institutions. I am satisfied with the vote on this text because it will simplify procedures at European level, strengthen cooperation between Member States and institutions and, most importantly, make the Union more accessible to European citizens.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP today voted against the approval of a new interinstitutional agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission.  UKIP is opposed in principle to the EU having any power of any kind to make and pass legislation, whether by way of Directive, Regulation or any other means which will have primacy over UK law and thus over-ride the sovereignty of the United Kingdom Parliament. Secondly, we do not believe that this interinstitutional agreement will alter in any way the profoundly undemocratic nature of the European Union in general or the European Parliament in particular. Thirdly we note that this document is, in terms, a singular and ringing indictment of the nature of the last 59 years of legislation by the EU and its predecessor organisations. The new agreement identifies with clarity the very real deficiencies in EU law-making which has placed so damaging a burden on the competitiveness and profitability of UK businesses, the vast majority of whom do not even do business outside the UK. For those reasons, we have voted against this agreement.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the conclusion of an interinstitutional agreement (new IIA) between Parliament, the Council and the Commission on better legislation, highlighting the importance of the provisions of the new IIA on better legislating tools, such as impact assessments and consultations of citizens and stakeholders. From my point of view, this will contribute to a knowledgeable, inclusive and transparent decision-making process and to the proper implementation of legislation. I welcome this report for considering the 'annual burden analysis' provided for in the IIA as an instrument for clearly and transparently identifying and monitoring the results of the Union's efforts to avoid and reduce overregulation and administrative burdens. While Recognising that the measures agreed to improve the exchange of views and information between Parliament and the Council as legislators are a step forward, I agree that they should be further explored. In view of the foregoing, and also because I believe that the new IIA should be implemented seriously, so the commitments and deadlines set should be respected, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission are committed to fair and transparent cooperation throughout the legislative process. The three institutions recognise their joint responsibility in the task of empowering the Union with high-quality legislation and ensuring that such legislation focuses on areas where it can bring greater added value to European citizens; as efficient and effective as possible in achieving the Union's common policy objectives; that it is as simple and clear as possible and avoids overregulation and administrative burdens for citizens, administrations and businesses, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises; and designed to facilitate its transposition and practical implementation and to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union economy.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Interinstitutional Agreement on the Improvement of Legislation which seeks to ensure that EU legislation best serves the interests of citizens and businesses. The European and Spanish Socialists are defending reducing the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, and strengthening close cooperation between institutions, in particular in the area of legislative programming. It is also essential that the new Agreement strengthens impact assessments of new initiatives and the cost of non-action at EU level is valued. Finally, I welcome the establishment for the first time of a procedure to ensure that the Commission has to respond to proposals for acts coming from this Parliament.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the 'better legislation' inter-institutional agreement, which is an agreement between the European institutions to improve the planning, quality and transparency of the legislative process. As is often the case in this type of agreement, not everything is perfect. Nevertheless, given some progress, it was important that this text pass.  It is no secret that I have never been a great advocate of impact assessments, which can be a danger to the freedom of political decisions. Fortunately, this text responds favourably to my fears by clearly specifying that these analyses "do not replace the political decisions taken in the democratic decision-making process". I am also pleased to note that the agreement mentions that legislative updates and simplifications should not interfere with the objectives of the legislation. It was indeed unacceptable for me to simplify legislation by undermining the rights of European workers.  Among the negative points is the lack of agreement to create a common, mandatory and legally binding transparency register for lobbyists. I regret this all the more because I voted in favour of this register in plenary and I will not hesitate to do the same again in the future.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the interinstitutional agreement on better law-making. I see it as a really good compromise. The objectives set out therein for multi-annual legislative programmes, an impact assessment of the legislation already adopted, the reduction of administrative burdens on Member States and businesses, and the wider conduct of public consultations, cannot be at disapproval.  The only thing I have missed in this document is the commitment of all three institutions to report publicly annually on the real results of these objectives. I am convinced that it would be very interesting for politicians or political analysts, but also for all European citizens to know how much of the scope of EU legislation on their lives has changed over the years, how much has been reduced or increased by the european acquis of the famous 80,000 pages. This would be an important tool for increasing citizens' confidence in the European Union.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this report, which provides for an agreement between the three main institutions of the European Union, namely Parliament, the Council and the Commission, with the aim of improving the planning, quality and transparency of the European legislative process.  For example, the three institutions are committed to carrying out more comprehensive and balanced impact assessments of EU legislation. An analysis of the impact on SMEs and regions, but also with regard to competitiveness and red tape, will need to be provided, in addition to the existing analysis of the economic, environmental and social impacts. In addition, the institutions have committed to including in these new analyses the costs of 'non-Europe', i.e. to know how much it would cost to have 28 different national laws or no legislation at all, rather than having common European legislation. I supported this report because it provides for MEPs and ministers to be more involved in the development of the EU's long-term priorities. The three institutions also decided to make informal tripartite negotiations, known as "trilogues", more transparent, in particular through clear and joint communication after the agreements.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted against it, since although there are improvements in terms of transparency and procedures, they are not sufficient. Moreover, behind certain sections which are committed to 'better regulation' there is actually a path to deregulation, which in the context of the macro trade agreement negotiations is a very high risk.  This report also gives the European Commission more legislative powers to the detriment of the European Parliament. Parliament is the only body directly and democratically elected by European citizenship, so giving the Commission more powers only deepens the current model of European institutional architecture, with a Parliament with hardly any legislative capacity, which is a democratic anomaly.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. The agreement aims to create an open and transparent relationship between the three institutions. I hope that this will lead to better regulation, something that benefits all citizens of the Union. That is why I support the agreement.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against this agreement, negotiated behind Parliament's back through the irregular appointment of the liberal group's head of row as its representative, because it is a tremendous democratic involution. Parliament has reduced its powers over the Commission, which will strengthen technocratic and neoliberal control over the legislative process. Moreover, the setting of quantitative targets for the reduction of legislation and the fight against 'overregulation' in the text are tools to reduce the harmonised protection enjoyed by European workers and citizens (as has already been demonstrated by REFIT), which is a disturbing development to which we must oppose it.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2003, the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council concluded the Better Regulation Agreement with the aim of improving the way the EU legislates and ensuring that regulation meets the needs of society and businesses. With today's report, the better regulation agreement is being revised and updated. The proposal concerns, in particular, the common commitment of the three institutions to promote the simplicity, clarity and coherence of Union legislation, the strengthening of cooperation between the institutions and the use of better lawmaking instruments, such as impact assessments and public consultations of all interested parties and national parliaments. It also contains references to the importance of assessing the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises during the legislative cycle and the commitment to reducing administrative burdens. Although I believe that the agreement lacks ambition, I believe that this report is a step in the right direction for clearer and more transparent European legislation, so I voted in favour.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing ‒ I see the importance in the provision of a new interinstitutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on better law-making on better law-making instruments. These tools include, for example, impact assessment or consultation with the public and stakeholders. I therefore voted in favour of this decision.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I have decided to abstain from this report, and this reasoning for voting comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the new interinstitutional agreement is intended to address the problematic points raised by the European Parliament's Committee on Constitutional Affairs. It will be an appropriate basis for establishing and developing new, more open and transparent interrelationships between these institutions, enabling better law-making in the interests of Union citizens. The EU institutions have reached a cooperation agreement with a view to updating and simplifying legislation and exchanging views in this regard, before finalising the Commission Work Programme. The agreed measures to improve the mutual exchange of views and information between Parliament and the Council as legislators represent a step forward, but these measures should be further developed, in particular as regards mutual access to information and meetings, in order to ensure a genuine balance and equal treatment between legislators throughout the legislative procedure, and to ensure that the principle of mutual sincere cooperation between the institutions is respected. The agreement highlights the important role of national parliaments, which can participate positively in political dialogue and should also make better use of the existing subsidiarity and proportionality mechanisms and be more flexible within the eight-week period that national parliaments have to issue a reasoned opinion on non-compliance with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In 2003, the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission concluded an interinstitutional agreement on better law-making. Over the years, the legislative environment has changed, in particular the Treaty of Lisbon, and new negotiations were launched in 2015 in order to modernise the agreement and integrate best existing practices into it. In December 2015, the Conference of Presidents approved the interim agreement reached by the negotiators of all three institutions on the text of the new interinstitutional agreement. They have jointly committed themselves to promoting simplicity, clarity and consistency in the drafting of legislation, while advocating full transparency in the legislative process. The agreement also addresses tools for better law-making and, in particular, impact assessments. In February 2016, the Committee on Constitutional Affairs adopted a report on the conclusion of this agreement. The report presents a balanced assessment of the agreement, which provides a good basis for further cooperation between the institutions with the aim of ensuring better law-making, in the interests of EU citizens. In any case, this new interinstitutional agreement is based on the assumption that legislation is essentially a source of burdens and difficulties, and on the assumption that the EU's main problem is over-prescribing. However, we should draw attention to the real problem: bad political decisions. Because of the above, I did not support the report in plenary, but I abstained.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing ‒ in order to ensure the proper functioning of the Union, its legal acts must be clear and comprehensible, allowing for an easy understanding of the rights and obligations of its citizens. This is also a top priority of the new inter-institutional agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. Cooperation between the European institutions at lawmaking level is directed towards legislation that is not excessive and ensures that unnecessary administrative burdens are removed.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒In 2012, Parliament has repeatedly called for a renegotiation of the 2003 Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making in order to take into account the new legislative environment created by the Lisbon Treaty, bring together current best practices and modernise the agreement in line with the better law-making agenda. I welcome the results of the negotiations on multiannual and annual interinstitutional programming, the Commission's response to Parliament's legislative initiatives and the presentation of justifications and consultations on the envisaged withdrawals of legislative proposals. I would point out that the agreed strong focus on the Commission's Work Programme cannot be understood as justification for any restriction of Parliament's legislative powers or its right to initiative. The three institutions reaffirmed their commitment to make more frequent use of legislative recasting technique to amend existing legislation in full compliance with the Interinstitutional Agreement of 28 November 2001 on a more systematic use of the method for recasting legal acts. If the recast is not appropriate, the Commission, in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement of 20 December 1994 entitled 'Accelerated working method for formal codifying of legislative texts', will submit a proposal as soon as possible following the adoption of the amending act. Also, the three institutions committed to promote the most effective regulatory instruments, such as harmonisation and mutual recognition, in order to avoid excessive regulations and administrative burdens and meet the objectives of the Treaties. That's why I supported the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which proposes changes in annual and multiannual programming, which will give the Parliament more say in the process. This report demonstrates a commitment to more transparency in the legislative process, especially on behalf of the Council.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the new legislative environment created by the Lisbon Treaty, bringing together current best practices and modernling agreements in line with the Better Law-Making Programme are key factors in creating as effective and adequate legislation as possible within the European Union. Parliament has set out several important priorities that contribute greatly to the start of negotiations on a new Interinstitutional Agreement. These priorities include better quality of drafting legislative acts in the Commission, multiannual and annual programming, improving impact assessments of draft laws, an equal relationship between the two branches of the legislature during the legislative process on access to information, appropriate interinstitutional consultations, the Commission's handling of Parliament's proposals and recommendations, and detailed justifications for any envisaged withdrawal. Furthermore, the Agreement lays a stable foundation for the establishment and development of a new, more transparential and open relationship between the European Parliament, the Council of the EU and the European Commission, with a view to better drafting legislation for the benefit of EU citizens. I support my colleague Hübner's report on the conclusion of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. I believe that cooperation between the three EU institutions in the field of legislation is of great importance and has an important impact on everyday life in the EU.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement on better lawmaking. It is a step in the right direction and I will work hard, along with Conservative colleagues, to ensure the agreed text is put into practice.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The Better Regulation Effort (REFIT) is a process in which our group has repeatedly expressed its opposition, because instead of better legislation the Commission is moving towards reducing enterprise legislation. This pushes wage and social rights downwards at the same time as taxation of large companies is falling. Moreover, the procedure initiated for the adoption of the report did not provide for any right to amend it, which is completely undemocratic. For the above reasons we voted against the report.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – The codification of European legislation involves good cooperation between the main Community institutions, Parliament, the Council and the Commission. Even when disagreements arise between the three actors, there are mechanisms for dialogue to reach a mutually acceptable solution that takes into account the interests of the Member States and European citizens. The interinstitutional agreement provides the framework for this dialogue in appropriate parameters. The old agreement, adopted in 2003, was up to date in December 2015 without major changes. However, it is necessary to further protect agreements with the social partners and also to amend impact studies to include social, economic and environmental dimensions, together with the regulation of areas not currently included in the European legislative pillar. In this respect, the European Parliament must have a harder word to say in the field of annual and multiannual programming, and the Council's legislative procedures must become more transparent. Member States may apply the Directives as close as possible to existing national legislation, but the application of the Directives must be monitored by the Commission. The current agreement is an important step forward and deserves to be supported.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The better regulation agenda was one of the key topic during the election campaign and with the final agreement, we are about to deliver on it, as promised to the Czech people. Better regulation and administration burden reduction is the essential tool if the Europe wants to find the path the growth and competitiveness again. It is of paramount importance that it delivers results. It will definitely improve the way the EU regulates and its impact on European businesses and first of all SMEs. That is why I very much welcome the conclusion of this inter-institutional agreement, which was one of our priorities during this mandate, and I appreciate the fact that our Group was the leading one throughout the negotiations. Some elements are lacking, but crucial points such as better impact assessments, more transparency and the creation of an Annual Burden survey are present. If correctly implemented, this agreement will improve EU regulation and decrease the administration burden for our businesses.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. \u2012 It is absolutely essential for the European Union to have clearer, more comprehensible and therefore closer rules to its citizens. Reducing over-regulation and bureaucracy is necessary in order to achieve a better functioning of the European institutions, but this must not result in a reduction in basic protections for citizens and businesses. This report also rightly underlines the role of the national parliaments with which we need to continue a constant political dialogue. The agreement between the institutions to cooperate with the aim of updating and simplifying legislation and to exchange views on it before the Finalisation of the Commission's work programme is very important. We are now following up these commitments.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report because there is no doubt that better law-making must become a key objective of the European Parliament's action. It is worth supporting the agreement already concluded between the Union institutions on cooperation aimed at simplifying and updating the existing legislation. This is a good step towards meeting the expectations of these Citizens of the Union, who have been dissatisfied with the unclear procedures and complex legal definitions that have made EU legislation unfriendly to citizens. It is also necessary to recall the need for the EU institutions to use more often political dialogue with national parliaments, which will undoubtedly strengthen the subsidiarity and proportionality mechanism in the legislative process.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. The report on the conclusion of the Interinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on better law-making, as I believe that the agreement is a good basis for establishing and developing a new, more open and transparent relationship between the institutions. I am convinced that this cooperation will ensure better law-making in the interests of union citizens.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted against it, since although there are improvements in terms of transparency and procedures, they are not sufficient. Moreover, behind certain sections which are committed to 'better regulation' there is actually a path to deregulation, which in the context of the macro trade agreement negotiations is a very high risk. This report also gives the European Commission more legislative powers to the detriment of the European Parliament. Parliament is the only body directly and democratically elected by European citizenship, so giving the Commission more powers only deepens the current model of European institutional architecture, with a Parliament with hardly any legislative capacity, which is a democratic anomaly.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The report stresses the need for ongoing dialogue between stakeholders, the role and effectiveness of impact assessments and the obligation to transparency, healthy but totally out of step with reality. No concrete measures are envisaged to combat lobbying or simply to take into account the public interest. The report does not question anything, does not reveal the shadow of the slightest criticism of the system. At the time of the TTIP negotiations, it is quite funny to see such a text under consideration.  So I voted AGAINST this democratic sham.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament has repeatedly requested the renegotiation of the 2003 Interinstitutional Agreement in order to take account of the new regulatory environment created by the Treaty of Lisbon, to consolidate current best practices and to modernise the agreement in line with the Better Regulation Agenda. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted against it, since although there are improvements in terms of transparency and procedures, they are not sufficient. Moreover, behind certain sections which are committed to 'better regulation' there is actually a path to deregulation, which in the context of the macro trade agreement negotiations is a very high risk.  This report also gives the European Commission more legislative powers to the detriment of the European Parliament. Parliament is the only body directly and democratically elected by European citizenship, so giving the Commission more powers only deepens the current model of European institutional architecture, with a Parliament with hardly any legislative capacity, which is a democratic anomaly.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in this report because although this new IIA is much better than the original COM proposal, it is still based on the consideration that legislation is, by its essence, a source of burdens and problems. I do not support the idea that the main problem of the EU nowadays is overregulation.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: Writing. – I welcome the agreement reached by the institutions and believe that this agreement is the right basis for identifying and developing new, more open and transparent relations between them, so that legislation is better for the citizens of the Union.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the conclusion of the inter-institutional agreement on better law-making representing an agreement among Parliament, the Council and the Commission to improve the planning, quality and transparency of their law-making. The agreement aims to strengthen co-operation between the European institutions, in order to deliver more transparent and workable legislation, particularly by better taking into account the results of impact assessments in the legislative process. It targets both enhancing public understanding of how the EU makes its laws and improving the quality of new and updated EU legislation.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about an important agreement which will replace the existing 2003 interinstitutional agreement on better regulation and the interinstitutional best practice agreement between Council, Parliament and Commission 2005. The agreement covers the three most important areas: better regulation, interinstitutional relations and legislative processes, including programming, delegated acts and implementing acts. This agreement has been reached after a great deal of negotiation and consensus between the parties, so I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Interinstitutional Agreement on the Improvement of Legislation which seeks to ensure that EU legislation best serves the interests of citizens and businesses. The European and Spanish Socialists are defending reducing the administrative burden on citizens and businesses, especially SMEs, and strengthening close cooperation between institutions, in particular in the area of legislative programming. It is also essential that the new Agreement strengthens impact assessments of new initiatives and the cost of non-action at EU level is valued. Finally, I welcome the establishment for the first time of a procedure to ensure that the Commission has to respond to proposals for acts coming from this Parliament.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: Written. The N-VA delegation has serious reservations about the way in which the interinstitutional agreement was reached. This largely happened behind closed doors. The delegation considers that this does not benefit the basic principles of better regulation at all. Moreover, the negotiator's mandate for the European Parliament was discussed only to a very limited extent. The N-VA delegation considers that this undermines the democratic content of the European Parliament. The text voted on is a decision of the European Parliament, in response to the IIA. The N-VA is pleased that it has succeeded in adding to this text some essential observations such as a clear objective of reducing taxes, the independence of the body to assess the impact of certain legislative proposals and a reference to the SME and competitiveness test (two essential tools for assessing the impact of legislation on small businesses and competition). The inclusion of these important points is the decisive factor for the N-VA to support this text, which precedes the IIA.  For the N-VA, better regulation is of exceptional importance: only acting at European level where necessary, creating simple and easily applicable rules and no administrative burden.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. I voted in favour of this Interinstitutional Agreement. This agreement aims to improve the interinstitutional legislative process and to reduce both over-regulation and red tape for citizens and businesses as much as possible.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This stated objective hides regrettably the interests that are intended to be served. The so-called "competitiveness" of enterprises becomes the first and absolute criterion in determining the opportunity and content of EU legislation.  And it is not the interests of SMEs that are intended to defend themselves, but rather those of the great capital and the large economic groups of the great powers, and even more so far. Social and environmental criteria are now relegated to an even more secondary plan. Moreover, this agreement represents new and more serious limitations to the democraticity of the legislative and decision-making process. The door is open for a greater concentration of power in the European Commission and to limit the capacity of co-legislators to intervene, especially members. Finally, statements of good intentions about "transparency" result in a handful of nothing. In the shadow, they send the fatic powers.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Fundamental improvements relate to the legislative process and cooperation or work between the EU institutions Parliament, the Commission and the Council. There is more transparency, there should be a stricter review of whether new laws are needed, etc. But we should and should have gone further. Again, an opportunity was wasted. Nevertheless, the 'Community method' was strengthened, and so was centralism. In this respect, abstention is the best option.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on the conclusion of an interinstitutional agreement on better regulation between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission. Improvements are urgently needed in the area of better regulation. The report takes up important positive points. However, there is still plenty of room for further improvement. However, better regulation will not solve the fundamental problem of the EU regulating far too much. The principle of subsidiarity is only held up verbally, but neither Parliament, nor the Council nor the Commission actually lived through the actions of either Parliament.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to thank my Labour colleague for his work on this report, and reiterate my own position: Very often, our colleagues on the right use ‘better-law making’ or ‘better regulation’ as coded jargon for deregulation, liberalisation, austerity, and the scrapping of important social policies.  Socialists and Democrats, and all those who want to see a more social and more equal Europe will never let such a misuse of language stand. Better law-making and better regulation must include a social perspective: how to create a society where social inclusion is advanced, equality is promoted, and fundamental rights are upheld. Often, the absence of laws and legislative initiatives only serve to perpetuate ongoing exclusion or stalemate.  We must use the opportunity of fresh commitment to better law-making to move towards a strong social Europe.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The aim of the institutions of the European Union is to establish a modern and for the benefit of citizens a framework of rules. In this direction we must all work towards improving the relevant legislative work. This report strengthens cooperation between the European institutions and improves the common legislative process.  I voted in favour following the example of my colleagues in the committee responsible for constitutional affairs.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: in writing. I believe that this report is very positive, as it reduces bureaucracy and thereby speeds up all processes and decision-making, which will be very positive for the optimal functioning of the EU. There is now an excess of laws in the Union, the degree of detail of which in some cases is too high and, instead of contributing to the agility of decision-making processes and good governance, this excess ends up slowing down EU activity. Through the formal adoption of the Interinstitutional Agreement, the legislative activities of the European Union will be much more coordinated and therefore their effectiveness will be much greater. This will certainly be very beneficial for all citizens and I therefore support this report.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ I supported the report on the conclusion of the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making. In addition to the fact that the old interinstitutional agreement was concluded in 2003 and therefore needed updating, I was also convinced by the fact that the agreement is mainly aimed at simplifying legislation and towards the overall objective of clearer, more consistent legislation and a more transparent process for its creation. At the same time, the report also talks about better and strengthened cooperation between the Commission, Parliament and the Council. From the outset, I have been adc and support all efforts to achieve less complicated European Union law, less frequent but, in turn, better and clearer legislation and a more transparent legislative process, as well as avoiding unnecessary new rules before the previous legislation is properly implemented and evaluated. I therefore hope that this agreement will also help achieve the objectives of better lawmaking, and I consider it the right step forward.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Hübner report because I believe that this agreement is a good basis for establishing and developing a new relationship between the European institutions, which is more open and transparent, with the aim of better legislation in the interests of the citizens of the European Union. The agreement aims, on the one hand, to provide the European Union with high-quality legislation and seeks to focus on areas where it can bring greater added value to society, avoiding overregulation and administrative burdens for citizens, administrations and businesses, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises. Furthermore, the legislation is intended to be designed to facilitate its transposition and practical implementation and to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union economy. I would stress that the socialist group has fought for safeguarding the integrity of the social partners' agreements, which includes their exclusion from impact assessment studies.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the Report on the conclusion of the Interinstitutional Agreement between the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union and the European Commission on better law-making.  The agreement reached between the institutions provides a good basis for establishing and developing a more open and transparent relationship between the institutions with a view to ensuring better law-making in the interests of Union citizens.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – When you look at the title of this report, which is about the agreement on tobacco products (the PMI agreement), you think that this PMI Commissioner is a small member of the EU's diversiated bureaucracy and stands for it. However, knowing the report, it turns out that this is Philip Morris International, a huge tobacco company. And it is clear from the report that the European Union also has a contractual relationship with four other tobacco companies. I have one piece of advice: in every EU country, including my country, Hungary, students who are about to graduate should show only this title, that it is an agreement between the European Union and Philip Morris International. And if you don't know why this is unacceptable, then you don't have the civic skills to get an education, you need to releath what it is to be transparent, what it is to be corruption, and so on.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, After studying all the documents, I have taken a restrained approach to this agreement. The documents at my disposal, at least, clearly show that the agreement that has already been here and on which we voted de facto today has clearly shown that, on the one hand, there has been a decrease in the number of philip morris products smuggled and counterfeit, but on the other hand, the number of smuggled and counterfeited 'white cigarettes' has risen immediately. In other words, the result of a general reduction in the illegal trade in tobacco products has not occurred. That is why I think we need to look for a different path, a more systemic path than just individual agreements with specific large producers, because it is quite clear that this does not break the market for illegal tobacco products. I therefore justify my reticence to the material on which we voted.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur It must be said that in my country , Latvia, the volume of smuggling and counterfeit tobacco products stopped growing every year. As if this is good, but on the other hand, it is clear that the poorest people are smuggling cigarettes in times of crisis and post-crisis crisis. That is clear. And the country here is powerless. Until we give them legal work, smuggling will increase. I would also like to join and regret the view that the Commission has been developing a technical evaluation for so long on the implementation of the Philip Morris International Agreement and the lessons learned. The report was published only on 24 February 2016, although it should have been published last May. But it is clear that the counterfeiting of tobacco products, in general terms, although it is illegal business, is thriving in some countries of the European Union. It is imperative that we draw up guidelines that will limit this illegal business. That is what I support.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the So far, there has been a treaty between Philip Morris and the EU. I believe that contracts of this kind should be avoided in principle. Firstly, because no money should flow. Secondly, because, in principle, the EU should not engage with individual companies. It's for everyone. The tobacco industry is trying to influence politics in various ways. We see this, among other things, in the arbitration proceedings, which this company – Philip Morris – is increasingly using in order to gain more influence over the concrete policy.  I believe that this must be stopped as a matter of urgency, and I am therefore very pleased that Parliament voted as it voted and ended this cooperation.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, the illicit trade in tobacco is causing losses of more than EUR 10 million per year in the European Union. It's our money, everyone's money, that we lose. In addition, the illicit tobacco trade contributes to the financing of international, cross-border organised crime, drug trafficking, children,people, weapons, and so on.m. As far as the Commission is concerned, I regret that it took him so long to present his technical assessment of this agreement with Philip Morris, and I hope that this will not be repeated in the future. I also call on the Commission to have transparent negotiations. Until now, anyone who wanted to see this extension of the philip Morris agreement had to do it in a secret, signature room without being able to write anything down. Let's be transparent, because it's about smuggling and it's about our money. I voted against extending this agreement with Philip Morris because it dates back to 2004. Since then, the world has changed. It's over twelve years! New means must be found to combat tobacco smuggling, counterfeit products and tax evasion.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 In July 2004, Philip Morris International and the EU signed an agreement to combat cigarette counterfeiting and smuggling. The initiative provided for wide-ranging procedures for product traceability and traceability, where the competent authorities could easily identify where authentic products were diverted from authorised sales channels. While it is true that the agreement has reduced cigarette smuggling, it is also true that the market and the regulatory environment have since changed, so the agreement with SMEs should not be renewed, extended or renegotiated. The Commission's commitment to the ratification of the protocol to combat smoking is undoubtedly an important step in tightening up tobacco legislation. For these reasons, I voted in favour, considering it essential for the EU to intervene in combating the practice of smuggling in order to protect the health of citizens.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: in writing. – We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it supports the necessary non-renewal of the agreement between the EU and Philip Morris International, while maintaining the need to act on tobacco smuggling and its associated problems. We share the need to act on tobacco smuggling because of the huge amount of taxes that Member States lose from their budgets. The multinational PMI is the great beneficiary of this smuggling that causes so many problems to both coffers and public health and it is therefore necessary to take action on the subject. But this bilateral agreement places a multinational, main beneficiary of smuggling, as a legitimate party to the public authority, this is what this resolution seeks to avoid. This is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. The vote on the "cooperation" agreement with Philip Morris is a great victory for us socialists and radicals, who spearhead the fight against the tobacco lobby in Europe. With this agreement expiring in July 2016, the question of renewal arose. On our initiative, the European Parliament has taken a stand against such a renewal of the agreement. The latter contravenes Article 5.3 of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which came into force in 2005 and is of which the European Union is a signatory. This article calls for minimizing interactions with tobacco manufacturers and ensuring full transparency. We offer other tools to effectively combat the illicit tobacco trade, such as traceability. On the other hand, we require that tobacco companies produce no more than the quantities absorbed by the legal market. The 700,000 premature deaths a year in the European Union deserve a relentless fight against these companies that flout public health and which - with millions of euros they divert from the Budget of Member States - finance an army of lobbyists to preserve their pensions and the remuneration of their shareholders.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Parliament has voted against extending the agreement to combat cigarette smuggling and counterfeiting with the tobacco company Philip Morris International, which I very much welcome. Beyond the fact that I cannot, in principle, endorse agreements with the tobacco industry, it is important to use existing international (the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control) and European (the EU Tobacco Directive) legal instruments in the fight against smuggling and counterfeiting of tobacco products.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This resolution, while imperfect, aims to end the existing agreement between the European Commission and the Philip Moris International consortium. These agreements aimed at combating the distribution of contraband cigarettes on the European market cannot be supported for the following reasons: despite the agreements, the European Commission reports large quantities of contraband; WHO calls for a strict minimum of government interactions with tobacco industries that require full transparency; the agreement is at odds with the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control signed by the 28 Member States and the EU, which requires that it be ensured that it is not influenced by the commercial and other interests of the tobacco industry in the development of public policy; for the sake of transparency. That is why I voted in favour of the joint resolution.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: in writing. We voted against renewing the tobacco agreement with the PMI tobacco company because, although it has contributed in principle to reducing the illegal tobacco of this firm by more than 85%, it has not served against new forms of illegal trade. The agreements, as signed in 2004, have not been able to respond to smuggling and continuing counterfeiting, where cheap white-label tobacco predominates today. The legal framework has also changed since the first agreement was approved more than ten years ago. At that time we did not have the legal instruments to be able to prosecute the main tobacco companies in justice. Fortunately, thanks to the Tobacco Directive and the WHO protocol we will be able from 2019 to legally pursue illegal tobacco from any producer. In order to avoid a legal vacuum, we call on the Commission to take action against the smuggling of white marks, to put in place all the measures necessary for the monitoring and location of PMI tobacco products, and to take legal action in the face of illegal seizures of products from this manufacturer.

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted the resolution preventing the renewal of the agreements signed in 2004 with Philip Morris. What's this all about? In exchange for EUR 2,150,000,000, the Commission and the Member States pledged to end legal proceedings against cigarette manufacturers over tariffs lost due to trafficking and smuggling, and subject to their commitment to combating these practices. However, these commitments are neither credible nor effective. On the other hand, the continuation of this kind of trafficking feeds criminal networks financially. Moreover, the tax shortfall as a result of these traffickings is estimated at EUR 10,000,000.000.  Therefore, continuing this agreement would have been outrageous nonsense. We put an end to it.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal not to extend the agreement with Philip Morris on cooperation in the fight against cigarette smuggling and to improve the application of EU and international anti-smuggling rules. In 2000, the European Commission and EU members brought cases against Philip Morris and several other tobacco manufacturers, accusing them of contributing to cigarette smuggling and obstructing the supervision of the tobacco industry by authorities. The cases were closed by agreements under which these companies committed to pay EUR 2.5 billion to the EU and its parties. and actively combat smuggling and counterfeiting of tobacco products. The agreement signed in 2004 with Philip Morris expires on 9 July this year. However, it was found that the agreement with Philip Morris was not effective as the reduced smuggling of original smokers was replaced by the smuggling of cheap 'white' cigarettes. I support the proposal to make more effective use of the new EU Tobacco Products Directive, which provides for measures to control and track the supply of tobacco products, as well as to ratify the relevant Protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. The Commission should present an action plan to combat the smuggling of low-cost 'white' cigarettes, and Philip Morris should continue to apply anti-smuggling measures, regardless of whether the agreement is extended.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. U2012 MEPs voted in favour of the Commission focusing on implementing the 2014 Community Tobacco Directive, which includes more effective instruments than the current PMI agreement to combat counterfeiting and smuggling, such as the monitoring and tracking system for cigarettes, starting in 2019. Member States should also ratify WHO's framework protocol on tobacco control, which provides for an internationally equivalent system. The signatory parties to the protocol are obliged to protect their public health policies from the commercial interests of the industry, and no responsibility in this area can be delegated to companies.  In order to cover the period when the provisions of the European Tobacco Directive are not yet applicable, we call on the Commission to prepare new rules to deal with the issue of cheap uncaught cigarettes, to monitor and localize and to initiate legal action in the event of apprehensions of cigarettes from that company. In this way we ended up with the current agreement that created some ethical problems, such as the use of some tobacco industry funds to finance the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) which could be a conflict of interest.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2004, the Commission and the Member States have negotiated agreements with tobacco producers in order to strengthen anti-smuggling and anti-counterfeiting measures. Under the agreements, producers should have collectively paid a contribution of EUR 2.5 billion, in return for the cessation of legal proceedings initiated against them by the EU and caused by the loss of revenue generated by the illegal cigarette trade estimated at over EUR 10 billion per year. Having serious doubts about the effectiveness of the agreement, I have today chosen to vote in favour of the joint resolution calling on the Commission not to renew the tobacco agreement with Philip Morris. The path followed by Europe must be that indicated by the EU Tobacco Directive 2014, which provides for more effective tools to combat smuggling, such as an EU cigarette traceability and monitoring system, in force since 2019.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. In this case Phillip Morris International, tobacco agreements were in place to close their eyes to their involvement in illegal tobacco circuits, in exchange for obtaining some collection based on the part of tobacco recognized by those same companies circulating on those circuits. We supported the GUE/NGL Resolution which required not only the cessation of these agreements but also elements of transparency and tough intervention. He didn't come out. However, a resolution has come out, which has also been supported, led by EFDD and Greens, which at least raises the completion of these agreements.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. I wanted to support the request not to renew the tobacco agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI), which expired in July 2016 and was established in 2014 to combat cigarette smuggling and counterfeiting.  In particular, I wanted to ask the European Commission to take responsibility for the transparency of its negotiations with the tobacco sector. In addition, questions are asked about the links that the Commission and OLAF have with tobacco companies. Considering that the EU wants to be a leader in tobacco control, including the WHO Framework Convention on tobacco control, the PMI agreement was in complete contradiction to the stated health ambitions. Finally, we reiterate our request to the Commission and the Council to immediately end its contacts with PMI or other tobacco manufacturers regarding a possible extension of the tobacco agreements and to refrain from concluding any similar agreements in the future; a common-sense request considering the potential for conflicts of interest and the need to preserve the independence of the bodies that are responsible for several areas of public services, including health.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution analysing the agreement to combat tobacco smuggling signed between the EU and Philip Morris International, while partly acceptable, does not offer concrete and clear solutions to overcome the period of regulatory vacuum that will be created between the end of this, in 2016, and the application of the new European legal framework that will enter into force from 2019. For these reasons, I have abstained.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The illegal tobacco trade calls into question public health policy against smoking by eliminating major disincentives for consumption, as well as representing a crime against the public treasury and a loss of more than EUR 10 billion per year in the EU in evaded excise duties on tobacco products. The EU and Philip Morris International (PMI) ratified an agreement in 2004 to combat more effectively cigarette fraud and smuggling that expires in July 2016. But since its signing, the legal framework has evolved radically and today we have powerful legal instruments to combat the illicit tobacco trade. The Tobacco Directive will allow for greater control of tobacco companies in the EU and a traceability system, and the WHO Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products will also enable illegal tobacco to be fought internationally.  I therefore voted in favour of this resolution which asks the Commission not to renew, extend or renegotiate the agreement with PMI after its current expiry date.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 In this resolution, the European Parliament examines the agreement of 9 July 2004 between Philip Morris International and its affiliates and between the European Union and its Member States on combating smuggling and counterfeiting. The main objective of the agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI) is to reduce the dominance of PMI product smuggling in the illicit EU tobacco market. The Technical Assessment of the Agreement with the PMI by the Commission concludes that this key objective has been effectively achieved, but that the smuggling of PMI products has not been substantially reduced in relation to illicit products on the EU market. The European Parliament notes that the tracking and monitoring system provided for in the Tobacco Products Directive should enter into force in May 2019. He stresses that the Commission must take immediate action to ensure full transposition of the Tobacco Products Directive in all Member States.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the resolution, which unequivocally campaigned against the extension of the tobacco agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI) and, in this spirit, also appealed to the Commission not to negotiate it. The so-called tobacco directive of 2014 provides effective tools for combating tobacco smuggling, and it is the task of the Member States to ratify as soon as possible the Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention (WHO) for Tobacco Control, which constitutes a similar international tool, which is expected to enter into force in 2022. An extension of the agreement, which would not actually be an extension but the opening of new negotiations on the agreement, would be contrary to both the efforts under the tobacco directive and the WHO guidelines. The fact is that the agreement currently in force is the result of the PMI-EU settlement concluded in 2004 following the judicial proceedings initiated by the EU against PMI in 2001. Therefore, opening the renegotiation of the agreement would be the wrong signal, as the circumstances have changed completely compared to those at the time.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Philip Morris' agreement partially fulfilled its purpose in reducing the access of contraband tobacco products on the EU market. But after 14 years the situation has changed and it is no longer in the interest of public health to have such an agreement with the tobacco industry.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the agreement with the SME should not be renewed because I am convinced that the benefits it brings are less than the positive aspects. Indeed, the causal link between the signing of the agreement and the reduction in the number of SME cigarettes smuggled into the European continent has not been demonstrated and, furthermore, the conclusion of this agreement would risk undermining the EU's leadership in the fight against smoking.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The illicit trade taking place at the union's borders endangers the stability of the single market, but also the rights that the European institutions have committed to ensuring to its citizens. This also applies to the tobacco industry, where the 2014 Tobacco Products Directive and the WHO Protocol already exist, which provide for identification and traceability measures and introduce security devices that facilitate the implementation of the law and are the best tools to combat illicit trade in the EU. In this context, I opposed the renewal of the Tobacco Agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI), given that its objectives are present in Union law, but also because the renewal of a special agreement with the tobacco industry would be inappropriate in the context of the EU's efforts to combat the impact that tobacco has on public health.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention. The EU has signed agreements with the four tobacco multinationals to actively contribute to the fight against smuggling. The first of these agreements was signed with Philip Morris International (SME) in 2004 and expires this year.  In its evaluation report, which was sent to Parliament very late, the Commission states that, although the agreement has helped to drastically reduce the smuggling of (questionable) SME products, the volumes of smuggling have not fallen at all. It is agreed that bilateral agreements with producers are an outdated instrument and, moreover, considered by the WHO to be the source of potential conflicts of interest.  According to anti-smoking organisations, the renewal, extension or renegotiation of the agreement would allow the tobacco industry to maintain control over traceability and traceability through Codentify, at a time when no independent safety assessment of the system has yet been carried out (which is an integral part of the agreement with SMEs).  But it is also true, on the other hand, that there is a risk of making the traceability systems already in place at national level useless, only to reintroduce them 'at EU level'.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. \u2012 The conflict between freedom and unlawful actions is ongoing. The European Union invests more than EUR 10 billion annually in the fight against crime, including the trafficking of contraband and counterfeit cigarettes. Moreover, I support my vote by stressing that the tobacco agreements are inconsistent with Article 5(2) of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. (3) of the WHO Framework Convention and do not correspond to Article 8(3) of the Whose Framework Convention. (12) of the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, which proves the possibility of a commercial interest in public health matters. I encourage the European Commission not to conclude contracts of any kind in the future if transparent cooperation between the parties is refused. Counterfeiting and illegal trafficking of tobacco products is worrying, as any product that is auctioned on the European Union market is verified and approved; on the other hand, there is no official information about counterfeit products, which means that their composition is unknown. This detail is extremely important for the health of the population as 700 000 Europeans lose their lives prematurely due to smoking every year.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Parliament has passed a resolution calling for an end to the agreement between the European Commission and the tobacco company Philip Morris. According to this agreement, the tobacco manufacturer pays a considerable amount of money to the Union to finance the fight against the illicit trafficking of tobacco products.  I believe that this agreement creates a conflict of interest. On the one hand, the European Commission must ensure the implementation of the anti-smoking directive and on the other it receives money from tobacco manufacturers. In addition, Philip Morris is challenging the anti-smoking directive, making it a questionable partner in the fight against tobacco trafficking. I am vehemently opposed to this agreement and I have therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the resolution tabled by S&D, Greens/EFA and EFDD to urge the European Commission not to renew the anti-smuggling and anti-counterfeiting agreement with Philip Morris, expiring in July 2016. I am deeply concerned that the budget of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is partly financed by the annual payments of the tobacco industry, as indicated in the agreements themselves, as this situation could lead to a conflict of interest. I have serious doubts as to the real effectiveness of the agreement with Philip Morris in reducing smuggling, because the increase in sales of non-branded cigarettes, the so-called 'cheap whites', immediately made up for the reduction in sales of counterfeit branded cigarettes. Rather than renewing the agreements with Philip Morris, the Commission should focus on implementing the 2014 Tobacco Directive, which provides for more effective tools to combat smuggling, such as an EU cigarette traceability and monitoring system, in place since 2019. Member States should also ratify a protocol adopted under the World Health Organisation Framework Convention to combat smoking, which provides for a similar requirement globally and is expected to enter into force in 2022.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I support this motion for a resolution as I believe that tobacco agreements with a particular company or any other tobacco manufacturers should not be renewed. Instead, the Commission should focus on ways to address the problem of illegal trade, counterfeiting and tax evasion in this area and on ratification of the WHO FCTC Protocol to Eliminate Illicit Trade in Tobacco products which would benefit our citizens to a far greater extent.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's commitment to the ratification of the protocol to combat smoking is undoubtedly an important step in tightening up tobacco legislation. For these reasons, I voted in favour, considering it essential for the EU to intervene in combating the practice of smuggling in order to protect the health of citizens.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Today’s vote is a positive signal. It is heartening to see a majority of Parliament see past big tobacco’s well-endowed lobby tactics that this deal has become a travesty. As the Commission (EC) contemplates a possible extension of the deal, we are facing litigious retaliation from Philip Morris, with an EU Court challenge against the EU’s review of the Tobacco Products Directive. And I find it astonishing that the EC maintains contact with its legal adversary on this very topic. I personally know of, and believe in, the Commissioner for Health’s commitment to fight the scourge of an industry whose product kills its customers but I very much fear that the officialdom in charge of trade policy will once again win the day. Member States and the EC have effectively outsourced key aspects smuggling and counterfeiting customs control to the industry itself, as part of a legal settlement over its misdemeanours, without subjecting the industry’s findings, which match its vested interests, to independent laboratory assessment. Public bodies need to be put back in charge of crucial aspects of public policy, and for these companies to be subjected to the same set of rules, not to special deals dating back to when they bought themselves out of court.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 There were various approaches to this report, as there was ambiguity. This proposal contains important positive elements, but it also contains several negative points.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the decision not to renew the agreement between Philip Morris International (SME) and the EU because this agreement was born to combat the smuggling of illicit products and for this reason I felt it was necessary to extend it.
