Indeed, I believe that renewal would not have led to inappropriate relations between the EU and the tobacco industry but, on the contrary, an important coalition in an attempt to counter a common enemy, smuggling, which directly affects the health of citizens and our economy. I also believe that the continuation of this agreement would have represented an important step forward in the fight against smoking, of which the EU is a world leader, in line with the position of the Italian Customs and Monopolies Agency, which points out that in the Italian case the agreement has in the past produced good results, particularly in the fight against smuggling.

name: David COBURN
text: in writing. ‒ We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ It is our obligation to intensify the fight against fraud and cigarette smuggling which contributes to the funding of other international organised criminal activities, including terrorism, and human, drugs and arms trafficking. Tobacco fraud is also a public-health concern, which poses an even greater health risk than genuine cigarettes. Progress registered should be sustained with further measures towards the continuous need to fight illicit trade, counterfeiting and tax evasion.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it supports the necessary non-renewal of the agreement between the EU and Philip Morris International, while maintaining the need to act on tobacco smuggling and its associated problems. We share the need to act on tobacco smuggling because of the huge amount of taxes that Member States lose from their budgets. The multinational PMI is the great beneficiary of this smuggling that causes so many problems to both coffers and public health and it is therefore necessary to take action on the subject. But this bilateral agreement places a multinational, main beneficiary of smuggling, as a legitimate party to the public authority, this is what this resolution seeks to avoid. This is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The mechanisms established by the Agreement on the Fight against Smuggling and Counterfeiting signed with Philip Morris International (PMI) in 2004 have proven to be effective against the theft of stolen products from PMI factories and the illicit sale of stolen products. However, it is noted that this agreement has not led to the overall reduction of contraband products on European markets, with the Union's border states frequently faced trafficking situations of tobacco products also called cheap whites. I would therefore like to draw attention to the importance of developing new mechanisms to combat the complete trafficking of counterfeit goods and cigarette smuggling.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The resolution on the tobacco agreement (PMI agreement) is prepared on the basis of oral questions from the political groups. There are currently four cooperation agreements between EU Member States: Philip Morris International (PMI), Japan Tobacco International (JTI), Imperial Tobacco Limited (ITL) and British American Tobacco (BAT). The PMI agreement expires in July 2016. The European Commission has continuingally edied the publication of the assessment on the PMI. The ECR Group therefore raised an oral question concerning, inter alia, the state of play and the timetable for the negotiations, and stressed that the European Parliament should be kept regularly informed. In particular, the European Parliament should be informed of the main results achieved under existing agreements with tobacco manufacturers and whether the Commission wants to renew current contracts or rather conclude new ones. The Commission's technical evaluation was not published until 24 February. In view of the main ideas contained in the document, namely the protection of the Union's financial interests, the contribution of the PMI to the fight against illegal trade in the past and the possible criminal consequences of smuggling, I supported this document in the vote.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The EU’s agreement with the tobacco manufacturer, Philip Morris International (PMI), was concluded in 2004 for a period of 12 years and its main aim was to tackle illicit tobacco trade. Although this core objective of the agreement has been met effectively, the reduction in PMI contraband products has not led to an overall reduction in the number of illicit products on the EU market. Since the Agreement was concluded, there have been significant changes to the market environment (the rise of illicit unbranded products – ‘cheap whites’ – which cannot be dealt with by this Agreement) and the regulatory environment, with the Tobacco Products Directive and the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control Protocol. Therefore, the added value to have such an agreement with PMI is questionable, and I voted against its renewal.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution aims to oppose the European Commission's decision to extend tobacco agreements, particularly with manufacturer Philip Morris.  As part of the fight against trafficking and counterfeiting, the European Union had signed agreements with four manufacturers, under which they agreed to pay the EU and Member States a total of $2.15 billion in exchange for the end of legal proceedings against them. Tobacco manufacturers have also pledged to implement measures against tobacco trafficking and counterfeiting.  Together with my colleagues in the French delegation of the EPP Group, I strongly opposed the extension of these agreements, considering on the one hand that a clear lack of transparency does not allow us to prove the effectiveness of these agreements, and whereas on the other hand, in view of the health issue related to cigarette consumption, the fight against trafficking and counterfeiting should be carried out at the level of the Member States and the European Union.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I objected to the extension and renewal of the agreement between the European Union and Philip Morris International (PMI). This type of agreement is, in my view, unacceptable because it amounts to delegating control of tobacco products to the tobacco companies themselves, which can lead to a risk of conflicts of interest.  In addition, these agreements contradict the Tobacco Directive adopted in 2014 and the World Health Organization (WHO) Framework Convention on the Control of These Products. Similarly, these agreements are seriously lacking in transparency.  I would also like to make it clear that the end of this agreement will not lead to a legal vacuum that undermines the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco products. Indeed, the protocol to combat the illicit trade in these products provides for very clear and effective provisions at both Member States and international level. The modalities for this protocol call for a five-year deadline for the implementation of an independent tobacco industry monitoring and traceability scheme, but these provisions can be put in place without delay.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. 'Parliament today gave a clear signal to the European Commission: the TOBACCO Agreement between the EU and Philip Morris International (PMI) should not be renewed, renewed or renegotiated.  The fight against illegal trade and smuggling in cigarettes must remain a priority, a fortiori for small countries with an open economy. The proceeds of this serious crime are used to finance other forms of organised crime. Moreover, illegal cigarettes usually do not meet product standards and are therefore even more dangerous to public health than legal products. Finally, illegal trade also causes a loss of revenue for the authorities of an estimated EUR 10 billion per year.  The Commission failed to make the added value of the agreement with PMI hard, and the transparency on this dossier leaves absolutely no hope.  The tobacco products directive (tracking and tracking system) and the Protocol to the FCTC Convention of the World Health Organisation provide the key instruments. The Commission and the Member States must make every effort to implement and ratify these two instruments as soon as possible. The Commission may, if necessary, make proposals to further strengthen the legal framework for the fight against illegal tobacco trade.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which opposes the renewal of a cooperation agreement concluded in 2004 by the Member States providing for compensation for the philip Morris tobacco company of $1.25 billion over a 12-year period.  This rejection is a victory. It is in line with Article 5.3 of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control (of which the European Union is a signatory) which calls for a strict minimum of interactions with tobacco manufacturers and full transparency. Not to mention that the cooperation agreement no longer corresponds to the new realities of the illicit cigarette trade. This is a strong signal to the tobacco lobby which continues to undermine the implementation of the EU Tobacco Directive (which is due to be implemented by 2016).  For the record, tobacco is the leading cause of death in Europe, with nearly 650,000 deaths each year. Passive smoking, despite the ban on smoking in public places in some EU countries, remains a scourge, with 19,000 deaths per year. Tobacco-related pollution also affects the planet. A cigarette butt takes about 12 years to decompose.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution asking the Commission not to renew the anti-trafficking agreement with Phillip Morris International, which is due to expire next July and involved the payment of EUR 1.25 billion to compensate the European Union and Member States for the tax shortfall resulting from cigarette smuggling and counterfeiting. On the basis of the information provided to us, I have serious doubts about the effectiveness of this type of agreement, which I also consider to be totally unethical. I would not want OLAF, whose operating budget is partly financed by payments from the tobacco sector, to be involved in a conflict of interest.  I therefore call for a clarification of the situation and, rather than renewing an agreement which poses many problems, I encourage the Commission to redouble its efforts towards the implementation of the 2014 Tobacco Products Directive, which provides for the introduction of a traceability and monitoring system by 2019. I also urge Member States to ratify the protocol to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which includes global provisions.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The agreement with Philip Morris International partially served its purpose, as there has been a significant decrease in the smuggling of goods into the EU since its conclusion. Moreover, there have been substantial changes in legislation: we now have the Tobacco Products Directive, which represents a Pan-European cigarette monitoring and tracking system from 2019 on the one hand, and the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control ratified by five Member States, on the other. Unfortunately, however, there has also been a significant increase in market share for unbranded cigarettes. We must focus on controlling the illegal trade and counterfeiting of tobacco products in the EU. The current situation in which the tobacco industry checks confiscated cigarettes in its own laboratories is not ideal, but until the TPD enters into force, there is no better solution. At least a check like this is still better than no check. Any loophole in the rules could serve as an open door for criminal groups. It is therefore our duty to ensure that illicit trade in tobacco products has no place at all in the EU, starting with active prevention and ending with sanctions of liquidation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This text calls on the European Commission to take responsibility for transparency. He denounced the fact that OLAF was partly financed by payments from the tobacco industry. The resolution also stresses that EU public health policies should not be influenced by commercial interests. For these reasons, I voted for this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the permission to open negotiations with Philip Morris International to extend the tobacco agreement. This Agreement expires in July 2016 and I am at all opposed to signing such an agreement in the future, as its benefits are not in practice clear enough. The European Commission does not provide Parliament with sufficient information on the objectives achieved. There is also a delay in our requests for such information. Since 2015, Parliament has been trying to obtain the technical evaluation of this agreement, but the Commission only published it in February this year.  I also do not support the fact that OLAF's budget is partly financed by the funds received from the annual payments from the tobacco industry.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote in favour. This motion for a resolution corresponds to reality, tries to cut off the Union's suspected links with tobacco companies and at the same time is interested in combating smuggling and the health of citizens.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Written. \u2012 The resolution highlights the problem of the current system and the fact that the Commission has been slow in providing Parliament with an evaluation of the agreements currently in force. It is important that we move as quickly as possible from a situation where we are building the fight against smuggling, counterfeit products and tax evasion on individual agreements with private companies to internationally comprehensive regulations that are equal for all. I would therefore like to see the Commission ensure that we leave these agreements as soon as possible and that the agreements in force in force are not to be renegotiated or renewed.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. An estimated 700,000 people die prematurely in the EU each year from smoking.  In addition to health damage, illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular smuggling and cigarette smuggling, causes the EU and its Member States to lose revenues of more than EUR 10 billion per year, and undermine the results of policies to combat smoking by increasing access to tobacco products, especially for young people and low-income groups. Member States and the EU have concluded agreements in which companies have committed to collectively pay US$2.15 billion to the EU and signatory states in order to combat illegal cigarette trade. The effects of these agreements are scarce. In view of the end of the period of validity of the agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI), secret and formal negotiations between the European Commission and the tobacco industry were known. The resolution calls on the Commission and the Council to suspend any further contact with PMI or other tobacco manufacturers for a possible extension of tobacco agreements and to waive other such agreements. We voted in favour.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the current agreement with Philip Morris International has been in force since 2004 and was originally due to expire in July this year. Its purpose is to combat and take common action against counterfeiting and illicit smuggling of tobacco products. The illegal trade in tobacco products is a serious problem. It contributes to the financing of various types of organised crime, including trafficking in human beings, drugs, arms and, according to several experts, to the financing of international terrorism. On average, one in 10 cigarettes in the European Union has been the subject of trade. As a result, Member States lose more than EUR 10 billion a year in tax collection. Falsified cigarettes using tobacco of uncontrolled quality pose a much greater risk to human health than original ones. Moreover, the lower price makes them more affordable for adolescents, whose statistics in terms of the number of smokers unfortunately are already on an upward trend. The European Commission's assessment of the results of the agreement showed that it also resulted in a not insignificant decrease in the incidence of smuggled PMI products on the so-called black tobacco market in the European Union. The possible continuation of such agreements must be subject to better enforceability of the obligations undertaken by tobacco companies. Strict rules must be set. The European Commission must be able to scrutinise these agreements and supervise the fulfilment of all the obligations arising therefro.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the extension of an agreement with Philip Morris that was designed to help tackle smuggling and fraud of branded cigarettes. I believe that although the agreement has been useful, changes in the market and regulatory environment mean it is no longer the best means to continue the fight against illicit tobacco.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution as trafficking, smuggling and counterfeiting of tobacco within the EU is a growing problem. This motion for a Resolution urges the competent authorities to implement a number of measures to act against these practices which represent an even greater public health problem than genuine cigarettes. It is therefore not appropriate to renew, prolong or renegotiate the agreement with PMI.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. We voted against the renewal of the tobacco agreement with the PMI tobacco company because, although it has contributed to the reduction of more than 85% of the illegal tobacco of this firm, it has not prevented new forms of illegal trade. The agreements, as signed in 2004, have not been able to respond to smuggling and continuing counterfeiting in a market where cheap white-label tobacco is currently prevalent. The legal framework has also changed since the first agreement was approved more than 10 years ago. At the time, we did not have the legal instruments to prosecute the main tobacco companies. Fortunately, thanks to the Tobacco Directive and the WHO protocol we will be able, from 2019, to legally pursue illegal tobacco from any producer. In order to avoid a loophole, we call on the Commission to take action against the smuggling of white marks and the initiation of legal action against illegal seizures of PMI products.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Every year, we lose EUR 10 billion in public revenue through the illicit trade in tobacco products and cigarette smuggling. Moreover, this illicit trade constitutes a serious offence. The continuation of the PMI agreement regulating the tobacco market is intended to counteract this.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against extending the agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI) which was signed in 2004 with the intention of tackling the illicit tobacco trade. Since then, a lot has changed. The illicit tobacco market has changed significantly. It is now mainly made up of cheap whites (foreign brands made for the black market) which weren't covered under the 2004 agreement. The Tobacco Products Directive and the WHO’s Framework Convention on Tobacco Control sufficiently address our concerns.  At the same time it is important we don't have dual standards here. I opposed these deals 12 years ago, which effectively subsidise tobacco producers. Tobacco related deaths in some parts of my West Midlands constituency are more than one-and-a-half times the national average. The illicit tobacco trade costs the UK GBP 2bn a year. The Tobacco Products Directive will help track, trace and stop the movement of illegal tobacco products. Only with cooperation at EU level can we tackle this problem – it would be so much more difficult for us in the UK were we to do this on our own.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: In writing. I voted against the renewal of the agreement against cigarette trafficking and counterfeiting signed 12 years ago between the European Union and Philip Morris International. As I recall, this agreement was the result of a rather sordid negotiation and any benefit to the industry: the EU withdrew its complaint against the tobacco company, suspected at a minimum of complacency towards the smuggling of its own cigarettes and money laundering; in exchange, Philip Morris agreed to pay $1.2 billion over 12 years, 10% of which was for the European Union, and better traceability of its products. By the way, we learn that the European Anti-Fraud Office, Olaf, benefits greatly from this windfall, which is quite a confusion of genres! The Commission itself admits that it is difficult to assess the causal link between the evolution of the illegal cigarette market, which today mainly deals with unmarked products, and the agreement in question. It is therefore that it is tenuous and that the agreement has become useless. All the more useless because the regulatory environment has changed. To use my colleague José Bové's excellent comparison, working with the tobacco industry to combat, allegedly, against smuggling is like entrusting the fight against organised crime to Al Capone.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. In this case Phillip Morris International, tobacco agreements were in place to close their eyes to their involvement in illegal tobacco circuits, in exchange for obtaining some collection based on the part of tobacco recognized by those same companies circulating on those circuits. We supported the GUE/NGL Resolution which required not only the cessation of these agreements but also elements of transparency and tough intervention. He didn't come out. However, a resolution has come out, which has also been supported, led by EFDD and Greens, which at least raises the completion of these agreements.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The tobacco report is very important and I congratulate the rapporteur on her success. I am also pleased that my political group did not support the extension of the PMI agreement. Personally, I cannot accept an agreement between the EU and a company, a tobacco producer, no matter how large. Tobacco causes casualties and is harmful to health but, in addition to this extremely important, I believe that the EU's role in trade agreements is outdated. The EU can replace agreements with states, but not with a company, and I regret that there was such an agreement under the puerile grounds of combating cigarette smuggling. I voted for the report on the resolution of the non-extension of the PMI agreement.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which opposes the renewal of the 2004 agreement between Philip Morris International (PMI), the European Union and its Member States, which undertook the tobacco company to provide them with EUR 1 billion a year in aid in the fight against counterfeiting of PMI tobacco products.  Although I am committed to the fight against smuggling, which is a source of funding for certain criminal groups, I am strongly opposed to the renewal of this agreement. Firstly, because according to the Commission's working paper of 24 February 2016, the reduction in the smuggling of PMI products has not led to an overall reduction in the number of illicit products on the EU market. Secondly, and above all, because this agreement seems to me to be unentasy, since there can be no converging interest between the tobacco industry and public health.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution strongly condemning the cooperation agreements between the European Commission and the tobacco industry. These agreements actually lead to delegating control of counterfeiting and cigarette smuggling to cigarette manufacturers themselves. This is an unacceptable situation, which could create serious conflicts of interest within the European Commission, while the Tobacco Directive adopted in 2014 and the World Health Organization conventions prohibit this kind of obscure link with tobacco manufacturers. The European Parliament has thus sent a strong message which I hope will be heard by the Commission.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. The agreement between the European Commission and Philip Morris International expires in July 2016 and I voted against its renewal. Indeed, the continuation of this agreement does not seem justified for several reasons.  Since 2004, when the agreement was signed, the context for tobacco control has changed considerably. The 2014 Tobacco Products Directive proposes new tools, such as product traceability, to effectively combat cigarette trafficking. WHO has also put in place a framework convention that the EU could ratify if it really wanted to combat smuggling and counterfeiting.  In addition, the funds collected by the Commission and the Member States have not been the subject of any budgetary planning. It would have been legitimate to dedicate this money to tobacco control or public health policies. But it's impossible to know what's been done with it. Finally, no visible results resulting in a decrease in cigarette trafficking were observed. These agreements are therefore very problematic and the opacity in which they are negotiated does not contribute to the record. It is now up to the Commission to take Parliament's opinion into account.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. I believe that the main tools to fight illicit trade, counterfeiting of tobacco products and tax evasion should be the Tobacco Products Directive and the FCTC Protocol. The money from these illicit activities goes mainly into funding organised crime.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Written. We do not believe that the EU should renew the current cooperation agreement with the PMI. The cooperation agreement is not effective in today's real problem of illegal trade in tobacco products in the EU, which consists almost exclusively of the smuggling of unlabelled cigarettes. Instead, we are concerned that extending the cooperation agreement with the PMI is incompatible with the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control to protect public health policy against the influence of the tobacco industry and would instead legitimise the tobacco industry and give it undesirable influence. In order to obtain the strongest possible protection of public health, we have voted in today's vote against individual resolutions to support instead the joint resolution (RC-B8-0312/2016) that has been drafted.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. We voted against renewing the tobacco agreement with the PMI tobacco company because, although it has contributed in principle to reducing the illegal tobacco of this firm by more than 85%, it has not served against new forms of illegal trade. The agreements, as signed in 2004, have not been able to respond to smuggling and counterfeiting in continuous mutation where cheap white-label tobacco is predominantly on the market today. The legal framework has also changed since the first agreement was approved more than 10 years ago. At that time we did not have the legal instruments to be able to prosecute the main tobacco companies in justice. Fortunately, thanks to the Tobacco Directive and the WHO protocol we will be able from 2019 to legally pursue illegal tobacco from any producer. In order to avoid a legal vacuum, we call on the Commission to take action against the smuggling of white marks, to put in place all the measures necessary for the monitoring and location of PMI tobacco products, and to take legal action in the face of illegal seizures of products from this manufacturer.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Smuggling of tobacco products, in particular the smuggling and counterfeiting of cigarettes, causes revenue losses in the EU and its Member States (in terms of customs duties, VAT and excise duties) exceeding EUR 10 billion per year. The resolution we have adopted calls for the agreement on combating cigarette smuggling and counterfeiting of tobacco products with the PMI, which expires in July 2016, not to be renewed. Instead, we call on the EU to focus on the available international legislative instruments to combat smuggling.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported a strong call from the Parliament to the European Commission not to renew or extend the agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI) beyond its current expiry date. I voted to say that the only guiding factor when considering a possible extension of agreements with the tobacco industry should be public health considerations. I also supported the call to ask the Commission to prioritise the combined use of the Tobacco Products Directive of 2014 and the WHO protocol which foresee track and trace and introduce security features provisions facilitating law enforcement. Apart from anything else PMI is suing the EU over the 2014 Tobacco Products Directive including its provisions on security and the tracking and tracing of illegal tobacco products.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ For this Tobacco Agreement, I voted to support resolutions that stated clearly that the Commission should not renew, extend or renegotiate the Agreement with Phillips Morris International (PMI) beyond its current date of expiry. I believe that this Agreement is in contradiction with recent tobacco legislation that the EU has passed.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The fight to reduce smoking is one of the most important health policy objectives in the Eu Member States. According to world health organisation data, smoking is the number one cause of preventable diseases in Europe, responsible for 87% of deaths from chronic diseases. In my view, preventing the authorised trade in tobacco is a public task which, in full independence from the tobacco industry, must be carried out exclusively by the State. It is well known that the Hungarian Government is committed to reducing smoking and is at the forefront of this area at EU level because of a number of measures, sometimes by traditional means. In addition to the United Kingdom, Ireland, France and Norway, Hungary recently prepared a draft legislation on single cigarette packaging, which could come before the government in early spring. Since the agreement between Philip Morris International and the Union in 2004, the market and the regulatory environment have changed considerably. Today, 'cheap white' cigarettes make up the bulk of the illegal trade, which these agreements cannot deal with. The new legal framework set out in the EU Tobacco Products Directive and the Protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control already covers all elements of agreements previously concluded with tobacco companies. Against this reason, I am opposed to the extension or renewal of the EU agreement with Philip Morris International in any form.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: in writing. ‒ We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I have decided to vote against the renewal of an agreement reached in 2004 between the European Commission and the tobacco company Philip Morris International (PMI) to combat smuggling and counterfeiting. The European Union is always very picky when it comes to regulating state aid and combating conflicts of interest that concern European historical enterprises. Surprisingly, it allows the world's first cigarette manufacturer to lead the fight against smuggling, while at the same time the volume of low-priced products has exploded on the parallel market.  If the results are not there, how can we continue to encourage this agreement?

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Written. \u2012 The European Parliament sent a strong message to tobacco companies. There is no desire to extend the agreements with the companies against smuggling and counterfeiting. As a result of the agreements, the smuggling of branded cigarettes was brought down, but on the other hand, the smuggling of unspicable cheap cigarettes increased. There is a desire to end cooperation with tobacco companies that erode public health. Only large international tobacco companies that collect their income at the expense of public health benefit from smoking.  In Finland, tobacco policy has been moving in a tighter direction since 1976. At the time, the first tobacco law was enacted, aimed at reducing smoking. Finland is moving towards smoke-free. Since the early 2000s, smoking among young people and adults has decreased.  The bill submitted to the Finnish Parliament in February for a new Tobacco Law aims to end the use of tobacco products and other nicotine-containing products.  Finland's direction is also a good direction for Europe.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted against the European Parliament's Resolution on the Tobacco Agreement B8-0311/2016 (EUL/NGL), and abstained on the European Parliament Resolution on the Tobacco Agreement RC8-0312/2016 (S&D, Greens/EFA and EFDD) following the instructions and policy decisions of the ALDE Group in the European Parliament.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that a common goal throughout Europe should be to reduce the health-related damages of tobacco use. In my view this should be a long term priority of health services and governments in all Member States. The PMI agreement aims to reduce the trade in illicit tobacco products in Europe. Although I do have concerns regarding the fact that tobacco companies are involved in the anti-contraband and anti-counterfeit detection, I believe that when the agreement lapses, there should be no regulatory gap before the entry into force of the Tobacco Products Directive and the WHO’s Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. I would also point out that the PMI agreement has returned large amounts of money to the public purse, and we must therefore continue to reduce contraband and counterfeit tobacco trade in Europe.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the agreements between the European Commission and the tobacco industry (THE "PMI" agreement) with the aim of combating counterfeiting and cigarette smuggling. The tobacco industries have the task of combating cigarette smuggling and counterfeiting and therefore are responsible for the control of tobacco products. This undoubtedly leads to a conflict of interest. Yet this is a serious danger to public health. This practice must therefore be stopped. The EU can fight smuggling on its own, which costs it more than EUR 10 billion a year. This resolution has been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. This European Parliament resolution dealt with whether or not to renew a cooperation agreement signed in 2004 between the European Union and Philip Morris to reduce the illicit tobacco trade in the EU. I am particularly committed to the renewal of this agreement for a number of reasons. Firstly, because the illicit tobacco trade is partly organized by the tobacco companies themselves. Secondly, because we now have adequate tools to combat trafficking with the protocol to the WHO Convention against the Illicit Tobacco Trade and the Tobacco Directive 2014. It is therefore necessary to focus on the effective implementation of these texts rather than renewing this agreement.  Finally, because this agreement would have allowed Philip Morris to quietly continue its small business under the guise of respectability.  By voting against the renewal of this agreement, the European Parliament was able to resist the very aggressive lobbying of tobacco companies which manifested itself until the last moment. Let us now hope that the same will be true for the Commission not to renew this agreement.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Tobacco Agreement between the Commission and PMI. I particularly welcome the call for the combined use of the Tobacco Products Directive and the relevant WHO Protocol, and beyond that extensions of such agreements should be suspended as they do not bring significant added value.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the extension of an agreement with Philip Morris, as changes in the market and regulatory environment mean it is no longer the best means to continue the fight against illicit tobacco. The Commission should focus on implementing the 2014 EU Tobacco Directive, which provides for more effective tools, such as an interoperable tracing and tracking system for the cigarettes at EU level.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ Despite the measures taken by the EU, Member States and the industry there is still incidence of contraband and counterfeit cigarettes. They create a parallel illegal supply. I voted in favour of this report so as to stop this illegal supply. The fight against counterfeit and contraband cigarettes must be a priority for Member States.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I, like a very large majority of MEPs, voted in favour of a resolution calling on the European Commission not to renew its cooperation agreements with Philip Morris International on the fight against cigarette smuggling and counterfeiting.  I welcome the approval of this resolution by the European Parliament. Indeed, despite an initial agreement between 2004 and 2016, the volume of unmarked products - therefore not affected by the agreement - at low prices, has increased in the parallel market. These agreements are unacceptable because they amount to delegating control of tobacco products to the tobacco companies themselves, and they pose a real risk of conflicts of interest. In this regard, it seems to us, the Tobacco Directive adopted in 2014 and the WHO Framework Convention on the Control of Tobacco Products.   Indeed, the French delegation of the EPP Group did not vote like the EPP Group! We opposed the extension of this agreement between the European Commission and the American cigarette giant, contrary to the group's official line.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. On Wednesday 9 March, Parliament took a stand against a renewal of an anti-smuggling and counterfeiting agreement signed with cigarette producer Philip Morris. In this resolution, Parliament announces that it does not want to renew an agreement with Philip Morris in which the EU pledged to fight counterfeiting in exchange for traceability guarantees on cigarettes and financial aid of EUR 1 billion. With the establishment of a WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, Parliament believes that the EU no longer needs to link up with Philip Morris to fight counterfeiting and prefers to put its action with WHO, whose convention is incompatible with agreements with tobacco companies, ahead of its efforts.  With this vote, Parliament announces that it is abandoning its cooperation with tobacco companies, the agreement with Philip Morris being the first of four agreements with the four largest tobacco companies in the world. I have, of course, supported this position of the European Parliament.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. I voted for the joint resolution on the tobacco agreement. As a reminder: in the early 2000s the Philip Morris International consortium (PMI) was indicted for organising cigarette smuggling from the former Yugoslavia. In July 2004 PMI concluded an agreement with the European Union by which PMI committed not to sell third-country cigarettes on the wholesale market. In return, the EU has pledged to combat counterfeit cigarette smuggling by providing cooperation between Member States' customs services and PMI.  This agreement is coming to an end, and so the question of its renewal arises. I am opposed to that. The Commission is the only one conducting the negotiations, with closed-door meetings and a minimum of documents made public. Renewing the agreements would send a counterproductive message, and would imply that the EU is engaging in inappropriate interactions with the tobacco industry.  This text focuses a lot on the public health aspect. While the added value of this argument should have been emphasized, it would have been preferable if the resolution had also devoted more attention to transparency and the fight against fraud.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because it stresses that EU public health policies should not be influenced by the tobacco industry.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. As a world leader in tobacco control, the European Union, for the sake of credibility and transparency, had an interest in not renewing the tobacco agreement, concluded with Philip Morris International in 2004 (PMI partly funded OLAF (European Anti-Fraud Office) and in return the European Union was committed to combating cigarette smuggling).  Thus, this agreement maintained the lobbying activities carried out by PMI and in general by the commercial entities.  In addition, it went against the fight against tobacco signed by the 28 Member States signed by the 28 Member States. Although the text focuses primarily on public health rather than the fight against fraud and transparency, it puts an end to this agreement. That's why I voted FOR.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted against renewing the tobacco agreement with the PMI tobacco company because, even though I have contributed in principle to reducing the illegal tobacco of this firm by more than 85%, it has not served against new forms of illegal trade. The agreements, as signed in 2004, have not been able to respond to smuggling and counterfeiting in continuous mutation, where what is prevalent today in the market is cheap white-label tobacco. The legal framework has also changed since the first agreement was approved more than ten years ago. At that time we did not have the legal instruments to be able to prosecute the main tobacco companies in justice. Fortunately, thanks to the Tobacco Directive and the WHO protocol we will be able from 2019 to legally pursue illegal tobacco from any producer. In order to avoid a legal vacuum, we call on the Commission to take action against the smuggling of white marks, to put in place all the measures necessary for the monitoring and location of PMI tobacco products, and to take legal action in the face of illegal seizures of products from this manufacturer.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it supports the necessary non-renewal of the agreement between the EU and Philip Morris International, while maintaining the need to act on tobacco smuggling and its associated problems. We share the need to act on tobacco smuggling because of the huge amount of taxes that Member States lose from their budgets. The multinational PMI is the great beneficiary of this smuggling that causes so many problems to both coffers and public health and it is therefore necessary to take action on the subject. But this bilateral agreement places a multinational, main beneficiary of smuggling, as a legitimate party to the public authority, this is what this resolution seeks to avoid. This is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna ŁUKACIJEWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is very important for the European market to combat the illicit trade in cigarettes, because we do not know what ingredients such cigarettes contain, and the budget is also lost. Experience so far has shown that the current arrangements, which were signed back in 2004, have worked well. The PMI agreement has so far significantly reduced the smuggling of products, but has also provided a system for tracking the origin of cigarettes. I believe that this agreement should be extended and for these reasons I voted in favour of it.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against all the proposals of the political groups on the EU agreement with Philip Morris, although I supported calls in the partial votes on individual points for the EU not to conclude such agreements anymore. However, I did not agree with the calls for further EU tobacco directives. Therefore, as the EU agreement with the tobacco company expires, I voted against it in the final vote. I strongly disagree with the corporatist principle that the EU should enter into ad hoc agreements with corporations in this way, accept money from them and give up the right to conduct legal proceedings with the corporation. OLAF, the EU anti-corruption institution, has a conflict of interest if it raises money from Philip Morris International.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ smuggling and counterfeiting of illegally imported cigarettes is hurting the economies of Member States' budgets and the EU budget of more than EUR 10 billion per year, while endangering the lives and health of the population. This has further negative effects on public finances. In July 2016, the Tobacco Agreement concluded between the EU and Philip Morris International expires, which has been regulating the fight against smuggling and counterfeiting of tobacco products since 2004 in order to reduce the incidence of smuggled cigarettes on the EU black market. However, the market and regulatory environment has changed since its effectiveness. Member States must comply with the deadline for transposition of Directive 2014/40/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 3 April 2014 responding to new conditions in the field of tobacco products. I support the proposal for the Commission to adopt control measures for the tracing and tracing of PMI tobacco products and to take the necessary legal action in the event of illegal detention. At the same time, it needs to come forward with new additional legislation to introduce Track and Trace and other instruments to combat the smuggling and counterfeiting of tobacco products.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. In 2004, the EU entered into a cooperation agreement with the multinational Philip Morris to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products. Under the terms of the agreement, Philip Morris will have to contribute $1.25 billion over 12 years to the Member States' budget (90%) Commission (10%). With this agreement expiring in July 2016, the question of a possible renewal arises. Nevertheless, it contravenes compliance with the WHO Framework Convention, which calls for a strict minimum of interactions with tobacco manufacturers and full transparency. Moreover, the provisions of this agreement are obsolete because of the new realities of the illicit cigarette trade. Finally, in 2014, the EU adopted a directive on tobacco products to combat illicit trade; Philip Morris has made extensive attempts to hinder the implementation of this directive. For all of these reasons, and given the health and safety dangers of the illicit tobacco trade, I am voting against the renewal of the cooperation agreement with Philip Morris.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the motion for a resolution on the Tobacco Agreement (PMI agreement) because it is well documented.

name: David MARTIN
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that this Resolution emphasises that the Commission must take immediate steps to ensure the full transposition of the Tobacco Products Directive in all Member States.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the extension of an agreement with Philip Morris International.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the motion for a resolution. The Commission should make increased efforts to combat tobacco smuggling and smuggling at European and international level.  However, in this resolution, I believe that a correct reading of the dangers of tobacco to public health has been devalued or not.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution as the Commission will propose a revised Tobacco Products Directive over the coming year.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing – The proposal tabled to extend the agreement between the EU, the Member States and Philip Morris International (PMI) states that the purpose of this agreement is to combat cigarette smuggling and counterfeiting and the associated reduction of PMI cigarettes on the EU black market. The main argument for extending the agreement is that the direct cooperation of investigators at national and European level with the tobacco company in the fight against cigarette smuggling and counterfeiting has led to numerous cases of arrest and indictment of suspects, as well as the detection and dissolution of international organised groups. However, it should be pointed out that there is no evidence of a link between cooperation with the tobacco company and the resolution of these cases (behind which, above all, olaf's quality work must be sought). By negotiating this type of agreement, the Union risks sending a negative signal to the third countries with which it cooperates in the fight against trafficking that it considers bilateral agreements with tobacco companies to be a priority in cases of smuggling and counterfeiting, which in turn may lead to a threat to the ratification of the Protocol on Illicit Trade. However, what I see as the most important thing is that the agreement with the tobacco company does not contribute in any way to the protection of public health, but, on the contrary, has far-reaching negative consequences for it. From the doctor's point of view, I cannot agree with the proposal tabled and I am voting strictly against it.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I am against the extension of an agreement with Philip Morris that was designed to help tackle smuggling and fraud of branded cigarettes.  The agreement with Philip Morris was innovative and a useful tool in the fight against the smuggling of cigarettes when it was first introduced. However, this agreement has run its course and I have opposed its renewal or extension.  Changes in the market and regulatory environment mean that the agreement is no longer the best tool to fight bootlegging or smuggling of tobacco products.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I find the extension of the agreement with Phillip Morris on illicit tobacco unnecessary. Although it was a useful tool to fight against the illicit tobacco trade for the past 12 years, the agreement with Phillip Morris has become obsolete. The development of new regulatory tools such as the Tobacco Products Directive and the WHO Protocol on Tobacco Control and the uncovered issue of unbranded cigarettes known as ‘cheap-whites’ which are traded in considerable amounts has transformed this agreement in an obsolete tool to fight against illicit tobacco trade. Concerning the possible gap between the expiration of this agreement and the entering into force of the new regulatory tools, I believe this can be solved by adopting temporary measures.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 A motion for a resolution was tabled by the GUE/NGL, Verts/ALE, ECR, EFDD, ALDE, PPE and S&D groups on the GUE/NGL (PMI) and others and the Agreement between the EU and its Member States on 9 July 2004 against smuggling and counterfeiting, expiring on 9 July 2016. On the one hand, the S&D, Verts/ALE and EFDD and, on the other hand, the PPE and ECR political groups have drawn up a joint draft compromise. By my vote, I supported the first compromise motion mentioned.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. These various motions for a resolution relate to the renewal of agreements between the EU - via the European Commission - and the Philip Morris International (PMI) tobacco consortium expiring in July 2016. In 2004 PMI concluded an agreement with OLAF whereby PMI agreed not to sell third-country cigarettes destined for the EU on the wholesale market (after being caught smuggling). In return, the EU pledged to combat cigarette smuggling by providing cooperation between the customs services of the Member States and the company (training for customs officers, financing of detection equipment, provision of counterfeit experts). The European Commission recognises that these agreements have not produced satisfactory results, as smuggling is now more important than ever; these agreements are not transparent and Parliament is not involved in negotiations with the tobacco industry; OLAF is therefore partly funded by the tobacco industry, which can be used to corrupt EU public health policies through commercial interests. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolutions proposing not to renew these agreements with the tobacco industry (GUE, Greens, S and D, EFDD).

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted against the motion calling for the renewal of the agreements between the European Commission and the tobacco industry to combat counterfeiting and cigarette smuggling.  These agreements give tobacco companies direct control over tobacco products, which contradicts the 2014 Tobacco Directive and the WHO Framework Convention. I am therefore opposed to their renewal.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. I was not able, for medical reasons, to attend the plenary session from 7 to 10 March 2016. Nevertheless, I would like to express my support for Parliament's decision to call for the non-renewal of agreements with the tobacco industry in the fight against cigarette trafficking. The agreements are intended to delegate control of tobacco products to the industry itself. I am particularly pleased that Parliament has therefore chosen to oppose it.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this motion for a resolution regarding the Tobacco agreement after its assessment.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I admit that agreements with tobacco companies may have had some positive results in the fight against counterfeit and smuggled cigarettes, but I am in favour of a systemic approach in the form of legislative and regulatory instruments. In addition, it turns out that the biggest problem is counterfeit cigarettes of lesser-known brands, which do not cover or cover these agreements. I therefore believe that the Commission should focus on the rapid and thorough implementation of the Tobacco Products Directive as a systemic solution to the problem of counterfeit and smuggled cigarettes.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Tobacco Agreement between the Commission and the PMI Group. I welcome the call to bring the Tobacco Products Directive and the WHO Protocol into line and to suspend the renewal of such agreements as long as they do not bring significant added value.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. The previous PMI agreement is coming to an end and it is necessary to extend the agreement in order to act against the illegal tobacco trade until more active participation in the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control increases. Nevertheless, the resolution left points in support of the activities of tobacco companies, which are not reasonable and do not help the EU to combat the trafficking of tobacco products.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. U2012 Tobacco smuggling is estimated to cost the European Union around EUR 10 billion and we are all aware of its sometimes link to organised crime. Binding agreements such as the one at hand with tobacco company Philip Morris (PMI) have certainly had an effect, achieving significant achievements in the fight against smuggling. This agreement expires in July 2016 and we discuss whether or not it should be renewed. I believe that since the signing of this agreement the situation has changed markedly at the regulatory level in the European Union. We have Directive 2014/40/EU on tobacco products. The one that has not yet been alarmed by many, who believe that a legal vacuum will be created until then, resulting in a setback in the achievements achieved with the PMI. I consider that there is no reason for such alarms. The WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control and its protocols already provide for mechanisms in the fight against smuggling. There are no excuses and there should be no room for fear. We have the tools, we just have to commit to its application.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU's financial interests must be adequately protected and trade in smuggled and counterfeit goods must be prevented. However, there are doubts as to whether the extension of agreements with tobacco industry will lead to the proper implementation of measures to combat cigarette smuggling. There is no indication of how much money has been allocated to each Member State and how they have used the money received under such agreements. I believe that the Commission should, at EU level, develop, before the expiry of the agreement, all the tools necessary to monitor and track PMI tobacco products and take legal action against any illegal seizure of the products of this producer. It should be noted that there must be no regulatory gaps in the agreement with the PMI before the entry into force of the Tobacco Products Directive and the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. Therefore, as an additional tool to combat trafficking in smuggling and counterfeit goods, a proposal for a new additional regulation would be introduced to establish a monitoring and surveillance system and apply due diligence ('know your customer').

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Illicit tobacco trafficking, in addition to leading to a substantial economic loss, contributes to the financing of the activities of international organized crime. Considering the findings of the agreement in the Italian case to be positive, I consider the renewal of the agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI) to be commendable, considering the extension necessary so that there is no regulatory vacuum until the entry into force of the Tobacco Products Directive and the WHO Protocol (FCTC). I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. I supported a joint resolution calling on the Commission not to renew or renew the agreement or negotiate with Philip Morris International (PMI), one of the largest tobacco manufacturers in the world. It is necessary to go on the side line with tobacco in a different and effective way and in the spirit of the tobacco directive. Now the circumstances have changed significantly, and such an agreement is no longer necessary, and we have adopted a new European tobacco directive that will commit the tobacco industry to higher standards of traceability of tobacco products. Renewing the agreement with a tobacco company would also send a bad message to third countries that the European Union has inappropriate contacts with the tobacco industry, even though they are clearly prohibited by the PROTOCOL of the WHO Tobacco Control Convention.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The fight against tobacco smuggling requires more effective tools and measures on top of current agreements with the tobacco industry, tobacco companies and tobacco producers. I accept the joint resolution on the grounds that it leads to additional consumer protection, the prevention of smuggling and fraud and the further suppression of the black market in tobacco and tobacco products.  As many as seven hundred thousand CITIZENS of the European Union die prematurely every year as a result of the effects of smoking. Therefore, I believe that we should also work on greater awareness among citizens about the harmfulness of smoking.  The previous agreement with Phillip Morris International did not contribute to reducing the smuggling of tobacco products, nor did it have an impact on improving the public health of our citizens. Unmarked cigarettes are increasingly present on the market and available to citizens, especially young people, at very low prices.  I assess the positive proposal expressed in a joint resolution calling on the Commission to propose an action plan that will set out new measures to urgently address the problems posed by brandless cigarettes. I hope that this action plan will bear better fruit than agreements with the tobacco industry that have not proved successful.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The resolution calls for more transparency, strongly challenges the tobacco industry's funding of OLAF and the weight of commercial interests in EU public health decisions. This last point is also valid in many areas other than tobacco... That is why I am voting in favour of this text which is critical of the European Union and which underlines some of its most serious shortcomings.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The main objective of the PMI agreement was to reduce the prevalence of smuggled products of the company in the illicit tobacco market in the EU. At the end of February, the Commission concluded in its technical assessment of the PMI agreement that this basic objective had been effectively achieved, but I express concern that the decrease in PMI smuggled products did not result in an overall reduction in the number of illicit products on the EU market. I would like to recall that counterfeit cigarettes that are illegally produced and imported, and whose ingredients are unknown, imply even greater health risks from the risks associated with the original products and create public health problems. While the PMI agreement initially made an important contribution in the fight against illicit tobacco trade, I would like to stress that since the signing of the current agreement, there have been significant changes in both the market and regulatory environments, in particular with regard to the increased presence of cigarettes of an unknown brand intended for illicit sale - the so-called cheap whites. I therefore consider that the agreement with PMI for the EU no longer represents added value in the fight against illicit tobacco trade and should not be extended as such.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. Every year, seven hundred thousand people lose their lives prematurely as a result of the health damage caused by smoking — a result of revenue losses of more than €10 billion a year in the EU through illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular smuggling and cigarette smuggling. This is a situation that undermines the results of policies to combat smoking by increasing access to tobacco products, especially for young people and low-income groups. The large agreements concluded by Member States and the EU with the tobacco industry to combat the illegal trade in cigarettes have had very little significant effect. In view of the end of the period of validity of the agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI), secret and formal negotiations between the European Commission and the tobacco industry were known. The resolution calls on the Commission and the Council to suspend any further contact with PMI or other tobacco manufacturers for a possible extension of tobacco agreements and to waive other such agreements. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – I welcome this resolution and fully support it. The agreement with Philip Morris International, currently in force, expires in July this year and it is necessary to decide whether to sign a new one. In my view, when discussing the signing of the new agreement, it is essential, in the first place, to take into account the changes that have occurred in the tobacco products market since the signing of the last agreement. As highlighted in the resolution, the previous agreement did not address the serious problem of cigarette smuggling without a designated brand of manufacturer, and the trend has been growing in recent years. The resolution also calls on the Commission, which I particularly support, for possible negotiations on a new tobacco agreement to take place in a transparent climate in order to avoid conflicts of interest as much as possible and allow for open and democratic debate.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very glad that today the European Parliament has prevented the extension of the existing CONVENTION between the EU and Philip Morris International. I see no reason why these and other similar agreements should continue. It is in the interest of the tobacco companies themselves to continue to participate independently in the fight against tobacco smugglers. The current agreement is obsolete and does not meet today's challenges, such as the so-called cheap whites, whose sales in the EU cause large tax losses to Member States every year. Effective monitoring and search mechanisms should therefore be established to effectively address this problem while being independent of tobacco companies. The renewal of this agreement would also constitute a conflict between the interests of the tobacco industry and those of public health. Therefore, the framework convention on tobacco control to which the EU has committed itself would be breached. At the same time, it should be borne in mind that in 2014 the European Union approved the Tobacco Products Directive, which, together with the FCTC Protocol, constitutes effective tools to combat the illegal importation of tobacco products. I therefore want to appeal to all Member States to ratify this directive as soon as possible in order to engage not only in the fight against the illegal trade in tobacco products, but also to take a step in the interests of public health.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. I objected to the renewal of the European Commission's anti-trafficking agreement with cigarette manufacturer Philip Morris International in 2004, which expires in July 2016. Although this agreement is aimed at combating smuggling, its effectiveness may be called into question. In addition, the agreement poses a risk of conflict of interest, with part of the funding of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) coming from the cigarette manufacturer. I therefore call on the Commission to work on the practical application of the Tobacco Products Directive adopted in 2014.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which addresses the Commission's proposal of 4 May 2015 on behalf of the European Union for the ratification of the Protocol for the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products, adopted on the World Health Organisation's Convention-Framework for Tobacco Control. An opinion is also issued on the agreement to combat tobacco smuggling and tobacco smuggling between Philip Morris International (PMI) and subsidiaries, the Commission and 10 Member States. Although it was an innovative tool in 2004, I agree that this agreement with the PMI is outdated for a number of reasons, including the fact that smuggling is an international problem, whereas that agreement only applies to the EU. Furthermore, I consider that all the elements covered by the agreement with the PMI are now covered by the new legal framework, and that agreement does not include the relevant characteristics of the current illicit tobacco trade. To this end, I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, because I agree that the Commission should not renew, extend or renegotiate the agreement with the PMI.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. By refusing this lunchtime the renewal of the agreement with Philip Morris International, 414 MEPs have said NO to any compromise with tobacco companies. An industry responsible for the deaths of seven hundred thousand Europeans each year cannot be considered an industry like any other! The EU was already guilty of having signed an agreement with PMI in 2004, in complete opacity, making the financial interest clearly put ahead of any ethical and public health considerations. Practically, the binding agreement provided for a payment of 1.25 billion euros over twelve years by the PMI group in exchange for an obligation for the group to control the smuggling of its cigarettes. The Commission does not seem to have learned the lesson from what Vice-President Georgieva said in the plenary session on 25 February. For those like me who have fiercely defended the health of citizens during the negotiations on the 2014/40/EU directive on tobacco products, such an attempt to interfere with the tobacco industry in public affairs is unacceptable. The Commission has no choice but to stand behind the European Parliament, not to renew the agreement with PMI, at the risk otherwise of adding cynicism to European fatalism.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 There are 4 such agreements between the EU, the Member States and 4 tobacco companies. Philip Morris's is the first to expire (in July) and it was necessary to consider the possibility of renewal. All these agreements aim to combat the illicit trade in tobacco and involve the collaboration of companies. The Socialist Group in the European Parliament has expressed its position against the extension of the agreement with Philip Morris, believing that, although it has been useful in combating fraud, changes in the market (appearance of white label products) and in the regulations that frame this trade (Tobacco Products Directive) have made it no longer the best way to continue the fight against illicit tobacco. Parliament confirmed the socialist group's position.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The illegal tobacco trade calls into question public health policy against smoking by eliminating major disincentives for consumption, as well as representing a crime against the public treasury and a loss of more than EUR 10 billion per year in the EU in evaded excise duties on tobacco products. The EU and Philip Morris International (PMI) ratified an agreement in 2004 to combat more effectively cigarette fraud and smuggling that expires in July 2016. But since its signing, the legal framework has evolved radically and today we have powerful legal instruments to combat the illicit tobacco trade. The Tobacco Directive will allow for greater control of tobacco companies in the EU and a traceability system, and the WHO Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products will also enable illegal tobacco to be fought internationally.  I therefore voted in favour of this Resolution which asks the Commission not to renew, extend or renegotiate the agreement with PMI after its current expiry date.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. On this thorny (if not "smoky") issue, my vote was very clear: I supported the majority resolution, not that of my group, which believes that the renewal of the agreement with Philip Morris Brands SARL would send a damaging and counterproductive message by suggesting that the European Union is engaging in inappropriate interactions with the tobacco industry and which considers that it is appropriate not to renew , extend or renegotiate the agreement beyond its current expiry date.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. The agreement with tobacco giant Philip Morris International is in some way legalising its products that appear on the market but do not label labels and labels. The aim of the agreement with pmi is to reduce the illicit circulation of PMI products in the illicit EU tobacco market. The Commission found in its technical assessment that this objective had been effectively achieved, although the smuggling of PMI products could not be substantially reduced in relation to illicit products on the EU market.  For its part, the European Parliament stresses the urgent need for the Commission to take immediate action to ensure full transposition of the Tobacco Products Directive in all Member States. As regards the objectives of reducing illicit trade, I consider the agreement with the PMI, as I have already mentioned, to partially justify the illegal circulation of its products, to be rejected.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. Since 2004, Member States and the Commission have had a cooperation agreement with Philip Morris to combat the illicit trade in tobacco products. They receive $1.25 billion over 12 years and, in return, forego legal action against Philip Morris.  As this cooperation agreement came to an end, the Group of Socialists and Democrats strongly opposed its renewal and obtained a vote by Parliament to do so. It contravened Article 5.3 of the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which calls for limiting interactions with tobacco manufacturers. Moreover, this agreement was far removed from the realities of the market that is beyond its reach.  Other tools exist to combat the illicit tobacco trade and are included in the 2014 Directive and the WHO Protocol Against Illicit Tobacco Trade: traceability, production of quantities absorbable by the legal market. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which opposes the renewal of an agreement reached in 2004 between the European Commission and Philip Morris, the leading international manufacturer of cigarettes, to combat smuggling and counterfeiting. This agreement established a conflict of interest relationship: Philip Morris provided financial resources to the European Union's Anti-Fraud Organization, and in exchange fought against the trafficking and counterfeiting of tobacco products.  In addition to ethical issues, the effectiveness of such agreements should be questioned given the increase in the trafficking of "cheap white" cigarettes.  The non-extension of this agreement is in line with the principles of the tobacco directive adopted in 2014 and avoids any situation of conflict of interest.
