Rather, it is a matter of working on the implementation of the 2014 Tobacco Products Directive, which provides a number of instruments to combat smuggling. It is also crucial that Member States ratify the protocol to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which obliges parties to protect their public health policies from the commercial interests of the tobacco industry.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. In this case Phillip Morris International, tobacco agreements were in place to close their eyes to their involvement in illegal tobacco circuits, in exchange for obtaining some collection based on the part of tobacco recognized by those same companies circulating on those circuits. We supported the GUE/NGL Resolution which required not only the cessation of these agreements but also elements of transparency and tough intervention. He didn't come out. However, a resolution has come out, which has also been supported, led by EFDD and Greens, which at least raises the completion of these agreements.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ The original PMI agreement played an important role in compensating for lost revenue and fighting the trade in illicit tobacco. However, the arrangement is now outdated and does not take account of more recent developments, such as the availability of unbranded products, the so-called ‘cheap whites’, and the new provisions in the Tobacco Products Directive. This changed environment calls for new solutions.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Written. (u2012" When the agreement with Philips Morris was made, it was due to a regulatory vacuum. This gap was filled by the adoption of the Tobacco Directive, with which we will be seriously combating contraband cigarettes. In addition, the agreement with Philip Morris has so far not resulted in fewer contraband cigarettes on the European market, only fewer from PM. In other words, there is no need for an extension or renewal of the agreement with the PM. That is why I voted against an extension and a renewal.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it supports the necessary non-renewal of the agreement between the EU and Philip Morris International, while maintaining the need to act on tobacco smuggling and its associated problems. We share the need to act on tobacco smuggling because of the huge amount of taxes that Member States lose from their budgets. The multinational PMI is the great beneficiary of this smuggling that causes so many problems to both coffers and public health and it is therefore necessary to take action on the subject. But this bilateral agreement places a multinational, main beneficiary of smuggling, as a legitimate party to the public authority, this is what this resolution seeks to avoid. This is why I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 Illicit trade in tobacco represents losses of more than EUR 10 billion to the EU and its Member States, in addition to the increased health risks related to the presence of unauthorised substances and the impact on producers' income. Over the years, cooperation agreements have been concluded with four of the world's leading cigarette manufacturers to combat illicit tobacco trade in the EU. The EU agreement with tobacco manufacturer Philip Morris International (PMI) will expire in July 2016 and should decide on its renewal. I voted not to renew the agreement with the PMI tobacco company because it is insufficient to address the current characteristics of the illicit tobacco trade and because the desirable legal framework is defined in the legal framework set up by Directive 2014/40/EU. The Commission was required to draw up additional measures for the monitoring and location of PMI tobacco, and to allow legal proceedings against illegal seizures of the manufacturer's products until all the provisions of the Directive are fully in force, in order to avoid a regulatory gap between the expiry of the agreement with the PMI and the entry into force of the Directive.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ We recognise the intention of these Agreements as helping in the fight against counterfeit cigarettes and note that so-called ‘plain whites’ cause particular problems.  However, as UKIP MEPs there is another issue: the various motions for resolution all support further legislation by the Commission. We are unconvinced that this will do any good; the Commission has a poor track record on such matters.  The Tobacco Products Directive in particular is a poorly-drafted piece of legislation.  We note further that many of the reports call for non-renewal of the agreement with PMI.  We consider it to be unrealistic to expect PMI to adhere to their side of the agreement once an agreement is no longer in force; balance is required. We therefore opposed the various motions for resolutions on this subject.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Unfortunately, I cannot support the PMI agreement renewal in its current form. The agreement was supposed to reduce significantly counterfeit tobacco product smuggling, but it did not achieve this. Instead the agreement seems to have benefited Philip Morris International (PMI), insofar that there was an reduction in the amount of counterfeit PMI products sold, but the trade of illicit tobacco products overall has not reduced. We need to get up and running a framework for tracking and tracing tobacco products in order to bring down this kind of activity, for which the tobacco products directive provides. The Tories, meanwhile, have clearly shown where their allegiances lie: with the big corporations and not the interest of the public.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported this joint proposal for a regulation that would not be possible to renew the Tobacco Agreement between the Commission and philip morris international (PMI). The current PMI agreement expires in July 2016 and the Commission has not yet published an assessment of the effectiveness of this agreement. Following the adoption of the Harmonisation Of Laws and Other Regulations of the Member States on the production, presentation and sale of tobacco and related products, Agreements such as this no longer bring added value in the fight against the illegal sale of tobacco products. Protecting public health from the harmful effects of tobacco products is a cornerstone of my arguments against pmi agreements. All legal restrictions on this policy related to the prices of tobacco products are adopted to discourage people from smoking, not only young people, and the illegal sale of cigarettes undermines the importance and effectiveness of these restrictions and policies. In my view, there are alternatives to the Agreement, which, once it ceases to be beneficial to the wider community, becomes only an obstacle to adopting new policies to protect European citizens.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Tobacco smuggling undermines EU public health policies and means that illicit tobacco products are available in many places at a significant illegal discount. Counterfeit cigarettes are not only illegally manufactured and imported, but also contain unknown ingredients, poses a serious threat to health. That is why the Commission is committed to ratifying the Protocol to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products in order to combat illicit trade in tobacco products, which is an essential step to strengthen the legal framework for combating illicit trade in tobacco products. This Protocol has so far been ratified by 15 countries, including five EU Member States, and the EU is currently preparing for ratification. At the same time, the Commission should also invite other Member States and third countries to ratify the Protocol so that agreements with tobacco companies with any derogations are not possible. The public health of eu citizens must be prioritise over the interests of tobacco firms. Therefore, the Commission must take immediate measures to ensure full transposition of the Tobacco Products Directive in all Member States.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Illicit tobacco trade is a global problem which is why Member States lose up to EUR 10 billion per year. Over the past 12 years, the EU has signed tobacco agreements with four global tobacco manufacturers to help Member States recover revenues from the duties they are losing as a result of tobacco smuggling. The agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI) in 2004, when it was first concluded, was an appropriate instrument in the fight against illicit trade in tobacco products, but the market and the regulatory environment have since undergone a number of changes, so the agreement does not address the important features of today's illicit tobacco trade, especially not the large proportion of cigarettes today represented by illicit whites. The Agreement has also been replaced by the provisions of the Tobacco Products Directive and the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control. The convention also emphasises that such agreements with the tobacco industry are in conflict with the objectives of the Convention and jeopardise progress on tobacco control. Renewing tobacco agreements would send the wrong signal to countries outside the EU. In view of the above, I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the Commission not to extend the agreement on preventing cigarette smuggling.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the renewal of the agreement concluded in 2004 between the EU and Philip Morris International (SME), which provides for the latter's commitment to work with the European Commission, specifically with the Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF), and with the Member States to prevent its products from being placed in smuggling channels in Europe and the rest of the world. The agreement, which expires in June 2016, should not be renewed because, as the evaluation report presented by the Commission shows, its primary purpose - the reduction of SME smuggling products - has been achieved, with an 85% drop in the trade in illegal cigarettes. Although further efforts are still needed before a general reduction in this phenomenon can be made, I believe that the fight against smuggling cannot be delegated to the tobacco industry but should be conducted on the basis of the legal instruments available, such as the WHO Framework Convention to Combat Smoking and the Protocol on the Elimination of Illegal Trade in Tobacco Products and Directive 2014/40 on Tobacco Products, which introduces, in particular, a legal obligation for product traceability by tobacco companies.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 Protecting the EU's financial interests is one of the Commission's top priorities and, according to some estimates, illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular the smuggling of illicit and counterfeit cigarettes, costs national budgets and the EU budget more than EUR 10 billion a year in lost government revenues. In its technical assessment of the PMI Agreement, the Commission concludes that this central objective has been effectively achieved, but questions the causal link between this result and points out that the decrease in pmi contraband has not led to an overall reduction in the number of illicit products on the EU market. Therefore, renewing the PMI agreement would be incompatible with the EU obligations referred to in Article 5(3) of the WHO FCTC protocol, which could damage the EU's reputation as a global leader in tobacco control, and I supported the resolution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ The tobacco industry today is one of the largest in the world and generates huge financial revenues, contributing to the strong growth of the economies of many countries around the world. However, illicit trade in tobacco products is also significantly widespread. Such illegal trade, in particular the smuggling of counterfeit cigarettes, results in losses in revenues of the European Union and its Member States, reaching more than 10 billion euros a year when unpaid duties, taxes and excise duties are taken into account. The Tobacco Products Directive provides for a legal obligation, which will enter into force no later than 2019, under which tobacco companies must introduce and maintain a system for monitoring and finding tobacco products. However, it is essential that the Commission takes measures to ensure the full transposition of the Tobacco Products Directive into the national legislation of all Member States of the European Union and that the Commission focuses on European and international legislative instruments to address smuggled and counterfeit cigarettes more effectively. I agree that Member States must implement the Tobacco Products Directive in a timely manner and, in particular, measures relating to the monitoring and finding of tobacco products. I also think it is not right that the annual payments of the tobacco industry partly finance the budget of the European Anti-Fraud Office, as such activity can lead to conflicts of interest.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the joint resolution on tobacco smuggling which calls for the agreement to combat cigarette smuggling and counterfeiting of tobacco products with Philip Morris International (PMI), which expires in July 2016, not to be renewed. The big cigarette companies should let the state take up its role in the fight against smuggling, since there are already WTO rules on which states can rely.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution opposing the renewal of the agreement between Philip Morris International (PMI) and the European Commission, which expired in July 2016. It can be seen that, although smuggling was initially reduced as a result of the PMI agreement, the established void was soon filled by unbranded, smuggled so-called cheap white cigarettes, as economic, social and regulatory conditions changed. Instead of renewing the agreement, however, I consider the implementation of the 2014 EU Tobacco Products Directive to be a good instrument, which is more effective than, for example, the EU-wide tracking and tracking system. I believe that the profits of manufacturers, the turnover of smugglers and counterfeiters in the black zone and the tobacco tax revenue of governments are all skyrocketing. Meanwhile, national governments, especially the Orban government sweeping everything into their pockets, are surrounded by a wide variety of corruption allegations. That is why I supported the european Commission's expiring agreements not to renew them in their present form, while agreeing with the approach of combating smuggling at all levels, including at Commission level, by all EU and international instruments. This is also due to the fact that the th trade in tobacco products, and in particular the trade in smuggled and counterfeit cigarettes, causes the EU and its Member States (customs duties, VAT and excise duties) to loss of revenue of more than EUR 10 billion per year.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 At the end of the 1990s, due to the huge increase in illicit trade in tobacco products, the European Commission decided to sign agreements to combat this practice with the four largest tobacco companies. The agreement with Philip Morris International (PMI) signed in 2004 will expire in July this year. However, in general, illicit trade has not decreased and PMI products have been replaced by non-branded cigarettes. The funds that the PMI provided under the agreement to the budgets of the European Commission and the Member States were used to effectively combat cigarette smuggling, e.g. the purchase of specialised equipment. Moreover, PMI provided its own codentify cigarette traceability system, which greatly facilitated the work of customs officers. Since the signing of the PMI agreement, the EU has adopted the Tobacco Products Directive and the Protocol to the Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, which can effectively replace it. Unfortunately, they will only be fully operational from 2019 (Directive) and 2022-23 (Convention).  In view of the need to find an effective solution to the legal gap that will arise between 2016 and 2019, when customs authorities will have to work without the help of the PMI, I decided to vote against the proposed motion for a resolution.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: Written. \u2012 I voted against the tobacco agreement because there should be no cooperation with the tobacco industry. The extension of the agreement would have risked the reputation of the european Union as a whole, as it would have been contrary to the principle of the FCTC , an international tobacco convention ratified by 180 countries (including Finland) and also by the EU Commission (cooperation with the tobacco industry). The extension of the tobacco agreement could also have jeopardised the adoption and implementation of the FCTC's anti-smuggling protocol.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Having been a facilitator of social dialogue in an independent capacity between the Commission and a private tobacco company I have decided to abstain on every resolution.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. The European Socialists are determined to fight the tobacco lobby. In 2004, the Commission and Member States concluded a "cooperation" agreement with Philip Morris International, which had committed EUR 1.2 billion over 12 years, to compensate for the harms of the illicit tobacco trade in Europe. This agreement expires in July, and by its vote, the European Parliament has expressed its resolution not to renew it.  Indeed, the financing of public institutions by the tobacco industry is an anomaly that we had to correct, since it contravenes the framework convention of the World Health Organization. Moreover, this agreement no longer corresponds to illegal tobacco practices, since we are seeing an increase in the production of Cheap Whites, i.e. unsealed cigarettes produced outside the European Union.  While Philip Morris has used all its lobbying forces to fight the Tobacco Directive of 2014, and the company does not back down from any obstacles to avoid its transposition, we refuse the renewal of this agreement. 700,000 Europeans die prematurely each year because of smoking, so let's not let manufacturers defraud with impunity.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I believe that fraud in the tobacco sector affects public health and poses an even greater health risk than original tobacco products, as counterfeit cigarettes are produced and imported illegally and use unknown ingredients. I believe that the central objective of this agreement is to reduce the representation of smuggled tobacco products in the illicit tobacco market in the European Union.  I emphasise that the European Commission must look for ways to deal transparently and responsibly with the involvement of the European Parliament. I therefore consider that all arguments for and against the extension of the Philip Morris International Agreement should be taken into account, as its extension marks a transitional arrangement to prevent a regulatory gap until the Tobacco Products Directive fully enters into force.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a joint resolution on the Tobacco Agreement, as the expiring agreement with the PMI sends a counterproductive and controversial message to both EU citizens and third countries. Renewing and renewing such an agreement would be a step backwards in the area of tobacco control. I believe that the pressing problem of the illegal tobacco trade must be tackled in a more efficient way and with transparent tools. The extension of the agreement is particularly pointless, as a comparable but more effective international tool is the 2014 European Tobacco Products Directive and the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. In this case Phillip Morris International, tobacco agreements were in place to close their eyes to their involvement in illegal tobacco circuits, in exchange for obtaining some collection based on the part of tobacco recognized by those same companies circulating on those circuits. We supported the GUE/NGL Resolution which required not only the cessation of these agreements but also elements of transparency and tough intervention. He didn't come out. However, a resolution has come out, which has also been supported, led by EFDD and Greens, which at least raises the completion of these agreements.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that it is urgent that action has be taken against contraband cigarettes on European territory, first because the illegal sale is cheaper and more accessible to the population, especially young people, and second because Member States fail to enter a significant amount of taxes. I support the European institutions to take the necessary measures to address an effective and forceful way as a public safety issue.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 Member States and the Commission concluded agreements with tobacco producers Philip Morris International in 2004, Japan Tobacco in 2007, British American Tobacco in 2010 and Imperial Tobacco in 2010. Through these agreements, those companies undertake to sell only to trusted customers and to implement a surveillance system to help prevent and combat illegal cigarette trafficking. These agreements are extremely important, especially given that the 2014 Tobacco Directive has not been fully transposed by the Member States and that they have not yet ratified the Protocol to the World Health Organisation Framework Convention on Tobacco Control, so these instruments are not, for the time being, operational. In this respect, in order to protect the health of European citizens and the financial interests of the European Union, given that national and European budgets are losing EUR 10 billion each year due to trafficking in counterfeit and contraband cigarettes, it is necessary to renew the agreement with Philip Morris International until other instruments are available. I therefore voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Tobacco Agreement.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The main objective of the pmi agreement is to reduce almost the dominance of counterfeit PMI products in the EU illegal tobacco market. The decrease in the smuggling of PMI products has not led to an overall decrease in the volume of illegal products on the EU market. The Commission should take immediate steps to ensure that the Tobacco Products Directive is fully trans implanted in all Member States. I voted in favour of the S&D group's position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. In this case Phillip Morris International, tobacco agreements were in place to close their eyes to their involvement in illegal tobacco circuits, in exchange for obtaining some collection based on the part of tobacco recognized by those same companies circulating on those circuits. We supported the GUE/NGL Resolution which required not only the cessation of these agreements but also elements of transparency and tough intervention. He didn't come out. However, a resolution has come out, which has also been supported, led by EFDD and Greens, which at least raises the completion of these agreements.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the resolution rejects the renewal of the Tobacco agreement with Philip Morris International. I am against the renewal of the agreement as it has become a useless tool to protect public health, because there is a fundamental and irreconcilable conflict between the tobacco industry’s interests and public health policy interests and because there is a huge reputational risk for the EU in renewing the agreement.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's decision to call on the Commission not to renew agreements with tobacco giants on the smuggling and counterfeiting of cigarettes, because the existing transactions were in exchange for the suspension of legal proceedings against them for billions of dollars of lost duties due to the illegal trade in cigarettes.  Although more than two billion dollars have been recovered in this way, the illegal trade in cigarettes has not only not stopped, but brings more than ten billion euros in losses to the EU, along with a sharp increase in smuggling of other types, especially "cheap white" cigarettes. Therefore, it cannot be considered normal practice for the EU to negotiate with individual tobacco companies where the most recent Tobacco Directive of 2014 provides for specific measures to combat cigarette smuggling and counterfeiting. The efforts of the Commission and the Member States must focus on the strict implementation of the effective toolkit in the Accelerated Introduction directive for interoperable tracking schemes for cigarettes and tobacco products in the EU, including those of the companies concerned. It is also essential that member states ratify the Protocol to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control in order to ensure the necessary traceability of cigarettes internationally.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on tobacco agreement (PMI agreement), which appeals to the Commission not to renew an EU anti-smuggling and anti-counterfeiting deal with Philip Morris International (PMI), as it proved ineffective. The agreement required the four largest tobacco firms to pay the EU and its Member States a total of USD 2.15 billion to drop legal proceedings against them to recover duties lost to illegal trade in cigarettes, where the companies also agreed to devotedly fight tobacco smuggling and counterfeiting.  However, despite reducing tobacco smuggling, the agreement´s side-effect was a rise in illegal trafficking of low-quality white cigarettes. The resolution suggests using EU and international legislative tools to combat smuggling. It equally expresses concern that annual payments from the tobacco industry could lead to a conflict of interest. Overall, the resolution aims at preventing illegal trafficking of tobacco and increasing the transparency of the tobacco industry in the EU.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We are talking about a Resolution pointing to the Protocol on the Elimination of Illicit Trade in Tobacco Products and Directive 2014/40/EU as the main instruments of the Union in its fight against illicit trade in tobacco, and requesting that the Commission enerat the full transposition of the Tobacco Products Directive in all Member States and also to present an action plan setting out new measures to solve the problem of cheap and unmarked cigarettes. We are therefore talking about a resolution which seeks to move the Commission forward in the fight against the illicit trade in tobacco, so I think it is appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. We voted against renewing the tobacco agreement with the PMI tobacco company because, although it has contributed in principle to reducing the illegal tobacco of this firm by more than 85%, it has not served against new forms of illegal trade. The agreements, as signed in 2004, have not been able to respond to smuggling and counterfeiting in continuous mutation where cheap white-label tobacco is predominantly on the market today. The legal framework has also changed since the first agreement was approved more than 10 years ago. At that time we did not have the legal instruments to be able to prosecute the main tobacco companies in justice. Fortunately, thanks to the Tobacco Directive and the WHO protocol we will be able from 2019 to legally pursue illegal tobacco from any producer. In order to avoid a legal vacuum, we call on the Commission to take action against the smuggling of white marks, to put in place all the measures necessary for the monitoring and location of PMI tobacco products, and to take legal action in the face of illegal seizures of products from this manufacturer.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the tobacco resolution first of all because I believe that the current agreements with the producing industries are a resounding example of a total lack of transparency. These agreements were concluded because the European Commission took legal action against Philip Morris International and other companies, accusing them of cigarette smuggling: a large proportion of the smuggled goods came directly from the manufacturing companies. Philip Morris has paid the Member States eur 1 billion over twelve years, but we do not know how this proceeds, and the proceeds of fines for seizures of original material, have been used. The resolution therefore calls for these agreements not to be renewed, and also calls for an independent traceability system to be set up: at the moment it is the manufacturers themselves who have the system for tracking cigarette packets, that is to say, controllers and controllers are the same thing. Furthermore, the resolution calls on the Commission to ratify the WHO protocol on the elimination of the illegal trade in tobacco products in good time and to address the issue of cheap whites, which are illegal cigarettes in Europe and sold on the black market, with serious damage to the health of citizens.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the framework of the tobacco trade.  Smuggling in this area would cost Member States up to EUR 10 billion in unpaid taxes, often to the financing of criminal activities. Several cooperation agreements now require the tobacco industry to implement controls and product monitoring and limit sales based on demand.  These agreements also contain provisions that are now irreconcilable with EU legislation on the presentation and sale of cigarette packets.  One of the agreements expires in July 2016. While this agreement may have been useful at the time it was concluded in 2004, the significant changes that have taken place in the regulatory framework no longer justify its renewal.  The elements relating to the illicit tobacco trade will in any case be covered by the Tobacco Products Directive and the protocol at the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control.  I voted against the renewal of such an agreement that could be derogatory and for the report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 700 000 EU citizens die prematurely each year due to smoking. Illicit trade in tobacco products, in particular smuggling and cigarette smuggling, causes the EU and its Member States to generate losses of more than EUR 10 billion per year and, in addition to compromising policies to combat smoking, increases access to tobacco products, especially for young people and low-income groups. Member States and the EU have concluded agreements in which companies have undertaken to collectively pay a total amount of US$2.15 billion to the EU and the signatory States in order to combat the illegal trade in cigarettes, although to date there has been no positive effect on public health as a result of these agreements.  In the light of the termination of the agreement with Philip Morris International, secret and formal negotiations between the Commission and the tobacco industry were known, contradicting the objectives of transparency. The resolution voted on today therefore calls on the Commission and the Council to suspend any further contact with PMI or other tobacco manufacturers on the possible extension of tobacco agreements and to completely renounce any other such agreements.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. Although the Commission's assessment is that while there has been an 85% decrease in smuggled PMI cigarettes over the period 2006-2014, the overall view is that this reduction in PMI contraband has not led to a general decrease in illegal products on the EU market. It is therefore questionable whether the agreement has had a positive impact on the health of EU citizens and thus served its proper purpose.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's resolution on an agreement with the tobacco company PMI. The report aims to protect the Financial Interests of the European Union, wants the agreement to combat illegal trade to contribute to this, and assesses the possible consequences of tobacco smuggling. I am opposed to state interests being pursued through agreements with private groups. State and private should be separate spheres, and Parliament should regulate necessary matters through universal laws.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Here, yet again, is an example of the EU being able to tackle a serious public health issue in a manner that Member States cannot undertake alone. The tobacco industries’ attempts to foil the Tobacco Products Directive were ferocious; we have seen PMI’s aggressive strategies of intimidation, and law-suits against governments all around the world who try to regulate tobacco products. The Directive was adopted in 2014 much due to the tenacious and determined work of Labour MEPs.  European national governments would most likely not have been able to stand strong in the face of  mass lobbying from a large industry, and this demonstrates the collective strength of EU legislators.  I welcome the EU signing up to the WHO programme to tackle illicit trade in tobacco products, and support my S&D colleagues in their work on this important public health and public interest issue.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted to end the current agreement with Philip Morris International because it has not fulfilled its aim of reducing the illegal tobacco trade.  The agreement requires the company to pay an annual fee to the EU and to pay a fine if their own cigarettes are seized during smuggling, but there have been few seizures of genuine branded products.  Philip Morris is also actively opposing the Tobacco Products Directive, despite it containing a framework for the tracking and traceability of tobacco products. There are 700 000 smoking-related premature deaths every year in the EU and we should not be extending agreements that do not work. Instead, Labour MEPs want to see the Tobacco Products Directive framework up and running, and new proposals for tackling unbranded cigarettes.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing ‒ Illicit trade in tobacco products and cigarette smuggling costs national and EU budgets an estimated €10 billion in lost public revenue per year. The agreement with the PMI expires on 9 July 2016 and the main objective of this agreement has been met. However, the reduction in the volume of smuggled cigarettes has not led to an overall reduction in the number of illegal products on the EU market. Tobacco products are available in many places at a significant illegal discount, including to young people. Moreover, since counterfeit cigarettes are not only illegally imported but also produced, there is also a risk bordering on the certainty that such products contain unknown and potentially health-threatening ingredients. I therefore supported the Commission's proposal to ratify the Protocol to eliminate illicit trade in tobacco products to the WHO Framework Convention on Tobacco Control and not to continue the policy of agreements with tobacco companies.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the extension of the Agreement with Philip Morris International, which aimed to combat fraud and smuggling of branded cigarettes. I believe that, although the Agreement was useful as an innovative tool to combat illicit tobacco trade when it was negotiated, today markets and the international regulatory framework have undergone significant changes. The agreement does not cover important features of the current illicit tobacco trade, in particular the high percentage of unbranded cigarettes. Therefore, in accordance with the terms in which it was submitted to the European Parliament, I consider that the agreement should not be renewed, extended or renegotiated. Alternatively, the European Commission is asked to take immediate action to ensure the full transposition of the Tobacco Products Directive in all Member States and to present an action plan setting out new measures to tackle the problem of unbranded cigarettes as soon as possible.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. The European Commission signed an agreement in 2004 with the US giant Philip Morris (PMI) which will expire in July 2016 and could therefore be renewed. The aim of the agreement, worth more than eur 1 billion, was to encourage the fight against cigarette smuggling with the cooperation of the multinational tobacco company. However, it turned out that a large proportion of the illegal goods came directly from the producers, who smuggled their own product from secondary locations where it was produced more than the legitimate market required.  The classic paradox in which controller and controlled coincide. The mix between the EU institutions and the tobacco and cigarette multinationals is therefore becoming increasingly obscure. Doubts arise as to why the European Commission has repeatedly postponed the publication of the assessment of the agreement with this tobacco giant. I could only vote in favour of the resolution which, thanks to the action of us the 5-Star Movement, will commit the European Commission not to renew the agreement with Philip Morris. We in the M5S have worked to ensure that the entire European Parliament is in favour of some of our most important battles: the protection of public health, the fight against fraud and maximum transparency.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted against a legislative resolution which calls on the European Commission not to renew or extend the agreement or to negotiate with Philip Morris International (PMI) because I believe that there will be a legislative gap in this case and there will be no need for close supervision and monitoring of the peddling and counterfeiting of PMI tobacco products.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: That concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: First of all, Mr Gollnisch made a personal comment. Mr Gollnisch, please tell us on the basis of which Rule of the Rules of Procedure do you wish to make the personal comment.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, I am relying on Article 164 on personal facts. It was reported to me that, during the votes, the presiding officer, who was none other than you, Mr President, in the face of my insistent request for a reminder of the rules, had stated that he wanted to make tranquilizers available to me if I did not calm down. Let me tell you, Mr President, with all due respect to you and your office, that I find the expression quite contemptuous. But I assure you right now, I am not asking for any sanctions against Mr Schulz. I personally recognize freedom of expression. I simply wanted, by this pointing to the rules, to point out that Section 22 of our Presidential Act, as well as Articles 165 and 166 on the Disciplinary Power of the Speaker, certainly allowed you to expel or sanction a Member who seriously disrupted the sitting, but did not allow you to expel a Member of Parliament who seriously disturbed the sitting, but did not allow you to expel a Member of Parliament who had seriously disturbed the sitting. , at the time you made this decision, did not disturb the sitting in any way, without having heard it and without giving it the opportunity to wash up the accusations you were making against him, which seems to me, in any event, whatever one thinks of his words, rather contrary to the human rights that this Parliament proposes to export to the whole world.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Please very much, Mr Gollnisch.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate with Stefan Löfven, Prime Minister of Sweden, on the current situation in the European Union (2016/2599(RSP)). Dear Prime Minister Löfven, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his excellent work and for his excellent work. I warmly welcome you to the European Parliament. It is a great honour for us that you want to present your ideas on the state of the European Union to us in the European Parliament today. Prime Minister, before I give you the floor, I would point out that, following the decision of the Conference of Presidents on this item on the agenda, we do not allow a catch-the-eye procedure, nor will I accept 'blue cards'.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Prime Minister of Sweden. – Mr President, I thank you very much for the invitation to be here today. It is an honour for me and it is a pleasure.  ‘It was the best of times, it was the worst of times, it was the age of wisdom, it was the age of foolishness, it was the epoch of belief, it was the epoch of incredulity, it was the season of Light, it was the season of Darkness, it was the spring of hope, it was the winter of despair.’. These are the opening lines of Dickens’ ‘A Tale of Two Cities’. He is describing Europe at the end of the 18th century – but he could just as well have been talking about our own times. We have indeed weathered a winter of despair: of terrorists and extremists attempting to attack our fundaments; of Russia continuing to try to move European borders using armed force; of our Union not being able to cope with youth unemployment, social hopelessness and the global refugee crisis.  But there are also some rays of hope in the world. The global climate agreement, the new sustainable development goals, and a large part of the African countries rising from poverty: these all show that we live in a time when global cooperation really can make a difference.  And the EU also has a chance at a spring of hope if standing strong and united against external threats, if tackling common challenges with the collective strength required to resolve them, if clearing away the last ruins of the financial crisis and starting to build strong societies again. I was born in 1957, the same year as the Treaty of Rome. My generation was given vast opportunities and had great hope for the future. To many of us, the world seemed to be ours to explore and to make into a better place.  Now I cannot see a greater duty than to give the same opportunity and hope to the young generation of today. And I know that the European Union can be a driving force for that, if we stand up for three central values of our Union: that is democracy, cooperation and also added value for our citizens. Let me start with democracy. We are currently strengthening our joint action against terrorism following cowardly and appalling attacks against our society. Many of these actions that we are taking are tough, but they are necessary. But the work to defend democracy is a much greater task.  Defending democracy is standing up for the safety of our Jewish citizens at a time when anti-Semitic threats, hatred and violence once again echo throughout Europe. It is never accepting or spreading populists’ and extremists’ demonisation of Muslims, even if it scores cheap points with the electorate. It is working for the rights of the Roma and of all minorities who are held back by prejudice and poverty.  Defending democracy is also defending free and independent media, freedom of reporting and freedom of the press, because we know that politics always benefits from hard scrutiny. Defending democracy is respecting every person’s right to meet, to be tried in free and fair trials, to move freely in society and to love whoever they want. If we do not defend these democratic values, we will lose Europe as we know it. That brings me to my second point, which is cooperation. Rarely have so many people been displaced in the world as they are right now, but rarely have so few European countries stepped up and been prepared to act. During a two-month period last autumn, Sweden took in some 80 000 people at a rate that is equivalent to 25 million asylum seekers annually in the European Union as a whole. This brought our reception system to the brink of collapse and, in the absence of working European solutions, it forced us to take unilateral action. Now the Schengen Agreement and the free movement it creates is a foundation pillar of the European Union, and crucial for our economies. But if we do not act, and act fast, we might lose it. I see a lot of words and plans to move forward, but far too little action. I therefore urge all the Member States to take their responsibility. It is time to act, to ensure control of our external borders, to enhance our cooperation with Turkey on the basis of international law, to implement the redistribution of refugees within the European Union, fight human smuggling and also strengthen our common foreign policy to put a stop to the causes of the refugee crisis. So we must move from chaos to control, otherwise we risk European cooperation as we know it. And, looking ahead, it is time to admit that the Dublin Regulation is not working and needs to be replaced. If we do not create a new, common and sustainable asylum system, more countries will be forced to act unilaterally, which will hurt mobility, trade and – most of all – it will hurt the human beings who are fleeing. Sweden is ready – and will act – for a new asylum system in the EU that is based on equal distribution, and in which asylum is sought in the EU – not in an individual country. Quite simply, to put it shortly, if we are to share an external border and have free movement between our countries, we must also share a system of asylum reception. To be honest, I cannot see how countries that do not participate in the common asylum system can participate in Schengen cooperation either. This brings me to my third point, and that is the added value for our citizens. Now we have shown that we are ready to work hard to keep together, as we have recently done to help to keep the United Kingdom within our Union. But the complaints against the European Union all over our continent should not be brushed aside. These complaints show us the dire need to emphasise that special something that keeps us together – the European spirit, the shared value of cooperation for our citizens.  We need to demonstrate the value of 28 countries and 508 million inhabitants joining together: to address challenges such as climate change that no country can manage alone, in this time of global interdependence; to create an even larger common market, in this time of global competition; and to generate greater security for our people, in this time of global unease. But if EU cooperation is to truly gain the broad popular support that is needed to stay strong in the 21st century, we must have a Union that works much harder for the wellbeing of the people, the citizens. In a world where 62 people own as much as 3.5 billion people, in such a world, we need a European Union that works for equality and everyone’s chance to pursue their innermost hopes for a good life. This is why we need to build a social Europe that strengthens people through more secure jobs, better living conditions and strengthens enterprises through more secure access to citizens with purchasing power. Because when people and enterprises are strengthened, economies grow. In a social Europe, the EU is a prime advocate for good terms and conditions for everyone working in the Union, making sure that workers are never forced to compete against each other through lower wages or poorer working conditions. Ensuring that in a tricky world of global subcontractors, there is always someone who is responsible for ensuring that you are safe at work. In a social Europe, the EU should work to unleash the energy of a growing labour force. If women were employed to the same extent as men in the European Union, GDP could grow or increase some 12% by 2030.  So the EU must not only act as a sentinel for sound finances, it must also act as a driving force for women’s entry into the labour market and a truly equal world of work. This is as ethically right as it is economically smart. In a social Europe, the EU should take a collective stand against the youth unemployment that is breaking down the youth and also breaking down our economies and our societies’ faith in the future.  So we should prioritise investment in education, expand exchanges of European students between not only higher education institutions but also upper secondary schools. And create the jobs for the future for young people via social investment, ambitious free trade agreements and a digital internal market. This is the kind of social Europe that can win the hearts of the people in Europe. The Commission’s proposal for amending the Posting of Workers Directive and the development of the social pillar show that the work is finally and truly under way, which I welcome. Taking steps towards more decent working conditions and social progress is paramount. So let us continue onwards and upwards. Let us come together for a summit and draw up a strategy to move this idea of a social Europe forward, and I would be pleased and honoured to host such a summit in Sweden next year in 2017. (Applause) We are working for an EU that works hard for the size of the market, yes, but even harder for the wellbeing of its people. I see Parliament and the Commission as key actors on all three issues. I can feel in this very Hall and in our Union that we carry the ability to create the same hope that I felt as the generation of 1957, for the generations of 1997, 2007, 2017, and many generations to come. So Europe’s winter of despair has been long and hard. But if we stand up for democracy when democracy is tested, if we cooperate and turn words into deeds to address the migration crisis, and if we create a social Europe that increases the wellbeing in people’s everyday lives, then we will be able – in these best of times and in these worst of times – to create a new spring of hope in Europe. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, President Juncker has asked me to replace him in this debate and convey his greetings. Yes, it is the best of times and it is the worst of times but, above all, it is the time for us in Europe to stand up for our values and be counted. Prime Minister, I am very honoured to welcome you in this Chamber, where you have just done exactly that. Thank you. Sweden is a country that has shaped its own destiny with values and the conviction that we can live and work together and provide for a fair society. You have also influenced those beyond your borders – the rest of us in Europe. I will just recall that, together with your Scandinavian partners, you were the first to understand the value of free movement: it was the then Nordic Council which, in the 1950s, launched free travel and the original labour market for the first time. Your achievement has served you very well and it is serving Europe very well. Today, on behalf of our President, I would like to pay tribute to Sweden’s response to the refugee crisis. Your country has long received the highest number of people seeking protection, way before the current crisis started. Your solidarity is a shining light. When a country so far north in the Union is affected so directly by events to the south, we know we are in this together. No country can manage this crisis alone and no country should be left alone, be it Greece, Sweden, Austria or Germany. No country can carry the weight on its own. Together we have to protect our borders. Together we have to help people who depend on us for their survival. We recognise the effort Sweden has made and we have suspended the relocation of refugees to Sweden from Greece and Italy. That is pragmatic and fair.  Today, as you have said, in most parts of Europe we need to restore order. We need to restore the Schengen system. Your country knows the cost of life without Schengen. I was struck by how costly it is to have border controls on the Øresund Bridge between Sweden and Denmark – the costs run into hundreds of millions of euros a month. Last Friday, the Commission published a roadmap setting out the steps to restore Schengen to full health and lift all internal borders by December 2016 at the latest. This gives us an opportunity to make Schengen more resilient. We have to learn from the crisis that the system works only if we all participate: otherwise it does not work at all. That is why, obviously, we all have to pull together. At the Commission we are not interested in pointing the finger. We are interested in solutions and in helping Member States – all Member States – to bear a shared responsibility for restoring and protecting Schengen. Prime Minister, let me turn to a second topic which you touched upon and which also has to do with values in Europe: Europe’s social model. It is one of our greatest achievements. Far more than a way to organise our economy, it is part of who we are, it is part of our treaties and it is part of our identity. Sweden has written entire chapters in this story. Listening to you and your government, you are holding the pen and still writing. Thank you for that.  What we have demonstrated to the rest of the world is that our social market economy can have prosperity and social justice going hand in hand. My former employer, the World Bank, called the European Union a lifestyle superpower because of the standards we have established for our citizens – standards in gender equality, in public health and in the environment, and above all in our welfare system. Our challenge is to adapt this model to a world which is changing much faster than in the years that you and I were born.  With this in mind – the need to constantly adapt – we at the Commission have launched a proposal for a European pillar of social rights. It sets out principles and practices to ensure that work is decent and fair and that we meet our goals of equal opportunity, fair conditions and proper social protection. It is about delivering fairness for individuals and also building resiliency into our labour market and our economy. By revealing the gaps in the current legislation, the pillar will show what measures we still need to take. Let me make one final point. Over many decades, Sweden has embodied European values, values of equality, values of compassion for people seeking protection, and today you are showing that these values are very strong. We are going to respond to the greatest test of our time. These values are the light that we ought to follow. There is a European solution. And that, moreover, is the only solution.  I would like to thank you, Prime Minister, and to thank Sweden, for being such a key part of it.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Madam Vice-President and Prime Minister, welcome here! It is good to hear a Social Democratic Prime Minister, as well as other representatives of Sweden, so clearly emphasize that Sweden is behind European cooperation, strong and stable.  We live in a time when the crises come from outside – Russia, Syria, Russia in Syria, ISIS, terrorism, the climate issue, the refugees – and present the fundamental values of our society to great challenges. It is only through a strong Europe that we can deal with this, and that is why I would like to say never: 'We have to solve all these problems next week, otherwise cooperation will have failed'.  We will need this cooperation for a very long time, because the problems we face are greater than the existence of a simple solution and a decision. Instead of always asking ourselves what europe can do for us, we have to ask ourselves what we can do for Europe. I know that wording has been used in the past, but that is what we have to do. On social issues, do not weaken European cooperation by taking them from the national parliaments to the European Parliament. Then we have the conflicts, then we get the over-regulation, then we get the bureaucracy that people around Europe turn against.  What is first said in the British debate, and which many of us in Sweden also share, is that there is too much bureaucracy. We are going to cut red tape and we are going to make things easier from here by removing a jungle of national regulations that hinder the development of the economy. A free trade agreement with the United States, stable public finances. I would like the Prime Minister to talk to those in his own groups who believe that you get more money by spending more money than you have. The refugee issue: our country has taken a very great responsibility there. We must ensure that there is a burden-sharing. We have to make sure we follow the rules. This also applies to the Öresund Bridge. When we introduce controls, we should follow the rules and not impose a carrier liability. As far as refugees are concerned, we must ensure that the other countries take responsibility, ensure that borders are complied with and ensure that the necessary responsibilities are assumed throughout Europe. With regard to Turkey: clear demands for democracy and freedom of the press. In this cooperation, we must make Turkey more democratic and more legally state-owned if we are to protect the people whose fates are at stake.  And Prime Minister, remember, we're going to make Europe strong. It will take a lot for a long time, but together we will make it.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Prime Minister, in your impassioned speech you spoke of democracy and cooperation. he spoke, that is, of values. Well, I believe that the real battle for the future of Europe is not about military action. In Syria as elsewhere, the battle for Europe is first and foremost a battle for values. We must show that we can adapt the European Union to the global transformations of recent decades, without having lost, indeed strengthening, our values. Above all, there is a value that is above all: the value of solidarity, a word that in this Europe torn apart by nationalism and selfishness may no longer be fashionable but remains the foundation of the European Union. Solidarity and dignity were two values dear to Olof Palme, whose 30th anniversary we remembered a few days ago. I like to remember one of his sentences. Palme said , "for us democracy is a matter of human dignity and human dignity is political freedom". Dignity and solidarity. Solidarity means, first and foremost, solidarity with those who are oppressed and flee from wars. You mentioned impressive numbers: 80 000 refugees from Sweden. Thank you, Prime Minister!  It is clear that, faced with the new international context, states alone cannot cope and Europe is needed. Sweden, Germany or Italy or another Member State cannot do everything on their own. We need a common European asylum system in addition to a review of Dublin, as you have indicated. Solidarity today means fighting for the social Europe that you rightly mentioned: not a Europe that divides workers, but a union that unites them, giving them the same protections. This means recognising that all workers, whatever their nationality, are paid for the same work.  Our group, also thanks to the important contribution of the delegation from your country, has obtained the maintenance and commitment of the Juncker Commission to the presentation of the Posted Workers Directive and we welcome this presentation and we will endeavour to ensure that this vision succeeds with all its most positive developments.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Three weeks ago in Strasbourg, we were talking about two Members who were talking about firing orders outside the House. I wanted to tell you that yesterday the group leadership of our group decided to encourage these two Members to leave our group by 31 March. (Applause) Prime Minister, this is the first time that I have received applause from this side of the House, and probably the last time, Prime Minister, you have mentioned twice that you were born in 1957. In 1957, as a hamburger, I cycled to Gothenburg for the first time without gear shifts and was enthusiastic about your country. Today I must also shout to you three times: happy Swede!  For the first time, because your government steadfastly refuses to adopt the euro. In 1998, as President of the Federation of German Industries, I was invited to the Stockholm Chamber of Commerce to promote the euro. Well, the Swedish people were smarter than Swedish industry and, I have to say, wiser than I was. In Sweden, the population was allowed to vote on the euro – in Germany, people are allowed to vote on a railway station. Whether it's unemployment, economic growth or public debt, Sweden is doing much better than the eurozone.  You, Prime Minister, are showing not only the social democratic party friends here, but all the Euromantics in this Parliament, that a currency must correspond to the fiscal cultures of the country and that we should stop subjecting the different fiscal cultures to the needs of a currency. You also show that small can be beautiful, and you also show that Europe suffers not from too little, but from too much.  Second, you have chosen a responsible refugee policy in Sweden. As a long-standing member of Amnesty International, I know how difficult you have been to control your borders now. Prime Minister, that was not irresponsible, as many here accuse you, that was responsible. Of the asylum seekers or applications registered in Europe last year, 72.3% were men. What this can mean for some municipalities in terms of social policy, I do not want to say here – Cologne, for example. But I want to talk about something else. Has anyone here ever thought about what it means for these men to leave their wives, their daughters, their mothers, their sisters alone and unprotected? By the way, most of these refugees came from areas that are not currently contested, but from undoubtedly precarious but safe camps. Has anyone ever thought about how many people put their lives in danger or lost because they accepted the invitation of the German Government and believed in the promises of irresponsible smugglers? This brings me to the third reason to say 'happy Sweden' here today. In the euro and refugee policy, the German government has driven not only its own people, but also Europe, into a dead end with its policy of attitude. By contrast, the Swedish Government is pursuing a policy of responsibility. You don't have to worry about the fact that your country has now lost the position of moral superpower to Merkel's Germany – any more than the Germans should be proud of this dubious title.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: On the other: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to welcome the Prime Minister here to the European Parliament today. It's nice that you're sharing this afternoon with us. As you know, Sweden is a medium-sized Member State of the EUROPEAN Union, and I would urge the Prime Minister to take advantage of this. I know that you in the Swedish Government agree with me that the Dublin Regulation, that is, the cornerstone of a functioning European asylum policy, must be reformed. I will lead that work here in Parliament and look forward to our continued cooperation on this. But now I ask you, Stefan Löfven, to take the lead in the Council of Ministers and convince the other governments of the need to create a solidarity-based, sustainable asylum policy in the EU. That is the only way we can jointly bring about real change that is needed now more than ever. Unfortunately, Sweden has gone from being a country that has dared to take battles in the Council of Ministers, and which with weight and credibility in asylum and migration issues has been able to influence other Member States in the right direction, to the fact that nowadays is increasingly regarded as a country that is rather passively following the current and repeats the mantra: "people on the run are the responsibility of someone else and not ours". That is not how we lead the work towards common European responsibility. The agreement with Turkey on Monday will not resolve the situation in the long term. There is much evidence that the essential elements of it are contrary to the Geneva Convention and also to the EU Treaties. Even if many of the people who are now trying to get to europe are stopped, they will find other ways to get to Europe and not everyone can stay in Greece. If we do not have a European asylum policy in which everyone participates, no Member State will be able to do this. We will see repeated examples of the Greek tragedy taking place across europe. Instead of outsourcing our responsibility for the refugees to Turkey, the EU should now secure its own external borders, create legal safe routes for refugees and secure an asylum system in which responsibility is shared fairly among all 28 countries. Migration cooperation with Turkey can only work if there is a common border guard and a common asylum policy.  Stefan Löfven, take the initiative now and build good coalitions with the other countries. Show leadership and tell us which countries in the Council are putting a spanner in the works. Now the happy days in the Council of Ministers must be over, because we have a good Swedish practice of openness and transparency that should guide the Council as well. One of the EUROPEAN leaders has to break the race to the bottom, and I would like it to be the government of my own country that did it. Europe simply deserves much, much more than we are doing at the moment.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Prime Minister, welcome to the European Parliament!  Sweden has taken great responsibility in 2015 for receiving people on the run. That is right and good, but then something happened in the autumn and you made a case with the right-wing opposition parties about closing our borders. I think that was the wrong decision, but that is not what we are going to debate here.  The important thing today is that we face the same situation and the same challenge at European level. Should Europe accept refugees and organise a dignified reception, or should we argue that europe too needs breathing space and closing its borders? What role will Sweden play in that choice? For me, the answers are obvious, Prime Minister.  The EU as a whole has received a prosely small proportion of the people who are on the run today. We should, of course, share and receive more, dignified, and I believe, of course, that Sweden should be a leader in this development, in a political change of course for the EU that ensures that we do not close our borders.  Unfortunately, I do not see enough of that role in the Council. Let me be clear, a new superborder police with extraordinary powers to forcibly reject and act in third countries and intervene without consent in a Member State is not a solution. NATO patrols in the Mediterranean are not a solution and, last but not least, the deal with Turkey with mass expulsions is not a solution. Refugees are not fishing quotas that we unload and unload. It is people of flesh and blood who have fled and left everything in conflict.  Prime Minister, I'm not naïve. I see that it is not possible to get Orbán and some other countries on board. The EU-28 has reached the end of the road, whatever people here say, both morally and politically. That is why you need a plan B based on a coalition of willing Member States, which wants to take the lead in close cooperation with the UNHCR, who was here yesterday and spoke very wisely. You can use the European institutions even in a smaller coalition.  Finally, it is not worthy of a Social Democratic government here in Europe or in any country to set refugees against welfare. It only plays into the hands of the racists, and you cannot work with them. We do not yet know what 2016 will be, but it is pretty much up to us here and up to you in the Council. Is it going to be the year we erected the walls or is it going to be the year of solidarity with the refugees?

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to thank you for bringing such a calm tone to the debate on the state of the European Union, because I believe that we all need it, even though I am thinking back to the debate on this morning's summit. A little thought about what else there are besides the refugee question, I think that is very, very necessary for us. I would also like to thank you, Sweden, your country, because I believe that you have been doing better refugee policy in the European Union for a long time, not just in the crisis of last year. And when you returned to border controls, my impression was: Aha, that is now the wake-up call from Sweden. The Swedes say that we can no longer, we are resorting to a means that we do not want, but we want a European solution. However, the search for this European solution has continued ever since, and this closure of borders has developed almost in the snowball system. I do not know how much time we have left to deal with it. We are dealing with global changes and global challenges, and in the European Council it looks as if we are thinking that we have a lot of time. I would like to know from you whether it is not time at some point to say that a group of states is moving forward in certain areas of refugee policy and saying that we are the group of states that is actually prepared to provide solidarity with each other in terms of taking in more refugees. Everything we discuss with Turkey is to be criticised. It is partly a small step forward. But where do we end up if we cannot distribute refugees behind management on an external border between Turkey and Greece? I believe that what you said in your speech is incredibly important, that we in the European Union manage to turn against new fears and against fear-mongers. Mr Henkel, if you apologise now for your achievements in introducing the euro, I do not want to know what kind of sin register you have as the chief lobbyist of the Federation of German Industries. But a sin that really is not plead is the founding of the Alternative for Germany, because you have thus laid the foundation in Germany for the fact that this climate of fear and incitement has also become much worse for us. Europeans must then start to fear when they are no longer able to act together in the face of the global challenges that the refugees have brought to us, which we have tried to displace time and again. And we need to talk about this common action. The demands on the richer and more stable countries of the world will not diminish, but will become more. Yesterday, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees actually gave us another good global overview. In the face of the escalation by Putin and Assad in Syria, we have clearly seen that this war will not end quickly. As Europeans, we will only get out of these catastrophic intensifications well together, we will only show solidarity if we also show solidarity with others. In this sense, Mr Löfven, I really found your speech a comforting contribution from the Council.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Stefan Löfven, you have said yourself that we in Sweden have been naïve in our reception of refugees. You may have inherited the sinking of the Reinfeldt government's sinking migration ship, but the irresponsible policy you have been in for a year and a half has made the situation many times worse. Due to countries such as Sweden, the EU's migration policy situation has developed into an economic, political and humanitarian chaos. Today you are standing here in plenary and want to impose the consequences of your naïve policy on the whole of Europe. You ask other Member States to 'save yourself in need' when it is you who have made a fool of yourself.  The EU Member States must take joint responsibility, you say. Your government must take more responsibility and actively contribute to ending mass migration to the EU, I say. Do you really believe in compulsive distribution? How will this solution ever work? Many Member States do not have the resources, the capacity or the political will to integrate the huge number of migrants. Country after country, dissociate yourself from the redistributive mechanism you are promoting.  Stefan Löfven, you get to bite the sour apple, and realize that Sweden's really big problem instead is how we, on our own, will be able to deport the approximately 80,000 migrants that your government announced will leave Sweden. How are we going to do that? We can't even evacuate 30 asylum seekers from a bus!

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – We used to go to Sweden with our family in the early 1980s. Sweden was then a beautiful country, beautiful, prosperous and safe. I even spoke about Sweden when I was about eleven years old. And I was able to report that Sweden was at the forefront of women's rights, that Swedish schoolchildren were among the best performers in Europe and that the Swedish national government was also open and transparent.  Last year I went on holiday in Sweden with my own children. I'm freaked out. What can a country change! My daughter, 12, is now speaking about Sweden. She has to tell her classmates that Sweden is the country with the second highest rape rate in the world. Only in Lesotho is a woman less safe!  The rape rate - I say it again - is the second highest in the world in Sweden, higher than in Mexico, Nigeria or Russia. My daughter must now also report that the Swedish Government is withholding information so as not to play into the hands of political opponents. And the school performance of Swedish children is going down enormously.  Mr President, I am shocked. How can a country deteriorate like this in 30 years? There is only one way to do this, namely because of the EU and the devastating effect of the EU. The EU fails and draws Sweden into its slipstream. This is the failure of the EU, this is the failure of the political elite.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Daniel Friebe, a Swedish economist and writer who lives in Budapest now, said that one of the best things about Hungary is that people, unlike western Europeans, still believe in conservative values. We don't just believe in it, we want to make our decisions in that spirit. You believe in liberal values. Accordingly, for decades, 100,000 refugees and immigrants have been accepted, taking on economic hardship, coexistence difficulties and an increase in crime. It's your decision! It's a sovereign decision of a sovereign country. But accept that there are countries that do not want to take in tens and hundreds of thousands of migrants who protect their own culture, who do not want to build a society in parallel. Hungary is the same, and you have talked about democracy, accept that we want to strengthen the political decision in Hungary by referendum on this issue – as a sovereign decision of a sovereign country.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, the refugee crisis is the worst humanitarian emergency we have had in Europe since World War II and we will not solve it with inhumane solutions. Mr Prime Minister, building a wall or closing a border does not end the migrant crisis. All it does is more inhumane the desperate flight of men, women and children, and it dehumanizes us Europeans. We Europeans are equal in difficulty and we must be, it is true, equal in responsibility. That is why we support a common immigration and asylum policy here, which is why here we support a common management of our external borders, in order to protect the Schengen area. National solutions do not solve European problems, on the contrary. That is precisely why Europe exists; because, at present, national solutions do not even solve national problems. For example, his Government unilaterally decides to reintroduce border controls, including forcibly for private transport companies to conduct examinations, to identify those they transport. For example, your Government has approved the possibility of suspending Schengen for three years, when the rule only allows a two-year suspension. These, Mr Prime Minister, are national, popular, defensive solutions, and they are insufficient solutions which, surely, in your opinion, are good for Sweden. The Socialists of this House, like the greens of this House, like us, are defending a Europe without borders. Even this morning they spoken very harshly against the agreement with Turkey. His Government, however, has once again erected barriers to the migrant crisis in the face of the refugee crisis. Which one of us is the real socialist discourse? Which one of us is the real green speech? Europe must be built little by little because, when we stop building Europe, nationalism grows again, and with nationalism always xenophobia, with nationalism fanaticism always grows and populism grows. Europe's motto is "United in Diversity", but today it must also be "United – not separated – in adversity". Mr Prime Minister, you have asked for a more social Europe, but it draws my attention that, at the same time calling for a more social Europe, when faced with the most social of problems, which is the flight of refugees, it once again raises its borders. Maybe if what we said matched what we do, the populists wouldn't be right.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you for being here, Stefan Löfven. It's good and it's important. You hear how the walking legends and all the completely unreasonable claims fly through the air. They often do in this House, and that's why it's so nice to have you here. I would like to return to talking about inequality, the one that is growing throughout Europe. We currently have 23 million registered openly unemployed and we know that in reality there are many more. All over Europe – and yes, even in this room – there are those who think that, in this situation, we should face this crisis, this unemployment with low wages and worse conditions and that we should have a labour market that is segregated both between European citizens and the new arrivals who come here, who at the same time should have even worse conditions. This is despite the fact that it leads to even greater inequalities and even more unequal, unfair conditions in the labour market. We Social Democrats want to put an end to social dumping, of wage dumping. After all, competition with poorer conditions and low wages is dragging down everyone, not just those who are at the forefront. Commission President Juncker has put it as 'no social dumping - equal pay for equal work'. It must be a given, but I feel this way: can we really trust That Juncker can make this a real deal?
