I'm sure he believes it, but does he have the power to make it a reality? Today, there are too many who lack confidence in the ability of politics. They turn to extreme parties, ones that you hear noises and rumbles up there – they are like the AIK heel, if I suddenly think about what it looks like at home, and sometimes it is worse. They turn to extreme parties, voters who do not think they are getting answers to their questions. If we do not manage to push back unemployment and stop social dumping, we run the risk of even more people giving up on politics and turning to the extremists. It can't happen. Yesterday, the Commission presented various proposals to strengthen a social Europe. It was about a change in the posting of workers directive, about giving back power to the social partners, about jobs and education. Do you think that will be enough for us to achieve the goal of equal pay for equal work – equal pay for equal work?

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Welcome to the European Parliament, Prime Minister Stefan Löfven. You come to us at a time that is quite difficult for the European Union. We have been grappling with a climate challenge where we need to find our solutions for the future. We are grappling with a migration challenge where we must also find our solutions, and we are also grappling with an increasingly fractured Europe marked by a Brexit debate and an increasing number of populists spreading across the European Union. That is why I am glad that you are here and that is why our debate today is very, very important.  I would like to begin by praising the Prime Minister, because I have rarely heard you as clearly as you were just now in your speech on migration policy. You were clear that if we have taken joint decisions, there must also be consequences if we do not follow them. I think it was very honourable for the Prime Minister to take the leader's jersey there, because I have asked for that many times, most recently in recent days in the media. At the same time, we have seen quite clearly how the Council has taken decisions on several occasions with which nothing is happening. This risks making the Council an impotent part of the European Union. What difference does it make what decisions we take here or in the Council if it is not actually the workshop of those decisions? The area of migration is just one of the areas where we must ensure that the decisions taken also receive political delivery. What I have more doubts about, however, is the idea of social Europe. Is it not the case that the Prime Minister himself was involved in talks with David Cameron, thereby declaring social Europe dead? What started there was of course to roll back what the Social Democrats have been pushing in the election campaign, what has been one of the government's parade branches. I am thinking about how the Prime Minister sees it being connected, the work that the Prime Minister himself did with David Cameron and what he said in this House? I am a little worried that the Social Democrats have lost their idea for Europe. Like my colleague Gunnar Hökmark, I am keen that the Social Democrats support a strong Europe. It was the Social Democratic Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson who brought Sweden into Europe. It was the Social Democratic Prime Minister Goran Persson who embraced the enlargement of the EU. It was the nonsocialist Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt who brought Sweden to the heart of the European cooperation. But what is the current government's idea of tomorrow's Europe?

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his work I would not have thought, and so the European Parliament is always good for surprises, that I can say directly to the speech of an ALDE Member: yes, that is exactly the question I would like to ask you now. I think it is very good that you have come here and say that we are at a very critical time in the European Union, and we must do something to ensure that we get out of this together, and we can only do that if this is done in solidarity and really democratically and together. But then it also says: yes, we need a social Europe. At the same time, however, as a member of the Council – and as I am addressing you here – you are partly responsible for the fact that a deal has been struck with the United Kingdom that not only puts this social Europe to the test, but also puts away an essential side of this social Europe. I think it is very worrying that we are now putting to the test important regulations, which we have just found in connection with the free movement of workers from the Member States of the European Union, and finally to say that we are suspending one of these essential pillars – including the fundamental freedoms of the European Union. In this context, I would also like to say that if colleagues here say that there is a contradiction among you by saying that we want a social Europe and, on the other hand, you want to advocate a common solution to the refugee issue, then I say that this is precisely what belongs together. We will never achieve a democratic, social Europe if we start to share human rights, divide them by nation, by country of origin, and when we say that we are not coming together and trying to resolve this together. I expect you – and Here I fully agree with my colleague Malin Björk, who spoke earlier – that we expect you to take the first step. It is not acceptable that, as in the disarmament negotiations, we are waiting for everyone to find a common solution, but that no one is taking the first step. Please take the first step towards a common European solution to the refugee issue.

name: Peter ERIKSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Prime Minister, welcome! The recent European Council deal with Turkey leaves a series of difficult questions unanswered. It is good if Sweden has received wordings on respecting international law and international agreements on asylum, but how it should be achieved is far from clear. I would therefore like to ask the Prime Minister a few questions about this.  Greece believes that Turkey should be regarded as a safe country on these issues, but Sweden does not. But surely the EU should have a common position on this issue? Otherwise, it is the choice that determines whether the refugee should be sent back, not where you come from or whether you have asylum reasons. If the Greek road is effectively closed, what other routes will people choose instead? Are they safer? Is there any analysis on this? Are you sure this agreement won't make the situation even worse for those fleeing? How will the Swedish Government act in the near future to get all these questions answered, so that we can say that the EU stands up for the right of asylum? Is there an idea of how the Swedish government will work to clear this up? And finally, a more personal question for you, Stefan. Do you yourself, after all these meetings and negotiations, really have hope for your colleagues in the European Council to take responsibility and agree to distribute future refugee flows in a reasonable and solidarity-based manner?

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Then we are finally here. Two regular working-class guys who got into the world of politics. The welder and the truck driver. We are both members of IF Metall and we both believe in the Swedish model, but it is also about where the similarities end between us, I would say. While Stefan Löfven and his government have lived in naivety, where mistakes have been made after mistakes on each other, I and other representatives of my party have for a long time very clearly pointed out what would result from both the naïve signal policy of both the previous and current governments. Measures that my party has long proposed, and which led to ridiculous epithets from Stefan Löfven in debates, are now being used by both the government and the nonsocialists. Your hypocrisy is gigantic. Germany and Sweden bear a great responsibility for the situation that we are now in and which affects the Swedish welfare model extremely hard. Every week we see municipalities on their knees and sign up themselves because the systems can not cope more. This is at the same time as more than 60% of those who come to the EU today, according to the EU, are economic migrants, and at the same time as over 16 000 children die every day in the world because of the lack of clean water and food. Stefan, you say you're happy with the deal for England after the meeting in Brussels. Then my question to you is Stefan: When will you and your government demand the same and if not, why should Sweden, which has paid over 160 billion kronor to the EU since joining the EU, also demand a similar deal? Sweden has become a dissuasive example in the eyes of many, and I blame this entirely on the crippling political correctness of the current government in particular.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In Europe, no stone will be left unto the other. I recently read this in a very good commentary, and that has given me a lot to think about and has taken me deeply. Listening to the debate today, the contributions of some colleagues, such as Mrs Harms or Mrs Björk, i am even more intries, because I wonder: are these ladies living on a different planet from the rest of this? So much of what you hear is actually a borderline dangerous naivety that comes out here. If you look at the crisis, this migration crisis, the procedures and the completely uncoordinated and completely headless approach of those responsible in the European Union, we know that it is precisely these people who have played a very significant part in making the crisis worse as we are now experiencing. At the moment, the situation proves even more that the individual Member States, which can also make proper use of their competences, have far more problem-solving powers than this European Union. In Austria, we are already seeing that the government is adopting one-to-one ideas from the Freedom Party, and without much obfuscation tactics, but these ideas are being adopted and implemented there. The actions of the Merkel Union have brought us – the European Union and Europe – into a major crisis. The only solutions that we see and where we see that they work come mainly from the eastern states. And a small statistic: for every 100 asylum applications from people from Algeria last year in Austria, 155 crimes were committed – not harmless offences, mind you. And you know – as has already been mentioned today – 75% of asylum seekers are men. Cologne still has a horrible memory for all of us. I ask you: do we want all this to happen? In Graz, my hometown, women can no longer even walk through the city park untroubled. Do we want that? I would like to say a big thank you to Orban Viktor for preventing this somewhat windy deal with Turkey, at least in the first round.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Mr President, unfortunately the current situation in the European Union could not be described as the best. The problems are many and, instead of trying to provide solutions, with constant postponements and delays they accumulate even more. In particular in the countries of the South unemployment, youth unemployment, cuts in wages and pensions, the collapse of the health system are very important issues. Migration and economics are prominent on the agenda and we have focused there, ignoring other equally important ones on which we could provide solutions. Ideological anchorages and the purposes of political groups that had learned not to hear different voices and opinions undermine both the sense of democracy and the right to self-identify other political views. In democracy there are no measures and red lines. We don't weigh more or less democracy. Ideologies in Europe are not supposed to be persecuted, as are different views. History for some countries has been written and is not embellished, as some people wish, so we must not forget the past in order to move forward. As a European Union, we either change or sink.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask you for some explanation, taking advantage of your presence. Because you in the Council support PNR, that is, the passenger register, while your party and government colleagues here in Parliament reject it all the time. And then, how do you explain your country's change of course, from an open-door policy to a policy of closed doors, with restrictions on asylum applications that are totally at odds with the lines of socialists and greens always here in the European Parliament?  Above all, however, I would like to ask you, Prime Minister: how is it possible that in Sweden too, a model of acceptance of tolerance, of equal opportunities, we see an increase in the dramatic phenomenon of anti-Semitism? Even in Malmö, the city that welcomed thousands of Jews fleeing Nazism in 1943, there have been several episodes of intolerance. But so alarming that the few hundred Jews who still live there, according to a documentary broadcast on television, are afraid to leave the house, do not feel safe and are thinking of leaving the city. Of course, Stockholm is another story, but we are concerned.  Over and above the fine and fair words you have spoken here, I would like to know what your government intends to do, because even a minister has said things that, if true, would be disturbing. But I say to you, Prime Minister, that if the Jews, who helped to build European culture, think that Europe, that Sweden is no longer a safe place for them, is no longer their home, believe me, the lights of hope will go out and the winter of despair will be long and dark.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, it is a great pleasure to receive the Prime Minister here at the European Parliament. Prime Minister, you are coming with a strong pro-European voice, building on the Swedish experience. Sweden does, of course, have several problems, but it remains one of the best examples to be followed in the European Union as a whole. First of all, when it comes to democracy, as you have just mentioned, you have high standards of representative democracy in Sweden.  Secondly, Sweden remains one of the best examples of how we can push for sustainable development combining the economic, social and environmental dimensions while delivering a stronger recovery with good jobs. Finally, Sweden remains a good example of a high degree of engagement with international responsibilities. I know that you are very committed to working for a global new deal.  Of course, in spite of the problems, Sweden remains a very important positive example as to how to integrate the refugees. Well let me say that I recently went again to Sweden to get some inspiration and I would like to tell the House what I saw. Sweden is managing a very big flow of refugees. Firstly, I saw refugees being received decently at the border; secondly, I saw them being distributed across the country in many municipalities, where they could find decent housing and access to basic social services. Then I saw very well—organised programmes for retraining and integrating refugees into the labour market. So that was the reality which I saw in Sweden. What I conclude from this is that these are very simple and nonetheless very humane things to do, and they can be done – as Sweden is proving – and should be done throughout Europe.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you, Prime Minister, for being here. I hope you have found the debate of the last hour interesting, general and fruitful. You are talking about a social Europe, but you did not mention the elephant in the room. The EU has a misconstructed and dysfunctional monetary union that has helped exacerbate the economic crisis and keep millions of people in unemployment. It is clear that Sweden made the right decision when we turned down the possibility of joining EMU in our referendum. But I often hear from Members of this House that Sweden does not have the right to remain free from monetary union for as long as possible. They do not respect the choice of the Swedish people, and I believe that in the long term it would be good and safer if Sweden were given a clear treaty-based derogation from EMU, just as many other countries have. I also believe that, in the long term, we need to ensure that good conditions are created for all those countries of the European Union that do not want to join monetary union. Security guarantees are needed for those countries, to ensure that the decisions taken by the EU are good for everyone and not just for some. I hope that Sweden can take a leading role in ensuring that this is the case.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: Prime Minister of Sweden. – Mr President, I wish to thank everyone very much for the discussion and all the interventions. Naturally, I cannot answer everyone but I will do my best to give my view on the different things that have been raised.  First, to Gunnar Hökmark. My point is not to deliver a lot of new rules that will burden companies, when I talk about social Europe, but my point is this: we have a common economy, we have a common labour market and in this labour market we need a future for those who are working, those who are actually delivering the wealth that we are trying to distribute , and I cannot see the smart thing in showing people a negative future – your wages will perhaps go down, your working conditions might worsen. That is not the future that the European people are looking for.  We have a common interest, a common responsibility to make sure that the European labour market is guided by some very important values and, at the same time, give the different countries the possibility to rule in the way they see fit. But the Laval case we saw in 2007 – the ruling on the Laval case showing that the Swedish trade unions could not defend collective agreements – that was wrong.  It would have been very easy to say, of course, if Sweden has collective agreements then protect them as long as you do not discriminate against anyone who comes into the country, but if the workers, the employees of Europe, are looking at a future when they are supposed to compete with lower wages, then I can assure you that those people will not be in favour of this cooperation.  So let us promise ourselves, one another, that we should develop a labour market in Europe that is a promising future, and let us realise that those women and men who go to work every day, they are the ones who really make a difference and they are the ones to whom we should be giving good conditions and a future.  There have been a lot of interventions of course about the refugee crisis. My message is this. We have and we will have refugees in the world, unfortunately. The problem, as some say, is that this is Sweden’s problem; Sweden has caused the problem because we received refugees. The problem is the crisis in Syria and the crisis in the Middle East that forces people to flee because they are afraid, they are terrorised, they are in the middle of a war. That is the real problem. And I think it is a human thing to say to people who are fleeing for their lives that yes, we need to help you.  We can do that in different ways. We need to help to solve the problem that causes the people to actually have to flee. That is the root thing. You have to help people in the neighbourhood, yes, but those who actually arrive – are you going to shut the door? Some parties think so. I think it is human to say that we also need to help people who are fleeing for their lives.  And we are in this organisation together, 28 member countries, and if we had done this together we would have solved it. It would not have been a problem. We are 508 million inhabitants on this continent. We could have solved it together. And it is alright for some to say that they will not participate. If they choose to do that, my point is that I think it is fair to say that if you do not participate in this system, the asylum system, perhaps you should not participate in the Schengen system. You cannot just choose the good things, the easy things, and sit in the quiet easy corner. You need sometimes to step up and also do the tricky things, the difficult things. We want a future system that actually distributes the responsibility amongst 28 Member States. Someone asked whether I believed this would happen. I am not sure, I do not know, because I hear the resistance, yes, but this is the only way for the European Union to function well: that we help one another, we assist one another, and those who do not want to participate should consider another thing. If this does not work it will affect the whole European Union, also affecting those who are now sitting in the backseat doing nothing. It will affect them as well. If we want an efficient, really working European Union we need to cooperate also on these difficult issues. That is my point, and I think we need to be clear with one another.  Regarding the agreement with Turkey, yes, I think it is right to do this. I think we need to find a solution, to find that and to have that cooperation with Turkey, otherwise I would not have supported it. I cannot answer all the detailed questions but what would that mean?  President Tusk is now being given a mandate, we gave him a mandate, to negotiate on these principles that we want this trafficking of human beings to stop. We need to do something about it, because those who are against everything also need to show the alternatives. The reality right now is that thousands and thousands of people are risking their lives on the water, in the sea, and we have people that are selling these trips who do not care at all about these lives. We have at least so far, more than 400 people, perhaps 500 people today who have died so far this year, and I think we need to stop it.  This is one way of going. It is not the only solution. No, it is not the only solution but it is one of the things that we need to do and now let us see what the negotiations will bring. We will see that result and then we will discuss it, but I think it is the right thing to do.  I was asked also about the Posting of Workers Directive and the changes, and will that solve everything, if I understood the question correctly. No it will not solve everything but it is a very good step forward, to show the employees, and the employers I would say, of Europe, that we can develop a European labour market that is functioning and that respects collective agreements, or legislation or whatever we choose to develop in our respective countries.  But no matter what way we choose as individual countries the European Union should give that platform, should give that possibility. For our country it means respecting the collective agreement. This is a path that we have chosen. It has been a good path, it has been a very efficient one with wealth, with growth, but also with quite a fair distribution between the citizens of our country and I would like to stick to that path. Therefore, I think what the Commission has proposed now is very good. It is a step forward. It will bring more hope to the employees, the workers of Europe and I think that is a very good start. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – In 2012, the Swedish Parliament adopted a resolution urging the Government of its country to recognize the Democratic Saharawi Arab Republic, a courageous decision in the face of Morocco's economic pressures and hostile reaction. Sweden has repeatedly demonstrated its coherence in the defence of international law in the case of Palestine. Like Israel, Morocco is an occupying state that prevents the free self-determination of the Saharawi people, maintaining a colonial system of exploitation of their lands. From the European United Left/Nordic Green Left we support rasD recognition, as has been the case of the Palestinian State to the United Nations, and will celebrate the fulfilment of the Swedish Parliament's mandate to recognize the Democratic Saharawi Arab Republic. It is fair and international law is without it, so we invite the Swedish Government to take this significant step which would be a step towards resolving the conflict of a people who have been suffering from the Moroccan occupation for more than 40 years.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Eritrea (2016/2568(RSP)).

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, it is indeed important to exchange views on the situation in Eritrea. This very small country in the Horn of Africa is – or continues to be, I have to say – in the headlines because many people are fleeing the country on a monthly basis, many of them to Europe, seeking a better life without political oppression, a better life and better employment opportunities. And yes, we are deeply concerned about the gross human rights violations.  Respect for human rights is a basic principle of the EU’s foreign policy and it is part of our political dialogues with governments around the world, including with the Eritrean authorities. Through this dialogue, but also publicly, we raise our concerns about violations of human rights obligations and reaffirm the need for Eritrea to respect fundamental democratic rights.  We have also repeatedly requested concrete gestures, such as freeing prisoners detained incommunicado since 2001, among them Mr Dawit Isaak, a Swedish Eritrean citizen, and we will continue to do so at all levels and on all occasions.  The EU also raises issues related to the human rights situation in Eritrea in international fora, notably at meetings of the UN Human Rights Council. We appeal to Eritrea to cooperate with the UN Special Rapporteur and the UN Commission of Inquiry on Eritrea and give them access to the country. Let me underline that we believe that a critical engagement with the country is still the best option for the EU for a number of reasons. Firstly, because critical engagement creates the possibility to stress the need for concrete changes and progress across the board, and it gives us the possibility to insist on the importance of adhering to international standards on human rights. Isolation rarely helps in these circumstances. A second reason why we think that critical engagement with the country is useful is the fight against poverty. Regardless of the nature of the political regime, the EU is committed to supporting the population and improving its living conditions through development projects; so no budget support. A lot needs to be done to alleviate the huge stress upon Eritrea’s population.  Eritreans are facing a problematic food security situation and lack of economic opportunities. Their despair translates into a constantly high rate of people, especially young people, trying to flee the country. They often venture on a dangerous journey, mainly towards Europe, by illegal means and are easy prey for traffickers.  This is why EU development aid under the 11th European Development Fund (the EDF) will support social and economic development in Eritrea. The programme foresees increasing access to renewable energy and supports economic governance, which will in turn contribute to economic growth and the creation of job opportunities. Under the EDF programme EU engagement also foresees measures to improve the human rights situation in Eritrea. There is a third element to take into account. The country has a strategic position in the Horn of Africa, bordering Sudan, Ethiopia and Djibouti, as well as the Red Sea with its access to the Arabian Peninsula. A peaceful and stable Eritrea and an Eritrea that respects its neighbours will have a positive impact on the overall situation in this region.  The conflict in Yemen and the tensions in the Arab world are changing dynamics in the Horn of Africa and our critical engagement should therefore also be seen in this regional context. The policy of isolation has not worked. Direct EU support to improve the living conditions of the populations also make them less prone to radicalisation and violent extremism. It is also in this framework that we want to engage with Eritrea, thus contributing to regional peace and stability.  Let me conclude by addressing the issue of migration and asylum. The constant high outflow of migrants and asylum seekers from Eritrea is a major challenge. Eritrea is a key country of origin. Eritrean asylum seekers are generally recognised for international protection in the EU with a very high acceptance rate – understandably so – but Eritrea is also an active partner in the Khartoum Process which addresses, among other things, human rights issues, as well as border management and migration management.  By discussing the human rights record and improving the livelihoods of the people of Eritrea, our engagement is expected to address some of the push factors for migration. This is part of our comprehensive response to the current migration crisis. Let me say clearly that we engage with Eritrea for the sake of its people and I would like to stress that once again. Yes, the critical engagement is also in our own interest. It is the only way to try to help move things in the right direction. In Eritrea or elsewhere, critical engagement based on a good understanding of the dynamics and challenges is a pragmatic way to help promote positive change.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. Mr. President, last year we had a discussion in this house about Eritrea. For the most part, all political groups were skeptical of the Commission's idea of giving development aid and asked the Commission if it came to this point that this cooperation must focus on issues of good rule and respect for human rights, as it is the dictatorial regime's systematic violation of human rights that makes people flee Eritrea to Europe.  The programme proposed by the Commission shortly afterwards focuses on energy investments and, in a small part, in effective governance in the energy sector and therefore did not reflect the conclusions of our debate in Parliament. Members of the Development Committee made a negative recommendation for its adoption. But the Development Committee recommendation was also ignored, the Commission's proposal almost unchanged, unanimously adopted at a session of the EDF Committee. That is why I would particularly like to highlight a paragraph of our joint resolution calling for an interinstitutional agreement of a binding nature, which will better arrange Parliament's control over the European Development Fund.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has It is good that the issue of Eritrea is being raised in a resolution today, because the human rights situation in that country is catastrophic. One only has to look at the report by Amnesty International. We have thousands of political prisoners whose family members are not informed about what is going on in the prisons and what the state of the detainees is. We must also mention that Eritrea is constantly justifying the state of emergency on domestic political grounds and saying that we have problems with Ethiopia, and that is why we are basically in a state of war. The country has five million inhabitants and 300 000 are in the military. 400 000 have fled Eritrea, almost one in ten have left the country. This shows how dramatic the situation is. We have a chance, as the EU, to exert our influence through our projects. Just saying again and again that 'the human rights situation is difficult' is not enough. We need to demand much more from Eritrea here. We also want, as a Parliament, to be more involved in the decisions of the Council and the Commission. I believe that this would be a step forward. The way in which Parliament has been dealt with up to now does not help, and it does not help the people of Eritrea.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – There is indeed a great need to improve the life situation of the population in Eritrea. But you know, the decision to significantly increase the European aid package to Eritrea is, in my opinion, a gross error of judgement. It also goes against the recommendation and the position of this Parliament. The European Commission attributes the exodus from the country mainly to the economic situation. Error! It thus ignores the real suffering of the Eritrean people. President Afewerki's Eritrea is one of the most totalitarian states in the world. An open prison where the population lives in permanent fear. Arbitrary arrests, torture, extrajudicial killings are the rule. No free speech, freedom of association or religious freedom. There is a mandatory military service for an indefinite period. From an early age, children have been recruited by this military regime. Education does not know these young people, their future is brutally taken away from them. Against this background of gross human rights violations, you have to explain the large flow of refugees to Europe. I see no intention whatsoever with the authorities to really improve the fate of the population. More European money will only enable them to continue their dictatorial repressive practices. Is that what we want? The people will not benefit from our money if it does not serve clear development objectives and if there are no conditions for respect for human rights. And there's more. Finding a better and safer home in the European Union, even that turns out to be an illusion for many refugees. Regime spies are pursuing people on European soil. They require them to pay an income tax. Those who refuse must fear for the fate of the remaining family. This long arm of the regime has been reporting in the media for years. The United Nations launched an investigation, but the Commission and the EEAS remain silent. Madam Minister, shouldn't we really put this regime on hold? It is high time for realism, for action and for decisiveness.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Mrs Hennis-Plasschaert, this morning we have witnessed a degraded debate on the dubiously legal pre-agreement signed by the European Union and Turkey, a debate in which the Presidents of the Council and the Commission have not been present. A pre-agreement that shames us and discredits us, because it seeks to solve the desperate, as inefficiently and morally unjustifiable, the problem of managing migration flows that is currently collapsing europe.  In this Parliament we have repeated numerous times that, in addition to the short-term measures we often discuss, the causes underlying the problems must be addressed.  Today we are debating a resolution affecting hundreds of thousands of people seeking refuge and asylum fleeing a country, Eritrea, which offers them no more opportunities than labour slavery. Today we are debating the two hundred million that the European Union is going to donate to the Eritrean Government over the next five years: will it serve to help Eritreans think of anything other than leaving their country?  Ladies and gentlemen, we cannot give that money once again, without guaranteeing that it will not go to a government that systematically violates human rights as few do in the world.  Madam Minister, the Committee on Development of this Parliament, of which I am a member, made it clear last November to the Commission and the European External Action Service that the Indicative Programme should not be adopted as there were serious doubts that this money would be used for the purpose for which it was intended. The position of this institution, chosen directly by the citizens we serve, was ignored.  This position is based on facts such as those reported by the United Nations Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in Eritrea, which ensures that military service is used to enslave the population at work.  Precisely, Madam Minister, one of the commitments Eritrea made to the European Union to receive the two hundred million was to limit military service to eighteen months. Just two weeks ago, the government said it has no intention of doing so.  I would like to ask the Commission: have you found any way to ensure that European taxpayers' money is not going to go back into the hands of one of the worst dictators on Earth?  Development aid must be a finalist, and we are responsible for weaving programmes that help solve the structural problems of the poorest countries. We need to be wary of the use of funds and, above all, maintain proper conditionality and inexcusable respect for human rights.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, I would like to welcome this resolution, the first since 2004. Eritrea is one of the world's worst dictatorships, North Korea's Africa, an open-air prison, a country that young people are fleeing by the thousands to escape an indefinite military service and whose diaspora is racketeering. In 2011, Eritrea unilaterally decided to sever relations with the European Union. Obsessed with the migration issue, the latter now wants to take them back. Where will European aid go? There are no state structures other than security. No NGO can work there. How will aid reach the population? How can electrification projects be implemented without primarily serving the interests of a few multinationals? What political dialogue with leaders who have just declared that the European Union's aid will have no impact on the duration of national service, contrary to their very small promises? What guarantees for refugees when they claim to want to train Eritrean border guards who, according to the UN, are compromised in human trafficking? All of this will do nothing to reduce poverty or reduce the stress of the population, nor will the tension in the region, quite the contrary.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – It has not happened before that the European Parliament unanimously rejects a development programme. But that is exactly what we did last November. The Council unanimously ignored that opinion. We are not rejecting development aid for Eritrea, but we are rejecting this plan. Because this EUR 200 million plan is aimed at countering what the Council calls the fight against irregular migration. But it's a refugee crisis! Eritreans flee en masse from The North Korea of Africa because they are exploited, emaciated and starved. And if they manage to make that perilous journey - and remember, the Eritrean border guard has a shoot to kill policy - they are not safe in Europe for the long arm from Asmara either. They are financially squeezed out by their embassies with an illegal 2% tax. Mr President, it is indeed necessary to have a conversation with President Afewerki. But that conversation should not take the turn of the Turkey deal: pay for border security!

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, despite being a country of only six million people, Eritreans form the second largest ethnic group in the current migrant crisis, with many seeking passage to the United Kingdom. Much of this has to do with the country’s brutal military dictatorship, which suppresses all liberties and enforces unlimited military conscription, rather than economic hardship. So can someone tell me why the EU has seen fit to boost its economic aid to Eritrea’s despotic leaders, who are said to be operating a totalitarian government with no accountability and no rule of law? Surely this is yet another example of the EU blindly throwing British taxpayers’ money at a problem without the slightest understanding of what the root causes and influencing factors are.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Eritrea's independence in 1993 raised hopes that the newly formed state would be democratic. The constitution, adopted in 1997, introduced the rule of law, respect for human rights. Unfortunately, it has never entered force, and no elections have been held in the country so far – it is totalitarianly managed by Isaiaja Afwerka. Human rights violations, the difficult political and humanitarian situation, including the droughts that have hit the country, have led to mass emigration of people. More than 5,000 people flee to neighbouring countries, including Europe, according to UN estimates. The establishment of a €200 million national reactivation programme under the European Development Fund is only a step to help the people of the country, albeit only in the short term. It can help reduce poverty, but it certainly won't solve all the problems that prevail there. In order for Eritrea to move on to sustainable development, fundamental structural reforms are needed.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: – Mr President, as Chair of the Committee on Development, there are many things I am proud about regarding EU development policy, but the decision by the Ministers and the Commission to award an aid programme to Eritrea is not one of them. You have heard colleagues from across this Parliament talk about the appalling human rights situation in Eritrea, and that is why in November our Committee unanimously asked that no decision on a new programme be made without further dialogue with Parliament, without further discussion with Ministers. But you went ahead and you signed off on that programme, and the view of Parliament was not just ignored, it was not even reported to the EDF Committee. I hope I have your assurance, Minister – and there is nobody here from the Commission, I hope we get their assurance also – that this does not happen again. This is a very serious decision and I hope that when the spending and annual action programmes come forward Parliament will be involved in these matters. Secondly, Minister, you said that the money will go to tackle poverty, but 87% of the funding is due to be allocated to energy projects – but to whom is the money going? There is no private sector in Eritrea. Who is getting the money? That is what we need to know. Finally, you said our response is part of a current response to the migration crisis – that makes me even more sceptical. The number of Eritreans getting refugee status in my country is going down. And let us be clear: the Eritreans who come are refugees from an appalling political system – they are not migrants. I think we should make no link, no tie-up, between our relationship with Eritrea and reducing the number of refugees coming from that country. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Honourable Member, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. You – perhaps not without reason – say that aid to Eritrea will be mis-addressed, right? It will go not where it needs to be, without social benefit. I would therefore ask for conclusions, positive ideas: what is the different aid structure for Eritrea supposed to look like, how to control expenditure if it is wasted? It is better to point out positive solutions than to cultivate only criticism. I wonder what kind of idea you have for this help and its structuring.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: blue-card answer. – It is very difficult to engage with a government which carries out such appalling human rights violations, and I am questioning the very basis of having an aid programme with such a government. What we have agreed now is a kind of framework. No money has actually been allocated. I am asking that, before any money is actually allocated, a lot more thought go into this and Parliament be fully involved.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: – Mr President, the European Union has signed an agreement by which Eritrea will receive two hundred million euros for the most part large energy projects which will do little or nothing to help poverty reduction and which will surely be reversed in large European multinationals and in the hands of the corrupt. In addition, at the end of 2014, the European Union signed with the authorities of Eritrea and other states in the area the so-called 'Khartoum Agreement', a cooperation agreement on migration, for Eritrea to act as a stopper state within the logic of outsourcing control of European borders.  Eritrea, ladies and gentlemen, is a dictatorship that systematically violates human rights and represses its people. According to UNHCR, 20% of people crossing the Mediterranean are originally from Eritrea – one in five – because people try to escape that regime anyway.  The agreements that have been signed with Eritrea are a clear exercise in cynicism, they legitimize the dictatorship to put it at the service of our geostrategic and security interests. And, at the same time, we close our eyes to the dramatic situation that the population is living under that regime. Please, let's be consistent and stop funding tyrant governments.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dialogue in foreign policy is always fundamental and choosing with whom to talk is even more important. The Eritrean Government has so far proved to be a very uncredible interlocutor. In addition to suspicions of support for al-Shabaab militias in Somalia, we must remember the very serious case of forced conscription, including of minors, who are then forced to emigrate alone on the dangerous route sudan, Libya, Europe and if discovered to flee they are arbitrarily detained by the authorities, with intolerable violations of human rights. Not to mention cases of torture, political prisoners and enforced disappearances, extrajudicial executions.  It is good to use the Eu ropean Union's aid trust fund, but only if we see concrete steps towards compliance with cross compliance. That does not seem to me to be the case. We are in spirit of strong support for the Eritrean people, for combating the poverty that is causing emigration. But we want to see real progress. Uncritically supporting a government like this often means openly condemning its people.  Who do we want to defend today? This Parliament, I think, has a very clear line: it wants to defend the Eritrean people and the Council must take that into account.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: Mr President, the situation in Eritrea is critical. Every month, thousands of Eritreans flee their country because of the many human rights violations that occur there. The UN investigation report on the subject, as well as the statements of the UN Special Rapporteur on the human rights situation in Eritrea, are worrying in this regard. The members of the Committee on Development drew the attention of the European Commission and the Council to these too many violations and violations of human rights in Eritrea, within the framework of our democratic control over the national indicative programmes of the ACP countries receiving the EDF. I sincerely regret that the recommendations of our committee have not been listened to. Respect and defence of human rights are founding values of the European Union. We cannot compromise on their respect. Thus, if the European Union is to stand with the Eritrean people, it is crucial that further monitoring of human rights violations committed is carried out and that appropriate measures are then taken to put an end to them. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. You have built up what you have to say along the lines of human rights. Although many in this chamber have already referred to corruption, the regime itself embraces all European assistance and does not pass it on to the people. Do you think this is a real situation, or is it simply that we have human rights problems? Because, by the way, that's what you can keep in mind in all our foreign policy maneuvers, in Other Language, the conditioning. And not just in relation to human rights, but also in relation to corruption.

name: Maurice PONGA
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would simply say that it is up to the Eritrean government to take its part in the fight against human rights violations. It is up to us in Parliament to have our demands on the aid we provide to Eritrea.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: – Mr President, Madam Minister, this morning we had a long debate in Parliament on the refugee crisis in the European Union.  It is true that Eritrea is not the largest focus of refugee generation – we have Syria, we have Iraq, we have other countries in the area – but Eritrea's contribution with about 400,000 refugees, which account for 9% of its population, and 5,000 who are continually leaving Eritrea every day is not small. All of them contribute to the number of refugees in the world reaching already 60 million people, more or less the population of a country such as France or the United Kingdom.  The case of Eritrea is a clear case of a Government that violates fundamental freedoms, pursues its citizens, pursues non-governmental organizations, hijacks fundamental rights and freedoms, and does not even accept the Convention against Torture.  I therefore agree with the expression that we have to maintain critical engagement with Eritrea, but in return for it being critical, that is, that our aid is linked to Eritrea's commitment to addressing and resolving these problems.  Further, I repeat what the president of my committee has said: Parliament does not want to be ignored in the process of development cooperation with Eritrea. On the contrary, you want to be an active part of it.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: Mr President, Madam Minister, the situation in Eritrea and our relations with Eritrea perfectly illustrate the stakes for the European Union, on the one hand, the coherence of its policies on development, human rights and migration and, on the other hand, the capacity of our instruments to serve not only as instruments of pressure, but also as a lever to promote the entry of this country on a possible path to democratisation and human rights. Two points on this point: make better use of the European Development Fund. This Parliament has already called for the national indicative programme, particularly in the 'governance' component, to allow us to converge on the founding principles of the European Union's foreign policy, but also towards the foundations of a more open and stable Eritrea. Secondly, in the current migration context, given that Eritrean women represented, in 2014, the second contingent of people who arrived on Italian shores after the Syrians, the European Development Fund, the Khartoum process and our relations under the Cotonou agreement must be better used to find a solution first and foremost in favour of Eritreans and their fundamental rights. In fact, the causes of irregular migration must be addressed, and in this respect Eritrea is a concrete example to show that we are capable of mobilizing.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I welcome the delegation of the Independent Trade Union Solidarity Lower Silesia with President Kazimierz Kimso. We warmly welcome our solidarity colleagues.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – The systematic violation of human rights in Eritrea, exacerbated by the indefinite military recruitment policy that maintains the regime of slavery, leads to the flight of 500 Eritreans per month to Europe, already totalling 400,000 refugees, or about 9 % of the population.  There is no rule of law in Eritrea, there is no functioning legislature, no national budget, no independent press or government organizations working in the country since 2001. Still, the European Union is ready to agree on a €200 million development aid plan with the dictatorship of Isaias Afewerki to stem the flow of refugees. How can the Commission believe that this plan can ever actually improve the living conditions of the oppressed Eritrean people? What guarantees does the Commission offer that this aid, approved under the European Development Fund and against the negative opinion of the European Parliament, and without democratic scrutiny, because it does not exist within that fund, how can it ensure that it will not be used for other purposes, such as the purchase of arms, the destabilisation of the region and more repression on the people of Eritrea.  The Commission must at least require a democratic reform plan and also to ensure that the monitoring of Union-funded projects is strictly controlled by independent entities and has to be given access to non-governmental organisations as well as UN rapporteurs and special representatives.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, Minister, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Every day, people flee Eritrea.  Not because there is war in their country, but because a dictatorship was established there under President Afewerki, which deprives them of the right to life. However, this does not prevent the Commission from making EUR 200 million available from the 11th Development Fund for a new National Indicative of Programmes, including EUR 20 million for good governance. A joke, I mean! We could have learned: eur 122 million has already been allocated to Eritrea in the 10th Development Fund. This was then reduced to EUR 53 million because there was no progress in development cooperation, and in 2014 the European delegation from Eritrea reported that this money could not be implemented either – but that does not prevent the Commission from providing new, fresh money for Eritrea. I think we have a case here which means that the European Development Fund is finally under parliamentary control, because our opinion had the right tone and the right direction.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr 5,281 days! For so long, the Swedish-Eritrean journalist Dawit Isaak has been imprisoned without trial in Eritrea. 5,281 days – that's more than 14 years of uncertainty and concern for Dawit Isaak's family. He is today the only European citizen imprisoned for his views. However, his situation is not unique. His fate is shared by many other journalists and political prisoners. It is not just freedom of expression that is being attacked in Eritrea today. According to reports by the UN Special Envoy, there are systematic human rights violations in Eritrea, and the country's leadership has restricted the majority of people's freedoms. The list is very long. One of the main objectives of the EU's foreign and security policy is precisely to promote democracy, the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. This must also apply in relation to Eritrea.  I welcome the resolution, but I would like to know what the Commission and the Vice-President intend to do to get Dawit Isaak out of Eritrea.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to thank you for a well-formulated resolution on the situation in Eritrea. I would also like to thank Mr Dawit Isaak for my own work.  The Swedish-Eritrean journalist Dawit Isaak has, as we heard, been imprisoned for more than 14 years in appalling conditions for the sole reason that he has stood up for human rights. It is therefore important that the European Parliament now calls for the immediate release of all political prisoners. At the same time, more needs to be done. If human rights violations continue, there must be consequences for long-term development cooperation.  The fact that the EU is handing out billions of aid to Eritrea unconditionally is unacceptable. It is time to link aid to demands for human rights and the release of Dawit Isaak and other political prisoners. It is time to recognise today from what we are seeing that Eritrea is, unfortunately, a rogue state.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, the European Union has decided to resume its development assistance to Eritrea, notably via a National Indicative Programme (NIP) – as was mentioned, for EUR 200 million – despite the fact that Scrutiny Working Group A of Parliament’s Committee on Development, which I chair, called on the EDF Committee on 11 November 2015 not to adopt the draft NIP, pending further discussion. It seems that Parliament is, unfortunately, not being taken into consideration. This is explained mainly by the human rights situation in Eritrea, which has long been deteriorating. There is a messy situation in this country. Nowadays, civilians are regularly and arbitrarily detained or arrested for a number of unjustifiable reasons, for example: criticising or opposing the government, practising journalism, practising an unofficial religion, evading or deserting mandatory national service, or trying to flee the country. Eritreans fleeing the country now constitute the third largest group of refugees making the perilous journey to Europe. However, our call to the Commission was not taken into consideration. We call on you, as the representative of the Council, to take our decisions into consideration.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Mr President, I hope to visit Eritrea in the coming weeks and months with an Irish NGO, Vita, which is involved in food security and development. I hope to take to Eritrea the message of the resolution, which hopefully will be passed tomorrow by my colleagues. We need to ensure human rights are defended in a circumstance where there is such corruption in Eritrea, but we also need to ensure that, where EU citizens’ finances are actually funding Eritrea, that it is for the people of Eritrea, to the benefit of them and nobody else, that the funding is actually used. I believe the strong message to the Minister, to the Commission, to the Presidency and to the Council is that there must be conditionality on the funding that we, as EU citizens, put into Eritrea and other parts of the developing world – conditionality in terms of human rights to make sure that the government there accepts our bona fides. I agree with everyone in terms of the comprehensive motion which has been put. I also accept that there is a need to make progress on the case of Mr Dawit Isaak in terms of his detention there, and I reiterate the need to ensure that the EU funding that goes into Eritrea must be to the benefit of the people of Eritrea and nobody else.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Eritrea is the country of origin of many of the refugees arriving in Europe. According to the UN and Human Rights Watch, the exodus is fuelled by human rights violations. There is talk of summary executions, without trial, disappearances, torture and forced conscription. A UN report shows that the government would also use tensions with neighbouring countries as a pretext for ignoring respect for human rights and for subjecting every aspect of daily life to military control.  In the past, precisely because of the very harsh conditions in the country, Amnesty International has asked many states to stop the practice of the forced repatriation of Eritrean exiles. This issue was also discussed at the EU-Turkey summit on the migration crisis. The European Union must resolve the issue of migratory flows with Asmara and make economic aid conditional on a significant improvement in fundamental freedoms in the country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, according to the UN Human Rights Council, there are systematic and serious human rights violations in Eritrea. Eritrea has not held democratic elections since 1993. Since 2001 there has been a dictatorship regime in the country, while 5% of the population has left the country due to political situation and economic distress. In addition, in Eritrea there are restrictions on freedom of speech and free press as well as religious freedom, and torture and executions often occur during military service.  In the face of the violation of rights taking place in Eritrea, the European Union should contribute to the promotion of a democratic model of governance. At the same time, each Member State of the Union must condemn the violation of human rights and the link between government operations and corruption. Finally, the European Union should review its investment policy in the country and contribute to combating inequalities and poverty in the region.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, we have witnessed for years that Eritrea is the country where human rights violations are the worst, where we have forms of slavery, where we do not of course have freedom of religion, not to talk about violence against women, about the LGBT community and their rights of course there is no talk at all, about the imprisonment of our fellow MPs, about the imprisonment of our Europeans in Eritrea and all that we have heard.  Should Eritrea be helped? In the end, yes, Eritrea needs help. We all say here that we need to help by directing the Development Fund towards what will be for the citizens of Eritrea.  Dear Minister, are we capable of doing this? We guarantee ourselves that money will really end up like that, not in the hands of dictators, because otherwise help doesn't make any sense.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, Eritrea is a country that faces many challenges. Political instability, human rights abuses and forced conscription have led to a humanitarian crisis. Eritrea is a major source of people in the ongoing migration crisis, with tens of thousands making the perilous journey to Europe. With Somalia, Eritrea and the Sudan on its borders, Ethiopia’s role in providing for security in the Horn of Africa must not be overlooked. Over 130 000 refugees from Eritrea are hosted by Ethiopia and credit must be given for the leading military role that Ethiopia plays in the fight against al-Shabaab. Mr President, more must be done to address the political and economic drivers for the migration crisis originating in Eritrea and, as in the Middle East, it is only through close partnership with regional powers and support for people close to home that we can address this issue quickly and in the best possible way, both for people in the north of Africa and the Middle East and for those here in Europe.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, as I already said earlier during this debate, we are seriously concerned by the gross human rights violations in this country and we do address human rights issues at all meetings with Ministers and in the Article 8 political dialogue meetings with the government. We are also addressing these issues in international fora and notably at the Human Rights Council of the United Nations.  Under the 11th EDF National Indicative Programme (NIP), the EU will support the implementation of recommendations made to Eritrea under the UN-led Universal Periodic Review (UPR). It will allow the EU to deepen the dialogue on human rights with the government of Eritrea. The EU is looking for a partnership with Eritrea in a more-for-more spirit. This is conditionality. To this effect, the EU has addressed with the government of Eritrea the necessity for our cooperation to be accompanied by action on reforms. These reforms must relate to the effective implementation of the UPR recommendations, the improvement of economic governance, as well as reform of the national service.  Under the NIP for Eritrea for the period 2016-2020, the intervention sectors are, amongst others, community-based energy projects as a prerequisite for increasing food security and agriculture productivity. Economic governance will also be addressed to create good conditions for sustainable economic growth. EU-funded interventions will support the population with the objective of improving livelihoods and reducing poverty. Finally, measures to improve the human rights situation in Eritrea are also foreseen. The EU will support, and continue to support, implementation of the recommendations made to Eritrea under the UN-led Universal Periodic Review.  Now, development assistance – and I noted many remarks about this specific issue – is implemented on the basis of projects that are tailor-made to address the needs of the population in Eritrea: to create jobs, reduce poverty. There is no support to the central government. The process of approving and implementing EU projects is carried out transparently, following EU and European Development Fund rules at all stages. Furthermore, projects are being strictly monitored, following the EU financial and auditing regulations. The benefit of the funding – this was raised several times – will be for the Eritrean people. Let me stress it once more: there is no such thing as support to the central government. I am conscious, as was pointed out, of the very difficult political context in which we are operating when engaging with Eritrea. We will review our engagement at regular intervals, taking stock of how far we have progressed and how serious the government is in reforming its system. The High Representative, Ms Mogherini, will report on such progress, or lack of it, to you. So it is not at all my intention to ignore Parliament. Be assured that we will continue to follow very closely the development of the human rights situation in Eritrea and the country’s role in the region. As I said at the beginning, we engage with Eritrea for the sake of its people. One thing is sure: further isolation will not help the Eritrean people.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 10 March 2016.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Eritrea ranks almost last in the world in terms of the rate of social development, and numerous examples of human rights violations are a particular cause for concern. These factors make Eritreans, fleeing poverty and oppression to Europe, the fourth largest group of refugees. The European Union recently provided EUR 200 million in long-term assistance to Eritrea. Of course, this money can help create new jobs and improve the economic situation of the country, but this should be done on a conditional basis to ensure that European money does not support the authoritarian regime. Furthermore, I am afraid that without a decisive improvement in human rights, we will not be able to stop the wave of Eritrean refugees satisfactorily. I therefore believe that we should put constant and decisive pressure on the country's authorities to start implementing democratic reforms, ensure respect for human rights and implement the recommendations of the UN Universal Periodic Review of 2014.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. "Eritrea today is a country from which everyone who can escape. Europe has the fourth highest number of migrants coming from this country. Today's decision points out that part of the serious security risk to the country is that whatever is in the law, there is no religious freedom in the country in reality. According to data from the Organization Open Doors, Eritrea is rated third on the list of countries where Christians are subjected to the most serious and common atrocities. Forcing seminarists to serve in the military, banning the departure of clerics, imprisoning Christians: among other things, this is part of local reality, according to reports on the ground by the international aid organisation ACN. Years ago, local church leaders frantically announced in their open letter that their parishioners were fleeing en masse. It is a serious mistake on the part of the Union to ignore this and to give serious development aid to these systems without disclaiming human rights abuses. We cannot go without a word with the dramatic events of our time in the wider region. In Ethiopia, extremists have robbed churches, church hospitals and child protection institutions. Local Christian leaders reported in shock that it was those who had been supported by their church before. In Yemen, Islamist militants brutally killed four nuns from mother Teresa's Missionaries of Charity and 15 residents of their care home. Let the martyrs remind us Europeans that we are responsible for the Christian persecuted.

name: Kati PIRI
text: in writing. – Cross-border kidnappings and aggression, compulsory national service stretching to a decade, and Eritreans’ involvement in the war in Yemen are reported by the UN Monitoring Group. This is the country to which the European Union has signed a 200-million-euro package of financial support in January for a four—year period. Each month, as many as 5 000 people flee Eritrea according to UN figures. The Eritreans are the third largest group of people who risk the journey across the Mediterranean to reach Europe. And even after they find new homes in Europe, they are not free of the Eritrean regime’s grasp. It was reported that some interpreters working for the Dutch immigration service were linked to the Eritrean regime. The regime also targets our free media! In the Netherlands alone, eight court cases have been launched against liberal newspapers, radio stations, websites who are critical of the authoritarian regime. The reports suggest that senior government officials are behind this campaign. Which monitoring measures does the Commission take to ensure that our support leads to the development of the country and to better living conditions of Eritreans, and not to the strengthening of this authoritarian government inside and outside of that country?

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing – The situation in Eritrea, one of the youngest countries in the world, is very complicated. Eritrea is now an authoritarian state where human rights are suppressed. As a result of fear and oppression, there are a huge number of Eritreans on the run, representing the third largest group of refugees heading to Europe, given the 5000 refugees per month. A month ago, on my journey from Strasbourg on my last flight from Vienna to Košice, I also flew with 57 refugees from Eritrea who are UN refugees and after a few months of staying in Slovakia, where they will learn English, they will fly to the USA. Looking at old people, women, children who were dressed very modestly despite the winter, I was very sad. There was incredible sadness in their faces, the hopelessness of people who were forced to leave their homeland, relatives and embarked on an uncertain journey in the hope of a better chance of life for their children. It was just a small group of refugees from six million Eritreans, but since meeting them, the question has arisen: Is it just an authoritarian state that forces them to leave their own country, not even multinational corporations and the globalisation policy of rich states that exploits the poorest? Let each of us get an answer. Development aid to poor Africa is a good intention, but it is few and many times unassuing.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statement on the 2015 report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (2015/2895(RSP)).

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me first of all reiterate the Council’s commitment to the EU accession process of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, although the critical situation in the country is a serious cause for concern.  In 2015 the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia faced one of its most severe political crises, which was marked by a divisive political culture, backsliding on freedom of expression and judicial independence, as well as further erosion of trust in public institutions. It is now essential to overcome this crisis and to ensure that these shortcomings will be addressed decisively. The June-July Pržino political agreement reached among the political leaders, as well as the urgent reform priorities which have been issued by the Commission, provide the blueprint for what needs to be done. We have taken good note of the decision to postpone the early parliamentary elections to 5 June, given that necessary conditions for holding credible elections on 24 April were not in place. It will now be essential for all political actors to live up to their responsibility and to take the necessary measures, including the election—related media reform. A constructive and inclusive political dialogue within the country will be crucial in order to move forward.  Obviously the holding of credible elections in which all citizens and parties freely participate is a first major step towards ending the ongoing political crisis. We are closely monitoring this process in cooperation with the OSCE Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights.  Let me also commend the close cooperation between the EU actors, necessary to pave the way out of the country’s political crisis. I want to mention in particular Commissioner Hahn’s substantive engagement and to thank him very much, and to thank as well the three Members of this House, Mr Vajgl, Mr Howitt and Mr Kukan.  Sustainable reforms to address systematic values in the areas of the rule of law, public administration, protection of fundamental rights and media freedom, as well as the fight against corruption, continue to remain central for the country’s path towards the EU. Let me also reiterate the importance of an independent investigation of all the allegations brought to the fore by the wiretapping affair. The Special Prosecutor and the parliamentary committee of inquiry need to be supported in their work. Equally, I want to repeat the Council’s call for the Kumanovo events of May 2015 to be fully investigated in an objective and transparent manner.  On migration let me commend the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia for its efforts in addressing the refugee and migration crisis last year. For some weeks now several unilateral decisions and regional coordinated responses have been put in place along the western Balkan route. On 18 February the European Council was very clear that only through concerted action can we address the challenge in a proper manner. There is no alternative to a comprehensive European solution. And yes, it is very important that the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, as our neighbouring and candidate country, plays its part in this process.  The EU is providing – and will continue to provide – significant support to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in order to strengthen border controls and to improve border and asylum management. The same goes for several Member States which do it on a bilateral level. Finally, let me underline that good neighbourly relations, including a negotiated and mutually accepted solution to the name issue under the auspices of the UN, remain central for the stability of the region. The accession process of the country is at a critical juncture. The Commission has stated its readiness to extend its recommendation to open accession negotiations. These shall, however, be conditional on the continued implementation of the June—July political agreement and on substantial progress in the implementation of the urgent reform priorities.  The Council will refer to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia after its elections. Right now I strongly believe that the political leaders have the responsibility to take the necessary steps and put their country back onto the Euro-Atlantic path.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Minister for her friendly words concerning our work. I would also like to say thanks once again to three Members of your Parliament – Mr Vajgl, Mr Kukan and Mr Howitt – for their unceasing work on and with this country and its key players in order to facilitate, together with us, a political agreement last summer. It was – and is – crucial and essential that we are helping the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to address the political challenge they are facing and that we are keeping the political agreement alive in the months afterwards.  The three MEPs paid a visit only two weeks ago, following a letter from the EU delegation and the US Ambassador, to the Prime Minister, presenting our joint view that the conditions for organising credible elections on 24 April were not in place. With the EU delegation, your colleagues brokered a deal among the political leaders to postpone the date of the early parliamentary elections from 24 April to 5 June. I would like to stress how important it is that the European Parliament has played its role to engage with the country and to help in the democratic process. I hope it will be possible to be present with observers around the election day. I also would like to take this opportunity to thank Parliament’s Committee on Foreign Affairs, and rapporteur Ivo Vajgl in particular, for the resolution which is before you today for adoption. I find it balanced and in line with the main findings of our 2015 Report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. As you all know, the reporting period was very challenging for the country. I am convinced, however, that our report struck the right balance. On the one hand, we acknowledged that the country has a good level of preparation in developing a functioning market economy. It also has a relatively good level of alignment with the acquis. This means that the right laws and strategies are more or less in place. The issue, as in all these countries, is the application and implementation, as well as the will to take if necessary hard decisions. On the other hand, the country has faced the most severe political crisis in years. The parliament was boycotted by the main opposition party for more than a year. The situation deteriorated further with the publication of intercepted conversations which suggests that the system has been undermined by political interference and high-level corruption.  In order to overcome this political crisis, we adopted a two-track approach. Firstly, the political agreement, which was reached by the four political leaders last summer, as mentioned, was a decisive step forward. Some commitments have been met within the agreed deadlines. The main opposition party returned to the parliament and the special prosecutor was appointed in September. I regret that some other deadlines have been met with considerable delay and required active involvement from the European Union.  In parallel to the political agreement in June last year, we presented a set of urgent reform priorities aiming at addressing underlying rule of law issues.
