Once again, political will is key to progress on these priorities. In our report, we stated that the Commission is prepared to extend its recommendation to open accession negotiations with the country conditional on the continued implementation of the June/July political agreement and substantial implementation of the urgent reform priorities. We are monitoring these issues constantly and will report on this in due course.  As you rightly pointed out in your resolution, the inter-ethnic situation remains fragile in the country. Proactive measures should be undertaken to address inter-ethnic issues and to build greater trust between communities. In this respect, the review of the Ohrid Framework Agreement needs to be completed.  Good neighbourly relations are also essential for the country. Resolving the name issue remains a priority. The country is also on the front line of Europe’s unprecedented refugee and migration crisis, and the Commission remains committed to continue to help the country in this challenge. I look forward to the debate.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur, – Honourable President-in-Office, Minister, Dear Jeanine, Commissioner Hahn. Let me say right from the outset that, on behalf of all three colleagues, I would like to express my sincere thanks for the lovely words you have given to our cooperation. It has been a great pleasure to work with all of us, Commissioner.  The resolution on Macedonia, drawn up together with the excellent shadow rapporteurs, the Secretariat and colleagues who have tabled some 300 amendments, will be adopted at a critical time for this country. Not only is he waiting too long at the door of the European Union as a candidate, but she is facing the challenge these days of the thousands of refugees at the borders who want to go to the Union along the Balkan route, and we are looking for the means to cut this way. On 5 June, there will be early parliamentary elections in Macedonia to end the political crisis. If the elections are in accordance with democratic standards, then it will be time for the Commission to submit and the Council finally confirms the opening of negotiations on Macedonia's accession to the Union under the same conditions previously in force in the enlargement process. Macedonia largely fulfils the acquis conditions, demonstrates satisfactory economic stability and growth, is active in developing good-neighbouring relations and is acting proactively when it comes to building trust with the countries with which it has open problems - Greece and Bulgaria. In the resolution, as before, in the Commission's report to which we are responding, we pointed to the problems revealed by the eavesdropping affair. The consistent exasification of these anomalies is in line with the so-called The Pržinski agreements are entrusted to the special prosecutor's office and is a prerequisite for building trust and functioning of the country's democratic system. The same applies to the urgent reforms envisaged by the agreement of the political parties, which was created with the intervention of the European Union, the Commission, in particular Commissioner Hahn, and with the participation of the us diplomatic representatives and three mediators, members of the European Parliament.  I would also particularly underscore the need to open up the media space in accordance with the principles of democratic and creative opinion. Dear colleagues, it is time for Macedonia to take a new step towards Euro-Atlantic integration, and my ALDE Group supports this. President-in-Office, I am sorry that you only had to give the rapporteur two minutes, I do not think that this is particularly 'fair'. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), blue card question. Mr Vajgl, I have listened carefully to your positions in relation to the YROM. You know that at the moment he has built fences, he has fired tear gas, desperate people have accumulated, who are in a humanitarian crisis. In your view, should this attitude of the F.B.I. towards this very important European problem be taken into account in view of its accession talks with the European Union?

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: blue-card answer. – I must confess that the interpretation technics were quite bad, so I did not catch the meaning of the question, but let me guess what you said. Of course it is huge problem for a small country if you have to deal with such a big problem on your borders. I think that the European Commission, the European Union, has to stand by Macedonia in handling the problem at the border. Was this your question?

name: Tunne KELAM
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Mr Vajgl, for his constructive and inclusive approach, as well as for his efforts to positively balance a very complex issue. Indeed, Macedonia has been an EU candidate for 10 years now and it has been considered the most advanced candidate on the basis of its alignment with the acquis. However, the start of official accession negotiations has been blocked for years in the Council. This report addresses, first of all, the need to establish stability and working cooperation between different political forces there, because dialogue, mutual respect and also respect for the basic freedoms, including the freedom of the press, are necessary for a credible rule-of-law society. At the same time, the boycott of the parliament by those who have lost elections is certainly not in accordance with a functioning democracy and is damaging to the country. New elections will have a key importance for all of us, and we appeal to all sides to stick to the national Kumanovo Agreement.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I have been rapporteur and I am now both shadow rapporteur and parliamentary mediator for this country and I remain utterly committed to it joining the European Union and – on behalf of the Socialist and Democrats – I have been very happy to join with my ALDE and PPE colleagues to put aside our own party differences – to encourage the parties in Skopje to do the same.  But there is a grave political crisis where Europe’s commitment is not questioned but where the democratic commitment in the country very much is. So in our vote tomorrow we will send some very clear messages. As Mr Hahn has repeated this afternoon, the Commission has made the positive recommendation to start the EU accession talks contingent on full implementation of the Pržino inter-party agreement, which we helped to negotiate. The European Council has supported him in their December conclusions and tomorrow this Parliament will stand squarely with them and say, preserve your democracy or the positive recommendation is withdrawn.  After the latest set of talks in which we were involved last month, when the ruling VMRO Party claimed that we had agreed no further media reforms before the election and no further electoral assessments, as mediators and with clear statements from the EU and US Ambassadors, we put on record that these were not part of any agreement and the Dutch President-in-Office , I am grateful, has repeated that this afternoon.  The position of the Council and the Commission, to be fully supported by Parliament tomorrow, is that progress must continue to be made on urgent reforms and I note that the Commission has told us that there has been backsliding. I also note that the Special Prosecutor investigating the deep allegations of criminality against politicians has told us that she has not received the full cooperation which she needs from the country’s court system and in our vote tomorrow we reiterate that she must be given full powers and autonomy to undertake her work.  I and my Group will not join those who use the fact that this country is at the heart of the refugee crisis in order to attack it. We do insist on solidarity with Skopje to match the solidarity needed from all countries if there is to be an adequate response. But tonight we do send a very tough message. A tough message that politicians are not yet fulfilling their obligations and that there is no alternative to them doing so. A tough message: not against the Macedonian people, but for them, for their democracy and for a better future for their country. We are sure that is what they want and their politicians must demonstrate that they want it too. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE/NGL), blue card question. – Mr Howitt, the resolution in recital G states that the Commission, the Council and Parliament agree that maintaining the positive recommendation on opening accession negotiations with the country depends on the full implementation of the Political Agreement June-July 2015 and substantial progress in the implementation of the urgent reform priorities. I have a question: Where have you seen this? And I ask you the question, because this amendment is yours. The Council on 15 December states in paragraph 38 of its conclusions that it merely takes note of the Commission's view on the heresy as to the opening of negotiations. In my view, this does not in any way indicate whether it agrees with it.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I do stand by those S&D amendments, and I also say to our Greek friends that our friends in Skopje can never use the lack of reconciliation of the name issue as an excuse not to pursue those reform priorities. But I also appeal to our Greek friends to make progress too on the name issue, in the interest of your country, in the interest of theirs, and in the interest of Europe.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Thank you to Mr Weigl for his overall work on the Report on Macedonia and his commitment to resolving the political crisis in the country.  I would like to state categorically that I, as both a Bulgarian and the ECR Group, support fraternal Macedonia's aspiration striving for its membership of the European Union. But local authorities need to know that each candidate country is judged on merit, and the speed and quality of the necessary reforms set the timetable for its accession. There are reasonable doubts that Macedonia is in a political crisis, reforms are stalled, there are suspicions that the judiciary and political power are corrupt and the media is censored. The rights of some of the national communities, such as the Bulgarian one, are constantly being violated. This is not the progress we expect and steps need to be taken in this direction.  I have no doubt and there is no question that the Macedonian authorities should stop justifying the name problem, but start solving the political problems of the country. A step forward will be for the government to recognize the existence of a Bulgarian community and guarantee its rights and freedoms, make them full citizens of the state, stop forgery of our common history and stop using the language of hate. It is high time to see progress in the accession process, but this can be done by improving good neighbourly relations with the Member States of the European Union, which goes hand in hand with the necessary internal reforms. (The Speaker agrees to answer a question asked by raising a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Honourable Member, you, as one of the representatives of the neighbourhood compared to Macedonia, have consistently referred to this country as Macedonia and, of course, also referred to the name dispute. Others, I hope, aren't just translations that cheat me, they say to Fyrom. You think that it is possible to enter the European Union under the name Fyrom, or rather to call it Macedonia, and here the EU has a serious responsibility: it should somehow manage the debate between a candidate and a member.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Dear Colleague, my country, the Republic of Bulgaria, is the first to recognise the independence of the Republic of Macedonia under that name. We are aware that there is a dispute that some of the Greek colleagues do not accept the name and claim that it should be called by the name of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. But my country has recognised this country under that name and I am fully entitled to use it with all due respect to the feelings of our friends from the Hellenic Republic.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: At this point allow me to refer, as President-in-Office of the sitting, to the decisions of the European Parliament, which the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schultz, reiterated once again in a letter dated 19 February.  I read it to you in English: "Parliament pays particular attention to use for all diplomatic, political and administrative purposes the name FYROM, which is the internationally categorized name of this country."

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, and on the occasion of last year's report I stressed that the policy of the Commission and Parliament to reward the setback, as most of you have admitted here today, and the negative results that make up the current situation of the country would act as a setback for its progress. The developments fully confirmed the country's systemic deficit in key areas, culminating in the postponement of the April elections. Even today the substance and content of the June-July political agreement is up in the air. The Copenhagen political criteria, to which we are all talking here and which concern the rule of law, the functioning of democratic institutions, freedom of expression, the independence of the judiciary and the media, only if we turn a blind end, can we say that they are approaching the European acquis.  On the crucial issue of refugees, it is an insult to describe the FYLOM as a reliable partner, when every day it violates international treaties with closed borders, quotas on refugees and incidents of violence against refugees. Go, ladies and gentlemen, to Idomeni to see how your trusted partner behaves.  In conclusion, I repeat: The nomenclature is not a bilateral issue between Greece and the FYLOM as expressed in the report. It is an international open issue and the only way to resolve it is to continue negotiations under the auspices of the UN, as both sides have accepted. Its analysis is strictly part of good neighbourly relations, which are an essential element of the enlargement, stabilisation and association process, and affect regional peace and stability. Ladies and gentlemen, the same short-sighted policy is being pursued with Turkey. As much as it serves the interests of some, the results will be tragic.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, as usual the rapporteur did a splendid job and it was a pleasure working with him. The resolution is indeed a strong one; it deserves the support of the entire House. Dear colleagues, I could talk at length about the importance of implementing the June/July agreements, the urgency of implementing the necessary reforms, the need for all political actors to assume their responsibility and find ways of cooperation in the interest of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, and indeed in the interest of the Macedonian people, and that would be true. However, what I want to underline is that we, the European Union, also have a responsibility in this, and this is not just the name issue. The name issue is one of them, but not the only one. The impotence of the Council in finding the much talked about European-level, Europe-wide solution to the migration crisis is one of the elements in contributing to the crisis. The ill-considered campaign promise made by the President of the Commission of a digestion period, necessary before further enlargement, is another element contributing to this crisis. These are all important contributions to the loss of perspective in the entire region of the Western Balkans. We are actually losing the region, losing it day by day, and we are allowing it to be messed up politically. History tells us that is a decidedly bad idea.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it was March 2004 when Macedonia's accession process began; so 12 years ago. This path was abruptly interrupted: the democratic spirit was lost, the political factions began to clash.  Now, it is clear that we have the task and the duty to try to get Macedonia back on that path, and we must do so on the basis of certain assumptions, such as media reform, that they are free media, that they are no longer under government pressure, such as the fight against effective and multi-level corruption, as a support for justice that does its course. , with the Special Prosecutor and with the courts, who give the right sentences to the guilty. But also with the provision of conditions for regular and free lessons, therefore with a cleaning of the electoral registers that is necessary to go to the vote.  We hope that we will soon have Macedonia in democratic conditions and that it will be able to return to being a friendly country with which to work together.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the reports in the European Parliament are definitely following and similar. In its expansionist will, the European Union always puts forward two demands which seem to condition the admission of new Member States more than others: membership of NATO, whose existence is no longer justified since the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact, and the promotion of gender ideology, with its procession of communitarian demands. For example, paragraph 22 of the resolution calls for following the union's so-called model - open quotation marks - "in terms of discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation and gender identity", a vague concept which justifies the delusions of obviously disturbed ideologues. However, your obsessions prevent you from seeing the real problems facing the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. You are talking about the Roma - those bands of merry troubadours that you want to see everywhere except, of course, in the gardens of your second homes - but not a word about the Albanians of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The latter, however, constitute a minority that is constantly growing in population and whose demands threaten the stability of the country, especially since Kosovo's self-proclaimed independence. It was on the border of this historically Serb territory that albanians from the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia sparked violent riots last May and June. Finally, with regard to a problem that affects all of us, that of the tidal wave of migration, I, for one, would like to welcome the recent measures taken by the authorities of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. On his way to the last summit of the Visegred group, President George Ivanov showed that he trusted budapest officials more than the bureaucrats in Brussels to stem the flow of immigration to Europe.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Mr President, the accession of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia – the official name of the country overlooked in the report – to the European Union aims to strengthen European capital in the Balkans as an energy corridor, an investment field and a geostrategic front of confrontation with Russian interests. The people of the country will pay even harder for the plans of the domestic bourgeoisie. Remember: The process of integrating the FYLOM began with war, the dissolution of Yugoslavia, protectorate states of NATO and the European Union. The result of the EU integration of the FYROM is the unacceptable closure of its borders and the Balkan corridor to refugees with savage police repression and their entrapment in Greece, for which the previous day's statement of the summit congratulates it. This policy, reproduced in the European Parliament and by the so-called 'Friends of Macedonia' group, fosters ethno-religious divisions, altruisms of sovereign rights, turning the Balkans literally into a powder keg. It turns out that the European Union and the system it serves mean exploitation, poverty, competition and war.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Mr President, as we all know, since the end of 2015, the European Commission has removed the word 'progress' from the title of the annual reports for candidate or potential candidate countries. For some cases, maybe it's not right that this is happening. For Macedonia, I think it's appropriate not to talk about "progress." Perhaps it would have been quite appropriate to talk about "regression" in the case of Macedonia, because this has happened, and responsible for the situation is the political class and, in particular, those who systematically cultivate boycott and radicalism as political solutions. Unfortunately, some of our colleagues are also encouraging them. Against the background of such a political culture, which refuses dialogue, Macedonia is in a perpetual political crisis and we certainly want things to change. It would be good for the entire political class to treat responsibly the commitments it has made. Personally, I was very disappointed to see how quickly the Socialists had dissed themselves from the commitments [...] made to the election date, originally scheduled for April. I hope you don't change your mind again and the election can [...] (the president interrupted the speaker). Mr President, I have seen that you have let all the other speakers spend much more time allocated, and I do not understand why you do not allow me to conclude. I had a minute and [...] (the president interrupted the speaker). I think you're doing partisan. Privilege your colleagues. group. That's unacceptable!

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr. Preda, your time is up. You have a minute. Your time is long gone. You're the one who got over it more than anyone, Mr. President. Preda, respect the president's decision, which is fair in all directions. Please sit down.  Respect the President, who is fair in all directions. I gave you half a minute more. Don't abuse my tolerance.

name: Jens NILSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr 2015 clearly showed that the country is facing enormous challenges. The political agreement between the government and the opposition of June was very important in essence, but now it has to be shown that there is a real will to change. Comprehensive reforms are crucial to the future of the country and the most important thing right now is for the people themselves to finally have a democratic election. There are still a number of fundamental preconditions for a fair election, for example, media freedom must be guaranteed. Free and independent media is the cornerstone of any democratic society. It is crucial for the stability of the country and it is crucial for eu membership to be possible, and now there are shortcomings. In addition to the political crisis, the country has also done an enormous job in terms of the influx of refugees, and there must be a sense that there is solidarity from the EU with Macedonia in order to cope with the terrible mission of refugees. But, as I said, the most important thing is to ensure that all necessary measures are taken for a fair and democratic election in June.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Skopje has for several days closed its borders, resulting in more than 15,000 refugees being stranded in Idomeni. This action by Skopje violates international law and in particular the 1951 Geneva Convention on Refugees, as UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has said. Yet, Mr Hahn, I have not seen any action taken to force Skopje to comply with the obligations arising from international law. Skopje also a few days ago violated greece's territorial integrity by throwing flash grenades, tear gas and chemicals into Greek territory in order to repel the stranded refugees, so as not to approach the barbed wire of shame and shame they have raised.  Furthermore, rapporteur, in your report you should use the term "YROM" and not "Macedonia", which you wrongly use, in violation of the UN resolutions recognised by Skopje under the name YROM. I say, Mr President, once again that I am strongly opposed to any possible accession of Skopje to the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, I would first and foremost want to thank our colleagues in Parliament and congratulate them on their excellent work in order to stabilise the Balkans and stabilise Macedonia. What I want to emphasize here is also an open dialogue with Greece and I think that is really great and I want to encourage colleagues in both Greece and Macedonia to really try to find common ground on all topics as they have already managed on many topics. What I want to highlight in particular as rapporteur for the Adriatic-Ionian strategy of this Parliament is that I support what was said in the report because I know that it is extremely important for Macedonia to enter into the Adriatic-Ionian strategy of the European Union and thus embrace together this country that needs our help.  In the end, Mr. Hahn, please do everything right now so that the 15,000 people who are on the border between Greece and Macedonia can really get help and that we can resolve this situation because it is really unsustainable.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, as we are hearing during this debate, the name of Macedonia has been a diplomatic headache since the break-up of Yugoslavia, clearly illustrating a deep-seated contradiction within the EU. As a candidate country with aspirations of EU membership, Macedonia must align to the Common Foreign and Security Policy.  As my country prepares to decide on our continued EU membership, we are already hearing one argument for remaining. It is that somehow the CFSP acts as an amplifier for British foreign policy, despite our permanent seat on the UN Security Council and our NATO membership. Yet the Macedonian name issue highlights precisely how the EU is not an amplifier for Member State foreign policy. Rather, it is an independent force with its own logic, sometimes at odds with those Member States for the sake of his own aims.  The EU discredits British foreign policy in Gibraltar, by backing Spain against Gibraltarians even though they are, of course, EU citizens. Thus, the UK is not treated any differently, and nor it we be if we give the Commission free rein by voting to remain EU members on 23 June.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card question. – You raise the issue of Gibraltar, which clearly is not part of this debate. In the event of Brexit, what kind of leverage would the United Kingdom have over the Spanish Government in keeping the border of Gibraltar and Spain open? Why is it that almost all Gibraltarians will be voting to remain and virtually none voted for your party at the last European election? They know full well that Britain remaining in the European Union is the only way in which Spain will be obliged to keep that border open. Please comment.

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Tannock, one day you will realise that the EU is not the answer for everything. I mean this is the hypocrisy of the issue. We have one rule for Spain with regard to her territories in Morocco and one rule for the British territory of Gibraltar, and does that not just highlight the hypocrisy of this place? We have our organisation of other international organisations, the United Nations Security Council, which we are a permanent member of, and I think we will be in a far better position to actually stand up for British interests and British citizens’ interests, including our dependent territories, when we reclaim our place as a global trading nation and turn our back on this shambles of a democracy.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, mr President-in-Office of the Council, mr President-in-Office Vajgl, although it is an official document, mentions in many cases the word macedonian in violation of ethics, while at the same time provoking Greek sensitivity on this issue. That is why this should be avoided. Otherwise, it reveals the democratic deficits that exist in Skopje. Political parties cannot agree on the holding of elections and are constantly postponing the date of the elections, but even if these elections are held no one knows whether they will be held by democratic procedures and whether their results will be acceptable. Corruption also prevails in the country. There is no freedom of the press, there is no independence of the judiciary, the work of the special prosecutor is hindered, Parliament's role is limited and democratic rights are being violated. At the same time, Skopje is violating the obligation of an acceding country to create conditions of good neighbourliness by causing Greece to close its borders.  After the theft of history, culture and the expression and formulation of expansive views against Greece, we also have the closure of borders. With this troubled country do you want to hold accession talks? Isn't Turkey enough for us? Do we want to raise another blackmailer? I wonder, is there a political mechanism in the leadership of the European Union?

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, most sincere thanks to Ivo Vajgl for the report. Macedonia is in a difficult situation. The political crisis is not over yet and, together with migration flows and the underlying fragile situation in the country, I firmly believe that the country needs our backing and support. The EU integration process is still a key to the future of the country. We need to stay engaged and help it to strengthen democracy and political stability. In order to move things forward we need to see full implementation of last year’s political agreements, including well prepared, free and fair elections in June and the implementation of the urgent reform priorities. It is unfortunate that Macedonia has been waiting, and is still waiting, for more than seven years for the opening of negotiations. Now, faced with these challenges, it will have to redouble its efforts to move further along the EU path, and we should help it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, I congratulate my colleague Vajgl on an objective account of a truly turbulence year for Macedonia. On the one hand, the content of our discussions is repeated, the same recommendations on opening negotiations, disputes over names without concrete progress, but on the other hand the political situation in the country has unfortunately gradually deteriorated. That is why the agreement from Pržin, the agreement between the authorities and the opposition after the engaged mediation of our colleagues, was welcomed. The status quo would only multiply the country's problems, but the real danger is that they become chronic or even spill over its borders. A special effort is needed to remediate the refugee crisis because Macedonia is one of the most exposed countries. Macedonia is a small, multiethnic country plagued by serious internal conflicts in a turbulent geopolitical environment. Problems such as accusations of illegal wiretapping of thousands of citizens, threats against journalists, widespread corruption and the frequent intertwining of party and state activities have resulted in deep divisions in society and the absence of political dialogue. That is why further delaying agreed reforms would further deepen distrust and undermine the European perspective.  (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure)).

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), blue card question. Mr President, I am following the debate and I am truly saddened that the European Parliament, which is essentially a state of democracy and legitimacy, instead of respecting the decisions of the United Nations on the Skopje nomenclature, insists that some colleagues instead of the correct name FYROM refer to 'Macedonia'.  What Tito did not achieve after the Second World War, which essentially created a new nation and distributed the Greek symbols and the Greek name, we as the European Parliament are trying to impose it, a name that is purely Greek. Macedonia is a Greek culture, a Greek name, a Greek history. We want to enforce it and in this way vindicate Tito, who did not succeed when he was trying to enforce it.  (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Tonino PICULA
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Fellow MP, fully understanding your sensitivity on this topic, I will only say that in international political communication we of course have Macedonia recognized under the name of its constitution and Macedonia under the name you use, meaning the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. My country, the Republic of Croatia, has recognised Macedonia under its constitutional name and regardless of the sensitivity I understand, I will continue to use that name. I hope for a deal between Skopje and Athens.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Firstly, thanks for the good report to Minister Weigel. Secondly, I highly value what Commissioner Hahn is doing on this gradual – perhaps not very fast, but there are no other options – to expand the European Union. I am in favour of enlargement. I believe that Macedonia – well, all right, the former Yugoslav Federative Republic of Macedonia, let it be anyway – is part of Europe's cultural heritage, part of European civilisation. And the place of Skopje – perhaps I will say so more neutrally – is in the European Union. I do not want the problems with democratic freedoms to be treated as an excuse, I stress – as an excuse – to slow down this Skopje march to the European Union. I believe that the pro-European efforts of this nation must be supported.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Mr President, I believe three points are crucial to get the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia back on track. Firstly, all political parties need to assume their responsibilities and ensure the full implementation of all their commitments in a sustainable manner. Secondly, the country needs to prepare early for parliamentary elections and also to ensure free and fair election procedures. Thirdly, the fight against corruption must continue in an objective and determined manner. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia needs our support in the European Parliament. Hopefully, this resolution will make an important contribution to keeping this country on its European path, and special thanks go to the rapporteur, Ivo Vajgl.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I take note of the decision by the Macedonian Parliament of 23 February to set a new date to hold early parliamentary elections on 5 June 2016. The fact that there was no consensus with the opposition party is highly regrettable and represents a missed political opportunity, as the media reforms and inter-party talks may now be delayed until after the elections. I strongly believe all the political parties in Macedonia should make efforts to create the conditions for credible early elections and that an all-party agreement remains essential to fulfil all elements in the Pržino Agreement. Moreover, substantial progress in the implementation of the urgent reform priorities has to be made. Bilateral issues with Greece and Bulgaria should not be used to obstruct the EU and NATO accession process but should be addressed in a constructive spirit as early as possible in the process, taking into account the principles and values of the United Nations and the European Union. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE), blue card question. Mr Frunzulica, I have listened carefully to you talking about bilateral issues and differences in the region, but I would like to put this in mind: According to data from the Organisation for Journalists Without Borders which assesses freedom of the press, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia ranks 117th , 90 places lower than it was in 2009; it is the last in Europe. There are serious distortions in legislation, in the expression of the media, in state intervention through advertising. I would like to ask you: Are you not concerned about the violation of such a serious criterion, which is at the heart of the European Union, for a country requesting a date of accession?

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card answer. – Of course Macedonia has to comply with all the requests considering all these kinds of issues, by all means. But at the same time, we cannot leave all these countries from the Western Balkans in a grey area. It is a necessity to gradually integrate all these countries into the European Union and NATO if we want to secure the future of this organisation called the European Union. It is very important for all of us.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, Macedonia is a small landlocked country with internal political tensions that would indeed greatly benefit, as a country, from further Euro-Atlantic integration. The interim government in Macedonia shares my view and is keen to pursue its rightful membership of the European Union in order to progress and to advance its economy. We need to strongly support the candidacy of Macedonia, calling on Member States with concerns to find ways of seeking solutions and compromise, particularly over the vexed name question. In the ongoing migration crisis, Macedonia is facing huge pressures and it has also now got elections in June. All these things are particularly delicate, particularly given the inter-ethnic relations, which have always been fragile in this small country. Accession negotiations with Macedonia have been stalled now for far too long, and we should not waste any more time in beginning what will be another lengthy process. As its neighbours in the Western Balkans move ahead, I do not want to reach a future point in which Macedonia is still only a candidate country surrounded by states which are all in the European Union.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Colleague Tannock, you mentioned that you are in for the accession and opening of negotiations with Macedonia.  What do you think, given your report on Montenegro, about this country's NATO membership? Second, do you think the Commission has given enough financial resources to address this difficult humanitarian situation on the border between Greece and Macedonia, which is becoming more demanding every day?

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: blue-card answer. – This is strictly speaking not directly related to Montenegro, for which I am the rapporteur. Montenegro does not have the border pressures that Macedonia has, of course. I think a figure of something like EUR 700 million – from memory, as I am not on the relevant committee for this – has been identified in terms of aid. Clearly Macedonia is under enormous pressure with the closure of the border, but I am of the opinion that you cannot have unlimited numbers of migrants: there has to be a deal. We looked at the deal that was done with Turkey, we now hope that will be effective in slowing down the flow, and I hope that the Western Balkans can cope and that there will be a programme with Turkey which will enable these people to remain in their camps in Turkey, Lebanon and Jordan, rather than all coming to Europe via the Balkans.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE). Mr President, the problem with the negotiations between the European Union and Skopje is not the name; Respect for the Copenhagen criteria is the point, and the Copenhagen criteria include respect for good neighbourly relations between states. The European Commission's report has highlighted the setback in the issues of justice, transparency, the functioning of the media, the democratic state. The use by the report of the adjective 'Macedonian' essentially gives the feeling that the European Parliament is taking a stand in favour of Skopje. The name issue is not a bilateral issue; it is an international issue and as an international issue must be resolved within the framework of the United Nations.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The previous speakers have already mentioned the problems: corruption, lack of media freedom and a lack of quality of the democratic process. These shortcomings can be explained by the country's major problems, but they do not excuse them. Undoubtedly, the biggest challenge for the country was the refugee crisis. Almost all refugees have travelled through the country on their way to Europe. Skopje has overcome these challenges, including with the help of the EU. An assessment of whether it has actually complied with these European standards is quite contradictory. I speak from my own experience, I have travelled the Balkan route several times. One thing to note is that there is a great willingness of the population to help. NGOs, such as the non-denominational Legislature, are exemplary in seeking care and legal support. On the other hand, there are serious reports that professional smuggling networks operate. On my last visit to Gevgelija last week, I was confronted with the fact that refugees reported arbitrary treatment and physical use of force by the border authorities. Such incidents can be used as a measure of the country's capacity for integration, but should also make thoughtful those who believe that the country has a central role to play in closing the Balkan route.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – I congratulate my colleague Iu Vajgel on the work done responsibly and on the essential issues. The political developments of the last year have further shown that the European perspective of Macedonia - the former Yugoslav Republic - depends not only on its reform will and its European partners, but on its internal stability and quality of democracy.  I regret that internal political development is the result of a tentative recommendation for the first time. This represents an additional call for the main political forces to implement what they have committed to under the Pržinski agreement. Only consistent implementation can strengthen the credibility of the accession process and stabilise the political picture of the candidate country. I would like to recall that refugee and other challenges reinforce the need for more symmetrical progress of the whole region towards a European perspective.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: – Europe will not be strong and secure without the countries of the Western Balkans, including Macedonia, becoming part of our union. But I will not talk about the migration crisis, but about problems that have been for decades, at least since 1944 in these places.  In this report, I reiterated my appeal to remove hate speech in the textbooks, for barriers and discrimination against citizens with Bulgarian identity, joint celebrations of common historical events, restoration and maintenance of Bulgarian symbols and monuments in the Republic of Macedonia. These recommendations have been an integral part of the reports in recent years. It is inexplicable to me that provocations in this direction continue, which do not lead to overcoming the accumulated mistrust between the neighbors, especially the legacy of the communist regime. I'il give her a fresh example. I was contacted by the grandson of the prominent Bulgarian writer and patriot Dimitar Talev, who signaled that two of his grandfather's books, "The Iron Candlestick" and "The Prespa Bells", had come out in Skopje in violation of copyright and with altered content. The writer was declared "Macedonian" and the terms "Bulgarian" and "Bulgarian" were removed or replaced with "Macedonian" and "Macedonian". I wish from the bottom of my heart the success of macedonian citizens and the Republic of Macedonia on the path of European membership, especially in this difficult situation, and I believe that only this European membership and integration can overcome these disgusting practices of the past.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, I congratulate my colleague Vajgl on the report and thank him for accepting my amendments regarding Macedonia's NATO membership and opening negotiations with the European Union. I fully agree with him in noting that Macedonia is the candidate country that has made the most progress in aligning legislation with the acquis of the Union. It is therefore unfair for Macedonia to be kept in the waiting room for more than 10 years. I call on the Council to open negotiations to Macedonia and for bilateral issues to be resolved during the negotiations. I also express concern that the agreement reached last year, related to the holding of elections in Macedonia, is not in contempt. I believe, Commissioner Hahn, that elections should not have been postponed because those who wish to govern without elections are asking for it. The situation is causing political instability in the country and making reforms more difficult to implement. Macedonia plays an important role in managing the migrant crisis, where stronger support from the European Union needs to be received.  Macedonia needs the European Union and the Union needs Macedonia. I therefore call once again on the Council to open negotiations for Macedonia.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: – Mr. Chairman, I congratulate my colleague Vajgl at the beginning for an excellently prepared report, and dear Commissioner Hahn, I have two requests for you. One is to find mechanisms on how to strengthen administrative capacities in the European Union delegation in Macedonia, because Macedonia has lost 70m euros in the IPA decommitment, and the system is actually centralised and these funds are contracted by the delegation. So we should avoid that in the next periods.  The second plea is related to returning this 70m euros to Macedonia to be used to manage the migrant crisis, as this country has to invest heavily in border management and quality refugee accommodation, and the 70 millions lost are very much. I also ask you to take into account that all this that is in front of Macedonia in the negotiations should have been done by other countries, which were much faster and more successful when the negotiations were opened.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – Congratulations to Mr Vajgel on his quality report. In these challenging circumstances, when the European Union, or Europe, is facing a wider refugee crisis, Macedonia has proved to be an active, responsible and reliable player in its management. Despite the challenging internal political situation, despite the upcoming elections, this non-member of the European Union better protects European interests and Schengen better than some members of the Schengen area. We have a new progress report on Macedonia ahead. The Commission's report is similar year after year: Macedonia is ready to enter into negotiations. It is high time that the European Union and the Council also began negotiations for Macedonia's accession to the European Union as soon as possible.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there is concern about the deteriorating situation in FYROM, particularly as regards the rule of law, freedom of the media and fundamental rights, which are fundamental parameters for the European Union. There are still strong inter-ethnic tensions across the country, and the uncooperative approach to the migration emergency does not help.  Thousands of migrants, including many children, mass on the border with Greece, a border closed by barbed wire walls and where only a few migrants are let through, many of whom are being challenged by documents issued by the Greek authorities. Skopje needs Europe's help, but the country's alignment with the decisions of the European Union is a key element in the process of European integration.  I believe that it is difficult to support the application for membership of countries that have not adequately clarified their basic political and strategic choices.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Thank you to Mr Weigl for the balanced report. Nearly a year ago, I stated from this grandstand that the integration of the Western Balkans is not because of their political elites, but because of the civil societies of these young democracies. Unfortunately, today Macedonia is dangerously divided, and this political crisis can very quickly undermine the country's European path.  We must also not forget the crisis of the ongoing refugee flow, which can only be solved with the help of the European Union and not with the use of tear gas. However, the European Union must not give up. It is of strategic importance to keep the country's European dream alive and the seventh consecutive recommendation in the report on the opening of negotiations is exactly that way. I would like to call on all political forces to hold fair and free elections, by all European and international standards, and to remind them that it is their duty to serve the citizens of Macedonia, including minorities. Only then will they be able to restore trust in the institutions and initiate much-needed reforms that will revive the country's integration drive.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the European Commission's report on the progress of the Skopje accession process in 2015 is revealing. Ten years after the acquisition of the status of candidate country, no progress has been made on the name issue and on the repudiation of the territorial claims against Greece, which the name conceals. On the contrary, good neighbourly relations are burdened by the falsification and usurpation of Greek history and cultural heritage and by the construction of strange monuments in the city of Skopje.  Beyond that there is a setback in crucial areas such as the consolidation of democracy and respect for human rights, with the Gruevski regime moving in an increasingly authoritarian direction. There can be no discounts on any of these issues on the part of the European Union and therefore the conditions for opening accession negotiations are not met.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – Dear colleague Vajgl, thank you for all the energy and time you have put into this well-prepared report. The former ..., that is, Macedonia, has been in the waiting room for ten years and more and is identified as one of the most advanced countries in the Western Balkans, especially as regards the conditions for membership. I think, of course, there is a certain internal political conflict, that there are, of course, quite a number of challenges, but the refugee crisis is also a much bigger challenge today.  Macedonia has borne and bears a great burden, a much greater burden of this refugee crisis than any Member State, and I also think that the European Union must move from words to action and, indeed, to help Macedonia financially. As for the conditions, I must say that obviously sometimes the Commission also has a different dioptria, because if we look at the agreement with Turkey, we are actually prepared to make great indulgences, and not in Macedonia for 10 years.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my colleague Ivo Vajgl enormously for the excellent and excellent work he has done on this report, which is always honest and balanced. , still accused of being selective, the politicisation of public administration, corruption, problems of inter-ethnic coexistence and, more importantly, media freedom.  We are firmly convinced for a future and a prospect of enlargement for all the Western Balkans. But we also see a serious political mistake that the European Union and the Commission are making at the moment. , a redistribution mechanism for migration. This is a mistake: we are calling for free and transparent elections for Macedonia and a more balanced process.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE). Mr President, Mr Hahn, the question is what we are asking of the candidate countries: compliance with the European acquis, with the Copenhagen criteria. What is happening in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia? It has a serious deficit in the separation of powers, respect for human and minority rights, respect for freedom of the press – it is last in Europe: 90 below 2009.  Are we going to open the way to discounts today? And how are we going to respond to Turkey's demands like this?  What the ambassadors of the European Union and the United States are recording about the reasons for postponing the elections is added to the behaviour of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia today at the Greek-Macedonian border. Where refugees in need of international protection are not allowed to pass. Is this consistent with the spirit and letter of european decisions? The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia still has a long way to go. To make its democracy work like European democracies and then to open the door to the European Union!

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would very much like any bilateral issue between states, of course, not to hamper macedonia's accession process. I congratulate the rapporteur on the report he has submitted.  It is a fact that Macedonia is, to some extent, lagging behind the expectations that we had associated with its accession talks. I agree that Macedonia needs to be added, and then, of course, it can, I suppose, count on the full support of us in its accession talks, in its journey to the European Union.  These questions, which have been legitimately raised by my colleagues, cannot be crossed just because this country needs our help at the moment. The leaders of this country really need to work, and I say this as the former president of the Group of Friends, the Czech Republic and Macedonia.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I wish to thank Members for the debate once again, and in particular those who have followed the whole debate. I think the political leaders of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia now have the responsibility to take the necessary steps to put their country back on the Euro-Atlantic track. We have sent a clear signal; they need to implement the political agreement in full and in good faith and address the urgent reform priorities to which the government has also committed itself.  The next challenge for the political leaders is to show political will and to take the necessary measures in order to organise credible elections on 5 June. Under the political agreement the elections are meant to be a key step as part of the reform process. The elections should restore citizens’ faith in the electoral process and move the country beyond the political crisis. With your support we will continue to follow and measure progress very closely.  The country has no time to lose and I am saying this in particular in respect to what has been discussed here and mentioned several times, namely the refugee and migration flow, and therefore I think the political leadership in the country should be focused on this. I can also reassure you that the European Union is supporting the country in terms of expertise, but also in terms of money, but also here I have to say, this is always based on the concrete needs assessment. It is not about transferring money on an unclear request, it is always on the basis of a clear, so to say, traceable need and then support is possible and has already been provided.  The political crisis should end for once and for all, in the interest of the country hopefully and the future, and in the interest and need and demand of its citizens.  So I count on the support of this House in sending unified messages to the political leaders of the country and may I say to all of those who have criticised, shall I say, the democratic development of the country, these sceptics are right and I agree, but I think we should understand and share the view that the biggest leverage for the European Union , for our own interests, is to have negotiations where we can really address these deficiencies.  We have only leverage at the point where we prepare the opening of accessions and we have a particular leverage during the negotiations. As we can see in some examples we do not have a real leverage after the accession. So this is something we should be aware of if we are thinking about further development of a country, in particular of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. In this respect I count on you, also for the future, and once again thank you not only for the debate today but also for your commitment.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, to conclude, let me express once more my sincere gratitude to you, Mr Vajgl, as well as to Mr Howitt and Mr Kukan for your excellent work and commitment.  The Council attaches great importance to moving ahead with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. However we remain seriously concerned as to the fragile domestic political situation. The need for constructive dialogue extends to all parts of the political scene, most notably to the main political parties. The Commission has made its recommendation to open accession negotiations with the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia conditional on the full implementation of the June/July agreement and on substantial progress in urgent reform priorities, and rightly so. This issue shall be addressed again after the parliamentary elections and, on that basis, the Council will refer to the matter. It is currently, as I mentioned in the beginning, up to the political leaders of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to deliver. I am happy to note that most of you did agree, or do agree, upon this approach. We count, in this regard, on the continued support of the European Parliament to call on all leaders of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to cooperate in good faith and to put the country back on the reform track.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: I have received a motion for a resolution. The debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 10 March 2015 at 12 noon. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I am in favour of the report, because we must continue to build trust through dialogue and continue the neighbourly agreement. In 2015, the country faced one of its worst political crises. Freedom of expression and the independence of the courts have been compromised and confidence in public institutions continues to decline. It is our task as a European neighbour to support Macedonia in its reform efforts. This is also true in view of the current migration problem: Macedonia has to cope with an unprecedented influx of migrants, in 2015 more than 500,000 people crossed the country. There is no alternative to a comprehensive European solution to the refugee issue, and Macedonia has shown itself to be a responsible partner in managing the huge influx of migrants and refugees.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – In its report on the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia in 2015, Parliament highlighted the lack of effective institutional checks and balances in the country in political crises. The only way out of this situation is to fully implement the Przino political convention, since the stability of the political situation is key to keeping euro integration processes moving. However, political stability is even more appreciated when you consider the enormous pressure the country is under because of the migrant crisis. It is therefore important that the European Union effectively supports this candidate state and considers it a key partner in dealing with the migrant crisis.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – I cannot remain indifferent to the current developments in Macedonia. At times, Macedonia seems to have found itself not only in a strategically sensitive position as the EU's first neighbour, but also in a vicious circle. An agreement on reforms has been reached, the date of the election, which could mean a democratic awakening of the country. And yet, will things really change radically this time? I welcome the appointment of a special prosecutor to lead an investigation into a wiretap that further deepened the political crisis last year, but I am not convinced of its independence from the rest of the judicial system in a country whose impartiality is not taken for granted. The June elections must be held in accordance with the highest democratic standards. These could be threatened by the state of media freedom, and political parties do not look at the appropriateness of the means to gain sympathy from the electoral body. In the upsetting social and political reality of Macedonia, I would like to highlight in particular the situation of young people. The lack of a real perspective and high unemployment lead to the emergence of a generation of desperate young people who are without a clear vision and, consequently, are more prone to identifying extremist ideologies or religious radicalisation. And that will be the highest price Macedonia will pay for its future. This must sober up Macedonian political leaders and force them to lead a less selfish and more constructive policy.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The report fails to reflect the real situation for the country. Rewarding the principles of FYROM is a suspensive for the real progress of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It is unacceptable for FYROM to be declared a 'reliable partner' at a time when it is taking reprehensible unilateral actions such as closing borders and using force against refugees. FYROM should be called upon to respect international treaties on refugees and to guarantee the possibility of safe and permanent transit for all people in need of international protection, regardless of their origin.  In addition, it must finally be accepted by all that the issue of Greece-FYROM relations is neither a bilateral issue nor limited to the nomenclature. It is an unresolved international and regional problem that must be solved under the auspices of the UN. Its development is a prerequisite for good neighbourly relations, which are an essential element in the enlargement process with decisive implications for regional peace. It is clear that the EU, in order to promote the Euro-Atlantic integration of FYROM in order to serve its energy interests, is prepared to set itself off once again and to defend the principles it invokes. That's why we voted against it.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the statements by the Council and the Commission on the 2015 report on Montenegro (2015/2894(RSP)).

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, let me start by thanking you for the continuous and constructive contribution of the European Parliament to the advancement of Montenegro’s accession process to the European Union and, in particular, your rapporteur Charles Tannock. Over the past year, relations between the European Union and Montenegro have maintained a positive momentum. In its conclusions adopted in December last year, the Council welcomed the continued progress. It took positive note of improvements in the legal framework in the area of the rule of law and work on the establishment of new institutions.  Now the Council also noted with satisfaction Montenegro’s positive role in further developing regional cooperation and in advancing good neighbourly relations. It also commended Montenegro for its cooperation on foreign policy issues, in particular, for its continued full alignment with the EU’s foreign policy positions. It is furthermore encouraging evidence that two further negotiation chapters could be opened up at the accession conference in December, bringing the total number of chapters now opened to 22 out of 35.  Looking to the future, we need to stress again the importance of the rule of law, which is a fundamental value of the European Union and a cross cutting concern for the enlargement process. As your draft resolution rightly points out, further progress in Montenegro’s accession negotiations continues to depend on progress in this area.  The Council also restated how important it is for the entire rule of law system to deliver concrete results, in particular, by establishing a solid track record in the fight against corruption and organised crime. Further efforts are needed to focus on effective reform implementation, leading to tangible results towards the interim benchmarks. The Council will continue to closely monitor developments in this area. On a related note, the Council shares the view expressed in your draft resolution that Montenegro should intensify its efforts to guarantee freedom of expression and of the media, to pursue the public administration reform and to strengthen the independence of institutions, as well as to improve the business environment. Your draft resolution spells out many other important concerns to address, which are also highlighted by the findings of the Commission’s progress report. With the upcoming parliamentary elections in Montenegro this year, I would stress that ensuring the full implementation of the new electoral legislation is crucial. We are well aware that Montenegro currently is facing a difficult political situation and that this could hamper the reform efforts. Therefore, it is important to recall the need for all political parties to show responsibility and to re-engage in constructive dialogue, with parliament being the key forum for political debate. In this context, we count on the government and on the opposition to work together, not least to meet the expectations of the Montenegrin citizens. This is also important for ensuring public trust in the political process and in the state institutions. Sustainable and constructive cooperation remains essential to maintaining the necessary political commitments to effectively address outstanding challenges, to deliver on the reform agenda and to progress in the accession negotiations. Dialogue and inclusiveness are also key issues raised by your draft resolution, and I would like to stress how valuable it is that this message is passed on to Montenegro. In this respect the European Parliament’s important contribution through its work in the stabilisation and association parliamentary committee is most welcome. Mr President, let me conclude by saying that, looking ahead, we do hope to see continued progress.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for your invitation to the discussion on Parliament’s resolution on Montenegro. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur for Montenegro, Charles Tannock, for his balanced and comprehensive draft resolution. It is a text that well reflects the assessment of the Commission’s 2015 Montenegro Report. This June, we will mark four years since the opening of accession negotiations with Montenegro. As your resolution points out, we have, as was already mentioned by the Minister, to date opened 22 negotiating chapters with Montenegro, of which two are provisionally closed. Concerning the rule of law, which is, as you know, at the heart of the accession process, over the last few years we have seen the first steps in achieving lasting reforms, through the adoption of legislation and the establishment of institutions. As you also point out however – and as the Commission stated in its November report – this is not the whole story. Our assessment is, unfortunately, that real progress on the ground on the rule of law remains limited, including in establishing a track record in the fight against corruption and organised crime. This is the message that the Commission is giving to Montenegro at a rule of law meeting in Podgorica today. When I met Prime Minister Djukanovic last month, I congratulated him on his country’s invitation to join NATO. I also stressed, however, that while the country was moving ahead overall, we were now entering a decisive phase, in particular in the accession negotiations and on the rule of law. We need to see Montenegro making credible progress on Chapters 23 and 24. We must see a tangible track record of implementation. This is not only for the benefit of the accession negotiations: legal certainty, a functioning independent judicial system, a transparent administration and fundamental rights, such as for instance property rights, are necessary not only for meeting the rule of law criteria; they are preconditions for attracting investment, improving competitiveness and stimulating growth and jobs. And therefore, as you know, I prefer to talk about the accession process and less about negotiations because it is about the development of a country towards European Union membership. We are also working very closely with Montenegro on improving the country’s competitiveness through our economic dialogue. The focus is on sectoral reforms, including on education, labour market, infrastructure, and the business environment. Concerning the other negotiating chapters, we have given Montenegro guidance on what needs to be done, through the opening benchmarks. Meeting them is a challenge for the country, in particular when we talk about alignment with the EU acquis on competition policy, or environment and climate change. Let me turn now to the political situation in Montenegro. The political dialogue that was launched in December was put on hold, without an agreement, on 19 February. However, despite the fact that there is, to date, no agreement among the political leaders on the establishment of a ‘government of electoral trust’, it is crucial that the dialogue within the parliament continues.  This year, Montenegro will hold local and parliamentary elections. The full implementation of the electoral legislation is crucial for the organisation of these elections so that they are credible. It is the responsibility of Montenegro’s political leaders to ensure this.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, 2016 is a very important year for Montenegro politically. As it approaches its 10th anniversary since independence, the country is not only going to the polls in parliamentary elections, it is also in the process of crucial negotiations regarding its accession to NATO following its invitation to join the alliance last year. Montenegro continues to progress well, and has now opened 22 chapters including the key ones of 23 and 24, and 2016 will see the opening of further chapters and hopefully the provisional closing of others. As both the Commission report and the resolution as adopted in committee note, corruption and organised crime continue to be of concern, along with some aspects of media freedom, but the situation is generally improving and progress is being made. We are seeing an increased number of charges brought against those involved in high-level corruption, and the work of the Special Prosecutor’s Office is beginning to establish itself. With the launch of the Anti-Corruption Agency on 1 January this year I am encouraged by the increase in state resources that have been made available to tackle these issues. But of course there are some concerns as to the administrative capacity of such institutions in terms of their financing and these need to be addressed. But we must remain conscious of the financial constraints facing a very small country like Montenegro, which already gets some specialist assistance from neighbouring former-Yugoslav countries already in the EU, like Slovenia and Croatia. Very much to its credit, Montenegro has been a leading example in aligning its foreign policy with that of the EU’s CFSP and its Member States, and it has clearly demonstrated its ability to interact competently with its partners on such issues. Montenegro bravely fully aligned itself with the EU on the sanctions regime against Russia following the annexation of Crimea despite its economic ties with that country, and works in close cooperation with the European Union in tackling international Jihadi terrorism. There will be much talk in the year ahead of the need for a referendum regarding NATO membership. My position as rapporteur is clear in that I believe this is an internal matter for Montenegro and not something that we in the EU should be interfering with. That being said, however, we should be aware of the wider context of the debate and the external influences that are being brought to bear on tiny Montenegro. In summary, I am very happy with the resolution before us today and I am pleased that we have been able to work constructively across the political groups to agree to this in the committee. I always say that Montenegro is the good news story of the Western Balkans, but with the added current pressure that the migration crisis has brought to the entire Western Balkans region, Montenegro is increasingly seen as a beacon of stability too.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I would like to first thank the rapporteur for his good cooperation, Mr Tannock. We have repeatedly described Montenegro as the "successful example" in the Western Balkans. In recent months, we have witnessed protests and violence in the streets following the vote of no confidence in the government. No "success story" is guaranteed – freedom and democracy must be worked on every day. After last week's failed no-confidence vote, the opposition is calling for the exit of parliament and new elections. The Euro-Atlantic orientation of the country is being questioned and a reorientation to Russia is requested. The report supports the full alignment of the country's foreign policy with the Common Security and Defence Policy. Montenegro can set an example for other countries in the region, such as Macedonia and Serbia, to work together with the European Union in this direction. We must support Montenegro's European orientation in order to keep it on the path of Euro-Atlantic development and not allow citizens to fall victim to pressure from third countries.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Montenegro is the champion of the Western Balkans on the road to the European Union. Significant progress has been made in recent years, confirmed by the opening of 22 chapters and the temporary closure of 2. This report comes at a critical time for Montenegro. The elections to be held this year are crucial for stability and we hope that they will be completed in the best possible political climate. The Socialist Group welcomes the country's efforts over the years on its way to the successful conclusion of negotiations with the European Union.  But we must avoid reform fatigue, which can create obstacles. That is why, in the resolution in addition to the important reforms that have been made, we stress the need for additional efforts in the areas of public administration, independence of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime. We are still waiting for action to tackle tax evasion, high social inequalities, long-term unemployment and poverty. Social progress for us is the most important factor in the accession process.  Finally, I would like to address the issue of Montenegro's accession to NATO. We are by no means opposed to joining the Alliance, as some here want to present. But we believe that it is a decision that every country must take on its own, without any external intervention. What we disagree with is the attempt to link these two different processes. Today here we are discussing Montenegro's accession to the European Union. The European Union and NATO are two different organisations, with different objectives. Any link between the two undermines the autonomy of the European vision. That is why we have tabled an amendment which makes this position clear.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam President, I would first like to congratulate and thank Mr. Tannock for a quality report that handles the overall situation in Montenegro well and for the good cooperation that I hope and am convinced has contributed to the quality of this report.  Montenegro is the country most advanced on the road from six Western Balkan countries to the European Union. Although it is the smallest country, it can have a major positive impact on the entire Area of the Western Balkans, especially on the two neighbouring countries, namely Kosovo and Bosnia and Herzegovina.  The report mentions all outstanding issues very clearly and I agree with Commissioner Hahn that Montenegro's integration is at a critical point. It is time for Montenegro, in addition to the formal results, to show real progress in a number of areas mentioned in the report, the fight against corruption, freedom of the media, the fight against organised crime, the role and strength of civil society, minority rights, but I would nevertheless emphasize one most important thing in my opinion for Montenegro, which is elections.  That country has been deeply divided since its very creation. One part of that country's political forces is actually against independence, almost the existence of that country, and that is why the elections ahead are actually the most important process. If these are fair, clear and transparent elections that no significant political force will contest, then Montenegro will have a democratic future and then its path to the European Union will be much clearer.  With the perpetuation of the conflict in Montenegro after the election, Montenegro's chances of being a democratic country and being successful on the road to the European Union are much lower. That is why I call on the Commission to actively monitor this process of preparation and implementation of elections in Montenegro.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we welcome Montenegro's efforts in many important areas, as noted. However, we are critical of the insistence in the text of the report on interconnecting the process of accession to the European Union with NATO. NATO membership cannot strengthen stability in the region, as reflected in the report; on the contrary, we believe that this process militarizes and creates greater destabilization in the western region, in the Balkans and in the country itself. In addition, we invite Parliament to consider the fact that public opinion in Montenegro is divided over the possibility of joining NATO, so they should be able to decide: it is called democracy. Also, as a group, we are against privatization policies promoted through the accession process, because of the social problems that accompany these policies. These economic models have proven to have a negative impact on European citizens and, consequently, there is no need to impose them on the States that are now trying to join the European Union.
