Let us deepen our relationship, of course, let us support the country in its efforts to address the serious problems it has. Let us help in strengthening the rule of law and democracy, in the fight against corruption and organized crime, and strengthening the protection of freedom of expression, the media and journalists.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Montenegro as such is, yes, something of a success story. It is a country which has for quite some time now been in a negotiation process with the European Union, and there has been quite some progress. The report by Mr Tannock – and I would like to thank him for this – is a well drafted and well balanced one, with lots of emphasis on the fight against corruption and organised crime, which is important, the reform of the judiciary, media freedom, threats to critical NGOs, and also the rights of minorities. For example, there has been progress for LGBTI people but also setbacks – for example, no Pride was held in Nikšić last year. But I would like to refer more to the critical situation at the moment in Montenegro, a crisis that we are seeing, a political crisis. I would like to hail the small sister party of mine, Pozitivna Montenegro, which has made a very constructive proposal in order to make sure that all parties are included in transitional government and that the electoral laws will be improved to make sure that free and fair elections are possible in the autumn. I hope they will be successful because it is important to make sure that this process towards elections is one where the citizens really feel that their vote is going to be listened to and heard and will count.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Charles Tannock, for his work on this report, which absolutely shows the great experience, the great knowledge of the country. Montenegro is, in my view, certainly an example in the Western Balkans and among the candidate countries, and it is also one that, seeing the steps taken in recent years, is the closest, in this process of rapprochement, to the Union and to accession to it.  It certainly still needs to make enormous progress on the issue of corruption, also on the issue of the functioning of public administration, which continues – but it is a scourge common to many candidate countries in this area – to still be too politicised and still too closely linked to party activity.  I would like to highlight the problem of high unemployment, especially among young people, which afflicts the country. Unfortunately, I cannot agree with the part in which it welcomes NATO membership with great positivity, especially in its timing, which, in my opinion, risks fuelling tensions and divisions, which are very deep with neighbouring countries, but which is dividing up even more and helping to split the internal political landscape.  What is needed is great cohesion in order to continue on the road to accession, and we therefore need a strong and democratic Montenegro, capable of carrying out reforms that can then lead it to join the European family.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, your enlargement policy still pits the West against the East. Whenever a problem arises, it is the flight forward and the problems remain whole, as is the case, for example, with the immigration channels managed by organized crime in Montenegro. Your Western policy is the permanent Anschlu in the name of the European people, which does not exist, in favour of a pro-US, pro-NATO oligarchy, which exists, against the peoples of Europe and against united continental Europe. Just back, the divide, the rupture is now there, at home, against this Europe: Danish referendum where no wins, Dutch referendum on Ukraine, Hungarian referendum, future referendum on Brexit and, tomorrow, France. Your Europe, those who want to enter it, is despotic Turkey, the Kosovar narco-state, the Montenegrin kleptocratic. Historical and democratic states, on the other hand, are asking questions and even want to get out of them. Your Europe, organized criminal networks are taking control with Turkey, which has already submitted you. Your Europe? A field of ruins, because in the name of Europe, you have betrayed Europe, the worst betrayal.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: – Madam President, when it comes to Montenegro, then I can say that solid progress has been made when it comes to integration and certainly needs to support Montenegro's progress in terms of integration. For every commendation is progress in foreign policy and defence policy where there has been alignment with European Union policy. However, there is still a lot of work to be done for Montenegro to get into the situation, regardless of what it has already opened 22 chapters and regardless of everything that has been done so far, I would like to mention some of my amendments that have passed, some that have not.  I would like to thank Mr. Tannock for his excellent report, but I would like to mention in the form of good-minded relations that progress has been made regarding Bosnia and Herzegovina, but we have not yet resolved the Prevlaka issue in relation to Croatia. I also want to mention the issue of the succesion of military assets of the former Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia. It is also worth noting here the fair reparations for the victims of the Montenegrin camps, remembering the recent homeland war, which we have not yet solved and I think the moment to mention it here. There is also Boka Kotorska as one special region, I think it should be taken into account and that its identity should be nurtured.  Anyway, I'm for this report, but I felt compelled to mention these specifics.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Madam Chairman, Mr. Charles Tannock's report is an exhaustive and balanced document because it clearly explains the areas where Montenegro made clear progress last year, but also problems such as, say, high levels of corruption that are clearly more resilient to reform. Twenty-two open chapters in membership negotiations, including Chapters 23 and 24, are measurable. I would also like to congratulate Montenegro on its recent invitation to join nato. As a representative from Croatia, I am pleased by the geopolitical fact that a new member of the Alliance is coming to our land and sea borders. Twenty-five years ago, there was aggression against my country from this area, and in the future we will jointly deal with security issues with a new ally.  There are several open issues left – border demarcation, the succesion of the former Yugoslavia, reparations to the victims of war are just some of them. In addition, the protection of the multiethnic character of Boka Kotorska must be one of the priorities. Despite progress, Montenegro is divided by a period of time until membership in the European Union, in which it will have to resolve a whole series of internal blockades by adapting to European standards. That is why it is important to establish and maintain an open dialogue with the domestic public on the social costs of reforms. In addition, the rhythm and quality of the work that the country needs to do is certainly influenced by the relations between the authorities and the opposition, and they are, unfortunately, severely damaged at this point.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Madam President, Montenegro is experiencing a major political crisis, so I think it is too pragtistic to expect a genuine commitment to reforms at this time.  But what worries me above all is the fact that Montenegro is not working enough to improve relations with its neighbours. The border dispute with Croatia has not even begun to be resolved, and Montenegro is nevertheless embarking on exploration and exploitation of hydrocarbons in the Adriatic Sea, counting on almost 2000 square kilometres of the Croatian Sea and deviating from the 2002 Protocol on a Temporary Regime along the Southern Border.  Back in 2011, Croatia sent a protest note to Montenegro for the determination of hydrocarbon exploration and production blocks, whose lateral border to Croatia significantly deviated from the demarcation line under the 2002 protocol. Montenegrins have the right to exploit oil and gas from the Adriatic, but only in their waters, the final dimensions of which we will not know until the border issue is resolved.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Montenegro is a vivid example of successfully implemented reforms and macroeconomic stability. The progress the country has made in the past year is a ray of light for the development of the region. It is no coincidence that 22 negotiating chapters are now open, including chapters 23 and 24 on fundamental rights and justice, and two have been promptly closed.  Montenegro is a stoger of regional stability, and its relations with our neighbours deserve our admiration. Its foreign policy is fully in line with the European Union's foreign and defence policy, and quite logically, NATO has invited the country to join the alliance. Of course, the progress made carries additional responsibilities. The government must strengthen the role of the national parliament and continue to fight corruption. It is necessary to adopt new laws on European standards for minorities and on the legal status of religious communities in order to ensure their participation in the socio-political life of the country.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, NATO’s contribution to the safety and security of Europe has been immeasurable, when their principles of collective security secured the West against Soviet oppression and nuclear war. I have, and always will, stand against the EU’s attempts to piggyback onto these achievements. It is NATO that secured peace on this continent, not the European Union. However, what honest friend to NATO would I be if I did not offer criticism when I believed it necessary. I have misgivings over the accession of Montenegro to the alliance. Europe is in the middle of its most insecure time since Glasnost. Whilst we must not bow down to pressure from Putin, we must also not needlessly provoke further potential for conflict. Realistically, what can Montenegro contribute to the alliance in military terms? The great strength of NATO is that it is a military alliance, and, unlike the European Union, not a political union. But it would seem in this case that political posturing has trumped military sense.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have the utmost respect for the Montenegrin people who, in 1912, dared to declare war on the Ottoman Empire and ended the ottoman Empire from our continent. Nevertheless, we regret his decision, taken on the margins and under questionable conditions, to separate from another people, the Serbian people. As for this report, in addition to its usual lenient formulas, it contains dubious insertions aimed at recognising the independence of this pseudo-State that is Kosovo or dictating to Montenegro its foreign policy, prohibiting it from any privileged link with Russia and, above all, endorsing its entry, most questionable, into this machine to crush the peoples that is NATO. This report is inherently perverse, and we denounce it.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank our rapporteur, Charles Tannock. I believe his resolution draws a realistic picture of Montenegro’s path towards the European Union. As we have already heard, progress in the alignment with and implementation of the EU acquis has been achieved: out of a total of 35 negotiation chapters, 22 chapters have now been opened, while two chapters have already been provisionally closed. In particular, I welcome NATO’s decision to invite Montenegro to join the alliance. I hope that efficient and successful accession negotiations will follow.  As the standing rapporteur for Serbia, I would like to highlight that ten years after Montenegro declared its independence the two countries maintain a good relationship. A protocol on cooperation and European integration was signed in July 2015 and a number of high-level meetings between Serbian and Montenegrin officials contribute to the overall stability in the region. The role of both countries is a good example of how regional issues in the Western Balkans need to be dealt with.

name: Goffredo Maria BETTINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the resolution on Montenegro seems to me to be balanced and useful for montenegro's journey towards the European Union. There is, however, one sensitive issue, which concerns the point of Montenegro's demands for NATO membership. The Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D) has tabled a very clear, logical and irrefutable amendment. As the text of the resolution does, we cannot superimpose the path of EU membership with that of NATO.  The EU is a political, cultural, economic and social body. NATO is a military alliance. Europe cannot be distorted and NATO misunderstood. These are different things and they must remain so. Otherwise, Russia would be right to denounce our association and stabilisation agreements with its neighbours, such as a Trojan horse, in order to pave the way for the Atlantic Alliance close to its borders.  We do not need to suspicious someone, to foster misunderstandings, to show the muscles unnecessarily. It seems to me that there is already so much tension in international relations and Europe certainly shows that it does not come to terms with it easily. Russia is an indispensable ally to fight ISIS, if only for a diplomatic and tactical sense. Let us avoid useless words and let us not touch on susceptibility.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, thanks to Mr Tannock we have a very good report. I am glad that it is focused on priorities, such as the judiciary, the fight against corruption, but also on such critical issues as media freedom in the country. Montenegro advanced in the accession process and deserves our continued support. I think it is important to mark this progress with closing negotiating chapters which are already finalised.  We have to see Montenegro’s accession process in a broader, regional context. We should welcome its cooperation and constructive role in the region and also its 100% alignment with the EU’s foreign policy. As in many countries of the region, Montenegro too has internal political fights between the government and the opposition. It is always important to remind politicians to fight these battles in the parliament and avoid violence on the streets.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I note, not concealing the many misgivings, the positive debate on the Stabilisation Agreement with Montenegro. It seems essential to make every effort to ensure free and democratic participation in the forthcoming elections. Just as I continue to stress the need for full recognition of the rights and protection of workers. To ensure safety at the workplace and adequate social protection for workers in retirement.  Finally, I would like to express my concern about the limits that have been found so far in terms of the level of protection of minorities, both religious and ethnic and political, of the LGBT community. A final recommendation should be extended to promote women's right to participate in political life, institutional life and the labour market.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: – Madam Vice President, first of all, I congratulate my colleague Tannock on preparing the report. It is clear that Montenegro has gone the furthest out of all southeast European countries on its European path with twenty-two provisionally opened chapters and several closed. It is now essential to address the systemic reforms imposed by Chapters 23 and 24, namely the independence of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime, and the rule of law.  After the serious political crisis we have witnessed in recent months, I think that achieving a broad cross-party consensus in the Process of European Integration is a capital issue for further stability and a culture of dialogue in Montenegro. Also, congratulations on the invitation to join the North Atlantic Alliance – this will stabilise Montenegro, but also the entire Adriatic basin. I expect Montenegro to respect the rights of minorities, especially the rights of the Croatian minority, to resolve the remaining issues related to the dissolution of the former Yugoslavia, to prosecute war crimes and to also resolve the issue of the Adriatic school ship.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, Montenegro is a key example of how the EU is able to push for positive reform in third countries, using its collective weight to promote stability, prosperity and human rights in its neighbourhood to benefit us all in a way a single Member State would be unable to do. Close cooperation with Montenegro is not just key in view of its position on the migration route running through the Western Balkans – it is also a transit country for trafficking of illegal weapons that could end up in Europe. I applaud the increased cooperation with the EU under the action plan against illicit arms trafficking that was adopted by the Commission in the wake of the Paris attacks. I also welcome the recent opening of two negotiation chapters with the EU on transport and energy, giving a new boost to our relations with this important neighbour.  Yet some important concerns remain: further progress has to be made on strengthening the rule of law, reforming the judiciary and fighting corruption. The elections this year will be another key test. In order for them to be free and fair, implementing the new electoral legislation will be vital, as will making sure that the media are able to operate freely and independently.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – I congratulate my colleague Charles Tannock on the new good report and Montenegro on making significant progress by opening and closing the negotiating chapters over the last year. At the same time, I would like the stage to win the candidate country by opening up the negotiations without reducing its dynamism and ambition to progress on a broad front of well-known issues on which reforms are necessary.  With the urgent need to increase attention first in building a functioning rule of law, I consider it crucial that Montenegro does not join countries whose internal development and European perspective are paralyzed ... internal political polarisation. Montenegro's political forces have a responsibility to find common denominators that are necessary to strengthen political stability and the credibility and dynamics of the European perspective.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate Mr Tannock for the substance of this report. Listening to our debate and looking at the report, it is crystal clear where Montenegro stands today on the accession path. I think we can all agree that further efforts are needed in a number of areas. I am referring to an effective, transparent and accountable public administration, an independent and efficient judiciary, and a credible and bold fight against corruption and organised crime. But Montenegro, since the start of the accession negotiations, has come a long way. A total of 22 chapters were opened, two have been provisionally closed. Needless to say, Montenegro is in the lead in the enlargement process. The progress of Montenegro goes well beyond its borders. Its success demonstrates that the accession process is still credible and predictable. It shows that EU enlargement is still able to deliver.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I also want to congratulate the rapporteur on the report submitted. I've studied the part that concerns the judiciary and the fight against corruption the most. I have been dealing with this subject for more than ten years and I must say that Montenegro has an ambitious programme to improve the functioning of domestic justice, the issue of introducing a code of ethics for judges or new disciplinary proceedings, as well as strengthening judicial councils. These are necessary prerequisites, but they must not only remain with the introduction of laws, they must also be fulfilled in practice. And I would like to ask and call on the Commission here to assist Montenegro in this matter as much as possible. As the Czech Republic at the time of accession, it helped us when experts, judges from Member States went to the Czech Republic and there they helped to put unwritten rules, but also written laws into practice. So please, Commissioner, let us help Montenegro, let us not only stay with the fact that we are noting what needs to be introduced, but let us also try to strengthen the rule of law in Montenegro with our own action.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Madam Chairman, I agree fully with the Commissioner that the process of joining the European Union is much more than just negotiations. This is about democratising society and adopting the values of partnership, competitiveness and an open single market for common European policies.  That is why I am pleased that in the discussion we particularly emphasized the establishment of a favourable business environment that means an efficient judiciary and fast and simple public administration. I find chapters 22 and 32 particularly interesting, and this is where progress is unfortunately modest, and these chapters indicate Montenegro's readiness to establish quality and transparent management of public finances.  I believe that technical assistance needs to be stepped up to help Montenegro with any changes ahead. Finally, I stress that in the process of joining the European Union, it is important to resolve open issues with neighbouring countries, and for Croatia, border issues, property succesion and reparations for the victims of Montenegrin camps are very important.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Madam President, on the basis of this report, we are pleased to conclude that, despite all the political divisions and still living contradictions in montenegro's democratisation, we are at the forefront of the western Balkans accession process and with good results in catching up. I would like to draw the Commission's attention to the fact that this is in itself a value that the EU should use through a more active and flexible accession negotiation strategy to motivate and stabilise the country and the whole region to European values. This, of course, will, above all, regain the credibility of our own enlargement policy and then re-dynamic it. Let us finally move beyond treating enlargement policy as second-class, because in the current situation of the Union, we need all the positive integration impulses.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, Montenegro is a great example of how quickly the country can be democratised, how change is emerging and how government is beginning to adapt to what European standards mean. This is also a good example for Montenegro's neighbours, and I am primarily thinking of Albania, which is in no way really starting negotiations with the European Union, and we know how important it is for this to happen in Albania, and of course in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Macedonia, which we have previously talked about.  What, as a friend of Montenegro, as a person who is often in that country, I want to emphasize in particular is my invitation to both the authorities and the opposition in Montenegro, I want to really call for a sincere dialogue, for open conversation and government and opposition in Montenegro and even extra-parliamentary opposition, in order to hold fair elections and to really accelerate the entry and rapprochement of Montenegro with the European Union after this election.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, while in the last case we are with Macedonia, I think we have all raised quite a few eyebrows about the snagging of this country's accession process, so in the case of Montenegro, I, too, would like to applaud the progress that this country has made. The fact is that Montenegro is indeed at the top of the european union at the moment, and I want to congratulate this country, of course.  Mr Pospisil spoke here about the field of internal security and justice. I would also like to talk about the issue of depoliticisation of the civil service, that is, the civil service, which should indeed be depoliticised according to the rules. This is very important for Montenegro to also fulfil as an access requirement for talks with the European Union. Finally, although Montenegro is now going through some internal political problems, its people are undoubtedly heading for the European Union.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – I would like to point out that Montenegro is the country that has made the greatest progress in the accession negotiations in the Western Balkans. It has opened twenty-two chapters and I think, of course, we all want it to continue with the same zeal and commitment.  There are, of course, quite a number of issues that need to be identified more specifically, including corruption issues in certain areas. In the area of justice, of course, we want the elections to be held this year as free and democratic as possible.  However, as a Representative of the Greens, I would like to mention one more thing. Montenegro has a wonderful nature, and I would also like to point out, as a Green Member, and, of course, to call on the representatives of the authorities not to build up the whole of Montenegro on God willing and to protect important landscape areas, especially the salt pans in Ulcinj and Buljarica, because in this way they can preserve the habitat for future generations.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me conclude my presentation today by reiterating my appreciation to the Members of the European Parliament, and in particular to rapporteur Tannock for your work in helping Montenegro to move closer to the European Union. Your resolution captures the basic elements of our policy towards the country, acknowledging progress achieved but setting out clearly the challenges for the future.  Joining the European Union is a key foreign policy priority for the country and it enjoys strong cross-party support. Montenegro is actively pursuing the goal of EU integration and the support of this Parliament is crucial in ensuring the transformative power of enlargement for the country. In May, Montenegro will celebrate the 10th anniversary of its independence. It has already achieved a lot in the past 10 years. Starting negotiations for accession to the European Union and receiving an invitation to join NATO can be counted amongst these achievements. However, as it has already been said several times by many of the speakers, important challenges remain. In the short term, these include the full implementation of the new electoral legislation that will ensure credible local and parliamentary elections in 2016. They also include making tangible progress on the rule of law, delivering on the commitments of its economic reform programme and ensuring a depoliticised and effective public administration.  As I mentioned in my opening remarks, we see 2016 as the year of tangible results, especially on the rule of law issues. We expect Montenegro to achieve results and we count on the support of this House in helping Montenegro reach its goal.

name: Jeanine HENNIS-PLASSCHAERT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, as many Members noted during this debate, the UN and Montenegro have maintained a positive momentum in relations. And many of you noted as well that Montenegro still has work to do in the field of the rule of law. The EU’s fundamental values, and notably the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights make us unique in the world, and we should be proud of that. Therefore it is important and it will continue to be important that Montenegro’s rule-of-law system delivers concrete results and establishes a solid track record in, for example, the fight against corruption and organised crime. Many of you also commented on Montenegro’s relationship with NATO. I consider Montenegro a partner country that contributes towards the further development of peaceful and friendly international relations. Montenegro’s positive role in further developing regional cooperation and advancing good neighbourly relations is also noted. So, the invitation for Montenegro is also an important contribution to stability in the region. That does not mean that no further efforts on reforms on rule-of-law issues are needed – they are needed. Madam President, to conclude, when moving ahead in the accession process I would like to assure Parliament that we will closely monitor the progress made, paying particular attention to the area of the rule of law and the other important issues also mentioned here today.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 10 March 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – In line with the report before the European Parliament, I welcome the progress made in the accession negotiations with Montenegro and the efforts made to implement the legislation. The 2015 Country Report is a balanced, objective document that mentions the progress made over the past year, but also draws attention to the shortcomings of the country, where it needs to make significant progress.  Montenegro's foreign policy is commendable as the country successfully coordinates its foreign policy with the European Union. Given the similar conditions of accession between NATO and the EU, the country's membership in NATO will result in better preparedness in the accession negotiations. However, parliament's report also points out that Montenegro needs to take a stronger fight against corruption, which is swaying the country's democratic foundations and social and economic development.  The issue of media freedom, fair and equal access for parties to the media and the self-organisation of the media have also been important in the report this year. In my field of expertise, it is important that the report commands the government's commitment to extending quality early childhood education and welcomes the increase in pre-school enrolments in the wake of the targeted campaign.  In my view, improving the quality of education, and in particular early childhood education, is generally going in the right direction, and enhancing the skills of educators. As the report realistically presents montenegro's current situation and its achievements over the past year, I propose its adoption.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. – I would like to thank my colleague Tannock for a good resolution on Montenegro's progress in 2015. I am pleased that, on the 10th anniversary of independence, Montenegro has made good progress in accession negotiations with the EU, opening 22 chapters (including the 23rd and 24th, concerning the functioning of the rule of law). Nevertheless, it still has a lot of work to do, to tackle corruption, to improve the electoral system, to guarantee media freedom, to combat organised crime.  I congratulate Montenegro on the opening of negotiations on NATO membership and would like to see it become its 29th member as soon as possible. Bringing NATO closer is not the same as bringing the European Union closer, but the conditions of entry are similar. In the process of accession to NATO, Montenegro will have to carry out reforms to ensure that it respects certain democratic and civil society norms. I believe that joining NATO will also give it a greater willingness to join the EU and stability to the wider region. Montenegro has proven to be a good foreign policy partner for the EU, both in sanctions against Russia over Crimea and in the fight against extremist Islamic radicalism. I am sorry that some of the country's backers are proposing to put an end to sanctions against Russia and that external pressures are emerging that they want to halt Montenegro's rapprochement with euro-Atlantic organisations.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Françoise Grossetête, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on veterinary medical products (COM(2014)0558 – C8-0164/2014 – 2014/0257(COD)) (A8—0046/2016), and  – the report by Claudiu Ciprian Tănăsescu, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on authorisation and supervision of veterinary medicinal products (COM(2014)0557 – C8-0142/2014 – 2014/0256(COD)) (A8-0035/2016).

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I hope that my colleagues have had time to arrive in the Chamber, because I would like to start by thanking very warmly my fellow shadow rapporteurs and commissioner Andriukaitis's teams who have worked with me on this issue. With more than 1,000 amendments and nearly 150 articles, this was a titanic work, which we did as a team, in a spirit of cooperation and compromise that I very much appreciated. This was necessary in light of the important issues at stake in this legislative review. While the World Health Organization warns us that the world is in danger of sinking into a post-antibiotic era, where antibiotic resistance would kill more people each year than cancer, it was time to take strong action and grasp the problem at its root. The fight against antibiotic resistance must begin in farms. With this report, we want to ban the purely preventive use of antibiotics, restrict mass treatments to specific cases, ban the veterinary use of antibiotics critical to human medicine or end the online sale of antibiotics, vaccines and psychotropic products. Through these measures, we hope to reduce the amount of antibiotics that end up on the consumer base. However, we must not reduce the therapeutic arsenal of veterinarians. They are responsible professionals, whom we must trust. They are best placed to choose the most appropriate treatments depending on the circumstances. This regulation is designed to facilitate their work and not to over-regulate a profession that has already demonstrated its commitment to high ethical rigour.  It should also be noted that there is a real problem with the availability of medicines on the veterinary market. To preserve animal health, the quality of treatment must be improved and the use of drugs outside of marketing authorization must be reduced. To do this, it is absolutely necessary to encourage research and innovation in this sector. Our report is therefore very ambitious on this point. It proposes to extend certain periods of commercial exclusivity, including those for medicines for minor species, in order to create strong incentives for research. The cumbersome administrative procedures, particularly in terms of pharmacovigilance, are another obstacle to the introduction of innovative products. On the basis of the Commission's proposals, we have therefore revised certain provisions in order to set up a new system of pharmacovigilance that is more flexible, more efficient and less bureaucratic. Accelerated procedures must also allow laboratories to respond quickly to outbreaks, for example, without compromising our quality and safety standards, which are among the highest in the world. Finally, this new regulation must first and foremost be at the service of farmers and farmers, whose current difficulties we know and who will be the first to be affected by this text. The rules of this legislation are therefore not intended to stigmatize them, but to help them and to better care for their herds. In particular, I wanted to ensure, together with our colleagues in the AGRI Committee and the farmers' unions, that these new rules are applicable on the ground and do not add to the administrative burden under which they are already falling. In conclusion, the main issue was threefold: protection of animal health and therefore of human health, the fight against antibiotic resistance and the competitiveness of our farms and our veterinary drug industry, objectives which may seem contradictory, but which we have managed to reconcile perfectly in this legislative report. I now hope that we will not waste any more time. Parliament is ready. The ball is in the Council's court and I will be delighted to hear from my colleagues.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very pleased to have the opportunity to discuss with you the proposals revising the legislation on veterinary medicines. The proposal for a regulation of veterinary medicines seeks to make more veterinary medicines available and to strengthen considerably European Union action to fight antimicrobial resistance (AMR). I know it is a key concern of this Parliament and, as you will know, it is a concern that I share deeply. I welcome very much that the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) adopted its report on 17 February by an overwhelming majority. I take this opportunity to congratulate Madam Grossetête for her excellent and timely work as rapporteur for this file and for the excellent cooperation with the Commission. Madam Grossetête succeeded in gaining strong support on 39 compromise amendments covering all the important provisions of this proposal. The Commission appreciates in particular the efforts made in proposing constructive amendments and concrete alternatives regarding the provisions related to labelling, environmental risk assessment, harmonisation of all products, pharmacovigilance and last, but not least, on AMR. The Commission welcomes the spirit of these amendments and they are in line with the co-objectives of the proposals. Now let me touch upon the Proposal amending Regulation (EC) No 726/2004. This proposal was necessary to allow for the incorporation of the rules on centralised authorisation in a single regulation on veterinary medicines. Its secondary aim was to perform the necessary and obligatory alignment of the Regulation to the Lisbon Treaty. The ENVI Committee adopted its report on 17 February and I also congratulate Mr Tănăsescu for his work as rapporteur for this file, which was confirmed with the adoption of the report by a large majority of the Committee. The Commission appreciates the efforts made to improve the proposal in order to take into account the specificities of the veterinary sector. Let me underline once again that the cooperation between Parliament and the Commission on the two files respectively has been excellent. Naturally we will strive to keep it that way, to bring this file to a satisfactory conclusion as early as possible. I am convinced that a first reading agreement is possible and, indeed, desirable and I am convinced that today’s vote will represent an important incentive for the Council to speed up its work. Finally let me reaffirm my commitment to the fight against AMR. For the years to come, my main ambition and first priority is to make the European Union a best practice region in the field of AMR. In order to make this possible I hope every Member State will be equipped with a comprehensive action plan against AMR, developed following the one-health approach. To assist this process I will put in place in the coming months, a one-health AMR network to bring together Member States’ experts from both the veterinary and human health domains, as well as actors from the environmental sector.  The European Union has indeed a key role to play both within its borders and globally, and your constructive work on these proposals will certainly represent an important contribution to succeeding in our endeavour. I thank Parliament again for its substantial proposals in the framework for this legislation, and its continuous interest and involvement in the ongoing fight against AMR. I count on the support of this House to ensure that the very important and urgent new measures designed to tackle AMR are adopted and applied as swiftly as possible. Thank you for your attention and I now look forward to hearing the views of honourable Members.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I want to start by saying that I appreciate the Commission's proposal to separate marketing authorisations for veterinary medicinal products from those for medicinal products for human use, so as to take account of the specific needs of the veterinary sector. In addition to the new Regulation on Veterinary Medicinal Products, just mentioned by Mrs Grossetête, it was also necessary to amend, on the part of the Commission, Regulation No 17. However, as can be seen from my report, there were some elements in the proposal that needed improvement. Firstly, for the sake of clarity, since all the articles relating to the authorisation procedure for veterinary medicinal products are now being moved to a new regulation, I have clarified in the text that the European Medicines Agency remains responsible, under the centralised authorisation procedure, for both medicinal products for human and veterinary use. The report shall also ensure that the revised Regulation complies with the new Financial Regulation. We now have a clear and up-to-date picture of the principles applicable to the Agency's budget, including a separation between the different revenue sources that make up the budget of the European Medicines Agency. As a result of the broad support received in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, Parliament should be fully involved in the process of setting the Agency's fees through the ordinary legislative procedure, as has recently been done for legislation on pharmacovigilance fees.  Finally, the text voted on in the ENVI Commission recognises the role of the European Medicines Agency in increasing access to medicines. The report also contains a statement on the Agency's cooperation with medical technology assessment bodies, as is currently the case, in order to further facilitate cooperation and exchange of scientific information. The EMA should also be able to provide Member States with a comparative assessment of medicinal products for human use. Such an assessment could then be used by Member States on a voluntary basis during the national decision-making process on the setting of prices and repayment conditions, activities which, of course, remain within national competence. Now, as shadow rapporteur in the Grossetête report, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and colleagues on their good cooperation. We now have a very well structured report, which allows for considerable improvements in the field of veterinary medicinal products. Proposed measures include limiting and controlling the use of antibiotics in the treatment of animals, but also creating a favourable framework for investment in the research and development of new medicines, and beyond. It is intended to increase access to veterinary medicinal products and to provide veterinarians with a much wider therapeutic arsenal. In this respect, the requirements for medicinal products for limited markets are also simplified. In addition, the movement of veterinary medicinal products between Member States is facilitated by better authorisation procedures and clear rules on modern forms of retailing. In this respect, we have reached an agreement allowing the retail sale of veterinary medicinal products on the internet, with the exception of antimicrobial substances, psychotropic products and immunological biological products. Similarly to what happens in the case of medicinal products for human use, the Commission is invited to adopt guidelines to support Member States in the development of a harmonised system of digital prescriptions in the European Union. It is regrettable that a large proportion of the antibiotics sold in the European Union are given to animals. It is our duty to protect the effectiveness of antibiotics in medical centres, but also on farms. This report sets out clear measures for the correct and proper use of antibiotics on the farm, as well as a ban on the preventive, routine use of antimicrobial substances. This is complemented by stricter standards for the use of antimicrobial metafilactic treatment. In order to combat antimicrobial resistance, everyone should be involved, including national authorities, patients, doctors, but also veterinarians, farmers and consumers.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: rapporteur on the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to begin by thanking Mrs Grossetête for her excellent work and a fantastic cooperation. Having started with almost 1 100 amendments, we have now landed a very good compromise proposal with your help and with the help of Mr. Tănăsescu's leadership. This bill will prove important not only for the well-being of the earth and the development of the pharmaceutical industry. It will also benefit public health and the environment in Europe. As far as I am sure, we are making such strong demands on the use of antibiotics. Routine, preventive treatments, frivolous group treatments should no longer occur. I am also pleased that the proposal includes who should have the right to prescribe veterinary medicines, what data should be collected, how they should be used and how we deal with environmental risks in this context. The package is well balanced between consumer concerns, taking into account the proposal to provide strong incentives for industry to produce medicine, including the generic industry, consideration for the fight against antibiotic resistance and environmental considerations. If this is the end result, we will have helped to increase access to effective medicines that are manufactured and used in a way that does not threaten public health, animal health or our environment. As alde,we support this package and hope that the other colleagues will do the same.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: draftsman of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Madam President, in the one minute I have, I will be addressed to the European Medicines Agency, and I want to thank the rapporteur, Mr Tănăsescu, who has accepted a number of comments from our AGRI Committee. To some extent, I would like to express some doubts about the Commission's proposal as to the structure and level of the fees paid to the Agency and the way in which the fees are set for the competent authorities of the Member States. These fees cannot be determined by an implementing act. The European Parliament should be fully involved in setting the fees paid to the Agency, as is the case with pharmacovigilance legislation. This is in the form of full codecision. This is already in Mr Tănăsescu's draft report.  It is necessary to include a number of references in the new Regulation precisely to veterinary medicinal products and to clearly define the role of the European Medicines Agency in the authorisation and supervision of veterinary medicinal products through a centralised procedure. I would like to support the requirement that the new measures take into account the specific features of the veterinary sector and that fees be available for the sector.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking my fellow Members, in particular Mrs Grossetête, with whom we have done a long and important job in committee. There were many amendments, but I believe that a balance has been struck, a significant compromise point.  What I think needs to be emphasised is that we are obviously talking here about new rules, new regulations and, immediately, some people may be afraid, of new rules, of Europe imposeing new rules in a sector that is already highly bureaucratic, unfortunately, such as agriculture and livestock farming. On the other hand, the approach that has been taken to this work is exactly the opposite approach, in the sense that these are new rules which have been checked on the ground, so that they do not in any way constitute a further bureaucratization of the system but, even more so, they are rules that move towards overall European harmonisation and I believe that from these benches, on this occasion, they do not in any way constitute a further bureaucratization of the system. , it is also necessary to remember that we, when we talk about farmers, are talking about a sector such as milk, which in Italy, but not only in Italy, in several European countries, is really on its knees today. He's going through a really dramatic crisis.  These new rules will, in some way, help this sector. Firstly, because they are new rules that will create the same regulations for everyone in Europe, so that all european realities that have to produce milk and raise animals will have the same and the same regulation. Because, you understand, if the rules are not the same or are not enforced in the same way, you get to ensure that someone can produce milk at a lower price than what can perhaps be produced in Italy.  This, on the other hand, is a new regulation that unites everyone under the same hat, I believe that it can be an element of advantage and, above all, a further signal that we cannot leave our farms alone: we must support them, because the crisis they are experiencing is really a hard and difficult crisis.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has We have already adopted the Animal Health Act this week, which sought to show, first and foremost, the link between animal health, animal welfare and public health, through good animal husbanding practices and the prudent use of veterinary medicinal products. In the spirit of this prudent use of veterinary medicinal products, this Pharmaceutical Sea Law has also been negotiated by Madame Grossetéte and all the shadow rapporteurs. I am very grateful that these compromises have been negotiated, because they really carry on the idea that it is necessary to look at animal health and human health together, especially when using medicines. We need to separate veterinary medicinal products and medicinal products for human use and, in reality, to retain those special medicines for humans. However, we must also encourage innovation. We must help to ensure that, above all, those who prescribe these medicines do not necessarily sell and earn from them, but that there are very clear rules in this regard. It was also necessary for us to ban the internet trade here, especially for antibiotics. There is much in this legislative package to be proud of. It will allow for the improvement of availability, it will enable innovation. It should, of course, also help to step up the fight against antibiotic resistance at all levels, including the prescription of veterinary medicinal products. In this sense, I am convinced that we have taken the right path, and I hope that there will be broad support in the vote.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I very much welcome and welcome the report by Mrs Grossetête and Mr Tănăsescu, as well as the atmosphere that accompanies the search for compromises. When we mean a veterinary medicinal product, I am thinking, first of all, of the work that has been carried out on a difficult and complex process aimed not only at the safety and protection of animals in the broad sense, as the content of the report indicates in the first place, but also of the process of protecting human health, food safety and numerous aspects of environmental protection. In my opinion, security should be given priority, and I am referring to various aspects of security. Firstly, a medicine that is safe and effective for an animal, safe for man as a user who uses this medicine for an animal, safe for man as a food consumer, or finally safe for man as a patient, especially when we need to limit the build-up of resistance of microbes to antibiotics; also a drug safe for the environment. I wholeheartedly support cascading mechanisms aimed at reducing the use and use of antibiotics in particular. There needs to be a clear differentiation between treatment, metaphylaxis and antibiotic prophylaxis, which, moreover, is banned in this document – and very well. Legal and commercial issues have also been regulated. Many concerns were raised about the arrangements for allowing the distribution of medicines and the criteria for advertising. In my opinion, these are serious challenges that concern not only veterinary medicinal products. Product advertising and distribution, especially online, is a major challenge. We must also bear in mind the important topic of data protection, because bad legislation in this area can put out the innovative measures so necessary in this area.  On one point, I have a different opinion as a doctor: I cannot agree with the specific proposals for amendments to this report. In particular, I have doubts about the numerous references made to so-called homeopathic medicines. I have the impression that ideological rather than scientific considerations prevailed. Science does not give clear evidence confirming the effectiveness of homeopathic tics in animals. In humans, the placebo effect or belief in the effectiveness of drugs counts. Whether a similar mechanism works in animals – I do not know, but I doubt very seriously.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. "Myself, I reassure the Congressman, and I, too, consider it a very, very thorough and beautiful work done by the editors. Rather, with regard to the future, I would like to ask you a question as to whether you could support the European Parliament's future development of closer cooperation with the European Medicines Agency, so that we would be in the process, and not just checking from time to time.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Both institutions for today, Dear Mate, are the subject of this institution, because the EMA is an executive part of the European Commission. I understand that there should be some unity in veterinary medicinal products and in human medicinal products, such proposals are and in many countries there are agencies that deal with both human medicines and animal medicines. Because the co-incident, or equality of these events, their interactions, the interactions are unequivocal. I agree with this proposal.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to the two rapporteurs, Mr Tansescu and Mrs Grossetéte.  It is indeed the case that these two reports, with this legislation, improve something quite crucial, which is now also improving antibiotic resistance, which we are discussing a great deal. This has to do with the fact that the Tnsescu report is now actually separating the authorisation of medicinal products for human and veterinary use, which is currently still in a regulation. It makes perfect sense that, at the same time, we are also adapting to the Treaty of Lisbon, so that the fees for admission to the EMA, as we want, are then also made in the co-determination procedure. These are all things that make sense. I think perhaps even more important – and this is also the larger report – is the report by Mrs Grossetéte. In fact, it is the case that prophylaxis, metaphylaxis and treatment are processed very precisely. In prophylaxis, it is said that there should be no more critical antibiotics, that prophylactic administration via the feed should generally no longer be permitted, at most if, for example, an animal is directly in front of an operation.  The allocation of antibiotics to animals should then only be subject to specialist treatment by veterinarians. I also think it is important to see the cascade system, which has been said to be that some antibiotics should really only be used for human treatment, so that they really have an effect when used in humans.  Then it is also said that if, for example, one veterinary medicinal product is not available in one Member State, then another can be taken, another special one, which is available in other Member States. In individual cases, you can also administer human medications with or something individually manufactured. But basically, of course, we should always take the veterinary medicinal product that is intended for this particular case. Personally, unlike a previous speaker, I also think it is absolutely right and important that homeopathic remedies should also be authorised in the future, because – it is possible to argue for a long time whether or not it has been scientifically proven – there have already been very good successes with them. I think we should allow everything possible to treat animals without breeding further antibiotic resistance.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, first of all, my warmest thanks go to the rapporteurs and all colleagues for their long-standing good cooperation on this issue.  When we talk about veterinary care, we inevitably talk about antibiotics, and we must remember that this issue also deals with access to veterinary products, administrative issues and also matters relating to competition and innovation. The draft report sets clear conditions for the prescription and sale of antibiotics. The Commission's original proposal would have removed the possibility of national restrictions on the use of antimicrobials, which would have weakened the situation in my country, Finland, for example.  I would like to warmly thank all the actors for resolving the matter during the committee debate and for having the opportunity to use stricter regulation in our area as well. In Finland and other Nordic countries, antibiotics used to treat animal diseases are only available on veterinary prescription, and thanks to long withdrawal periods and strict control, Finnish meat or milk does not bulge antibiotic residues.  When things have been done smartly in the past, it is worth making sure that this can continue to be done. A warm thank you to all the actors once again, and let's remember that healthy, well-kept animals are the starting point for everything.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur and colleagues for working together so well. I have to say that we have made the Commission's proposal much better. I think it is important to point out, of course, that we must also act. We have conditions that we cannot accept. The fact that twice as many antibiotics are still used in animal husbandry – mainly in fattening, incidentally – as in human medicine is unacceptable in the long run. We have the problem of resistance. We have 26 000 deaths in Europe from antibiotic resistance. The irresponsible, over-massive use in animal husbandry also contributes to this. That is why we need to address the issues of prophylaxis and metaphylaxis. Too many antibiotics are used in actually healthy animals. This has something to do with incorrect farming conditions and with false breeds, and this problem is also addressed by this proposal that we consider this in order to use fewer antibiotics. I think this is extremely important. We also need to talk about reserve antibiotics. Reserve antibiotics are really reserved for human medicine. We must not compromise on this. We also need to improve the collection of data in the European Union, where there is insufficient data collection. And we also need to look at the environmental impact of antibiotics, especially in the production and application. I would like to make one more point. Unfortunately, my colleague from the ECR is now gone. We must not discriminate against homeopathic remedies in the regulation. We must recognise them as equivalent, and we must put everything that strengthens alternatives to antibiotics in the foreground. I would therefore ask you to vote in favour of Amendments Nos 115 and 116 so that homeopathy is not jeopardised.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I consider the text adopted in the ENVI Committee to be a good text and I would like to thank Mrs Grossetête for allowing all the groups to make changes in order to further improve the content of the Commission's proposal. It must be said that the Commission has repeatedly stressed that the main aim of the proposal was to stimulate competitiveness, stimulate innovation and, above all, improve the functioning of the internal market.  In our opinion, however, the main aim of the future legislative framework for veterinary medicinal products must be to protect public health and animal welfare. In my own-initiative report on patient safety, I already mentioned the importance of tackling antibiotic resistance in veterinary medicine as well. That is why we are very satisfied, because routine prophylaxis is banned and because the use of antibiotics in a metaphylactic way is restricted only to cases of clinically ill animals.  However, in our opinion, in order to find new effective antibiotics, we must prevent the use and abuse of the pharmaceutical monopolist, who imposes his own price under copyright laws. The game of industry is to exploit certain substances for as long as possible, without stimulating real research. The current text in this area needs to be improved, because it extends from 10 to 18 years, the period during which the industry can exclusively exploit a new drug.  This goes against the rules of competition and prevents small and medium-sized enterprises producing generic medicines from entering the market by lowering prices. We are against evergreening because it means limited access to generic medicines, which has an unacceptable impact on animal health and welfare.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, after long negotiations led by our colleague Françoise Grossetête, whom I warmly thank for her work and her search for consensus, we still have to debate a very sensitive text. Despite our compromises, I have to express some reservations. First, animals that have undergone clinical trials should not be reintegrated into the food chain. When you admit a precautionary period, it means that you also admit a risk. However, we cannot maintain this risk in the area of food security. In addition, the online sale of veterinary medicines needs to be more regulated. Drugs that require a prescription by qualified veterinarians or professionals should not be sold on the internet, and I stress this point. This restriction preserves two pillars of the sector: on the one hand, the health mesh provided by our veterinarians, whose action must be supported and protected by the profession - it is thanks to these veterinarians that the consumption of antibiotics has been reduced in France, in particular; on the other hand, the quality of our farms, which we cannot sell out through deregulation favouring counterfeiting and multiple deliverances due to the lack of control. Finally, I object to meat from animals treated by professionals other than veterinarians being allowed to be exported within the internal market. We have had too serious food crises related to the lack of treatment and the deregulation of the veterinary medicine sector. So let's be vigilant and cautious.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to thank both rapporteurs, but especially Francoise Grossetéte, and compliment her very much, because this is a very, very extensive technical dossier and she has guided us very well through the difficult negotiations. It is a good report and we should vote in favour of it by a large majority.  I would like to talk above all about antibiotic resistance. According to the Commission and the World Health Organisation, 25 000 people die every year because antibiotics lose their effect because they suffer from germs that are no longer helped.  This is where we have to start in veterinary medicine – I will come to human medicine in a while. Much has already been said. I would ask the Commission and then also the Council, when we go to the trialogue, to look in particular at Amendments Nos 245 and 246. It is a question of not only covering antibiotics – this is already included in the Commission proposal – but also drawing conclusions when a farmer uses significantly more antibiotics than other comparable farms.  This already exists in some Member States, and the vets tell me that the farmers come preventively and say before the official veterinarian comes and tells me what to do, please tell me how I can avoid using so many antibiotics by means of better hygiene, better breeding and so on. I believe that we should introduce this throughout Europe. A word about human medicine. If 25 000 people die every year, then we must also look at where people are treated. Prescription practice in human medicine is still too generous, and hygiene in hospitals leaves much to be desired. But we also need innovation. Even if we are still doing so well, we already have the resistant germs and unfortunately we do not have enough modern antibiotics. I would therefore like to draw your attention to Amendment No 22. We need not only innovation in veterinary medicine, but especially in human medicine. I would ask the Commission to present a concrete proposal there as soon as possible.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: – Madam President, esteemed colleagues, this regulation regulates relations in the distribution and use of veterinary medicines, but my focus was on combating antimicrobial resistance. It is important that the regulation contains a provision prohibiting certain antibiotics in veterinary care in order to preserve them for human use. But for this to make sense it must be retroactive, therefore include the obligation to withdraw from the market those spare antibiotics already on sale.  Furthermore, the key is to binder the distribution of antibiotics with a prescription issued by an authorized person. Likewise, to prevent possible abuses in the interest of public health is to ban the online sale of antibiotics. Human and animal health are increasingly connected due to our eating habits and intensive farming methods, which is why we need to address the problem of antibiotics through a "one health" approach. Alarm bells have been ringing for a long time and future generations may be wondering if it's possible that for profit we've ruined one of the greatest achievements in medical science. Through this law, the European Union has an extraordinary opportunity to contribute to global efforts to preserve the effectiveness of antibiotics. In conclusion, I believe that the proposal for regulation coming out of Parliament is well designed and will contribute to better protection of animal and human health.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, much of the parliamentary discussion and indeed contact from the public has been around antimicrobial resistance. Of course this is important and I completely endorse the approach taken by the rapporteur in terms of the restriction on prophylactic use, but there are other things in this report and I particularly wanted to say thank you to the rapporteur and the team of shadows for listening to calls from the UK where we are asking to continue our long-established and very well—thought—of practice of using specially qualified persons.  I welcome this flexibility and the recognition that one-size-fits-all does not always work, especially given the background of the referendum debate in the UK – it gives me something very positive to say. Can I just end my time by urging colleagues not to vote for the retabled GM banning amendment. This would take 19 well used veterinary products off the market. It is a dangerous precedent. We should make a very clear distinction between GM crops and GM science for medicine.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: – Dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the OECD forecasts that antibiotic use will increase by 67% worldwide in just one generation. Action must therefore be taken both veterinary and humane. It is irresponsible to compensate for poor housing for animals with the preventive use of antibiotics.  Further research into new antibiotics, veterinary medicines and vaccines is also crucial. The use of genetic modification should remain possible, just as is the case with human medicines. This technology, for example, produced insulin for diabetes patients. In some cases, a GMO drug or vaccine is even the only solution. The amendments which seek to ban genetic modification therefore put both public health and animal health at risk and have no basis in reality.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: – This Regulation contains positive aspects. Ensuring the production of safe, effective and affordable veterinary medicines is an important objective for our producers. The introduction of the issue of generic medicines, antimicrobial resistances or small markets are important elements that go in the right direction.  We thought, however, that it could go further, were it not for the pressure of multinational companies that want to extend their privileges to the fullest, capturing monopolistic incomes, if possible, to eternity.  We could have gone further in a greater generalisation of the centralised method, in our view the only one that safeguards the interests of the smaller countries and prevents multinationals from making their products available only in the most profitable markets.  Let us be clear, however. The great concern with safety and good application of veterinary medicinal products is not only solved by this regulation, it is solved by attacking the problem at the root of a common agricultural policy, which essentially productivist, which promotes intensive monoculture and destroys small and medium-sized European family farming.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, the link between the overuse of antibiotics on farms and the growth in resistant bacteria was put starkly by the UK’s Chief Medical Officer, Liam Donaldson, who said that every inappropriate use of antibiotic in animals is potentially signing the death warrant for a future patient.  With a range of medical organisations raising the alarm about the spread of antibiotic resistance, it is incumbent upon European policymakers to introduce strict regulation of their use, both in humans and in animals. At present, antibiotics can be prescribed to all animals on a farm if only one animal is sick, and can be given to animals that show no sign of disease but are merely at risk of catching an infection. We are pleased that the new regulations will ban this sort of routine use of antibiotics.  As Greens, we are determined that the use of antibiotics should not be a substitute for good animal husbandry. When animals are kept in insanitary conditions in overcrowded sheds, their health inevitably suffers and infections spread more easily. Less intensive farming practices would ensure better lives for animals, as well as reducing the demand for antibiotics.

name: Julia REID
text: – Madam President, we in UKIP believe that the responsible use of all veterinary medicines in the UK is of great importance, especially for those drugs used in British livestock, where it is vital that our farmers are able to maintain the high standards of food safety, animal health and welfare for which we are well known. However, I do not believe that veterinary medicine should be used to improve performance or to compensate for poor animal husbandry. I think that all veterinary medicines, especially antibiotics, should be used responsibly, under veterinary care and according to licencing conditions. However, current EU legislation, which came into force in 2001 and 2004, has caused the UK a number of problems, in particular the high costs due to the considerable administrative burden imposed by Brussels. Thus we in UKIP oppose the creation of a new regulatory framework that we believe will be as damaging as the old one. UKIP believes that only the UK Government should be able to legislate in this area, and post-Brexit they will.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the two rapporteurs, Françoise Grossetête, very much for their extraordinary work. However, Mr Liese and the other members who have spoken have also spoken at length about his report, so, if I may say so, I wanted to focus on another aspect as well. Because we will really take a first step, with tomorrow's vote, also towards changing the process by which medicines are approved at European level and we will be able, by voting on the amendments to the regulation, to take a first step towards a drastic reduction, I hope, in the time between the authorisation of the marketing of a new drug and the decisions of individual countries on their reimbursement.  The current procedure, in fact, creates very marked differences in the timing of access to new medicines, because the same drug is evaluated for its effectiveness 28 times, once for each Member State, while always relying on the same data. The case of Trastuzumab, an effective drug against a particular breast cancer, has remained classic and dramatically known, so effective that it becomes the standard for the treatment of this type of breast cancer, so effective that it is included in the list of essential drugs by the World Health Organization, that is, the list of medicines that should be accessible in all countries of the world , but to get to some countries and be really used and refunded, it sometimes took even more than 10 years.  I therefore very much hope that this first step will show us a new way of overcoming these difficulties.

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. We have a very important regulation here today in the debate. A great deal has already been said on the most important point for me, namely antibiotics. However, I would like to repeat it and say quite clearly that antibiotics are not a fattening aid, nor are they a substitute for poor animal husbandry. We must make this very clear and reiterate it here. Reserve antibiotics, as the word goes well, must also be the reserve for human medicine. I am very pleased that we are now including comprehensive monitoring in the regulation, thereby also stipulate sticking to all Member States that the use of antibiotics must be recorded.  I am also pleased and thank both rapporteurs for this, and I would like to express my sincere thanks to the fact that we have succeeded in including the environmental impact sit-downs from production to the removal of the leftovers on the field, and for looking very carefully at what we have in terms of environmental impact and how we can deal with them. Thank you again. We have taken a very important step towards a new approach to veterinary medicines.

name: Bas BELDER
text: – As ecr shadow rapporteur in the Committee on Agriculture, I attach great importance to this dossier on veterinary medicines.  It is a question of the legislative framework encouraging the development of new veterinary medicines. This includes a reasonable period of data protection, as also mentioned by the rapporteur. Reducing administrative burdens is also important. It is a good thing that companies will soon have the opportunity to convert a decentralised marketing authorisation into a central authorisation. Responsible use of antibiotics is a joint task. I am pleased that this wording on jointness has been incorporated into the text. However, I would point out that reductions in antibiotic use already achieved in some Member States should be recognised in future reduction targets. Because a concerted effort and a level playing field are needed to achieve an effective and lasting result.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for It is a big step that we will take today. It is a struggle that many have been engaged in for a long time. I would like to mention in particular two former colleagues, Marit Paulsen from the Liberals in Sweden and Karl-Erik Olsson from my own Liberal Party, the Center Party, who started this fight back in the nineties. When we talk about European merit, I can join in the chorus of tributes that come from almost every grouping here. We are some who are also working on this in the act on medicated feed, which we are going to take a little later this year.  Are we to be able to preserve the most important instrument we have in our management of our health – i.e. antibiotics, which enable us to perform surgical procedures, which means that pneumonia is not a death-threatening disease, but which also allows one to know in agriculture that there is no risk that all animals in the herds you have died because the antibiotics do not work , because we can hold back resistance – we have indeed created European added value for both the agricultural sector and the human race.  Thank you, Mrs Grossetête, for your work. I look forward to seeing the result.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to our rapporteur, Mr Grossetéte. I believe that we have a very good report here.  Having effective medicines available for animals and curbing antibiotic resistance are the two central objectives of this package of regulations. I am convinced that the text before us will do both well. Companies are encouraged to do research and innovation, and the use of antibiotics is very limited. Prophylactic antibiotic use is kept to an absolute minimum and routine use is completely prohibited. The Commission is to draw up a list of reserve antibiotics. In order to ensure effective treatment for domestic and farm animals, complementary therapies – I am thinking, for example, of homeopathic medicines – can also play an important role. I obviously see this differently from my colleague from the ECR before. Homeopathics can be a good alternative, not least in the fight against the increasing spread of antibiotic resistance. For this reason, I am committed to making it easier to register or approve them.
