In my view, it makes a great deal of sense to see the Veterinary Medicines Regulation and the Pharmaceutical Feed Regulation as a common, coherent package. I therefore welcome the fact that we have succeeded in this in the definitions. We also strengthen the role of the veterinarian – his role is taken into account responsibly.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for The increased resistance to antibiotics in society and nature is a huge problem about which too little has been said so far, and this report is therefore a step in the right direction. Infections caused by resistant bacteria are becoming more difficult to treat, and even today we see devastating consequences of this, including premature babies, the sick and the elderly suffer from the terrible that you cannot get help today. At European level, a proper and strong regulatory framework is now needed to reduce antibiotic resistance among both animals and humans. Europe needs clarity that we do not want routine unnecessary prophylaxis of antibiotics of animals that are healthy. The starting point must be that only sick animals should be medicated, when there is a need. I would therefore like to say that the legislation on which we are going to vote tomorrow is a step in the right direction, but we must also ensure that there is a ban on prophylaxis, against antibiotics given as a preventive measure.

name: Pilar AYUSO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I too would like to congratulate my colleague Mrs Grosset-te: she has had a huge number of amendments, but her great spirit of consensus and good work have made this report a great report and a good report.  The need to clearly differentiate in this Regulation the different forms of treatment has been resolved: curative, control and preventive or prophylaxis. The administrative burden must be reduced because this does not favour administration, but guarantees of quality, efficacy, safety and correct information of veterinary medicinal products must also be maintained.  As regards the availability of veterinary medicinal products, it is not a minor issue and solutions must be sought for certain species and pathologies which we call 'minor species' and 'minor uses'. For these particular cases, it is important to support measures to encourage innovation.  Finally, it is very important that the proposal has been amended to enable veterinarians to use medicines for species and indications that are not included in the manufacturer's recommendations.  In short, I believe that a cascading prescribing system should be maintained and even used for medicines for human use; as a last resort, yes, and only when there is no better alternative. I think this is vitally important and is a task for the veterinary expert to do.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mrs. Dormand! I would also like to thank the rapporteur for doing a very good job. I fully support the text on veterinary medicines on which we will be voting tomorrow and welcome the fact that this is the first time we have seriously addressed antibiotic resistance in EU legislation. This is necessary because about 25 000 people die a year because we have developed resistance and therefore cannot treat enough against infections. This development of resistance has come partly because we have seen an overuse of antibiotics in agriculture. I am therefore pleased that we are taking a step in the right direction by moving closer to a real ban on prophylactic use. We should not give antibiotics to healthy animals, only to sick animals. In fact, I would have liked to have seen that we had made a real ban on animal doctors selling the medicine they prescribe, but we did not come to terms with that. Maybe we can take that next time. I support the text and hope that this means that we can now seriously tackle the fight against antibiotic resistance in Europe.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: I too would like to thank the rapporteur for the wonderful work she has done. It is important that this report makes the organisation of the market a lot more efficient.  For me, however, the measures taken in the fight against antibiotic resistance stand out. Due to a large-scale use of antibiotics, also preventively in healthy animals, more and more bacteria become resistant and thereby reduces the effect of some antibiotics. With the development of new types of antibiotics also sputtering, this is rightly causing concern. All the actors involved in the sector agree: the use of antibiotics must be reduced, but a complete ban, as some colleagues have suggested, is, in my view, a bridge too far.  Careful and responsible use of antibiotics is necessary. This report celebrates that starting point. Routine, preventive antibiotics are restricted. This is an excellent thing, because this avoids bad conditions, such as newborn piglets with resistant bacteria. However, there has been no complete ban on preventive use, and I think that is common sense. Just before or during the operation of an animal, the farmer should be able to continue to use antibiotics preventively. Such exceptions are necessary to limit animal cruelty.  The list of exceptions will be drawn up by the European Medicines Agency. That too is a good choice, because that is how we get the guarantee that the list will be compiled on a scientific basis.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Madam President, I would like to join the two rapporteurs who are co-rapporteurs with congratulations: Mrs Grosset-te, of course, on the great work done; also mr. Tonsescu. I think that a great deal of global work has been done, given the difficulty and that they were really very technical regulations.  I followed this debate in particular because being rapporteur of the report on the Regulation on Medicinal Feed, the substance of which is discussed in the Committee on Agriculture, had a lot to do with these reports, and I have therefore followed up in particular.  And I would like to thank you for the work that has been done because it has certainly made it easier for us to work with the Medicines Regulation, a regulation which will regulate one of the forms of administration of veterinary medicinal products and which will be voted on next week in the Committee on Agriculture.  And I would like to highlight finally the difficulty in finding veterinary medicines for minor species and uses, and that I am pleased that the cascading procedure has been approved as is in the Committee on the Environment: it initially improves the Commission's proposal.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: – Madam President, antimicrobial resistance is a serious public health problem in the European Union and every opportunity must be taken and all necessary measures put in place to combat it. And that is why I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteurs on their greater ambition to the Commission's proposal and to have made this effort in this report and to have taken this opportunity.  Indeed, the proposal is greatly improved. I think it is an important step forward in tackling and trying to combat, as I say, the problem of antimicrobial resistance in the European Union: 25,000 deaths a year; more than EUR 1.5 billion costs us the public health of the Member States every year. So, my congratulations.  It obviously can't be complete and there are still ways to keep working and I'm sure we will. But, as has been said here, the path has begun; I therefore join in the congratulations and hope that this will simply be the beginning to combat the great challenge we have in public health in the European Union today.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, congratulations to Mrs Grossetête, who has indeed done a very great job and has been very open to the fact that it is absolutely necessary to limit antibiotic resistance, because there is really a link between the use of antibiotics and the increase in the resistance of bacteria. I'm raising, then, very positive things: the ban on the sale of antibiotics on the internet, the strengthening of the ban on the prophylactic use of veterinary drugs, the stricter framework of metaphylactic use, i.e. not treating the whole herd when there is only one sick animal, and, at the same time, the list reserved for humans, so-called "antibiotics". I would like to emphasize a couple of things. There is a real need to promote alternatives. Indeed, we can reduce the use of antibiotics, but we must also strengthen - and here I support the amendment of my colleague Martin Huusling - homeopathy. At the same time, it's a shame we haven't talked about it, we need to increase research on phage therapy, which is killing certain bacteria with bacteriophages. I am thinking of salmonella in many farms, which are subject to this problem, and also to the use of antibiotics in aquatic environments, because there are more and more salmon farms. The problem is that antibiotics cannot be controlled in an open environment at all.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the legal framework in force in the field of veterinary medicines needed improvement, particularly as regards the functioning of the internal market, the phenomenon of antibiotic resistance, the lack of incentives for innovation and the administrative burdens imposed in the pharmacovigilance process. With this report, many of these shortcomings are being filled.  The fundamental problem is undoubtedly antibiotic resistance: in this area it is essential that the Member States take into account the guidelines drawn up by the Commission for the prudent use of antibiotics. More comprehensive data are needed on how antibiotics are used and plans need to be put in place to discourage their administration for preventive or prophylactic purposes. But antibiotic resistance must be combated, with some of them reserved exclusively for humans, just as the ban on trade in antibiotics on the Internet must be ensured and the possibility for veterinarians to prescribe antibiotics to be prescribed at the same time should be made even more limited.  The solution, therefore, is to be found in the concept of one health: by safeguarding animal health, we also safeguard human health.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, we are discussing the authorisation of medicinal products for veterinary use and the impact of these medicinal products on public health. Firstly, as regards the central marketing authorisation for veterinary products, it should be disconnected from that of medicinal products for humans, as the needs of the veterinary sector for medicinal products differ greatly from those of humans. Moreover, in the veterinary field there are different types of animals, resulting in market fragmentation and increasing the need for investment in order to extend the authorisation of medicinal products from one animal species to another. In addition, despite the health measures taken by farmers, animals also need veterinary medicinal products to treat a disease and avoid any possible transmission of it to humans. The veterinary industry must therefore ensure that medicinal substances placed on the market are not harmful to public health, animal health and the environment and we should also pay particular attention to the antibiotics it administers to animals intended for food production.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I am very grateful that a regulation is now coming that does something about antibiotic resistance. As a reminder, around 88% of turkey meat sold in discount stores in Germany is contaminated with antibiotic-resistant germs. But how can such a ban be enforced when we have animal farms with 200 000 or more animals, chickens specifically? Here we needed antibiotics for this type of animal breeding. That is why I urge you to adopt this regulation tomorrow, which I think is very good, we will not sit back in a relaxed manner, but remember that it will be a tough fight to keep this regulation and defend it against external attacks!

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, you have heard my explanation setting out the Commission’s intentions and opinion on this proposed new regulation on veterinary medicines and I have listened to the views of this House with great interest. It is important to reach an agreement on these new rules in order to increase the availability of veterinary medicines and, even more urgently, to address the risks to public health arising from the use of antimicrobials in veterinary medicine. The Commission welcomes further provisions addressing AMR and considers most of them positive. I also welcome the amendment introducing precise conditions on prophylactics and methaphylactic use of antimicrobials, inter alia prophylactic use restricted to single animals and only when fully justified by a veterinarian, and methaphylactic use restricted to clinically ill animals and to single animals that are identified as being at high risk of contamination. I am sure that we will have very interesting discussions on this issue during the trilogue and you will be able to access those in detail.  Some Members have mentioned very important issues relating to innovations. Use of new innovative treatments is very important to all of us. Innovations, access to veterinary medicines, the fight against AMR and the protection of public health are not in contradiction. On the contrary, innovation is a main tool to guarantee public health.  I am sure that we must also debate in detail many other issues; for example, the proposal to collect data at farm level needs to be further assessed as it could be burdensome and may create additional administrative burdens. I firmly believe that on the basis of the good work done by the European Parliament we will be able to fully achieve those goals in the near future. I would like to once again thank Madam Grossetête and Mr Tănăsescu for their excellent work. Now it is the time for the Council to follow the good example of the European Parliament and speed up its work on the proposals with the aim of coming to a first-reading agreement. I can assure you of the full support of the Commission towards reaching agreement with the Council as soon as possible.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would first like to thank the colleagues who have intervened in this evening's debate, in particular for their support. I would like to say that, on the whole, there is a sense of satisfaction with the content of this report. I must say that this is the result of teamwork: it is not only my report, but it is really Parliament's report. That is why I would like to thank in particular all the shadow rapporteurs who have participated in many meetings. We had sometimes very complex subjects. It was necessary to take into account the particularity of some Member States, while still following this guideline, which was indeed - as you all recognised - the fight against antibiotic resistance. On this point, I will not go into detail, because the Commissioner has just talked about it, but it is fundamental. At the same time, we really had to take into account support for innovation, because we have a severe shortage of veterinary drugs. We have therefore constantly sought the balance between this fight against antibiotic resistance and the need to support innovation, to provide for the protection of commercial data, but in a differentiated way for major or minor species, or even very particular species, such as bees for which we are determined to provide 20-year protection, because we have a real problem in this regard. On sale online: of course, veterinary drugs are allowed, except for antibiotics and immunological or psychotropic products. So we really tried to put everything that could be important in this regulation on veterinary drugs. I would like to say that we have also taken environmental impact into account - this was quoted by one of our colleagues. If I have a message to send now to finish - I really appeal to all of you - it is because we need a good majority for this report, because that would allow us to lobby the Council to waste as little time as possible to enter into negotiations with it. My concern is that the Council will treat this with a little carelessness, take the time and not feel really concerned. It would be very serious because it is an animal health problem and a human health problem. If you give your overwhelming support to this report, we can lobby the Council!

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking rapporteur Grossetête, as well as all shadow rapporteurs and colleagues, for their work and for the excellent cooperation we have had on both dossiers. I would like to point out that, through these two reports, we have clearer legislation and better adapted to the specifics of the veterinary sector. Among other things, we have clarified the role of the Agency in the authorisation of medicinal products and created a favourable framework for the development of new medicines. Tomorrow's vote is a huge step to protect animal and human health, but also to fight antibiotic resistance. I hope we will have your support in this.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The joint debate is closed.  The vote will take place on Thursday, 10 March 2016. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The updating of legislation on veterinary medicinal products is necessary as the need for new and more effective medicines is increasing and their availability and prices often prevent the farmer from obtaining the product he needs at the moment. The European Commission m.in. to increase access to medicinal products, to improve the functioning of the internal market for these substances (while reducing the administrative burden linked to pharmacovigilance), and to combat increasing antibiotic resistance. Of course, I fully support all these measures, but the new legislation should include precise and clear provisions on certain issues. In particular, the text lacks an appropriate definition of 'responsible use of veterinary medicinal products' – it should cover all parties involved comprehensively, from pharmaceutical companies to veterinarians to farmers. Furthermore, online sales of antibiotics to animals (the EC's proposed solution to accessibility) should not be allowed and only over-the-counter sales of medicines should be possible. The biggest problem, on the other hand, is the increasing resistance of animals, as well as humans, to antibiotics. Fertilisers of animal origin cause bacteria resistant to antimicrobials to enter arable land and water, which poses a risk to the environment and humans. Therefore, it is imperative to put an end to any abuse of antibiotics and not to give them without a reliable diagnosis, but only after other possibilities for assistance have been eliminated.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the debate on – the oral question to the Commission on Thalidomide by Françoise Grossetête, Mairead McGuinness and Esteban González Pons, on behalf of the PPE Group Matthias Groote, Pavel Poc, Nicola Caputo, and Soledad Cabezón Ruiz, on behalf of the S&D Group,  Julie Girling, Bolesław G. Piecha, on behalf of the ECR Group, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz, Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea, on behalf of the ALDE Group, Kateřina Konečná, Stefan Eck, Eleonora Forenza, Estefanía Torres Martínez, Lynn Boylan, Miguel Urbán Crespo, Lola Sánchez Caldentey, Barbara Spinelli, Josu Juaristi Abaunz, Fabio De Masi, Jiří Maštálka, Merja Kyllönen, Ángela Vallina, Paloma López Bermejo, Patrick Le Hyaric, Tania González Peñas, Xabier Benito Ziluaga, Marisa Matias, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group Bas Eickhout , Jill Evans, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group, and Piernicola Pedicini, Eleonora Evi, Marco Affronte, David Borrelli, Marco Zullo, Rosa D'Amato, Fabio Massimo Castaldo, Isabella Adinolfi, Laura Ferrara, Tiziana Beghin, Rolandas Paksas, Peter Lundgren, Tim Aker, William (The Earl of) Dartmouth, John Stuart Agnew, on behalf of the EFDD Group (O—000035/2016 – B8-0120/2016).

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: Author. – Madam President, why the taddomy? Because it's a nazi-invented drug that a German lab sold until 1961. Because it causes irreparable malformations in newborns. Because no one stopped it from occurring and spreading among pregnant women. Because countless gynecologists received gifts for prescribing it. Because more than 10,000 children had to be born without limbs, or with short limbs, before any authority reacted. Because, it sounds like a lie, but it's true, the victims have had to wait fifty years before anyone apologizes to them. Because the governments of European countries closed their eyes. Because it is the greatest health tragedy in European history. Because the mothers who took the medicine advised by their doctors have been the only ones to feel guilty, and many are already getting older without any authority telling them, "Ma'am, it was our fault." Because all mothers are innocent victims and no one loves their children more than they do. Because we have never had this debate in the European Parliament. Because we are facing a human drama that demands a political solution. Because it's embarrassing that fifty years later there's still no political solution. Because in my country, under Franco's dictatorship, the drug withdrew three years later. Because in Spain there were 500 victims and only 24 have been recognized. Because in Spain no government of any party, nor the governments of my party, has wanted to solve the problems of all those affected. Because he cries out to heaven. Because in Spain the victims were hid by dictatorship and forgotten by democracy. Because vademécum continued to consist of medicines containing tydomid until 1975. Because everyone in my generation could have been victims of tydomy. Because the European Union must mediate before the German Government and the Spanish Government. Because I've never felt more confident than I've been since this seat. Why the taddomy? Because the victims are feeling that their health is getting worse, without them having any remedies or repairs. Because tomorrow will be too late to repair so much pain. Because it's justice.

name: Matthias GROOTE
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report and for the In fact, it is sad that today, so long after the thalidomide scandal, we have to talk about the fact that more than 900 victims have not been properly compensated so far, that there is still no solution there at the end of the day.  I am also grateful to the Commissioner for sitting here with us today and for putting pressure on the governments of the individual states that have included this product thalidomide as a licensee. There must be a fund here, there must be compensation here – and time is running out, because the victims are living their daily lives every day in considerable agony. We should draw conclusions from this in order to exert pressure to send a signal to the capitals of those states that have been affected by this scandal and where the people live. I have to say that blaming each other or blaming a country for not moving is of no use to the victims at all, but I think it is good if we act together here, send a clear signal that we need a European solution for those who are not compensated by the Contergan Foundation – as we have in Germany – but who are covered by a licensed product. These people need compensation as soon as possible.  I am also looking forward to the Council's reaction – the Council bench is unfortunately empty today. I would have liked some Member States to be represented there and listen to what we have to say here – on the spot. But perhaps we are sending out the first signal, and we will not let go at this point, but will continue to fight for the 900 people who have not been properly compensated so far to be properly compensated, and for them to be given justice at the end of the day.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: author. – Madam President, many people think of the thalidomide issue as history – something that happened in the middle of the last century and was dealt with. Nothing of course could be further from the truth. The effects of thalidomide are not just historic: they are ongoing, they are in the present. Many thalidomide survivors and their families across Europe have suffered for over 50 years and are still suffering without adequate financial support; they cannot meet their everyday living costs and they certainly cannot meet their health costs. They do not want to live a life of luxury: they want enough to live in relative comfort, free from worry and chronic pain. Those who are still in work find it increasingly difficult to maintain a full-time working schedule; their mobility is deteriorating and often depression can be heaped on top of this critical physical condition. So what is happening to help? Well, different countries in Europe have dealt with this in different ways and we know that in Germany the government is contributing to the funding for survivors via the Conterganstiftung. This is a welcome acknowledgment of their responsibility. So what then of all the other sufferers in Europe who have received little or nothing? They are still waiting for the German Government to address its moral responsibility and allocate the relatively modest, and annually decreasing, sums required. So why have we brought this here to the European Parliament? For me, it is about saying to the Commission: please, Mr Andriukaitis, help us to take this forward, help us to broker a deal that will be put in place for every single one of those victims, so that they can live out the rest of their lives in the comfort that they have been denied until now.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, it is striking that today we are in the House debating an issue and facts that occurred fifty years ago: today your victims are still suffering the consequences.  Many citizens who are following us will wonder what has happened in all this time. The answer is that, half a century later, many of the victims of tydomy continue to demand justice, the guarantee of a minimally dignified life is still being demanded.  The tragedy of tydomy changed the history of medicines in Europe, allowed legislation with higher levels of quality and safety to be passed and other pharmaceutical disasters to be avoided, although the current model of research and clinical trials continues to suffer from the transparency it must manifest.  However, no progress has been made in repairing the damage suffered by many of the poisoned children and who are now living a precarious old age after a lifetime of suffering. In many cases, care and necessary medical care cannot be afforded.  Within this drama, it is worth noting the injustice committed with the Spanish victims.  In 1972, the Contergan Foundation was created with a law establishing the universal character of aid. The reality is that 3,000 German citizens and only one Spaniard have been recognised for aid. Those affected from other countries have received aid from the Foundation or its governments, including in Australia. In the case of the Spaniards, neither the State nor the pharmacist remembered them: they have been condemned to a situation of helplessness and marginality.  From the very first moment of my parliamentary activity, I have known firsthand the heroic struggle maintained by the members of AVITE, the Spanish Association of Victims of the Talidomide.  Commissioner, it is time for action, it is time for concrete measures. It is time to end the discrimination faced by victims and it is certainly time to establish a protocol in the European Union, as this oral question raises, where all European citizens affected by tydomy receive the same compensation. We have to act without delay simply because we owe it to it, simply because it is fair and because there is nothing more contrary to the European Union than discrimination.

name: Stefan ECK
text: Author. Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The Contergan case is arguably the most well-known pharmaceutical disaster that the pharmaceutical industry has caused. After thalidomide was tested in animal experiments – we see once again: animal testing is generally the wrong way – the German company Grünenthal launched this substance under the name Contergan. The drug has been approved in 52 countries as a safe product for pregnant women and young mothers, although no tests have been carried out on the effect on embryos. Between 5 000 and 10 000 injured children have been born worldwide. There were also an unknown number of stillbirths. The Contergan victims were compensated absolutely poorly and 900 of them were not at all. Today, they are often unable to cover their medical costs. The EU must provide assistance to the victims after Grünenthal has failed to fulfil its moral obligation. All those affected should receive comparable compensation, higher pensions and easy access to assistance and assistance. Victims have a right to financial security in old age, barrier-free living and a self-determined life. That is what we must ensure. I firmly believe that, with a common market for pharmaceutical companies, the EU must also establish a common system to support the victims of pharmaceutical disasters, even if this is not yet the EU's competence. As a member of the ENVI Committee, it is particularly important to me that the Commission and the Council support strict liability rules for pharmaceutical companies operating inside and outside Europe. Those affected need social acceptance, but above all they need justice. Justice must be done to them. And we, the European Union, should give them this justice. Commissioner Andriukaitis, the German ex-Bundesk Chancellor Willy Brandt once said that politics needs an ethical foundation. There is nothing else to add to this sentence.

name: Jill EVANS
text: author. – Mr President, for many years now, thalidomide survivors have had to campaign for justice – my constituents in Wales, like those across the European Union. As their health needs increase we must do all we can to ensure that action is now taken – action which is long overdue. We know that the campaign goes on to ensure that all the facts come to light regarding the German Government’s role in the premature ending of the 1970 trial; the only ever criminal trial relating to the whole thalidomide scandal. Because it ended early, valuable evidence was suppressed and many thalidomide survivors could not make claims for compensation to cover their lifelong needs as a result. While some survivors have received some support, others have received nothing. We want equality and justice for all the survivors in all countries. As their elected representatives we want to ensure that their present and future care needs are met. We need to look at a European framework to achieve that; they have already waited over 50 years. It was believed that over 10 000 babies worldwide were affected by thalidomide; more recent information suggests that the numbers were much, much higher than that. There is a wealth of evidence about the ongoing suffering and the increasing health needs of the survivors. Detailed studies have been done in the UK and in Germany, which show just how urgent these needs are. There has been strong cross-party support in this House for the campaign for justice, the 50 year fight. I believe that it is time for us to act now to help put right a terrible wrong.

name: Diane JAMES
text: author. – Mr President, firstly I want to congratulate and recognise thalidomide victims across Europe and campaigners for their dogged persistence in their campaign. In May 2015, nine months ago, MEPs of every political group here in the EU Parliament insisted that a solution be found to the scandal of the lack of action of the urgent needs of thalidomide victims. A solution to a problem that is approaching 60 years old.  During those 60 years the German government system and the pharmaceutical company concerned have deployed every possible prevarication and procrastination tactic to avoid addressing those needs. All these organisations should be absolutely ashamed of their actions, resorting to every legal and administrative excuse, loophole and delaying tactic to prevent a financial settlement. It is absolutely scandalous and an affront to human dignity that this situation continues.  Survivors, many of them profoundly disabled, are still however human beings and they should be treated as such. They require an adequate and reasonable sum to help them cope with the daily challenges that life throws at them as they get older. Their needs should not be ignored. For an institution that trumpets a minimum wage or a living wage or even human rights for the healthy and non-disabled individuals, why is it so supremely difficult to find a financial sum that will allow thalidomide victims to also live a normal life as best as their disability allows. I now call on the Commission, the Council and MEPs to censure the German Government and State, and the commercial interests concerned, for this inhumane, cruel and unnecessary delay. Nine months is bad enough; 60 years is inexcusable.

name: Diane JAMES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much indeed for the possibility to speak here today. The thalidomide disaster reminds us today, and will always remind us, of the potential tragic consequences that the absence of an appropriate regulatory framework for medicines may trigger. The thalidomide disaster did, however, serve as an important driver to inspire the European Union’s pharma legislation over 50 years ago to reach agreement on harmonised rules focusing on a high level of public health protection. The origin of this tragedy dates back more than half a century, but there are still many survivors living with its consequences – survivors who need moral, social and financial support, especially as their medical and physical condition is worsening day by day.  Many Members of the European Parliament have written to me personally and to the Commission, highlighting the issue and calling for support for the victims. I met thalidomide survivors from the UK, Italy, Spain and Sweden last year in Brussels, and we discussed their request. I recognise the need to find a suitable solution for all survivors, which ensures their quality of life, and I have taken several steps to support this. In September 2015, I informed the national governments of the five countries concerned by my meeting with the representatives of survivors with the aim of raising awareness. I thank all the thalidomide survivors once again for accepting my invitation to participate in the ‘50 years of pharma legislation’ event and for presenting a very outspoken movie on the subject. I also met in October with Members of the European Parliament to discuss the topic and the possibilities to raise awareness of the situation of survivors in Europe. I have also discussed this issue several times since the beginning of my mandate with the pharma association FPA. A few weeks ago, I also spoke in front of his House about clinical trials, as you remember. This topic is closely related, and I would like to see the pharma industry taking more moral responsibility. However, it needs to be recognised that under Article 168 of the Treaty, the organisation and delivery of health services and medical care, including the management and allocation of the resources assigned to them, is a Member State competence. As we all know injury compensation schemes at the moment, unfortunately, are not a matter of the European Union competence. Therefore, the Commission is not in a position to establish a framework for compensation at European level. It can only support finding a political solution at Member State-level through sincere cooperation. I would encourage you, as Members of the Parliament, to relay back to your national governments the specific needs of thalidomide survivors and the need to support their cause. Finally let me emphasise once again the social responsibility of the pharmaceutical industry to support victims in this situation, not only in this case, but also when speaking about medication errors in general.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: for the PPE Group – It has been more than 60 years since the prescribed medicine – a German medicine from Grünenthal – Thalidomide, which was sold under the company name Contergan. However, this medicine has also been authorised in 52 other countries around the world, and therefore in many European countries, and has, of course, had the same negative effects as in the country in which it was developed, namely Germany. We know that it had terrible effects on the fetus, babies were born mainly with focomely, that is, as if palms, hands came directly from the shoulder, upper limbs were absent, but also other disorders of the heart, internal organs, ototoxic effect on hearing – these were all tragic effects of this drug, which was administered as a cure for morning sickness in pregnant or common headache, or mild difficulty in flu. I regret that, to this day, we have not actually found common ground on how to compensate these victims, because it is not only the 3 000 German victims who have been compensated, tens of thousands around the world, and it should be remembered that many mothers have been affected by the birth of dead children or had spontaneous premature abortions of their children who, if they had not taken this medicine, were not. would be born healthy.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, the tidomide crisis was so severe that, as has been said here, it led to the implementation of the European pharmacovigilance system. But the response received by the victims (five hundred in Spain and hundreds of others in the UK, Sweden...) was not proportionate. There are not many, but the suffering they still have is great, especially when they think they have been forgotten. Not only do we have to persevere and try to appeal to the social responsibility of the company, but I also believe that the Member States have an ethical and political responsibility. And that is what I ask the Commission: to encourage and coordinate this necessary response that we have to give to these victims. In Spain, the Socialist Government, in 2010, made a decree to recognize these victims and try to give them compensation as much as possible. But it is clear that to this day it has been shown that it was not enough. I would therefore like to stress and call for the Commission to be able to promote this necessary coordination from the Member States and to give a fair and adequate response to all these victims from Europe.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, you said 'it is the responsibility of the Member States to compensate the victims'. But you are ignoring a directive which concerns us closely and which my colleagues do not mention either - I am a little surprised - namely the European Directive on Defective Products of 1985. This directive needs to be completely revised. What for? Because it provides deadlines that no longer correspond to reality. The victim can only act within three years of knowing the damage within 10 years of the time the drug has been put into circulation. These deadlines are far too short. What does this lead to? You are talking about the dramatic thalidomide scandal in Spain. 180 victims attacked the High Court, which, under the 1985 directive, found that the facts were prescribed. As a result, they could not be compensated by the grunnenthal laboratory, which marketed thalidomide. So this is not a problem for the Member States, but with the directive that we voted on in 1985. Secondly, in this 1985 directive, victims must prove causal link between their damage, their illness and the drug. In the wake of the thalidomide scandal, what did the Germans do? Well, they reversed the burden of proof. It will absolutely have to be done in our directive when it is revised.  Third thing: when a victim suffers from a side effect due to taking a drug, he or she cannot claim any compensation if it is mentioned in the notice. Commissioner, you are, like me, very sensitive to pharmaceutical companies, and they must be pressured to compensate these victims. It is a responsibility of Europe.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, between the 1950s and 1960s, thalidomide was prescribed to pregnant women in Europe as a nausea medicine. Then it turned out that it caused the birth of thousands of children with severe malformations in Italy, Germany, Spain and England, especially in the limbs. Today, almost 4 000 people live on their skin in Europe, the consequences of this wretched drug. Who's to blame? A large German company, which has not taken responsibility for what happened. But the main fault lies with the German Government, which has been hiding the truth for over 50 years.  Germany, which wants to give lessons to everyone, which is the master of Europe, Germany has been hiding the misdeeds of German society for decades, and for me, those who hide the truth are complicit. The German state is complicit. It is time for Germany to admit its guilt in the face of the thousands of thalidomics struggling to see their rights recognised. This is finally being talked about in this House. But I and above all the National President of TAI ONLUS, Vincenzo Tomasso, who is in the gallery, Nadia and many other thalidomics who are following this debate in streaming want the truth.  We in Germany want a formal apology and we demand recognition of responsibilities with adequate compensation. Just hide the truth! We want justice: we also want justice for those mothers who felt guilty, unjustly, for taking that damn drug.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, this evening I want to place on record my ongoing support for the victims and survivors of the thalidomide tragedy, for whom the absence of truth, justice and compensation continues to overshadow their everyday lives. Over five decades on, the pain, suffering and trauma caused by the effect of this drug for pregnant women remains as salient as ever. Today we fight for those who live with the consequences. But we also think of those who were robbed of a chance to live full and free lives. Reports such as ‘Securing our Future’ in the UK evidenced the financial cost of living with thalidomide and, after much lobbying, our national government makes a contribution by a health grant in lieu of its role in this scandal. However, the United Kingdom was not the only guilty party. It is high time that the German Government took it upon itself to address its moral responsibilities to thalidomide survivors right across Europe: in Sweden, in the United Kingdom, in Spain and in Italy.  Let us get real: the estimated cost of between EUR 18 million and EUR 25 million is not a lot to one of Europe’s major powers, but it would mean everything to these survivors and their families. I trust that this debate will send a powerful message to the German Government that this issue and this brave band of individuals is not going away.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Thalidomide tragedy has affected several Member States and many of the victims are still awaiting compensation after half a century. The manufacturer of the drug, the German pharmaceutical company Grünenthal, only in 2012 resigned itself to apologizing to the thousands of people who were victims of the drug, but denied compensation. It is essential to take initiatives at European level to provide support and assistance to victims and their families, by providing for a framework protocol, in order to enable all European citizens who are victims of Thalidomide to receive adequate compensation regardless of the Member State of origin.  The Commission and the Council shall make every effort to urge the Member States and find a solution to ensure adequate compensation for these persons. The thalidomide victims and their families absolutely need practical economic aid.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, first of all, it is important that we are  having this debate, and I want to acknowledge – and I hope everyone will support me in this – Stuart Kenworthy, Phil Williams, Nick Dobrik and Craig Millward. I think we should say that, of all of the people who have lobbied me in this House, they did it with supreme effectiveness and with great dignity and they should not have had to do it. I think if nothing else we should acknowledge their work and their diligence and their incredible patience as victims to try and get their voices heard. I was hugely impressed with them.  I was watching television on Sunday night at home and a British drama called The Midwife is showing an episode set in that era with children being born with thalidomide  effects. It was actually very shocking because it was very real, and I know people who are living survivors with thalidomide.  We know that there are responsibilities on the German Government, the Irish Government – all governments where this occurred – to help, and I am not sure what tonight’s debate will achieve, except this: we have a sympathetic Commissioner, an engaged Parliament and we have a moral responsibility and duty not to let this rest. It is not a big amount of money, but the principle of looking after these victims is already established. For their dignity and their patience, let us not give up after this debate but keep going on this campaign.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the case of the thalidomide victims is a story that weighs like a boulder on the consciences of the protagonists in politics and institutions and, above all, on those responsible for moral compensation for these innocent victims: a few thousand, four hundred in my country alone, Italy, which has borne the social costs of highly disabling mutilation. , because they are strongly limiting the autonomy of people, to whom important fragments of life have been subtracted.  This is a matter that deserves attention and therefore arrives here in this Parliament, which always accepts applications for social justice. Parliament and the institutions are therefore called upon to take responsibility for a decision. Ask those who have been the protagonists of this tragic event to take concrete action.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: – First there was a tragedy, then there was an injustice. This is the result of moral duties. The dignity of the persons affected requires that we achieve a breakthrough that must lead to compensation for the persons affected, who will be given an adequate quality of life, regardless of which country they are from. Anyone affected by talidomide should receive similar compensation. I therefore expect the Commission, which speaks with sensitivity about this problem, to present measures at the appropriate level to provide effective support and assistance to victims of talidomide and their families, regardless of the Member State in which they live.  We have already learned a great deal from the tragedy, but I regret that all those affected have not yet come to satisfaction. I am particularly reminded of the urgency of being treated with caution and sensitive treatment, because I remember how it was once said in these matters. The thing came in the name of health, science, attention to man, and then we saw it in a different light.  Another asset may become questionable, which is considered scientifically sound, medicinal and modern today.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Europe, after more than 50 years, the dramatic consequences of the administration of Thalidomide-based medicines to pregnant women continue to be a problem for many people who, having survived, are in such a state of health, not least as a result of ageing, that they require specialist and ongoing care. The Commission is no doubt aware of recent studies, which represent an up-to-date picture in 21 countries of the specific needs for assistance, allowances and rights provided to some Thalidomide survivors.  While respecting the division of competences between the Union and the Member States, I believe that the Commission can and must act to demand with force and insistence that everyone be treated fairly, I repeat, of all thalidomides, overcoming the unjust disparities that still exist, not only between the Member States but within the Member States themselves, depending, for example, on the year of birth.  The Thalidomide scandal was the first European legislation on drug safety to prevent such tragedies from happening again. That is also why we must not leave these fellow citizens and their families alone.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Commissioner, thank you for your reply. I hope and believe that it is necessary to come to terms with the past and to ensure that mistakes do not happen again. It is necessary to compensate victims even if we do not return their health, but it is a debt for poor health care that the state should guarantee. Pharmaceuticals and their development, use and health care is exactly what cannot be left to the free market, because it is about human health and lives. From this point of view, I have a report from the Czech Ministry of Health that there are no known cases of thalidomide use in the Czech Republic that would lead to harm to health and subsequently to courts and disputes. This is probably also due to the fact that in the former Czechoslovakia Contergan containing thalidomide was not used, registered or traded. Therefore, these damages did not arise. But I also support all the more my colleagues from Spain, Britain, Germany, who have expressed themselves here in order to compensate these victims. Lessons must also be learned in the future within the European Union and great caution should be exercised in the development and marketing of new medicines. Health must be a priority, not a profit for pharmaceutical companies. I am convinced that the Czech Republic is an example of good practice in this, because we have good prevention and strict rules in the use of thalidomide and the marketing of new medicines.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Mr President, for the thalidomide survivors, like my constituent Lizzy – the important point she made to me was that as survivors age, their health problems and care needs become more complex. She wants to live independently, as long as possible, and make choices in her life, choices which the rest of us take for granted. These choices allowing you to live in your own home for as long as possible could be as simple as adapting a bathroom, or changing a kitchen.  What they are asking for is not huge but is something the German Government could practically help with as these 6 000 surviving victims age and enter a new period in their lives: a period where they should have a quality of life and live with dignity. Their asking tonight for the German Government to help those remaining survivors across the EU is important. I am pleased to see how this issue unifies us across Parliament and so it should. We will all continue to campaign on this subject and I am pleased that this is the start of this campaign being heard; not in the corridors and the offices but on the floor of this House where it belongs.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin, not with the data that has already been mentioned, nor in retracing this dramatic story with which we are all familiar, but with the words of the President of the Italian Thalidomidic Association, who recalls: 'It was thanks to the action of us victims – as you also mentioned, Commissioner – that pharmacovigilance was invented and rigorous tests were instituted on medicines before they were put on the market.  Last year we celebrated the fiftieth anniversary of the first European medicines law. Let us bear this in mind, because today we have been discussing an unresolved tragedy for more than 50 years, marked by silences, lies and omissions, which have weighed and continue to weigh dramatically on so many families and on the daily lives of thousands of victims. Well, after 50 years of silence, the time has come to act. The philosopher French Gilles Deleuze, wrote that we are not responsible for the victims but we are responsible to the victims and an apology is not enough in the face of these victims.  We have to repay the damage. It is impossible to repay this damage. However, we must give them compensation so that they can calmly face the costs of their physical condition which, as they age, will become even more burdensome. Here, let's tell the truth. They would have preferred a vote. Let us ensure that this debate does not just remain a debate, and I ask you, Commissioner, on behalf of all of them, to wear the role of mediator, in order to find a fair agreement between all the survivors, the German Government, the German company and all the governments involved, so that all these victims have justice and dignity.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Mr President, more than fifty years have passed since the tydomid Holocaust: fifty years of shame.  The drug was sold under the slogan "as harmless as a lump of sugar" and caused disabilities for thousands of babies. In Spain, Francoism hid it. Democracy didn't answer. The judges spoke of limitations, as if the human rights violation were understood as prescriptions. The laboratories – in this case, the German laboratory – trampled on them: they scopped the economic interest in human dignity, on health; and that responsibility, no doubt, has to be assumed by someone. And that is why we are asking for the Commission's help.  Of course, it is the responsibility of the pharmacist who invented, designed and marketed the product; responsibility of the German Government which also marketed it abroad and which allowed it to exit; responsibility of the Governments of the Member States which allowed their entry.  We are, in Spain, one of the countries where the victims have not yet collected any compensation.  Today, from the European Parliament, we can do a lot because we have the opportunity to stand up for equality for all and to say that we belong to a Europe that does not forget its innocents.  When a human being – and, in this case, many (and many who are no longer there) – is suffering an injustice, he is enduring suffering, one must take sides, because neutrality is the sharpening of injustice, and in no case helps the victims. And that is why I ask the Commission to take sides, not to stay in a debate and to give a solution to the victims.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I listened to the whole debate with great help. I really want to thank the authors for opening the topic of this dangerous drug here in plenary. There were terrible facts that there were still 900 victims not compensated. That some governments are turning their backs. The Commissioner here said what he had done, that he was acting on this matter, that he was meeting with the victims of this great tragedy. However, it also noted that the compensation scheme is not the responsibility of the European Union. This is right, of course, but we are a political body, representing all the citizens of the European Union who voted for us in free and secret elections, and we should therefore be able to put real pressure on national governments to deal with this problem, in addition to our powers. I therefore wanted to ask the Commissioner not only to end up dealing with victims, but also to put pressure on national governments and pharmaceutical companies, through the Commission, for 900 victims to be compensated and at least compensated for the future and to live a dignified life.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, I would like to join my voice with that of the colleagues who have defended these people who are victims of this great drama of tydomy, but, in particular, I would like to join my voice with the victims of tydommid in Spain, who suffer from double discrimination, because they have not received any compensation; especially the voice of these victims and their association, AVITE, which makes a permanent defense of their rights and works to keep this great drama from being forgotten. It is incredible to hear here, in this House, Mr González Pons and some other representative of the Government of the People's Party, who has helped nothing. Spain's socialist government did something—not enough, it's true—but the People's Party in government has done nothing. Nothing at all. More than fifty years later, there is great discrimination against tydomidomid victims in Europe and a European response is needed. If not, they suffer from double discrimination and that is absolutely unfair. Please intervene, Commissioner, sensitively to the drama of these victims, especially the Spanish victims, who, because they were born in Spain and were born sick – not because of them – must be doubly discriminated against.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the issue of talidomide has been of particular concern to us in the Committee on Petitions. That's where the victims came in and raised the issue. We have heard all the views and said that this issue must go ahead, and move on to the plenary of the European Parliament as we are doing now, because it is an issue that has been of particular concern to Spain over the years, where the Franco regime has literally hidden this issue. He gave no answer. The same applies to other victims in other regions, such as Belgium in Germany and other states.  The question is: What do we do? There should certainly be compensation for the victims. The compensation must be paid by the German pharmaceutical company as well as by the German State. He has enormous responsibilities for not checking this particular medicinal product, which has led to side effects. It is also the responsibility of the governments of certain States which have kept this issue in relation to the movement of the products of this medicine. The matter is therefore topical and we must, Commissioner, have an answer from the Commission as well, even though, as you say, there is no competence of the Commission in this matter.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, of course I fully agree with all the honourable Members of Parliament. But let us do all things together. I have been deeply involved in details. I debated these issues with governments, then I raised questions with the pharmaceutical industry, then I followed the situation which decisions were taken in such a long way. It is not true to say that nothing was done. No, no. Some things were done, but of course it is a minimum because today the survivors are getting older and older, they have new problems. We must see how to support these people today and for what we need a solution.  I would like to hear your ideas on how to solve these problems because we followed the situation, we analysed the legal situation and how to deal with the issue. It is not so easy. It is not about saying to the Commissioner, ‘Can you do it?’ I am ready to do my best today, tomorrow and the day after tomorrow and I would like to say it is really so difficult to see the situation. I am a medical doctor and for me I would like to ask you, maybe it is possible to continue and of course also to debate those issues with national governments for months again. Mairead McGuiness asked why the Council is not here. But you have influence, I ask you to put pressure on governments and to say that maybe it is possible to also move forward and raise these questions in the Council. I will do it, it is my obligation, but also I need possibilities to see a common action plan, how to move forward, how to be together. I discussed this with the pharma industry again two weeks ago, and I asked them if they were ready to understand, because it is a question of moral responsibility, of trust in the pharma industry. Of course I am ready to help people, I am ready, please send me your views. Some have mentioned a directive, I do not know about a directive. Of course we must see the possibility maybe to introduce new laws, but it needs real instruments today on the ground, and not only to send in statements. It is not enough about statements, we need results and of course I am ready, I am open to see and I will continue to follow the question and explore any possibility to facilitate a concrete solution that may help thalidomide survivors. Is that absolutely crystal clear? But as you mentioned, it is not only the German Government; the Spanish Government did not do enough from my point of view. But we need to debate together with Italy, Spain, UK, Sweden, Germany and of course industry and to see how to move forward with those issues. We need some practical solutions. I will do my best, but I also ask you to be very active, to speak with your national representatives, to raise these questions at national parliament level, to invite committees of national parliaments to do something together. It is not blaming and shaming, I am sorry, it is a very serious question.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. – Talidomide is the pharmacological active ingredient developed by the company Chemie Grünenthal, germany, in the 1950s, it was sold as tranquilizer and antinausea and mistakenly declared harmless for use in pregnancy. It is estimated that more than two million doses were distributed in 50 countries and under forty different trade names. It was withdrawn from the market only in 1961, when the devastating effects on fetuses became clear. Unfortunately, women treated with Talidomide gave birth to newborns with severe congenital changes in limb development, i.e. amelia or varying degrees of focomelia, it is estimated that these malformations affected at least 20,000 children. After more than fifty years, the survivors are still trying to find a solution that will enable them to cover the costs of their physical and medical condition, which has unfortunately worsened over the years. Nothing can erase what has happened, but I believe that providing effective support and assistance to the victims of The Talidomide and their families is the least that the European Union can do.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – The tydomid crisis determined the implementation of the European Pharmacovigilance System, which has just turned 50 years old. However, despite affecting many EU countries, this crisis did not bring with it eer the recognition of victims or support measures towards them at European level. The company reached an agreement with the German government in its day and indemnified the German victims but never recognized the Spanish victims. The Spanish Government approved in 2010 a decree establishing a scale and financial compensation to Spanish victims. The revision of the review is not discarded. However, the aftermath is so important and serious that the company's participation is essential to be able to compensate them. On 23 September 2015, the Supreme Court of Spain held that the nearly 500 Spanish survivors of tydomid are not entitled to compensation from the pharmaceutical company due to the limitation of the facts.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. – The tydomid crisis was so severe that it determined the implementation of the European Pharmacovigilance System, which has just turned 50 years old. However, despite affecting many EU countries, it never led to recognition of victims or measures towards victims at European level. The company reached an agreement with the German government in its day and indemnified the German victims but never recognized the Spanish victims. The Spanish Government approved in 2010 a decree establishing a scale and financial compensation to Spanish victims and not ruling out the revision of the same. However, the aftermath is so important and serious that the company's participation is essential to be able to compensate them. On 23 September 2015, the Supreme Court of Spain sentencing that the nearly 500 Spanish survivors of tydomid are not entitled to compensation by the pharmaceutical company due to the limitation of the facts.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. – The tragedy associated with the use of thalidomide by pregnant women has shown the importance of adopting European legislation on medicines and ensuring the safety of medicines. But the consequences of thalidomide left thousands of children in the 1950s and 1960s need to be confronted. It is completely unacceptable that the manufacturer of this substance only apologised to those who have to live with the disability caused by its product only in 2012. As victims get older, their health problems worsen and the need for adequate care increases. All those affected by thalidomide – no matter what country they live in – should receive compensation that would guarantee decent living conditions.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the international protection of whistleblowers (2016/2579(RSP)).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome this second opportunity to debate the international protection of whistle-blowers after the discussion Commissioner Jourová had with you ten months ago.  Blowing the whistle requires civil courage. It is about promotion of good governance and the fight against corruption. It is also about protecting privacy and preserving the freedom of expression and of information. As you know, and as was mentioned in the debate on the theme last April, there is no overarching harmonised system in place in the European Union for the protection of whistle-blowers. The Commission is well aware of Parliament’s strong calls for putting such a system in place. As you also know, in cases where no sectoral EU laws exist, it is up to the Member States to regulate this issue.  The Commission is closely following the evolving jurisprudence of the European Court of Human Rights on whistle-blowing, as well as the Council of Europe discussions on a possible framework convention on this issue. The Commission has taken good note of the Council of Europe’s 2014 recommendation on the protection of whistle-blowers, which calls on the Council of Europe member states to create a normative, judicial and institutional framework for the protection of whistle-blowers, and the Commission welcomes the fact that several Member States have already put such an institutional framework in place. European Union rules on whistle-blowing currently exist only in some specific areas regulated at EU level. In addition, let me recall that the anti-money laundering directive which was adopted in December 2014 contains provisions on the protection of those who report suspicious financial transactions. Also in December last year, the Commission adopted an implementing directive to the market abuse regulation. Member States have to establish effective mechanisms to protect whistle-blowers who would report infringement of the regulation.  You will also remember that last December you adopted a directive on the protection of trade secrets against unlawful acquisition, use or disclosure. This legislation considerably strengthens the rights of whistle-blowers. According to this directive, any claim on an alleged unlawful acquisition, use or disclosure of trade secrets should be dismissed when such conduct is carried out in the general public interest for the purpose of revealing misconduct, wrongdoing or illegal activity.  Let me also refer to the 2014 European Union anti-corruption report, which covers whistle-blowing for all our Member States. This is an important topic in our bilateral discussions with the Member States in the follow-up to the report.  Finally, the Commission wants to ensure that whistle-blowers who would report European Union fraud and corruption cases to the future European Public Prosecutor’s Office receive the necessary protection in accordance with national law. As you know, the negotiations on the European Public Prosecutor’s Office are ongoing and Parliament’s support in this respect would be most helpful and welcome. To sum up, a lot has already been done at EU level in a field where the European Union has competence. The Commission is monitoring the developments with a view to assessing the possible need for further action at European Union level. I shall now be glad to listen to your views on how such action could improve the protection of whistle-blowers.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the I would also like to thank the Commissioner for making a statement on whistleblowers here. In principle, it is good that we should look at the question of how to deal with this issue in a sensible way, and in particular the question: what are the limits of possibilities? After all, whistleblowers are often judged as a general remedy.  I would also like to make it clear at this point that the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats would be very critical of the inclusion of comprehensive whistleblower protection, which is above criminal law. But in a reasonable procedure, we are not fundamentally opposed to protecting whistleblowers.  That is why it is important to talk about these structures – structures in companies, associations and authorities, where structures must be established so that appropriate protection can also apply in the event of alleged violations of the law. The debate about whistleblowers is complex and difficult to handle because it covers various areas: freedom of expression, privacy protection, data protection, ethical issues, national security, corporate secrets, tax issues, fraud, etc. Then you have to focus directly on the individual cases. You can't lump everything together and then just say: we're protecting in general now. You have to look very carefully at the areas involved.  We are already convinced that this protection of whistleblowers is actually a national task and competence and that we can therefore confine ourselves here to the exchange of guidelines and principles. In any case, however, the rule of law should be maintained and respected, including in this case.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner, what are we talking about here at this session of the European Parliament? We are talking about a matter of the greatest topicality and of the greatest seriousness, because it raises great concern: the protection of Fundamental European rights and the privacy of Europeans.  But it is also necessary to contemplate the protection of what is known internationally with this English locution of the 'whistleblower' which, translated into Spanish, would be the delator, the complainant of a situation affecting cases of corruption, attacks on national security, environmental crimes, fraud, economic crimes that therefore require active cooperation with law enforcement agencies : law enforcement agencies. And that's what we're talking about.  Why did you get so topical? Evidently in the wake of the so-called 'Snowden case' which reveals an invasive and massive practice against fundamental rights, not longer europeans, but citizens around the world, potentially by the US National Security Agency.  And it therefore tells us of the need to protect these whistleblowers, who can bring tax fraud, concealment in tax havens, environmental crimes, crimes with an impact on health, abuses that undermine the full enjoyment of fundamental rights, which European law is obliged to guarantee, to be known to justice or law ensuring.  The European Parliament has taken care of this. In 2013, I chaired a commission on mass surveillance on the fundamental rights of Europeans in the Committee on Freedoms, Justice and Home Affairs, the conclusions of which were adopted in October 2013.  And, in 2015, we held a hearing at the LIBE Commission – the Committee on Freedoms, Justice and Home Affairs – to conclude that a framework of protection is needed to develop the rights referred to in Articles 11, 30 and 41 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, which is consistent with the Council of Europe and the OECD , but above all, give rules and safe channels to ensure the confidences of these crime delators that matter to us and we want to pursue.  This is what we have to do in the European Parliament: how to improve the protection of confidants with uniform status throughout European law, with European legislation fulfilling the mandate of the conclusions of the committee of inquiry which I chaired as chairman of the Committee on Freedoms, Justice and Home Affairs.  This is the task ahead of us and we must undertake it. We have to complete it and we have to do it.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. – Mr. Chairman, the role of whistleblowers is of immense importance to every society. These are the most responsible and courageous individuals who warn about the problem before it becomes unsolvable. Unfortunately, they rarely get the recognition they deserve, and much more often at risk of health and disillusioned with the system leave their workplace within a year or two.  In countries shaken by the rule of law, whistleblowers face almost never real complacency due to systemic shortcomings and corruption. While in many developed countries it is very difficult to hire the best lawyers because they prefer to have wealthy corporations for their clients who do not want to work with those who represent whistleblowers. We also often witness politics flirting with whistleblowers because they have great moral credibility in the public eye, so they bring easy political points.  I believe that the policy towards whistleblowers should be treated much more constructively and responsibly because they show what needs to be fixed, and because of their experience and knowledge of the internal situation, they often offer concrete quality solutions. Because of all this, we need to strongly promote the positive role of whistleblowers in society, and our states need to do everything they can to make the best legal aid available to them at all times. We must also be prepared to offer asylum to whistleblowers from third countries in order to protect them and their families from revanchism and possible danger.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to agree with Mr López Aguilar that a framework of protection is needed. We are talking about white-gloved criminals, who can hide crimes; in fact, because of their sophistication and technical and intellectual training, it is very, very difficult to discover, and much more difficult to prove the crimes. When crimes are committed by large corporations, which carry them out, because they are carrying out illegal espionage work, or by some politicians within their parties or in local, regional, national or European power, it is extremely difficult to punish them. Internal informants are therefore the key to impunity. At the United Nations Convention against Corruption, which entered into force in 2005, the 167 countries that have ratified it recognize the importance of the issue. However, many of them still do not provide whistleblowers with adequate legal protection. Most countries do not go from general declarations of principle, because it is very uncomfortable, very difficult, very sensitive, and only four Member States have extensive legislation on whistleblower protection. Creating a healthy culture of transparency is just as important as designing specific whistleblower protection legislation. My own country, Spain, is in line, with many other countries, in this area. And I can assure you that we could have gotten rid of much of the corruption if we had good whistleblower protection legislation. Protection surely goes through the establishment of a legal statute. Undoubtedly, when someone makes the decision to dare to report a felony within a large corporation, state or political party, if their anonymity is not protected, they will suffer a situation of isolation and harassment, with potential risks to their professional career and their personal tranquility, as we have said. They need the protection of their physical integrity and need secure reporting protocols, which ensure the confidentiality of the information received. They require legal assistance, free of charge, as well as being guaranteed access to psychological care, if necessary. Because we are talking about the search for the annulment of the people who make these kinds of complaints. We cannot forget that, in some cases, whistleblowers of serious illegalities have been persecuted even internationally. Julian Assange's case we all know him. The Working Group on Arbitrary Detention of the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights has concluded that it is subject to deprivation continues its freedom. Commissioner, we need you to develop everything you can carry out. We need a framework of protection. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Diane JAMES
text: blue-card question. – I found your speech very interesting, and you referred to companies. Can I just ask and double check with you: are you assuming that only companies will be subject to any legislation, directive or regulation that the EU dreams up? What do you feel in terms of political organisations, governments, state bodies, local authorities – in fact any organisation where a whistle-blower exposes some wrongdoing? I do find it difficult to see how the EU would be able to influence that, but I would welcome your comments.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs James, these are specific offences, which we would describe as a 'white glove', which relate to fraud, corruption... a series of absolutely sophisticated crimes and generated in environments that are also intellectually very, very prepared. There is a part of the legislation that has to be national, but there may be a part of the legislation that may be at European level, and we can explore this possibility. It's not an easy subject, because it hasn't been worked hard enough. Beyond the conventions, beyond those of the issues that have taken place in Parliament and which Mr López Aguilar has spoken about, it is not fully developed. Most countries have not done so yet.
