However, we must do so, because a significant part of the crimes that go unpunished and which are more serious are within this framework; these are crimes that some multinationals may commit or that may be committed by states or political parties. We know. Of course, in our country, we know that very well. We have to work on it and, of course, I'm willing to talk to you about everything that's necessary for it.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Wikileaks, Falciani List, Luxleaks, Snowden, Chelsea Manning..... Thanks to the action of whistleblowers or advocates of the right to information, international public opinion has known, among thousands of other cases, that the US authorities pressured justice and the Spanish government to prevent investigations into allegations of torture at Guantanamo. The secret flights of the CIA, the murder of spanish journalist José Couso by American troops in Iraq... Whistleblowers play an essential role in identifying various crimes, from tax fraud to large-scale espionage. They've done it taking very high risks. They are therefore human rights defenders, and must be recognized as such and, as a particularly vulnerable group, subject to special protection. I welcome the fact that here in the House those who are speaking are rightly in this regard, but so far the European Union has done more little to preserve the security of key informants who point to cases of internal corruption, within the institutions themselves and nothing has been done with regard to the protection of whistleblowers outside the institutions of the European Union itself. That's why I'm asking you two very specific questions. What will be the legislative and programme efforts made by the Commission in the coming months in this area? But we would also like to know the Commission's position on the opinion of the United Nations Working Group on Arbitrary Detention, in the case of information rights defender Julian Assange, unjustly held for years at the Embassy of Ecuador in London. What are you going to do to get Julian Assange to solve your case? It's a very specific question.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your support. Antoine Deltour, Keith Harrison, Guido Strack, András Horváth, and there's a long way to go before names can be listed. These are not only names from different Member States, but also fates linked by the fact that they have been reported to the public on matters which are in the public interest and are in the public interest. And yet, instead of taking effective action in these cases, the authorities took action against them, and the companies took action against them. It is unacceptable that there is no comprehensive protection in Europe to ensure that whistleblowers, brave people fighting corruption, are given the protection they deserve.  We need a single European directive, which also provides for minimum rules for Member States on the minimum level of protection that we need to ensure for whistleblowers in all Member States, and the same level of protection must be ensured within the institutions of the European Union, as we have seen in many cases that the Union itself does not go ahead in protecting whistleblowers in the public interest. We must make it clear that those who risk everything in the public interest must feel that the public is on their side, that we are on their side in the European institutions. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I have a specific question for you. In fact, you have criticised, in a way, the way whistleblowers are being approached in the European Union. What do you think of the introductory presentation, do you think that the current Commission's approach is trying to change its attitude towards whistle-blowers, or is the current Commission leaving the people you have appointed here at the mercy of being ostracised?

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: "blue card question". Thank you very much for your question. The Commission should first and foremost comment on the current Commission's position. What we have known so far, in recent times, suggests that, at the moment, there is no political decision in the Commission to legislate at European level in order to protect whistleblowers in the public interest. In my opinion, this is unacceptable. The European institutions and the European Commission should lead by example with their own rules and the internal rules of the European institutions, and should initiate the creation of a new directive that provides adequate protection and minimum protection for whistleblowers in all Member States.

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, there is no more difficult subject than whistle-blowing, given its interpretations. The options are: is it revelation or is it revenge?  The more secretive or controlling and authoritarian a state is, the more contentious and confrontational whistle-blowing becomes. Now, it is difficult enough in the United Kingdom where we have a cultural attitude and a legal structure to facilitate genuine whistle-blowing; but for many other countries and Member States, whistle-blowing is just too confrontational to the state mechanisms.  I do not believe that the Commission has any role in this remit, and I have heard this evening comments about installing minimum standards. Well there is absolutely no guarantee that those minimum standards would be adopted. We have got proof of that in other areas.  I would remind people in the Chamber this evening – the few that there might be – that citizens of former Communist countries still remember that night-time knock on the door, and that was the result of whistle-blowing. So this is a subject where platitudinous generalisations and approaches are an insult to individuals demonstrating great personal courage and risk in the face of real issues. I do not think the EU has a role in this area.

name: Michał BONI
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, those who warn us of possible danger have always been important to society. Their role is important, especially nowadays when we have a lot of information sources and many communication channels. If the whistle-blowers warn us about wrongdoings, corruption, illegal actions and the breaking of the law, they have a similar function to journalists warning us via the media. In this sense, their role for a democratic society is positive. As stated in the EU anti-corruption report, whistle-blowing faces a difficulty as there is a reluctance to act against one’s own organisation due to the fear of retaliation. Whistle-blowers are often acting according to their conscience, but outside or against a legal framework. They are forced to break the law to act according to their moral compass. In this role, they are contributing to the democracy mechanisms and helping to reveal criminal activities, for instance corruption, but it should not lead to the destruction of the state and in functions. In democratic societies, for instance, investigative journalists have rights and are protected. That is why I believe we need to develop our discussion on whistle-blowers. We need to raise awareness of the problem, continue efforts on finding and implementing a better framework for protecting their rights as persons, as professionals. Some countries in Europe have done so in an advanced way, so this is a duty for all Member States.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, whistle-blowers play a key role in the fight against corruption, evasion and organised crime, phenomena that are now moving very casually across national borders. These are European phenomena, and that is why we need solutions that are European. We need a European directive setting minimum standards for the protection of whistle-blowers and detecting safe channels for revealing information. We cannot be credible in the fight against these phenomena unless we protect the speaker. Unfortunately, however, at European level, only eight Member States have completed legislation in this area. As long ago as 2013, as part of the REPORT of the CRIM Committee, this Parliament called, by a very large majority, for the European Commission, by 2013, to prepare a legislative proposal that would go in the direction of an effective and comprehensive European programme for the protection of whistle-blowers. Three years have passed and we have not yet seen any trace of this proposal. I would therefore like to ask the Commission why this delay and this resistance have been delayed.  Finally, I would like to point out that since January 2014 the European institutions have made it compulsory to introduce internal rules on complaints of irregularities, including the protection of whistleblowers. Well, an inquiry carried out by the European Ombudsman has shown that, with the exception of the Commission and the Court of Auditors, the other institutions, including, alas, this Parliament, have done very little in the area of whistle-blower protection. This misses an important opportunity to demonstrate to the public that the European institutions are for transparency and to encourage and protect whistleblowers.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, the European Union must ensure the effective protection of the people who help with their information to uncover corruption scandals. According to a 2013 survey by Transparency International, most Eu countries fail to offer adequate legal protection against workplace retaliation, while concern about criminal prosecutions is another suspensive factor for whistleblowers. As the President of the Commission, Mr President-in- Juncker, in September 2015 before the European Parliament, we must adopt a common European policy on this issue.  Let us all reflect on the scale of the Luxleaks scandal or the Volkswagen scandal and realise how much it would help if there was harmonised legislation so that whistleblowers are not afraid to denounce what they know. Corruption moves in the dark. Only if we incentivise citizens to come out and denounce it will we be able to combat it effectively.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Commissioner, we in the European People's Party believe that the European Union is founded on values such as transparency, integrity and the protection of human rights.  The European Union has a duty to ensure the protection of fundamental rights and freedoms for all those who choose to step down and to draw attention to violations of these values. Whistle-blowers are one of the elements of the control mechanisms, which ensures that power is not centred in the wrong hands and is not misused for the wrong purposes.  We must ensure that these controls have sufficient protection in our legal environment, and this also applies to Mr Assange. Despite my personal reservations about Mr Assange's person, we cannot ignore his legacy, which is of great importance to us in understanding the complexity of international affairs.  Many people are very interested in sweeping some things under the rug, and it is no wonder that people like Julian Assange are simply uncomfortable. However, we must bear in mind that inconvenient whistle-blowers can very easily fall victim to fabricated accusations and persecution, which we, members of the European Parliament and the representatives of the European Union, are supposed to prevent. That is why I am in the process of saying that the imprisonment of Julian Assange should be ended. And he should be granted international legal protection. If, as the European Union, we do not provide adequate protection for Assange and other whistleblowers, we will send the wrong signal to all those who intend to expose any crimes.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, like so much else that passes through this House, this is us blathering on in righteous tones about an issue while, at the same time, the reality of what is actually happening on the same issue is the total opposite.  Over eight years ago, Jonathan Sugarman resigned from the plum job of Risk Manager that he then held with UniCredit Bank Ireland. In his own words: ‘I did that in order not to incriminate myself.’ Jonathan’s job entailed checking and signing off on the liquidity of the bank at the end of each day’s trading. What he says he found, day after day, was that the bank was short of that figure, not just by a few percentage points but by up to 40 times the accepted margin. As per the law, he told the bank and told the regulator.  The bank told him to shut up. The regulator ignored him. The Central Bank, when it eventually got around to an investigation of sorts, told him they could guarantee neither his anonymity nor his immunity. Things are so bad he was not even called to give evidence at the recent banking inquiry.  We can talk all we want in here, but I await the day we actually do something about it, when it is those who have had the whistle blown on them who have something to fear, rather than those who blow that whistle.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I consider the whistleblower debate to be one of the key anti-corruption measures. If we look at the opinion polls in the individual countries of the European Union, then the citizens of the European Union see corruption as one of the key issues that is burning them very much. It is a little surprising that most countries in the European Union do not have a complete adjustment to the subject of whistle-blowers, only some states have this matter in the area of labour law. I personally believe that it would therefore be worth considering, Commissioner, if you were to consider a more general arrangement setting a minimum European standard for the status of a whistle-blower. You have mentioned here specific examples of directives where the subject of the whistle-blower is, in principle, only marginally constructed. However, I believe that the general regulation would be worth considering if it is in minimal form, for example, if the person concerned reports a crime, not just an ethical offence, just as we have legislation today that regulates so-called anti-discrimination laws. This has also been acquired by the European Union. Five years ago, I was responsible for legislation in the Czech Government and I prepared this law. But there was no political will to pass such a law. To this day, the Czech Republic does not have whistleblower protection. This is the example of why I think that coming up with such an idea from a European level, from Brussels, makes sense and it can help those who are not afraid to report crime.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, those few who dare to report illegalities do not receive adequate legal protection in the European Union. All this is despite the fact that the complaints have shown their usefulness, since the various banking scandals, volkswagen scandals, money laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance are on the agenda. The LuxLeaks scandal, the Borgens and Lagarde lists, which have not yet been fully exploited by the competent authorities, especially in Greece, have shown that individuals as well as multinationals systematically avoid and avoid tax. The introduction of the protection of whistle-blowers is therefore bound to highlight other cases of infringement of the tax and legislation of the Member States of the European Union in general. It is therefore in the interests of European citizens to strengthen the institutional framework for the protection of these people. We must not forget, Mr President, the recent prosecutions of journalists in Luxembourg which revealed the LuxLeaks scandal.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it was very interesting to listen to the debates. I would like to thank you warmly for today’s very interesting discussions, especially for me. Be assured that I will inform my colleague, Commissioner Jourová, who is in charge of this file, on the content of today’s debate.  Let me stress once again the following. We all agree that we should protect whistle-blowers. The question is how? In other words, what is best and what is realistic. It is a very complex question and, of course, we are speaking about human rights and the possibility of a framework covering all the European Union. To conclude, Commissioner Jourová asked me to convey the following message to you: she looks forward to continuing and deepening these discussions with you. Once again, thank you very much for a very interesting debate.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed.
